entries.entry:
I The dot which we place over the small or lower case i dates only from the 14th century. The sounds of I and J were originally represented by the same character, and even after the introduction of the form J into English dictionaries, words containing these letters were, till a comparatively recent time, classed together. ī. I, the ninth letter of the English alphabet, takes its form from the Phœnician, through the Latin and the Greek. The Phœnician letter was probably of Egyptian origin. Its original value was nearly the same as that of the Italian I, or long e as in mete. Etymologically I is most closely related to e y j g; as in dint, dent, beverage, L. bibere; E. kin, AS. cynn; E. thin, AS. þynne; E. dominion, donjon, dungeon. In English I has two principal vowel sounds: the long sound, as in pīne īce; and the short sound, as in pĭn. It has also three other sounds: (a) That of e in term, as in thirst. (b) That of e in metein words of foreign origin), as in machine pique regime. (c) That of consonant yin many words in which it precedes another vowel), as in bunion million filial Christian, etc. It enters into several digraphs, as in fail field seize feign. friend; and with o often forms a proper diphtong, as in oil join coin.Guide to Pronunciation Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 98-106.
In our old authors, I was often used for ayor aye), yes, which is pronounced nearly like it.
As a numeral, I stands for 1, II for 2, etc.

Chemistry applied to, or used in, medicine; -- used especially with reference to the doctrines in the school of physicians in Flanders, in the 17th century, who held that health depends upon the proper chemical relations of the fluids of the body, and who endeavored to explain the conditions of health or disease by chemical principles.

entries.entry: I"bex ☞ The Alpine ibex (Capra ibex) is the best known. The Spanish, or Pyrenean, ibex (Capra Hispanica) has smoother and more spreading horns. ī"bĕks n.; pl. E. Ibexes ī"bĕks*ĕz, L. Ibices īb"ĭ*sēz. L., a kind of goat, the chamois Zoöl One of several species of wild goats having very large, recurved horns, transversely ridged in front; -- called also steinbok.

entry.ety: L

entry.note: ☞ The sacred ibis of the ancient Egyptians (Ibis Æthiopica) has the head and neck black, without feathers. The plumage of the body and wings is white, except the tertiaries, which are lengthened and form a dark purple plume. In ancient times this bird was extensively domesticated in Egypt, but it is now seldom seen so far north. The glossy ibis (Plegadis autumnalis), which is widely distributed both in the Old World and the New, has the head and neck feathered, except between the eyes and bill; the scarlet ibis (Guara rubra) and the white ibis (Guara alba) inhabit the West Indies and South America, and are rarely found in the United States. The wood ibis (Tantalus loculator) of America belongs to the Stork family (Ciconidæ). See Wood ibis.
entry.ety: L. ibis, Gr. �; of Egyptian origin
entry.def: Any bird of the genus Ibis and several allied genera, of the family Ibidæ, inhabiting both the Old World and the New. Numerous species are known. They are large, wading birds, having a long, curved beak, and feed largely on reptiles.

-ic. L. -icus, Gr. �: cf. F. -ique

Chem A suffix, denoting that the element indicated enters into certain compounds with its highest valence, or with a valence relatively higher than in compounds where the name of the element ends in -ous; as, ferric, sulphuric . It is also used in the general sense of pertaining to; as, hydric, sodic, calcic .

entry.ety: acronym intercontinental ballistic missile
entry.def: An intercontinental ballistic missile, a long-range ballistic missile that is capable of traveling from one continent to another. Contrasted with IRBM.

entry.note: ☞ Water freezes at 32° F. or 0° Cent., and ice melts at the same temperature. Ice owes its cooling properties to the large amount of heat required to melt it.
entry.cs:
Anchor ice ice which sometimes forms about stones and other objects at the bottom of running or other water, and is thus attached or anchored to the ground. Bay ice ice formed in bays, fiords, etc., often in extensive fields which drift out to sea. Ground ice anchor ice. Ice age Geol the glacial epoch or period. See under Glacial. Ice anchor Naut a grapnel for mooring a vessel to a field of ice. Kane. Ice blink Dan. iisblink
a streak of whiteness of the horizon, caused by the reflection of light from ice not yet in sight. Ice boat. A boat fitted with skates or runners, and propelled on ice by sails; an ice yacht. A strong steamboat for breaking a channel through ice.
Ice boxorIce chest
a box for holding ice; a box in which things are kept cool by means of ice; a refrigerator. Ice brook a brook or stream as cold as ice. Poetic Shak. Ice cream for iced cream
cream, milk, or custard, sweetened, flavored, and frozen. Ice field an extensive sheet of ice.
Ice float Ice floe
a sheet of floating ice similar to an ice field, but smaller. Ice foot shore ice in Arctic regions; an ice belt. Kane. Ice house a close-covered pit or building for storing ice. Ice machine Physics a machine for making ice artificially, as by the production of a low temperature through the sudden expansion of a gas or vapor, or the rapid evaporation of a volatile liquid. Ice master. See Ice pilotbelow). Ice pack an irregular mass of broken and drifting ice. Ice paper a transparent film of gelatin for copying or reproducing; papier glacé. Ice petrel Zoöl a shearwater (Puffinus gelidus) of the Antarctic seas, abundant among floating ice. Ice pick a sharp instrument for breaking ice into small pieces. Ice pilot a pilot who has charge of a vessel where the course is obstructed by ice, as in polar seas; -- called also ice master. Ice pitcher a pitcher adapted for ice water. Ice plow a large tool for grooving and cutting ice.
Ice sludge bay ice broken small by the wind or waves; sludge. Ice spar Min a variety of feldspar, the crystals of which are very clear like ice; rhyacolite. Ice tongs large iron nippers for handling ice. Ice water. Water cooled by ice. Water formed by the melting of ice. Ice yacht. See Ice boatabove). To break the ice. See under Break. Water ice a confection consisting of water sweetened, flavored (usually with a fruit syrup), and frozen.
entry.ety: OE. is iis, AS. īs; aksin to D. ijs, G. eis, OHG. īs, Icel. īss, Sw. is, Dan. iis, and perh. to E. iron

sn.def: Water or other fluid frozen or reduced to the solid state by cold; frozen water. It is a white or transparent colorless substance, crystalline, brittle, and viscoidal. Its specific gravity (0.92, that of water at 4° C. being 1.0) being less than that of water, ice floats.
Concreted sugar.
Water, cream, custard, etc., sweetened, flavored, and artificially frozen.
Any substance having the appearance of ice; as, camphor ice .

To chill or cool, as with ice; to freeze.

entry.note: ☞ Icebergs are large detached portions of glaciers, which in cold regions often project into the sea.

entry.def: A large mass of ice, generally floating in the ocean.

sn.def: A ship with a reinforced bow to break up ice and keep channels open for navigation; an icebreaker.

entry.def: Totally surrounded with ice, so as to be incapable of advancing; as, an icebound vessel; also, surrounded by or fringed with ice so as to hinder easy access; as, an icebound coast.

sn.syn: iceboat.

sn.def: A remark or action intended to relieve tension or reduce formality when initiating conversation or beginning a speech; it is often a humorous or light remark.
Composed of ice.
Loaded with ice.

having flow restricted by ice; -- of rivers or conduits; as, ice-clogged rivers.
as cold as ice; extremely cold.
entry.syn: arctic, freezing, frigid, gelid, glacial, icy, polar.

entry.def: free of ice and open to travel; -- of water routes; as, an ice-free channel in the river.

entry.cs: Iced cream. Same as Ice cream, under Ice.

sn.def: Covered with ice.
Chilled with ice; as, iced water; iced tea; iced coffee; -- of beverages.
Covered with something resembling ice, as sugar icing; frosted; as, iced cake.

entry.def: A frozen waterfall, or mass of ice resembling a frozen waterfall.
a building used for storing ice, especially one built partly below ground and insulated so as to preserve ice obtained during the winter from frozen lakes or rivers.
A native, or one of the Scandinavian people, of Iceland.
Of or pertaining to Iceland; relating to, or resembling, the Icelanders.
The language of the Icelanders. It is one of the Scandinavian group, and is more nearly allied to the Old Norse than any other language now spoken.

entries.entry: Ice"land moss`. Bot A kind of lichen (Cetraria Icelandica) found from the Arctic regions to the North Temperate zone. It furnishes a nutritious jelly and other forms of food, and is used in pulmonary complaints as a demulcent.
Ice"land spar`. Min A transparent variety of calcite, the best of which is obtained in Iceland. It is used for the prisms of the polariscope, because of its strong double refraction. Cf. Calcite.

Ice"man n.; pl.Icemen.
A man who is skilled in traveling upon ice, as among glaciers.
One who deals in ice; one who retails or delivers ice.

Ice" plant`. Bot A plant (Mesembryanthemum crystallinum), sprinkled with pellucid, watery vesicles, which glisten like ice. It is native along the Mediterranean, in the Canaries, and in South Africa. Its juice is said to be demulcent and diuretic; its ashes are used in Spain in making glass.

entry.def: The crash or concussion attending the breaking up of masses of ice, -- often due to contraction from extreme cold.
A shoe with a metal runner (called a blade) attached to permit the wearer to glide on ice.
One who skates on ice wearing an ice skate; esp. an athlete who performs athletic or artistic movements on a sheet of ice, wearing ice skates; a speed skater or a figure skater.

entry.note: ☞ In the Southern dialect of Early English this is the regular form. Cf. Ik.
entry.def: I.

entry.note: ☞ The female deposits her eggs upon, or in, the bodies of other insects, such as caterpillars, plant lice, etc. The larva lives upon the internal tissues of the insect in which it is parasitic, and finally kills it. Hence, many of the species are beneficial to agriculture by destroying noxious insects.
entry.cs: Ichneumon fly. See Ichneumon, 2.
entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �, lit., the tracker; so called because it hunts out the eggs of the crocodile, fr. � to track or hunt after, fr. 'i`chnos track, footstep

sn.def: Any carnivorous mammal of the genus Herpestes, and family Viverridæ. Numerous species are found in Asia and Africa. The Egyptian species (Herpestes ichneumon), which ranges to Spain and Palestine, is noted for destroying the eggs and young of the crocodile as well as various snakes and lizards, and hence was considered sacred by the ancient Egyptians. The common species of India (Herpestes griseus), known as the mongoose, has similar habits and is often domesticated. It is noted for killing the cobra.
Any hymenopterous insect of the family Ichneumonidæ, of which several thousand species are known, belonging to numerous genera.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the Ichneumonidæ, or ichneumon flies.

entries.entry: ‖Ich`thy*o*sau"rus n.; pl.Ichthyosauri #. NL., fr. Gr. 'ichqy`s -y`os, a fish + say^ros a lizard Paleon An extinct genus of marine reptiles; -- so named from their short, biconcave vertebræ, resembling those of fishes. Several species, varying in length from ten to thirty feet, are known from the Liassic, Oölitic, and Cretaceous formations.

entry.note: In a graphical user interface, pointing to and clicking on an icon may cause any of several types of actions, such as opening a file or executing a program, depending on how the icon properties are defined.
entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. e'ikw`n

sn.def: An image or representation; a portrait or pretended portrait.
sn.q: Netherlands whose names and icons are published.

sn.def: A sacred picture representing the Virgin Mary, Christ, a saint, or a martyr, and having the same function as an image of such a person in the Latin Church. The term is used especially for a highly stylized and conventionalized representation of a holy person, rich in symbolism and used in devotional services in many of the eastern Orthodox churches, especially the Greek and Russian Orthodox Churches.
a symbol, especially a symbol whose form suggests its meaning or the object it represents.
a graphical symbol for a data object whose form suggests the nature or function of the object; especially, such a symbol as viewed on the computer screen.
any object of uncritical devotion.
sn.q: The former congresswoman and Vice-Presidential candidate Geraldine Ferraro is still an icon to many party members.

sn.def: an outstanding example of something which has come to represent the class of things to which it belongs; a paragon; used of persons as well as objects.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or consisting of, images, pictures, or representations of any kind.

cs.cd: the study of the representations in art of the Deity, the persons of the Trinity, angels, saints, virtues, vices, etc.

entry.ety: Gr. � a sketch or description; e'ikw`n an image + � of describe: cf. F. iconographie

sn.def: The art or representation by pictures or images; the description or study of portraiture or representation, as of persons; as, the iconography of the ancients.
The study of representative art in general.

entry.ety: Gr. e'ikw`n an image + � to worship: cf. F. iconolâtre
entry.def: One who worships images.

entry.ety: See Iconolater
entry.def: The worship of images as symbols; -- distinguished from idolatry, the worship of images themselves.

entry.ety: Gr. �; e'ikw`n an image + � discourse: cf. F. iconologie
entry.def: The discussion or description of portraiture or of representative images. Cf. Iconography.

entry.ety: Gr. � a war against images; e'ikw`n an image + � fight
entry.def: Hostility to images as objects of worship.

entry.ety: NL. See Icon, and Mania
entry.def: A mania or infatuation for icons, whether as objects of devotion, bric-a-brac, or curios.

entry.ety: Gr. �; e'ikw`n image + � fight
entry.def: Opposed to pictures or images as objects of worship.

entry.ety: Gr. e'ikw`n an image + � to love
entry.def: A student, or lover of the study, of iconography.

entry.ety: See Icosahedron
entry.def: Having twenty equal sides or faces.

cs.cd: one of the five regular polyhedrons, bounded by twenty equilateral triangules. Five triangles meet to form each solid angle of the polyhedron.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � twenty + � seat, base, fr. � to sit
entry.def: A solid bounded by twenty sides or faces.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � twenty +�, �, man, male: cf. F. icosandrie
entry.def: A Linnæan class of plants, having twenty or more stamens inserted in the calyx.
Pertaining to the class Icosandria; having twenty or more stamens inserted in the calyx.

entry.ety: Gr. � twenty + �, combining form of � four + � seat, base
entry.def: A twenty-four-sided solid; a tetragonal trisoctahedron or trapezohedron.

entries.entry:
-ics ☞ The names sciences ending in ics, as mathematics mechanics metaphysics optics, etc., are, with respect to their form, nouns in the plural number. The plural form was probably introduced to mark the complex nature of such sciences; and it may have been in imitation of the use of the Greek plurals �, �, �, �, etc., to designate parts of Aristotle's writings. Previously to the present century, nouns ending in ics were construed with a verb or a pronoun in the plural; but it is now generally considered preferable to treat them as singular. In Greman we have die Mathematik die Mechanik, etc., and in French la metaphysique la optique, etc., corresponding to our mathematics mechanics metaphysics optics, etc. Mathematics have for their object the consideration of whatever is capable of being numbered or measured. John Davidson. The citations subjoined will serve as examples of the best present usage.Ethics is the sciences of the laws which govern our actions as moral agents. Sir W. Hamilton. All parts of knowledge have their origin in metaphysics, and finally, perhaps, revolve into it. De Quincey.
Mechanics, like pure mathematics, may be geometrical, or may be analytical; that is, it may treat space either by a direct consideration of its properties, or by a symbolical representation. Whewell. . A suffix used in forming the names of certain sciences, systems, etc., as acoustics, mathematics, dynamics, statistics, politics, athletics.

entry.def: A remedy for the jaundice.

entry.ety: L. ictericus, Gr. 'ikteriko`s, fr. 'i`kteros jaundice: cf. F. ictérique

sn.def: Pertaining to, or affected with, jaundice.
Good against the jaundice.

entry.def: Yellow; of the color of the skin when it is affected by the jaundice.

entry.ety: Gr. � jaundice + -oid
entry.def: Of a tint resembling that produced by jaundice; yellow; as, an icteroid tint or complexion.

entry.ety: NL. See Icteric a.
entry.def: The jaundice.

entry.ety: L. ictus blow
entry.def: Pertaining to, or caused by, a blow; sudden; abrupt.
A genus of fishes comprising the buffalofishes.
An extinct reptile intermediate in form between the therapsids and most primitive true mammals.
An order of extinct reptiles of the Upper Triassic.

entry.ety: L., fr. icere ictum, to strike

sn.def: The stress of voice laid upon accented syllable of a word. Cf. Arsis.
A stroke or blow, as in a sunstroke, the sting of an insect, pulsation of an artery, etc.

entry.ety: AS. īsig. See Ice

sn.def: Pertaining to, resembling, or abounding in, ice; cold; frosty.
sn.q: Icychains.
Icyregion.
Icyseas.

sn.def: Characterized by coldness, as of manner, influence, etc.; chilling; frigid; cold.
sn.q: Icy was the deportment with which Philip received these demonstrations of affection.

entry.def: Spangled with ice.
entry.q: Mounting up in icy-pearled car.

entry.ety: shortened form of identification
entry.def: any document testifying to teh identity of the bearer, especially a card or badge.

entries.entry: I'd. A contraction from I would or I had; as, I'd go if I could.

entry.def: A small fresh-water cyprinoid fish (Leuciscus idus or Idus idus) of Europe. A domesticated variety, colored like the goldfish, is called orfe in Germany.
That part of a person's psyche which is the unconscious source of impulses seeking gratification or pleasure; the impulses are usually modified by the ego and superego before being acted upon.
a resident of Idaho.
Of or pertaining to Idalium, a mountain city in Cyprus, or to Venus, to whom it was sacred.
entry.q: IdalianAphrodité.

entry.def: Same as first Id, the fish.

entries.entry: -ide. Chem A suffix used to denote: The nonmetallic, or negative, element or radical in a binary compound; as, oxide, sulphide, chloride . A compound which is an anhydride; as, glycolide, phthalide . Any one of a series of derivatives; as, indogenide, glucoside, etc.

I*de"a ☞ “In England, Locke may be said to have been the first who naturalized the term in its Cartesian universality. When, in common language, employed by Milton and Dryden, after Descartes, as before him by Sidney, Spenser, Shakespeare, Hooker, etc., the meaning is Platonic.”
Abstract idea Association of ideas
etc. See under Abstract Association, etc.
There is scarcely any other word which is subjected to such abusive treatment as is the word idea, in the very general and indiscriminative way in which it is employed, as it is used variously to signify almost any act, state, or content of thought. n.; pl.Ideas #. L. idea, Gr. �, fr. � to see; akin to E. wit: cf. F. idée. See Wit
The transcript, image, or picture of a visible object, that is formed by the mind; also, a similar image of any object whatever, whether sensible or spiritual. Her sweet idea wandered through his thoughts. Being the right idea of your father Both in your form and nobleness of mind. This representation or likeness of the object being transmitted from thence [the senses] to the imagination, and lodged there for the view and observation of the pure intellect, is aptly and properly called its idea.
A general notion, or a conception formed by generalization. Alice had not the slightest idea what latitude was.
Hence: Any object apprehended, conceived, or thought of, by the mind; a notion, conception, or thought; the real object that is conceived or thought of. Whatsoever the mind perceives in itself, or as the immediate object of perception, thought, or undersanding, that I call idea.
A belief, option, or doctrine; a characteristic or controlling principle; as, an essential idea; the idea of development.
That fellow seems to me to possess but one idea, and that is a wrong one. What is now “idea” for us? How infinite the fall of this word, since the time where Milton sang of the Creator contemplating his newly-created world, “how it showed . . . Answering his great idea,” to its present use, when this person “has an idea that the train has started,” and the other “had no idea that the dinner would be so bad!”
A plan or purpose of action; intention; design. I shortly afterwards set off for that capital, with an idea of undertaking while there the translation of the work.
A rational conception; the complete conception of an object when thought of in all its essential elements or constituents; the necessary metaphysical or constituent attributes and relations, when conceived in the abstract.
A fiction object or picture created by the imagination; the same when proposed as a pattern to be copied, or a standard to be reached; one of the archetypes or patterns of created things, conceived by the Platonists to have excited objectively from eternity in the mind of the Deity. Thence to behold this new-created world, The addition of his empire, how it showed In prospect from his throne, how good, how fair, Answering his great idea. Notion; conception; thought; sentiment; fancy; image; perception; impression; opinion; belief; observation; judgment; consideration; view; design; intention; purpose; plan; model; pattern.

entry.ety: L. idealis: cf. F. idéal

sn.def: Existing in idea or thought; conceptional; intellectual; mental; as, ideal knowledge.
Reaching an imaginary standard of excellence; fit for a model; faultless; as, ideal beauty.
sn.q: There will always be a wide interval between practical and ideal excellence.

sn.def: Existing in fancy or imagination only; visionary; unreal.
sn.q: Planningidealcommon wealth.

sn.def: Teaching the doctrine of idealism; as, the ideal theory or philosophy.
Imaginary.
sn.syn: Intellectual; mental; visionary; fanciful; imaginary; unreal; impracticable; utopian.

entry.cs: Beau ideal. See Beau ideal.
entry.def: A mental conception regarded as a standard of perfection; a model of excellence, beauty, etc.
entry.q: The ideal is to be attained by selecting and assembling in one whole the beauties and perfections which are usually seen in different individuals, excluding everything defective or unseemly, so as to form a type or model of the species. Thus, the Apollo Belvedere is the ideal of the beauty and proportion of the human frame.

entry.def: Destitute of an idea.

sn.def: Same as idealize.
Same as idealization.

entry.ety: Cf. F. idéalisme

sn.def: The quality or state of being ideal.
Conception of the ideal; imagery.
The system or theory that denies the existence of material bodies, and teaches that we have no rational grounds to believe in the reality of anything but ideas and their relations.
The practice or habit of giving or attributing ideal form or character to things; treatment of things in art or literature according to ideal standards or patterns; -- opposed to realism.
a belief in the feasibility of the implementation of ideal principles and noble goals, and the practice or habit of pursuing such goals; -- opposed to realism and cynicism.

entry.ety: Cf. F. idéaliste

sn.def: One who idealizes; one who forms picturesque fancies; one given to romantic expectations.
One who holds the doctrine of idealism, in any sense. In senses 4 and 5 of idealism, opposed to realist.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to idealists or their theories.

entries.entry:
I`de*al"i*ty n.; pl.Idealities.
The quality or state of being ideal.
The capacity to form ideals of beauty or perfection.
Phren The conceptive faculty.

sn.def: The act or process of idealizing.
The representation of natural objects, scenes, etc., in such a way as to show their most important characteristics; the study of the ideal.
A defense mechanism that splits something one is ambivalent about into two representations -- one good and one bad.
something that exists only as an idea.
a protrayal of something as ideal.
sn.syn: glorification.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Idealized; p. pr. & vb. n. Idealizing

sn.def: To make ideal; to consider as ideal; to give an ideal form or value to; to attribute ideal characteristics and excellences to; as, to idealize real life.
To treat in an ideal manner. See Idealization, 2.
to form ideals.

entry.ety: Cf. F. idéaliser
entry.def: To form ideals.
An idealist.
In an ideal manner; by means of ideals; mentally.
Of or pertaining to an idealogue, or to idealization.

entry.ety: Idea + -logue, as in theologue: cf. F. idéologue
entry.def: One given to fanciful ideas or theories; a theorist; a spectator.

entry.ety: LL. ideatum. See Idea
entry.def: The actual existence supposed to correspond with an idea; the correlate in real existence to the idea as a thought or existence.

sn.def: To form in idea; to fancy.
sn.q: The ideated man . . . as he stood in the intellect of God.

sn.def: To apprehend in thought so as to fix and hold in the mind; to memorize.

entry.def: The faculty or capacity of the mind for forming ideas; the exercise of this capacity; the act of the mind by which objects of sense are apprehended and retained as objects of thought.
entry.q: The whole mass of residua which have been accumulated . . . all enter now into the process of ideation.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or characterized by, ideation.
entry.q: Certain sensational or ideational stimuli.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: The same; the same as above; -- often abbreviated id.
Identical.

cs.cd: an equation which is true for all values of the algebraic symbols which enter into it.

entry.ety: Cf. F. identique. See Identity

sn.def: The same; the selfsame; the very same; not different; as, the identical person or thing.
sn.q: I can not remember a thing that happened a year ago, without a conviction . . . that I, the same identical person who now remember that event, did then exist.

sn.def: Uttering sameness or the same truth; expressing in the predicate what is given, or obviously implied, in the subject; tautological.
sn.q: When you say body is solid, I say that you make an identical proposition, because it is impossible to have the idea of body without that of solidity.

entry.def: In diplomacy (esp. in the form identic), precisely agreeing in sentiment or opinion and form or manner of expression; -- applied to concerted action or language which is used by two or more governments in treating with another government.
In an identical manner; with respect to identity.
entry.q: Identicallythe same.
Identicallydifferent.

entry.def: The quality or state of being identical; sameness.
Capable of being identified.

entry.ety: Cf. F. identification
entry.def: The act of identifying, or proving to be the same; also, the state of being identified.
recognized; having the identity established.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Identified; p. pr. & vb. n. Identifying
entry.ety: Cf. F. identifier. See Identity, and -fy

sn.def: To make to be the same; to unite or combine in such a manner as to make one; to treat as being one or having the same purpose or effect; to consider as the same in any relation.
sn.q: Every precaution is taken to identify the interests of the people and of the rulers.
Let us identify, let us incorporate ourselves with the people.

sn.def: To establish the identity of; to prove to be the same with something described, claimed, or asserted; as, to identify stolen property.
To become the same; to coalesce in interest, purpose, use, effect, etc.
To coalesce in interest, purpose, use, effect, etc.; to associate oneself in name, goals, or feelings; usually used with with; as, he identified with the grief she felt at her father's death.
sn.q: An enlightened self-interest, which, when well understood, they tell us will identify with an interest more enlarged and public.

sn.def: serving to distinguish or identify an object, person, species or group; as, we were asked to describe any identifying marks or distinguishing features.
sn.syn: distinguishing, distinctive.

entry.ety: trademark
entry.def: A set of images containing a wide variety of facial features, such as noses, hairlines, chins, etc. on transparencies which can be overlayed in combinations to build up a picture of a person; it is used by police agencies to create concrete images of a crime suspect from the descriptions of witnesses; the image created with the kit is also called an Identikit, or more properly an Identikit picture.

entry.ety: See Identity
entry.def: The doctrine taught by Schelling, that matter and mind, and subject and object, are identical in the Absolute; -- called also the system of identityordoctrine of identity.

entries.entry:
I*den"ti*ty n.; pl.Identities #. F. identité, LL. identitas, fr. L. idem the same, from the root of is he, that; cf. Skr. idam this. Cf. Item
The state or quality of being identical, or the same; sameness.
Identity is a relation between our cognitions of a thing, not between things themselves.
The condition of being the same with something described or asserted, or of possessing a character claimed; as, to establish the identity of stolen goods.
Math An identical equation.
I"de*o-. A combining form from the Gr. �, an idea.

entry.def: Of or relating to ideology.

entry.ety: Ideo- + -geny, from the same root as Gr. �, birth: cf. F. idéogénie
entry.def: The science which treats of the origin of ideas.

entry.ety: Ideo- + -gram; cf. F. idéograme

sn.def: An original, pictorial element of writing; a kind of hieroglyph expressing no sound, but only an idea.
sn.q: Ideograms may be defined to be pictures intended to represent either things or thoughts.
You might even have a history without language written or spoken, by means of ideograms and gesture.

sn.def: A symbol used for convenience, or for abbreviation; as, 1, 2, 3, +, -, �, $, �, etc.
A phonetic symbol; a letter.

entry.def: Same as Ideogram.

entry.ety: Cf. F. idéographique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to an ideogram; representing ideas by symbols, independently of sounds; as, 9 represents not the word “nine,” but the idea of the number itself.
The system of writing in ideographic characters; also, anything so written.
The representation of ideas independently of sounds, or in an ideographic manner, as sometimes is done in shorthand writing, etc.
concerned with or suggestive of ideas; as, an ideologic argument.

entry.ety: Cf. F. idéologique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to ideology.

sn.def: One who treats of ideas; one who theorizes or idealizes; one versed in the science of ideas, or who advocates the doctrines of ideology.
An ideologue.

entry.def: an adherent to or advocate of some ideology{3}.

entry.note: ☞ By a double blunder in philosophy and Greek, idéologie . . . has in France become the name peculiarly distinctive of that philosophy of mind which exclusively derives our knowledge from sensation. Sir W. Hamilton.
entry.ety: Ideo- + -logy: cf. F. idéologie

sn.def: The science of ideas.
A theory of the origin of ideas which derives them exclusively from sensation.

A set or system of theories and beliefs held by an individual or group, especially about sociopolitical goals and methods to attain them; in common usage, ideology is such a set of beliefs so strongly held by their adherents as to cause them to ignore evidence against such beliefs, and thus fall into error -- in this sense it is viewed as a negative trait; contrasted to pragmatism, and distinct from idealism.

entry.def: An ideo-motor movement.

entry.ety: Ideo- + motor
entry.def: Applied to those actions, or muscular movements, which are automatic expressions of dominant ideas, rather than the result of distinct volitional efforts, as the act of expressing the thoughts in speech, or in writing, while the mind is occupied in the composition of the sentence.

entry.note: ☞ Eight days in each month often pass by this name, but only one strictly receives it, the others being called respectively the day before the ides, and so on, backward, to the eighth from the ides.
entry.ety: L. idus: cf. F. ides
entry.def: The fifteenth day of March, May, July, and October, and the thirteenth day of the other months.
entry.q: The ides of March remember.

entries.entry: Id"i*o- ĭd"ĭ*�-. A combining form from the Greek 'i`dios, meaning private personal peculiar distinct.

entry.ety: Ideo- + -blast
entry.def: An individual cell, differing greatly from its neighbours in regard to size, structure, or contents.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: Idiocracy.

entries.entry:
Id`i*oc"ra*sy n.; pl.Idiocrasies #.
Idio- + Gr. kra^sis a mixture, fr. � to mix: cf. F. idiocrasie
Peculiarity of constitution; that temperament, or state of constitution, which is peculiar to a person; idiosyncrasy.

entry.def: Peculiar in constitution or temperament; idiosyncratic.

entry.ety: From idiot; cf. Gr. � uncouthness, lack of education, fr. �. See Idiot, and cf. Idiotcy
entry.def: The condition or quality of being an idiot; absence, or marked deficiency, of sense and intelligence.
entry.q: I will undertake to convict a man of idiocy, if he can not see the proof that three angles of a triangle are equal to two right angles.

entry.ety: Idio- + Gr. � circle + � to appear
entry.def: Same as Idiophanous.

entry.ety: Idio- + electric: cf. F. idioélectrique
entry.def: Electric by virtue of its own peculiar properties; capable of becoming electrified by friction; -- opposed to anelectric.

entry.ety: Gr. � autographic; 'i`dios one's own + gra`fein to write
entry.def: A mark or signature peculiar to an individual; a trade-mark.
Of or pertaining to an idiograph.

entry.ety: Idio- + Gr. � to worship
entry.def: Self-worship; excessive self-esteem.
the language or speech of one individual at a particular period in life.

entry.usage: Idiom Dialect. The idioms of a language belong to its very structure; its dialects are varieties of expression ingrafted upon it in different localities or by different professions. Each county of England has some peculiarities of dialect, and so have most of the professions, while the great idioms of the language are everywhere the same. See Language.
entry.ety: F. idiome, L. idioma, fr. Gr. 'idi`wma, fr. 'idioy^n to make a person's own, to make proper or peculiar; fr. 'i`dios one's own, proper, peculiar; prob. akin to the reflexive pronoun o"y^ o'i^ 'e`, and to "eo`s 'o`s, one's own, L. suus, and to E. so

sn.def: The syntactical or structural form peculiar to any language; the genius or cast of a language.
sn.q: Idiom may be employed loosely and figuratively as a synonym of language or dialect, but in its proper sense it signifies the totality of the general rules of construction which characterize the syntax of a particular language and distinguish it from other tongues.
By idiom is meant the use of words which is peculiar to a particular language.
He followed their language [the Latin], but did not comply with the idiom of ours.

sn.def: An expression conforming or appropriate to the peculiar structural form of a language.
sn.q: Some that with care true eloquence shall teach, And to just idioms fix our doubtful speech.

sn.def: A combination of words having a meaning peculiar to itself and not predictable as a combination of the meanings of the individual words, but sanctioned by usage; as, an idiomatic expression; less commonly, a single word used in a peculiar sense.
sn.q: It is not by means of rules that such idioms as the following are made current: “I can make nothing of it.” “He treats his subject home.” Dryden. “It is that within us that makes for righteousness.” M. Arnold.
Sometimes we identify the words with the object -- though by courtesy of idiom rather than in strict propriety of language.

sn.def: The phrase forms peculiar to a particular author; as, written in his own idiom .
sn.q: Every good writer has much idiom.

sn.def: Dialect; a variant form of a language.
sn.syn: Dialect.

entry.ety: Gr. 'idiwmatiko`s

sn.def: Of or pertaining to, or conforming to, the mode of expression peculiar to a language; as, an idiomatic meaning; an idiomatic phrase.
Of or pertaining to, or of the nature of an idiom3}; having a meaning that is peculiar to itself and not predictable from general rules.

entry.def: Idiomorphous.

entry.ety: Gr. 'idio`morfos of peculiar form; 'i`dios peculiar + morfh` form

sn.def: Having a form of its own.
Apperaing in distinct crystals; -- said of the mineral constituents of a rock.

entry.ety: Idio- + muscular
entry.def: Applied to a semipermanent contraction of a muscle, produced by a mechanical irritant.
Idiopathic.

entry.ety: Cf. F. idiopathique
entry.def: Pertaining to idiopathy; characterizing a disease arising primarily, and not in consequence of some other disease or injury; -- opposed to symptomatic sympathetic, and traumatic.

entries.entry:
Id`i*op"a*thy n.; pl.Idiopathies #. Gr. �; 'i`dios proper, peculiar + �, �, to suffer: cf. F. idiopathie
A peculiar, or individual, characteristic or affection. All men are so full of their own fancies and idiopathies, that they scarce have the civility to interchange any words with a stranger.
Med A morbid state or condition not preceded or occasioned by any other disease; a primary disease.

entry.ety: Idio- + � to appear
entry.def: Exhibiting interference figures without the aid of a polariscope, as certain crystals.
Same as Idioplasma.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'i`dios proper, peculiar + � a form, mold
entry.def: That portion of the cell protoplasm which is the seat of all active changes, and which carries on the function of hereditary transmission; -- distinguished from the other portion, which is termed nutritive plasma. See Hygroplasm.

entry.ety: Idio- + repulsive
entry.def: Repulsive by itself; as, the idiorepulsive power of heat.

entries.entry:
Id`i*o*syn"cra*sy n.; pl.Idiosyncrasies #. Gr. �; 'i`dios proper, peculiar + � a mixing together, fr. � to mix together; � with + � to mix: cf. F. idiosyncrasie. See Idiom, and Crasis
A peculiarity of physical or mental constitution or temperament; a characteristic belonging to, and distinguishing, an individual; characteristic susceptibility; idiocrasy; eccentricity. The individual mind . . . takes its tone from the idiosyncrasies of the body.

entry.def: Of peculiar temper or disposition; belonging to one's peculiar and individual character.

entry.ety: F. idiot, L. idiota an uneducated, ignorant, ill-informed person, Gr. 'idiw`ths, also and orig., a private person, not holding public office, fr. 'i`dios proper, peculiar. See Idiom

sn.def: A man in private station, as distinguished from one holding a public office.
sn.q: St. Austin affirmed that the plain places of Scripture are sufficient to all laics, and all idiots or private persons.

sn.def: An unlearned, ignorant, or simple person, as distinguished from the educated; an ignoramus.
sn.q: Christ was received of idiots, of the vulgar people, and of the simpler sort, while he was rejected, despised, and persecuted even to death by the high priests, lawyers, scribes, doctors, and rabbis.

sn.def: A human being destitute of the ordinary intellectual powers, whether congenital, developmental, or accidental; commonly, a person without understanding from birth; a natural fool. In a former classification of mentally retarded people, idiot designated a person whose adult level of intelligence was equivalent to that of a three-year old or younger; this corresponded with an I.Q. level of approximately 25 or less.
sn.q: Life . . . is a tale Told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, Signifying nothing.

sn.def: A fool; a simpleton; -- a term of reproach.
sn.q: Weenest thou make an idiot of our dame?

entry.ety: Cf. Idiocy
entry.def: Idiocy.
Rendered idiotic; befooled.

entry.ety: Idio- + thermic
entry.def: Self-heating; warmed, as the body of animal, by process going on within itself.

entry.ety: L. idioticus ignorant, Gr. �: cf. F. idiotique. See Idiot

sn.def: Common; simple.
Pertaining to, or like, an idiot; characterized by idiocy; foolish; fatuous; as, an idiotic person, speech, laugh, or action.

entry.def: In an idiotic manner.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � belonging to a private man, private. See Idiot
entry.def: A dictionary of a peculiar dialect, or of the words and phrases peculiar to one part of a country; a glossary.
Like an idiot; foolish.

entry.ety: F. idiotisme, L. idiotismus the way of fashion of a private person, the common or vulgar manner of speaking, Gr. �, fr. � to put into or use common language, fr. �. See Idiot

sn.def: An idiom; a form, mode of expression, or signification, peculiar to a language.
sn.q: Scholars sometimes give terminations and idiotisms, suitable to their native language, unto words newly invented.

sn.def: Lack of knowledge or mental capacity; idiocy; foolishness.
sn.q: Worse than mere ignorance or idiotism.
The running that adventure is the greatist idiotism.

entry.def: To become stupid.
Idiocy.

entry.cs: Idle pulley Mach a pulley that rests upon a belt to tighten it; a pulley that only guides a belt and is not used to transmit power. Idle wheel Mach a gear wheel placed between two others, to transfer motion from one to the other without changing the direction of revolution. In idle in vain. Obs “God saith, thou shalt not take the name of thy Lord God in idle.” Chaucer.
entry.usage: Idle Indolent Lazy. A propensity to inaction is expressed by each of these words; they differ in the cause and degree of this characteristic. Indolent denotes an habitual love to ease, a settled dislike of movement or effort; idle is opposed to busy, and denotes a dislike of continuous exertion. Lazy is a stronger and more contemptuous term than indolent.
entry.ety: OE. idel, AS. īdel vain, empty, useless; akin to OS. īdal, D. ijdel, OHG. ītal vain, empty, mere, G. eitel, Dan. & Sw. idel mere, pure, and prob. to Gr. � clear, pure, � to burn. Cf. Ether

sn.def: Of no account; useless; vain; trifling; unprofitable; thoughtless; silly; barren.
sn.q: Desertsidle.
Every idle word that men shall speak, they shall give account thereof in the day of judgment.
Down their idle weapons dropped.
This idle story became important.

sn.def: Not called into active service; not turned to appropriate use; unemployed; as, idle hours.
sn.q: The idle spear and shield were high uphing.

sn.def: Not employed; unoccupied with business; inactive; doing nothing; as, idle workmen.
sn.q: Why stand ye here all the day idle?

sn.def: Given rest and ease; averse to labor or employment; lazy; slothful; as, an idle fellow.
Light-headed; foolish.
sn.syn: Unoccupied; unemployed; vacant; inactive; indolent; sluggish; slothful; useless; ineffectual; futile; frivolous; vain; trifling; unprofitable; unimportant.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Idled; p. pr. & vb. n. Idling
entry.def: To lose or spend time in inaction, or without being employed in business.
To spend in idleness; to waste; to consume; -- often followed by away; as, to idle away an hour a day.

sn.def: Foolish; stupid.
sn.q: The superstitiousidle-headedeld.

sn.def: Delirious; infatuated.

entry.ety: AS. īdelnes
entry.def: The condition or quality of being idle (in the various senses of that word); uselessness; fruitlessness; triviality; inactivity; laziness.
Idle-headed; stupid.

sn.def: One who idles; one who spends his time in inaction; a lazy person; a sluggard.
One who has constant day duties on board ship, and keeps no regular watch.
An idle wheel or pulley. See under Idle.

entry.def: Idleness.
entry.q: Inydlesse.
And an idlesse all the day Beside a wandering stream.

entry.def: In a idle manner; ineffectually; vainly; lazily; carelessly; (Obs.) foolishly.

An artificial international language, selected by the “Delegation for the Adoption of an Auxillary International Language” (founded at Paris in 1901), made public in 1907, and subsequently greatly revised and extended by a permanent committee or “Academy.” It is a revised and simplified form of Esperanto. It combines systematically the advantages of previous schemes with a thoroughly logical word formation, and has neither accented constants nor arbitrarily coined pronominal words. For each idea that root is selected which is already most international, on the principle of the “greatest facility for the greatest number of people.” The word “Ido” means in the language itself “offspring.” The official name is: “Linguo Internaciona di la Delegitaro (Sistema Ido).”

entry.ety: Gr. e'i^dos form + kra^sis mixture, from keranny`nai to mix; cf. F. idocrase
entry.def: Same as Vesuvianite.

entry.ety: OE. idole, F. idole, L. idolum, fr. Gr. �, fr. � that which is seen, the form, shape, figure, fr. � to see. See Wit, and cf. Eidolon

sn.def: An image or representation of anything.
sn.q: Do her adore with sacred reverence, As th' idol of her maker's great magnificence.

sn.def: An image of a divinity; a representation or symbol of a deity or any other being or thing, made or used as an object of worship; a similitude of a false god.
sn.q: That they should not worship devils, and idols of gold.

sn.def: That on which the affections are strongly (often excessively) set; an object of passionate devotion; a person or thing greatly loved or adored.
sn.q: The soldier's god and people's idol.

sn.def: A false notion or conception; a fallacy.
sn.q: The idols of preconceived opinion.

entry.ety: OE., for idolatre
entry.def: An idolater.

entry.ety: F. idolâtre: cf. L. idololatres, Gr. �. See Idolatry

sn.def: A worshiper of idols; one who pays divine honors to images, statues, or representations of anything made by hands; one who worships as a deity that which is not God; a pagan.
An adorer; a great admirer.
sn.q: Jonson was an idolater of the ancients.

entry.def: A female worshiper of idols.

entry.ety: Cf. F. idolâtrique
entry.def: Idolatrous.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Idolatrized; p. pr. & vb. n. Idolatrizing
entry.def: To worship idols; to pay idolatrous worship.
To make in idol of; to idolize.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to idolatry; partaking of the nature of idolatry; given to idolatry or the worship of false gods; as, idolatrous sacrifices.
sn.q: Josiah] put down the idolatrous priests.

sn.def: Consisting in, or partaking of, an excessive attachment or reverence; as, an idolatrous veneration for antiquity.

entry.def: In a idolatrous manner.

entries.entry:
I*dol"a*try n.; pl.Idolatries #. F. idolâtrie, LL. idolatria, L. idololatria, Fr. Gr. �; � idol + � service
The worship of idols, images, or anything which is not God; the worship of false gods. His eye surveyed the dark idolatries Of alienated Judah.
Excessive attachment or veneration for anything; respect or love which borders on adoration.

entry.def: Idolatrous.
The worship of idols.
A worshiper of idols.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Idolized; p. pr. & vb. n. Idolizing

sn.def: To make an idol of; to pay idolatrous worship to; as, to idolize the sacred bull in Egypt.
To love to excess; to love or reverence to adoration; as, to idolize gold, children, a hero.

entry.def: To practice idolatry.
entry.q: To idolize after the manner of Egypt.

entry.def: One who idolizes or loves to the point of reverence; an idolater.

entry.ety: Gr. � idol + � to break
entry.def: A breaker of idols; an iconoclast.

entry.ety: Idol + -graph
entry.def: Descriptive of idols.
Idolatrous.

entries.entry:
‖I*do"lum ‖I*do"lon
n.; pl. Idola # . L. See Idol; cf. Eidolon
Appearance or image; a phantasm; a spectral image; also, a mental image or idea.

entry.ety: L. idoneus
entry.def: Appropriate; suitable; proper; fit; adequate.
entry.q: An ecclesiastical benefice . . . ought to be conferred on an idoneous person.

entry.ety: Gr. � form + E. organ
entry.def: A morphological unit, consisting of two or more plastids, which does not possess the positive character of the person or stock, in distinction from the physiological organ or biorgan. See Morphon.

entry.ety: Cf. F. idrialine
entry.def: A bituminous substance obtained from the mercury mines of Idria, where it occurs mixed with cinnabar.
Of or pertaining to ancient Idumea, or Edom, in Western Asia.

def2.def: An inhabitant of Idumea, an Edomite.

entry.ety: L. idyllium, Gr. �, fr. � form; literally, a little form of image: cf. F. idylle. See Idol
entry.def: A short poem; properly, a short pastoral poem; as, the idyls of Theocritus; also, any poem, especially a narrative or descriptive poem, written in an eleveted and highly finished style; also, by extension, any artless and easily flowing description, either in poetry or prose, of simple, rustic life, of pastoral scenes, and the like.
entry.q: Wordsworth's solemn-thoughted idyl.
His [Goldsmith's] lovely idyl of the Vicar's home.

entry.def: Of or belonging to idyls.
Abbreviation of Latin id est, that is.

entry.cs: As if But if . See under As But.
entry.ety: OE. if gif, AS. gif; akin to OFries. ief gef ef, OS. ef of, D. of, or, whether, if, G. ob whether, if, OHG. oba ibu, Icel. ef, Goth. iba ibai, an interrogative particle; properly a case form of a noun meaning, doubt (cf. OHG. iba doubt, condition, Icel. if ef ifi efi), and therefore orig. meaning, on condition that

sn.def: In case that; granting, allowing, or supposing that; -- introducing a condition or supposition.
sn.q: Tisiphone, that oft hast heard my prayer, Assist, if Œdipus deserve thy care.
If thou be the Son of God, command that these stones be made bread.

sn.def: Whether; -- in dependent questions.
sn.q: Uncertain if by augury or chance.
She doubts if two and two make four.

entries.entry: I' faith". In faith; indeed; truly.

entry.ety: Corrupted fr. in fere
entry.def: Together.

entry.ety: See Igasurine
entry.def: Pertaining to, or obtained from, nux vomica or St. Ignatius's bean; as, igasuric acid.

entry.ety: Malay igasura the nux vomica
entry.def: An alkaloid found in nux vomica, and extracted as a white crystalline substance.

sn.def: An Eskimo snow house.
A cavity, or excavation, made in the snow by a seal, over its breathing hole in the ice.

entries.entry: Ig*na"tius bean`. Bot See Saint Ignatius's bean, under Saint.

entry.ety: L. igneus, fr. ignis fire; allied to Skr. agni, Lith. ugnis, OSlav. ogne

sn.def: Pertaining to, having the nature of, fire; containing fire; resembling fire; as, an igneous appearance.
Resulting from, or produced by, the action of fire; as, lavas and basalt are igneous rocks.

entry.ety: L. ignescens, p. pr. of ignescere to become inflamed, fr. ignis fire: cf. F. ignescent
entry.def: Emitting sparks of fire when struck with steel; scintillating; as, ignescent stones.

entry.ety: L. ignis fire + colere to worship
entry.def: A worshiper of fire.

entry.ety: L. ignifer; ignis fire + ferre to bear
entry.def: Producing fire.

entry.ety: L. ignifluus; ignis fire + fluere to flow
entry.def: Flowing with fire.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ignified; p. pr. & vb. n. Ignifying
entry.ety: L. ignis fire + -fy
entry.def: To form into fire.

entry.ety: L. ignigenus; ignis fire + genere ginere, to beget, produce
entry.def: Produced by the action of fire, as lava.
Power over fire.

entry.ety: L. ignipotens; ignis fire + potens powerful
entry.def: Presiding over fire; also, fiery.
entry.q: Vulcan is called the powerful ignipotent.

entries.entry:
‖Ig"nis fat"u*us; pl.Ignes fatui #. L. ignis fire + fatuus foolish. So called in allusion to its tendency to mislead travelers
A phosphorescent light that appears, in the night, over marshy ground, supposed to be occasioned by the decomposition of animal or vegetable substances, or by some inflammable gas; -- popularly called also Will-with-the-wisp, or Will-o'-the-wisp, and Jack-with-a-lantern, or Jack-o'-lantern.
Fig.: A misleading influence; a decoy. Scared and guided by the ignis fatuus of popular superstition.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ignited; p. pr. & vb. n. Igniting
entry.ety: L. ignitus, p. p. of ignire to ignite, fr. ignis fire. See Igneous

sn.def: To kindle or set on fire; as, to ignite paper or wood.
To subject to the action of intense heat; to heat strongly; -- often said of incombustible or infusible substances; as, to ignite iron or platinum.

entry.def: To take fire; to begin to burn.
set afire or burning.

sn.def: a substance used to ignite or kindle a fire.
sn.syn: ignitor, lighter.

sn.def: a device for lighting or igniting fuel or charges or fires.
sn.syn: lighter, light, ignitor.

entry.def: Capable of being ignited.

entry.ety: Cf. F. ignition

sn.def: The act of igniting, kindling, or setting on fire.
The state of being ignited or kindled.

entry.def: One who, or that which, produces ignition; especially, a contrivance for igniting the powder in a torpedo or the like.

entry.ety: L. ignivomus; ignis fire + vomere 8vomit
entry.def: Vomiting fire.

entry.ety: L. ignobilitas: cf. F. ignobilité
entry.def: Ignobleness.

entry.ety: L. ignobilis; pref. in- not + nobilis noble: cf. F. ignoble. See In- not, and Noble a.

sn.def: Of low birth or family; not noble; not illustrious; plebeian; common; humble.
sn.q: I was not ignoble of descent.
Her royal stock graft with ignoble plants.

sn.def: Not honorable, elevated, or generous; base.
sn.q: 'T is but a base, ignoble mind, That mounts no higher than a bird can soar.
Far from the madding crowd's ignoble strife.

sn.def: Not a true or noble falcon; -- said of certain hawks, as the goshawk.
sn.syn: Degenerate; degraded; mean; base; dishonorable; reproachful; disgraceful; shameful; scandalous; infamous.

entry.def: To make ignoble.
State or quality of being ignoble.
In an ignoble manner; basely.

entry.ety: L. ignominiosus: cf. F. ignominieux

sn.def: Marked with ignominy; incurring public disgrace; dishonorable; shameful.
sn.q: Then first with fear surprised and sense of pain, Fled ignominious.

sn.def: Deserving ignominy; despicable.
sn.q: One single, obscure, ignominious projector.

sn.def: Humiliating; degrading; as, an ignominious judgment or sentence.

entry.def: In an ignominious manner; disgracefully; shamefully; ingloriously.

entries.entry:
Ig"no*min*y n.; pl.Ignominies #. L. ignominia ignominy (i.e., a deprivation of one's good name); in- not + nomen name: cf. F. ignominie. See In- not, and Name
Public disgrace or dishonor; reproach; infamy. Their generals have been received with honor after their defeat; yours with ignominy after conquest. Vice begins in mistake, and ends in ignominy.
Ignominy is the infliction of such evil as is made dishonorable, or the deprivation of such good as is made honorable by the Commonwealth.
An act deserving disgrace; an infamous act. Opprobrium; reproach; dishonor.

entry.def: Ignominy.
entry.q: I blush to think upon this ignomy.

entry.ety: L., we are ignorant. See Ignore

sn.def: We are ignorant; we ignore; -- being the word formerly written on a bill of indictment by a grand jury when there was not sufficient evidence to warrant them in finding it a true bill. The phrase now used is, “No bill,” “No true bill,” or “Not found,” though in some jurisdictions “Ignored” is still used.
A stupid, ignorant person; a vain pretender to knowledge; a dunce.
sn.q: An ignoramus in place and power.

cs.cd: ignorance beyond the individual's control and for which, therefore, he is not responsible before God.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. ignorantia

sn.def: The condition of being ignorant; the lack of knowledge in general, or in relation to a particular subject; the state of being uneducated or uninformed.
sn.q: Ignorance is the curse of God, Knowledge the wing wherewith we fly to heaven.

sn.def: A willful neglect or refusal to acquire knowledge which one may acquire and it is his duty to have.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. ignorans -antis, p. pr. of ignorare to be ignorant. See Ignore

sn.def: Destitute of knowledge; uninstructed or uninformed; untaught; unenlightened.
sn.q: He that doth not know those things which are of use for him to know, is but an ignorant man, whatever he may know besides.

sn.def: Unacquainted with; unconscious or unaware; -- used with of.
sn.q: Ignorant of guilt, I fear not shame.

sn.def: Unknown; undiscovered.
sn.q: Ignorant concealment.
Alas, what ignorant sin have I committed?

sn.def: Resulting from ignorance; foolish; silly.
sn.q: His shipping, Poor ignorant baubles! -- on our terrible seas, Like eggshells moved.
sn.syn: Uninstructed; untaught; unenlightened; uninformed; unlearned; unlettered; illiterate.Ignorant Illiterate. Ignorant denotes lack of knowledge, either as to single subject or information in general; illiterate refers to an ignorance of letters, or of knowledge acquired by reading and study. In the Middle Ages, a great proportion of the higher classes were illiterate, and yet were far from being ignorant, especially in regard to war and other active pursuits.
sn.q: In such business Action is eloquence, and the eyes of the ignorant More learned than the ears.
In the first ages of Christianity, not only the learned and the wise, but the ignorant and illiterate, embraced torments and death.

entry.def: A person untaught or uninformed; one unlettered or unskilled; an ignoramous.
entry.q: Did I for this take pains to teach Our zealous ignorants to preach?

entry.def: The spirit of those who extol the advantage of ignorance; obscurantism.
One opposed to the diffusion of knowledge; an obscurantist.
In a ignorant manner; without knowledge; inadvertently.
entry.q: Whom therefoer ye ignorantly worship, him declare I unto you.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ignored; p. pr. & vb. n. Ignoring
entry.ety: L. ignorare; pref. in- not + the root of gnarus knowing, noscere to become acquainted with. See Know, and cf. Narrate

sn.def: To be ignorant of or not acquainted with.
sn.q: Philosophy would solidly be established, if men would more carefully distinguish those things that they know from those that they ignore.

sn.def: To throw out or reject as false or ungrounded; -- said of a bill rejected by a grand jury for lack of evidence. See Ignoramus.
Hence: To refuse to take notice of; to shut the eyes to; not to recognize; to disregard willfully and causelessly; as, to ignore certain facts; to ignore the presence of an objectionable person.
sn.q: Ignoring Italy under our feet, And seeing things before, behind.

entry.ety: L. ignoscibilis, fr. ignoscere to pardon, lit., not to wish to know; pref. in- not + gnoscere noscere, to learn to know. See In- not, and Know
entry.def: Pardonable.

entry.ety: L. ignotus; pref. in- not + gnotus notus, known, p. p. of gnocere nocere, to learn to know
entry.def: Unknown.

entry.note: ☞ The common iguana (Iguana tuberculata) of the West Indies and South America is sometimes five feet long. Its flesh is highly prized as food. The horned iguana (Iguana cornuta) has a conical horn between the eyes.
entry.ety: Sp. iguana, from the native name in Haiti. Cf. Guana
entry.def: Any species of the genus Iguana, a genus of large American lizards of the family Iguanidæ. They are arboreal in their habits, usually green in color, and feed chiefly upon fruits.
A superfamily (or suborder) of New World lizards including the Iguanidae.
Resembling, or pertaining to, the iguana.
Same as Iguanoid.
A natural family of New World lizards including the common Iguana, Iguana iguana.

entry.ety: Iguana + Gr. �, �, a tooth
entry.def: A genus of gigantic herbivorous dinosaurs having a birdlike pelvis and large hind legs with three-toed feet capable of supporting the entire body. Its teeth resemble those of the iguana, whence its name. Several species are known, mostly from the Wealden of England and Europe. See Illustration in Appendix.
Like or pertaining to the genus Iguanodon.

entry.ety: Iguana + -oid
entry.def: Pertaining to the Iguanidæ.

entry.ety: Malayan, flower of flowers
entry.def: A rich, powerful, perfume, obtained from the volatile oil of the flowers of Canada odorata, an East Indian tree.
The peculiar dress worn by pilgrims to Mecca.

entries.entry:
IHVH ☞ Numerous attempts have been made to represent the supposed original form of the word, as Jahaveh, Jahvaj, Jahve, Jahveh, Yahve, Yahveh, Yahwe, Yahweh, etc.. JHVH YHVH
A transliteration of the four constants forming the Hebrew tetragrammaton or “incommunicable name” of the Supreme Being, which in latter Jewish tradition is not pronounced save with the vowels of adonai or elohim, so that the true pronunciation is lost.

entry.note: ☞ The Northern dialectic form of I, in Early English, corresponding to ich of the Southern.
entry.ety: See I
entry.def: I.

entries.entry: Il-. A form of the prefix in-, not, and in-, among. See In-.

sn.def: A tropical American tree (Annona diversifolia) grown in the southern U. S. having a whitish pink-tinged fruit.
sn.syn: ilama tree, Annona diversifolia.

sn.def: whitish tropical fruit with a pinkish tinge related to custard apples, grown in the southern U. S.
An oil distilled from flowers of the ilang-ilang tree, used in perfumery.
An evergreen Asian tree (Cananga odorata) with aromatic greenish-yellow flowers yielding a volatile oil; widely grown in the tropics as an ornamental.
sn.syn: ylang-ylang, Cananga odorata.

entry.ety: AS. egl
entry.def: Ear of corn.

entry.ety: See Aisle
entry.def: An aisle.

entry.ety: See Isle
entry.def: An isle.

entry.cs: Ileac passion. Med See Ileus.
entry.ety: See Ileum

sn.def: Pertaining to the ileum.
See Iliac, 1.

entry.ety: Ileum + cæcal
entry.def: Pertaining to the ileum and cæcum.
Pertaining to the ileum and colon; as, the ileocolic, or ileocæcal, valve, a valve where the ileum opens into the large intestine.
An island on the Seine.

entry.note: ☞ Most modern writers restrict ileum to the division of the intestine and ilium to the pelvic bone.
entry.ety: L. ile ileum ilium, pl. ilia, groin, flank

sn.def: The last, and usually the longest, division of the small intestine; the part between the jejunum and large intestine.
See Ilium.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �, �, fr. � to roll up
entry.def: A morbid condition due to intestinal obstruction. It is characterized by complete constipation, with griping pains in the abdomen, which is greatly distended, and in the later stages by vomiting of fecal matter. Called also ileac passionoriliac passion.

entry.ety: L., holm oak
entry.def: The holm oak (Quercus Ilex).
A genus of evergreen trees and shrubs, including the common holly.

entry.ety: L. Iliacus, Gr. �. See Iliad
entry.def: Pertaining to ancient Ilium, or Troy.

entry.cs: Iliac crest the upper margin of the ilium. Iliac passion. See Ileus. Iliac region a region of the abdomen, on either side of the hypogastric regions, and below the lumbar regions.
entry.ety: Cf. F. iliaque. See Ileum, and cf. Jade a stone

sn.def: Pertaining to, or in the region of, the ilium, or dorsal bone of the pelvis; as, the iliac artery.
See Ileac, 1.

entry.def: Iliac.

entry.ety: L. Ilias -adis, Gr. �, � (sc. �), fr. �, �, Ilium, the city of Ilus, a son of Tros, founder of Ilium, which is a poetical name of Troy
entry.def: A celebrated Greek epic poem, in twenty-four books, on the destruction of Ilium, the ancient Troy. The Iliad is ascribed to Homer.
Pertaining to the ilium; iliac.

entry.ety: OE., fr. AS. gelīc. Cf. Alike
entry.def: Alike.

entry.ety: L. ilex ilicis, holm oak
entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, the holly (Ilex), and allied plants; as, ilicic acid.
The bitter principle of the holly.

entries.entry:
Il"i*o-. From Ilium
A combining form used in anatomy to denote connection with, or relation to the ilium; as, ilio-femoral, ilio-lumbar, ilio-psoas, etc.

entry.def: Pertaining to the ilium and femur; as, iliofemoral ligaments.
Pertaining to the iliac and lumbar regions; as, the iliolumbar artery.
Ilium, or Troy, the ancient city in Asia Minor that was the site of the Trojan War; -- a variant spelling of Ilium.
The great flexor muscle of the hip joint, divisible into two parts, the iliac and great psoas, -- often regarded as distinct muscles.

entry.ety: See Ileum
entry.def: The dorsal one of the three principal bones comprising either lateral half of the pelvis; the dorsal or upper part of the hip bone. See Innominate bone, under Innominate.

entry.ety: Ilex the genus including the holly + Gr. � yellow
entry.def: A yellow dye obtained from the leaves of the holly.

cs.cd: denoting that a person's surname and the title of his estate are the same; as, Grant of that ilk, i.e., Grant of Grant.
Of the same kind.

entry.ety: Scot. ilk, OE. ilke the same, AS. ilca. Cf. Each
entry.def: Same; each; every.
Kind; class; sort; type; as, him and his ilk ; -- sometimes used to indicate disapproval when applied to people.

entry.ety: See Ilk
entry.def: Same.

entry.ety: See Ilk, and One
entry.def: Each one; every one.

entry.cs:
Ill at ease uneasy; uncomfortable; anxious. “I am very ill at ease.” Shak. Ill blood enmity; resentment; bad blood. Ill breeding lack of good breeding; rudeness. Ill fame ill or bad repute; as, a house of ill fame, a house where lewd persons meet for illicit intercourse. Ill humor a disagreeable mood; bad temper. Ill nature bad disposition or temperament; sullenness; esp., a disposition to cause unhappiness to others. Ill temper anger; moroseness; crossness.
Ill turn. An unkind act. A slight attack of illness. Colloq. U.S Ill will
unkindness; enmity; malevolence.
entry.amorph: The regular comparative and superlative are wanting, their places being supplied by worse and worst, from another root
entry.ety: OE. ill ille, Icel. illr; akin to Sw. illa, adv., Dan. ilde, adv

sn.def: Contrary to good, in a physical sense; contrary or opposed to advantage, happiness, etc.; bad; evil; unfortunate; disagreeable; unfavorable.
sn.q: Neither is it ill air only that maketh an ill seat, but ill ways, ill markets, and ill neighbors.
There 's some ill planet reigns.

sn.def: Contrary to good, in a moral sense; evil; wicked; wrong; iniquitious; naughtly; bad; improper.
sn.q: Of his own body he was ill, and gave The clergy ill example.

sn.def: Sick; indisposed; unwell; diseased; disordered; as, ill of a fever.
sn.q: I am in health, I breathe, and see thee ill.

sn.def: Not according with rule, fitness, or propriety; incorrect; rude; unpolished; inelegant.
sn.q: That 's an ill phrase.
sn.syn: Bad; evil; wrong; wicked; sick; unwell.

sn.def: Whatever annoys or impairs happiness, or prevents success; evil of any kind; misfortune; calamity; disease; pain; as, the ills of humanity.
sn.q: Who can all sense of others' ills escape Is but a brute at best in human shape.
That makes us rather bear those ills we have Than fly to others that we know not of.

sn.def: Whatever is contrary to good, in a moral sense; wickedness; depravity; iniquity; wrong; evil.
sn.q: Strong virtue, like strong nature, struggles still, Exerts itself, and then throws off the ill.

entry.note: ☞ Ill, like above well, and so, is used before many participal adjectives, in its usual adverbal sense. When the two words are used as an epithet preceding the noun qualified they are commonly hyphened; in other cases they are written separatively; as, an ill-educated man; he was ill educated; an ill-formed plan; the plan, however ill formed, was acceptable. Ao, also, the following: ill-affected or ill affected, ill-arranged or ill arranged, ill-assorted or ill assorted, ill-boding or ill boding, ill-bred or ill bred, ill-conditioned, ill-conducted, ill-considered, ill-devised, ill-disposed, ill-doing, ill-fairing, ill-fated, ill-favored, ill-featured, ill-formed, ill-gotten, ill-imagined, ill-judged, ill-looking, ill-mannered, ill-matched, ill-meaning, ill-minded, ill-natured, ill-omened, ill-proportioned, ill-provided, ill-required, ill-sorted, ill-starred, ill-tempered, ill-timed, ill-trained, ill-used, and the like.
entry.def: In a ill manner; badly; weakly.
entry.q: How ill this taper burns!
Ill fares the land, to hastening ills a prey, Where wealth accumulates and men decay.

entries.entry:
I' ll. Contraction for I will or I shall.
I'll by a sign give notice to our friends.

entry.def: Incapable of falling or erring; infalliable.

entry.ety: L. illacerabilis: cf. F. illacérable. See In- not, and Lacerable
entry.def: Not lacerable; incapable of being torn or rent.

entry.ety: L. illacrimabilis; pref. il- not + lacrimabilis worthy of tears
entry.def: Incapable of weeping.
A mountian in Bolivia, 20,873 feet high.

entry.ety: Pref. il- not + lapsable
entry.def: Incapable of slipping, or of error.
entry.q: Morally immutable and illapsable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Illapsed; p. pr. & vb. n. Illapsing
entry.ety: L. illapsus, p. p. of illabi; pref. il- in + labi to fall, slide
entry.def: To fall or glide; to pass; -- usually followed by into.

entry.ety: L. illapsus. See Illapse v. i.
entry.def: A gliding in; an immisson or entrance of one thing into another; also, a sudden descent or attack.
entry.q: They sit silent . . . waiting for an illapse of the spirit.

entry.def: Capable of being insnared or entrapped.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Illaqueated; p. pr. & vb. n. Illaqueating
entry.ety: L. illaqueatus, p. p. of illaqueare; pref. il- in + laqueare to insnare, fr. laqueus, noose, snare
entry.def: To insnare; to entrap; to entangle; to catch.
entry.q: Let not the surpassing eloquence of Taylor dazzle you, nor his scholastic retiary versatility of logic illaqueate your good sense.

sn.def: The act of catching or insnaring.
A snare; a trap.

entry.ety: L. illatio, fr. illatus, used as p. p. of inferre to carry or bring in, but from a different root: cf. F. illation. See 1st In-, and Tolerate, and cf. Infer
entry.def: The act or process of inferring from premises or reasons; perception of the connection between ideas; that which is inferred; inference; deduction; conclusion.
entry.q: Fraudulent deductions or inconsequent illations from a false conception of things.

cs.cd: a converse or reverse statement of a proposition which in that form must be true because the original proposition is true.
the faculty of the mind by which it apprehends the conditions and determines upon the correctness of inferences.

entry.ety: L. illativus: cf. F. illatif
entry.def: Relating to, dependent on, or denoting, illation; inferential; conclusive; as, an illative consequence or proposition; an illative word, as then therefore, etc.
An illative particle, as for because.
By inference; as an illative; in an illative manner.

entry.ety: L. illaudabilis. See In- not, and Laudable
entry.def: Not laudable; not praise-worthy; worthy of censure or disapprobation.
Boding evil; inauspicious; ill-omened.
entry.q: Ill-bodingstars.

entry.def: Badly educated or brought up; impolite; incivil; rude. See Note under Ill adv.

entry.ety: See Illecebrous
entry.def: Allurement.

entry.ety: L. illecebrosus, fr. illecebra allurement, fr. illicere to allure
entry.def: Alluring; attractive; enticing.

entry.ety: Pref. il- not + legal: cf. F. illégal
entry.def: Not according to, or authorized by, law; specif., contrary to, or in violation of, human law; unlawful; illicit; hence, immoral; as, an illegal act; illegal trade; illegal love.

entries.entry:
Il`le*gal"i*ty n.; pl.Illegalities #. Cf. F. illégalité
The quality or condition of being illegal; unlawfulness; as, the illegality of trespass or of false imprisonment; also, an illegal act.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Illegalized; p. pr. & vb. n. Illegalizing
entry.def: To make or declare illegal or unlawful.
In a illegal manner; unlawfully.
Illegality, unlawfulness.
The state or quality of being illegible.
Incapable of being read; not legible; as, illegible handwriting; an illegible inscription.
The state of being illegitimate.

cs.cd: the fertilization of pistils by stamens not of their own length, in heterogonously dimorphic and trimorphic flowers.

sn.def: Not according to law; not regular or authorized; unlawful; improper.
Unlawfully begotten; born out of wedlock; bastard; as, an illegitimate child.
Not legitimately deduced or inferred; illogical; as, an illegitimate inference.
Not authorized by good usage; not genuine; spurious; as, an illegitimate word.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Illegitimated; p. pr. & vb. n. Illegitimating
entry.def: To render illegitimate; to declare or prove to be born out of wedlock; to bastardize; to illegitimatize.
entry.q: The marriage should only be dissolved for the future, without illegitimating the issue.

entry.def: In a illegitimate manner; unlawfully.

sn.def: The act of illegitimating; bastardizing.
The state of being illegitimate; illegitimacy.
sn.q: Gardiner had performed his promise to the queen of getting her illegitimation taken off.

entry.def: To render illegitimate; to bastardize.

entry.ety: Pref. il- not + L. laedere laesum, to injure
entry.def: Not injurious; harmless.
Not leviable; incapable of being imposed, or collected.
having an exceedingly bad reputation.

sn.def: marked by or promising bad fortune; unsuccessful; as, an ill-fated business venture.
sn.syn: ill-omened, ill-starred, unlucky.

entry.def: Wanting beauty or attractiveness; unattractive; deformed; ugly; ill-looking; -- usually used of a face; as, an ill-favored countenance.
entry.q: Ill-favored and lean-fleshed.

entry.def: not getting adequate food.
Fitting poorly; not the proper size and cut; -- of clothing.

sn.def: not grammatical; ungrammatical; not conforming to the rules of grammar or accepted usage. Opposite of grammatical.
sn.syn: ungrammatical.

entry.def: obtained illegally or by improper means; as, ill-gotten gains.
ill-natured; having a sour, disagreeable, or surly disposition. Opposite of good-natured.

entry.ety: L. illiberalis; pref. il- not + liberalis liberal: cf. F. illibéral

sn.def: Not liberal; not free or generous; close; niggardly; mean; sordid.
sn.q: A thrifty andilliberalhand.

sn.def: Indicating a lack of breeding, culture, and the like; ignoble; rude; narrow-minded; disingenuous.
Not well authorized or elegant; as, illiberal words in Latin.

entry.def: Illiberality.

entry.ety: L. illiberalitas: cf. F. illibéralité
entry.def: The state or quality of being illiberal; narrowness of mind; meanness; niggardliness.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Illiberalized; p. pr. & vb. n. Illiberalizing
entry.def: To make illiberal.
In a illiberal manner, ungenerously; uncharitably; parsimoniously.
The state of being illiberal; illiberality.

entry.ety: L. illicitus; pref. il- not + licitus, p. p. of licere to be allowed or permitted: cf. F. illicite. See In- not, and License
entry.def: Not permitted or allowed; prohibited; unlawful; as, illicit trade; illicit intercourse; illicit pleasure.
entry.q: One illicit . . . transaction always leads to another.

entry.def: Illicit.

entry.ety: So called, in allusion to its aroma, from L. illicium an allurement
entry.def: A genus of Asiatic and American magnoliaceous trees, having star-shaped fruit; star anise. The fruit of Illicium anisatum is used as a spice in India, and its oil is largely used in Europe for flavoring cordials, being almost identical with true oil of anise.
To enlighten.

entry.ety: Pref. il- not + limitable: cf. F. illimitable
entry.def: Incapable of being limited or bounded; immeasurable; limitless; boundless; as, illimitable space.
entry.q: The wild, the irregular, the illimitable, and the luxuriant, have their appropriate force of beauty.
entry.syn: Boundless; limitless; unlimited; unbounded; immeasurable; infinite; immense; vast.

entry.ety: Pref. il- not + limitation: cf. F. illimitation
entry.def: State of being illimitable; lack of, or freedom from, limitation.
Not limited; interminable.
entry.q: The absoluteness and illimitedness of his commission was generally much spoken of.

entry.ety: L. illinire illinere, to besmear; pref. il- in, on + linire linere, to smear

sn.def: A smearing or rubbing in or on; also, that which is smeared or rubbed on, as ointment or liniment.
A thin crust of some extraneous substance formed on minerals.
sn.q: A thin crust or illinition of black manganese.

entry.def: A tribe of North American Indians, which formerly occupied the region between the Wabash and Mississippi rivers.

entry.ety: Pref. il- in + L. liquare to melt
entry.def: The melting or dissolving of one thing into another.
Somewhat ill.

entry.ety: L. illisio, fr. illidere illisum, to strike against; pref. il- in + laedere to strike
entry.def: The act of dashing or striking against.

entries.entry:
Il*lit"er*a*cy n.; pl.Illiteracies #. From Illiterate
The state of being illiterate, or uneducated; lack of learning, or knowledge; ignorance; specifically, inability to read and write; as, the illiteracy shown by the last census.
An instance of ignorance; a literary blunder. The many blunders and illiteracies of the first publishers of his [Shakespeare's] works.

entry.def: Not literal.

entry.ety: L. illiteratus: pref. il- not + literatus learned. See In- not, and Literal
entry.def: Unable to read or write; ignorant of letters or books; unlettered; uninstructed; uneducated; as, an illiterate man, or people.
entry.syn: Ignorant; untaught; unlearned; unlettered; unscholary. See Ignorant.

entry.def: Lack of learning; illiteracy.
Not well judged; unwise; not well considered or thought out; as, an ill-judged attempt.
Leading a wicked life.
Having a bad look; threatening; ugly. See Note under Ill adv.
Impolite; rude; displaying socially incorrect behavior.
Ill-disposed.

entry.sn: Of habitual bad temper; having an unpleasant disposition; surly; disagreeable; cross; peevish; fractious; crabbed; -- of people; as, an ill-natured person; an ill-natured disagreeable old man. Opposite of good-natured.Narrower terms: argumentative, contentious, disputatious, disputative, litigious : atrabilious, bilious, dyspeptic, liverish : bristly, prickly, snappish, splenetic, waspish : cantankerous, crotchety, ornery : choleric, irascible, hotheaded, hot-headed, hot-tempered, quick-tempered, short-tempered : crabbed, crabby, cross, fussy, fussbudgety, grouchy, grumpy, bad-tempered, ill-tempered: cranky, fractious, irritable, peevish, peckish, pettish, petulant, testy, tetchy, techy : crusty, curmudgeonly, gruff, ill-humored, ill-humoured: dour, glowering, glum, moody, morose, saturnine, sour, sullen : feisty, touchy : huffish, sulky: misanthropic, misanthropical : misogynous : shirty, snorty ill-tempered or annoyed: shrewish, nagging, vixenish : surly, ugly Also See: unpleasant.

sn.def: Dictated by, or indicating, ill nature; spiteful.
sn.q: Theill-naturedtask refuse.

sn.def: Intractable; not yielding to culture.
sn.q: Ill-naturedland.

entry.sn: not to one's liking; unpleasant; disagreeable. Opposite of agreeable. wns=2Narrower terms: annoying, galling, chafing, irritating, nettlesome, pesky, pestiferous, pestilent, plaguy, plaguey, teasing, vexatious, vexing; nerve-racking, nerve-wracking, stressful, trying disagreeable.

entry.usage: Illness Sickness. Within the present century, there has been a tendency in England to use illness in the sense of a continuous disease, disorder of health, or sickness, and to confine sickness more especially to a sense of nausea, or “sickness of the stomach.”
entry.ety: From Ill

sn.def: The condition of being ill, evil, or bad; badness; unfavorableness.
sn.q: Theillnessof the weather.
