sn.def: Disease; indisposition; malady; disorder of health; sickness; as, a short or a severe illness .
Wrong moral conduct; wickedness.
sn.syn: Malady; disease; indisposition; ailment.

entry.def: Ill-bred.
Lack of locality or place.
Ignorant or negligent of the rules of logic or correct reasoning; as, an illogical disputant; contrary of the rules of logic or sound reasoning; as, an illogical inference.
Having unlucky omens; inauspicious. See Note under Ill adv.

sn.def: out of proportion in shape.
sn.syn: lopsided, one-sided.

sn.def: lacking pleasing shape.

cs.cd: A brothel; bordello.

entry.def: Bad reputation; notoriety.
so badly formed or out of shape as to be ugly; as, an ill-shapen vase.
not well matched.
Fated to be unfortunate; unlucky; as, an ill-starred man or day.

sn.def: Of bad temper; grouchy; morose; crabbed; sour; peevish; fretful; quarrelsome.
sn.syn: crabbed, crabby, cross, fussy, fussbudgety, grouchy, grumpy, bad-tempered.

sn.def: Unhealthy; ill-conditioned.
sn.q: So ill-tempered I am grown, that I am afraid I shall catch cold, while all the world is afraid to melt away.

entry.def: Done, attempted, or said, at an unsuitable or unpropitious time; occurring at an inappropriate time; as, an ill-timed intervention.
entry.syn: ill timed(predicate), inappropriate, unseasonable, untimely, wrong, poorly timed, badly timed.

entry.def: To treat cruelly or improperly; to ill use; to maltreat.

entries.entry: ill-treated adj. physically abused.Narrower terms: assaulted, molested, raped ; battered, beaten ; misunderstood abused, maltreated, mistreated.

entry.def: cruel or inhumane treatment.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Illuded; p. pr. & vb. n. Illuding
entry.ety: L. illudere illusum; pref. il- in + ludere to play: cf. OF. illuder. See Ludicrous
entry.def: To play upon by artifice; to deceive; to mock; to excite and disappoint the hopes of.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Illumed; p. pr. & vb. n. Illuming
entry.ety: Cf. F. illuminer. See Illuminate
entry.def: To throw or spread light upon; to make light or bright; to illuminate; to illumine.
entry.q: The mountain's brow,Illumed with fluid gold.

entry.def: Capable of being illuminated.

entry.ety: L. illuminans -antis, p. pr. of illuminare
entry.def: That which illuminates or affords light; as, gas and petroleum are illuminants .
Illuminative.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Illuminated; p. pr. & vb. n. Illuminating
entry.ety: L. illuminatus, p. p. of illuminare; pref. il- in + luminare to enlighten, fr. lumen light. See Luminous, and cf. Illume Illumine Enlimn Limn

sn.def: To make light; to throw light on; to supply with light, literally or figuratively; to brighten.
To light up; to decorate with artificial lights, as a building or city, in token of rejoicing or respect.
To adorn, as a book or page with borders, initial letters, or miniature pictures in colors and gold, as was done in manuscripts of the Middle Ages.
To make plain or clear; to dispel the obscurity to by knowledge or reason; to explain; to elucidate; as, to illuminate a text, a problem, or a duty.

entry.def: To light up in token or rejoicing.

entry.ety: L. illuminatus, p. p
entry.def: Enlightened.
One who is enlightened; esp., a pretender to extraordinary light and knowledge.

entry.ety: p. p. of illuminate

sn.def: rendered luminous by rays of light striking and reflecting; -- used especially of illumination by artificial light.
sn.syn: lighted.

sn.def: Adorned with pictorial or graphical designs, as a book or page with borders, initial letters, or miniature pictures in colors and gold, as was done in manuscripts of the Middle Ages; as, an illuminated manuscript.

entries.entry:
‖Il*lu`mi*na"ti n. pl. L. illuminatus. See Illuminate v. t., and cf. Illuminee
Literally, those who are enlightened; -- variously applied as follows: Eccl Persons in the early church who had received baptism; in which ceremony a lighted taper was given them, as a symbol of the spiritual illumination they has received by that sacrament.
Eccl. Hist Members of a sect which sprung up in Spain about the year 1575. Their principal doctrine was, that, by means of prayer, they had attained to so perfect a state as to have no need of ordinances, sacraments, good works, etc.; -- called also Alumbrados Perfectibilists, etc.
Mod. Hist Members of certain associations in Modern Europe, who combined to promote social reforms, by which they expected to raise men and society to perfection, esp. of one originated in 1776 by Adam Weishaupt, professor of canon law at Ingolstadt, which spread rapidly for a time, but ceased after a few years.
Also applied to: An obscure sect of French Familists;
The Hesychasts, Mystics, and Quietists;
The Rosicrucians.
Any persons who profess special spiritual or intellectual enlightenment.

entry.cs: Illuminating gas. See Gas n., 2 .
entry.def: Giving or producing light; used for illumination.

entry.ety: L. illuminatio: cf. F. illumination

sn.def: The act of illuminating, or supplying with light; the state of being illuminated.
Festive decoration of houses or buildings with lights.
Adornment of books and manuscripts with colored illustrations. See Illuminate v. t., 3.
That which is illuminated, as a house; also, an ornamented book or manuscript.
That which illuminates or gives light; brightness; splendor; especially, intellectual light or knowledge.
sn.q: The illumination which a bright genius giveth to his work.

sn.def: The special communication of knowledge to the mind by God; inspiration.
sn.q: Hymns and psalms . . . are framed by meditation beforehand, or by prophetical illumination are inspired.

entry.def: Illuminism.

entry.ety: Cf. F. illuminatif
entry.def: Tending to illuminate or illustrate; throwing light; illustrative.
entry.q: Illuminativereading.

entry.ety: L., an enlightener, LL. also, an illuminator of books

sn.def: One whose occupation is to adorn books, especially manuscripts, with miniatures, borders, etc. See Illuminate v. t., 3.
A condenser or reflector of light in optical apparatus; also, an illuminant.

entry.ety: Cf. F. illuminer. See Illuminate
entry.def: To illuminate; to light up; to adorn.

entry.ety: F. illuminé. Cf. Illuminati
entry.def: One of the Illuminati.
One who, or that which, illuminates.

entry.ety: Cf. F. illuminisme
entry.def: The principles of the Illuminati.
Of or pertaining to illuminism, or the Illuminati.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Illuminized; p. pr. & vb. n. Illuminizing
entry.def: To initiate the doctrines or principles of the Illuminati.
Bright; clear.

entry.ety: Pref. il- in + lure
entry.def: To deceive; to entice; to lure.
entry.q: The devil insnareth the souls of many men, by illuring them with the muck and dung of this world.

sn.def: cruel or inhumane treatment.
sn.syn: maltreatment, ill-treatment, abuse.

sn.def: to treat badly.
sn.syn: mistreat, maltreat, abuse, ill-treat.

sn.def: taken advantage of; treated badly; -- of persons.
sn.syn: exploited, put-upon, used, victimized.

sn.def: Misapplied.

entry.note: ☞ Some modern writers distinguish between an illusion and hallucination, regarding the former as originating with some external object, and the latter as having no objective occasion whatever.
entry.ety: F. illusion, L. illusio, fr. illudere, illusum, to illude. See Illude

sn.def: An unreal image presented to the bodily or mental vision; a deceptive appearance; a false show; mockery; hallucination.
sn.q: To cheat the eye with blear illusions.

sn.def: Hence: Anything agreeably fascinating and charming; enchantment; witchery; glamour.
sn.q: Ye soft illusions, dear deceits, arise!

sn.def: A sensation originated by some external object, but so modified as in any way to lead to an erroneous perception; as when the rolling of a wagon is mistaken for thunder.
A plain, delicate lace, usually of silk, used for veils, scarfs, dresses, etc.
sn.syn: Delusion; mockery; deception; chimera; fallacy. See Delusion. Illusion Delusion. Illusion refers particularly to errors of the sense; delusion to false hopes or deceptions of the mind. An optical deception is an illusion; a false opinion is a delusion.

entry.def: Liable to illusion.
marked by or producing illusion; as, illusionary stage effects.

sn.def: One given to illusion; a visionary dreamer.
A magician or conjurer who produces illusions by sleight of hand; a prestidigitator.

entry.ety: See Illude
entry.def: Deceiving by false show; deceitful; deceptive; false; illusory; unreal.
entry.q: Truth from illusive falsehood to command.

entry.def: In a illusive manner; falsely.
The quality of being illusive; deceptiveness; false show.

entry.ety: Cf. F. illusore
entry.def: Deceiving, or tending of deceive; fallacious; illusive; as, illusory promises or hopes.
Capable of illustration.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Illustrated; p. pr. & vb. n. Illustrating
entry.ety: L. illustratus, p. p. of illustrare to illustrate, fr. illustris bright. See Illustrious

sn.def: To make clear, bright, or luminous.
sn.q: Here, when the moon illustrates all the sky.

sn.def: To set in a clear light; to exhibit distinctly or conspicuously.
sn.q: To prove him, and illustrate his high worth.

sn.def: To make clear, intelligible, or apprehensible; to elucidate, explain, or exemplify, as by means of figures, comparisons, and examples.
To adorn with pictures, as a book or a subject; to elucidate with pictures, as a history or a romance.
To give renown or honor to; to make illustrious; to glorify.
sn.q: Matter to me of glory, whom their hateIllustrates.

entry.ety: L. illustratus, p. p
entry.def: Illustrated; distinguished; illustrious.
entry.q: This most gallant, illustrate, and learned gentleman.

entry.def: provided with pictures; -- of a publication; as, an illustrated weekly. Opposite of unillustrated.

entry.ety: L. illustratio: cf. F. illustration

sn.def: The act of illustrating; the act of making clear and distinct; education; also, the state of being illustrated, or of being made clear and distinct.
That which illustrates; a comparison or example intended to make clear or apprehensible, or to remove obscurity.
A picture designed to decorate a volume or elucidate a literary work.
Tending or designed to illustrate, exemplify, or elucidate.
Making illustrious.

entry.def: By way of illustration or elucidation.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who illustrates.
Serving to illustrate.

entry.ety: L. illustris, prob. for illuxtris; fr. il- in + the root of lucidus bright: cf. F. illustre. See Lucid

sn.def: Possessing luster or brightness; brilliant; luminous; splendid.
sn.q: Quench the light; thine eyes are guides illustrious.

sn.def: Characterized by greatness, nobleness, etc.; eminent; conspicuous; distinguished.
sn.q: Illustrious earls, renowened everywhere.

sn.def: Conferring luster or honor; renowned; as, illustrious deeds or titles.
sn.syn: Distinguished; famous; remarkable; brilliant; conspicuous; noted; celebrated; signal; renowened; eminent; exalted; noble; glorious. See Distinguished Famous.

entry.def: In a illustrious manner; conspicuously; eminently; famously.
The state or quality of being eminent; greatness; grandeur; glory; fame.

entry.ety: Pref. il- not + lustrous
entry.def: Without luster.

entry.ety: Pref. il- in + L. lutum mud: cf. F. illutation
entry.def: The act or operation of smearing the body with mud, especially with the sediment from mineral springs; a mud bath.
Not luxurious.

entries.entry: Ill`-will". See under Ill a.

entry.def: One who wishes ill to another; an enemy.

entry.ety: A word not fully approved, but sometimes used for the adverb ill
So called from Ilmen, a branch of the Ural Mountains
entry.def: Titanic iron. See Menaccanite.

entry.ety: NL. See Ilmenite
entry.def: A supposed element claimed to have been discovered by R.Harmann.

entry.ety: From L. Ilva, the island now called Elba
entry.def: A silicate of iron and lime occurring in black prismatic crystals and columnar masses.

entries.entry: I'm. A contraction of I am.
Im-. A form of the prefix in- not, and in- in. See In-. Im- also occurs in composition with some words not of Latin origin; as, imbank, imbitter.

entry.cs:
Electrical image. See under Electrical. Image breaker one who destroys images; an iconoclast.
Image graver Image maker
a sculptor. Image worship the worship of images as symbols; iconolatry distinguished from idolatry; the worship of images themselves. Image Purkinje Physics the image of the retinal blood vessels projected in, not merely on, that membrane. Virtual image Optics a point or system of points, on one side of a mirror or lens, which, if it existed, would emit the system of rays which actually exists on the other side of the mirror or lens. Clerk Maxwell.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. imago imaginis, from the root of imitari to imitate. See Imitate, and cf. Imagine

sn.def: An imitation, representation, or similitude of any person, thing, or act, sculptured, drawn, painted, or otherwise made perceptible to the sight; a visible presentation; a copy; a likeness; an effigy; a picture; a semblance.
sn.q: Even like a stony image, cold and numb.
Whose is this image and superscription?
This play is the image of a murder done in Vienna.
And God created man in his own image.

sn.def: Hence: The likeness of anything to which worship is paid; an idol.
sn.q: Thou shalt not make unto thee any graven image, . . . thou shalt not bow down thyself to them.

sn.def: Show; appearance; cast.
sn.q: The face of things a frightful image bears.

sn.def: A representation of anything to the mind; a picture drawn by the fancy; a conception; an idea.
sn.q: Can we conceiveImage of aught delightful, soft, or great?

sn.def: A picture, example, or illustration, often taken from sensible objects, and used to illustrate a subject; usually, an extended metaphor.

The figure or picture of any object formed at the focus of a lens or mirror, by rays of light from the several points of the object symmetrically refracted or reflected to corresponding points in such focus; this may be received on a screen, a photographic plate, or the retina of the eye, and viewed directly by the eye, or with an eyeglass, as in the telescope and microscope; the likeness of an object formed by reflection; as, to see one's image in a mirror.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Imaged ĭm"�jd; 48; p. pr. & vb. n. Imaging

sn.def: To represent or form an image of; as, the still lake imaged the shore; the mirror imaged her figure.
sn.q: Shrines ofimagedsaints.

sn.def: To represent to the mental vision; to form a likeness of by the fancy or recollection; to imagine.
sn.q: Condemn'd whole years in absence to deplore, And image charms he must behold no more.

entry.def: That may be imaged.
Having no image.
One who images or forms likenesses; a sculptor.
entry.q: Praxiteles was ennobled for a rare imager.

entry.ety: OE. imagerie, F. imagerie

sn.def: The work of one who makes images or visible representation of objects; imitation work; images in general, or in mass.
sn.q: Paintedimagery.
In those oratories might you see Rich carvings, portraitures, and imagery.

sn.def: Fig.: Unreal show; imitation; appearance.
sn.q: What can thy imagery of sorrow mean?

sn.def: The work of the imagination or fancy; false ideas; imaginary phantasms.
sn.q: The imagery of a melancholic fancy.

sn.def: Rhetorical decoration in writing or speaking; vivid descriptions presenting or suggesting images of sensible objects; figures in discourse.
sn.q: I wish there may be in this poem any instance of good imagery.

entry.def: Capacity for imagination.

entry.ety: L. imaginabilis: cf. F. imaginable
entry.def: Capable of being imagined; conceivable.
entry.q: Men sunk into the greatest darkness imaginable.

cs.cd: masses of hypodermic cells, carried by the larvæ of some insects after leaving the egg, from which masses the wings and legs of the adult are subsequently formed.

entry.ety: L. imaginalis

sn.def: Characterized by imagination; imaginative; also, given to the use or rhetorical figures or imagins.
Of or pertaining to an imago.

In a imaginary manner; in imagination.
The state or quality of being imaginary; unreality.

entry.ety: L. imaginarius: cf. F. imaginaire
entry.def: Existing only in imagination or fancy; not real; fancied; visionary; ideal.

entry.syn: Ideal; fanciful; chimerical; visionary; fancied; unreal; illusive.

entry.def: An imaginary expression or quantity.
Imaginative.

entry.usage: Imagination Fancy. These words have, to a great extent, been interchanged by our best writers, and considered as strictly synonymous. A distinction, however, is now made between them which more fully exhibits their nature. Properly speaking, they are different exercises of the same general power -- the plastic or creative faculty. Imagination consists in taking parts of our conceptions and combining them into new forms and images more select, more striking, more delightful, more terrible, etc., than those of ordinary nature. It is the higher exercise of the two. It creates by laws more closely connected with the reason; it has strong emotion as its actuating and formative cause; it aims at results of a definite and weighty character. Milton's fiery lake, the debates of his Pandemonium, the exquisite scenes of his Paradise, are all products of the imagination. Fancy moves on a lighter wing; it is governed by laws of association which are more remote, and sometimes arbitrary or capricious. Hence the term fanciful, which exhibits fancy in its wilder flights. It has for its actuating spirit feelings of a lively, gay, and versatile character; it seeks to please by unexpected combinations of thought, startling contrasts, flashes of brilliant imagery, etc. Pope's Rape of the Lock is an exhibition of fancy which has scarcely its equal in the literature of any country. -- “This, for instance, Wordsworth did in respect of the words ‘imagination' and ‘fancy.' Before he wrote, it was, I suppose, obscurely felt by most that in ‘imagination' there was more of the earnest, in ‘fancy' of the play of the spirit; that the first was a loftier faculty and gift than the second; yet for all this words were continually, and not without loss, confounded. He first, in the preface to his Lyrical Ballads, rendered it henceforth impossible that any one, who had read and mastered what he has written on the two words, should remain unconscious any longer of the important difference between them.” Trench.
entry.ety: OE. imaginacionum, F. imagination, fr. L. imaginatio. See Imagine

sn.def: The imagine-making power of the mind; the power to create or reproduce ideally an object of sense previously perceived; the power to call up mental imagines.
sn.q: Our simple apprehension of corporeal objects, if present, is sense; if absent, is imagination.
Imagination is of three kinds: joined with belief of that which is to come; joined with memory of that which is past; and of things present, or as if they were present.

sn.def: The representative power; the power to reconstruct or recombine the materials furnished by direct apprehension; the complex faculty usually termed the plastic or creative power; the fancy.
sn.q: The imagination of common language -- the productive imagination of philosophers -- is nothing but the representative process plus the process to which I would give the name of the “comparative.”
The power of the mind to decompose its conceptions, and to recombine the elements of them at its pleasure, is called its faculty of imagination.

The business of conception is to present us with an exact transcript of what we have felt or perceived. But we have moreover a power of modifying our conceptions, by combining the parts of different ones together, so as to form new wholes of our creation. I shall employ the word imagination to express this power.

sn.def: The power to recombine the materials furnished by experience or memory, for the accomplishment of an elevated purpose; the power of conceiving and expressing the ideal.
sn.q: The lunatic, the lover, and the poet Are of imagination all compact . . . The poet's eye, in a fine frenzy rolling, Doth glance from heaven to earth, from earth to heaven, And as imagination bodies forth The forms of things unknown, the poet's pen Turns them to shapes, and gives to airy nothing A local habitation and a name.

sn.def: A mental image formed by the action of the imagination as a faculty; a conception; a notion.
sn.syn: Conception; idea; conceit; fancy; device; origination; invention; scheme; design; purpose; contrivance.
sn.q: The same power, which we should call fancy if employed on a production of a light nature, would be dignified with the title of imagination if shown on a grander scale.

entry.def: Pertaining to, involving, or caused by, imagination.
Idealism.

entry.ety: F. imaginatif

sn.def: Proceeding from, and characterized by, the imagination, generally in the highest sense of the word.
sn.q: In all the higher departments of imaginative art, nature still constitutes an important element.

sn.def: Given to imagining; full of images, fancies, etc.; having a quick imagination; conceptive; creative.
sn.q: Milton had a highly imaginative, Cowley a very fanciful mind.

sn.def: Unreasonably suspicious; jealous.

entry.def: the capability of imagining; the power of imagination.

sn.def: To represent to one's self; to think; to believe.

sn.def: To form images or conceptions; to conceive; to devise.
To think; to suppose.

A person with a degree of mental retardation between that of an idiot and a moron; in a former classification of mentally retarded person, it applied to a person with an adult mental age of from four to eith years, and an I.Q. of from 26 to 50.

The quality of being imbecile; weakness; feebleness, esp. of mind. Cruelty . . . argues not only a depravedness of nature, but also a meanness of courage and imbecility of mind. Debility; infirmity; weakness; feebleness; impotence. See Debility.

entry.ety: L. imbricatus, p. p. of imbricare to cover with tiles, to form like a gutter tile, fr. imbrex -icis, a hollow tile, gutter tile, fr. imber rain

Lying over each other in regular order, so as to “break joints,” like tiles or shingles on a roof, the scales on the leaf buds of plants and the cups of some acorns, or the scales of fishes; overlapping each other at the margins, as leaves in æstivation.
In decorative art: Having scales lapping one over the other, or a representation of such scales; as, an imbricated surface; an imbricated pattern.

overlapping or layered as scales or shingles; -- used especially of leaves or bracts.

entry.ety: Imide + isatin

A compound with, or derivative of, the imido group; specif., a compound of one or more acid radicals with the imido group, or with a monamine; hence, also, a derivative of ammonia, in which two atoms of hydrogen have been replaced by divalent basic or acid radicals; -- frequently used as a combining form; as, succinimide .

cs.cd: an organic acid, consisting of one or more acid radicals so united with the imido group that it contains replaceable acid hydrogen, and plays the part of an acid; as, uric acid, succinimide, etc., are imido acids .

entry.def: Pertaining to, containing, or combined with, the radical NH, which is called the imido group.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Imitated; p. pr. & vb. n. Imitating

sn.def: To follow as a pattern, model, or example; to copy or strive to copy, in acts, manners etc.

sn.q: A place picked out by choice of best alive The Nature's work by art can imitate.
This hand appeared a shining sword to weild, And that sustained an imitated shield.

sn.def: To resemble (another species of animal, or a plant, or inanimate object) in form, color, ornamentation, or instinctive habits, so as to derive an advantage thereby; sa, when a harmless snake imitates a venomous one in color and manner, or when an odorless insect imitates, in color, one having secretion offensive to birds.

entry.note: ☞ Imitation is often used adjectively to characterize things which have a deceptive appearance, simulating the qualities of a superior article; -- opposed to real or genuine; as, imitation lace; imitation bronze; imitation modesty, etc.
entry.ety: L. imitatio: cf. F. imitation

sn.def: The act of imitating.

sn.def: That which is made or produced as a copy; that which is made to resemble something else, whether for laudable or for fraudulent purposes; likeness; resemblance.
sn.q: Both these arts are not only true imitations of nature, but of the best nature.

sn.def: One of the principal means of securing unity and consistency in polyphonic composition; the repetition of essentially the same melodic theme, phrase, or motive, on different degrees of pitch, by one or more of the other parts of voises. Cf. Canon.
The act of condition of imitating another species of animal, or a plant, or unanimate object. See Imitate v. t., 3.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or employed in, imitation; as, imitational propensities.

entry.ety: L. imitavitus: cf. F. imitatif

Formed after a model, pattern, or original.
sn.q: This temple, less in form, with equal grace, Was imitative of the first in Thrace.

sn.def: Designed to imitate another species of animal, or a plant, or inanimate object, for some useful purpose, such as protection from enemies; having resemblance to something else; as, imitative colors; imitative habits; dendritic and mammillary forms of minerals are imitative.

entry.def: A verb expressive of imitation or resemblance.

entry.q: Clement] is mainly concerned in enforcing the immanence of God. Christ is everywhere presented by him as Deity indwelling in the world.

entry.q: A cognition is an immanent act of mind.
An immanent power in the life of the world.

entry.def: Not manifest.

Unfadingly.
Not having a distinctive margin or border.
Not martial; unwarlike.
To cover, as with a mask; to disguise or conceal.
Matchless; peerless.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + material: cf. F. immatériel

sn.def: Not consisting of matter; incorporeal; spiritual; disembodied.
sn.q: Angels are spirits immaterial and intellectual.

sn.def: Of no substantial consequence; without weight or significance; unimportant; as, it is wholly immaterial whether he does so or not.
sn.syn: Unimportant; inconsequential; insignificant; inconsiderable; trifling.

entry.ety: Cf. F. immatérialisme

sn.def: The doctrine that immaterial substances or spiritual being exist, or are possible.

The doctrine that external bodies may be reduced to mind and ideas in a mind; any doctrine opposed to materialism or phenomenalism, esp. a system that maintains the immateriality of the soul; idealism; esp., Bishop Berkeley's theory of idealism.

entry.ety: Cf. F. immatérialiste
entry.def: One who believes in or professes, immaterialism.

entries.entry: Im`ma*te`ri*al"i*ty n.; pl.Immaterialities #. Cf. F. immatérialité The state or quality of being immaterial or incorporeal; as, the immateriality of the soul.

entry.q: Immateralized spirits.

sn.def: In an immaterial manner; without matter or corporeal substance.

entry.def: The state or quality of being immaterial; immateriality.
Immaterial.

The state or quality of being immature; immaturity.

entry.def: The quality of being immeasurable; immensurability.

entry.q: Eternity and immeasurableness belong to thought alone.

entry.def: In an immeasurable manner or degree.

entry.def: Immeasurable.
Not mechanical.
The relation of freedom from the interventionof a medium; immediateness.

entry.ety: F. immédiat. See In- not, and Mediate

sn.def: Not separated in respect to place by anything intervening; proximate; close; as, immediate contact.
sn.q: You are the most immediate to our throne.

sn.def: Not deferred by an interval of time; present; instant.
sn.q: Assemble weimmediatecouncil.
Death . . . not yet inflicted, as he feared, By some immediate stroke.

sn.def: Acting with nothing interposed or between, or without the intervention of another object as a cause, means, or agency; acting, perceived, or produced, directly; as, an immediate cause.
sn.q: The immediate knowledge of the past is therefore impossible.
sn.syn: Proximate; close; direct; next.

sn.def: In an immediate manner; without intervention of any other person or thing; proximately; directly; -- opposed to mediately; as, immediately contiguous.
sn.q: God's acceptance of it either immediately by himself, or mediately by the hands of the bishop.

sn.def: Without interval of time; without delay; promptly; instantly; at once.
sn.q: And Jesus . . . touched him, saying, I will; be thou clean. And immediately his leprosy was cleansed.

sn.def: As soon as. Cf. Directly, 8, Note.
sn.syn: Directly; instantly; quickly; forthwith; straightway; presently. See Directly.

entry.def: The quality or relations of being immediate in manner, place, or time; exemption from second or interventing causes.

entry.ety: L. Immedicabilis. See In- not, and Medicable
entry.def: Not to be healed; incurable.
entry.q: Woundsimmedicable.

entry.def: Not melodious.

entry.ety: L. immemorabilis; pref. im- not + memorabilis memorable: cf. F. immémorable. See Memorable
entry.def: Not memorable; not worth remembering.

cs.cd: a time antedating (legal) history, and beyond “legal memory” so called; formerly an indefinite time, but in 1276 this time was fixed by statute as the begining of the reign of Richard I. (1189). Proof of unbroken possession or use of any right since that date made it unnecessary to establish the original grant. In 1832 the plan of dating legal memory from a fixed time was abandoned and the principle substituted that rights which had been enjoyed for full twenty years (or as against the crown thirty years) should not be liable to impeachment merely by proving that they had not been enjoyed before.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + memorial: cf. F. immémorial
entry.def: Extending beyond the reach of memory, record, or tradition; indefinitely ancient; as, existing from time immemorial .
entry.q: Immemorialelms.
Immemorialusage or custom.

entry.def: Beyond memory.

entry.ety: L. immensus; pref. im- not + mensus, p. p. of metiri to measure: cf. F. immense. See Measure
entry.def: Immeasurable; unlimited. In commonest use: Very great; vast; huge.
entry.q: Immensethe power
Immenseand boundless ocean.
O Goodness infinite! Goodness immense!
entry.syn: Infinite; immeasurable; illimitable; unbounded; unlimited; interminable; vast; prodigious; enormous; monstrous. See Enormous.

entry.def: In immense manner or degree.
The state of being immense.

entry.ety: Immense + -ible
entry.def: Immeasurable.

entries.entry:
Im*men"si*ty n.; pl.Immensities #. L. immensitas: cf. F. immensité
The state or quality of being immense; inlimited or immeasurable extension; infinity; vastness in extent or bulk; greatness. Lost in the wilds of vast immensity. The immensity of the material system.

entry.def: Huge.
The quality of being immensurable.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + L. mensurabilis measurable: cf. F. immensurable. Cf. Immeasurable
entry.def: Immeasurable.
entry.q: What an immensurable space is the firmament.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + mensurate
entry.def: Unmeasured; unlimited.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Immerged; p. pr. & vb. n. Immerging
entry.ety: L. immergere; pref. im- in + mergere to dip, plunge: cf. F. immerger. See Merge, and cf. Immerse
entry.def: To plungel into, under, or within anything especially a fuid; to dip; to immerse. See Immerse.
entry.q: We took . . . lukewarm water, and in it immerged a quantity of the leaves of senna.
Their souls are immerged in matter.

entry.def: To dissapear by entering into any medium, as a star into the light of the sun.
Lack of worth; demerit.
Unmerited.

entry.ety: L. immeritus; pref. im- not + meritus, p. p. of merere mereri, to deserve
entry.def: Undeserving.
See Immersible.

entry.ety: L. immersus, p. p. of immergere. See Immerge
entry.def: Immersed; buried; hid; sunk.
entry.q: Thingsimmersein matter.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Immersed; p. pr. & vb. n. Immersing

sn.def: To plunge into anything that surrounds or covers, especially into a fluid; to dip; to sink; to bury; to immerge.
sn.q: Deep immersed beneath its whirling wave.
More than a mile immersed within the wood.

sn.def: To baptize by immersion.
To engage deeply; to engross the attention of; to involve; to overhelm.
sn.q: The queen immersed in such a trance.
It is impossible to have a lively hope in another life, and yet be deeply immersed inn the enjoyments of this.

sn.def: Deeply plunged into anything, especially a fluid.
Deeply occupied; engrossed; entangled.
Growing wholly under water.

entry.ety: From Immerse
entry.def: Capable of being immersed.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + L. mersus, p. p. of mergere to plunge
entry.def: Not capable of being immersed.

cs.cd: a microscopic objective of short focal distance designed to work with a drop of liquid, as oil, between the front lens and the slide, so that this lens is practically immersed.

entry.ety: L. immersio; cf. F. immersion

sn.def: The act of immersing, or the state of being immersed; a sinking within a fluid; a dipping; as, the immersion of Achilles in the Styx.
Submersion in water for the purpose of Christian baptism, as, practiced by the Baptists.
The state of being overhelmed or deeply absorbed; deep engagedness.
sn.q: Too deep an immersion in the affairs of life.

sn.def: The dissapearance of a celestail body, by passing either behind another, as in the occultation of a star, or into its shadow, as in the eclipse of a satellite; -- opposed to emersion.

entry.def: One who holds the doctrine that immersion is essential to Christian baptism.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Immeshed; p. pr. & vb. n. Immeshing
entry.ety: Pref. im- in + mesh. Cf. Inmesh
entry.def: To catch or entangle in, or as in, the meshes of a net. or in a web; to insnare.
Not methodical; without method or systematic arrangement; without order or regularity; confused.
Without method; confusedly; unsystematically.
Lack of method.
To render immethodical; to destroy the method of; to confuse.
Not metrical or rhythmical.
See Emmew.

entry.ety: L. immigrans, p. pr. of immigrare to go into: cf. F. immigrant. See Immigrate
entry.def: One who immigrates; one who comes to a country for the purpose of permanent residence; -- correlative of emigrant.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Immigrated; p. pr. & vb. n. Immigrating
entry.ety: L. immigrare immigratum, to immigrate; pref. im- in + migrare to migrate. See Migrate
entry.def: To come into a country of which one is not a native, for the purpose of permanent residence. See Emigrate.

entry.ety: Cf. F. immigration
entry.def: The act of immigrating; the passing or coming into a country for the purpose of permanent residence.
entry.q: The immigrations of the Arabians into Europe.

entry.ety: Cf. F. imminence, L. imminentia, See Imminent

sn.def: The condition or quality of being imminent; a threatening, as of something about to happen. The imminence of any danger or distress.
That which is imminent; impending evil or danger.
sn.q: But dare allimminence.

entry.def: the state of being imminent and liable to happen soon; imminence.

entry.usage: Imminent Impending Threatening. Imminent is the strongest: it denotes that something is ready to fall or happen on the instant; as, in imminent danger of one's life. Impending denotes that something hangs suspended over us, and may so remain indefinitely; as, the impending evils of war. Threatening supposes some danger in prospect, but more remote; as, threatening indications for the future.
entry.ety: L. imminens, p. pr. of imminere to project; pref. im- in + minerein comp.) to jut, project. See Eminent

sn.def: Threatening to occur immediately; near at hand; impending; -- said especially of misfortune or peril.
sn.q: In dangerimminent.

sn.def: Full of danger; threatening; menacing; perilous.
sn.q: Hairbreadth scapes i' the imminent deadly breach.

sn.def: With upon) Bent upon; attentive to.
sn.q: Their eyes ever imminent upon worldly matters.
sn.syn: Impending; threatening; near; at hand.
sn.q: Three times to-day You have defended me from imminent death.
No story I unfold of public woes, Nor bear advices of impending foes.
Fierce faces threatening war.

entry.def: In an imminent manner.
To mingle; to mix; to unite; to blend.

entry.ety: L. imminutio, fr. imminuere imminutum, to lessen; pref. im- in + minuere
entry.def: A lessening; diminution; decrease.

entry.ety: Cf. F. immiscibilité
entry.def: Incapability of being mixed, or mingled.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + miscible: cf. F. immiscible

sn.def: Not capable of being mixed or mingled.
sn.q: A chaos of immiscible and conflicting particles.

sn.def: Not miscible; forming two distinct phases when mixed at some concentration; -- of two liquids; as, water and gasoline are immiscible .

entry.ety: L. immissio: cf. F. immission. See Immit
entry.def: The act of immitting, or of sending or thrusting in; injection; -- the correlative of emission.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Immitted; p. pr. & vb. n. Immiting
entry.ety: L. immittere immissum; pref. im- in + mittere to send
entry.def: To send in; to inject; to infuse; -- the correlative of emit.

entry.ety: L. immitigabilis; fr. pref. im- not + mitigare to mitigate
entry.def: Not capable of being mitigated, softened, or appeased.
In an immitigable manner.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + mix
entry.def: To mix; to mingle.
entry.q: Amongst her tears immixing prayers meek.

entry.def: Not mixable.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + mixed, p. p. of mix
entry.def: Unmixed.
entry.q: How pure and immixed the design is.

entry.def: Freedom from mixture; purity.

entry.ety: L. immobilis: cf. F. immobile. See Immobility
entry.def: Incapable of being moved; immovable; fixed; stable.
The act or process of limiting movement or making incapable of movement; as, immobilization of the injured knee was necessary; the storm caused complete immobilization of the rescue team.

entry.ety: L. immobilitas, fr. immobilis immovable; pref. im- not + mobilis movable: cf. F. immobilité. See Mobile
entry.def: The condition or quality of being immobile; fixedness in place or state.

entry.ety: Pref. im- in + mobilize; cf. f. immobiliser
entry.def: To make immovable; in surgery, to make immovable (a naturally mobile part, as a joint) by the use of splints, or stiffened bandages.
See Immobile.

entry.ety: From Immoderate
entry.def: Immoderateness.

entry.ety: L. immoderantia
entry.def: Immoderateness; excess.

entry.ety: L. immoderatus; pref. im- not + moderatus moderate. See Moderate
entry.def: Not moderate; exceeding just or usual and suitable bounds; excessive; extravagant; unreasonable; as, immoderate demands; immoderate grief; immoderate laughter.
entry.q: So every scope by the immoderate use Turns to restraint.
entry.syn: Excessive; exorbitant; unreasonable; extravagant; intemperate; inordinate.

entry.def: In an immoderate manner; excessively.
The quality of being immoderate; excess; extravagance.

entry.ety: L. immoderatio: cf. F. imodération
entry.def: Lack of moderation.

entry.ety: F. immodeste, L. immodestus immoderate; pref. im- not + modestus modest. See Modest

sn.def: Not limited to due bounds; immoderate.
Not modest; wanting in the reserve or restraint which decorum and decency require; indecent; indelicate; obscene; lewd; as, immodest persons, behavior, words, pictures, etc.
sn.q: Immodest deeds you hinder to be wrought, But we proscribe the least immodest thought.
sn.syn: Indecorous; indelicate; shameless; shameful; impudent; indecent; impure; unchaste; lewd; obscene.

entry.def: In an immodest manner.

entry.ety: L. immodestia: cf. F. immodestie
entry.def: Lack of modesty, delicacy, or decent reserve; indecency.
entry.q: A piece ofimmodesty.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Immolated; p. pr. & vb. n. Immolating
entry.ety: L. immolatus, p. p. of immolare to sacrifice, orig., to sprinkle a victim with sacrifical meal; pref. im- in + mola grits or grains of spelt coarsely ground and mixed with salt; also, mill. See Molar Meal ground grain

sn.def: To sacrifice; to offer in sacrifice; to kill, as a sacrificial victim.
sn.q: Worshipers, who not only immolate to them [the deities] the lives of men, but . . . the virtue and honor of women.

sn.def: To destroy by fire.

entry.ety: L. immolatio: cf. F. immolation

sn.def: The act of immolating, or the state of being immolated, or sacrificed.
That which is immolated; a sacrifice.
Destruction by fire.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who offers in sacrifice; specifically, one of a sect of Russian fanatics who practice self-mutilation and sacrifice.
To mold into shape, or form.

entry.ety: See Immomentous
entry.def: Trifling.
entry.q: Immomenttoys.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + momentous
entry.def: Not momentous; unimportant; insignificant.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + moral: cf. F. immoral
entry.def: Not moral; inconsistent with rectitude, purity, or good morals; contrary to conscience or the divine law; wicked; unjust; dishonest; vicious; licentious; as, an immoral man; an immoral deed.
entry.syn: Wicked; sinful; criminal; vicious; unjust; dishonest; depraved; impure; unchaste; profligate; dissolute; abandoned; licentious; lewd; obscene.

entries.entry:
Im`mo*ral"i*ty n.; pl.Immoralities #. Cf. F. immoralité
The state or quality of being immoral; vice. The root of all immorality.
An immoral act or practice. Luxury and sloth and then a great drove of heresies and immoralities broke loose among them.

entry.def: In an immoral manner; wickedly.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + morigerous
entry.def: Rude; uncivil; disobedient.

cs.cd: immortelles; everlastings.

entry.ety: L. immortalis; pref. im- not + mortalis mortal: cf. F. immortel. See Mortal, and cf. Immortelle

sn.def: Not mortal; exempt from liability to die; undying; imperishable; lasting forever; having unlimited, or eternal, existance.
sn.q: Unto the King eternal, immortal, invisible.
For my soul, what can it do to that, Being a thing immortal as itself?

sn.def: Connected with, or pertaining to immortality.
sn.q: I have immortal longings in me.

sn.def: Destined to live in all ages of this world; abiding; exempt from oblivion; imperishable; as, immortal fame.
sn.q: One of the few, immortal names, That were not born to die.

sn.def: Great; excessive; grievous.
sn.syn: Eternal; everlasting; never-ending; ceaseless; perpetual; continual; enduring; endless; imperishable; incorruptible; deathless; undying.

entry.def: One who will never cease to be; one exempt from death, decay, or annihilation.
One who holds the doctrine of the immortality of the soul.

entries.entry:
Im`mor*tal"i*ty n.; pl.Immortalities #. L. immortalitas: cf. F. immortalité
The quality or state of being immortal; exemption from death and annihilation; unending existance; as, the immortality of the soul. This mortal must put on immortality.
Exemption from oblivion; perpetuity; as, the immortality of fame.

entry.def: The act of immortalizing, or state of being immortalized.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Immortalized; p. pr. & vb. n. Immortalizing
entry.ety: Cf. F. immortaliser

sn.def: To render immortal; to cause to live or exist forever.
To exempt from oblivion; to perpetuate in fame.
sn.q: Alexander had no Homer to immortalize his guilty name.

entry.def: To become immortal.
In an immortal manner.

entries.entry:
Im`mor*telle" n.; pl.Immortelles #. F. See Immortal
Bot A plant with a conspicuous, dry, unwithering involucre, as the species of Antennaria Helichrysum Gomphrena, etc. See Everlasting.

entry.def: Failure to mortify the passions.
The quality or state of being immovable; fixedness; steadfastness; as, immovability of a heavy body; immovability of purpose.

cs.cd: an appliance, like the plaster of paris bandage, which keeps fractured parts firmly in place.
feasts which occur on a certain day of the year and do not depend on the date of Easter; as, Christmas, the Epiphany, etc.

sn.def: Incapable of being moved; firmly fixed; fast; -- used of material things; as, an immovable foundation.
sn.q: Immovable, infixed, and frozen round.

sn.def: Steadfast; fixed; unalterable; unchangeable; -- used of the mind or will; as, an immovable purpose, or a man who remains immovable .
Not capable of being affected or moved in feeling or by sympathy; unimpressible; impassive.
Not liable to be removed; permanent in place or tenure; fixed; as, an immovable estate. See Immovable n.
That which can not be moved.

Lands and things adherent thereto by nature, as trees; by the hand of man, as buildings and their accessories; by their destination, as seeds, plants, manure, etc.; or by the objects to which they are applied, as servitudes.

entry.def: Quality of being immovable.
In an immovable manner.

entry.ety: L. immundus; pref. im- not + mundus clean
entry.def: Unclean.

entry.ety: Cf. F. immondicité, L. immunditia immundities
entry.def: Uncleanness; filthiness.

entry.ety: L. immunis. See Immunity

sn.def: Exempt; protected.
Protected from disease due to the action of the immune system, especially by having been inoculated against or previously exposed to a disease.
Of or pertaining to the immune system or the components of the immune system.
Not responsive; as, immune to suggestion.

entry.def: One who is immune; esp., a person who is immune from a disease by reason of previous affection with the disease or inoculation.

The complex of cells, cellular processes, and substances within and diffused throughout an organism which allow the organism to counteract or destroy noxious foreign substances introduced into the body, destroy infectious agents such as bacteria and viruses, destroy malignant cells, and remove cellular debris, thus protecting the organism against many of the potentially harmful external agents and internal events that could lead to sickness or death. The system has numerous interacting components, including circulating antibodies, antibody-producing cells, white blood cells and lymphokines, lymph tissue and lymph nodes, and stem cells which may differentiate into other types of cell, together with the thymus and spleen. The system is responsible for the phenomenon of immunity{3}. See also immunoglobulin and antibody.
Same as immunization.

entries.entry:
Im*mu"ni*ty n.; pl.Immunities #. L. immunitas, fr. immunis free from a public service; pref. im- not + munis complaisant, obliging, cf. munus service, duty: cf. F. immunité. See Common, and cf. Mean a.
Freedom or exemption from any charge, duty, obligation, office, tax, imposition, penalty, or service; a particular privilege; as, the immunities of the free cities of Germany; the immunities of the clergy.
Freedom; exemption; as, immunity from error.
The state of being insusceptible to disease, certain poisons, etc.

entry.def: the act of making immune (especially by inoculation).

sn.def: rendered less susceptible (to disease) by treatment with a vaccine.
sn.syn: vaccinated.

sn.def: rendered insusceptible.

entry.def: electrophoresis to separate antigens and antibodies.
any substance that produces immunity when introduced into the body.

entry.note: The immunoglobulins form a series of related proteins which are each composed of two pairs of polypeptide chains, called heavy (H) and light (L, meaning of lower molecular weight), all linked together by disulfide bonds. They are subdivided on the basis of the structural and antigenic properties of the H chains into four subgroups, immunoglobulin GIgG), immunoglobulin AIgA), immunoglobulin MIgM), and immunoglobulin DIgD). They are divided also into subclasses. Both H and L chains of anny given class and subclass have regions which are of constant structure within that class, as well as regions which are of variable structure. The variable regions impart the ability to recognize and bind to specific molecular structures, thus providing the organism the capacity to recognize and defend itself against the harmful effects of substances foreign to the body.
entry.def: any one of a class of globular proteins which are antibodies and are produced by the immune system in animals.
Of or pertaining to immunology.
The science which studies the immune system, the processes of immunity, and the nature of the immune response, and techniques of analysis which use the immune response.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Immured; p. pr. & vb. n. Immuring
entry.ety: Pref. im- in + mure: cf. F. emmurer

sn.def: To wall around; to surround with walls.
To inclose whithin walls, or as within walls; hence, to shut up; to imprison; to incarcerate.
sn.q: Those tender babes Whom envy hath immured within your walls.
This huge convex of fire, Outrageous to devour, immures us round.

entry.def: A wall; an inclosure.
The act of immuring, or the state of being immured; imprisonment.
Inharmonious; unmusical; discordant.

entry.ety: L. immutabilitas: cf. F. immutabilité
entry.def: The state or quality of being immutable; immutableness.

entry.ety: L. immutabilis; pref. im- not + mutabilis mutable. See Mutable
entry.def: Not mutable; not capable or susceptible of change; unchangeable; unalterable.
entry.q: That by two immutable things, in which it was impossible for God to lie, we might have a strong consolation.
Immutable, immortal, infinite, Eternal King.

entry.ety: L. immutatus, p. p. of immature
entry.def: Unchanged.

entry.ety: L. immutatio, from immutare immutatum, to change. See Immute
entry.def: Change; alteration; mutation.

entry.ety: L. immutare immutatum; perf. im- in + mutare to change : cf. OF. immuter
entry.def: To change or alter.

entry.ety: OE. imp a graft, AS. impa; akin to Dan. ympe, Sw. ymp, prob. fr. LL. impotus, Gr. � engrafted, innate, fr. � to implant; � in + � to produce; akin to E. be. See 1st In- Be

sn.def: A shoot; a scion; a bud; a slip; a graft.
An offspring; progeny; child; scion.
sn.q: The tender imp was weaned.

sn.def: A young or inferior devil; a little, malignant spirit; a puny demon; a contemptible evil worker.
sn.q: To mingle in the clamorous fray Of squabbling imps.

sn.def: Something added to, or united with, another, to lengthen it out or repair it, -- as, an addition to a beehive; a feather inserted in a broken wing of a bird; a length of twisted hair in a fishing line.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Imped; p. pr. & vb. n. Imping
entry.ety: AS. impian to imp, ingraft, plant; akin to Dan. ympe, Sw. ympa, OHG. impfōn impitōn, G. impfen. See Imp n.

sn.def: To graft; to insert as a scion.

entry.sn:
Falconry To graft with new feathers, as a wing; to splice a broken feather. Hence, Fig: To repair; to extend; to increase; to strengthen; to equip. Archaic
Imp out our drooping country's broken wing. Who lazily imp their wings with other men's plumes. Here no frail Muse shall imp her crippled wing. Help, ye tart satirists, to imp my rage With all the scorpions that should whip this age.

entry.ety: L. pref. im- not + pacare to quiet. See Pacate
entry.def: Not to be appeased or quieted.

entry.ety: Pref. im- in + pack
entry.def: The state of being closely surrounded, crowded, or pressed, as by ice.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impacted; p. pr. & vb. n. Impacting
entry.ety: L. impactus, p. p. of impingere to push, strike against. See Impinge

sn.def: To drive close; to press firmly together: to wedge into a place.
To affect or influence, especially in a significant or undesirable manner; as, budget cuts impacted the entire research program; the fish populations were adversely impacted by pollution.
To collide forcefully with; to strike.
Contact or impression by touch; collision; forcible contact; force communicated.
sn.q: The quarrel, by that impact driven.

sn.def: The single instantaneous stroke of a body in motion against another either in motion or at rest.

cs.cd: a fracture in which the fragments are driven into each other so as to be immovable.

sn.def: Driven together or close.
Grown in an abnormal direction so that it is wedged against another tooth and cannot erupt normally; -- of teeth, especially the third molar; as, to extract an impacted third molar.

entry.ety: L. impactio a striking : cf. F. impaction

sn.def: The driving of one fragment of bone into another so that the fragments are not movable upon each other; as, impaction of the skull or of the hip.

An immovable packing; Med, a lodgment of something in a strait or passage of the body; as, impaction of the fetal head in the strait of the pelvis; impaction of food or feces in the intestines of man or beast.

entry.def: To paint; to adorn with colors.
entry.q: Toimpainthis cause.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impaired; p. pr. & vb. n. Impairing
entry.ety: OE. empeiren enpeiren, OF. empeirier empirier, F. empirer, LL. impejorare; L. pref. im- in + pejorare to make worse, fr. pejor worse. Cf. Appair
entry.def: To make worse; to diminish in quantity, value, excellence, or strength; to deteriorate; as, to impair health, character, the mind, value.
entry.q: Time sensibly all things impairs.
In years he seemed, but not impaired by years.
entry.syn: To diminish; decrease; injure; weaken; enfeeble; debilitate; reduce; debase; deteriorate.

entry.def: To grow worse; to deteriorate.

entry.ety: F. impair uneven, L. impar; im- not + par equal
entry.def: Not fit or appropriate.
Diminution; injury.
One who, or that which, impairs.

entry.ety: OE. enpeirement, OF. empirement
entry.def: The state, act, or process of being impaired; injury.
entry.q: Theimpairmentof my health.

entry.def: An antelope (Aepyceros melampus) of Southeastern Africa, the male of which has ringed lyre-shaped horns, which curve first backward, then sideways, then upwards. ALso called impalla and pallah.
Unpalatable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impaled; p. pr. & vb. n. Impaling
entry.ety: See 2d Empale

sn.def: To pierce with a pale; to put to death by fixing on a sharp stake. See Empale.
sn.q: Then with what life remains, impaled, and left To writhe at leisure round the bloody stake.

sn.def: To inclose, as with pales or stakes; to surround.
sn.q: Impale him with your weapons round about.
Impenetrable, impaled with circling fire.

sn.def: To join, as two coats of arms on one shield, palewise; hence, to join in honorable mention.
sn.q: Ordered the admission of St. Patrick to the same to be matched and impaled with the blessed Virgin in the honor thereof.

sn.def: The act of impaling, or the state of being impaled.
An inclosing by stakes or pales, or the space so inclosed.
That which hedges in; inclosure.
The division of a shield palewise, or by a vertical line, esp. for the purpose of putting side by side the arms of husband and wife. See Impale, 3.

entry.def: Same as Impala.
To make pallid; to blanch.
To grasp with or hold in the hand.

entry.ety: Cf. F. impalpabilité
entry.def: The quality of being impalpable.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + palpable: cf. F. impalpable

sn.def: Not palpable; that cannot be felt; extremely fine, so that no grit can be perceived by touch.
sn.q: Impalpablepowder.

sn.def: Not material; intangible; incorporeal.
sn.q: Impalpable, void, and bodiless.

sn.def: Not apprehensible, or readily apprehensible, by the mind; unreal; as, impalpable distinctions.

entry.def: In an impalpable manner.
To palsy; to paralyze; to deaden.

entry.ety: LL. impanatus, p. p. of impanare to impanate; L. pref. im- in + panis bread
entry.def: Embodied in bread, esp. in the bread of the eucharist.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impanated; p. pr. & vb. n. Impanating
entry.def: To embody in bread, esp. in the bread of the eucharist.

entry.ety: Cf. F. impanation. See Impanate a.
entry.def: Embodiment in bread; the supposed real presence and union of Christ's material body and blood with the substance of the elements of the eucharist without a change in their nature; -- distinguished from transubstantiation, which supposes a miraculous change of the substance of the elements. It is akin to consubstantiation.

entry.ety: LL
entry.def: One who holds the doctrine of impanation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impaneled or Impanelled; p. pr. & vb. n. Impaneling or Impanelling
entry.ety: Pref. im- in + panel. Cf. Empanel
entry.def: To enter in a list, or on a piece of parchment, called a panel; to form or enroll, as a list of jurors in a court of justice.
The act or process of impaneling, or the state of being impaneled.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Imparadised; p. pr. & vb. n. Imparadising
entry.ety: Pref. im- + paradise: cf. F. emparadiser
entry.def: To put in a state like paradise; to make supremely happy.
entry.q: Imparadisedin one another's arms.

entry.def: Unparalleled.

entry.ety: Cf. F. impardonnable
entry.def: Unpardonable.

entry.ety: L. impar unequal + digitus finger
entry.def: Having an odd number of fingers or toes, either one, three, or five, as in the horse, tapir, rhinoceros, etc.

entry.ety: L. impar unequal + E. pinnate
entry.def: Pinnate with a single terminal leaflet.

entry.ety: L. impar unequal + E. syllabic: cf. F. imparisyllabique
entry.def: Not consisting of an equal number of syllables; as, an imparisyllabic noun, one which has not the same number of syllables in all the cases; as, lapis lapidis; mens mentis.

entry.ety: Pref. im- + parity: cf. F. imparité

sn.def: Inequality; disparity; disproportion; difference of degree, rank, excellence, number, etc.
Lack of comparison, correspondence, or suitableness; incongruity.
sn.q: In this region of merely intellectual notion we are at once encountered by the imparity of the object and the faculty employed upon it.

sn.def: Indivisibility into equal parts; oddness.

entry.ety: Cf. Empark
entry.def: To inclose for a park; to sever from a common; hence, to inclose or shut up.
entry.q: They . . . impark them [the sheep] within hurdles.

entry.ety: OF. emparler; pref. em-L. in) + parler to speak. See In, prep., and Parley

sn.def: To hold discourse; to parley.
To have time before pleading; to have delay for mutual adjustment.

entry.note: ☞ Imparlance and continuance by imparlance have been abolished in England.
entry.ety: Cf. Emparlance Parlance

sn.def: Mutual discourse; conference.

sd.def: Time given to a party to talk or converse with his opponent, originally with the object of effecting, if possible, an amicable adjustment of the suit. The actual object, however, has long been merely to obtain further time to plead, or answer to the allegations of the opposite party.
Hence, the delay or continuance of a suit.

entry.ety: OF. empersone. See 1st In-, and Parson
entry.def: Presented, instituted, and inducted into a rectory, and in full possession.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Imparted; p. pr. & vb. n. Imparting
entry.ety: OF. impartir empartir, L. impartire impertire; pref. im- in + partire to part, divide, fr. pars partis, part, share. See Part n.

sn.def: To bestow a share or portion of; to give, grant, or communicate; to allow another to partake in; as, to impart food to the poor; the sun imparts warmth.
sn.q: Well may he then to you his cares impart.

sn.def: To obtain a share of; to partake of.
To communicate the knowledge of; to make known; to show by words or tokens; to tell; to disclose.
sn.q: Gentle lady, When I did first impart my love to you.
sn.syn: To share; yield; confer; convey; grant; give; reveal; disclose; discover; divulge. See Communicate.

sn.def: To give a part or share.
sn.q: He that hath two coats, let him impart to him that hath none.

sn.def: To hold a conference or consultation.

entry.def: Impartation.
The act of imparting, or the thing imparted.
entry.q: The necessity of this impartation.

entry.def: One who imparts.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + partial: cf. F. impartial
entry.def: Not partial; not favoring one more than another; treating all alike; unprejudiced; unbiased; disinterested; equitable; fair; just.
entry.q: Jove is impartial, and to both the same.
A comprehensive and impartial view.

entry.def: One who is impartial.

entry.ety: Cf. F. impartialité
entry.def: The quality of being impartial; freedom from bias or favoritism; disinterestedness; equitableness; fairness; as, impartiality of judgment, of treatment, etc.
entry.q: Impartiality strips the mind of prejudice and passion.

entry.def: In an impartial manner.
Impartiality.
The quality of being impartible; communicability.

entry.ety: Cf. F. impartibilité
entry.def: The quality of being incapable of division into parts; indivisibility.

entry.ety: From Impart
entry.def: Capable of being imparted or communicated.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + partible: cf. F. impartible
entry.def: Not partible; not subject to partition; indivisible; as, an impartible estate.
The act of imparting, or that which is imparted, communicated, or disclosed.
entry.q: It beckons you to go away with it, As if it some impartment did desire To you alone.

entry.ety: Cf. Unpassable
entry.def: Incapable of being passed; not admitting a passage; as, an impassable road, mountain, or gulf.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: An impassable road or way; a blind alley; cul-de-sac; fig., a position or predicament affording no escape.
entry.q: The issue from the present impasse will, in all probability, proceed from below, not from above.

entry.ety: L. impassibilitas: cf. F. impassibilité
entry.def: The quality or condition of being impassible; insusceptibility of injury from external things.

entry.ety: L. impassibilis; pref. im- not + passibilis passable: cf. F. impassible. See Passible
entry.def: Incapable of suffering; inaccessible to harm or pain; not to be touched or moved to passion or sympathy; unfeeling, or not showing feeling; without sensation.
entry.q: Impassibleto the critic.
Secure of death, I should contemn thy dart Though naked, and impassible depart.

entry.def: Impassibility.

entry.ety: Pref. im- in + passion. Cf. Empassion Impassionate v.
entry.def: To move or affect strongly with passion.
Excitable; susceptible of strong emotion.
Strongly affected.
To affect powerfully; to arouse the passions of.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + passionate
entry.def: Without passion or feeling.
Actuated or characterized by passion or zeal; showing warmth of feeling; ardent; animated; excited; as, an impassioned orator or discourse.
Not susceptible of pain or suffering; apathetic; impassible; unmoved.
entry.q: Impassive as the marble in the quarry.
On the impassive ice the lightings play.

entry.def: an absence of emotion.
The quality of being insusceptible of feeling, pain, or suffering; impassiveness.

entry.ety: F. See Impaste
entry.def: The act of making into paste; that which is formed into a paste or mixture; specifically, a combination of different substances by means of cements.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impasted; p. pr. & vb. n. Impasting
entry.ety: Pref. im- in + paste: cf. It. impastare, OF. empaster, F. empâter. See 1st In- and Paste

sn.def: To knead; to make into paste; to concrete.
sn.q: Blood . . . baked andimpasted.

sn.def: To lay color on canvas by uniting them skillfully together. Cf. Impasto.

entry.def: The laying on of colors to produce impasto.

entry.ety: It. See Impaste
entry.def: The thickness of the layer or body of pigment applied by the painter to his canvas with especial reference to the juxtaposition of different colors and tints in forming a harmonious whole.
To place in a pasture; to foster.

entry.ety: L. impatibilis; pref. im- not + patibilis supportable. See Patible

sn.def: Not capable of being borne; impassible.
sn.q: A spirit, and so impatible of material fire.

entry.ety: OE. impacience, F. impatience, fr. L. impatientia
entry.def: The quality of being impatient; lack of endurance of pain, suffering, opposition, or delay; eagerness for change, or for something expected; restlessness; chafing of spirit; fretfulness; passion; as, the impatience of a child or an invalid.
entry.q: I then, . . . Out of my grief and my impatience, Answered neglectingly.
With huge impatience he inly swelt More for great sorrow that he could not pass, Than for the burning torment which he felt.

entry.def: Impatience.

entry.ety: L., impatient
entry.def: A genus of plants, several species of which have very beautiful flowers; -- so called because the elastic capsules burst when touched, and scatter the seeds with considerable force. Called also touch-me-not jewelweed, and snapweed. Impatiens Balsaminasometimes called lady's slipper) is the common garden balsam.

entry.ety: OE. impacient, F. impatient, fr. L. impatiens; pref. im- not + patiens patient. See Patient

sn.def: Not patient; not bearing with composure; intolerant; uneasy; fretful; restless, because of pain, delay, or opposition; eager for change, or for something expected; hasty; passionate; -- often followed by at for of, and under.
sn.q: A violent, sudden, and impatient necessity.
Fame, impatient of extremes, decays Not more by envy than excess of praise.
The impatient man will not give himself time to be informed of the matter that lies before him.
Dryden was poor and impatient of poverty.

sn.def: Not to be borne; unendurable.
Prompted by, or exhibiting, impatience; as, impatient speeches or replies.
sn.syn: Restless; uneasy; changeable; hot; eager; fretful; intolerant; passionate.

entry.def: One who is impatient.
In an impatient manner.
Absolute seignory or possession; the act of investing with such possession.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impatronized; p. pr. & vb. n. Impatronizing
entry.def: To make lord or master; as, to impatronize one's self of a seigniory.
To pave.
entry.q: Impaved with rude fidelity Of art mosaic.

entry.ety: L. impavidus. See In- not, and Pavid
entry.def: Fearless.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impawned; p. pr. & vb. n. Impawning
entry.ety: Pref. im- + pawn: cf. Empawn
entry.def: To put in pawn; to pledge; to pawn.

entry.note: ☞ When used in law with reference to a witness, the term signifies, to discredit, to show or prove unreliable or unworthy of belief; when used in reference to the credit of witness, the term denotes, to impair, to lessen, to disparage, to destroy. The credit of a witness may be impeached by showing that he has made statements out of court contradictory to what he swears at the trial, or by showing that his reputation for veracity is bad, etc.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impeached; p. pr. & vb. n. Impeaching
entry.ety: OE. empeechier to prevent, hinder, bar, F. empêcher, L. impedicare to entangle; pref. im- in + pedica fetter, fr. pes pedis, foot. See Foot, and Appeach Dispatch Impede

sn.def: To hinder; to impede; to prevent.
sn.q: These ungracious practices of his sons did impeach his journey to the Holy Land.
A defluxion on my throat impeached my utterance.

sn.def: To charge with a crime or misdemeanor; to accuse; especially to charge (a public officer), before a competent tribunal, with misbehavior in office; to cite before a tribunal for judgment of official misconduct; to arraign; as, to impeach a judge. See Impeachment.
Hence, to charge with impropriety; to dishonor; to bring discredit on; to call in question; as, to impeach one's motives or conduct.
sn.q: And doth impeach the freedom of the state.

sn.def: To challenge or discredit the credibility of, as of a witness, or the validity of, as of commercial paper.
sn.syn: To accuse; arraign; censure; criminate; indict; impair; disparage; discredit. See Accuse.

entry.def: Hindrance; impeachment.
That may be impeached; liable to impeachment; chargeable with a crime.
entry.q: Owners of lands in fee simple are not impeachable for waste.

entry.def: One who impeaches.

entries.entry:
Im*peach"ment ☞ In England, it is the privilege or right of the House of Commons to impeach, and the right of the House of Lords to try and determine impeachments. In the United States, it is the right of the House of Representatives to impeach, and of the Senate to try and determine impeachments.
Articles of impeachment. See under Article. Impeachment of waste Law restraint from, or accountability for, injury; also, a suit for damages for injury. Abbott.
n. Cf. F. empêchement
The act of impeaching, or the state of being impeached; as: Hindrance; impediment; obstruction. Obs Willing to march on to Calais, Without impeachment. A calling to account; arraignment; especially, of a public officer for maladministration. The consequence of Coriolanus' impeachment had like to have been fatal to their state. A calling in question as to purity of motives, rectitude of conduct, credibility, etc.; accusation; reproach; as, an impeachment of motives.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impearled; p. pr. & vb. n. Impearling
entry.ety: Pref. im- in + pearl: cf. F. emperler

sn.def: To form into pearls, or into that which resembles pearls.
sn.q: Dewdrops which the sunImpearls on every leaf and every flower.

sn.def: To decorate as with pearls or with anything resembling pearls.
sn.q: With morning dews impearled.
The dews of the morning impearl every thorn.

entry.ety: Cf. F. impeccabilité
entry.def: The quality of being impeccable; exemption from sin, error, or offense.
entry.q: Infallibility and impeccability are two of his attributes.

entry.ety: L. impeccabilis; pref. im- not + peccare to err, to sin: cf. F. impeccable
entry.def: Not liable to sin; exempt from the possibility of doing wrong.

def2.def: One who is impeccable; esp., one of a sect of Gnostic heretics who asserted their sinlessness.

entry.q: God is infallible, impeccable, and absolutely perfect.

entry.def: Sinlessness.
Sinless; impeccable.
The state of being impecunious.

entry.ety: L. im- not + pecunia money: cf. F. impécunieux
entry.def: Not having money; habitually without money; poor.
entry.q: An impecunious creature.

entry.ety: Impede + -ance
entry.def:
The apparent resistance in an electric circuit to the flow of an alternating current, analogous to the actual electrical resistance to a direct current, being the ratio of electromotive force to the current. It is equal to R2 + X2
, where R = ohmic resistance, X = reactance. For an inductive circuit, X = 2πfL, where f = frequency and L = self-inductance; for a circuit with capacity X = 1 ÷ 2πfC, where C = capacity.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impeded; p. pr. & vb. n. Impeding
entry.ety: L. impedire, lit., to entangle the feet; pref. im- in + pes pedis, foot. See Foot, and cf. Impeach
entry.def: To hinder; to stop in progress; to obstruct; as, to impede the advance of troops.
entry.q: Whatever hinders or impedes The action of the nobler will.

entry.def: Capable of being impeded or hindered.

cs.cd: a defect which prevents distinct utterance.

entry.usage: Impediment Obstacle Difficulty Hindrance. An impediment literally strikes against our feet, checking our progress, and we remove it. An obstacle rises before us in our path, and we surmount or remove it. A difficulty sets before us something hard to be done, and we encounter it and overcome it. A hindrance holds us back for a time, but we break away from it.
entry.ety: L. impedimentum: cf. F. impediment
entry.def: That which impedes or hinders progress, motion, activity, or effect.
entry.q: Thus far into the bowels of the land Have we marched on without impediment.
The eloquence of Demosthenes was to Philip of Macedon, a difficulty to be met with his best resources, an obstacle to his own ambition, and an impediment in his political career.

entry.def: To impede.

entry.ety: L. See Impediment Impede
entry.def: Things which impede or hinder progress; incumbrances; baggage;
the supply trains which must accompany an army.
entry.q: On the plains they will have horses dragging travoises, dogs with travoises, women and children loaded with impedimenta.

entry.def: Of the nature of an impediment; hindering; obstructing; impeditive.
entry.q: Things so impedimental to success.

entry.ety: L. impeditus, p. p. See Impede
entry.def: Hindered; obstructed.
To impede.

entry.ety: L. impeditio
entry.def: A hindering; a hindrance.

entry.ety: Cf. F. impéditif
entry.def: Causing hindrance; impeding.
entry.q: Cumbersome, andimpeditiveof motion.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impelled; p. pr. & vb. n. Impelling
entry.ety: L. impellere; pref. im- in + pellere pulsum, to drive. See Pulse a beat, and cf. Impulse
entry.def: To drive or urge forward or on; to press on; to incite to action or motion in any way.
entry.q: The surge impelled me on a craggy coast.
entry.syn: To instigate; incite; induce; influence; force; drive; urge; actuate; move.

entry.def: motivated by an irresistable compulsion.

entry.ety: L. impellens, p. pr. of impellere
entry.def: Having the quality of impelling.
An impelling power or force.
One who, or that which, impels.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impenned and Impent; p. pr. & vb. n. Impenning
entry.def: To shut up or inclose, as in a pen.

entry.ety: L. impendĕre; pref. im- in + pendĕre to weigh out, pay
entry.def: To pay.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impended; p. pr. & vb. n. Impending
entry.ety: L. impendēre; pref. im- in + pendēre to hang. See Pendant
entry.def: To hang over; to be suspended above; to threaten from near at hand; to menace; to be imminent. See Imminent.
entry.q: Destruction sure o'er all your heads impends.

entry.def: The state of impending; the state of being imminent and liable to happen soon; also, that which impends.
entry.q: Impendenceof volcanic cloud.

entry.ety: L. impendens, p. pr. of impendēre
entry.def: Impending; threatening.
entry.q: Impendent horrors, threatening hideous fall.

entry.def: Hanging over; overhanging; suspended so as to menace; imminet; threatening.
entry.q: An impending brow.
And nodding Ilion waits th' impending fall.

entry.ety: Cf. F. impénétrabilité

sn.def: Quality of being impenetrable.
That property in virtue of which two portions of matter can not at the same time occupy the same portion of space.
Insusceptibility of intellectual or emotional impression; obtuseness; stupidity; coldness.

entry.ety: L. impenetrabilis; pref. im- not + penetrabilis penetrable: cf. F. impénétrable

sn.def: Incapable of being penetrated or pierced; not admitting the passage of other bodies; not to be entered; impervious; as, an impenetrable shield.
sn.q: Highest woods impenetrable To star or sunlight.

sn.def: Having the property of preventing any other substance from occupying the same space at the same time.
Inaccessible, as to knowledge, reason, sympathy, etc.; unimpressible; not to be moved by arguments or motives; as, an impenetrable mind, or heart.
sn.q: They will be credulous in all affairs of life, but impenetrable by a sermon of the gospel.

entry.def: The quality of being impenetrable; impenetrability.
In an impenetrable manner or state; imperviously.
entry.q: Impenetrablyarmed.
Impenetrablydull.

entry.ety: L. impenitentia: cf. F. impénitence
entry.def: The condition of being impenitent; failure or refusal to repent; hardness of heart.
entry.q: He will advance from one degree of wickedness and impenitence to another.

entry.def: Impenitence.

entry.ety: L. impaenitens; pref. im- not + paenitens penitens: cf. F. impénitent. See Penitent
entry.def: Not penitent; not repenting of sin; not contrite; of a hard heart.
entry.q: They . . . diedimpenitent.
A careless andimpenitentheart.

entry.def: One who is not penitent.
Without repentance.
Characterized by short wings covered with feathers resembling scales, as the penguins.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. pref. im- not + penna feather
entry.def: An order of birds, including only the penguins, in which the wings are without quills, and not suited for flight.

entry.ety: L. pref. im- not + penna wing
entry.def: Having no wings, as some insects.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impeopled; p. pr. & vb. n. Impeopling
entry.ety: See Empeople
entry.def: To people; to give a population to.
entry.q: Thou hast helped to impeople hell.

entry.ety: L. imperans, p. pr. of imperare to command
entry.def: Commanding.

entry.ety: L. imperatus, p. p. of imperare to command
entry.def: Done by express direction; not involuntary; communded.
entry.q: Those imperate acts, wherein we see the empire of the soul.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the imperative mood.

entry.ety: L. imperativus, fr. imperare to command; pref. im- in + parare to make ready, prepare: cf. F. impératif. See Perade, and cf. Empire

sn.def: Expressive of command; containing positive command; authoritatively or absolutely directive; commanding; authoritative; as, imperative orders.
sn.q: The suit of kings are imperative.

sn.def: Not to be avoided or evaded; obligatory; binding; compulsory; as, an imperative duty or order.
Expressive of commund, entreaty, advice, or exhortation; as, the imperative mood.

entry.def: The imperative mood; also, a verb in the imperative mood.
In an imperative manner.

entry.ety: L. See Emperor
entry.def: A commander; a leader; an emperor; -- originally an appellation of honor by which Roman soldiers saluted their general after an important victory. Subsequently the title was conferred as a recognition of great military achievements by the senate, whence it carried wiht it some special privileges. After the downfall of the Republic it was assumed by Augustus and his successors, and came to have the meaning now attached to the word emperor.

entry.ety: L. imperatorius

sn.def: Commanding; imperative; authoritative.
Of or pertaining to the title or office of imperator.
sn.q: Imperatoriallaurels.

entry.def: Imperial.
Imperative.
Imperceptible.
Not perceived.
The state or quality of being imperceptible.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + perceptible: cf. F. imperceptible
entry.def: Not perceptible; not to be apprehended or cognized by the senses; not discernible by the mind; not easily apprehended.
entry.q: Almost imperceptible to the touch.
Its operation is slow, and in some cases almost imperceptible.
Their . . . subtilty and imperceptibleness.

entry.def: Lack of perception.
Unable to perceive.
entry.q: The imperceptive part of the soul.

entry.def: Not perceiving, or not able to perceive.
The state or quality of being imperdible.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + L. perdere to destroy
entry.def: Not destructible.

cs.cd: an arch of less than a semicircle; a skew arch.
one not ending with the tonic, but with the dominant or some other chord; one not giving complete rest; a half close.
chords like the third and sixth, whose ratios are less simple than those of the fifth and forth.
a flower wanting either stamens or pistils.
one a semitone less than perfect; as, an imperfect fifth.
a number either greater or less than the sum of its several divisors; in the former case, it is called also a defective number; in the latter, an abundant number.
obligations as of charity or gratitude, which cannot be enforced by law.
a number which can not be produced by taking any whole number or vulgar fraction, as a factor, the number of times indicated by the power; thus, 9 is a perfect square, but an imperfect cube.
a tense expressing past time and incomplete action.

entry.ety: L. imperfectus: pref. im- not + perfectus perfect: cf. F imparfait, whence OE. imparfit. See Perfect

sn.def: Not perfect; not complete in all its parts; wanting a part; deective; deficient.
sn.q: Something he left imperfect in the state.
Why, then, your other senses grow imperfect.

sn.def: Wanting in some elementary organ that is essential to successful or normal activity.
sn.q: He . . . stammered like a child, or an amazed, imperfect person.

sn.def: Not fulfilling its design; not realizing an ideal; not conformed to a standard or rule; not satisfying the taste or conscience; esthetically or morally defective.
sn.q: Nothing imperfect or deficient left Of all that he created.
Then say not man's imperfect, Heaven in fault; Say rather, man's as perfect as he ought.

entry.def: The imperfect tense; or the form of a verb denoting the imperfect tense.
To make imperfect.
The state or quality of being imperfectible.
Incapable of being made perfect.

entry.ety: L. imperfectio: cf. F. imperfection. See Imperfect a.
