entry.def: The quality or condition of being imperfect; lack of perfection; incompleteness; deficiency; fault or blemish.
entry.q: Sent to my account With all my imperfections on my head.
entry.syn: Defect; deficiency; incompleteness; fault; failing; weakness; frailty; foible; blemish; vice.

entry.def: The state of being imperfect.

entry.ety: See Imperforate
entry.def: Incapable of being perforated, or bored through.

entry.ety: NL. See Imperforate
entry.def: A division of Foraminifera, including those in which the shell is not porous.

entry.ety: L. pref. im- not + perforatus, p. p. of perforate to perforate. See Perforate
entry.def: Not perforated; having no opening or aperture.

entry.ety: Cf. F. imperforation
entry.def: The state of being without perforation.

entry.cs:
Imperial bushel gallon
etc. See Bushel Gallon, etc. Imperial chamber the, the sovereign court of the old German empire. Imperial city under the first German empire, a city having no head but the emperor. Imperial diet an assembly of all the states of the German empire. Imperial drill. Manuf See under 8th Drill. Imperial eagle. Zoöl See Eagle. Imperial green. See Paris green, under Green. Imperial guard the royal guard instituted by Napoleon I. Imperial weights and measures the standards legalized by the British Parliament.
entry.ety: OE. emperial, OF. emperial, F. impérial, fr. L. imperialis, fr. imperium command, sovereignty, empire. See Empire

sn.def: Of or pertaining to an empire, or to an emperor; as, an imperial government; imperial authority or edict.
sn.q: The last That wore the imperial diadem of Rome.

sn.def: Belonging to, or suitable to, supreme authority, or one who wields it; royal; sovereign; supreme.
sn.q: Theimperialdemocracy of Athens.
Who, as Ulysses says, opinion crowns With an imperial voice.
To tame the proud, the fetter'd slave to free, These are imperial arts, and worthy thee.
He sounds his imperial clarion along the whole line of battle.

sn.def: Of superior or unusual size or excellence; as, imperial paper; imperial tea, etc.

entry.ety: F. impériale: cf. Sp. imperial

sn.def: The tuft of hair on a man's lower lip and chin; -- so called from the style of beard of Napoleon III.
An outside seat on a diligence.
A luggage case on the top of a coach.
Anything of unusual size or excellence, as a large decanter, a kind of large photograph, a large sheet of drawing, printing, or writing paper, etc.
A gold coin of Russia worth ten rubles, or about eight dollars.
A kind of fine cloth brought into England from Greece. or other Eastern countries, in the Middle Ages.
A game at cards differing from piquet in some minor details, and in having a trump; also, any one of several combinations of cards which score in this game.
The power or character of an emperor; imperial authority; the spirit of empire.
sn.q: Roman imperialism had divided the world.

sn.def: The policy, practice, or advocacy of seeking, or acquiescing in, the extension of the control, dominion, or empire of a nation, as by the acquirement of new, esp. distant, territory or dependencies, or by the closer union of parts more or less independent of each other for operations of war, copyright, internal commerce, etc. The practise of building or extending an empire.
sn.q: The tide of English opinion began to turn about 1870, and since then it has run with increasing force in the direction of what is called imperialism.

entry.ety: Cf. F. impérialiste
entry.def: One who serves an emperor; one who favors imperialism.
Of, pertaining to, or advocating imperialism.

entries.entry:
Im*pe`ri*al"i*ty n.; pl.Imperialities.
Imperial power.
An imperial right or privilegs. See Royalty. The late empress having, by ukases of grace, relinquished her imperialities on the private mines, viz., the tenths of the copper, iron, silver and gold.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Imperialized; p. pr. & vb. n. Imperializing
entry.def: To invest with imperial authority, character, or style; to bring to the form of an empire.
In an imperial manner.
Imperial power.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Imperiled or Imperilled; p. pr. & vb. n. Imperiling or Imperilling
entry.def: To bring into peril; to endanger.
The act of imperiling, or the state of being imperiled.

entry.usage: Imperious Lordly Domineering. One who is imperious exercises his authority in a manner highly offensive for its spirit and tone; one who is lordly assumes a lofty air in order to display his importance; one who is domineering gives orders in a way to make others feel their inferiority.
entry.ety: L. imperiosus: cf. F. impérieux. See Imperial

sn.def: Commanding; ascendant; imperial; lordly; majestic.
sn.q: A vast andimperiousmind.
Therefore, great lords, be, as your titles witness,Imperious.

sn.def: Haughly; arrogant; overbearing; as, an imperious tyrant; an imperious manner.
sn.q: This imperious man will work us all From princes into pages.
His bold, contemptuous, and imperious spirit soon made him conspicuous.

sn.def: Imperative; urgent; compelling.
sn.q: Imperious need, which can not be withstood.
sn.syn: Dictatorial; haughty; domineering; overbearing; lordly; tyrannical; despotic; arrogant; imperative; authoritative; commanding; pressing.

entry.def: In an imperious manner.
The quality or state of being imperious; arrogance; haughtiness.
entry.q: Imperiousness and severity is but an ill way of treating men who have reason of their own to guide them.

entry.def: The quality of being imperishable: indstructibility.
entry.q: Theimperishabilityof the universe.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + perishable: cf. F. impérissable
entry.def: Not perishable; not subject to decay; indestructible; enduring permanently; as, an imperishable monument; imperishable renown.

entries.entry:
‖Im*pe"ri*um n.; pl. Imperia # . L. See Empire
Supreme power; absolute dominion; empire.
Law The right to command, which includes the right to employ the force of the state to enforce the laws. It is one of the principal attributes of the executive power.

entry.def: Wearing a periwig.
Lack of permanence.
Not permanent.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + permeability: cf. F. imperméabilité
entry.def: The quality of being impermeable.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + permeable: cf. F. imperméable, L. impermeabilis
entry.def: Not permeable; not permitting passage, as of a fluid. through its substance; impervious; impenetrable; as, India rubber is impermeable to water and to air.
Not permissible.

entry.ety: L. imperscrutabilis
entry.def: Not capable of being searched out; inscrutable.
Not persevering; fickle; thoughtless.

cs.cd: a verb used with an indeterminate subject, commonly, in English, with the impersonal pronoun it; as, it rains; it snows; methinksit seems to me). Many verbs which are not strictly impersonal are often used impersonally; as, it goes well with him.

entry.ety: L. impersonalis; pref. im- not + personalis personal: cf. F. impersonnel. See Personal
entry.def: Not personal; not representing a person; not having personality.
entry.q: An almighty but impersonal power, called Fate.

entry.def: That which wants personality;
an impersonal verb.
The quality of being impersonal; want or absence of personality.
In an impersonal manner.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impersonated; p. pr. & vb. n. Impersonating

sn.def: To invest with personality; to endow with the form of a living being.
To ascribe the qualities of a person to; to personify.
To assume, or to represent, the person or character of; to personate; as, he impersonated Macbeth.
sn.q: Benedict impersonated his age.

entry.def: The act of impersonating; personification; investment with personality; representation in a personal form.
One who impersonates; an actor; a mimic.
Lack of perspicuity or clearness; vagueness; ambiguity.
Not perspicuous; not clear; obscure; vague; ambiguous.

entry.ety: Cf. Impersuasible
entry.def: Not to be persuaded; obstinate; unyielding; impersuasible.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + persuasible: cf. OF. impersuasible
entry.def: Not persuasible; not to be moved by persuasion; inflexible; impersuadable.

entry.ety: Cf. F. impertinence. See Impertinent

sn.def: The condition or quality of being impertinent; absence of pertinence, or of adaptedness; irrelevance; unfitness.
Conduct or language unbecoming the person, the society, or the circumstances; rudeness; incivility.
sn.q: We should avoid the vexation and impertinence of pedants who affect to talk in a language not to be understood.

sn.def: That which is impertinent; a thing out of place, or of no value.
sn.q: There are many subtile impertinences learned in schools.

entry.def: Impertinence.
entry.q: O, matter and impertinency mixed! Reason in madness!

entry.usage: Impertinent Officious Rude. A person is officious who obtrudes his offices or assistance where they are not needed; he is impertinent when he intermeddles in things with which he has no concern. The former shows a lack of tact, the latter a lack of breeding, or, more commonly, a spirit of sheer impudence. A person is rude when he violates the proprieties of social life either from ignorance or wantonness. “An impertinent man will ask questions for the mere gratification of curiosity; a rude man will burst into the room of another, or push against his person, inviolant of all decorum; one who is officious is quite as unfortunate as he is troublesome; when he strives to serve, he has the misfortune to annoy.” Crabb. See Impudence, and Insolent.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. impertinens -entis; pref. im- not + pertinens. See Pertinent

sn.def: Not pertinent; not pertaining to the matter in hand; having no bearing on the subject; not to the point; irrelevant; inapplicable.
sn.q: Things that are impertinent to us.
How impertinent that grief was which served no end!

sn.def: Contrary to, or offending against, the rules of propriety or good breeding; guilty of, or prone to, rude, unbecoming, or uncivil words or actions; as, an impertient coxcomb; an impertient remark.
Trifing; inattentive; frivolous.
sn.syn: Rude; officious; intrusive; saucy; unmannerly; meddlesome; disrespectful; impudent; insolent.

entry.def: An impertinent person.
In an impertinent manner.
entry.q: Not to betray myselfimpertinently.

entry.def: The quality or state of being impertransible.

entry.ety: L. pref. im- not + pertransire to go through. See Per- and Transient
entry.def: Incapable of being passed through.
The state or quality of being imperturbable.

entry.ety: L. imperturbabilis; pref. im- not + perturbare to disturb: cf. F. imperturbable. See Perture
entry.def: Incapable of being disturbed or disconcerted; as, imperturbable gravity.
In an imperturbable manner; calmly.

entry.ety: L. imperturbatio
entry.def: Freedom from agitation of mind; calmness; quietude.
Not perturbed.
The quality of being imperviable.
Not pervious; impervious.

entry.ety: L. impervius; pref. im- not + per through + via way. See Voyage
entry.def: Not pervious; not admitting of entrance or passage through; as, a substance impervious to water or air.
entry.q: This gulf impassable, impervious.
The minds of these zealots were absolutely impervious.

entry.def: Empery.
To affict with pestilence; to infect, as with plague.
See Pester.

entry.ety: L. impetiginous: cf. F. impétigineux
entry.def: Of the nature of, or pertaining to, impetigo.

entry.ety: L., fr. impetere to attack
entry.def: A cutaneous, pustular eruption, not attended with fever; usually, a kind of eczema with pustulation.

entry.ety: L. impetrabilis: cf. F. impétrable. See Impetrate
entry.def: Capable of being obtained or moved by petition.

entry.ety: L. impetratus, p. p. of impetrare to obtain; pref. im- in + patrare to bring to pass
entry.def: Obtained by entreaty.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impetrated; p. pr. & vb. n. Impetrating
entry.def: To obtain by request or entreaty.

entry.ety: L. impetratio: cf. F. impétration

sn.def: The act of impetrating, or obtaining by petition or entreaty.
sn.q: In way of impertation procuring the removal or allevation of our crosses.

sn.def: The obtaining of benefice from Rome by solicitation, which benefice belonged to the disposal of the king or other lay patron of the realm.

entry.ety: L. impetrativus obtained by entreaty
entry.def: Of the nature of impetration; getting, or tending to get, by entreaty.
Containing or expressing entreaty.

entry.ety: Cf. F. impétuosité

sn.def: The condition or quality of being impetuous; fury; violence.
Vehemence, or furiousnes of temper.

entry.ety: F. impetueux, L. impetuosus. See Impetus

sn.def: Rushing with force and violence; moving with impetus; furious; forcible; violent; as, an impetuous wind; an impetuous torrent.
sn.q: Went pouring forward with impetuous speed.

sn.def: Vehement in feeling; hasty; passionate; violent; as, a man of impetuous temper.
sn.q: The people, on their holidays,Impetuous, insolent, unquenchable.
sn.syn: Forcible; rapid; hasty; precipitate; furious; boisterous; violent; raging; fierce; passionate.

entry.note: ☞ Momentum is the technical term, impetus its popular equivalent, yet differing from it as applied commonly to bodies moving or moved suddenly or violently, and indicating the origin and intensity of the motion, rather than its quantity or effectiveness.
entry.ety: L., fr. impetere to rush upon, attack; pref. im- in + petere to fall upon, seek. See Petition

sn.def: A property possessed by a moving body in virtue of its weight and its motion; the force with which any body is driven or impelled; momentum.
Fig.: Impulse; incentive; stimulus; vigor; force; as, the President's strong recommendation provided the impetus needed to pass the campaign reform bill.
The altitude through which a heavy body must fall to acquire a velocity equal to that with which a ball is discharged from a piece.

entries.entry: Im"pey*an pheas"ant ☞ They are remarkable for the bright color and brilliant matallic hues of their plumage. The best known species (Lophophorus Impeyanus) has the neck of a brilliant metallic red, changing to golden yellow in certain lights. ĭm"pĭ*�n fĕz"�nt. From Lady Impey, who attempted to naturalize the bird in England Zoöl An Indian crested pheasant of the genus Lophophorus. Several species are known. Called also monaul monal.

entry.def: The African sugar cane (Holcus saccharatus), -- resembling the sorghum, or Chinese sugar cane.

entry.ety: Zulu
entry.def: A body of Kaffir warriors; a body of native armed men.
entry.q: As early as 1862 he crossed assagais with and defeated a Matabili impiwar band).

entry.def: Pictured; impressed.

entry.ety: Pref. im- in + pierce. Cf. Empierce
entry.def: To pierce; to penetrate.
Not capable of being pierced; impenetrable.

entries.entry:
Im*pi"e*ty ĭm*pī"�*t� n.; pl.Impieties ĭm*pī"�*tĭz. L. impietas, fr. impius impious; cf. F. impiété. See Impious Piety
The quality of being impious; lack of piety; irreverence toward the Supreme Being; ungodliness; wickedness.
An impious act; an act of wickedness. Those impieties for the which they are now visited. Ungodliness; irreligion; unrighteousness; sinfulness; profaneness; wickedness; godlessness.

entry.ety: LL. impignoratus, p. pl of impignorare to pawn. See Pignoration
entry.def: To pledge or pawn.

entry.ety: LL. impignoratio: cf. F. impignoration
entry.def: The act of pawning or pledging; the state of being pawned.

entry.ety: See Imp to graft

sn.def: The act or process of grafting or mending.
The process of repairing broken feathers or a deficient wing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impinged; p. pr. & vb. n. Impinging
entry.ety: L. impingere; pref. im- in + pangere to fix, strike; prob. akin to pacisci to agree, contract. See Pact, and cf. Impact
entry.def: To fall or dash against; to touch upon; to strike; to hit; to clash with; -- with on or upon.
entry.q: The cause of reflection is not the impinging of light on the solid or impervious parts of bodies.
But, in the present order of things, not to be employed without impinging on God's justice.

entry.def: The act of impinging.

entry.ety: L. impingens, p. pr
entry.def: Striking against or upon.

entry.ety: L. impinguatus, p. p. of impinguare to fatten; pref. im- in + pinguis fat
entry.def: To fatten; to make fat.
The act of making fat, or the state of being fat or fattened.

entry.usage: Irreligious is negative, impious and profane are positive. An indifferent man may be irreligious; a profane man is irreverent in speech and conduct; an impious man is wickedly and boldly defiant in the strongest sense. Profane also has the milder sense of secular.
entry.ety: L. impius; pref. im- not + pius piou. See Pious
entry.def: Not pious; wanting piety; irreligious; irreverent; ungodly; profane; wanting in reverence for the Supreme Being; as, an impious deed; impious language.
entry.q: When vice prevails, and impious men bear away, The post of honor is a private station.

entry.def: See Umpire.
Having the qualities, or showing the characteristics, of an imp; naughtily or annoyingly playful; as, teasing and worrying with impish laughter.
entry.syn: elfish, elvish, implike, mischievous, pixilated, prankish, puckish.

entry.def: In the manner of an imp.
Pitiless; cruel.

entry.ety: L. implacabilitas: cf. F. implacabilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being implacable.

entry.ety: L. implacabilis; pref. im- not + placabilis: cf. F. implacable. See Placable

sn.def: Not placable; not to be appeased; incapable of being pacified; inexorable; as, an implacable prince.
sn.q: I see thou art implacable.
An object of implacable enmity.

sn.def: Incapable of being relieved or assuaged; inextinguishable.
sn.q: O! how I burn with implacable fire.
Which wrought them painImplacable, and many a dolorous groan.
sn.syn: Unappeasable; inexorable; irreconcilable; unrelenting; relentless; unyielding.

entry.def: The quality of being implacable; implacability.
In an implacable manner.
Without a placenta, as marsupials and monotremes; nonplacental.

def2.def: A mammal having no placenta; a nonplacental mammal.

entry.ety: NL. See In- not, and Placental
entry.def: A primary division of the Mammalia, including the monotremes and marsupials, in which no placenta is formed.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Implanted; p. pr. & vb. n. Implanting
entry.ety: Pref. im- in + plant: cf. F. implanter
entry.def: To plant, or infix, for the purpose of growth; to fix deeply; to instill; to inculate; to introduce; as, to implant the seeds of virtue, or the principles of knowledge, in the minds of youth.
entry.q: Minds well implanted with solid . . . breeding.

entry.ety: Cf. F. implantation
entry.def: The act or process of implanting.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Implated; p. pr. & vb. n. Implating
entry.def: To cover with plates; to sheathe; as, to implate a ship with iron.
Lack of plausibility; the quality of being implausible.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + plausible: cf. F. implausible
entry.def: Not plausible; not wearing the appearance of truth or credibility, and not likely to be believed.
entry.q: Implausibleharangues.

entry.def: To pleach; to interweave.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impleaded; p. pr. & vb. n. Impleading
entry.ety: Cf. Emplead
entry.def: To institute and prosecute a suit against, in court; to sue or prosecute at law; hence, to accuse; to impeach.
To sue at law.
Not admitting excuse, evasion, or plea; rigorous.
One who prosecutes or sues another.
Unpleasing; displeasing.
To pledge.

entry.ety: LL. implementum accomplishment, fr. L. implere impletum, to fill up, finish, complete; pref. im- in + plere to fill. The word was perh. confused with OF. empleier emploier, to employ, F. employer, whence E. employ. See Plenty
entry.def: That which fulfills or supplies a want or use; esp., an instrument, tool, or utensil, as supplying a requisite to an end; as, the implements of trade, of husbandry, or of war.
entry.q: Genius must have talent as its complement and implement.

sn.def: To accomplish; to fulfill.
sn.q: Revenge . . . executed and implemented by the hand of Vanbeest Brown.

sn.def: To provide with an implement or implements; to cause to be fulfilled, satisfied, or carried out, by means of an implement or implements.
sn.q: The chief mechanical requisites of the barometer are implemented in such an instrument as the following.

sn.def: To fulfill or perform, as a contract or an engagement.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or characterized by, implements or their use; mechanical.

entry.ety: L. impletio. See Implement

sn.def: The act of filling, or the state of being full.
That which fills up; filling.

entry.ety: L. implexus, p. p. of implectere to infold; pref. im- in + plectere to plait: cf. F implexe
entry.def: Intricate; entangled; complicated; complex.
entry.q: The fable of every poem is . . . simple or implex. it is called simple when there is no change of fortune in it; implex, when the fortune of the chief actor changes from bad to good, or from good to bad.

entry.ety: L. implexio
entry.def: Act of involving, or state of being involved; involution.
Not pliable; inflexible; unyielding.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Implicated; p. pr. & vb. n. Implicating
entry.ety: L. implicatus, p. p. of implicare to involve; pref. im- in + plicare to fold. See Employ Ply, and cf. Imply Implicit

sn.def: To infold; to fold together; to interweave.
sn.q: The meeting boughs and implicated leaves.

sn.def: To bring into connection with; to involve; to connect; -- applied to persons, in an unfavorable sense; as, the evidence implicates many in this conspiracy; to be implicated in a crime, a discreditable transaction, a fault, etc.

entry.def: culpably involved; connected; -- of persons with respect to responsibility for events.
a charge that implicates someone (usually of wrongdoing).

entry.ety: L. implicatio: cf. F. implication

sn.def: The act of implicating, or the state of being implicated.
sn.q: Three principal causes of firmness are. the grossness, the quiet contact, and the implication of component parts.

sn.def: An implying, or that which is implied, but not expressed; an inference, or something which may fairly be understood, though not expressed in words.
sn.q: Whatever things, therefore, it was asserted that the king might do, it was a necessary implication that there were other things which he could not do.

entry.def: arousing a mental association; evocative.
Tending to implicate.
By implication.

entry.cs: Implicit function. Math See under Function.
entry.ety: L. implicitus, p. p. of implicare to entwine, entangle, attach closely: cf. F. implicite. See Implicate

sn.def: Infolded; entangled; complicated; involved.
sn.q: In his woolly fleece I cling implicit.

sn.def: Tacitly comprised; fairly to be understood, though not expressed in words; implied; as, an implicit contract or agreement.
Resting on another; trusting in the word or authority of another, without doubt or reserve; unquestioning; complete; as, implicit confidence; implicit obedience.
sn.q: Back again to implicit faith I fall.

sn.def: In an implicit manner; without reserve; with unreserved confidence.
sn.q: Not to dispute the methods of his providence, but humbly and implicitly to acquiesce in and adore them.

sn.def: By implication; impliedly; as, to deny the providence of God is implicitly to deny his existence.

entry.def: State or quality of being implicit.
Implicitness.
Virtually involved or included; involved in substance; inferential; tacitly conceded; -- the correlative of express, or expressed. See Imply.
By implication or inference.
To burst inward; contrasting with explode.
Formed by implosion.
An implosive sound.

entry.ety: L. imploratio: cf. OF. imploration. See Implore
entry.def: The act of imploring; earnest supplication.
One who implores.
entry.q: Mere implorators of unholy suits.

entry.def: Supplicatory; entreating.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Implored; p. pr. & vb. n. Imploring
entry.ety: L. implorare; pref. im- in + plorare to cry aloud. See Deplore
entry.def: To call upon, or for, in supplication; to beseech; to pray to, or for, earnestly; to petition with urgency; to entreat; to beg; -- followed directly by the word expressing the thing sought, or the person from whom it is sought.
entry.q: Imploring all the gods that reign above.
I kneel, and then implore her blessing.
entry.syn: To beseech; supplicate; crave; entreat; beg; solicit; petition; prey; request; adjure. See Beseech.

entry.def: To entreat; to beg; to prey.
Imploration.
One who implores.
That implores; beseeching; entreating.

entry.ety: Formed by substitution of pref. im- in for pref. ex- in explosion

sn.def: A bursting inwards, as of a vessel from which the air has been exhausted; -- contrasted with explosion.

The inward-moving detonation wave cause by detonation of explosives arrayed spherically around a core; -- a technique used in atomic bombs to compress fissionable material to allow a chain reaction time to produce an explosion of the fissionable material.

A sudden compression of the air in the mouth, simultaneously with and affecting the sound made by the closure of the organs in uttering p t, or k, at the end of a syllable (see Guide to Pronunciation, §§159, 189); also, a similar compression made by an upward thrust of the larynx without any accompanying explosive action, as in the peculiar sound of b d, and g, heard in Southern Germany.

entry.def: Formed by implosion.
Not plumed; without plumes or feathers; featherless.
To plunge.

entry.ety: L., fr. impluere to rain into; pref. im- in + pluere to rain
entry.def: In Roman dwellings, a cistern or tank, set in the atrium or peristyle to recieve the water from the roof, by means of the compluvium; generally made ornamental with flowers and works of art around its birm.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Implied; p. pr. & vb. n. Implying
entry.ety: From the same source as employ. See Employ Ply, and cf. Implicate Apply

sn.def: To infold or involve; to wrap up.
sn.q: His head in curlsimplied.

sn.def: To involve in substance or essence, or by fair inference, or by construction of law, when not include virtually; as, war implies fighting.
sn.q: Where a malicious act is proved, a malicious intention is implied.
When a man employs a laborer to work for him, . . . the act of hiring implies an obligation and a promise that he shall pay him a reasonable reward for his services.

sn.def: To refer, ascribe, or attribute.
sn.q: Whence might this distaste arise?
If [from] neither your perverse and peevish will. To which I most imply it.
sn.syn: To involve; include; comprise; import; mean; denote; signify; betoken. See Involve.

entry.ety: Cf. Empoison
entry.def: To poison; to imbitter; to impair.
A poisoner.

entry.ety: Cf. Empoisonment
entry.def: The act of poisoning or impoisoning.
Not according to or in, the direction of the poles.
The quality of being impolitic; inexpedience; unsuitableness to the end proposed; bads policy; as, the impolicy of fraud.

entry.ety: L. impolitus unpolishied, pref. im- not + politus, p. p. of polire to polish, refine. See Polite
entry.def: Not polite; not of polished manners; wanting in good manners; discourteous; uncivil; rude.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + politic; cf. F. impolitique
entry.def: Not politic; contrary to, or wanting in, policy; unwise; imprudent; indiscreet; inexpedient; as, an impolitic ruler, law, or measure.
entry.q: The most unjust and impolitic of all things, unequal taxation.

entry.def: Impolitic.
In an impolitic manner.
The quality of being impolitic.

entry.ety: Cf. F. impondérabilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being imponderable; imponderableness.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + ponderable: cf. F. impondérable
entry.def: Not ponderable; without sensible or appreciable weight; incapable of being weighed.

An imponderable substance or body; specifically, in the plural, a name formerly applied to heat, light, electricity, and magnetism, regarded as subtile fluids destitute of weight but in modern science little used.
The quality or state of being imponderable.
Imponderable.

entry.ety: L. imponere impositum, to place upon; pref. im- in + ponere to place. See Position
entry.def: To stake; to wager; to pledge.
entry.q: Against the which he has imponed, as I take it, six French rapiers and poniards.

entry.def: The eland.
The duykerbok.
To impoverish.

entry.ety: Perf. im- not + porosity: cf. F. imporosité
entry.def: The state or quality of being imporous; lack of porosity; compactness.
entry.q: The . . .imporositybetwixt the tangible parts.

entry.def: Destitute of pores; very close or compact in texture; solid.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Imported; p. pr. & vb. n. Importing
entry.ety: L. importare to bring in, to occasion, to cause; pref. im- in + portare to bear. Sense 3 comes through F. importer, from the Latin. See Port demeanor

sn.def: To bring in from abroad; to introduce from without; especially, to bring (wares or merchandise) into a place or country from a foreign country, in the transactions of commerce; -- opposed to export. We import teas from China, coffee from Brazil, etc.
To carry or include, as meaning or intention; to imply; to signify.
sn.q: Every petition . . . doth . . . always import a multitude of speakers together.

sn.def: To be of importance or consequence to; to have a bearing on; to concern.
sn.q: I have a motion much imports your good.
If I endure it, what imports it you?
sn.syn: To denote; mean; signify; imply; indicate; betoken; interest; concern.

entry.def: To signify; to purport; to be of moment.
entry.q: For that . . .importethto the work.

sn.def: Merchandise imported, or brought into a country from without its boundaries; -- generally in the plural, opposed to exports.
sn.q: I take the imports from, and not the exports to, these conquests, as the measure of these advantages which we derived from them.

sn.def: That which a word, phrase, or document contains as its signification or intention or interpretation of a word, action, event, and the like.
Importance; weight; consequence.
sn.q: Most serious design, and the great import.

entry.ety: Cf. F. importable. See Import
entry.def: Capable of being imported.

entry.ety: L. importabilis; pref. im- not + portabilis bearable: cf. OF. importable. See Portable
entry.def: Not to be endured; insupportable; intolerable.

entry.ety: F. importance. See Important

sn.def: The quality or state of being important; consequence; weight; moment; significance.
sn.q: Thy own importance know, Nor bound thy narrow views to things below.

sn.def: Subject; matter.
sn.q: Upon importance of so slight and trivial a nature.

sn.def: Import; meaning; significance.
sn.q: The wisest beholder could not say if the importance were joy or sorrow.

sn.def: Importunity; solicitation.
sn.q: At our importance hither is he come.

entry.def: Importance; significance; consequence; that which is important.
entry.q: Careful to concealimportancies.

entry.ety: F. important. See Import v. t.

sn.def: Full of, or burdened by, import; charged with great interests; restless; anxious.
sn.q: Thou hast strength as much As serves to execute a mind very important.

sn.def: Carrying or possessing weight or consequence; of valuable content or bearing; significant; weighty.
sn.q: Things small as nothing . . . He makes important.

sn.def: Bearing on; forcible; driving.
sn.q: He fiercely at him flew, And with important outrage him assailed.

sn.def: Importunate; pressing; urgent.
sn.syn: Weighty; momentous; significant; essential; necessary; considerable; influential; serious.

entry.def: appearing to be important; as, an important-looking sealed document.
In an important manner.

entry.ety: Cf. F. importation. See Import v. t.

sn.def: The act of carrying, conveying, or delivering.
The act or practice of importing, or bringing into a country or state; -- opposed to exportation.
That which is imported; commodities or wares introduced into a country from abroad.

entry.def: brought into the country from a foreign source; -- used of especially merchandise; -- correlative of exported.
One who imports; the merchant who brings goods into a country or state; -- opposed to exporter.
Full of meaning.
Void of meaning.
Heavy; insupportable.

entry.ety: From Importunate
entry.def: The quality of being importunate; importunateness.

entry.ety: See Importune

sn.def: Troublesomely urgent; unreasonably solicitous; overpressing in request or demand; urgent; teasing; as, an importunate petitioner, curiosity.
Hard to be borne; unendurable.

entry.def: One who importunes; an importuner.

entry.ety: F. importun, L. importunus; pref. im- not + a derivative from the root of portus harbor, importunus therefore orig. meaning, hard of access. See Port harbor, and cf. Importunate

sn.def: Inopportune; unseasonable.
Troublesome; vexatious; persistent; urgent; hence, vexatious on account of untimely urgency or pertinacious solicitation.
sn.q: And their importune fates all satisfied.
Of all other affections it [envy] is the most importune and continual.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Importuned ĭm`pŏr*tūnd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Importuning
entry.ety: From Importune a.: cf. F. importuner

sn.def: To request or solicit, with urgency; to press with frequent, unreasonable, or troublesome application or pertinacity; hence, to tease; to irritate; to worry.
sn.q: Their ministers and residents here have perpetually importuned the court with unreasonable demands.

sn.def: To import; to signify.
sn.q: Itimportunesdeath.

entry.def: To require; to demand.
entry.q: We shall write to you, As time and our concernings shall importune.

entry.def: In an importune manner.
One who importunes.

entries.entry:
Im`por*tu"ni*ty n.; pl.Importunities #. L. importunitas unsuitableness, rudeness: cf. F. importunité
The quality of being importunate; pressing or pertinacious solicitation; urgent request; incessant or frequent application; troublesome pertinacity. O'ercome with importunity and tears.

entry.ety: L. importuosus; pref. im- not + portuosus abounding in harbors, fr. portus harbor
entry.def: Without a port or harbor.

entry.ety: Cf. F. imposable
entry.def: Capable of being imposed or laid on.
Quality of being imposable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Imposed; p. pr. & vb. n. Imposing
entry.ety: F. imposer; pref. im- in + poser to place. See Pose v. t.

sn.def: To lay on; to set or place; to put; to deposit.
sn.q: Cakes of salt and barley [she] did impose Within a wicker basket.

sn.def: To lay as a charge, burden, tax, duty, obligation, command, penalty, etc.; to enjoin; to levy; to inflict; as, to impose a toll or tribute.
sn.q: What fates impose, that men must needs abide.
Death is the penalty imposed.
Thou on the deep imposest nobler laws.

sn.def: To lay on, as the hands, in the religious rites of confirmation and ordination.
To arrange in proper order on a table of stone or metal and lock up in a chase for printing; -- said of columns or pages of type, forms, etc.

entry.cs:
To impose onorTo impose upon
to pass or put a trick on; to delude; to cheat; to defraud. “He imposes on himself, and mistakes words for things.” Locke. to place an unwelcome burden or obligation on (another person); as, she imposed on her friend to drive her daughter to school. to take unfair advantage of (a person, a friendship); as, he imposed on his friendship with The Mayor to gain business.
entry.def: To practice tricks or deception.
A command; injunction.
p. p. of impose; as, rules imposed by society.
Imposition.
One who imposes.
entry.q: The imposers of these oaths might repent.

sn.def: Laying as a duty; enjoining.
Adapted to impress forcibly; impressive; commanding; as, an imposing air; an imposing spectacle.
sn.q: Large andimposingedifices.

sn.def: Deceiving; deluding; misleading.

cs.cd: the stone on which the pages or columns of types are imposed or made into forms; -- called also imposing table.

entry.def: The act of imposing the columns of a page, or the pages of a sheet. See Impose v. t., 4.
In an imposing manner.
The quality of being imposing.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. impositio the application of a name to a thing. See Impone

sn.def: The act of imposing, laying on, affixing, enjoining, inflicting, obtruding, and the like.
sn.q: Fromimpositionof strict laws.
Made more solemn by the imposition of hands.

sn.def: That which is imposed, levied, or enjoined; charge; burden; injunction; tax.
An extra exercise enjoined on students as a punishment.
An excessive, arbitrary, or unlawful exaction; hence, a trick or deception put on laid on others; cheating; fraud; delusion; imposture.
sn.q: Reputation is an idle and most false imposition.

sn.def: The act of laying on the hands as a religious ceremoy, in ordination, confirmation, etc.
The act or process of imosing pages or columns of type. See Impose v. t., 4.
sn.syn: Deceit; fraud; imposture. See Deception.

entries.entry:
Im*pos`si*bil"i*ty
Logical impossibility a condition or statement involving contradiction or absurdity; as, that a thing can be and not be at the same time. See Principle of Contradiction, under Contradiction.
n.; pl.Impossibilities #. L. impossibilitas: cf. F. impossibilité
The quality of being impossible; impracticability. They confound difficulty with impossibility.
An impossible thing; that which is not possible; that which can not be thought, done, or endured.
Impossibilities! O, no, there's none.
Inability; helplessness. R

cs.cd: an imaginary quantity. See Imaginary.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. impossibilis; pref. im- not + possibilis possible. See Possible
entry.def: Not possible; incapable of being done, of existing, etc.; unattainable in the nature of things, or by means at command; insuperably difficult under the circumstances; absurd or impracticable; not feasible.
entry.q: With men this is impossible; but with God all things are possible.
Without faith it is impossible to please him.

entry.def: An impossibility; as, he tried to do the impossible .
entry.q: “Madam,” quoth he, “this were an impossible!”

entry.def: incapability of existing or occurring; impossibility.
Not possibly.

entry.note: ☞ The impost is called continuous, if the moldings of the arch or architrave run down the jamb or pier without a break.
entry.ety: OF. impost, F. impot, LL. impostus, fr. L. impostus, p. p. of imponere to impose. See Impone

sn.def: That which is imposed or levied; a tax, tribute, or duty; especially, a duty or tax laid by goverment on goods imported into a country.
sn.q: Even the ship money . . . Johnson could not pronounce to have been an unconstitutional impost.

sn.def: The top member of a pillar, pier, wall, etc., upon which the weight of an arch rests.
sn.syn: Tribute; excise; custom; duty; tax.

entry.ety: See Imposthume
entry.def: To apostemate; to form an imposthume or abscess.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Imposthumated; p. pr. & vb. n. Imposthumating
entry.def: To affect with an imposthume or abscess.
Imposthumated.

sn.def: The act of forming an abscess; state of being inflamed; suppuration.
An abscess; an imposthume.

entry.ety: A corruption of aposteme. See Aposteme
entry.def: A collection of pus or purulent matter in any part of an animal body; an abscess.
Same as Imposthumate.

entry.ety: L. impostor a deceiver, fr. imponere to impose upon, deceive. See Impone
entry.def: One who imposes upon others; a person who assumes a character or title not his own, for the purpose of deception; a pretender.
entry.q: The fraudulentimpostorfoul.

entry.def: The condition, character, or practice of an impostor.

entry.ety: LL. impostrix. See Impostor
entry.def: A woman who imposes upon or deceives others.
Characterized by imposture; deceitful.
entry.q: Impostrouspretense of knowledge.

entry.def: Imposture; cheating.

entry.ety: L. impostura: cf. F. imposture. See Impone
entry.def: The act or conduct of an impostor; deception practiced under a false or assumed character; fraud or imposition; cheating.
entry.q: From new legends And fill the world with follies and impostures.

entry.def: Done by imposture.
Impostrous; deceitful.
entry.q: Strictness fales and impostrous.

entry.def: Imposture.

entry.ety: L. impotenia inability, poverty, lack of moderation. See Impotent

sn.def: The quality or condition of being impotent; lack of strength or power, animal, intellectual, or moral; weakness; feebleness; inability; imbecility.
sn.q: Some were poor by impotency of nature; as young fatherless children, old decrepit persons, idiots, and cripples.
O, impotence of mind in body strong!

sn.def: Lack of self-restraint or self-control.
Lack of procreative power; inability to copulate, or beget children; also, sometimes, sterility; barrenness;
the inability to achieve or sustain a penile erection; erectile dysfunction.
same as fertilized, 1.
sn.syn: fertilized, inseminated.

entry.ety: F. impotent, L. impotens -entis; pref. im- not + potens potent, powerful. See Potent

sn.def: Not potent; wanting power, strength. or vigor. whether physical, intellectual, or moral; deficient in capacity; destitute of force; weak; feeble; infirm.
sn.q: There sat a certain man at Lystra, impotent inhis feet.
O most lame and impotent conclusion!
Not slow to hear, Nor impotent to save.

sn.def: Wanting the power of self-restraint; incontrolled; ungovernable; violent.
sn.q: Impotent of tongue, her silence broke.

sn.def: Wanting the power of procreation; unable to copulate; also, sometimes, sterile; barren;
unable to achieve or sustain a penile erection.

entry.def: One who is impotent.
In an impotent manner.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impounded; p. pr. & vb. n. Impounding
entry.def: To shut up or place in an inclosure called a pound; hence, to hold in the custody of some authority such as police or a court; as, to impound stray cattle; to impound an illegally parked car; to impound a document for safe keeping.
entry.q: But taken and impounded as a stray, The king of Scots.

sn.def: The act of impounding, or the state of being impounded.
The fee or fine for impounding.

entry.def: One who impounds.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impoverished; p. pr. & vb. n. Impoverishing
entry.ety: OF. empovrir; pref. em-L. in) + povre poor, F. pauvre; cf. OF. apovrir, F. appauvrir, where the prefix is a-, L. ad. Cf. Empoverish, and see Poor, and -ish

sn.def: To make poor; to reduce to poverty or indigence; as, misfortune and disease impoverish families.
To exhaust the strength, richness, or fertility of; to make sterile; as, to impoverish land.

entry.def: One who, or that which, impoverishes.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. empoverissement, and F. appauvrissement
entry.def: The act of impoverishing, or the state of being impoverished; reduction to poverty.
See Empower.
A pole for supporting a scaffold.

entries.entry:
Im*prac`ti*ca*bil"i*ty n.; pl.Impracticabilities.
The state or quality of being impracticable; infeasibility.
An impracticable thing.
Intractableness; stubbornness.

sn.def: Not practicable; incapable of being performed, or accomplished by the means employed, or at command; impossible; as, an impracticable undertaking.

Not to be overcome, persuaded, or controlled by any reasonable method; unmanageable; intractable; not capable of being easily dealt with; -- used in a general sense, as applied to a person or thing that is difficult to control or get along with.
sn.q: This though, impracticable heart Is governed by a dainty-fingered girl.
Patriotic but loyal men went away disgusted afresh with the impracticable arrogance of a sovereign.

sn.def: Incapable of being used or availed of; as, an impracticable road; an impracticable method.
sn.syn: Impossible; infeasible.Impracticable Impossible. A thing is impracticable when it can not be accomplished by any human means at present possessed; a thing is impossible when the laws of nature forbid it. The navigation of a river may now be impracticable, but not impossible, because the existing obstructions may yet be removed. “The barons exercised the most despotic authority over their vassals, and every scheme of public utility was rendered impracticable by their continued petty wars with each other.” Mickle. “With men this is impossible, but with God all things are possible.” Matt. xix. 26.

entry.def: The state or quality of being impracticable; impracticability.
In an impracticable manner.
entry.q: Morality not impracticably rigid.

entry.def: Not practical.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Imprecated; p. pr. & vb. n. Imprecating
entry.ety: L. imprecatus, p. p. of imprecari to imprecate; pref. im- in, on + precari to pray. See Pray

sn.def: To call down by prayer, as something hurtful or calamitous.
sn.q: Imprecate the vengeance of Heaven on the guilty empire.

sn.def: To invoke evil upon; to curse; to swear at.
sn.q: In vain we blast the ministers of Fate, And the forlorn physicians imprecate.

entry.ety: L. imprecatio: cf. F. imprécation
entry.def: The act of imprecating, or invoking evil upon any one; a prayer that a curse or calamity may fall on any one; a curse.
entry.q: Men cowered like slaves before such horrid imprecations.
entry.syn: Malediction; curse; execration; anathema. See Malediction.

entry.def: Of the nature of, or containing, imprecation; invoking evil; as, the imprecatory psalms.
Lack of precision.

entry.ety: Cf. F. impregner. See Impregnate
entry.def: To impregnate; to make fruitful.
entry.q: His pernicious words, impregned With reason.
Semele doth Bacchus bearImpregned of Jove.

entry.def: The quality or state of being impregnable; invincibility.

entry.ety: F. imprenable; pref. im- not + prenable pregnable, fr. prendre to take, L. prehendere. See Comprehend Get to obtain
entry.def: Not to be stormed, or taken by assault; incapable of being subdued; able to resist attack; unconquerable; as, an impregnable fortress; impregnable virtue.
entry.q: The man's affection remains wholly unconcerned and impregnable.

entry.ety: See Impregnate
entry.def: Capable of being impregnated, as the egg of an animal, or the ovule of a plant.

entry.ety: See Impregnate
entry.def: That which impregnates.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + pregnant
entry.def: Not pregnant; unfertilized or infertile.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impregnated -n�*tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Impregnating -n�*tĭng
entry.ety: LL. impraegnatus, p. p. of impraegnare to impregnate, fr. L. pref. im- in + praegnans pregnant. See Pregnant

sn.def: To make pregnant; to cause to conceive; to render prolific; to get with child or young.
To come into contact with (an ovum or egg) so as to cause impregnation; to fertilize; to fecundate.
To infuse an active principle into; to render fruitful or fertile in any way; to fertilize; to imbue.

To infuse particles of another substance into; to communicate the quality of another to; to cause to be filled, imbued, mixed, or furnished (with something); as, to impregnate India rubber with sulphur; clothing impregnated with contagion; rock impregnated with ore.

entry.def: To become pregnant.

entry.ety: LL. impraegnatus, p. p
entry.def: Impregnated; made prolific.
entry.q: The scorching ray Here pierceth not, impregnate with disease.

entry.ety: p. p. from impregnate
entry.def: same as fertilized, 1.

entry.note: ☞ In the broadest biological sense, impregnation, or sexual generation, consists simply in the coalescence of two similar masses of protoplasmic matter, either derived from different parts of the same organism or from two distinct organisms. From the single mass, which results from the fusion, or coalescence, of these two masses, a new organism develops.
entry.ety: Cf. F. imprégnation, LL. impraegnatio

sn.def: The act of impregnating or the state of being impregnated; fecundation.

The fusion of a female germ cell (ovum) with a male germ cell (in animals, a spermatozoön) to form a single new cell endowed with the power of developing into a new individual; fertilization; fecundation.
That with which anything is impregnated.
Intimate mixture; infusion; saturation.
An ore deposit, with indefinite boundaries, consisting of rock impregnated with ore.

entry.def: Not prejudged; unprejudiced; impartial.
Impregnable.
Lack of preparation.

entry.ety: It. See Emprise, and cf. Impress n., 4
entry.def: A device on a shield or seal, or used as a bookplate or the like.
entry.q: My impresa to your lordship; a swain Flying to a laurel for shelter.

entries.entry:
‖Im`pre*sa"ri*o n.; pl.Impresarios #. It., from impresa enterprise
The projector, manager, or conductor, of an opera or concert company.
Hence, broadly: Any manager who organizes performances of a group.

entry.ety: Cf. F. imprescriptibilité
entry.def: The quality of being imprescriptible.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + prescriptible: cf. F. imprescriptible

sn.def: Not capable of being lost or impaired by neglect, by disuse, or by the claims of another founded on prescription; -- of rights.
sn.q: The right of navigation, fishing, and others that may be exercised on the sea, belonging to the right of mere ability, are imprescriptible.

sn.def: Not derived from, or dependent on, external authority; self-evidencing; obvious.
sn.q: The imprescriptible laws of the pure reason.

entry.def: In an imprescriptible manner; obviously.
A device. See Impresa.
entry.q: An imprese, as the Italians call it, is a device in picture with his motto or word, borne by noble or learned personages.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impressed; p. pr. & vb. n. Impressing
entry.ety: L. impressus, p. p. of imprimere to impress; pref. im- in, on + premere to press. See Press to squeeze, and cf. Imprint

sn.def: To press, stamp, or print something in or upon; to mark by pressure, or as by pressure; to imprint (that which bears the impression).
sn.q: His heart, like an agate, with your print impressed.

sn.def: To produce by pressure, as a mark, stamp, image, etc.; to imprint (a mark or figure upon something).
To fix deeply in the mind; to present forcibly to the attention, etc.; to imprint; to inculcate.
sn.q: Impress the motives of persuasion upon our own hearts till we feel the force of them.

sn.def: To take by force for public service; as, to impress sailors or money.
sn.q: The second five thousand pounds impressed for the service of the sick and wounded prisoners.

entry.def: To be impressed; to rest.
entry.q: Such fiendly thoughts in his heart impress.

entries.entry:
Im"press
Impress gang a party of men, with an officer, employed to impress seamen for ships of war; a press gang. Impress money a sum of money paid, immediately upon their entering service, to men who have been impressed.
n.; pl.Impresses.
The act of impressing or making.
A mark made by pressure; an indentation; imprint; the image or figure of anything, formed by pressure or as if by pressure; result produced by pressure or influence. The impresses of the insides of these shells. This weak impress of love is as a figure Trenched in ice.
Characteristic; mark of distinction; stamp.
A device. See Impresa. To describe . . . emblazoned shields,Impresses quaint.
See Imprest Press to force into service The act of impressing, or taking by force for the public service; compulsion to serve; also, that which is impressed. Why such impress of shipwrights?

entry.def: having the conscious mind deeply or markedly affected or influenced; -- usually used with by or with.
The quality of being impressible; susceptibility.

entry.ety: Cf. F. impressible
entry.def: Capable of being impressed; susceptible; sensitive.

cs.cd: one of the early impressions taken from an engraving, before the plate or block is worn.

entry.ety: F. impression, L. impressio

sn.def: The act of impressing, or the state of being impressed; the communication of a stamp, mold, style, or character, by external force or by influence.
That which is impressed; stamp; mark; indentation; sensible result of an influence exerted from without.
sn.q: The stamp and clear impression of good sense.
To shelter us from impressions of weather, we must spin, we must weave, we must build.

sn.def: That which impresses, or exercises an effect, action, or agency; appearance; phenomenon.
sn.q: Portentous blaze of comets and impressions in the air.
A fiery impression falling from out of Heaven.

sn.def: Influence or effect on the senses or the intellect hence, interest, concern.
sn.q: His words impression left.
Such terrible impression made the dream.
I have a father's dear impression, And wish, before I fall into my grave, That I might see her married.

sn.def: An indistinct notion, remembrance, or belief.
Impressiveness; emphasis of delivery.
sn.q: Which must be read with an impression.

sn.def: The pressure of the type on the paper, or the result of such pressure, as regards its appearance; as, a heavy impression; a clear, or a poor, impression ; also, a single copy as the result of printing, or the whole edition printed at a given time; as, a copy from the fifth impression .
sn.q: Ten impressions which his books have had.

sn.def: In painting, the first coat of color, as the priming in house painting and the like.
A print on paper from a wood block, metal plate, or the like.

entry.def: The quality of being impressionable.

entry.ety: Cf. F. impressionnable
entry.def: Liable or subject to impression; capable of being molded; susceptible; impressible; as, a bad influence on impressionable youths.
entry.q: He was too impressionable; he had too much of the temperament of genius.
A pretty face and an impressionable disposition.

entry.def: The quality of being impressionable.

entry.ety: F. impressionnisme
entry.def: The theory or method of suggesting an effect or impression without elaboration of the details; -- a disignation of a recent fashion in painting and etching.

entry.ety: F. impressionniste
entry.def: One who adheres to the theory or method of impressionism in art; especially, a painter who paints in the impressionistic style; as, the skyrocketing prices of paintings by the French impressionists .
Pertaining to, or characterized by, impressionism.
Having the quality of not being impressed or affected; not susceptible.

entry.ety: Cf. F. impressif

sn.def: Making, or tending to make, an impression; having power to impress; adapted to excite attention and feeling, to touch the sensibilities, or affect the conscience; as, an impressive discourse; an impressive scene.
Capable of being impressed.

entry.def: The act of seizing for public use, or of impressing into public service; compulsion to serve; as, the impressment of provisions or of sailors.
entry.q: The great scandal of our naval serviceimpressmentdied a protracted death.

entry.ety: LL., a printer
entry.def: One who, or that which, impresses.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. impressure, LL. impressura
entry.def: Dent; impression.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Imprested; p. pr. & vb. n. Impresting
entry.ety: Pref. im- + prest: cf. It. imprestare. See Prest n.
entry.def: To advance on loan.

entry.ety: Cf. It. impresto imprestito, LL. impraestitum. See Imprest v. t., and Impress compulsion to serve
entry.def: A kind of earnest money; loan; -- specifically, money advanced for some public service, as in enlistment.
entry.q: The clearing of their imprests for what little of their debts they have received.

entry.def: A sum of money to be used as petty cash.
Lack of prevalence.
The state or quality of being impreventable; inevitability.
Not preventable; inevitable.

entry.ety: L., let it be printed

sn.def: A license to print or publish a book, paper, etc.; also, in countries subjected to the censorship of the press, approval of that which is published.
Permission granted from a designated eccliastical authority to publish a book or other document; -- required by church law for Catholics, especially ecclesiastics, who wish to publish.
Official approval for some proposed activity; as, a contract this large needs the imprimatur of the legal department.

entry.ety: F. imprimerie, fr. imprimer to imprint
entry.def: A print; impression.
A printing establishment.
The art of printing.
A beginning.
entry.q: Their springings andimprimings.

entry.ety: L., for in primis among the first, chiefly; in in + primus first
entry.def: In the first place; first in order.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Imptrinted; p. pr. & vb. n. Imprinting
entry.ety: OE. emprenten, F. empreint, p. p. of empreindre to imprint, fr. L. imprimere to impres, imprint. See 1st In- Print, and cf. Impress

sn.def: To impress; to mark by pressure; to indent; to stamp.
sn.q: And sees his num'rous herds imprint her sands.

sn.def: To stamp or mark, as letters on paper, by means of type, plates, stamps, or the like; to print the mark (figures, letters, etc., upon something).
sn.q: Nature imprints upon whate'er we see, That has a heart and life in it, “Be free.”

sn.def: To fix indelibly or permanently, as in the mind or memory; to impress.
sn.q: Ideas of those two different things distinctly imprinted on his mind.

sn.def: To create or acquire (a behavioral pattern) by the process of imprinting.

entry.ety: Cf. F. empreinte impress, stamp. See Imprint v. t.
entry.def: Whatever is impressed or imprinted; the impress or mark left by something; specifically, the name of the printer or publisher (usually) with the time and place of issue, in the title-page of a book, or on any printed sheet.
entry.q: Thatimprintof their hands.

entry.def: The learning of a behavioral pattern that occurs soon after birth or hatching in certain animals, in which a long-lasting response to an individual (such as a parent) or an object is rapidly acquired; it is particularly noted in the response of certain birds to the animal they first see after hatching, usually the parent, as in ducks who will follow the adult duck they first see.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Imprisoned; p. pr. & vb. n. Imprisoning
entry.ety: OE. enprisonen, OF. enprisoner, F. emprisonner; pref. en-L. in) + F. & OF. prison. See Prison

sn.def: To put in prison or jail; To arrest and detain in custody; to confine.
sn.q: He imprisoned was in chains remediless.

sn.def: To limit, restrain, or confine in any way.
sn.q: Try to imprison the resistless wind.
sn.syn: To incarcerate; confine; immure.

entry.def: One who imprisons.

entry.cs: False imprisonment. Law See under False.
entry.ety: OE. enprisonment; F. emprisonnement
entry.def: The act of imprisoning, or the state of being imprisoned; confinement; restraint.
entry.q: His sinews waxen weak and raw Through long imprisonment and hard constraint.
Every confinement of the person is an imprisonment, whether it be in a common prison, or in a private house, or even by foreibly detaining one in the public streets.

entries.entry:
Im*prob`a*bil"i*ty n.; pl.Improbabilities #. Cf. F. improbabilité
The quality or state of being improbable; unlikelihood; also, that which is improbable; an improbable event or result.

entry.ety: L. improbabilis; pref. im- not + probabilis probable: cf. F. improbable. See Probable
entry.def: Not probable; unlikely to be true; not to be expected under the circumstances or in the usual course of events; as, an improbable story or event.
entry.q: He . . . sent to Elutherius, then bishop of Rome, an improbable letter, as some of the contents discover.

entry.ety: L. improbatus, p. p. of improbare to disapprove; pref. im- not + probare to approve
entry.def: To disapprove of; to disallow.

entry.ety: L. improbatio

sn.def: The act of disapproving; disapprobation.
The act by which falsehood and forgery are proved; an action brought for the purpose of having some instrument declared false or forged.

entry.def: Implying, or tending to, improbation.

entry.ety: L. improbitas; pref. im- not + probitas probity: cf. F. improbité
entry.def: Lack of probity; lack of integrity or rectitude; dishonesty.
entry.q: Persons . . . cast out for notorious improbity.

entry.def: Lack of proficiency.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + profitable: cf. F. improfitable
entry.def: Unprofitable.
Not progressive.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + prolific: cf. F. improlifique
entry.def: Not prolific.

entry.ety: Pref. im- in + prolificate
entry.def: To impregnate.
Not ready.

entry.ety: F. impromptu, fr. L. in promptu in readiness, at hand; in in + promptus visibility, readiness, from promptus visible, ready. See Prompt
entry.def: Offhand; without previous study; extemporaneous; extempore; as, an impromptu verse.

sn.def: Something made or done offhand, at the moment, or without previous study; an extemporaneous composition, address, or remark.
A piece composed or played at first thought; a composition in the style of an extempore piece.

entry.cs: Improper diphthong. See under Diphthong. Improper feud an original feud, not earned by military service. Mozley & W. Improper fraction. See under Fraction.
entry.ety: F. impropre, L. improprius; pref. im- not + proprius proper. See Proper

sn.def: Not proper; not suitable; not fitted to the circumstances, design, or end; unfit; not becoming; incongruous; inappropriate; indecent; as, an improper medicine; improper thought, behavior, language, dress.
sn.q: Follow'd his enemy king, and did him service,Improper for a slave.
And to their proper operation still, Ascribe all Good; to their improper, Ill.

sn.def: Not peculiar or appropriate to individuals; general; common.
sn.q: Not to be adorned with any art but such improper ones as nature is said to bestow, as singing and poetry.

sn.def: Not according to facts; inaccurate; erroneous.

entry.def: To appropriate; to limit.
entry.q: He would in like manner improper and inclose the sunbeams to comfort the rich and not the poor.

entry.ety: L. improperare improperatum, to taunt
entry.def: The act of upbraiding or taunting; a reproach; a taunt.
entry.q: Improperatios and terms of scurrility.

entry.ety: L., reproaches
entry.def: A series of antiphons and responses, expressing the sorrowful remonstrance of our Lord with his people; -- sung on the morning of the Good Friday in place of the usual daily Mass of the Roman ritual.
In an improper manner; not properly; unsuitably; unbecomingly.
Impropriety.
Unpropitious; unfavorable.
entry.q: Dreams wereimpropitious.

entry.def: Not proportionable.
Not proportionate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impropriated; p. pr. & vb. n. Impropriating
entry.ety: Pref. im- in + L. propriatus, p. p. of propriare to appropriate. See Appropriate

sn.def: To appropriate to one's self; to assume.
sn.q: To impropriate the thanks to himself.

sn.def: To place the profits of (ecclesiastical property) in the hands of a layman for care and disbursement.

entry.def: To become an impropriator.
Put into the hands of a layman; impropriated.

sn.def: The act of impropriating; as, the impropriation of property or tithes; also, that which is impropriated.

sd.def: The act of putting an ecclesiastical benefice in the hands of a layman, or lay corporation.
A benefice in the hands of a layman, or of a lay corporation.

entry.def: One who impropriates; specifically, a layman in possession of church property.

entries.entry: Im*pro`pri*a"trix n.; pl. E. -trixes, L. -trices. A female impropriator.

Im`pro*pri"e*ty n.; pl.Improprieties #. L. improprietas; cf. F. impropriété. See Improper
The quality of being improper; unfitness or unsuitableness to character, time place, or circumstances; as, impropriety of behavior or manners.
That which is improper; an unsuitable or improper act, or an inaccurate use of language. But every language has likewise its improprieties and absurdities. Many gross improprieties, however authorized by practice, ought to be discarded.

entry.ety: Cf. F. improspérité
entry.def: Lack of prosperity.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + prosperous: cf. F. improspère, L. improsper
entry.def: Not prosperous.
The state or quality of being improvable; improvableness.

entry.ety: From Improve

sn.def: Capable of being improved; susceptible of improvement; admitting of being made better; capable of cultivation, or of being advanced in good qualities.
sn.q: Man is accommodated with moral principles, improvable by the exercise of his faculties.
I have a fine spread of improvable lands.

sn.def: Capable of being used to advantage; profitable; serviceable; advantageous.
sn.q: The essays of weaker heads afford improvable hints to better.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + prove: cf. L. improbare, F. improuver

sn.def: To disprove or make void; to refute.
sn.q: Neither can any of them make so strong a reason which another can not improve.

sn.def: To disapprove; to find fault with; to reprove; to censure; as, to improve negligence.
sn.q: When he rehearsed his preachings and his doing unto the high apostles, they could improve nothing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Improved; p. pr. & vb. n. Improving
entry.ety: Pref. in- in + prove, in approve. See Approve Prove.

sn.def: To make better; to increase the value or good qualities of; to ameliorate by care or cultivation; as, to improve land.
sn.q: I love not to improve the honor of the living by impairing that of the dead.

sn.def: To use or employ to good purpose; to make productive; to turn to profitable account; to utilize; as, to improve one's time; to improve his means.
sn.q: We shall especially honor God by improving diligently the talents which God hath committed to us.
A hint that I do not remember to have seen opened and improved.
The court seldom fails to improve the opportunity.
How doth the little busy beeImprove each shining hour.
Those moments were diligently improved.
True policy, as well as good faith, in my opinion, binds us to improve the occasion.

sn.def: To advance or increase by use; to augment or add to; -- said with reference to what is bad.
sn.q: We all have, I fear, . . . not a little improved the wretched inheritance of our ancestors.
sn.syn: To better; meliorate; ameliorate; advance; heighten; mend; correct; rectify; amend; reform.

cs.cd: to make useful additions or amendments to, or changes in; to bring nearer to perfection; as, to improve on the mode of tillage.

sn.def: To grow better; to advance or make progress in what is desirable; to make or show improvement; as, to improve in health.
sn.q: We take care to improve in our frugality and diligence.

sn.def: To advance or progress in bad qualities; to grow worse.
sn.q: Domitianimprovedin cruelty.

sn.def: To increase; to be enhanced; to rise in value; as, the price of cotton improves .

entry.sn: advanced to a more desirable or valuable or excellent state. Opposite of unimproved.Narrower terms: built, reinforced; cleared, tilled ; developed; grade ; graded, graveled Also See: restored.

sn.def: changed for the better; as, her improved behavior.
sn.syn: amended.

sn.def: The act of improving; advancement or growth; promotion in desirable qualities; progress toward what is better; melioration; as, the improvement of the mind, of land, roads, etc.
sn.q: I look upon your city as the best place of improvement.
Exercise is the chief source of improvement in all our faculties.

sn.def: The act of making profitable use or applicaton of anything, or the state of being profitably employed; a turning to good account; practical application, as of a doctrine, principle, or theory, stated in a discourse.
sn.q: A goodimprovementof his reason.
I shall make some improvement of this doctrine.

sn.def: The state of being improved; betterment; advance; also, that which is improved; as, the new edition is an improvement on the old.
sn.q: The parts of Sinon, Camilla, and some few others, are improvements on the Greek poet.

sn.def: Increase; growth; progress; advance.
sn.q: There is a design of publishing the history of architecture, with its several improvements and decays.
Those vices which more particularly receive improvement by prosperity.

sn.def: Valuable additions or betterments, as buildings, clearings, drains, fences, etc., on land or premises; as, to convey the land together with all improvements .
A useful addition to, or modification of, a machine, manufacture, or composition.

entry.def: One who, or that which, improves.
Unforeseen; unexpected; not provided against; unprepared.
entry.q: All improvided for dread of death.

entry.ety: L. improvidentia; OF. improvidence. Cf. Imprudence
entry.def: The quality of being improvident; lack of foresight or thrift.
entry.q: The improvidence of my neighbor must not make me inhuman.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + provident: cf. L. improvidus. See Provident, and cf. Imprudent
entry.def: Not provident; wanting foresight or forethought; not foreseeing or providing for the future; negligent; thoughtless; as, an improvident man.
entry.q: Improvident soldiers! had your watch been good, This sudden mischief never could have fallen.
entry.syn: Inconsiderable; negligent; careless; shiftless; prodigal; wasteful.

entry.def: Improvidently.
In a improvident manner.
entry.q: Improvidentlyrash.

cs.cd: an extended lease to induce the tenant to make improvements on the premises.

entry.def: Tending to improve, beneficial; growing better.

entry.ety: See Improvise
entry.def: Unpremeditated; impromptu; extempore.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Improvisated; p. pr. & vb. n. Improvisating
entry.def: To improvise; to extemporize.

entry.ety: Cf. F. improvisation

sn.def: The act or art of composing and rendering music, poetry, and the like, extemporaneously; as, improvisation on the organ.
That which is improvised; an impromptu.

entry.def: Same as Improvisate.
An improviser, or improvvisatore.
See Improvvisatore.
Of or pertaining to improvisation or extemporaneous composition.
See Improvvisatrice.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Improvised; p. pr. & vb. n. Improvising
entry.ety: F. improviser, it. improvvisare, fr. improvviso unprovided, sudden, extempore, L. improvisus; pref. im- not + provisus foreseen, provided. See Proviso

sn.def: To compose, recite, or sing extemporaneously, especially in verse; to extemporize; also, to play upon an instrument, or to act, extemporaneously.
To bring about, arrange, do, or make, immediately or on short notice, without previous preparation and with no known precedent as a guide.
sn.q: Charles attempted to improvise a peace.

sn.def: To invent, or provide, offhand, or on the spur of the moment; as, he improvised a hammer out of a stone.

entry.def: To produce or render extemporaneous compositions, especially in verse or in music, without previous preparation; hence, to do anything offhand.
One who improvises.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + provision
entry.def: Improvidence.

entry.ety: L. improvisus unforeseen; cf. It. improvviso
entry.def: Not prepared or mediated beforehand; extemporaneous.

entries.entry:
‖Im`prov*vi`sa*to"re n.; pl.Improvvisatori #. It. See Improvise
One who composes and sings or recites rhymes and short poems extemporaneously.
improvisatore

‖Im`prov*vi`sa*tri"ce n.; pl.Improvvisatrici #. It. See Improvise
A female improvvisatore.
improvisatrice

entry.ety: L. imprudentia: cf. F. imprudence. Cf. Improvidence
entry.def: The quality or state of being imprudent; want to caution, circumspection, or a due regard to consequences; indiscretion; inconsideration; rashness; also, an imprudent act; as, he was guilty of an imprudence .
entry.q: His serenity was interrupted, perhaps, by his own imprudence.

entry.ety: L. imprudens; pref. im- not + prudens prudent: cf. F. imprudent. See Prudent, and cf. Improvident
entry.def: Not prudent; wanting in prudence or discretion; indiscreet; injudicious; not attentive to consequence; improper.
entry.q: Her majesty took a great dislike at the imprudent behavior of many of the ministers and readers.
entry.syn: Indiscreet; injudicious; incautious; ill-advised; unwise; heedless; careless; rash; negligent.

entry.def: Not having arrived at puberty; immature.
entry.q: In impuberal animals the cerebellum is, in proportion to the brain proper, greatly less than in adults.

entry.def: The condition of not having reached puberty, or the age of ability to reproduce one's species; lack of age at which the marriage contract can be legally entered into.

entry.usage: Impudence Effrontery Sauciness. Impudence refers more especially to the feelings as manifested in action. Effrontery applies to some gross and public exhibition of shamelessness. Sauciness refers to a sudden pert outbreak of impudence, especially from an inferior. Impudence is an unblushing kind of impertinence, and may be manifested in words, tones, gestures, looks, etc. Effrontery rises still higher, and shows a total or shameless disregard of duty or decorum under the circumstances of the case. Sauciness discovers itself toward particular individuals, in certain relations; as in the case of servants who are saucy to their masters, or children who are saucy to their teachers. See Impertinent, and Insolent.
entry.ety: L. impudentia: cf. F. impudence. See Impudent
entry.def: The quality of being impudent; assurance, accompanied with a disregard of the presence or opinions of others; shamelessness; forwardness; lack of modesty.
entry.q: Clear truths that their own evidence forces us to admit, or common experience makes it impudence to deny.
Where pride and impudencein fashion knit Usurp the chair of wit.
entry.syn: Shamelessness; audacity; insolence; effrontery; sauciness; impertinence; pertness; rudeness.

entry.def: Impudence.
entry.q: Audacious without impudency.

entry.ety: L. impudens -entis; pref. im- not + pudens ashamed, modest, p. pr. of pudere to feel shame: cf. F. impudent

sn.def: Behaving boldly, with contempt or disregard for propriety in behavior toward others; unblushingly forward; impertinent; saucy.
sn.q: More than impudent sauciness.
When we behold an angel, not to fear Is to be impudent.

sn.def: Lacking modesty; shameless.
sn.syn: Shameless; audacious; brazen; bold-faced; pert; immodest; rude; saucy; impertinent; insolent.

entry.def: In an impudent manner; with unbecoming assurance; shamelessly.
entry.q: At once assail With open mouths, and impudently rail.

entry.ety: L. impudicus immodest; im- not + pudicus shamefaced, modest: cf. F. impudicité, L. impudicitia
entry.def: Immodesty.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impugned; p. pr. & vb. n. Impugning
entry.ety: OE. impugnen, F. impugner, fr. L. impugnare; in on, against + pugnare to flight. See Pugnacious
entry.def: To attack by words or arguments; to contradict; to assail; to call in question; to make insinuations against; to gainsay; to oppose; as, to impugn a person's integrity.
entry.q: The truth hereof I will not rashly impugn, or overboldly affirm.

entry.def: Capable of being impugned; that may be gainsaid.

entry.ety: L. impugnatio: cf. OF. impugnation
entry.def: Act of impugning; opposition; attack.
entry.q: A perpetual impugnation and self-conflict.

entry.def: One who impugns.
The act of impugning, or the state of being impugned.

entry.ety: Cf. F. impuissance
entry.def: Lack of power; inability.
entry.q: Their own impuissance and weakness.

entry.ety: F., fr. pref. im- not + puissant. See Puissant
entry.def: Weak; impotent; feeble.

entry.ety: L. impulsus, fr. impellere. See Impel

sn.def: The act of impelling, or driving onward with sudden force; impulsion; especially, force so communicated as to produced motion suddenly, or immediately.
sn.q: All spontaneous animal motion is performed by mechanical impulse.

sn.def: The effect of an impelling force; motion produced by a sudden or momentary force.
The action of a force during a very small interval of time; the effect of such action; as, the impulse of a sudden blow upon a hard elastic body.

A mental force which simply and directly urges to action; hasty inclination; sudden motive; momentary or transient influence of appetite or passion; propension; incitement; as, a man of good impulses; passion often gives a violent impulse to the will; to buy something on impulse.
sn.q: These were my natural impulses for the undertaking.
sn.syn: Force; incentive; influence; motive; feeling; incitement; instigation.

entry.ety: See Impel
entry.def: To impel; to incite.
to buy on impulse without proper reflection.

entry.ety: L. impulsio: cf. F. impulsion. See Impel

sn.def: The act of impelling or driving onward, or the state of being impelled; the sudden or momentary agency of a body in motion on another body; also, the impelling force, or impulse.
sn.q: Theimpulsionof the air.

sn.def: Influence acting unexpectedly or temporarily on the mind; sudden motive or influence; impulse.
sn.q: Theimpulsionof conscience.
Divineimpulsionprompting.

entry.ety: Cf. F. impulsif

sn.def: Having the power of driving or impelling; giving an impulse; moving; impellent.
sn.q: Poor men! poor papers! We and they Do some impulsive force obey.

sn.def: Actuated by impulse or by transient feelings.
sn.q: My heart, impulsive and wayward.

sn.def: Acting momentarily, or by impulse; not continuous; -- said of forces.

entry.def: That which impels or gives an impulse; an impelling agent.
In an impulsive manner.
The quality of being impulsive.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who, or that which, impels; an inciter.
Not punctate or dotted.

entry.ety: Pref. im- not + punctual: cf. F. imponctuel
entry.def: Not punctual.
Neglect of, or failure in, punctuality.

entry.ety: L. impunis
entry.def: Unpunished.
Without punishment; with impunity.

entry.ety: L. impunitas, fr. impunis without punishment; pref. im- not + poena punishment: cf. F. impunité. See Pain
entry.def: Exemption or freedom from punishment, harm, or loss.
entry.q: Heaven, though slow to wrath, Is never with impunity defied.
The impunity and also the recompense.

entry.def: Defilement; obscuration.

entry.ety: L. impurus; pref. im- not + purus pure: cf. F. impur. See Pure

sn.def: Not pure; not clean; dirty; foul; filthy; containing something which is unclean or unwholesome; mixed or impregnated extraneous substances; adulterated; as, impure water or air; impure drugs, food, etc.
Defiled by sin or guilt; unholy; unhallowed; -- said of persons or things.
Unchaste; lewd; unclean; obscene; as, impure language or ideas.
sn.q: Impuredesires.

sn.def: Not purified according to the ceremonial law of Moses; unclean.
Not accurate; not idiomatic; as, impure Latin; an impure style.

entry.def: To defile; to pollute.
In an impure manner.
The quality or condition of being impure; impurity.

entries.entry:
Im*pu"ri*ty n.; pl. Impurities #. L. impuritas: cf. F. impureté
The condition or quality of being impure in any sense; defilement; foulness; adulteration. Profaneness, impurity, or scandal, is not wit.
That which is, or which renders anything, impure; foul matter, action, language, etc.; a foreign ingredient. Foul impurities reigned among the monkish clergy.
Script Lack of ceremonial purity; defilement.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Impurpled; p. pr. & vb. n. Impurpling
entry.ety: Pref. im- in + purple. Cf. Empurple
entry.def: To color or tinge with purple; to make red or reddish; to purple; as, a field impurpled with blood.
entry.q: Impurpled with celestial roses, smiled.
The silken fleece impurpled for the loom.

entry.def: The quality of being imputable; imputableness.

entry.ety: Cf. F. imputable

sn.def: That may be imputed; capable of being imputed; chargeable; ascribable; attributable; referable.
sn.q: A prince whose political vices, at least, were imputable to mental incapacity.

sn.def: Accusable; culpable.
sn.q: The fault lies at his door, and she is no wise imputable.

entry.def: Quality of being imputable.
By imputation.

entry.ety: L. imputatio an account, a charge: cf. F. imputation

sn.def: The act of imputing or charging; attribution; ascription; also, anything imputed or charged.
sn.q: Shylock. Antonio is a good man.Bassanio. Have you heard any imputation to the contrary?
If I had a suit to Master Shallow, I would humor his men with the imputation of being near their master.

sn.def: Charge or attribution of evil; censure; reproach; insinuation.
sn.q: Let us be careful to guard ourselves against these groundless imputation of our enemies.
