sn.def: A setting of something to the account of; the attribution of personal guilt or personal righteousness of another; as, the imputation of the sin of Adam, or the righteousness of Christ.
Opinion; intimation; hint.

entry.ety: L. imputativus: cf. F. imputatif
entry.def: Transferred by imputation; that may be imputed.
entry.q: Actual righteousness as well as imputative.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Imputed; p. pr. & vb. n. Imputing
entry.ety: F. imputer, L. imputare to bring into the reckoning, charge, impute; pref. im- in + putare to reckon, think. See Putative

sn.def: To charge; to ascribe; to attribute; to set to the account of; to charge to one as the author, responsible originator, or possessor; -- generally in a bad sense.
sn.q: Nor you, ye proud, impute to these the fault, If memory o'er their tomb no trophies raise.
One vice of a darker shade was imputed to him -- envy.

sn.def: To adjudge as one's own (the sin or righteousness) of another; as, the righteousness of Christ is imputed to us.
sn.q: It was imputed to him for righteousness.
They meritImputed shall absolve them who renounce Their own, both righteous and unrighteous deeds.

sn.def: To take account of; to consider; to regard.
sn.q: If we impute this last humiliation as the cause of his death.
sn.syn: To ascribe; attribute; charge; reckon; consider; imply; insinuate; refer. See Ascribe.

entry.def: One who imputes.

entry.ety: Pref. im- + putrescible: cf. F. imputrescible
entry.def: Not putrescible.

entry.ety: Scot.; Gael. eun-bhrigh chicken soup
entry.def: A peculiar strong soup or broth, made in Scotland.

entries.entry:
In- ĭn-. See In prep. Cf. Em- En-
A prefix from Eng. prep. in, also from Lat. prep. in, meaning in into on among; as, inbred, inborn, inroad; incline, inject, intrude. In words from the Latin, in- regularly becomes il- before l ir- before r, and im- before a labial; as, illusion, irruption, imblue, immigrate, impart. In- is sometimes used with an simple intensive force.

In- ĭn-. L. in-; akin to E. un-. See Un-
An inseparable prefix, or particle, meaning not non-, un- as, inactive, incapable, inapt. In- regularly becomes il- before l ir- before r, and im- before a labial.
-in. A suffix. See the Note under -ine.

In
In as much asorInasmuch as
in the degree that; in like manner as; in consideration that; because that; since. See Synonym of Because, and cf. For as much as, under For prep.
In that because; for the reason that. “Some things they do in that they are men . . . ; some things in that they are men misled and blinded with error.” Hooker. In the name of in behalf of; on the part of; by authority; as, it was done in the name of the people; -- often used in invocation, swearing, praying, and the like. To be in for it. To be in favor of a thing; to be committed to a course. To be unable to escape from a danger, penalty, etc. Colloq
To be in withorTo keep in with . To be close or near; as, to keep a ship in with the land. To be on terms of friendship, familiarity, or intimacy with; to secure and retain the favor of. Colloq
prep. AS. in; akin to D. & G. in, Icel. ī, Sw. & Dan. i, OIr. & L. in, Gr. 'en. √197. Cf. 1st In- Inn
The specific signification of in is situation or place with respect to surrounding, environment, encompassment, etc. It is used with verbs signifying being, resting, or moving within limits, or within circumstances or conditions of any kind conceived of as limiting, confining, or investing, either wholly or in part. In its different applications, it approaches some of the meanings of, and sometimes is interchangeable with, within into on at of, and among. It is used: With reference to space or place; as, he lives in Boston; he traveled in Italy; castles in the air.
The babe lying in a manger. Thy sun sets weeping in the lowly west. Situated in the forty-first degree of latitude. Matter for censure in every page.
With reference to circumstances or conditions; as, he is in difficulties; she stood in a blaze of light.
Fetteredinamorous chains. Wrapt in sweet sounds, as in bright veils.
With reference to a whole which includes or comprises the part spoken of; as, the first in his family; the first regiment in the army.
Nine in ten of those who enter the ministry.
With reference to physical surrounding, personal states, etc., abstractly denoted; as, I am in doubt; the room is in darkness; to live in fear.
When shall we three meet again,In thunder, lightning, or in rain?
With reference to character, reach, scope, or influence considered as establishing a limitation; as, to be in one's favor.
Insight of God's high throne. Sounds inharmonious in themselves, and harsh.
With reference to movement or tendency toward a certain limit or environment; -- sometimes equivalent to into; as, to put seed in the ground; to fall in love; to end in death; to put our trust in God.
He would not plunge his brother in despair. She had no jewels to deposit in their caskets.
With reference to a limit of time; as, in an hour; it happened in the last century; in all my life.
Into; within; on; at. See At.

entry.note: ☞ The sails of a vessel are said, in nautical language, to be in when they are furled, or when stowed. In certain cases in has an adjectival sense; as, the in train (i. e., the incoming train); compare up grade, down grade, undertow, afterthought, etc.
entry.cs: In and in breeding. See under Breeding. In and out Naut through and through; -- said of a through bolt in a ship's side. Knight. To be in to be at home; as, Mrs. A. is in . To come in. See under Come.

sn.def: Not out; within; inside. In, the preposition, becomes an adverb by omission of its object, leaving it as the representative of an adverbial phrase, the context indicating what the omitted object is; as, he takes in the situation (i. e., he comprehends it in his mind); the Republicans were ini. e.in office); in at one ear and out at the other (i. e.in or into the head); his side was ini. e.in the turn at the bat); he came ini. e., into the house.
sn.q: Their vacation . . . falls in so pat with ours.

sn.def: With privilege or possession; -- used to denote a holding, possession, or seisin; as, in by descent; in by purchase; in of the seisin of her husband.

entry.note: Usually in the plural

cs.cd: nooks and corners; twists and turns.
the peculiarities or technicalities (of a subject); intricacies; details; -- used with of; as, he knew the ins and outs of the Washington power scene.

sn.def: One who is in office; -- the opposite of out.
A reëntrant angle; a nook or corner.
sn.q: All the ins and outs of this neighborhood.

entry.def: To inclose; to take in; to harvest.
entry.q: He that ears my land spares my team and gives me leave to in the crop.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + ability: cf. F. inhabileté. See Able, and cf. Unable
entry.def: The quality or state of being unable; lack of ability; lack of sufficient power, strength, resources, or capacity.
entry.q: It is not from an inability to discover what they ought to do, that men err in practice.
entry.syn: Impotence; incapacity; incompetence; weakness; powerlessness; incapability. See Disability.

entry.def: See Enable.
See Enablement.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + abstinence: cf. F. inabstinence
entry.def: Lack of abstinence; indulgence.
entry.q: Theinabstinenceof Eve.

entry.def: Not abstracted.
Without abuse.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inaccessibilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being inaccessible; inaccessibleness.
entry.q: Theinaccessibilityof the precipice.

entry.ety: L. inaccessibilis: cf. F. inaccessible. See In- not, and Accessible
entry.def: Not accessible; not to be reached, obtained, or approached; as, an inaccessible rock, fortress, document, prince, etc.
Not accordant; discordant.

entries.entry:
In*ac"cu*ra*cy n.; pl.Inaccuracies.
The quality of being inaccurate; lack of accuracy or exactness.
That which is inaccurate or incorrect; mistake; fault; defect; error; as, in inaccuracy in speech, copying, calculation, etc.

entry.note: The term inaccurate is usually used when an assertion or result is near to the truth, but not exactly, or has some basis for belief; however, it is sometimes used as a gentle euphemism for wrong even if the error is flagrant.
entry.def: Not accurate; not according to truth; inexact; not quite correct; incorrect; erroneous; as, in inaccurate man, narration, copy, judgment, calculation, etc.
entry.q: The expression is plainly inaccurate.
entry.syn: Inexact; incorrect; erroneous; faulty; imperfect; incomplete; defective.

entry.def: In an inaccurate manner; incorrectly; inexactly.
Lack of acquaintance.
Not acquiescent or acquiescing.

entry.ety: Pref. in. not + action: cf. inaction
entry.def: Lack of action or activity; forbearance from labor; idleness; rest; inertness.

entry.note: ☞ To inactivate an enzyme or chemical usually renders it permanently inactive; to inactivate a machine (as by turning a switch) may be reversible, and for machines and devices, the term deactivate is usually used. The distinction is worth preserving.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. inactivated; p. pr. & vb. n. inactivating
entry.def: to make inactive; as, boiling will inactivate most enzymes; acetylation of the antibiotic inactivated it.
The act or process of inactivating.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + active: cf. F. inactif

sn.def: Not active; having no power to move; that does not or can not produce results; inert; as, matter is, of itself, inactive .
Not disposed to action or effort; not diligent or industrious; not busy; idle; as, an inactive officer.

Not exhibiting any action or activity on polarized light; optically inactive; optically neutral; -- said of isomeric forms of certain substances, in distinction from other forms which are optically active; as, racemic acid is an inactive tartaric acid.

Lacking biological or biochemical activity; not causing a specific biological or biochemical effect; -- said of substances such as enzymes which have lost their catalytic power, or of small molecules which are tested for some type of biological activity and found to lack that activity; as, after boiling for ten minutes, the enzyme was totally inactive; the methyl analog was inactive as an antibiotic.
sn.syn: Inert; dull; sluggish; idle; indolent; slothful; lazy. See Inert.

entry.def: In an inactive manner.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inactivité

sn.def: The state or quality of being inactive; inertness; as, the inactivity of matter.
Idleness; habitual indisposition to action or exertion; lack of energy; sluggishness.
sn.q: The gloomy inactivity of despair.

entry.def: A variety of sugar, found in certain plants. It is optically inactive.
To put in action.
Operation.
Lack of adaptation; unsuitableness.

entry.ety: From Inadequate
entry.def: The quality or state of being inadequate or insufficient; defectiveness; insufficiency; inadequateness.
entry.q: The inadequacy and consequent inefficacy of the alleged causes.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + adequate: cf. F. inadéquat
entry.def: Not adequate; unequal to the purpose; insufficient; deficient; as, inadequate resources, power, conceptions, representations, etc.
Lack of exact correspondence.

sn.def: Not adhering.
Free; not connected with the other organs.

entry.def: Lack of adhesion.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inadmissibilité
entry.def: The state or quality of being inadmissible, or not to be received.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + admissible: cf. F. inadmissible
entry.def: Not admissible; not proper to be admitted, allowed, or received; as, inadmissible testimony; an inadmissible proposition, or explanation.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inadvertance

sn.def: The quality of being inadvertent; lack of heedfulness or attentiveness; inattention; negligence; as, many mistakes proceed from inadvertence .
sn.q: Inadvertency, or lack of attendance to the sense and intention of our prayers.

sn.def: An effect of inattention; a result of carelessness; an oversight, mistake, or fault from negligence.
sn.q: The productions of a great genius, with many lapses an inadvertencies, are infinitely preferable to works of an inferior kind of author which are scrupulously exact.
sn.syn: Inattention; heedlessness; carelessness; negligence; thoughtlessness. See Inattention.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inadvertant. See 2d In-, and Advert
entry.def: Not turning the mind to a matter; heedless; careless; negligent; inattentive.
entry.q: An inadvertent step may crush the snail That crawls at evening in the public path.

entry.def: Not advisable.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inaffabilité
entry.def: Lack of affability or sociability; reticence.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + affable
entry.def: Not affable; reserved in social intercourse.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + affectation: cf. F. inaffectation
entry.def: Freedom from affectation; naturalness.
Unaffected.
Incapable of being assisted; helpless.
The quality or state of being inalienable.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + alienable: cf. F. inaliénable
entry.def: Incapable of being alienated, surrendered, or transferred to another; not alienable; as, in inalienable birthright.
The quality or state of being inalienable; inalienability.
In a manner that forbids alienation; as, rights inalienably vested.
Affording no aliment or nourishment.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inaltérabilité
entry.def: The quality of being unalterable or unchangeable; permanence.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + alterable: cf. F. inaltérable
entry.def: Not alterable; incapable of being altered or changed; unalterable.
Unamiable.

entry.ety: L. inamissibilis: cf. F. inamissible
entry.def: Incapable of being lost.

entry.ety: It. innamorata, fem., innamorato, masc., p. p. of innamorare to inspire with love. See Enamor
entry.def: A woman in love; a mistress.
entry.q: The fairinamorata.

entry.def: Enamored.

entries.entry:
‖In*a`mo*ra"to n.; pl.Inamoratos #. See Inamorata
A male lover.

entry.def: Not amovable or removable.
An old game played with four dice. In signified a doublet, or two dice alike; in-and-in, either two doubles, or the four dice alike.
Applied to breeding from a male and female of the same parentage. See under Breeding.

entry.ety: L. inanis
entry.def: Without contents; empty; void of sense or intelligence; purposeless; pointless; characterless; useless.
entry.q: Vague andinaneinstincts.

entry.def: That which is void or empty.
entry.q: The undistinguishable inane of infinite space.

entry.def: Not angular.

entry.ety: L. inanis empty + loqui to speak
entry.def: Given to talking inanely; loquacious; garrulous.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in (or intensively) + animate
entry.def: To animate.

entry.ety: L. inanimatus; pref. in- not + animatus animate
entry.def: Not animate; destitute of life or spirit; lifeless; dead; inactive; dull; as, stones and earth are inanimate substances.
entry.q: Grieving, if aught inanimate e'er grieves.
entry.syn: Lifeless; dead; inert; inactive; dull; soulless; spiritless. See Lifeless.

entry.def: Destitute of life; lacking animation; unanimated.
The quality or state of being inanimate.
entry.q: The deadness and inanimateness of the subject.

entry.ety: See 2d Inanimate
entry.def: Lack of animation; lifeless; dullness.

entry.ety: See 1st Inanimate
entry.def: Infusion of life or vigor; animation; inspiration.
entry.q: The inanimation of Christ living and breathing within us.

entry.def: To produce inanition in; to exhaust for lack of nourishment.
Inanition.

entry.ety: F. inanition, L. inanitio emptiness, fr. inanire to empty, fr. inanis empty. Cf. Inane
entry.def: The condition of being inane; emptiness; lack of fullness, as in the vessels of the body; hence, specifically, exhaustion from lack of food, either from partial or complete starvation, or from a disorder of the digestive apparatus, producing the same result.
entry.q: Feeble from inanition, inert from weariness.
Repletion and inanition may both do harm in two contrary extremes.

entries.entry:
In*an"i*ty n.; pl.Inanities #. L. inanitas, fr. inanis empty: cf. F. inanité. See Inane
Inanition; void space; vacuity; emptiness.
Lack of seriousness; aimlessness; frivolity.
An inane, useless thing or pursuit; a vanity; a silly object; -- chiefly in pl.; as, the inanities of the world.

entry.def: Not bearing anthers; -- said of sterile stamens.

entries.entry: ‖In an"tis. L Arch Between antæ; -- said of a portico in classical style, where columns are set between two antæ, forming the angles of the building. See Anta.

entry.def: Sensibility; feeling; -- opposed to apathy.
Not admitting of appeal; not appealable.
Incapable of being appeased or satisfied; unappeasable.
The quality of being inappellable; finality.
entry.q: The inappellability of the councils.

entry.def: Inappealable; final.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + appetence: cf. F. inappétence
entry.def: Lack of appetency; lack of desire.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inapplicabilité
entry.def: The quality of being inapplicable; unfitness; inapplicableness.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + applicable
entry.def: Not applicable; incapable of being applied; not adapted; not suitable; as, the argument is inapplicable to the case.
entry.syn: Unsuitable; unsuited; unadapted; inappropriate; inapposite; irrelevant.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + application: cf. F. inapplication
entry.def: Lack of application, attention, or diligence; negligence; indolence.
Not apposite; not fit or suitable; not pertinent.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + appreciable: cf. F. inappréciable
entry.def: Not appreciable; too small to be perceived; incapable of being duly valued or estimated.
Lack of appreciation.

entry.ety: L. inapprehensibilis: cf. F. inappréhensible
entry.def: Not apprehensible; unintelligible; inconceivable.
Lack of apprehension.
Not apprehensive; regardless; unconcerned.
Not approachable; unapproachable; inaccessible; unequaled.
Not instrument (to); not appropriate; unbecoming; unsuitable; not specially fitted; -- followed by to or for.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + apt: cf. F. inapte. Cf. Inept
entry.def: Unapt; not apt; unsuitable; inept.

entry.ety: In- + aptitude: cf. F. inaptitude. Cf. Ineptitude
entry.def: Lack of aptitude.

entry.ety: L. inaquatus, p. p. of inaquare to make into water; pref. in- in + aqua water
entry.def: Embodied in, or changed into, water.
The state of being inaquate.
Not arable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inarched; p. pr. & vb. n. Inarching
entry.def: To graft by uniting, as a scion, to a stock, without separating either from its root before the union is complete; -- also called to graft by approach.
A method of ingrafting. See Inarch.

entry.ety: L. inarticulatus; pref. in- not + articulatus articulate

sn.def: Not uttered with articulation or intelligible distinctness, as speech or words.
sn.q: Music which is inarticulate poesy.

sd.def: Not jointed or articulated; having no distinct body segments; as, an inarticulate worm.
Without a hinge; -- said of an order (Inarticulata or Ecardines) of brachiopods.

sn.def: Incapable of articulating.
sn.q: The poor earl, who is inarticulate with palsy.

sn.def: Incapable of expressing one's ideas or feelings clearly.

entry.def: Not articulated; not jointed or connected by a joint.
In an inarticulate manner.
The state or quality of being inarticulate.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inarticulation
entry.def: Inarticulateness.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + artificial: cf. F. inartificiel
entry.def: Not artificial; not made or elaborated by art; natural; simple; artless; as, an inartificial argument; an inartificial character.

entry.ety: In + as + much
entry.def: In like degree; in like manner; seeing that; considering that; since; -- followed by as. See In as much as, under In prep.
entry.q: Inasmuch as ye did it not to one of the least of these, ye did it not to me.
entry.syn: Because; since; for; as. See Because.

entry.usage: Inattention Inadvertence. We miss seeing a thing through inadvertence when do not happen to look at it; through inattention when we give no heed to it, though directly before us. The latter is therefore the worse. Inadvertence may be an involuntary accident; inattention is culpable neglect. A versatile mind is often inadvertent; a careless or stupid one is inattentive.
entry.ety: Pref. in- not + attention: cf. F. inattention
entry.def: Lack of attention, or failure to pay attention; disregard; heedlessness; neglect.
entry.q: Novel lays attract our ravished ears; But old, the mind inattention hears.
entry.syn: Inadvertence; heedlessness; negligence; carelessness; disregard; remissness; thoughtlessness; neglect.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inattentif
entry.def: Not attentive; not fixing the mind on an object; heedless; careless; negligent; regardless; as, an inattentive spectator or hearer; an inattentive habit.
entry.syn: Careless; heedless; regardless; thoughtless; negligent; remiss; inadvertent.

entry.def: The quality of being inaudible; inaudibleness.

entry.ety: L. inaudibilis; pref. in- not + audire to hear: cf. F. unaudible. See In- not, and Audible
entry.def: Not audible; incapable of being heard; silent.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inaugurer. See Inaugurate
entry.def: To inaugurate.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inaugural
entry.def: Pertaining to, or performed or pronounced at, an inauguration; as, an inaugural address; the inaugural exercises.
An inaugural address.

entry.ety: L. inauguratus, p. p. of inaugurare to take omens from the flight of birds (before entering upon any important undertaking); hence, to consecrate, inaugurate, or install, with such divination; pref. in- in + augurare augurari, to augur. See Augur
entry.def: Invested with office; inaugurated.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inaugurated; p. pr. & vb. n. Inaugurating

sn.def: To introduce or induct into an office with suitable ceremonies or solemnities; to invest with power or authority in a formal manner; to install; as, to inaugurate a president; to inaugurate a king.

To cause to begin, esp. with formality or solemn ceremony; hence, to set in motion, action, or progress; to initiate; -- used especially of something of dignity or worth or public concern; as, to inaugurate a new era of things, new methods, etc.
sn.q: As if kings did choose remarkable days to inaugurate their favors.

sn.def: To celebrate the completion of, or the first public use of; to dedicate, as a statue.
To begin with good omens.

entry.ety: L. inauguratio a beginning: cf. F. inauguration

sn.def: The act of inuagurating, or inducting into office with solemnity; investiture by appropriate ceremonies.
sn.q: At his regal inauguration, his old father resigned the kingdom to him.

sn.def: The formal beginning or initiation of any movement, course of action, etc.; as, the inauguration of a new system, a new condition, etc.

entries.entry: In*au`gu*ra"tion Day. The day on which the President of the United States is inaugurated, the 20th of January in every year next after a year divisible by four. Prior to the adoption of the twentieth amendment to the Constitution of the United States (ratified February 6, 1933) the date was the 4th of March.

entry.def: One who inaugurates.
Suitable for, or pertaining to, inauguration.

entry.ety: L. inauratus, p. p. inaurare to gild; pref. in- in + aurum gold
entry.def: Covered with gold; gilded.
To cover with gold; to gild.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inauration
entry.def: The act or process of gilding or covering with gold.

entry.ety: L. inauspicatus; pref. in- not + auspicatus, p. p. auspicari. See Auspicate
entry.def: Inauspicious.
Not auspicious; ill-omened; unfortunate; unlucky; unfavorable.
entry.q: Inauspiciousstars.
Inauspiciouslove.

entry.def: Without authority; not authoritative.
To embark; to go or put into a barge.
a wood or metal receptacle placed on a desk to hold incoming material requiring attention, especially documents.
Shining in.
Inherence; inherent existence.
being neither at the beginning nor at the end in a series or time sequence; as, adolescence is an awkward in-between age.
To inclose.
Blown in or into.

sn.def: Inside the line of a vessel's bulwarks or hull; the opposite of outboard; as, an inboard engine; an inboard cargo; haul the boom inboard.
From without inward; toward the inside; as, the inboard stroke of a steam engine piston, the inward or return stroke.

entry.def: Born in or with; implanted by nature; innate; congenital; as, inborn passions.

entries.entry: in-bounds adj. Sports within the demarcated playing area. Opposite of out of bounds.Narrower terms: fair (vs. foul

entry.def: a wood or metal receptacle placed on a desk to hold incoming material requiring attention, especially documents.
A breaking in; inroad; invasion.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inbreathed; p. pr. & vb. n. Inbreathing
entry.def: To infuse by breathing; to inspire.
Bred within; innate; as, inbred worth.
entry.q: Inbredsentiments.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inbred; p. pr. & vb. n. Inbreeding
entry.ety: Cf. Imbreed

sn.def: To produce or generate within.
sn.q: To inbreed and cherish . . . the seeds of virtue.

sn.def: To breed in and in. See under Breed v. i.

entry.def: Burning within.
entry.q: Her inburning wrath she gan abate.

entry.def: Burnt in; ineffaceable.
entry.q: Her inburnt, shamefaced thoughts.

entry.def: A bursting in or into.
A Japanese measure of length equal to about two and one twelfth yards.

cs.cd: a small dove (Scardafella inca), native of Arizona, Lower California, and Mexico.

entry.def: An emperor or monarch of Peru before, or at the time of, the Spanish conquest; any member of this royal dynasty, reputed to have been descendants of the sun.
The people governed by the Incas, now represented by the Quichua tribe.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incaged; p. pr. & vb. n. Incaging
entry.ety: Cf. Encage
entry.def: To confine in, or as in, a cage; to coop up.
entry.q: Incagedbirds.

entry.def: Confinement in, or as in, cage.
The quality or state of being incalculable.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + calculable: cf. F. incalculable
entry.def: Not capable of being calculated; beyond calculation; very great; as, his action did incalculable harm.
The state of being incalescent, or of growing warm.
Incalescence.

entry.ety: L. incalescens -entis, p. pr. of incalescere to grow hot. See 1st In-, and Calescence
entry.def: Growing warm; increasing in heat.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + L. camera chamber, LL., also, jurisdiction: cf. F. incamération, It. incamerazione
entry.def: The act or process of uniting lands, rights, or revenues, to the ecclesiastical chamber, i. e., to the pope's domain.
Of or pertaining to the Incas.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incandescence
entry.def: A white heat, or the glowing or luminous whiteness of a body caused by intense heat.

cs.cd: a kind of lamp in which the light is produced by a thin filament of conducting material, now usually tungsten, but originally carbon, contained in a vacuum or an atmosphere of inert gas within a glass bulb, and heated to incandescence by an electric current. It was inventerd by Thomas Edison, and was once called the Edison lamp; -- called also incandescence lamp, and glowlamp. This is one of the two most common sources of electric light, the other being the fluorescent light fluorescent lamp or fluorescent bulb.

entry.ety: L. incandecens -entis, p. pr. of incandescere to become warm or hot; pref. in- in + candescere to become of a glittering whiteness, to become red hot, incho. fr. candere to be of a glittering whiteness: cf. F. incandescent. See Candle
entry.def: White, glowing, or luminous, with intense heat; as, incandescent carbon or platinum; hence, clear; shining; brilliant.
entry.q: Holy Scripture become resplendent; or, as one might say, incandescent throughout.

entry.ety: L. incanescens, p. pr. incanescere to become gray
entry.def: Becoming hoary or gray; canescent.

entry.ety: L. incanus; pref. in- in + canus hoary
entry.def: Hoary with white pubescence.

entry.ety: L. incantatio, fr. incantare to chant a magic formula over one: cf. F. incantation. See Enchant

sn.def: The act or process of using formulas sung or spoken, with occult ceremonies, for the purpose of raising spirits, producing enchantment, or affecting other magical results; enchantment.
sn.q: Mysterious ceremony andincantation.

sn.def: A formula of words used as above.
The repetitive invoking of old sayings, or emitting a wordy discourse with little or no meaning, to avoid serious discussion; obfuscation; as, to defend one's views with empty incantations .

entry.def: Dealing by enchantment; magical.
Enchanting.
To unite to, or form into, a canton or separate community.

sn.def: The quality of being incapable; incapacity.
Lack of legal qualifications, or of legal power; as, incapability of holding an office.

entry.note: ☞ Incapable is often used elliptically.
entry.ety: Pref. in- not + capable: cf. F. incapable, L. incapabilis incomprehensible

sn.def: Lacking in ability or qualification for the purpose or end in view; not large enough to contain or hold; deficient in physical strength, mental or moral power, etc.; not capable; as, incapable of holding a certain quantity of liquid; incapable of endurance, of comprehension, of perseverance, of reform, etc.
Not capable of being brought to do or perform, because morally strong or well disposed; -- used with reference to some evil; as, incapable of wrong, dishonesty, or falsehood.
Not in a state to receive; not receptive; not susceptible; not able to admit; as, incapable of pain, or pleasure; incapable of stain or injury.

Unqualified or disqualified, in a legal sense; as, a man under thirty-five years of age is incapable of holding the office of president of the United States; a person convicted on impeachment is thereby made incapable of holding an office of profit or honor under the government.
As a term of disgrace, sometimes annexed to a sentence when an officer has been cashiered and rendered incapable of serving his country.
sn.q: Is not your father grown incapable of reasonable affairs?
sn.syn: Incompetent; unfit; unable; insufficient; inadequate; deficient; disqualified. See Incompetent.

entry.def: One who is morally or mentally weak or inefficient; an imbecile; a simpleton.
The quality or state of being incapable; incapability.
In an incapable manner.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + capacious: cf. L. incapax incapable
entry.def: Not capacious; narrow; small; weak or foolish; as, an incapacious soul.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incapacitated; p. pr. & vb. n. Incapacitating
entry.ety: Pref. in- not + capacitate

sn.def: To deprive of capacity or natural power; to disable; to render incapable or unfit; to disqualify; as, his age incapacitated him for war.
To deprive of legal or constitutional requisites, or of ability or competency for the performance of certain civil acts; to disqualify.
sn.q: It absolutely incapacitated them from holding rank, office, function, or property.

entry.def: causing disability.
The act of incapacitating or state of being incapacitated; incapacity; disqualification.

entries.entry:
In`ca*pac"i*ty n.; pl.Incapacities. Cf. F. incapacité
Lack of capacity; lack of physical or intellectual power; inability.
Law Lack of legal ability or competency to do, give, transmit, or receive something; inability; disqualification; as, the inacapacity of minors to make binding contracts, etc.
Inability; incapability; incompetency; unfitness; disqualification; disability.

entry.def: To inclose completely, as in a membrane.
The process of becoming, or the state or condition of being, incapsulated; as, incapsulation of the ovum in the uterus.

cs.cd: hernia in which the constriction can not be easily reduced.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incarcerated; p. pr. & vb. n. Incarcerating
entry.ety: Pref. in- in + L. carceratus, p. p. of carcerare to imprison, fr. carcer prison

sn.def: To imprison; to confine in a jail or prison.
To confine; to shut up or inclose; to hem in.

entry.def: Imprisoned.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incarcération

sn.def: The act of confining, or the state of being confined; imprisonment.

sd.def: Formerly, strangulation, as in hernia.
A constriction of the hernial sac, rendering it irreducible, but not great enough to cause strangulation.

entry.def: One who incarcerates.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incarner. See Incarnate
entry.def: To cover or invest with flesh.
To develop flesh.

entry.ety: F. incarnadin, It. incarnatino; L. pref. in- in + caro carnis, flesh. Cf. Carnation Incarnate
entry.def: Flesh-colored; of a carnation or pale red color.
To dye red or crimson.
entry.q: Will all great Neptune's ocean wash this blood Clean from my hand? No; this my hand will rather The multitudinous seas incarnadine, Making the green one red.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + carnate
entry.def: Not in the flesh; spiritual.
entry.q: I fear nothing . . . that devil carnate or incarnate can fairly do.

entry.ety: L. incarnatus, p. p. of incarnare to incarnate, pref. in- in + caro carnis, flesh. See Carnal

sn.def: Invested with flesh; embodied in a human nature and form; united with, or having, a human body.
sn.q: Here shalt thou sit incarnate.
He represents the emperor and his wife as two devils incarnate, sent into the world for the destruction of mankind.

sn.def: Flesh-colored; rosy; red.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incarnated; p. pr. & vb. n. Incarnating
entry.def: To clothe with flesh; to embody in flesh; to invest, as spirits, ideals, etc., with a human from or nature.
entry.q: This essence to incarnate and imbrute, That to the height of deity aspired.

entry.def: To form flesh; to granulate, as a wound.
entry.q: My uncle Toby's wound was nearly well -- 't was just beginning to incarnate.

entry.ety: F. incarnation, LL. incarnatio

sn.def: The act of clothing with flesh, or the state of being so clothed; the act of taking, or being manifested in, a human body and nature.
The union of the second person of the Godhead with manhood in Christ.
An incarnate form; a personification; a manifestation; a reduction to apparent from; a striking exemplification in person or act.
sn.q: She is a new incarnation of some of the illustrious dead.
The very incarnation of selfishness.

sn.def: A rosy or red color; flesh color; carnation.
The process of healing wounds and filling the part with new flesh; granulation.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incarnatif
entry.def: Causing new flesh to grow; healing; regenerative.

entry.ety: See Incarnation, and -fy
entry.def: The act of assuming, or state of being clothed with, flesh; incarnation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incased; p. pr. & vb. n. Incasing
entry.ety: F. encaisser; pref. en-L. in) + caisse case. See Case a box, and cf. Encase Enchase
entry.def: To inclose in a case; to inclose; to cover or surround with something solid.
entry.q: Rich plates of gold the folding doors incase.

entry.ety: Cf. Casement

sn.def: The act or process of inclosing with a case, or the state of being incased.
That which forms a case, covering, or inclosure.

entry.def: To cover with a casque or as with a casque.
Confined or inclosed in a castle.
Hoofbound.

entry.ety: LL. incatenatio; L. pref. in- in + catena chain. See Enchain
entry.def: The act of linking together; enchaining.
Lack of caution.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + cautious: cf. L. incautus
entry.def: Not cautious; not circumspect; not attending to the circumstances on which safety and interest depend; heedless; careless; as, an incautious step; an incautious remark.
entry.q: You . . . incautious tread On fire with faithless embers overspread.
His rhetorical expressions may easily captivate any incautious reader.
entry.syn: Unwary; indiscreet; inconsiderate; imprudent; impolitic; careless; heedless; thoughtless.

entry.ety: L. incavatus, p. p. of incavare to make hollow: pref in- in + cavare to hollow out, fr. cavus hollow
entry.def: Made hollow; bent round or in.
Act of making hollow; also, a hollow; an excavation; a depression.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + cave. Cf. Encave Incavated
entry.def: Inclosed in a cave.
Inclosed or shut up as in a cavern.

entry.ety: L. incedere to walk majestically
entry.def: Majestically.
Lack of celebrity or distinction; obscurity.

entry.ety: L. incendere incensum, to kindle, burn. See Incense to inflame
entry.def: To inflame; to excite.

entry.ety: From Incendiary
entry.def: The act or practice of maliciously setting fires; arson.

entries.entry:
In*cen"di*a*ry ?; 277 n.; pl.Incendiaries #. L. incendiarius: cf. F. incendiaire. See Incense to inflame
Any person who maliciously sets fire to a building or other valuable or other valuable property.
A person who excites or inflames factions, and promotes quarrels or sedition; an agitator; an exciter. Several cities . . . drove them out as incendiaries.

cs.cd: a device designed to set a structure on fire; a firebomb.
a bombshell. See Carcass, 4.

entry.ety: L. incendiarius, fr. incendium a fire, conflagration: cf. F. incendiaire. See Incense to inflame

sn.def: Of or pertaining to incendiarism, or the malicious burning of valuable property; as, incendiary material; as incendiary crime.
Tending to excite or inflame factions, sedition, or quarrel; inflammatory; seditious.

entry.ety: L. incendiosus burning, hot
entry.def: Promoting faction or contention; seditious; inflammatory.

entry.ety: See Incense to anger
entry.def: A modern term applied to animals (as a boar) when borne as raging, or with furious aspect.
The offering of incense.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incensed; p. pr. & vb. n. Incensing
entry.ety: L. incensus, p. p. of incendere; pref. in- in + root of candere to glow. See Candle

sn.def: To set on fire; to inflame; to kindle; to burn.
sn.q: Twelve Trojan princes wait on thee, and labor to incense Thy glorious heap of funeral.

sn.def: To inflame with anger; to enrage; to endkindle; to fire; to incite; to provoke; to heat; to madden.
sn.q: The people are incensed him.
sn.syn: To enrage; exasperate; provoke; anger; irritate; heat; fire; instigate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incensed; p. pr. & vb. n. Incensing
entry.ety: LL. incensare: cf. F. encenser. See Incense n.

sn.def: To offer incense to. See Incense.
To perfume with, or as with, incense.
sn.q: Incensedwith wanton sweets.

cs.cd: the name of several balsamic trees of the genus Burseraor Icica) mostly tropical American. The gum resin is used for incense. In Jamaica the Chrysobalanus Icaco, a tree related to the plums, is called incense tree.
the fragrant wood of the tropical American tree Bursera heptaphylla.

entry.ety: OE. encens, F. encens, L. incensum, fr. incensus, p. p. of incendere to burn. See Incense to inflame

sn.def: The perfume or odors exhaled from spices and gums when burned in celebrating religious rites or as an offering to some deity.
sn.q: A thick cloud of incense went up.

sn.def: The materials used for the purpose of producing a perfume when burned, as fragrant gums, spices, frankincense, etc.
sn.q: Nadab and Abihu, the sons of Aaron, took either of them his censer, and put fire therein, and put incense thereon.

sn.def: Also used figuratively.
sn.q: Or heap the shrine of luxury and pride, With incense kindled at the Muse's flame.

entry.def: Breathing or exhaling incense.
entry.q: Incense-breathingmorn.

sn.def: Angered; enraged.
Represented as enraged, as any wild creature depicted with fire issuing from mouth and eyes.

entry.def: Fury; rage; heat; exasperation; as, implacable incensement .
One who instigates or incites.

entry.ety: L. incensio. See Incense to inflame
entry.def: The act of kindling, or the state of being kindled or on fire.
Tending to excite or provoke; inflammatory.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: A kindler of anger or enmity; an inciter.

entries.entry:
In*cen"so*ry ?; 277 n.; pl.Incensories #. LL. incensorium: cf. F. encensoir. See 2d Incense, and cf. Censer
The vessel in which incense is burned and offered; a censer; a thurible. R

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + censurable: cf. F. incensurable
entry.def: Not censurable.
The center of the circle inscribed in a triangle.

entry.ety: L. incentivus, from incinere to strike up or set the tune; pref. in- + canere to sing. See Enchant Chant

sn.def: Inciting; encouraging or moving; rousing to action; stimulative.
sn.q: Competency is the most incentive to industry.

sn.def: Serving to kindle or set on fire.
sn.q: Part incentive reed Provide, pernicious with one touch of fire.

entry.ety: L. incentivum
entry.def: That which moves or influences the mind, or operates on the passions; that which incites, or has a tendency to incite, to determination or action; that which prompts to good or ill; motive; spur; as, the love of money, and the desire of promotion, are two powerful incentives to action.
entry.q: The greatest obstacles, the greatest terrors that come in their way, are so far from making them quit the work they had begun, that they rather prove incentives to them to go on in it.
entry.syn: Motive; spur; stimulus; incitement; encouragement; inducement; influence.

entry.def: Incitingly; encouragingly.

entry.ety: L. inceptio, fr. incipere to begin; pref. in- in + capere to take. See Capable

sn.def: Beginning; commencement; initiation.
sn.q: Marked with vivacity of inception, apathy of progress, and prematureness of decay.

sn.def: Reception; a taking in.

entry.def: Beginning; expressing or indicating beginning; as, an inceptive proposition; an inceptive verb, which expresses the beginning of action; -- called also inchoative.
An inceptive word, phrase, or clause.

entry.ety: L

sn.def: A beginner; one in the rudiments.
One who is on the point of taking the degree of master of arts at an English university.

entry.ety: L. incerare to smear with wax; pref. in- in + cerare to wax, fr. cera wax: cf. F. incération
entry.def: The act of smearing or covering with wax.
Cleaving or sticking like wax.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + certain: cf. F. incertain, L. incertus. See Certain
entry.def: Uncertain; doubtful; unsteady.
entry.q: Very questionable and of uncertain truth.

entry.def: Uncertainty.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incertitude, LL. incertitudo, fr. L. incertus. See Incertain
entry.def: Uncertainty; doubtfulness; doubt.
entry.q: The incertitude and instability of this life.
He fails . . . from mere incertitude or irresolution.

cs.cd: a kind of masonry employed in building walls, in which the stones were not squared nor laid in courses; rubblework.

entry.def: Doubtful; not of definite form.

entry.ety: L. incessabilis; pref. in- not + cessare to cease
entry.def: Unceasing; continual.

entry.ety: From Incessant
entry.def: The quality of being incessant; unintermitted continuance; unceasingness.

entry.ety: L. incessans -antis; pref. in- not + cessare to cease: cf. F. incessant. See Cease
entry.def: Continuing or following without interruption; unceasing; unitermitted; uninterrupted; continual; as, incessant clamors; incessant pain, etc.
entry.q: Against the castle gate, . . . Which with incessant force and endless hate, They batter'd day and night and entrance did await.
entry.syn: Unceasing; uninterrupted; unintermitted; unremitting; ceaseless; continual; constant; perpetual.

entry.def: Unceasingly; continually.

entry.ety: L. incedere incessum, to walk
entry.def: Motion on foot; progress in walking.
entry.q: The incession or local motion of animals.

entry.cs: Spiritual incest. Eccl. Law The crime of cohabitation committed between persons who have a spiritual alliance by means of baptism or confirmation. The act of a vicar, or other beneficiary, who holds two benefices, the one depending on the collation of the other.
entry.ety: F. inceste, L. incestum unchastity, incest, fr. incestus unchaste; pref. in- not + castus chaste. See Chaste
entry.def: The crime of cohabitation or sexual intercourse between persons related within the degrees wherein marriage is prohibited by law;
sexual relations between closely related persons, usually taken as first cousins or closer.

entry.ety: L. incestuosus: cf. F. incestueux

sn.def: Guilty of incest; involving, or pertaining to, incest; as, an incestuous person or connection.
sn.q: Ere you reach to this incestuous love, You must divine and human rights remove.

sn.def: resembling incest; between people or groups so closely related as to make such activity improper or unethical; as, an incestuous coziness between the management of the company and its union; an incestuous relationship between the salesman and the purchasing manager.

entry.ety: Gael. inis
entry.def: An island; -- often used in the names of small islands off the coast of Scotland, as in Inchcolm, Inchkeith, etc.

entry.note: ☞ The meter, the accepted scientific standard of length, equals 39.37 inches; the inch is equal to 2.54 centimeters. See Metric system, and Meter.
entry.cs: By inches by slow degrees, gradually. Inch of candle. See under Candle. Inches of pressure usually, the pressure indicated by so many inches of a mercury column, as on a steam gauge. Inch of water. See under Water. Miner's inch Hydraulic Mining a unit for the measurement of water. See Inch of water, under Water.
entry.ety: OE. inche unche, AS. ynce, L. uncia the twelfth part, inch, ounce. See Ounce a weight

sn.def: A measure of length, the twelfth part of a foot, commonly subdivided into halves, quarters, eights, sixteenths, etc., as among mechanics. It was also formerly divided into twelve parts, called lines, and originally into three parts, called barleycorns, its length supposed to have been determined from three grains of barley placed end to end lengthwise. It is also sometimes called a prime'), composed of twelve seconds (''), as in the duodecimal system of arithmetic.
sn.q: 12 seconds ('') make 1 inch or prime. 12 inches or primes (') make 1 foot.

sn.def: A small distance or degree, whether of time or space; hence, a critical moment; also used metaphorically of minor concessins in bargaining; as, he won't give an inch; give him an inch and he'll take a mile.
sn.q: Beldame, I think we watched you at an inch.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inched; p. pr. & vb. n. Inching

sn.def: To drive by inches, or small degrees.
sn.q: He gets too far into the soldier's grace And inches out my master.

sn.def: To deal out by inches; to give sparingly.

entry.def: To advance or retire by inches or small degrees; to move slowly; as, to inch forward.
entry.q: With slow paces measures back the field, And inches to the walls.

cs.cd: boards, etc., sawed one inch thick.

entry.def: Measuring an inch in any dimension, whether length, breadth, or thickness; -- used in composition; as, a two-inch cable; a four-inch plank.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inchambered; p. pr. & vb. n. Inchambering
entry.ety: Pref. in- in + chamber: cf. OF. enchambrer
entry.def: To lodge in a chamber.
Unchangeableness.
See Enchant.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incharitable
entry.def: Uncharitable; unfeeling.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incharité
entry.def: Lack of charity.
See Enchase.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + chastity: cf. F. inchasteté
entry.def: Unchastity.
Having or measuring (so many) inches; as, a four-inched bridge.
To put into a chest.
a suffix signifying the head of a staff; as, editor-in-chief .
See Inchpin.

cs.cd: by small degrees; by inches.

entry.ety: See Meal a part, and cf. Piecemeal
entry.def: A piece an inch long.
Little by little; gradually.

entry.ety: L. inchoatus, better incohatus, p. p. of incohare to begin
entry.def: Recently, or just, begun; beginning; partially but not fully in existence or operation; existing in its elements; incomplete.
entry.q: Neither a substance perfect, nor a substance inchoate.

entry.def: To begin.

entry.ety: L. inchoatio incohatio
entry.def: Act of beginning; commencement; inception.
entry.q: The setting on foot some of those arts, in those parts, would be looked on as the first inchoation of them.
It is now in actual progress, from the rudest inchoation to the most elaborate finishing.

entry.ety: L. inchoativus incohativus: cf. F. inchoatif
entry.def: Expressing or pertaining to a beginning; inceptive; as, an inchoative verb.
entry.q: Someinchoativeor imperfect rays.

entry.def: The name of a town in Korea and of a battle in the Korean War (1950), in which United Nations forces made an amphibious landing at Inchon, a harbor on the west coast of Korea.

entry.ety: Written also inchipin inche-pinne inne-pinne
Cf. Gael. inne innidh, bowel, entrail
entry.def: The sweetbread of a deer.

The larva of any geometrid moth. It progresses forward by first bringing the rear end of the body forward, forming a loop, then moving the front part of the body; called also measuring worm, measuringworm spanner, and looper. See Geometrid.

entry.ety: L. incicur not tame; pref. in- not + cicur name
entry.def: Untamable.

entry.ety: L. incidere; pref. in- in + caedere to cut. See Concise, and cf. Incise
entry.def: To cut; to separate and remove; to resolve or break up, as by medicines.

cs.cd: the angle which a ray of light, or the line of incidence of a body, falling on any surface, makes with a perpendicular to that surface; also formerly, the complement of this angle.
the line in the direction of which a surface is struck by a body, ray of light, and the like.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incidence

sn.def: A falling on or upon; an incident; an event; an occurrence.
The direction in which a body, or a ray of light or heat, falls on any surface.
sn.q: In equal incidences there is a considerable inequality of refractions.

sn.def: The rate or ratio at which something occurs; as, the incidence of murder in Los Angeles; the incidence of cancer in men over 50.

entry.def: Incidence.

cs.cd: a proposition subordinate to another, and introduced by who which whose whom, etc.; as, Julius, whose surname was Cæsar, overcame Pompey.

entry.ety: L. incidens -entis, p. pr. & of incidere to fall into or upon; pref. in- in, on + cadere to fall: cf. F. incident. See Cadence

sn.def: Falling or striking upon, as a ray of light upon a reflecting surface.
Coming or happening accidentally; not in the usual course of things; not in connection with the main design; not according to expectation; casual; fortuitous.
sn.q: As the ordinary course of common affairs is disposed of by general laws, so likewise men's rarer incident necessities and utilities should be with special equity considered.

sn.def: Liable to happen; apt to occur; befalling; hence, naturally happening or appertaining.
sn.q: All chances incident to man's frail life.
The studies incident to his profession.

sn.def: Dependent upon, or appertaining to, another thing, called the principal.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incident

sn.def: That which falls out or takes place; an event; casualty; occurrence.
That which happens aside from the main design; an accidental or subordinate action or event.
sn.q: No person, no incident, in a play but must be of use to carry on the main design.

sn.def: Something appertaining to, passing with, or depending on, another, called the principal.
sn.syn: Circumstance; event; fact; adventure; contingency; chance; accident; casualty. See Event.

entry.def: Happening, as an occasional event, without regularity; coming without design; casual; accidental; hence, not of prime concern; subordinate; collateral; as, an incidental conversation; an incidental occurrence; incidental expenses.
entry.q: By some, religious duties . . . appear to be regarded . . . as an incidental business.
entry.syn: Accidental; casual; fortuitous; contingent; chance; collateral. See Accidental.
entry.q: I treat either or incidentally of colors.

entry.def: An incident; that which is incidental; esp., in the plural, an aggregate of subordinate or incidental items not particularized; as, the expense of tuition and incidentals .
Incidentally.
Capable of being incinerated or reduced to ashes.

entry.ety: LL. incineratus, p. p. of incinerare to incinerate; L. pref. in- in + cinis cineris, ashes
entry.def: Reduced to ashes by burning; thoroughly consumed by fire.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incinerated; p. pr. & vb. n. Incinerating
entry.def: To burn to ashes; to consume by fire; to burn.
entry.q: It is the fire only that incinerates bodies.

entry.ety: LL. incineratio: cf. F. incinération
entry.def: The act of incinerating, or the state of being incinerated; cremation.
entry.q: The phenix kind, Of whose incineration, There riseth a new creation.

entry.ety: L. incipientia
entry.def: Beginning; commencement; incipient state.

entry.ety: L. incipiens, p. pr. of incipere to begin. See Inception
entry.def: Beginning to be, or to show itself; commencing; initial; as, the incipient stage of a fever; incipient light of day.
See Encircle.

entry.ety: Cf. Encirclet
entry.def: A small circle.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + circumscriptible: cf. LL. incircumscriptibilis
entry.def: Incapable of being circumscribed or limited.
Condition or quality of being incircumscriptible or limitless.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + circumspect
entry.def: Not circumspect; heedless; careless; reckless; impolitic.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incirconspection
entry.def: Lack of circumspection.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incised; p. pr. & vb. n. Incising
entry.ety: L. incisus, p. p. of incidere to incise: cf. F. inciser. See Incide

sn.def: To cut in or into with a sharp instrument; to carve; to engrave.
sn.q: I on thy grave this epitaph incise.

sn.def: To cut, gash, or wound with a sharp instrument; to cut off.
Cut in; carved; engraved.
Having deep and sharp notches, as a leaf or a petal.

entry.def: In an incised manner.

entry.ety: L. incisio: cf. F. incision. See Incise

sn.def: The act of incising, or cutting into a substance;
the cutting action made during surgery to gain access to the body parts under the skin.
That which is produced by incising; the separation of the parts of any substance made by a cutting or pointed instrument; a cut; a gash;
the cut in the skin made during surgery to gain access to the interior of the body.
Separation or solution of viscid matter by medicines.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incisif

sn.def: Having the quality of incising, cutting, or penetrating, as with a sharp instrument; cutting;
sharp; acute; sarcastic; biting; trenchant.
sn.q: Anincisive, high voice.
And her incisive smile accrediting That treason of false witness in my blush.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the incisors; incisor; as, the incisive bones, the premaxillaries.
Clearly and succinctly stated, with penetrating insight into the issue at hand; as, an incisive comment.

entry.def: keenness and forcefulnelss of thought or expression or intellect.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: One of the teeth in front of the canines in either jaw; an incisive tooth. See Tooth.
Adapted for cutting; of or pertaining to the incisors; incisive; as, the incisor nerve; an incisor foramen; an incisor tooth.
Having the quality of cutting; incisor; incisive.

entry.ety: L. incisura: cf. F. incisure
entry.def: A cut; an incision; a gash.

entry.ety: L. incitans -antis, p. pr. of incitare. See Incite
entry.def: Inciting; stimulating.
That which incites; an inciting agent or cause; a stimulant.

entry.ety: L. incitatio: cf. F. incitation

sn.def: The act of inciting or moving to action.
That which incites to action; that which rouses or prompts; incitement; motive; incentive.
sn.q: The noblest incitation to honest attempts.

entry.def: A provocative; an incitant; a stimulant.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incited; p. pr. & vb. n. Inciting
entry.ety: L. incitare; pref. in- in + citare to rouse, stir up: cf. F. inciter. See Cite
entry.def: To move to action; to stir up; to rouse; to spur or urge on.
entry.q: Anthiochus, when he incited Prusias to join in war, set before him the greatness of the Romans.
No blown ambition doth our arms incite.
entry.syn: Excite; stimulate; instigate; spur; goad; arouse; move; urge; rouse; provoke; encourage; prompt; animate. See Excite.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incitement

sn.def: The act of inciting.
That which incites the mind, or moves to action; motive; incentive; impulse.
sn.q: From the long records of a distant age, Derive incitements to renew thy rage.
sn.syn: Motive; incentive; spur; stimulus; impulse; encouragement.

entry.def: One who, or that which, incites.
So as to incite or stimulate.

entry.ety: L. incitus incited + E. motor
entry.def: Inciting to motion; -- applied to that action which, in the case of muscular motion, commences in the nerve centers, and excites the muscles to contraction. Opposed to excito-motor.
Incitomotor.

entry.ety: L. incivilis; pref. in- not + civilis civil: cf. F. incivil
entry.def: Uncivil; rude.

entries.entry:
In`ci*vil"i*ty n.; pl.Incivilities #. L. incivilitas: cf. F. incivilité
The quality or state of being uncivil; lack of courtesy; rudeness of manner; impoliteness.
Any act of rudeness or ill breeding. Uncomely jests, loud talking and jeering, which, in civil account, are called indecencies and incivilities.
Lack of civilization; a state of rudeness or barbarism. R Impoliteness; uncourteousness; unmannerliness; disrespect; rudeness; discourtesy.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + civilization
entry.def: The state of being uncivilized; lack of civilization; barbarism.
Uncivilly.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + civism: cf. F. incivisme
entry.def: Lack of civism; lack of patriotism or love to one's country; unfriendliness to one's state or government.

entry.ety: L. inclamatio. See 1st In-, and Claim
entry.def: Exclamation.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + clasp. Cf. Enclasp
entry.def: To clasp within; to hold fast to; to embrace or encircle.
entry.q: The flattering ivy who did ever seeInclasp the huge trunk of an aged tree.

entry.def: Not closing or shutting.

entry.ety: LL. inclavatus; L. pref. in- in + clavare to fasten with nails, fr. clavus nail
entry.def: Set; fast; fixed.

entry.ety: See Inclavated
entry.def: Resembling a series of dovetails; -- said of a line of division, such as the border of an ordinary.
Same as Inkle.

entries.entry:
In*clem"en*cy n.; pl.Inclemencies #. L. inclementia: cf. F. inclémence
The state or quality of being inclement; lack of clemency; lack of mildness of temper; unmercifulness; severity. The inclemency of the late pope.
Physical severity or harshness (commonly in respect to the elements or weather); roughness; storminess; rigor; severe cold, wind, rain, or snow. The inclemencies of morning air. The rude inclemency of wintry skies. Harshness; severity; cruelty; rigor; roughness; storminess; boisterousness.

entry.ety: L. inclemens; pref. in- not + clemens mild: cf. F. inclément. See Clement

sn.def: Not clement; destitute of a mild and kind temper; void of tenderness; unmerciful; severe; harsh.
Physically severe or harsh (generally restricted to the elements or weather); rough; boisterous; stormy; rigorously cold, etc.; as, inclement weather.
sn.q: The guard the wretched from the inclement sky.
Teach us further by what means to shun The inclement seasons, rain, ice, hail, and snow!

entry.def: In an inclement manner.

entry.ety: L. inclinabilis. See Incline

sn.def: Leaning; tending.
sn.q: Likely and inclinable to fall.

sn.def: Having a propensity of will or feeling; leaning in disposition; disposed; propense; as, a mind inclinable to truth.
sn.q: Whatsoever other sins he may be inclinable to.
The very constitution of a multitude is not so inclinable to save as to destroy.

entry.def: The state or quality of being inclinable; inclination.

entry.cs: Inclination compass an inclinometer. Inclination of an orbit Astron the angle which the orbit makes with the ecliptic. Inclination of the needle. See Dip of the needle, under Dip.
entry.ety: L. inclinatio: cf. F. inclination

sn.def: The act of inclining, or state of being inclined; a leaning; as, an inclination of the head.
A direction or tendency from the true vertical or horizontal direction; as, the inclination of a column, or of a road bed.
A tendency towards another body or point.
The angle made by two lines or planes; as, the inclination of the plane of the earth's equator to the plane of the ecliptic is about 23° 28'; the inclination of two rays of light.
A leaning or tendency of the mind, feelings, preferences, or will; propensity; a disposition more favorable to one thing than to another; favor; desire; love.
sn.q: A mere inclination to a thing is not properly a willing of that thing.
How dost thou find the inclination of the people?

sn.def: A person or thing loved or admired.
Decantation, or tipping for pouring.
sn.syn: Bent; tendency; proneness; bias; proclivity; propensity; prepossession; predilection; attachment; desire; affection; love. See Bent, and cf. Disposition.

entry.def: Having the quality of leaning or inclining; as, the inclinatory needle.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inclined; p. pr. & vb. n. Inclining
entry.ety: OE. inclinen enclinen, OF. encliner incliner, F. incliner, L. inclinare; pref. in- in + clinare to bend, incline; akin to E. lean. See Lean to incline

sn.def: To deviate from a line, direction, or course, toward an object; to lean; to tend; as, converging lines incline toward each other; a road inclines to the north or south.
Fig.: To lean or tend, in an intellectual or moral sense; to favor an opinion, a course of conduct, or a person; to have a propensity or inclination; to be disposed.
sn.q: Their hearts inclined to follow Abimelech.
Power finds its balance, giddy motions cease In both the scales, and each inclines to peace.

sn.def: To bow; to incline the head.
sn.syn: To lean; slope; slant; tend; bend.

sn.def: To cause to deviate from a line, position, or direction; to give a leaning, bend, or slope to; as, incline the column or post to the east; incline your head to the right.
sn.q: Incline thine ear, O Lord, and hear.

sn.def: To impart a tendency or propensity to, as to the will or affections; to turn; to dispose; to influence.
sn.q: Incline my heart unto thy testimonies.
Incline our hearts to keep this law.

sn.def: To bend; to cause to stoop or bow; as, to incline the head or the body in acts of reverence or civility.
sn.q: With due respect my body I inclined.

entry.def: An inclined plane; an ascent or descent; a grade or gradient; a slope.

entry.cs: Inclined plane. Mech A plane that makes an oblique angle with the plane of the horizon; a sloping plane. When used to produce pressure, or as a means of moving bodies, it is one of the mechanical powers, so called. Railroad & Canal An inclined portion of track, on which trains or boats are raised or lowered from one level to another.

sn.def: Having a leaning or tendency towards, or away from, a thing; disposed or moved by wish, desire, or judgment; as, a man inclined to virtue.
sn.q: Each pensivelyinclined.

sn.def: Making an angle with some line or plane; -- said of a line or plane.
Bent out of a perpendicular position, or into a curve with the convex side uppermost.

entry.def: One who, or that which, inclines;
an inclined dial.
Same as Inclined, 3.

sn.def: Inclination; disposition.
sn.q: On the first inclining towards sleep.

sn.def: Party or side chosen; a following.
sn.q: Both you of my inclining, and the rest.

entry.ety: Incline + -meter
entry.def: An apparatus to determine the inclination of the earth's magnetic force to the plane of the horizon; -- called also inclination compass, and dip circle.
To clasp; to inclose.
entry.q: Whate'er the ocean pales, or sky inclips.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + cloister: cf. F. encloîtrer. Cf. Encloister
entry.def: To confine as in a cloister; to cloister.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inclosed; p. pr. & vb. n. Inclosing
entry.ety: See Enclose, and cf. Include

sn.def: To surround; to shut in; to confine on all sides; to include; to shut up; to encompass; as, to inclose a fort or an army with troops; to inclose a town with walls.
sn.q: How many evils have inclosed me round!

sn.def: To put within a case, envelope, or the like; to fold (a thing) within another or into the same parcel; as, to inclose a letter or a bank note.
sn.q: The inclosed copies of the treaty.

sn.def: To separate from common grounds by a fence; as, to inclose lands.
To put into harness; to harness.
sn.q: They went to coach and their horse inclose.

entry.def: One who, or that which, incloses; one who fences off land from common grounds.

entry.ety: See Inclose Enclosure

sn.def: The act of inclosing; the state of being inclosed, shut up, or encompassed; the separation of land from common ground by a fence.
That which is inclosed or placed within something; a thing contained; a space inclosed or fenced up.
sn.q: Within the inclosure there was a great store of houses.

sn.def: That which incloses; a barrier or fence.
sn.q: Breaking our inclosures every morn.

entry.def: To envelop as in clouds; to darken; to obscure.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Included; p. pr. & vb. n. Including
entry.ety: L. includere inclusum; pref. in- in + claudere to shut. See Close, and cf. Enclose

sn.def: To confine within; to hold; to contain; to shut up; to inclose; as, the shell of a nut includes the kernel; a pearl is included in a shell.

To comprehend or comprise, as a genus the species, the whole a part, an argument or reason the inference; to contain; to embrace; as, this volume of Shakespeare includes his sonnets; he was included in the invitation to the family; to and including page twenty-five.
sn.q: The whole included race, his purposed prey.
The loss of such a lord includes all harm.

sn.def: To conclude; to end; to terminate.
sn.q: Come, let us go; we will include all jars With triumphs, mirth, and rare solemnity.
sn.syn: To contain; inclose; comprise; comprehend; embrace; involve.

cs.cd: such as are shorter than the floral envelopes, or are concealed within them.

entry.def: Inclosed; confined.
Capable of being included.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. inclusus, p. p. of includere to shut in
entry.def: A tribe of bivalve mollusks, characterized by the closed state of the mantle which envelops the body. The ship borer (Teredo navalis) is an example.

entry.ety: L. inclusio: cf. F. inclusion. See Include

sn.def: The act of including, or the state of being included; limitation; restriction; as, the lines of inclusion of his policy.
Something that is included.
A foreign substance, either liquid or solid, usually of minute size, inclosed in the mass of a mineral.
A small body suspended within the cytoplasm of a cell.
The relationship existing between two sets if one is a subset of the other.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inclusif

sn.def: Inclosing; encircling; surrounding.
sn.q: The inclusive verge Of golden metal that must round my brow.

sn.def: Comprehending the stated limit or extremes; as, from Monday to Saturday inclusive, that is, taking in both Monday and Saturday; -- opposed to exclusive.

entry.def: In an inclusive manner.
To put a coach.

entry.ety: L. incoactus; pref. in- not + coactus forced. See Coact
entry.def: Not compelled; unconstrained.
Not coagulable.
The state of not coalescing.

entry.ety: Cf. Concoct
entry.def: Raw; indigestible.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + coercible: cf. F. incoercible

sn.def: Not to be coerced; incapable of being compelled or forced.
Not capable of being reduced to the form of a liquid by pressure; -- said of any gas above its critical temperature.
That can note be confined in, or excluded from, vessels, like ordinary fluids, gases, etc.; -- said of the imponderable fluids, heat, light, electricity, etc.

entry.def: The state of not coexisting.
Incognito.
entry.q: Depend upon it -- he'll remain incog.

entry.ety: L. incogitabilis; pref. in- not + cogitabilis cogitable
entry.def: Not cogitable; inconceivable.

entry.ety: L. incogitantia
entry.def: Lack of thought, or of the power of thinking; thoughtlessness; unreasonableness.
entry.q: 'T is folly and incogitancy to argue anything, one way or the other, from the designs of a sort of beings with whom we so little communicate.

entry.ety: L. incogitans; pref. in- not + cogitans, p. pr. of cogitare to think. See Cogitate
entry.def: Thoughtless; inconsiderate.
entry.q: Men are careless and incogitant.

entry.def: In an incogitant manner.
Not cogitative; not thinking; lacking the power of thought; as, a vegetable is an incogitative being.
The quality of being incogitative; lack of thought or of the power of thinking.

entry.ety: See Incognito

sn.def: A woman who is unknown or in disguise.
The state of being in disguise; -- said of a woman.

entry.def: Ignorant.

entry.ety: It. incognito, masc., incognita, fem., L. incognitus unknown; pref. in- not + cognitus known, p. p. of cognoscere: cf. F. incognito, fr. It. See Cognition
entry.def: Without being known; in disguise; in an assumed character, or under an assumed title; -- said esp. of great personages who sometimes adopt a disguise or an assumed character in order to avoid notice.
entry.q: 'T was long ago Since gods come down incognito.
The prince royal of Persia came thither incognito.

entries.entry:
In*cog"ni*to n.; pl.Incognitos #. See Incognito a.
One unknown or in disguise, or under an assumed character or name.
The assumption of disguise or of a feigned character; the state of being in disguise or not recognized. His incognito was endangered.

entry.def: Not cognizable; incapable of being recognized, known, or distinguished.
entry.q: The Lettish race, not a primitive stock of the Slavi, but a distinct branch, now become incognizable.

entry.def: Failure to cognize, apprehended, or notice.
entry.q: This incognizance may be explained.

entry.def: Not cognizant; failing to apprehended or notice.
entry.q: Of the several operations themselves, as acts of volition, we are wholly incognizant.

entry.def: Incognizable.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incohérence

sn.def: The quality or state of being incoherent; lack of coherence; lack of cohesion or adherence.
Lack of connection; incongruity; inconsistency; lack of agreement or dependence of one part on another; as, the incoherence of arguments, facts, etc.
sn.q: Incoherences in matter, and suppositions without proofs, put handsomely together, are apt to pass for strong reason.

sn.def: That which is incoherent.
sn.q: Crude incoherencies . . . and nauseous tautologies.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + coherent: cf. F. incohérent

sn.def: Not coherent; wanting cohesion; loose; unconnected; physically disconnected; not fixed to each; -- said of material substances.
Lacking logical coherence or agreement; incongruous; inconsistent; having no dependence of one part on another; logically disconnected; rambling; -- of speech or discourse.
sn.q: The same rambling,incoherentmanner.

sn.def: Exhibiting incoherent{2} speech or thought; -- of people; as, a confused and incoherent accident victim.
Lacking harmony or congruity of parts.

entry.ety: E. incoherent + L. facere to make
entry.def: Causing incoherence.
In an incoherent manner; without due connection of parts.
Incoherence.
The quality of being incoincident; lack of coincidence.
Not coincident; not agreeing in time, in place, or principle.

entry.ety: L. incolumitas, fr. incolumis uninjured, safe; perh. fr. in intens. + (doubtfulcolumis safe
entry.def: Safety; security.
See Encumber.
To be incapable of combining; to disagree; to differ.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incombustilité
entry.def: The quality of being incombustible.

cs.cd: a tissue of amianthus or asbestus; also, a fabric imbued with an incombustible substance.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + combustible: cf. F. incombustible
entry.def: Not combustible; not capable of being burned, decomposed, or consumed by fire; uninflammable; as, asbestus is an incombustible substance; carbon dioxide is an incombustible gas.

cs.cd: a bond issued on the income of the corporation or company issuing it, and the interest of which is to be paid from the earnings of the company before any dividends are made to stockholders; -- issued chiefly or exclusively by railroad companies.
a tax upon a person's incomes, emoluments, profits, etc., or upon the excess beyond a certain amount.

sn.def: A coming in; entrance; admittance; ingress; infusion.
sn.q: More abundant incomes of light and strength from God.
At mine income I louted low.

sn.def: That which is caused to enter; inspiration; influence; hence, courage or zeal imparted.
sn.q: I would then make in and steep My income in their blood.

sn.def: That gain which proceeds from labor, business, property, or capital of any kind, as the produce of a farm, the rent of houses, the proceeds of professional business, the profits of commerce or of occupation, or the interest of money or stock in funds, etc.; revenue; receipts; salary; especially, the annual receipts of a private person, or a corporation, from property; as, a large income .
sn.q: No fields afford So large an income to the village lord.

sn.def: That which is taken into the body as food; the ingesta; -- sometimes restricted to the nutritive, or digestible, portion of the food. See Food. Opposed to output.
sn.syn: Gain; profit; proceeds; salary; revenue; receipts; interest; emolument; produce.

sn.def: One who comes in.
sn.q: Outgoers and incomers.

sn.def: One who succeeds another, as a tenant of land, houses, etc.
Coming in; accruing.
sn.q: A full incoming profit on the product of his labor.

sn.def: Coming in, succeeding, or following, as occupant or possessor; as, in incoming tenant.
The act of coming in; arrival.
sn.q: The incomings and outgoings of the trains.

sn.def: Income; gain.
sn.q: Many incomings are subject to great fluctuations.

entry.def: Lack of comity; incivility; rudeness.

entries.entry:
‖In com*men"dam. See Commendam
Law See Commendam, and Partnership in Commendam, under Partnership.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incommensurabilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being incommensurable.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + commensurable: cf. F. incommensurable
entry.def: Not commensurable; having no common measure or standard of comparison; as, quantities are incommensurable when no third quantity can be found that is an aliquot part of both; the side and diagonal of a square are incommensurable with each other; the diameter and circumference of a circle are incommensurable.
entry.q: They are quantities incommensurable.

entry.def: One of two or more quantities which have no common measure.

sn.def: Not commensurate; not admitting of a common measure; incommensurable.
Not of equal of sufficient measure or extent; not adequate; as, our means are incommensurate to our wants.
sn.syn: Inadequate; insufficient; disproportionate.

entry.ety: L. incommiscibilis; pref. in- not + commiscibilis that can be mingled
entry.def: Not commiscible; not mixable.
A state of being unmixed; separateness.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incommodated; p. pr. & vb. n. Incommodating
entry.ety: L. incommodare. See Incommode
entry.def: To incommode.
The state of being incommoded; inconvenience.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incommoded; p. pr. & vb. n. Incommoding
entry.ety: F. incommoder, L. incommodare inconvenient; pref. in- not + commodus convenient. See Commodious
entry.def: To give inconvenience or trouble to; to disturb or molest; to discommode; to worry; to put out; as, we are incommoded by lack of room.
entry.syn: To annoy; disturb; trouble; molest; disaccomodate; inconvenience; disquiet; vex; plague.

entry.def: An inconvenience.
The act of incommoded.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + commodious: cf. LL. incommodious, L. incommodus, F. incommode
entry.def: Tending to incommode; not commodious; not affording ease or advantage; unsuitable; giving trouble; inconvenient; annoying; as, an incommodious seat; an incommodious arrangement.

entries.entry:
In`com*mo"di*ty n.; pl.Incommodities #. L. incommoditas: cf. F. incommodité. See Incommodious
Inconvenience; trouble; annoyance; disadvantage; encumbrance. Archaic A great incommodity to the body. Buried him under a bulk of incommodities.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incommunicabilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being incommunicable, or incapable of being imparted.

entry.ety: L. incommunicabilis: cf. F. incommunicable. See In- not, and Communicable
entry.def: Not communicable; incapable of being communicated, shared, told, or imparted, to others.
entry.q: Health and understanding are incommunicable.
Those incommunicable relations of the divine love.

entry.def: Not communicated or imparted.
Having no communion or intercourse with each other.

Not communicative; not free or apt to impart to others in conversation; reserved; silent; as, the messenger was incommunicative ; hence, not disposed to hold fellowship or intercourse with others; exclusive.
entry.q: The Chinese . . . an incommunicative nation.
His usual incommunicativeness.

entry.ety: L. incommutabilitas: cf. F. incommutabilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being incommutable.

entry.ety: L. incommutabilis: cf. F. incommutable. See In- not, and Commutable
entry.def: Not commutable; not capable of being exchanged with, or substituted for, another.
Not compact; not having the parts firmly united; not solid; incoherent; loose; discrete.

entry.ety: L. incomparabilis: cf. F. incomparable. See In- not, and Comparable
entry.def: Not comparable; admitting of no comparison with others; unapproachably eminent; without a peer or equal; matchless; peerless; transcendent.
entry.q: A merchant of incomparable wealth.
A new hypothesis . . . which hath the incomparable Sir Isaac Newton for a patron.
Delights incomparably all those corporeal things.

entry.def: Peerless; incomparable.
See Encompass.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + compassion: cf. F. incompassion
entry.def: Lack of compassion or pity.
Not compassionate; void of pity or of tenderness; remorseless.

entries.entry:
In`com*pat`i*bil"i*ty n.; pl.-ties. Cf. F. incompatibilité
The quality or state of being incompatible; inconsistency; irreconcilableness.

cs.cd: terms which can not be combined in thought.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + compatible: cf. F. incompatible

sn.def: Not compatible; so differing as to be incapable of harmonious combination or coexistence; inconsistent in thought or being; irreconcilably disagreeing; as, persons of incompatible tempers; incompatible colors, desires, ambition.
sn.q: A strength and obduracy of character incompatible with his meek and innocent nature.

sn.def: Incapable of being together without mutual reaction or decomposition, as certain medicines.
sn.syn: Inconsistent; incongruous; dissimilar; irreconcilable; unsuitable; disagreeing; inharmonious; discordant; repugnant; contradictory. See Inconsistent.

entry.def: An incompatible substance; esp., in pl., things which can not be placed or used together because of a change of chemical composition or of opposing medicinal qualities; as, the incompatibles of iron.
The quality or state of being incompatible; incompatibility.
In an incompatible manner; inconsistently; incongruously.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incompétence

sn.def: The quality or state of being incompetent; lack of physical, intellectual, or moral ability; lack of qualifications or training (for a particular task); insufficiency; inadequacy; as, the incompetency of a child for hard labor, or of an idiot for intellectual efforts.
sn.q: Some inherentincompetency.
sn.syn: incompetence.

sn.def: Lack of competency or legal fitness; incapacity; disqualification, as of a person to be heard as a witness, or to act as a juror, or of a judge to try a cause.
sn.syn: Inability; insufficiency; inadequacy; disqualification; incapability; unfitness.

entry.usage: Incompetent Incapable. Incompetent is a relative term, denoting a lack of the requisite qualifications for performing a given act, service, etc.; incapable is absolute in its meaning, denoting lack of power, either natural or moral. We speak of a man as incompetent to a certain task, of an incompetent judge, etc. We say of an idiot that he is incapable of learning to read; and of a man distinguished for his honor, that he is incapable of a mean action.
entry.ety: L. incompetens: cf. F. incompétent. See In- not, and Competent

sn.def: Not competent; wanting in adequate strength, power, capacity, means, qualifications, or the like; incapable; unable; inadequate; unfit.
sn.q: Incompetent to perform the duties of the place.
