sn.def: Wanting the legal or constitutional qualifications; inadmissible; as, a person professedly wanting in religious belief is an incompetent witness in a court of law or equity; incompetent evidence; a mentally defective person is incompetent to care for himself and requires a legal guardian.
sn.q: Richard III. had a resolution, out of hatred to his brethren, to disable their issues, upon false and incompetent pretexts, the one of attainder, the other of illegitimation.

sn.def: Not lying within one's competency, capacity, or authorized power; not permissible.
sn.syn: Incapable; unable; inadequate; insufficient; inefficient; disqualified; unfit; improper.

entry.def: In an competent manner; inadequately; unsuitably.
See Incompatibility.
See Incompatible.

cs.cd: an equation some of whose terms are wanting; or one in which the coefficient of some one or more of the powers of the unknown quantity is equal to 0.

entry.ety: L. incompletus: cf. F. incomplet. See In- not, and Complete

sn.def: Not complete; not filled up; not finished; not having all its parts, or not having them all adjusted; imperfect; defective.
sn.q: A most imperfect and incomplete divine.

sn.def: Wanting any of the usual floral organs; -- said of a flower.

entry.def: In an incomplete manner.
The state of being incomplete; imperfectness; defectiveness.
Lack of completion; incompleteness.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + complex: cf. F. incomplexe
entry.def: Not complex; uncompounded; simple.
Not compliable; not conformable.

sn.def: The quality or state of being incompliant; unyielding temper; obstinacy.
sn.q: Self-conceit produces peevishness and incompliance of humor in things lawful and indifferent.

sn.def: Refusal or failure to comply.

entry.def: Not compliant; unyielding to request, solicitation, or command; stubborn.
Disordered; disturbed.

entry.cs: Incomposite numbers. See Prime numbers, under Prime.
entry.ety: L. incompositus. See Composite
entry.def: Not composite; uncompounded; simple.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + compossible: cf. F. incompossible
entry.def: Not capable of joint existence; incompatible; inconsistent.
entry.q: Ambition and faith . . . are . . . incompossible.

entry.ety: L. incomprehensus
entry.def: Incomprehensible.
entry.q: Incomprehensein virtue.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incompréhensibilité
entry.def: The quality of being incomprehensible, or beyond the reach of human intellect; incomprehensibleness; inconceivability; inexplicability.
entry.q: The constant, universal sense of all antiquity unanimously confessing an incomprehensibility in many of the articles of the Christian faith.

entry.ety: L. incomprehensibilis: cf. F. incompréhensible. See In- not, and Comprehensible

sn.def: Not capable of being contained within limits.
sn.q: An infinite and incomprehensible substance.

sn.def: Not capable of being comprehended or understood; beyond the reach of the human intellect; inconceivable.
sn.q: And all her numbered stars that seem to roll Spaces incomprehensible.

entry.def: Lack of comprehension or understanding.
entry.q: These mazes andincomprehensions.

entry.def: Not comprehensive; not capable of including or of understanding; not extensive; limited.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incompressibilité
entry.def: The quality of being incompressible, or incapable of reduction in volume by pressure; -- formerly supposed to be a property of liquids.
entry.q: The incompressibility of water is not absolute.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + compressible: cf. F. incompressible
entry.def: Not compressible; incapable of being reduced by force or pressure into a smaller compass or volume; resisting compression; as, many liquids and solids appear to be almost incompressible .
Not computable.
Not concealable.
entry.q: Inconcealableimperfections.

entry.def: The quality of being inconceivable; inconceivableness.
entry.q: The inconceivability of the Infinite.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + conceivable: cf. F. inconcevable
entry.def: Not conceivable; incapable of being conceived by the mind; not explicable by the human intellect, or by any known principles or agencies; incomprehensible; as, it is inconceivable to us how the will acts in producing muscular motion.
entry.q: It is inconceivable to me that a spiritual substance should represent an extended figure.
The inconceivableness of a quality existing without any subject to possess it.

entry.def: Inconceivable.
Unimportant; trifling.
entry.q: Trifling andinconcerningmatters.

entry.ety: See Inconcinnous
entry.def: Dissimilar; incongruous; unsuitable.

entry.ety: L. inconcinnitas
entry.def: Lack of concinnity or congruousness; unsuitableness.
entry.q: There is an inconcinnity in admitting these words.

entry.ety: L. inconcinnus. See In- not, and Concinnity
entry.def: Not concinnous; unsuitable; discordant.
Not inferring a conclusion or consequence; not conclusive.
Inferring no consequence.

Not conclusive; leading to no conclusion; not closing or settling a point in debate, or a doubtful question; as, evidence is inconclusive when it does not exhibit the truth of a disputed case in such a manner as to satisfy the mind, and put an end to debate or doubt.
entry.q: Arguments . . . inconclusive and impertinent.

entry.ety: L. pref. in- not + concoctus, p. p. of concoquere. See Concoct
entry.def: Inconcocted.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + concocted
entry.def: Imperfectly digested, matured, or ripened.
The state of being undigested; unripeness; immaturity.

entry.ety: L. inconcretus incorporeal
entry.def: Not concrete.
Not concurring; disagreeing.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + L. concussibilis that can be shaken. See Concussion
entry.def: Not concussible; that cannot be shaken.
The quality or state of being incondensable.
Not condensable; incapable of being made more dense or compact, or reduced to liquid form.

entry.ety: L. inconditus; pref. in- not + conditus, p. p. of condere to put or join together. See Condition
entry.def: Badly put together; inartificial; rude; unpolished; irregular.
entry.q: Carolinconditerhymes.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + conditional: cf. F. inconditionnel
entry.def: Unconditional.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + conditionate: cf. F. inconditionné
entry.def: Not conditioned; not limited; absolute.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + conform
entry.def: Unconformable.
Unconformable.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inconformité
entry.def: Lack of conformity; nonconformity.
Not confused; distinct.
Freedom from confusion; distinctness.
Not confutable.

entry.ety: L. incongelabilis. See Congeal
entry.def: Not congealable; incapable of being congealed.
Not congenial; uncongenial.

entry.ety: L. incongruentia
entry.def: Lack of congruence; incongruity.

entry.ety: L. incongruens. See In- not, and Congruent
entry.def: Incongruous.

entries.entry:
In`con*gru"i*ty n.; pl.Incongruities #. Pref. in- not + congruity: cf. F. incongruité
The quality or state of being incongruous; lack of congruity; unsuitableness; inconsistency; impropriety. The fathers make use of this acknowledgment of the incongruity of images to the Deity, from thence to prove the incongruity of the worship of them.
Disagreement of parts; lack of symmetry or of harmony. Obs
That which is incongruous; lack of congruity.

cs.cd: two numbers, which, with respect to a third, are such that their difference can not be divided by it without a remainder, the two numbers being said to be incongruous with respect to the third; as, twenty and twenty-five are incongruous with respect to four.

entry.ety: L. incongruus. See In- not, and Congruous
entry.def: Not congruous; reciprocally disagreeing; not capable of harmonizing or readily assimilating; inharmonious; inappropriate; unsuitable; not fitting; inconsistent; improper; as, an incongruous remark; incongruous behavior, action, dress, etc.
entry.q: Incongruousmixtures of opinions.
Made up ofincongruousparts.
Incongruous denotes that kind of absence of harmony or suitableness of which the taste and experience of men takes cognizance.
entry.syn: Inconsistent; unsuitable; inharmonious; disagreeing; absurd; inappropriate; unfit; improper. See Inconsistent.

entry.def: Not connected; disconnected.
Disconnection.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + connexedp. p. of connex) + -ly
entry.def: Not connectedly; without connection.
Unconscionable.
Unconscious.
The state or quality of not being consecutive.

entry.ety: L. inconsequentia: cf. F. inconséquence
entry.def: The quality or state of being inconsequent; lack of just or logical inference or argument; inconclusiveness.
entry.q: Strange, that you should not see the inconsequence of your own reasoning!

entry.ety: L. inconsequens: cf. F. inconséquent. See In- not, and Consequent
entry.def: Not following from the premises; not regularly inferred; invalid; not characterized by logical method; illogical; arbitrary; inconsistent; of no consequence.
entry.q: Loose and inconsequent conjectures.

entry.def: Not regularly following from the premises; hence, irrelevant; unimportant; of no consequence.
The state of being inconsequential.
Inconsequence.
Not considerable; unworthy of consideration or notice; unimportant; small; trivial; as, an inconsiderable distance; an inconsiderable quantity, degree, value, or sum.
entry.q: The baser scum andinconsiderabledregs of Rome.

entry.def: Inconsiderateness; thoughtlessness.

entry.ety: L. inconsideratus. See In- not, and Considerate

sn.def: Not considerate; not attentive to safety or to propriety; not regarding the rights or feelings of others; hasty; careless; thoughtless; heedless; as, the young are generally inconsiderate; inconsiderate conduct.
sn.q: It is a very unhappy token of our corruption, that there should be any so inconsiderate among us as to sacrifice morality to politics.

sn.def: Inconsiderable.
sn.syn: Thoughtless; inattentive; inadvertent; heedless; negligent; improvident; careless; imprudent; indiscreet; incautious; injudicious; rash; hasty.

entry.def: In an inconsiderate manner.
The quality or state of being inconsiderate.

entry.ety: L. inconsideratio: cf. F. inconsidération
entry.def: Lack of due consideration; inattention to consequences; inconsiderateness.
entry.q: Blindness of mind, inconsideration, precipitation.
Not gross, willful, deliberate, crimes; but rather the effects of inconsideration.

entry.def: Inconsistency.

entries.entry:
In`con*sist"en*cy n.; pl.Inconsistencies #. Cf. F. inconsistance
The quality or state of being inconsistent; discordance in respect to sentiment or action; such contrariety between two things that both can not exist or be true together; disagreement; incompatibility. There is a perfect inconsistency between that which is of debt and that which is of free gift.
Absurdity in argument ore narration; incoherence or irreconcilability in the parts of a statement, argument, or narration; that which is inconsistent. If a man would register all his opinions upon love, politics, religion, and learning, what a bundle of inconsistencies and contradictions would appear at last!
Lack of stability or uniformity; unsteadiness; changeableness; variableness. Mutability of temper, and inconsistency with ourselves, is the greatest weakness of human nature.

entry.usage: Inconsistent Incongruous Incompatible. Things are incongruous when they are not suited to each other, so that their union is unbecoming; inconsistent when they are opposed to each other, so as render it improper or wrong; incompatible when they can not coexist, and it is therefore impossible to unite them. Habitual levity of mind is incongruous with the profession of a clergyman; it is inconsistent with his ordination vows; it is incompatible with his permanent usefulness. Incongruity attaches to the modes and qualities of things; incompatibility attaches to their essential attributes; inconsistency attaches to the actions, sentiments, etc., of men.
entry.ety: Pref. in- not + consistent: cf. F. inconsistant

sn.def: Not consistent; showing inconsistency; irreconcilable; contradictory, or having contradictory implications; discordant; at variance, esp. as regards character, sentiment, or action; incompatible; incongruous.
sn.q: Compositions of this nature . . . show that wisdom and virtue are far from being inconsistent with politeness and good humor.

sn.def: Not exhibiting uniformity of sentiment, steadiness to principle, etc.; unequal; fickle; changeable.
sn.q: Ah, how unjust to nature, and himself, Is thoughtless, thankless, inconsistent man.
sn.syn: Incompatible; incongruous; irreconcilable; discordant; repugnant; contradictory.

entry.def: In an inconsistent manner.
Inconsistency.
Inconsistent.

entry.ety: L. inconsolabilis: cf. F. inconsolable. See In- not, and Console
entry.def: Not consolable; incapable of being consoled; grieved beyond susceptibility of comfort; disconsolate.
entry.q: With inconsolable distress she griev'd, And from her cheek the rose of beauty fled.

entry.def: Lack of consonance or harmony of sound, action, or thought; disagreement.

entry.ety: L. inconsonans. See In- not, and Consonant
entry.def: Not consonant or agreeing; inconsistent; discordant.

entry.ety: L. inconspicuus. See In- not, and Conspicuous
entry.def: Not conspicuous or noticeable; hardly discernible.

entry.ety: F. See Inconstancy
entry.def: Inconstancy.

entry.ety: L. inconstantia
entry.def: The quality or state of being inconstant; lack of constancy; mutability; fickleness; variableness.
entry.q: For unto knight there was no greater shame, Than lightness and inconstancie in love.

entry.ety: L. inconstans: cf. F. inconstant. See In- not, and Constant
entry.def: Not constant; not stable or uniform; subject to change of character, appearance, opinion, inclination, or purpose, etc.; not firm; unsteady; fickle; changeable; variable; -- said of persons or things; as, inconstant in love or friendship.
entry.q: Theinconstantmoon.
While we, inquiring phantoms of a day,Inconstant as the shadows we survey!
entry.syn: Mutable; fickle; volatile; unsteady; unstable; changeable; variable; wavering; fluctuating.

entry.def: In an inconstant manner.
Not consumable; incapable of being consumed, wasted, or spent.

entry.ety: L. inconsummatus. See In- not, and Consummate
entry.def: Not consummated; not finished; incomplete.

entry.ety: L. inconsumptibilis
entry.def: Inconsumable.

entry.ety: L. incontaminatus. See In- not, and not, and Contaminate
entry.def: Not contaminated; pure.

entry.ety: See In- not, and Content
entry.def: Discontent.
The quality or state of being incontestable.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + contestable: cf. F. incontestable
entry.def: Not contestable; not to be disputed; that cannot be called in question or controverted; incontrovertible; indisputable; as, incontestable evidence, truth, or facts.
entry.syn: Incontrovertible; indisputable; irrefragable; undeniable; unquestionable; intuitable; certain.

entry.def: Not contested.

entry.ety: L. incontiguus that can not be touched. See In- not, and Contiguous
entry.def: Not contiguous; not adjoining or in contact; separate.

entry.ety: L. incontinentia: cf. F. incontinence

sn.def: Incapacity to hold; hence, incapacity to hold back or restrain; the quality or state of being incontinent; lack of continence; failure to restrain the passions or appetites; indulgence of lust; lewdness.
sn.q: That Satan tempt you not for your incontinency.
From the rash hand of bold incontinence.

sn.def: The inability of any of the animal organs to restrain the natural evacuations, especially urination, or defecation, so that the discharges are involuntary; as, incontinence of urine.

entry.ety: L. incontinens: cf. F. incontinent. See In- not, and Continent

sn.def: Not continent; uncontrolled; not restraining the passions or appetites, particularly the sexual appetite; indulging unlawful lust; unchaste; lewd.
Unable to restrain natural evacuations, such as urination or defecation.

entry.def: One who is unchaste.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incontinent
entry.def: Incontinently; instantly; immediately.
entry.q: He says he will return incontinent.

sn.def: In an incontinent manner; without restraint, or without due restraint; -- used esp. of the passions or appetites.
Immediately; at once; forthwith.
sn.q: Immediately he sent word to Athens that he would incontinently come hither with a host of men.

entry.def: Uncontracted.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + controllable: cf. F. incontrôlable
entry.def: Not controllable; uncontrollable.
The state or condition of being incontrovertible.
Not controvertible; too clear or certain to admit of dispute; indisputable.

entry.ety: L. inconvenientia inconsistency: cf. OF. inconvenience

sn.def: The quality or condition of being inconvenient; lack of convenience; unfitness; unsuitableness; inexpediency; awkwardness; as, the inconvenience of the arrangement.
sn.q: They plead against the inconvenience, not the unlawfulness, . . . of ceremonies in burial.

sn.def: That which gives trouble, embarrassment, or uneasiness; disadvantage; anything that disturbs quiet, impedes prosperity, or increases the difficulty of action or success; as, one inconvenience of life is poverty.
sn.q: A place upon the top of Mount Athos above all clouds of rain, or other inconvenience.
Man is liable to a great many inconveniences.
sn.syn: Incommodiousness; awkwardness; disadvantage; disquiet; uneasiness; disturbance; annoyance.

entry.def: To put to inconvenience; to incommode; as, to inconvenience a neighbor.
Inconvenience.

entry.ety: L. inconveniens unbefitting: cf. F. inconvénient. See In- not, and Convenient

sn.def: Not becoming or suitable; unfit; inexpedient.

Not convenient; giving trouble, uneasiness, or annoyance; hindering progress or success; uncomfortable; disadvantageous; incommodious; inopportune; as, an inconvenient house, garment, arrangement, or time.
sn.syn: Unsuitable; uncomfortable; disaccommodating; awkward; annoying; unseasonable; inopportune; incommodious; disadvantageous; troublesome; cumbersome; embarrassing; objectionable.

entry.def: In an inconvenient manner; incommodiously; unsuitably; unseasonably.
Incommunicative; unsocial; reserved.
Not conversant; not acquainted; not versed; unfamiliar.
Not turned or changed about.

entry.ety: L. inconvertibilitas
entry.def: The quality or state of being inconvertible; not capable of being exchanged for, or converted into, something else; as, the inconvertibility of an irredeemable currency, or of lead, into gold.

entry.ety: L. inconvertibilis: cf. F. inconvertible. See In- not, and Convertible
entry.def: Not convertible; not capable of being transmuted, changed into, or exchanged for, something else; as, one metal is inconvertible into another; bank notes are sometimes inconvertible into specie.
Inconvertibility.
In an inconvertible manner.

entry.ety: L. inconvincibilis. See In- not, and Convince
entry.def: Not convincible; incapable of being convinced.
entry.q: None are so inconvincible as your half-witted people.

entry.def: In a manner not admitting of being convinced.

entry.ety: Cf. Conny Canny
entry.def: Unlearned; artless; pretty; delicate.
entry.q: Most sweet jests! most incony vulgar wit!

entry.def: Not coördinate.

cs.cd: irregularity in movements resulting from inharmonious action of the muscles in consequence of loss of voluntary control over them.

entry.def: Lack of coördination; lack of harmonious adjustment or action.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + coronate
entry.def: Crowned.

entry.ety: L. incorporalis. See In- not, and Corporal, and cf. Incorporeal
entry.def: Immaterial; incorporeal; spiritual.

entry.ety: L. incorporalitas: cf. F. incorporalité
entry.def: Incorporeality.
Incorporeally.

entry.ety: L. incorporatus. See In- not, and Corporate

sn.def: Not consisting of matter; not having a material body; incorporeal; spiritual.
sn.q: Moses forbore to speak of angles, and things invisible, and incorporate.

sn.def: Not incorporated; not existing as a corporation; as, an incorporate banking association.

entry.ety: L. incorporatus, p. p. of incorporare to incorporate; pref. in- in + corporare to make into a body. See Corporate
entry.def: Corporate; incorporated; made one body, or united in one body; associated; mixed together; combined; embodied.
entry.q: As if our hands, our sides, voices, and minds Had been incorporate.
A fifteenth part of silver incorporate with gold.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incorporated; p. pr. & vb. n. Incorporating

sn.def: To form into a body; to combine, as different ingredients, into one consistent mass.
sn.q: By your leaves, you shall not stay alone, Till holy church incorporate two in one.

sn.def: To unite with a material body; to give a material form to; to embody.
sn.q: The idolaters, who worshiped their images as gods, supposed some spirit to be incorporated therein.

sn.def: To unite with, or introduce into, a mass already formed; as, to incorporate copper with silver; -- used with with and into.

To unite intimately; to blend; to assimilate; to combine into a structure or organization, whether material or mental; as, to incorporate provinces into the realm; to incorporate another's ideas into one's work.
sn.q: The Romans did not subdue a country to put the inhabitants to fire and sword, but to incorporate them into their own community.

sn.def: To form into a legal body, or body politic; to constitute into a corporation recognized by law, with special functions, rights, duties and liabilities; as, to incorporate a bank, a railroad company, a city or town, etc.

entry.def: To unite in one body so as to make a part of it; to be mixed or blended; -- usually followed by with.
entry.q: Painters' colors and ashes do better incorporate will oil.
He never suffers wrong so long to grow, And to incorporate with right so far As it might come to seem the same in show.

sn.def: United or combined together to form in one body.
Formed into a corporation and registered with a government body as such; made a legal entity.

entry.ety: L. incorporatio: cf. F. incorporation

sn.def: The act of incorporating, or the state of being incorporated.
The union of different ingredients in one mass; mixture; combination; synthesis.
The union of something with a body already existing; association; intimate union; assimilation; as, the incorporation of conquered countries into the Roman republic.

sd.def: The act of creating a corporation.
A body incorporated; a corporation.

entry.def: Incorporating or tending to incorporate; as, the incorporative languages (as of the Basques, North American Indians, etc. ) which run a whole phrase into one word.
entry.q: History demonstrates that incorporative unions are solid and permanent; but that a federal union is weak.

entry.def: One of a number of persons who gets a company incorporated; one of the original members of a corporation.

entry.cs: Incorporeal hereditament. See under Hereditament.
entry.ety: Pref. in- not + corporeal: cf. L. incorporeus. Cf. Incorporal

sn.def: Not corporeal; not having a material body or form; not consisting of matter; immaterial.
sn.q: Thus incorporeal spirits to smaller forms Reduced their shapes immense.
Sense and perception must necessarily proceed from some incorporeal substance within us.

sn.def: Existing only in contemplation of law; not capable of actual visible seizin or possession; not being an object of sense; intangible; -- opposed to corporeal.
sn.syn: Immaterial; unsubstantial; bodiless; spiritual.

entry.def: Existence without a body or material form; immateriality.
One who believes in incorporealism.
The state or quality of being incorporeal or bodiless; immateriality; incorporealism.
In an incorporeal manner.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + corporeity: cf. F. incorporéite
entry.def: The quality of being incorporeal; immateriality.
To incorporate.

entry.ety: L. incorrectus: cf. F. incorrect. See In- not, and Correct

sn.def: Not correct; not according to a copy or model, or to established rules; inaccurate; faulty.
sn.q: The piece, you think, is incorrect.

sn.def: Not in accordance with the truth; inaccurate; not exact; as, an incorrect statement or calculation.
Not accordant with duty or morality; not duly regulated or subordinated; unbecoming; improper; as, incorrect conduct.
sn.q: It shows a will most incorrect to heaven.
The wit of the last age was yet more incorrect than their language.
sn.syn: Inaccurate; erroneous; wrong; faulty.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + correction: cf. F. incorrection
entry.def: Lack of correction, restraint, or discipline.
Not correctly; inaccurately; not exactly; as, a writing incorrectly copied; testimony incorrectly stated.
The quality of being incorrect; lack of conformity to truth or to a standard; inaccuracy; inexactness; as, incorrectness may consist in defect or in redundance.
Lack of correspondence; disagreement; disproportion.
Not corresponding; disagreeing.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incorrigibilité
entry.def: The state or quality of being incorrigible.
entry.q: The ingratitude, the incorrigibility, the strange perverseness . . . of mankind.

entry.ety: L. incorrigibilis: cf. F. incorrigible. See In- not, and Corrigible
entry.def: Not corrigible; incapable of being corrected or amended; bad beyond correction; irreclaimable; as, incorrigible error.
entry.q: Incorrigiblefools.

entry.def: One who is incorrigible; a person whose persistent bad behavior cannot be changed; especially, a hardened criminal; as, the perpetual imprisonment of incorrigibles; incorrigible and disruptive children need to be placed in a separate classroom.
Incorrigibility.
In an incorrigible manner.
Incapable of being corroded, consumed, or eaten away.

entry.ety: L. incorruptus. See In- not, and Corrupt

sn.def: Not affected with corruption or decay; unimpaired; not marred or spoiled.
Not defiled or depraved; pure; sound; untainted; above the influence of bribes; upright; honest.
sn.q: Your Christian principles . . . which will preserve you incorrupt as individuals.

entry.def: Uncorrupted.
entry.q: Breathed into their incorrupted breasts.

entry.ety: L. incorruptibilitas: cf. F. incorruptibilité
entry.def: The quality of being incorruptible; incapability of corruption.

entry.ety: L. incorruptibilis: cf. F. incorruptible. See In- not, and Corrupt

sn.def: Not corruptible; incapable of corruption, decay, or dissolution; as, gold is incorruptible .
sn.q: Our bodies shall be changed into incorruptible and immortal substances.

sn.def: Incapable of being bribed or morally corrupted; inflexibly just and upright.

entry.def: One of a religious sect which arose in Alexandria, in the reign of the Emperor Justinian, and which believed that the body of Christ was incorruptible, and that he suffered hunger, thirst, pain, only in appearance.
The quality or state of being incorruptible.
In an incorruptible manner.

entry.ety: L. incorruptio: cf. F. incorruption. See In- not, and Corruption
entry.def: The condition or quality of being incorrupt or incorruptible; absence of, or exemption from, corruption.
entry.q: It is sown in corruption; it is raised in incorruption.
The same preservation, or, rather, incorruption, we have observed in the flesh of turkeys, capons, etc.

entry.ety: L. incorruptivus
entry.def: Incorruptible; not liable to decay.
Without corruption.
entry.q: To demean themselves incorruptly.

sn.def: Freedom or exemption from decay or corruption.
Probity; integrity; honesty.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incrassated; p. pr. & vb. n. Incrassating
entry.ety: L. incrassatus, p. p. of incrassare; pref. in- in + crassus thick
entry.def: To make thick or thicker; to thicken; especially, in pharmacy, to thicken (a liquid) by the mixture of another substance, or by evaporating the thinner parts.
entry.q: Acids dissolve or attenuate; alkalies precipitate or incrassate.
Liquors which time hath incrassated into jellies.

entry.def: To become thick or thicker.

entry.ety: L. incrassatus, p. p

sn.def: Made thick or thicker; thickened; inspissated.
Thickened; becoming thicker.
Swelled out on some particular part, as the antennæ of certain insects.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incrassation

sn.def: The act or process of thickening or making thick; the process of becoming thick or thicker.
The state of being incrassated or made thick; inspissation.

entry.def: Having the quality of thickening; tending to thicken.
A substance which has the power to thicken; formerly, a medicine supposed to thicken the humors.
Capable of being increased.
entry.q: An indefinite increasableness of some of our ideas.

cs.cd: a function whose value increases when that of the variable increases, and decreases when the latter is diminished; also called a monotonically increasing function.

entry.usage: To Increase Enlarge Extend. Enlarge implies to make larger or broader in size. Extend marks the progress of enlargement so as to have wider boundaries. Increase denotes enlargement by growth and internal vitality, as in the case of plants. A kingdom is enlarged by the addition of new territories; the mind is enlarged by knowledge. A kingdom is extended when its boundaries are carried to a greater distance from the center. A man's riches, honors, knowledge, etc., are increased by accessions which are made from time to time.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Increased; p. pr. & vb. n. Increasing
entry.ety: OE. incresen encresen enrescen, OF. encreistre, fr. L. increscere; pref. in- in + crescere to grow. See Crescent, and cf. Decrease

sn.def: To become greater or more in size, quantity, number, degree, value, intensity, power, authority, reputation, wealth; to grow; to augment; to advance; -- opposed to decrease.
sn.q: The waters increased and bare up the ark.
He must increase, but I must decrease.
The heavens forbid But that our loves and comforts should increase, Even as our days do grow!

sn.def: To multiply by the production of young; to be fertile, fruitful, or prolific.
sn.q: Fishes are more numerous or increasing than beasts or birds, as appears by their numerous spawn.

sn.def: To become more nearly full; to show more of the surface; to wax; as, the moon increases .
sn.syn: To enlarge; extend; multiply; expand; develop; heighten; amplify; raise; enhance; spread; aggravate; magnify; augment; advance.

entry.def: To augment or make greater in bulk, quantity, extent, value, or amount, etc.; to add to; to extend; to lengthen; to enhance; to aggravate; as, to increase one's possessions, influence.
entry.q: I will increase the famine.
Make denialsIncrease your services.

cs.cd: the twixt of a rifle groove in which the angle of twist increases from the breech to the muzzle.

entry.ety: OE. encres encresse. See Increase v. i.

sn.def: Addition or enlargement in size, extent, quantity, number, intensity, value, substance, etc.; augmentation; growth.
sn.q: As if increase of appetite had grown By what it fed on.
For things of tender kind for pleasure made Shoot up with swift increase, and sudden are decay'd.

sn.def: That which is added to the original stock by augmentation or growth; produce; profit; interest.
sn.q: Take thou no usury of him, or increase.
Let them not live to taste this land's increase.

sn.def: Progeny; issue; offspring.
sn.q: All the increase of thy house shall die in the flower of their age.

sn.def: Generation.
sn.q: Organs ofincrease.

sn.def: The period of increasing light, or luminous phase; the waxing; -- said of the moon.
sn.q: Seeds, hair, nails, hedges, and herbs will grow soonest if set or cut in the increase of the moon.
sn.syn: Enlargement; extension; growth; development; increment; addition; accession; production.

entry.sn: made greater in size or amount or degree. Opposite of decreased.Narrower terms: augmented ; exaggerated, hyperbolic, inflated; exaggerated, magnified, enlarged ; raised(prenominal), inflated

entry.def: Full of increase; abundant in produce.
entry.q: Increasefulcrops.

entry.def: Increase.
One who, or that, increases.

entry.sn: becoming greater or larger; as, increasing prices.Narrower terms: accretionary ; augmenting, augmentative, building ; expanding ; flared, flaring ; growing ; incorporative ; lengthening ; maximizing ; multiplicative ; profit-maximizing ; raising ; accretive ; rising decreasing

sn.def: same as growing, 1.
sn.syn: growing(prenominal), incremental.

entry.sn: Music increasing in some musical quality. Opposite of decreasing.Narrower terms: accelerando ; crescendo

entry.def: More and more.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Increated; p. pr. & vb. n. Increating
entry.ety: Pref. in- in + create
entry.def: To create within.

entry.ety: L. increatus. See In- not, and Create
entry.def: Uncreated; self-existent.
entry.q: Bright effluence of bright essence increate.

entry.ety: L. incredibilitas: cf. F. incrédibilité

sn.def: The quality or state of being incredible; incredibleness.
That which is incredible.

entry.ety: L. incredibilis: cf. OF. incredible. See In- not, and Credible
entry.def: Not credible; surpassing belief; too extraordinary and improbable to admit of belief; unlikely; marvelous; fabulous.
entry.q: Why should it be thought a thing incredible with you, that God should raise the dead?

entry.def: Incredibility.
In an incredible manner.
Uncredited.

entry.ety: L. incredulitas: cf. F. incrédulité
entry.def: The state or quality of being incredulous; a withholding or refusal of belief; skepticism; unbelief; disbelief.
entry.q: Of every species of incredulity, religious unbelief is the most irrational.

entry.ety: L. incredulus. See In- not, and Credulous

sn.def: Not credulous; indisposed to admit or accept that which is related as true, skeptical; unbelieving.
sn.q: A fantastical incredulous fool.

sn.def: Indicating, or caused by, disbelief or incredulity.
sn.q: Anincreduloussmile.

sn.def: Incredible; not easy to be believed.

entry.def: In an incredulous manner; with incredulity.
Incredulity.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + L. cremabilis combustible, fr. cremare to burn
entry.def: Incapable of being burnt; incombustibe.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + cremate
entry.def: To consume or reduce to ashes by burning, as a dead body; to cremate.
Burning; esp., the act of burning a dead body; cremation.

cs.cd: an infinitesimally small variation considered in Differential Calculus. See Calculus.

a calculus founded on the properties of the successive values of variable quantities and their differences or increments. It differs from the method of fluxions in treating these differences as finite, instead of infinitely small, and is equivalent to the calculus of finite differences.

entry.ety: L. incrementum: cf. F. incrément. See Increase

sn.def: The act or process of increasing; growth in bulk, guantity, number, value, or amount; augmentation; enlargement.
sn.q: The seminary that furnisheth matter for the formation and increment of animal and vegetable bodies.
A nation, to be great, ought to be compressed in its increment by nations more civilized than itself.

sn.def: Matter added; increase; produce; production; -- opposed to decrement.
sn.q: Largeincrement.

sn.def: The increase of a variable quantity or fraction from its present value to its next ascending value; the finite quantity, generally variable, by which a variable quantity is increased.
An amplification without strict climax, as in the following passage:
sn.q: Finally, brethren, whatsoever things are true, whatsoever things are honest, whatsoever things are just, whatsoever things are pure, whatsoever things are lovely, whatsoever things are of good report, . . . think on these things.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or resulting from, the process of growth; as, the incremental lines in the dentine of teeth.

entry.ety: L. increpatus, p. p. of increpare to upbraid; pref. in- in, against + crepare to talk noisily
entry.def: To chide; to rebuke; to reprove.

entry.ety: L. increpatio
entry.def: A chiding; rebuke; reproof.

entry.ety: L. increscens -entis, p. pr. of increscere. See Increase

sn.def: Increasing; growing; augmenting; swelling; enlarging.
sn.q: Between the incresent and decrescent moon.

sn.def: Increasing; on the increase; -- said of the moon represented as the new moon, with the points turned toward the dexter side.

entry.def: To adorn with a crest.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incriminated; p. pr. & vb. n. Incriminating
entry.ety: LL. incriminatus, p. p. of incriminare; in- in + criminare criminari, to accuse one of a crime. See Criminate
entry.def: To accuse; to charge with a crime or fault; to criminate.
charging or suggestive of guilt or blame; as, incriminating testimony; incriminating evidence.
The act of incriminating; crimination.
Of or pertaining to crimination; tending to incriminate; criminatory.

entry.note: ☞ The name is said to have been given in allusion not only to the extravagant dress, but also to the frequent use of the phrase “C'est vraiment incroyable” (That is really incredible.).
entry.ety: F., lit., incredible
entry.def: A French fop or dandy of the time of the Directory; hence, any fop.

entry.ety: L. incruentus. See In- not, and Cruentous
entry.def: Unbloody; not attended with blood; as, an incruental sacrifice.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incrusted; p. pr. & vb. n. Incrusting
entry.ety: L. incrustare; pref. in- in + crustare to cover with a crust: cf. F. incruster. See Crust

sn.def: To cover or line with a crust, or hard coat; to form a crust on the surface of; as, iron incrusted with rust; a vessel incrusted with salt; a sweetmeat incrusted with sugar.
sn.q: And by the frost refin'd the whiter snow,Incrusted hard.

sn.def: To inlay into, as a piece of carving or other ornamental object.

entry.ety: L. incrustatus, p. p. See Incrust
entry.def: Incrusted.
To incrust.

entry.ety: L. incrustatio: cf. F. incrustation. See Incrust

sn.def: The act of incrusting, or the state of being incrusted.
A crust or hard coating of anything upon or within a body, as a deposit of lime, sediment, etc., from water on the inner surface of a steam boiler.
A covering or inlaying of marble, mosaic, etc., attached to the masonry by cramp irons or cement.
Anything inlaid or imbedded.

entry.def: Incrustation.
Not crystallizable; incapable of being formed into crystals.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incubated; p. pr. & vb. n. Incubating
entry.ety: L. incubatus, p. p. incubare to lie on; pref. in- in, on + cubare to lie down. Cf. Cubit Incumbent

sn.def: To sit, as on eggs for hatching; to brood; to brood upon, or keep warm, as eggs, for the purpose of hatching.

To maintain (a living organism, such as microorganisms or a premature baby) under appropriate conditions, such as of temperature, humidity, or atmospheric composition, for growth; as, coliform bacteria grow best when incubated at 37° C..
To develop gradually in some interior environment, until fully formed; as, the ideas for his book were incubating for two years before he began to write.

cs.cd: the period which elapses between exposure to the causes of an infectious disease and the attack resulting from it; the time during which an infective agent must grow in the body before producing overt symptoms of disease.

entry.ety: L. incubatio: cf. F. incubation

sn.def: A sitting on eggs for the purpose of hatching young; a brooding on, or keeping warm, (eggs) to develop the life within, by any process.
The development of a disease from its causes, or its period of incubation. (See below
A sleeping in a consecrated place for the purpose of dreaming oracular dreams.
The maintenance (of a living organism, such as microorganisms or a premature baby) in appropriate conditions, such as of temperature, humidity, or atmospheric composition, for growth.
The gradual development in some interior environment, until fully formed; as, the incubation time for developing a new drug may be longer than ten years from its first discovery.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to incubation, or to the period of incubation.

sn.def: That which incubates, especially, an apparatus by means of which eggs are hatched by artificial heat.

An apparatus containing an enclosed chamber, used for the cultivation of microörganisms or tissue cultures by maintaining a suitable temperature and atmospheric composition. Some incubators have no provision for maintaining a special atmosphere, while in others, especially for anaerobic organisms and tissue culture, the moisture level and composition of the gases are also controlled.

An apparatus consisting of enclosed chamber, for maintaining prematurely born babies in a favorable environment until able to thrive under normal conditions. The temperature and level of oxygen in the atmosphere may be controlled.

entry.def: Serving for incubation.
To fix firmly, as in cube; to secure or place firmly.

entry.ety: Cf. L. incubitus
entry.def: Incubation.

entry.ety: From L. incubare to lie on
entry.def: Having the leaves so placed that the upper part of each one covers the base of the leaf next above it, as in hepatic mosses of the genus Frullania. See Succubous.

entries.entry:
In"cu*bus n.; pl. E. Incubuses #, L. Incubi #. L., the nightmare. Cf. Incubate
A demon; a fiend; a lascivious spirit, supposed to have sexual intercourse with women by night. The devils who appeared in the female form were generally called succubi; those who appeared like men incubi, though this distinction was not always preserved.
Med The nightmare. See Nightmare. Such as are troubled with incubus, or witch-ridden, as we call it.
Any oppressive encumbrance or burden; anything that prevents the free use of the faculties. Debt and usury is the incubus which weighs most heavily on the agricultural resources of Turkey.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inculcated; p. pr. & vb. n. Inculcating
entry.ety: L. inculcatus, p. p. of inculcare to tread on; pref. in- in, on + calcare to tread, fr. calx the heel; perh. akin to E. heel. Cf. 2d Calk Heel
entry.def: To teach and impress by frequent repetitions or admonitions; to urge on the mind; as, Christ inculcates on his followers humility.
entry.q: The most obvious and necessary duties of life they have not yet had authority enough to enforce and inculcate upon men's minds.
entry.syn: To instill; infuse; implant; engraft; impress.

entry.ety: L. inculcatio: cf. F. inculcation
entry.def: A teaching and impressing by frequent repetitions.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who inculcates.

entries.entry:
In*culk". v. t. Cf. F. inculquer. See Inculcate
To inculcate. Obs

entry.ety: Cf. inculper. See Inculpate
entry.def: To inculpate.

entry.ety: L. inculpabilis: cf. F. incupable
entry.def: Faultless; blameless; innocent.
entry.q: An innocent and incupable piece of ignorance.

entry.def: Blamelessness; faultlessness.
Blamelessly.

entry.note: A word of recent introduction
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inculpated; p. pr. & vb. n. Inculpating
entry.ety: LL. inculpatus, p. p. of inculpare to blame; pref. in- in + culpa fault. See Culpable
entry.def: To blame; to impute guilt to; to accuse; to involve or implicate in guilt. Contrasted with exculpate.
entry.q: That risk could only exculpate her and not inculpate them -- the probabilities protected them so perfectly.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inculpation
entry.def: Blame; censure; crimination.

entries.entry: inculpative adj. Inculpatory.Narrower terms: accusatorial, accusatory, accusing; comminatory, denunciative, denunciatory; condemnatory, condemning ; criminative, criminatory, incriminating, incriminatory ; damnatory, damning ; recriminative, recriminatory Also See: guilty. inculpatory.

entry.def: Imputing blame; causing blame to be imputed to; criminatory; compromising; implicating. Opposite of exculpatory.

entry.ety: L. incultus; pref. in- not + cultus, p. p. of colere to cultivate: cf. F. inculte
entry.def: Untilled; uncultivated; crude; rude; uncivilized.
entry.q: Germany then, says Tacitus, was incult and horrid, now full of magnificent cities.
His style is diffuse and incult.

entry.def: Uncultivated.
Lack of cultivation.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + culture: cf. F. inculture
entry.def: Want or neglect of cultivation or culture.

entries.entry:
In*cum"ben*cy n.; pl.Incumbencies #. From Incumbent
The state of being incumbent; a lying or resting on something.
That which is physically incumbent; that which lies as a burden; a weight.
That which is morally incumbent, or is imposed, as a rule, a duty, obligation, or responsibility. Theincumbenciesof a family.
The state of holding a benefice; the full possession and exercise of any office. These fines are only to be paid to the bishop during his incumbency.

entry.ety: L. incumbens -entis, p. pr. of incumbere to lie down upon, press upon; pref. in- in, on + cumberein comp.); akin to cubare to lie down. See Incubate

sn.def: Lying; resting; reclining; recumbent; superimposed; superincumbent.
sn.q: Two incumbent figures, gracefully leaning upon it.
To move the incumbent load they try.

sn.def: Lying, resting, or imposed, as a duty or obligation; obligatory; always with on or upon.
sn.q: All men, truly zealous, will perform those good works that are incumbent on all Christians.

sn.def: Leaning or resting; -- said of anthers when lying on the inner side of the filament, or of cotyledons when the radicle lies against the back of one of them.
Bent downwards so that the ends touch, or rest on, something else; as, the incumbent toe of a bird.

entry.def: A person who is in present possession of a benefice or of any office.
entry.q: The incumbent lieth at the mercy of his patron.

entry.def: In an incumbent manner; so as to be incumbent.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incumbered; p. pr. & vb. n. Incumbering
entry.def: See Encumber.
Incubation.

entry.ety: See Encumbrance

sn.def: A burdensome and troublesome load; anything that impedes motion or action, or renders it difficult or laborious; clog; impediment; hindrance; check.
A burden or charge upon property; a claim or lien upon an estate, which may diminish its value.

entry.def: One who holds an incumbrance, or some legal claim, lien, or charge on an estate.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. encombros
entry.def: Cumbersome; troublesome.

entries.entry:
‖In`cu*nab"u*lum n.; pl.Incunabula #. L. incunabula cradle, birthplace, origin. See 1st In-, and Cunabula
A work of art or of human industry, of an early epoch; especially, a book printed before a. d. 1500.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incurred; p. pr. & vb. n. Incurring
entry.ety: L. incurrere to run into or toward; pref. in- in + currere to run. See Current

sn.def: To meet or fall in with, as something inconvenient, harmful, or onerous; to put one's self in the way of; to expose one's self to; to become liable or subject to; to bring down upon one's self; to encounter; to contract; as, to incur debt, danger, displeasure, penalty, responsibility, etc.
sn.q: I know not what I shall incur to pass it, Having no warrant.

sn.def: To render liable or subject to; to occasion.
sn.q: Lest you incur me much more damage in my fame than you have done me pleasure in preserving my life.

entry.def: To pass; to enter.
entry.q: Light is discerned by itself because by itself it incurs into the eye.

entry.ety: Cf. F. incurabilité incurability, LL. incurabilitas negligence
entry.def: The state of being incurable; irremediableness.

entry.ety: F. incurable, L. incurabilis. See In- not, and Curable

sn.def: Not capable of being cured; beyond the power of skill or medicine to remedy; as, an incurable disease.
sn.q: A scirrhus is not absolutely incurable.

sn.def: Not admitting or capable of remedy or correction; irremediable; remediless; as, incurable evils.
sn.q: Rancorous and incurable hostility.
They were laboring under a profound, and, as it might have seemed, an almost incurable ignorance.
sn.syn: Irremediable; remediless; irrecoverable; irretrievable; irreparable; hopeless.

entry.def: A person diseased beyond cure.
The state of being incurable; incurability.
In a manner that renders cure impracticable or impossible; irremediably.
entry.q: Incurablydiseased.
Incurablywicked.

entry.ety: L. incuriositas: cf. F. incurosité
entry.def: Lack of curiosity or interest; inattentiveness; indifference.

entry.ety: L. incuriosus: cf. F. incurieux. See In- not, and Curious
entry.def: Not curious or inquisitive; without care for or interest in; inattentive; careless; negligent; heedless.
entry.q: Carelessnesses and incurious deportments toward their children.

entry.def: In an curious manner.
Unconcernedness; incuriosity.
entry.q: Sordid incuriousness and slovenly neglect.

entry.ety: See Incur
entry.def: The act of incurring, bringing on, or subjecting one's self to (something troublesome or burdensome); as, the incurrence of guilt, debt, responsibility, etc.

entry.ety: L. incurrens, p. pr. incurere incursum, to run in; in- + currere to run
entry.def: Characterized by a current which flows inward; as, the incurrent orifice of lamellibranch Mollusca.

entry.ety: L. incursio: cf. F. incursion. See Incur

sn.def: A running into; hence, an entering into a territory with hostile intention; a temporary invasion; a predatory or harassing inroad; a raid.
sn.q: The Scythian, whose incursions wild Have wasted Sogdiana.
The incursions of the Goths disordered the affairs of the Roman Empire.

sn.def: Attack; occurrence.
sn.q: Sins of daily incursion.
sn.syn: Invasion; inroad; raid; foray; sally; attack; onset; irruption. See Invasion.

entry.def: Making an incursion; invasive; aggressive; hostile.
To curtain.

entry.ety: L. incurvatus, p. p. of incurvare to crook; pref. in- in + curvus bent. See Curve, and cf. Incurve
entry.def: Curved; bent; crooked.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incurvated; p. pr. & vb. n. Incurvating
entry.def: To turn from a straight line or course; to bend; to crook.

entry.ety: L. incurvatio: cf. F. incurvation

sn.def: The act of bending, or curving.
The state of being bent or curved; curvature.
sn.q: An incurvation of the rays.

sn.def: The act of bowing, or bending the body, in respect or reverence.
sn.q: Theincurvationsof the knee.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Incurved ĭn*kûvd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Incurving
entry.ety: See Incurvate
entry.def: To bend; to curve; to make crooked.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + curved
entry.def: Bending gradually toward the axis or center, as branches or petals.

entry.ety: From L. incurvus bent. See Incurvate
entry.def: A state of being bent or curved; incurvation; a bending inwards.

entry.ety: L., anvil

sn.def: An anvil.
One of the small bones in the tympanum of the ear; the anvil bone. See Ear.
The central portion of the armature of the pharynx in the Rotifera.

entry.ety: See Incuse v. t.
entry.def: Cut or stamped in, or hollowed out by engraving.
entry.q: Irregularincusesquare.

entry.ety: L. incussus, p. p. of incutere to strike. See 1st In-, and Concuss
entry.def: To form, or mold, by striking or stamping, as a coin or medal.

entry.ety: See Incuse
entry.def: To strike or stamp in.
See Encyst.
See Encysted.
India.

entry.ety: L. indagatus, p. p. of indagare to seek
entry.def: To seek or search out.

entry.ety: L. indagatio: cf. F. indagation
entry.def: Search; inquiry; investigation.
Searching; exploring; investigating.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: A searcher; an explorer; an investigator.
entry.q: Searched into by such skillful indagators of nature.

entry.def: See Endamage.
Not damaged.
To pierce, as with a dart.

entry.ety: Indol + azote
entry.def: A bicyclic nitrogenous compound, C7H6N2, analogous to indole, having a benzene ring fused to a pyrazole ring; called also indazol and benzopyrazole. It can be produced from a diazo derivative of cinnamic acid.
Azure-colored; of a bright blue color.
See Endear.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Indebted; p. pr. & vb. n. Indebting
entry.ety: OE. endetten, F. endetter; pref. en-L. in) + F. dette debt. See Debt
entry.def: To bring into debt; to place under obligation; -- chiefly used in the participle indebted.
entry.q: Thy fortune hath indebted thee to none.

sn.def: Brought into debt; being under obligation; held to payment or requital; beholden.
sn.q: By owing, owes not, but still pays, at onceIndebted and discharged.

sn.def: Placed under obligation for something received, for which restitution or gratitude is due; as, we are indebted to our parents for their care of us in infancy; indebted to friends for help and encouragement.
The state of being indebted.
The sum owed; debts, collectively.

entry.ety: Cf. F. endettement
entry.def: Indebtedness.
See Indecency.
entry.q: Anindecenceof barbarity.

entries.entry:
In*de"cen*cy n.; pl.Indecencies #. L. indecentia unseemliness: cf. F. indécence
The quality or state of being indecent; lack of decency, modesty, or good manners; obscenity.
That which is indecent; an indecent word or act; an offense against delicacy. They who, by speech or writing, present to the ear or the eye of modesty any of the indecencies I allude to, are pests of society. Indelicacy; indecorum; immodesty; impurity; obscenity. See Indecorum.

entry.ety: L. indecens unseemly, unbecoming: cf. F. indécent. See In- not, and Decent
entry.def: Not decent; unfit to be seen or heard; offensive to modesty and delicacy; as, indecent language.
entry.syn: Unbecoming; indecorous; indelicate; unseemly; immodest; gross; shameful; impure; improper; obscene; filthy.

entry.def: In an indecent manner.

sn.def: Indeciduous.
Having no decidua; nondeciduate.

entry.def: Not deciduous or falling, as the leaves of trees in autumn; lasting; evergreen; persistent; permanent; perennial. Opposite of deciduous.
entry.q: The indeciduous and unshaven locks of Apollo.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + LL. decimare to tithe: cf. F. indécimable. See Decimate
entry.def: Not decimable, or liable to be decimated; not liable to the payment of tithes.
Not decipherable; incapable of being deciphered, explained, or solved.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + decision: cf. F. indécision
entry.def: Lack of decision; lack of settled purpose, or of firmness; indetermination; wavering of mind; irresolution; vacillation; hesitation.
entry.q: The term indecision . . . implies an idea very nicely different from irresolution; yet it has a tendency to produce it.
Indecision . . . is the natural accomplice of violence.

entry.ety: Cf. F. indécisif

sn.def: Not decisive; not bringing to a final or ultimate issue; as, an indecisive battle, argument, answer.
sn.q: The campaign had everywhere been indecisive.

sn.def: Undetermined; prone to indecision; irresolute; unsettled; wavering; vacillating; hesitating; as, an indecisive state of mind; an indecisive character.

entry.def: Without decision.
The state of being indecisive; unsettled state.

entry.ety: L. indeclinabilis: cf. F. indéclinable. See In- not, and Decline
entry.def: Not declinable; not varied by inflective terminations; as, nihilnothing), in Latin, is an indeclinable noun.

sn.def: Without variation.
Without variation of termination.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + decomposable: cf. F. indécomposable
entry.def: Not decomposable; incapable or difficult of decomposition; not resolvable into its constituents or elements.
Incapableness of decomposition; stability; permanence; durability.

entry.ety: L. indecorous. See In- not, and Decorous
entry.def: Not decorous; violating good manners; contrary to good breeding or etiquette; unbecoming; improper; out of place; as, indecorous conduct.
entry.q: It was useless and indecorous to attempt anything more by mere struggle.
entry.syn: Unbecoming; unseemly; unbefitting; rude; coarse; impolite; uncivil; ill-bred.

entry.def: In an indecorous manner.
The quality of being indecorous; lack of decorum.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + decorum: cf. L. indecorous unbecoming

sn.def: Lack of decorum; impropriety of behavior; that in behavior or manners which violates the established rules of civility, custom, or etiquette; indecorousness.
An indecorous or unbecoming action.
sn.syn: Indecorum is sometimes synonymous with indecency; but indecency, more frequently than indecorum, is applied to words or actions which refer to what nature and propriety require to be concealed or suppressed. Indecency is the stronger word; indecorum refers to any transgression of etiquette or civility, especially in public.

entry.ety: Prep. in + deed
entry.def: In reality; in truth; in fact; verily; truly; -- used in a variety of senses. Esp.: Denoting emphasis; as, indeed it is so. Denoting concession or admission; as, indeed, you are right. Denoting surprise; as, indeed, is it you? Its meaning is not intrinsic or fixed, but depends largely on the form of expression which it accompanies.
entry.q: The carnal mind is enmity against God; for it is not subject to the law of God, neither indeed can be.
I were a beast indeed to do you wrong.
There is, indeed, no great pleasure in visiting these magazines of war.

entry.def: The state of being indefatigable.

entry.ety: L. indefatigabilis: cf. OF. indefatigable. See In- not, and Defatigable, and cf. Infatigable
entry.def: Incapable of being fatigued; not readily exhausted; unremitting in labor or effort; untiring; unwearying; not yielding to fatigue; as, indefatigable exertions, perseverance, application.
entry.q: A constant,indefatigableattendance.
Upborne with indefatigable wings.

entry.def: Indefatigable quality; unweariedness; persistency.
Without weariness; without yielding to fatigue; persistently.
Indefatigableness; unweariedness.
The quality of being indefeasible.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + defeasible: cf. OF. indefaisable
entry.def: Not to be defeated; not defeasible; incapable of being annulled or made void; as, an indefeasible or title.
entry.q: That the king had a divine and an indefeasible right to the regal power.

entry.ety: Cf. F. indéfectibilité
entry.def: The quality of being indefectible.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + defectible: cf. F. indéfectible
entry.def: Not defectible; unfailing; not liable to defect, failure, or decay.
entry.q: An indefectible treasure in the heavens.
A state of indefectible virtue and happiness.

entry.def: Not defective; perfect; complete.
entry.q: Absolute,indefectiveobedience.

entry.def: Indefeasible.
The quality or state of not being defensible.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + defensible: cf. OF. indefensible indefensable
entry.def: Not defensible; not capable of being defended, maintained, vindicated, or justified; unjustifiable; untenable; as, an indefensible fortress, position, cause, statement, etc.
entry.q: Men find that something can be said in favor of what, on the very proposal, they thought utterly indefensible.

entry.def: In an indefensible manner.
Defenseless.
entry.q: The sword awes the indefensive villager.

entry.def: The state or quality of not being deficient.

entry.ety: L. indeficiens. See In- not, and Deficient
entry.def: Not deficient; full.
entry.q: Brighter than the sun, and indeficient as the light of heaven.

entry.def: Incapable of being defined or described; inexplicable.
In an indefinable manner.

entry.cs: Indefinite article Gram the word a or an, used with nouns to denote any one of a common or general class. Indefinite inflorescence. Bot See Indeterminate inflorescence, under Indeterminate. Indefinite proposition Logic a statement whose subject is a common term, with nothing to indicate distribution or nondistribution; as, Man is mortal. Indefinite term Logic a negative term; as, the not-good.
entry.ety: L. indefinitus. See In- not, and Definite

sn.def: Not definite; not limited, defined, or specified; not explicit; not determined or fixed upon; not precise; uncertain; vague; confused; obscure; as, an indefinite time, plan, etc.
sn.q: It were to be wished that . . . men would leave off that indefinite way of vouching, “the chymists say this,” or “the chymists affirm that.”
The time of this last is left indefinite.

sn.def: Having no determined or certain limits; large and unmeasured, though not infinite; unlimited; as, indefinite space; the indefinite extension of a straight line.
sn.q: Though it is not infinite, it may be indefinite; though it is not boundless in itself, it may be so to human comprehension.

sn.def: Boundless; infinite.
sn.q: Indefinite and omnipresent God, Inhabiting eternity.

sn.def: Too numerous or variable to make a particular enumeration important; -- said of the parts of a flower, and the like. Also, indeterminate.
sn.syn: Inexplicit; vague; uncertain; unsettled; indeterminate; loose; equivocal; inexact; approximate.

entry.def: In an indefinite manner or degree; without any settled limitation; vaguely; not with certainty or exactness; as, to use a word indefinitely .
entry.q: If the world be indefinitely extended, that is, so far as no human intellect can fancy any bound of it.

entry.def: The quality of being indefinite.
Indefiniteness; vagueness; also, number or quantity not limited by our understanding, though yet finite.

entry.ety: Cf. F. indéhiscence
entry.def: The property or state of being indehiscent.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + dehiscent: cf. F. indéhiscent
entry.def: Remaining closed at maturity, or not opening along regular lines, as the acorn, or a cocoanut.
Not delectable; unpleasant; disagreeable.

entry.ety: L. indeliberatus. See In- not, and Deliberate
entry.def: Done without deliberation; unpremeditated.
Indeliberate.

entry.ety: Cf. F. indélébilité
entry.def: The quality of being indelible.

cs.cd: fast colors which do not fade or tarnish by exposure.
an ink not obliterated by washing; esp., a solution of silver nitrate.

entry.ety: L. indelebilis; pref. in- not + delebilis capable of being destroyed: cf. F. indélébile. See In- not, and Deleble

sn.def: That can not be removed, washed away, blotted out, or effaced; incapable of being canceled, lost, or forgotten; as, indelible characters; an indelible stain; an indelible impression on the memory.
That can not be annulled; indestructible.
sn.q: They are endued with indelible power from above.
sn.syn: Fixed; fast; permanent; ineffaceable.
sn.q: Indelibly stamped and impressed.

entries.entry:
In*del"i*ca*cy n.; pl.Indelicacies #. From Indelicate
The quality of being indelicate; lack of delicacy, or of a nice sense of, or regard for, purity, propriety, or refinement in manners, language, etc.; rudeness; coarseness; also, that which is offensive to refined taste or purity of mind. The indelicacy of English comedy. Your papers would be chargeable with worse than indelicacy; they would be immoral.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + delicate: cf. F. indélicat
entry.def: Not delicate; wanting delicacy; offensive to good manners, or to purity of mind; coarse; rude; as, an indelicate word or suggestion; indelicate behavior.
entry.syn: Indecorous; unbecoming; unseemly; rude; coarse; broad; impolite; gross; indecent; offensive; improper; unchaste; impure; unrefined.

sn.def: The act or process of indemnifying, preserving, or securing against loss, damage, or penalty; reimbursement of loss, damage, or penalty; the state of being indemnified.
sn.q: Indemnification is capable of some estimate; dignity has no standard.

sn.def: That which indemnifies.
sn.q: No reward with the name of an indemnification.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Indemnified; p. pr. & vb. n. Indemnifying
entry.ety: L. indemnis unhurt (in- not + damnum hurt, damage) + -fy. Cf. Damn Damnify

sn.def: To save harmless; to secure against loss or damage; to insure.
sn.q: The states must at last engage to the merchants here that they will indemnify them from all that shall fall out.

sn.def: To make restitution or compensation for, as for that which is lost; to make whole; to reimburse; to compensate.

entries.entry:
In*dem"ni*ty ☞ Insurance is a contract of indemnity. Arnould. The owner of private property taken for public use is entitled to compensation or indemnity.
Act of indemnity Law an act or law passed in order to relieve persons, especially in an official station, from some penalty to which they are liable in consequence of acting illegally, or, in case of ministers, in consequence of exceeding the limits of their strict constitutional powers. These acts also sometimes provide compensation for losses or damage, either incurred in the service of the government, or resulting from some public measure.
n.; pl.Indemnities #. L. indemnitas, fr. indemnis uninjured: cf. F. indemnité. See Indemnify
Security; insurance; exemption from loss or damage, past or to come; immunity from penalty, or the punishment of past offenses; amnesty. Having first obtained a promise of indemnity for the riot they had committed.
Indemnification, compensation, or remuneration for loss, damage, or injury sustained. They were told to expect, upon the fall of Walpole, a large and lucrative indemnity for their pretended wrongs.

entry.def: The quality of being indemonstrable.

entry.ety: L. indemonstrabilis. See In- not, and Demonstrable
entry.def: Incapable of being demonstrated.
The act of naturalizing; endenization.
To naturalize.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Indenizened; p. pr. & vb. n. Indenizening
entry.def: To invest with the privileges of a denizen; to naturalize.
entry.q: Words indenizened, and commonly used as English.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Indented; p. pr. & vb. n. Indenting
entry.ety: OE. endenten to notch, fit in, OF. endenter, LL. indentare, fr. L. in + dens dentis, tooth. See Tooth, and cf. Indenture

sn.def: To notch; to jag; to cut into points like a row of teeth; as, to indent the edge of paper.
To dent; to stamp or to press in; to impress; as, indent a smooth surface with a hammer; to indent wax with a stamp.
To bind out by indenture or contract; to indenture; to apprentice; as, to indent a young man to a shoemaker; to indent a servant.

To begin (a line or lines) at a greater or less distance from the margin; as, to indent the first line of a paragraph one em; to indent the second paragraph two ems more than the first. See Indentation, and Indention.
To make an order upon; to draw upon, as for military stores.
To be cut, notched, or dented.
To crook or turn; to wind in and out; to zigzag.
To contract; to bargain or covenant.
sn.q: To indent and drive bargains with the Almighty.

sn.def: A cut or notch in the margin of anything, or a recess like a notch.
A stamp; an impression.
A certificate, or intended certificate, issued by the government of the United States at the close of the Revolution, for the principal or interest of the public debt.
A requisition or order for supplies, sent to the commissariat of an army.

cs.cd: indentation of all the lines of a paragraph except the first, which is a full line; also called a hanging indent.

sn.def: The act of indenting or state of being indented.
A notch or recess, in the margin or border of anything; as, the indentations of a leaf, of the coast, etc.
A recess or sharp depression in any surface.

sd.def: The act of beginning a line or series of lines at a little distance within the flush line of the column or page, as in the common way of beginning the first line of a paragraph.
The measure of the distance; as, an indentation of one em, or of two ems.

cs.cd: a line with alternate long and short faces, with salient and receding angles, each face giving a flanking fire along the front of the next.

sn.def: Cut in the edge into points or inequalities, like teeth; jagged; notched; stamped in; dented on the surface.
Having an uneven, irregular border; sinuous; undulating.
Notched like the part of a saw consisting of the teeth; serrated; as, an indented border or ordinary.
Bound out by an indenture; apprenticed; indentured; as, an indented servant.
Notched along the margin with a different color, as the feathers of some birds.

entry.def: With indentations.
Indentation; an impression like that made by a tooth.
Same as Indentation, 4.
Indenture.

entry.note: ☞ Indentures were originally duplicates, laid together and indented by a notched cut or line, or else written on the same piece of parchment and separated by a notched line so that the two papers or parchments corresponded to each other. But indenting has gradually become a mere form, and is often neglected, while the writings or counterparts retain the name of indentures.
entry.ety: OE. endenture, OF. endenture, LL. indentura a deed in duplicate, with indented edges. See the Note below. See Indent

sn.def: The act of indenting, or state of being indented.

A mutual agreement in writing between two or more parties, whereof each party has usually a counterpart or duplicate, sometimes with the edges indented for purpose of identification; sometimes in the pl., a short form for indentures of apprenticeship, the contract by which a youth is bound apprentice to a master.
sn.q: The law is the best expositor of the gospel; they are like a pair of indentures: they answer in every part.

sn.def: A contract by which anyone is bound to service.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Indentured; p. pr. & vb. n. Indenturing

sn.def: To indent; to make hollows, notches, or wrinkles in; to furrow.
sn.q: Though age may creep on, and indenture the brow.

sn.def: To bind by indentures or written contract; as, to indenture an apprentice.

entry.def: To run or wind in and out; to be cut or notched; to indent.
Bound by contract to work for another for a specified period of time.

cs.cd: the declaration of the Congress of the Thirteen United States of America, on the 4th of July, 1776, by which they formally declared that these colonies were free and independent States, not subject to the government of Great Britain.

entry.ety: Cf. F. indépendance

sn.def: The state or quality of being independent; freedom from dependence; exemption from reliance on, or control by, others; self-subsistence or maintenance; direction of one's own affairs without interference.
sn.q: Let fortune do her worst, . . . as long as she never makes us lose our honesty and our independence.

sn.def: Sufficient means for a comfortable livelihood.

entries.entry: In`de*pend"ence Day. In the United States, a holiday, the 4th of July, commemorating the adoption of the Declaration of Independence on that day in 1776.

sn.def: Independence.
sn.q: “Give me,” I cried (enough for me), “My bread, and independency!”

sn.def: Doctrine and polity of the Independents.

entry.cs: Independent company Mil one not incorporated in any regiment. Independent seconds watch a stop watch having a second hand driven by a separate set of wheels, springs, etc., for timing to a fraction of a second. Independent variable. Math See Dependent variable, under Dependent.
entry.ety: Pref. in- not + dependent: cf. F. indépendant

sn.def: Not dependent; free; not subject to control by others; not relying on others; not subordinate; as, few men are wholly independent .
sn.q: A dry, but independent crust.

sn.def: Affording a comfortable livelihood; as, an independent property.
Not subject to bias or influence; not obsequious; self-directing; as, a man of an independent mind.
Expressing or indicating the feeling of independence; free; easy; bold; unconstrained; as, an independent air or manner.
Separate from; exclusive; irrespective.
sn.q: That obligation in general, under which we conceive ourselves bound to obey a law, independent of those resources which the law provides for its own enforcement.

sn.def: Belonging or pertaining to, or holding to the doctrines or methods of, the Independents.
Not dependent upon another quantity in respect to value or rate of variation; -- said of quantities or functions.
Not bound by party; exercising a free choice in voting with either or any party.
sn.syn: Free; uncontrolled; separate; uncoerced; self-reliant; bold; unconstrained; unrestricted.

entry.note: ☞ In England the name is often applied (commonly in the pl.) to the Congregationalists.

sn.def: One who believes that an organized Christian church is complete in itself, competent to self-government, and independent of all ecclesiastical authority.
One who does not acknowledge an obligation to support a party's candidate under all circumstances; one who exercises liberty in voting.

entry.def: Independency; the church system of Independents.
In an independent manner; without control.
Incapable of being deposed.
entry.q: Princes indeposable by the pope.

entry.ety: L. indepravatus
entry.def: Undepraved.

entry.ety: L. indeprecabilis. See In- not, and Deprecate
entry.def: Incapable or undeserving of being deprecated.

entry.ety: L. indeprehensibilis. See In- not, and Deprehensible
entry.def: Incapable of being found out.
Incapable of being deprived, or of being taken away.
Incapable of being described.
In an indescribable manner; to a degree impossible to desribe; as, indescribably beautiful.
Not descriptive.
Ill desert.

entry.ety: L. indesinens. See In- not, and Desinent
entry.def: Not ceasing; perpetual.
Undesirable.

entry.ety: Cf. F. indestructibilité
entry.def: The quality of being indestructible.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + destructible: cf. F. indestructible
entry.def: Not destructible; incapable of decomposition or of being destroyed; as, the Russian harvesters had primitive electronics, but they were built so sturdily they were almost indestructible .

entry.ety: L. indeterminabilis: cf. F. indéterminable. See In- not, and Determine
entry.def: Not determinable; impossible to be determined; not to be definitely known, ascertained, defined, or limited.
An indeterminable thing or quantity.

cs.cd: that branch of analysis which has for its object the solution of indeterminate problems.
coefficients arbitrarily assumed for convenience of calculation, or to facilitate some artifice of analysis. Their values are subsequently determined.

an equation in which the unknown quantities admit of an infinite number of values, or sets of values. A group of equations is indeterminate when it contains more unknown quantities than there are equations.

a mode of inflorescence in which the flowers all arise from axillary buds, the terminal bud going on to grow and sometimes continuing the stem indefinitely; -- called also acropetal inflorescence botryose inflorescence centripetal inflorescence, and indefinite inflorescence.
a problem which admits of an infinite number of solutions, or one in which there are fewer imposed conditions than there are unknown or required results.
a quantity which has no fixed value, but which may be varied in accordance with any proposed condition.
a series whose terms proceed by the powers of an indeterminate quantity, sometimes also with indeterminate exponents, or indeterminate coefficients.

entry.ety: L. indeterminatus
entry.def: Not determinate; not certain or fixed; indefinite; not precise; as, an indeterminate number of years.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + determination: cf. indétermination

sn.def: Lack of determination; an unsettled or wavering state, as of the mind.
Lack of fixed or stated direction.

entry.def: Undetermined.

entry.ety: See In- not, Devirginate
entry.def: Not devirginate.

entry.ety: L. indevotus: cf. F. indévot. Cf. Indevout
entry.def: Not devoted.

entry.ety: L. indevotio: cf. F. indévotion
entry.def: Lack of devotion; impiety; irreligion.
entry.q: An age ofindevotion.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + devout. Cf. Indevote
entry.def: Not devout.
To indue.

entries.entry:
In"dex
Index error the error in the reading of a mathematical instrument arising from the zero of the index not being in complete adjustment with that of the limb, or with its theoretically perfect position in the instrument; a correction to be applied to the instrument readings equal to the error of the zero adjustment. Index expurgatorius. L See Index prohibitoriusbelow). Index finger. See Index, 5. Index glass the mirror on the index of a quadrant, sextant, etc. Index hand the pointer or hand of a clock, watch, or other registering machine; a hand that points to something. Index of a logarithm Math the integral part of the logarithm, and always one less than the number of integral figures in the given number. It is also called the characteristic.
Index of refractionorRefractive index
Opt the number which expresses the ratio of the sine of the angle of incidence to the sine of the angle of refraction. Thus the index of refraction for sulphur is 2, because, when light passes out of air into sulphur, the sine of the angle of incidence is double the sine of the angle of refraction. Index plate a graduated circular plate, or one with circular rows of holes differently spaced; used in machines for graduating circles, cutting gear teeth, etc.
Index prohibitorius L, or Prohibitory index
R. C. Ch a catalogue of books which are forbidden by the church to be read; the index expurgatorius L, or expurgatory index, is a catalogue of books from which passages marked as against faith or morals must be removed before Catholics can read them. These catalogues are published with additions, from time to time, by the Congregation of the Index, composed of cardinals, theologians, etc., under the sanction of the pope. Hook. Index rerum L a tabulated and alphabetized notebook, for systematic preservation of items, quotations, etc.
n.; pl. E. Indexes #, L. Indices #�). L.: cf. F. index. See Indicate Diction
That which points out; that which shows, indicates, manifests, or discloses; as, the increasing unemployment rate is an index of how much the economy has slowed. Tastes are the indexes of the different qualities of plants.
That which guides, points out, informs, or directs; a pointer or a hand that directs to anything, as the hand of a watch, a movable finger or other form of pointer on a gauge, scale, or other graduated instrument. In printing a sign [☞] (called also fist) used to direct particular attention to a note or paragraph.
A table for facilitating reference to topics, names, and the like, in a book, usually giving the page on which a particular word or topic may be found; -- usually alphabetical in arrangement, and printed at the end of the volume. Typically found only in non-fiction books.
A prologue indicating what follows. Obs
Anat The second finger, that next to the pollex (thumb), in the manus, or hand; the forefinger; index finger.
Math The figure or letter which shows the power or root of a quantity; the exponent. In this sense the plural is always indices
The ratio, or formula expressing the ratio, of one dimension of a thing to another dimension; as, the vertical index of the cranium.
A number providing a measure of some quantity derived by a formula, usually a form of averaging, from multiple quantities; -- used mostly in economics; as, the index of leading indicators; the index of industrial production; the consumer price index . See, for example, the consumer price index.
computers A file containing a table with the addresses of data items, arranged for rapid and convenient search for the addresses.
computers A number which serves as a label for a data item and also represents the address of a data item within a table or array.
R. C. Ch The Index prohibitorius, a catalogue of books which are forbidden by the church to be read; also called Index of forbidden books and Index Librorum Prohibitorum.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Indexed; p. pr. & vb. n. Indexing

sn.def: To provide with an index or table of references; to put into an index; as, to index a book, or its contents.

To adjust (wages, prices, taxes, etc.) automatically so as to compensate for changes in prices, usually as measured by the consumer price index or other economic measure. Its purpose is usually to copensate for inflation.
To insert (a word, name, file folder, etc.) into an index or into an indexed arrangement; as, to index a contract under its date of signing.

entry.def: a system of economic regulation in which wages and interest are tied to the cost-of-living index in order to compenaste for the effects of inflation.
One who makes an index.
Of, pertaining to, or like, an index; having the form of an index.
In the manner of an index.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + dexterity: cf. F. indextérité
entry.def: Lack of dexterity or readiness, especially in the use of the hands; clumsiness; awkwardness.
