entry.cs: India ink a nearly black pigment brought chiefly from China, used for water colors. It is in rolls, or in square, and consists of lampblack or ivory black and animal glue. Called also China ink. The true India ink is sepia. See Sepia. India matting floor matting made in China, India, etc., from grass and reeds; -- also called Canton mattingorChina matting. India paper a variety of Chinese paper, of smooth but not glossy surface, used for printing from engravings, woodcuts, etc. India proof Engraving a proof impression from an engraved plate, taken on India paper. India rubber. See Caoutchouc. India-rubber tree Bot any tree yielding caoutchouc, but especially the East Indian Ficus elastica, often cultivated for its large, shining, elliptical leaves.
entry.ety: See Indian
entry.def: A country in Southern Asia; the two peninsulas of Hither and Farther India; in a restricted sense, Hither India, or Hindostan.
To place or set in a diadem, as a gem or gems.

entries.entry: In"di*a*man n.; pl.Indiamen. A large vessel in the India trade.

entry.cs: Indian bay Bot a lauraceous tree (Persea Indica). Indian bean Bot a name of the catalpa. Indian berry. Bot Same as Cocculus indicus. Indian bread. Bot Same as Cassava. Indian club a wooden club, which is swung by the hand for gymnastic exercise. Indian cordage cordage made of the fibers of cocoanut husk. Indian cress Bot nasturtium. See Nasturtium, 2. Indian cucumber Bot a plant of the genus Medeola Medeola Virginica), a common in woods in the United States. The white rootstock has a taste like cucumbers. Indian currant Bot a plant of the genus Symphoricarpus Symphoricarpus vulgaris), bearing small red berries. Indian dye the puccoon. Indian fig. Bot The banyan. See Banyan. The prickly pear. Indian file single file; arrangement of persons in a row following one after another, the usual way among Indians of traversing woods, especially when on the war path. Indian fire a pyrotechnic composition of sulphur, niter, and realgar, burning with a brilliant white light. Indian grass Bot a coarse, high grass (Chrysopogon nutans), common in the southern portions of the United States; wood grass. Gray. Indian hemp. Bot A plant of the genus Apocynum Apocynum cannabinum), having a milky juice, and a tough, fibrous bark, whence the name. The root it used in medicine and is both emetic and cathartic in properties. The variety of common hemp (Cannabis Indica), from which hasheesh is obtained. Indian mallow Bot the velvet leaf (Abutilon Avicennæ). See Abutilon. Indian meal ground corn or maize. U.S Indian millet Bot a tall annual grass (Sorghum vulgare), having many varieties, among which are broom corn, Guinea corn, durra, and the Chinese sugar cane. It is called also Guinea corn. See Durra. Indian ox Zoöl the zebu. Indian paint. See Bloodroot. Indian paper. See India paper, under India. Indian physic Bot a plant of two species of the genus Gillenia Gillenia trifoliata, and Gillenia stipulacea), common in the United States, the roots of which are used in medicine as a mild emetic; -- called also American ipecac, and bowman's root. Gray. Indian pink. Bot The Cypress vine (Ipomœa Quamoclit); -- so called in the West Indies. See China pink, under China. Indian pipe Bot a low, fleshy herb (Monotropa uniflora), growing in clusters in dark woods, and having scalelike leaves, and a solitary nodding flower. The whole plant is waxy white, but turns black in drying. Indian plantain Bot a name given to several species of the genus Cacalia, tall herbs with composite white flowers, common through the United States in rich woods. Gray. Indian poke Bot a plant usually known as the white hellebore Veratrum viride). Indian pudding a pudding of which the chief ingredients are Indian meal, milk, and molasses. Indian purple. A dull purple color. The pigment of the same name, intensely blue and black. Indian red. A purplish red earth or pigment composed of a silicate of iron and alumina, with magnesia. It comes from the Persian Gulf. Called also Persian red. See Almagra. Indian rice Bot a reedlike water grass. See Rice. Indian shot Bot a plant of the genus Canna Canna Indica). The hard black seeds are as large as swan shot. See Canna. Indian summer in the United States, a period of warm and pleasant weather occurring late in autumn. See under Summer. Indian tobacco Bot a species of Lobelia. See Lobelia. Indian turnip Bot an American plant of the genus Arisæma. Arisæma triphyllum has a wrinkled farinaceous root resembling a small turnip, but with a very acrid juice. See Jack in the Pulpit, and Wake-robin. Indian wheat maize or Indian corn. Indian yellow. An intense rich yellow color, deeper than gamboge but less pure than cadmium. See Euxanthin.
entry.ety: From India, and this fr. Indus, the name of a river in Asia, L. Indus, Gr. �, OPers. Hindu, name of the land on the Indus, Skr. sindhu river, the Indus. Cf. Hindu

sn.def: Of or pertaining to India proper; also to the East Indies, or, sometimes, to the West Indies.
Of or pertaining to the aborigines, or Indians, of America; as, Indian wars; the Indian tomahawk.
Made of maize or Indian corn; as, Indian corn, Indian meal, Indian bread, and the like.
A native or inhabitant of India.
One of the aboriginal inhabitants of America; -- so called originally from the supposed identity of America with India.

entry.def: a resident of Indiana.

entry.note: ☞ In modern American usage, the word corn when unmodified usually refers to yellow corn, and Indian corn refers to the variegated variety.
entry.def: A cereal plant of the genus Zea Zea Mays), also simply called corn, used widely as a food; the maize, a native plant of America;

a primitive variety of Zea Mays having variegated kernels on each cob, in distinction from the more commonly used yellow corn; it is often used as decoration at Thanksgiving time. See Corn, and Maize.
An Indiaman.

entries.entry: In"di*a rub"ber. See Caoutchouc.
In"di*a steel. Same as Wootz.

entry.ety: From L. index indicis, an index
entry.def: Indexical.

entry.ety: See Indigo

sn.def: A glucoside (C14H17NO6) obtained from woad (indigo plant, Isatis Tinctoria) and other plants (see indigo), as a yellow or light brown sirup. When purified it is obtained as spear-shaped crystals. It has a nauseous bitter taste. By the action of acids, enzymes, etc., it breaks down into sugar and indigo. It is the source of natural indigo. Chemically it is the 3-glucoside of indole, H-indol-3-yl-β-D-glucopyranoside.

An indigo-forming substance, found in urine, and other animal fluids, and convertible into red and blue indigo (urrhodin and uroglaucin). Chemically, it is indoxyl sulphate of potash, C8H6NSO4K, and is derived from the indol formed in the alimentary canal. Called also uroxanthin.

entry.ety: L. indicans, p. pr. indicare. See Indicate
entry.def: Serving to point out, as a remedy; indicating.
That which indicates or points out; as, an indicant of the remedy for a disease.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Indicated; p. pr. & vb. n. Indicating
entry.ety: L. indicatus, p. p. of indicare to indicate; pref. in- in + dicare to proclaim; akin to dicere to say. See Diction, and cf. Indict Indite

sn.def: To point out; to discover; to direct to a knowledge of; to show; to make known.
sn.q: That turns and turns to indicate From what point blows the weather.

sn.def: To show or manifest by symptoms; to point to as the proper remedies; as, great prostration of strength indicates the use of stimulants. Opposite of contraindicate.
To investigate the condition or power of, as of steam engine, by means of an indicator.
sn.syn: To show; mark; signify; denote; discover; evidence; evince; manifest; declare; specify; explain; exhibit; present; reveal; disclose; display.

entry.cs: Indicated power. See Indicated horse power, under Horse power.
entry.def: Shown; denoted; registered; measured.

entry.ety: L. indicatio: cf. F. indication

sn.def: Act of pointing out or indicating.
That which serves to indicate or point out; mark; token; sign; symptom; evidence.
sn.q: The frequent stops they make in the most convenient places are plain indications of their weariness.

sn.def: Discovery made; information.
Explanation; display.
Any symptom or occurrence in a disease, which serves to direct to suitable remedies. Opposite of contraindication.
sn.syn: Proof; demonstration; sign; token; mark; evidence; signal.

cs.cd: that mood or form of the verb which indicates, that is, which simply affirms or denies or inquires; as, he writes; he is not writing; has the mail arrived?

entry.ety: L. indicativus: cf. F. indicatif

sn.def: Pointing out; bringing to notice; giving intimation or knowledge of something not visible or obvious.
sn.q: That truth is productive of utility, and utility indicative of truth, may be thus proved.

sn.def: Suggestive; representing the whole by a part, as a fleet by a ship, a forest by a tree, etc.

entry.def: The indicative mood.
In an indicative manner; in a way to show or signify.

entry.note: ☞ The common indicators are litmus, tropæolin, phenol phthalein, potassic permanganate, etc.

cs.cd: the figure drawn by an engine indicator, by means of which the working of the engine can be investigated and its power calculated. The Illustration shows one form of indicator card, from a steam engine, together with scales by which the pressure of the steam above or below that of the atmosphere, corresponding to any position of the engine piston in its stroke, can be measured. Called also indicator diagram.
a telegraph in which the signals are the deflections of a magnetic needle, as in the trans-Atlantic system.

entry.ety: L.: cf. F. indicateur

sn.def: One who, or that which, shows or points out; as, a fare indicator in a street car.

entry.sn:
Mach A pressure gauge; a water gauge, as for a steam boiler; an apparatus or instrument for showing the working of a machine or moving part; as: Steam Engine An instrument which draws a diagram showing the varying pressure in the cylinder of an engine or pump at every point of the stroke. It consists of a small cylinder communicating with the engine cylinder and fitted with a piston which the varying pressure drives upward more or less against the resistance of a spring. A lever imparts motion to a pencil which traces the diagram on a card wrapped around a vertical drum which is turned back and forth by a string connected with the piston rod of the engine. See Indicator cardbelow).
A telltale connected with a hoisting machine, to show, at the surface, the position of the cage in the shaft of a mine, etc.

sn.def: The part of an instrument by which an effect is indicated, as an index or pointer.
Any bird of the genus Indicator and allied genera. See Honey guide, under Honey.

That which indicates the condition of acidity, alkalinity, or the deficiency, excess, or sufficiency of a standard reagent, by causing an appearance, disappearance, or change of color, as in titration or volumetric analysis.

entry.def: Serving to show or make known; showing; indicative; signifying; implying.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A certain conic section supposed to be drawn in the tangent plane to any surface, and used to determine the accidents of curvature of the surface at the point of contact. The curve is similar to the intersection of the surface with a parallel to the tangent plane and indefinitely near it. It is an ellipse when the curvature is synclastic, and an hyperbola when the curvature is anticlastic.

entry.ety: L., he has indicated
entry.def: A writ of prohibition against proceeding in the spiritual court in certain cases, when the suit belongs to the common-law courts.

entry.ety: F. indice indication, index. See Index
entry.def: Index; indication.
See Index.

entry.ety: L., pl. of indicium, fr. index an index
entry.def: Discriminating marks; signs; tokens; indications; appearances.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Unspeakable.

entry.ety: L. indicum indigo + -lite: cf. F. indicolithe
entry.def: A variety of tourmaline of an indigo-blue color.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Indicted ĭn*dīt"ĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Indicting
entry.ety: OE. enditen. See Indite

sn.def: To write; to compose; to dictate; to indite.
To appoint publicly or by authority; to proclaim or announce.
sn.q: I am told shall have no Lent indicted this year.

sn.def: To charge with a crime, in due form of law, by the finding or presentment of a grand jury; to bring an indictment against; as, to indict a man for arson. It is the peculiar province of a grand jury to indict, as it is of a house of representatives to impeach.

entry.def: Capable of being, or liable to be, indicted; subject to indictment; as, an indictable offender or offense.
A person indicted.
One who indicts.

entry.note: ☞ This mode of reckoning time is said to have been introduced by Constantine the Great, in connection with the payment of tribute. It was adopted at various times by the Greek emperors of Constantinople, the popes, and the parliaments of France. Through the influence of the popes, it was extensively used in the ecclesiastical chronology of the Middle Ages. The number of indictions was reckoned at first from 312 a. d., but since the twelfth century it has been reckoned from the birth of Christ. The papal indiction is the only one ever used at the present day. To find the indiction and year of the indiction by the first method, subtract 312 from the given year a. d., and divide by 15; by the second method, add 3 to the given year a. d., and the divide by 15. In either case, the quotient is the number of the current indiction, and the remainder the year of the indiction. See Cycle of indiction, under Cycle.
entry.ety: L. indictio: cf. F. indiction. See Indict Indite

sn.def: Declaration; proclamation; public notice or appointment.
sn.q: Indictionof a war.
Secular princes did use to indict, or permit the indiction of, synods of bishops.

sn.def: A cycle of fifteen years.

entry.ety: L. indictivus. See Indict
entry.def: Proclaimed; declared; public.

entry.note: ☞ To the validity of an indictment a finding by the grand jury is essential, while an information rests only on presentation by the prosecuting authority.
entry.cs: Bill of indictment. See under Bill.
entry.ety: Cf. Inditement

sn.def: The act of indicting, or the state of being indicted.
The formal statement of an offense, as framed by the prosecuting authority of the State, and found by the grand jury.
An accusation in general; a formal accusation.

entry.def: One who indicts.
A name designating the East Indies, also the West Indies.
entry.q: Our king has all the Indies in his arms.

entry.ety: L. indifferentia similarity, lack of difference: cf. F. indifférence

sn.def: The quality or state of being indifferent, or not making a difference; lack of sufficient importance to constitute a difference; absence of weight; insignificance.
Passableness; mediocrity.
Impartiality; freedom from prejudice, prepossession, or bias.
sn.q: He . . . is far from such indifference and equity as ought and must be in judges which he saith I assign.

sn.def: Absence of anxiety or interest in respect to what is presented to the mind; unconcernedness; as, entire indifference to all that occurs.
sn.q: Indifference can not but be criminal, when it is conversant about objects which are so far from being of an indifferent nature, that they are highest importance.
sn.syn: Carelessness; negligence; unconcern; apathy; insensibility; coldness; lukewarmness.

entry.def: Absence of interest in, or influence from, anything; unconcernedness; equilibrium; indifferentism; indifference.
entry.q: To give ourselves to a detestable indifferency or neutrality in this cause.
Moral liberty . . . does not, after all, consist in a power of indifferency, or in a power of choosing without regard to motives.

cs.cd: the primitive, embryonic, undifferentiated tissue, before conversion into connective, muscular, nervous, or other definite tissue.

entry.ety: F. indifférent, L. indifferens. See In- not, and Different

sn.def: Not making a difference; having no influence or preponderating weight; involving no preference, concern, or attention; of no account; without significance or importance.
sn.q: Dangers are to me indifferent.
Everything in the world is indifferent but sin.
His slightest and most indifferent acts . . . were odious in the clergyman's sight.

sn.def: Neither particularly good, not very bad; of a middle state or quality; passable; mediocre.
sn.q: The staterooms are in indifferent order.

sn.def: Not inclined to one side, party, or choice more than to another; neutral; impartial.
sn.q: Indifferent in his choice to sleep or die.

sn.def: Feeling no interest, anxiety, or care, respecting anything; unconcerned; inattentive; apathetic; heedless; as, to be indifferent to the welfare of one's family.
sn.q: It was a law of Solon, that any person who, in the civil commotions of the republic, remained neuter, or an indifferent spectator of the contending parties, should be condemned to perpetual banishment.

sn.def: Free from bias or prejudice; impartial; unbiased; disinterested.
sn.q: In choice of committees for ripening business for the counsel, it is better to choose indifferent persons than to make an indifferency by putting in those that are strong on both sides.

entry.def: To a moderate degree; passably; tolerably.
entry.q: Newsindifferentgood.

entry.ety: Cf. F. indifférentisme

sn.def: State of indifference; lack of interest or earnestness; especially, a systematic apathy regarding what is true or false in religion or philosophy; agnosticism.
sn.q: The indifferentism which equalizes all religions and gives equal rights to truth and error.

sn.def: Same as Identism.
A heresy consisting in an unconcern for any particular creed, provided the morals be right and good.

entry.def: One governed by indifferentism.
In an indifferent manner; without distinction or preference; impartially; without concern, wish, affection, or aversion; tolerably; passably.
entry.q: That they may truly and indifferently minister justice, to the punishment of wickedness and vice, and to the maintenance of thy true religion, and virtue.
Set honor in one eye and death i' the other, And I will look on both indifferently.
I hope it may indifferently entertain your lordship at an unbending hour.

entry.ety: Indican + L. fulvus reddish yellow
entry.def: A reddish resinous substance, obtained from indican.

entry.ety: Indican + L. fuscus dusky
entry.def: A brown amorphous powder, obtained from indican.
Same as Indigene.

entry.ety: L. indigentia: cf. F. indigence. See Indigent
entry.def: The condition of being indigent; lack of estate, or means of comfortable subsistence; penury; poverty; as, helpless indigence .
entry.syn: Poverty; penury; destitution; want; need; privation; lack. See Poverty.

entry.def: Indigence.
entry.q: New indigencies founded upon new desires.

entry.ety: L. indigena: cf. F. indigène. See Indigenous
entry.def: One born in a country; an aboriginal animal or plant; an autochthon.

entry.ety: L. indigenus indigena, fr. OL. indufr. in in) + the root of L. gignere to beget, bear. See In, and Gender

sn.def: Native; produced, growing, or living, naturally in a country or climate; not exotic; not imported.
sn.q: Negroes were all transported from Africa and are not indigenous or proper natives of America.
In America, cotton, being indigenous, is cheap.

sn.def: Native; inherent; innate.
sn.q: Joy and hope are emotions indigenous to the human mind.

entry.ety: L. indigent, L. indigens, p. p. of indigere to stand in need of, fr. OL. indufr. in- in) + L. egere to be needy, to need

sn.def: Wanting; void; free; destitute; -- used with of.
Destitute of property or means of comfortable subsistence; needy; poor; in want; necessitous.
sn.q: Indigent faint souls past corporal toil.
Charity consists in relieving the indigent.

entry.def: In an indigent manner.

entry.ety: L. indigestus unarranged. See Indigested
entry.def: Crude; unformed; unorganized; undigested.
entry.q: A chaos rude andindigest.
Monsters and thingsindigest.

entry.def: Something indigested.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + digested

sn.def: Not digested; undigested.
sn.q: Indigestedfood.

sn.def: Not resolved; not regularly disposed and arranged; not methodical; crude; as, an indigested array of facts.
sn.q: In hot reformations . . . the whole is generally crude, harsh, and indigested.
This, like an indigested meteor, appeared and disappeared almost at the same time.

sd.def: Not in a state suitable for healing; -- said of wounds.
Not ripened or suppurated; -- said of an abscess or its contents.

sn.def: Not softened by heat, hot water, or steam.

entry.def: The state or quality of being undigested; crudeness.
The state or quality of being indigestible; indigestibleness.

entry.ety: L. indigestibilis: cf. F. indigestible. See In- not, and Digest

sn.def: Not digestible; not readily soluble in the digestive juices; not easily convertible into products fitted for absorption.
Not digestible in the mind; distressful; intolerable; as, an indigestible simile.

entry.def: the property of being difficult to digest.

entry.ety: L. indigestio: cf. F. indigestion. See In- not, and Digest
entry.def: Discomfort due to a lack of proper digestive action; a failure of the normal changes which food should undergo in the alimentary canal; dyspepsia; incomplete or difficult digestion.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + L. digitus finger
entry.def: To communicate ideas by the fingers; to show or compute by the fingers.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Indigitated; p. pr. & vb. n. Indigitating
entry.def: To point out with the finger; to indicate.
entry.q: The depressing this finger, . . . in the right hand indigitates six hundred.

entry.def: The act of pointing out as with the finger; indication.

entry.ety: Indican + glucin
entry.def: The variety of sugar (glucose) obtained from the glucoside indican. It is unfermentable, but reduces Fehling's solution.

entry.ety: L. indignus; pref. in- not + dignus worthy: cf. F. indigne. See Dignity
entry.def: Unworthy; undeserving; disgraceful; degrading.
entry.q: Counts it scorn to draw Comfort indign from any meaner thing.

entry.def: Indignation.

entry.ety: L. indignans -antis, p. pr. of indignari to be indignant, disdain. See Indign
entry.def: Affected with indignation; wrathful; passionate; irate; feeling wrath, as when a person is exasperated by unworthy or unjust treatment, by a mean action, or by a degrading accusation.
entry.q: He strides indignant, and with haughty cries To single fight the fairy prince defies.

entry.def: In an indignant manner.

entry.ety: F. indignation, L. indignatio. See Indign

sn.def: The feeling excited by that which is unworthy, base, or disgraceful; anger mingled with contempt, disgust, or abhorrence.
sn.q: Indignation expresses a strong and elevated disapprobation of mind, which is also inspired by something flagitious in the conduct of another.
When Haman saw Mordecai in the king's gate, that he stood not up, nor moved for him, he was full of indignation against Mordecai.

sn.def: The effect of anger; punishment.
sn.q: Hide thyself . . . until the indignation be overpast.
sn.syn: Anger; ire wrath; fury; rage. See Anger.

entry.ety: L. indignus unworthy + -fy
entry.def: To treat disdainfully or with indignity; to contemn.

entries.entry:
In*dig"ni*ty n.; pl.Indignities #. L. indignitas: cf. F. indignité. See Indign
Any action toward another which manifests contempt for him; an offense against personal dignity; unmerited contemptuous treatment; contumely; incivility or injury, accompanied with insult. How might a prince of my great hopes forget So great indignities you laid upon me? A person of so great place and worth constrained to endure so foul indignities.

entry.def: Unworthily.

entries.entry:
In"di*go ☞ Commercial indigo contains the essential coloring principle indigo blue or indigotine, with several other dyes; as, indigo red indigo brown, etc., and various impurities. Indigo is insoluble in ordinary reagents, with the exception of strong sulphuric acid.
Chinese indigo Bot
Isatis indigotica, a kind of woad. Wild indigo Bot the American herb Baptisia tinctoria which yields a poor quality of indigo, as do several other species of the same genus.
n.; pl.Indigoes #. F. indigo, Sp. indigo indico, L. indicum indigo, fr. Indicus Indian. See Indian
A kind of deep blue, one of the seven prismatic colors.
Chem A blue dyestuff obtained from several plants belonging to very different genera and orders, such as, the woad, Isatis tinctoriafamily Cruciferae), Indigofera suffroticosa Indigofera tinctoriafamily Leguminosae), Indigofera Anil Nereum tinctorium Polygonum tinctorium Ait. (family Polygonaceae), etc.; called also natural indigo. It is a dark blue earthy substance, tasteless and odorless, with a copper-violet luster when rubbed. Indigo does not exist in the plants as such, but is obtained by decomposition of the glycoside indican.

entry.cs: Indigo berry Bot the fruit of the West Indian shrub Randia aculeata, used as a blue dye. Indigo bird Zoöl a small North American finch (Cyanospiza cyanea). The male is indigo blue in color. Called also indigo bunting. Indigo blue. The essential coloring material of commercial indigo, from which it is obtained as a dark blue earthy powder, with a reddish luster, C16H10N2O2, which may be crystallized by sublimation. Indigo blue is also made from artificial amido cinnamic acid, and from artificial isatine; and these methods are of great commercial importance. Called also indigotin. A dark, dull blue color like the indigo of commerce. Indigo brown Chem a brown resinous substance found in crude indigo. Indigo copper Min covellite. Indigo green a green obtained from indigo. Indigo plant Bot a leguminous plant of several species (genus Indigofera), from which indigo is prepared. The different varieties are natives of Asia, Africa, and America. Several species are cultivated, of which the most important are the Indigofera tinctoria, or common indigo plant, the Indigofera Anil, a larger species, and the Indigofera disperma. Indigo purple a purple obtained from indigo. Indigo red a dyestuff, isomeric with indigo blue, obtained from crude indigo as a dark brown amorphous powder. Indigo snake Zoöl the gopher snake. Indigo white a white crystalline powder obtained by reduction from indigo blue, and by oxidation easily changed back to it; -- called also indigogen. Indigo yellow a substance obtained from indigo.
entry.def: Having the color of, pertaining to, or derived from, indigo.

entry.ety: NL., from E. indigo + L. ferre to bear
entry.def: A genus of leguminous plants (family Leguminosae) having many species, mostly in tropical countries, several of them yielding indigo, esp. Indigofera tinctoria Indigofera suffroticosa, and Indigofera Anil.

entry.ety: Indigo + -gen

sn.def: See Indigo white, under Indigo.
Same as Indican, 2.

entry.ety: Indigo + -meter
entry.def: An instrument for ascertaining the strength of an indigo solution, as in volumetric analysis.
The art or method of determining the coloring power of indigo.

entry.ety: Cf. F. indigotique
entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, indigo; as, indigotic acid, which is also called anilic or nitrosalicylic acid .
See Indigo blue, under Indigo.

entry.ety: Indigo + L. ruber red
entry.def: Same as Urrhodin.

entry.ety: Indican + humin
entry.def: A brown amorphous substance resembling humin, and obtained from indican.
Not dilatory.

entry.ety: L. indiligentia: cf. F. indiligence
entry.def: Lack of diligence.

entry.ety: L. indiligens: cf. F. indiligent. See Diligent
entry.def: Not diligent; idle; slothful.
Incapable of being diminished.

entry.ety: From Indigo
entry.def: A dark red crystalline substance, isomeric with and resembling indigo blue, and obtained from isatide and dioxindol.

entry.cs:
Indirect claims claims for remote or consequential damage. Such claims were presented to and thrown out by the commissioners who arbitrated the damage inflicted on the United States by the Confederate States cruisers built and supplied by Great Britain. Indirect demonstration a mode of demonstration in which proof is given by showing that any other supposition involves an absurdity (reductio ad absurdum), or an impossibility; thus, one quantity may be proved equal to another by showing that it can be neither greater nor less. Indirect discourse. Gram See Direct discourse, under Direct. Indirect evidence evidence or testimony which is circumstantial or inferential, but without witness; -- opposed to direct evidence. Indirect tax a tax, such as customs, excises,
etc., exacted directly from the merchant, but paid indirectly by the consumer in the higher price demanded for the articles of merchandise.
entry.ety: Pref. in- not + direct: cf. F. indirect

sn.def: Not direct; not straight or rectilinear; deviating from a direct line or course; circuitous; as, an indirect road.
Not tending to an aim, purpose, or result by the plainest course, or by obvious means, but obliquely or consequentially; by remote means; as, an indirect accusation, attack, answer, or proposal.
sn.q: By what bypaths and indirect, crooked ways I met this crown.

sn.def: Not straightforward or upright; unfair; dishonest; tending to mislead or deceive.
sn.q: Indirect dealing will be discovered one time or other.

sn.def: Not resulting directly from an act or cause, but more or less remotely connected with or growing out of it; as, indirect results, damages, or claims.
Not reaching the end aimed at by the most plain and direct method; as, an indirect proof, demonstration, etc.

entry.def: Not directed; aimless.

entry.ety: Cf. F. indirection
entry.def: Oblique course or means; dishonest practices; indirectness.
entry.q: Byindirectionsfind directions out.

entry.def: In an direct manner; not in a straight line or course; not in express terms; obliquely; not by direct means; hence, unfairly; wrongly.
entry.q: To tax it indirectly by taxing their expense.
Your crown and kingdom indirectly held.

sn.def: The quality or state of being indirect; obliquity; deviousness; crookedness.
Deviation from an upright or straightforward course; unfairness; dishonesty.

entry.ety: Indian + Gr. � resin
entry.def: A dark brown resinous substance obtained from indican.

entry.ety: Indigo + L. ruber red
entry.def: A substance isomeric with, and resembling, indigo blue, and accompanying it as a side product, in its artificial production.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + discernible: cf. F. indiscernable
entry.def: Not to be discerned; imperceptible; not discoverable or visible.
entry.q: Secret and indiscernible ways.

entry.def: The state or quality of being indiscerpible.
Not discerpible; inseparable.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + disciplinable: cf. F. indisciplinable
entry.def: Not disciplinable; undisciplinable.

entry.ety: L. indisplina: cf. F. indiscipline. See In- not, and Discipline
entry.def: Lack of discipline or instruction.
Not discoverable; undiscoverable.
Lack of discovery.

entry.ety: OE. indiscret, F. indiscret, fr. L. indiscretus unseparated, indiscreet. See In- not, and Discreet, and cf. Indiscrete
entry.def: Not discreet; wanting in discretion.
entry.q: So drunken, and so indiscreet an officer.
entry.syn: Imprudent; injudicious; inconsiderate; rash; hasty; incautious; heedless; undiscerning; foolish.

entry.ety: L. indiscretus unseparated. See Indiscreet

sn.def: Indiscreet.
Not discrete or separated; compact; homogenous.
sn.q: An indiscrete mass of confused matter.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + discretion: cf. F. indiscrétion

sn.def: The quality or state of being indiscreet; lack of discretion; imprudence.
An indiscreet act; indiscreet behavior.
sn.q: Past indiscretion is a venial crime.

entry.def: Not discriminate; wanting discrimination; undistinguishing; not making any distinction; confused; promiscuous.
entry.q: Blind orindiscriminateforgiveness.
The indiscriminate defense of right and wrong.

entry.def: Not discriminating.
Lack of discrimination or distinction; impartiality.
Making no distinction; not discriminating.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + discuss: cf. L. indiscussus
entry.def: Not discussed.

entry.ety: Cf. F. indispensabilité
entry.def: Indispensableness.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + dispensable: cf. F. indispensable

sn.def: Not dispensable; impossible to be omitted, remitted, or spared; absolutely necessary or requisite.
Not admitting dispensation; not subject to release or exemption.
sn.q: The law was moral and indispensable.

sn.def: Unavoidable; inevitable.

entry.def: The state or quality of being indispensable, or absolutely necessary.
In an indispensable manner.
entry.q: Indispensablynecessary.

entry.def: Not dispersed.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Indisposed; p. pr. & vb. n. Indisposing
entry.ety: OE. indispos indisposed, feeble, or F. indisposé indisposed. See In- not, and Dispose

sn.def: To render unfit or unsuited; to disqualify.
To disorder slightly as regards health; to make somewhat.
sn.q: It made him rather indisposed than sick.

sn.def: To disincline; to render averse or unfavorable; as, a love of pleasure indisposes the mind to severe study; the pride and selfishness of men indispose them to religious duties.
sn.q: The king was sufficiently indisposed towards the persons, or the principles, of Calvin's disciples.

entry.def: The condition or quality of being indisposed.

entry.ety: Cf. F. indisposition

sn.def: The state of being indisposed; disinclination; as, the indisposition of two substances to combine.
sn.q: A general indisposition towards believing.

sn.def: A slight disorder or illness.
sn.q: Rather as an indisposition in health than as any set sickness.

entry.ety: Cf. F. indisputabilité
entry.def: Indisputableness.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + disputable: cf. F. indisputable
entry.def: Not disputable; incontrovertible; too evident to admit of dispute.
entry.syn: Incontestable; unquestionable; incontrovertible; undeniable; irrefragable; certain; positive; undoubted; sure; infallible.

entry.def: Undisputed.
Incapable o� being dissipated.

entry.ety: Cf. F. indissolubilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being indissoluble.

entry.ety: L. indissolubilis: cf. F. indissoluble. See In- not, and Dissoluble, and cf. Indissolvable

sn.def: Not dissoluble; not capable of being dissolved, melted, or liquefied; insoluble; as, few substances are indissoluble by heat, but many are indissoluble in water.
Incapable of being rightfully broken or dissolved; perpetually binding or obligatory; firm; stable, as, an indissoluble league or covenant.
sn.q: To the which my duties Are with a most indissoluble tie Forever knit.

entry.def: Indissolubility.
In an indissoluble manner.
entry.q: On they move, indissolubly firm.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + dissolvable. Cf. Indissoluble
entry.def: Not dissolvable; incapable of being dissolved or separated; incapable of separation; perpetually firm and binding; indissoluble; as, an indissolvable bond of union.
Indissolubleness.
Lack of distance or separation; nearness.

entry.ety: L. indistinctus: cf. F. indistinct. See In- not, and Distinct

sn.def: Not distinct or distinguishable; not separate in such a manner as to be perceptible by itself; as, the indistinct parts of a substance.
sn.q: Indistinctas water is in water.

sn.def: Obscure to the mind or senses; not clear; not definite; confused; imperfect; faint; as, indistinct vision; an indistinct sound; an indistinct idea or recollection.
sn.q: When we come to parts too small four our senses, our ideas of these little bodies become obscure and indistinct.
Their views, indeed, are indistinct and dim.
sn.syn: Undefined; indistinguishable; obscure; indefinite; vague; ambiguous; uncertain; confused.

entry.def: Indistinguishable.

entry.ety: Cf. F. indistinction
entry.def: Lack of distinction or distinguishableness; confusion; uncertainty; indiscrimination.
entry.q: The indistinction of many of the same name . . . hath made some doubt.
An indistinction of all persons, or equality of all orders, is far from being agreeable to the will of God.

entry.def: Having nothing distinctive; common.
In an indistinct manner; not clearly; confusedly; dimly; as, certain ideas are indistinctly comprehended.
entry.q: In its sides it was bounded distinctly, but on its ends confusedly and indistinctly.

entry.def: The quality or condition of being indistinct; lack of definiteness; dimness; confusion; as, the indistinctness of a picture, or of comprehension; indistinctness of vision.
smilarity too close to be distinguished; exact sameness.

Not distinguishable; not capable of being perceived, known, or discriminated as separate and distinct; hence, not capable of being perceived or known; as, in the distance the flagship was indisguishable; the two copies were indisguishable in form or color; the difference between them was indisguishable.
In a indistinguishable manner.
Indistinct.
entry.q: Thatindistinguishedmass.

entry.def: Making no difference; indiscriminative; impartial; as, indistinguishing liberalities.
Freedom from disturbance; calmness; repose; apathy; indifference.
To bury in, or cast into, a ditch.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Indited; p. pr. & vb. n. Inditing
entry.ety: OE. enditen to indite, indict, OF. enditer to indicate, show, dictate, write, inform, and endicter to accuse; both fr. LL. indictare to show, to accuse, fr. L. indicere to proclaim, announce; pref. in- in + dicere to say. The word was influenced also by L. indicare to indicate, and by dictare to dictate. See Diction, and cf. Indict Indicate Dictate

sn.def: To compose; to write; to be author of; to dictate; to prompt.
sn.q: My heart is inditing a good matter.
Could a common grief have indited such expressions?
Hear how learned Greece her useful rules indites.

sn.def: To invite or ask.
sn.q: She will indite him to some supper.

sn.def: To indict; to accuse; to censure.

entry.def: To compose; to write, as a poem.
entry.q: Wounded I sing, tormented I indite.

entry.ety: Cf. Indictment
entry.def: The act of inditing.
One who indites.

entry.ety: NL. See Indigo
entry.def: A rare metallic element, of atomic number 49, discovered in certain ores of zinc, by means of its characteristic spectrum of two indigo blue lines; hence, its name. In appearance it resembles zinc, being white or lead gray, soft, malleable and easily fusible, but in its chemical relation it resembles aluminium or gallium (valence +3). Symbol In. Atomic weight, 114.82.
Not to be diverted or turned aside.
Indivisible.
Undivided.

entry.ety: L. individuus indivisible; pref. in- not + dividuus divisible, fr. dividere to divide: cf. F. individuel. See Divide

sn.def: Not divided, or not to be divided; existing as one entity, or distinct being or object; single; one; as, an individual man, animal, or city.
sn.q: Mind has a being of its own, distinct from that of all other things, and is pure, unmingled, individual substance.
United as one individual soul.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to one only; peculiar to, or characteristic of, a single person or thing; distinctive; as, individual traits of character; individual exertions; individual peculiarities.
A single person, animal, or thing of any kind; a thing or being incapable of separation or division, without losing its identity; especially, a human being; a person.
sn.q: An object which is in the strict and primary sense one, and can not be logically divided, is called an individual.
That individuals die, his will ordains.

sd.def: An independent, or partially independent, zooid of a compound animal.
The product of a single egg, whether it remains a single animal or becomes compound by budding or fission.

entry.def: Same as individualize.

entry.ety: Cf. F. individualisme

sn.def: The quality of being individual; individuality; personality.
An excessive or exclusive regard to one's personal interest; self-interest; selfishness.
sn.q: The selfishness of the small proprietor has been described by the best writers as individualism.

sn.def: The principle, policy, or practice of maintaining individuality, or independence of the individual, in action; the theory or practice of maintaining the independence of individual initiative, action, and interests, as in industrial organization or in government.

entry.def: a person who pursues independent thought or action.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the individual or individualism.
exhibiting marked individuality{3} in thought and action; as, an individualistic way of dressing.
sn.syn: individualist.

entries.entry:
In`di*vid`u*al"i*ty n.; pl.Individualities #. Cf. F. individualité
The quality or state of being individual or constituting an individual; separate or distinct existence; oneness; unity. They possess separate individualities.
The character or property appropriate or peculiar to an individual; that quality which distinguishes one person or thing from another; the sum of characteristic traits; distinctive character; as, he is a person of marked individuality .
A habit of thinking and acting in one's own distinctive manner and as one believes appropriate, not being heavily influenced by the opinions of others; -- of people.

entry.ety: Cf. F. individualization
entry.def: The act of individualizing; the state of being individualized; individuation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Individualized; p. pr. & vb. n. Individualizing
entry.ety: Cf. F. individualiser
entry.def: To mark as an individual, or to distinguish from others by peculiar properties; to invest with individuality; to give distinctive character to; to make distinctive; to enable differentiation from others of similar type; -- of properties of things.
entry.q: The peculiarities which individualize and distinguish the humor of Addison.

sn.def: to render (a product or service) suitable to each individual person by varying to some degree its characteristics; to personalize.
sn.syn: personalize, individualize, make personal, make more personal.

sn.def: To consider individually; to mention each individual.

entry.def: One who individualizes.

sn.def: In an individual manner or relation; as individuals; separately; each by itself; as, every person must apply individually for admission.
sn.q: Individuallyor collectively.
How should that subsist solitarily by itself which hath no substance, but individually the very same whereby others subsist with it?

sn.def: In an inseparable manner; inseparably; incommunicably; indivisibly; as, individually the same.
sn.q: Omniscience], an attribute individually proper to the Godhead.

entry.ety: See Individual
entry.def: Undivided.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Individuated; p. pr. & vb. n. Individuating
entry.def: To distinguish from others of the species; to endow with individuality; to divide into individuals; to discriminate.
entry.q: The soul, as the prime individuating principle, and the said reserved portion of matter as an essential and radical part of the individuation, shall . . . make up and restore the same individual person.
Life is individuated into infinite numbers, that have their distinct sense and pleasure.

entry.ety: Cf. F. individuation
entry.def: The act of individuating or state of being individuated; individualization.
One who, or that which, individuates.

entry.ety: L. individuitas
entry.def: Separate existence; individuality; oneness.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + divinity: cf. F. indivinité
entry.def: Lack or absence of divine power or of divinity.

entry.ety: Cf. F. indivisibilité
entry.def: The state or property of being indivisible or inseparable; inseparability.

entry.ety: L. indivisibilis: cf. F. indivisible. See In- not, and Divisible

sn.def: Not divisible; incapable of being divided, separated, or broken; not separable into parts.
sn.q: Oneindivisiblepoint of time.

sn.def: Not capable of exact division, as one quantity by another; incommensurable.

cs.cd: a kind of calculus, formerly in use, in which lines were considered as made up of an infinite number of points; surfaces, as made up of an infinite number of lines; and volumes, as made up of an infinite number of surfaces.

sn.def: That which is indivisible.
sn.q: By atom, nobody will imagine we intend to express a perfect indivisible, but only the least sort of natural bodies.

sn.def: An infinitely small quantity which is assumed to admit of no further division.

entry.def: The state of being indivisible; indivisibility.
In an indivisible manner.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + division: cf. F. indivision, LL. indivisio
entry.def: A state of being not divided; oneness.

entries.entry: In"do-. From L. Indus East Indian A prefix signifying Indiani. e., East Indian); of or pertaining of India.

entry.ety: Indigo + aniline
entry.def: Any one of a series of artificial blue dyes, in appearance resembling indigo, for which they are often used as substitutes.
Pertaining to the Indo-Aryans, or designating, or of, the Aryan languages of India.

A member of one of the native races of India of Aryan speech and blood, characterized by tall stature, dolichocephaly, fair complexion with dark hair and eyes, plentiful beard, and narrow and prominent nose.

entry.ety: Indo- + Briton
entry.def: A person born in India, of mixed Indian and British blood; a half-caste.

entry.ety: Indo- + Chinese

sn.def: Of or pertaining to Indo-China (i. e., Farther India, or India beyond the Ganges).
Of or pert. to the Mongoloid races of India, esp. Farther India, or designating, or of, their languages.
sn.q: Tradition and comparative philology agree in pointing to northwestern China, between the upper courses of the Yang-tsekiang and of the Ho-ang-ho, as the original home of the Indo-Chinese race.

entries.entry: In`do-do-Chinese languages. A family of languages, mostly of the isolating type, although some are agglutinative, spoken in the great area extending from northern India in the west to Formosa in the east and from Central Asia in the north to the Malay Peninsula in the south.

entry.def: The state of being indocible; indocibleness; indocility.

entry.ety: L. indocibilis. See In- not, and Docible
entry.def: Incapable of being taught, or not easily instructed; dull in intellect; intractable; unteachable; indocile.

entry.ety: L. indocilis: cf. F. indocile. See In- not, and Docile
entry.def: Not teachable; indisposed to be taught, trained, or disciplined; not easily instructed or governed; dull; intractable.

entry.ety: L. indocilitas: cf. F. indocilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being indocile; dullness of intellect; unteachableness; intractableness.
entry.q: The stiffness and indocility of the Pharisees.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Indoctrinated; p. pr. & vb. n. Indoctrinating
entry.ety: Pref. in- in + L. doctrina doctrine: cf. F. endoctriner

sn.def: To instruct in the rudiments or principles of learning, or of a branch of learning; to imbue with learning; to teach; -- often followed by in.
sn.q: A master that . . . took much delight in indoctrinating his young, unexperienced favorite.

sn.def: To instruct in, or imbue with, doctrines, principles or ideologies, especially from a specific point of view which may be partisan or biased; to strongly press one's own point of view upon.

entry.def: The act of indoctrinating, or the condition of being indoctrinated; instruction in the rudiments and principles of any science or system of belief; information.

entry.ety: Indo- + English
entry.def: Of or relating to the English who are born or reside in India; Anglo-Indian.

Aryan; -- applied to the languages of India and Europe which are derived from the prehistoric Aryan language; also, pertaining to the people or nations who speak these languages; as, the Indo-European or Aryan family.
entry.q: The common origin of the Indo-European nations.

entries.entry: In`do-Eu`ro*pe"an. A member of one of the Caucasian races of Europe or India speaking an Indo-European language. Professor Otto Schrader . . . considers that the oldest probable domicile of the Indo-Europeans is to be sought for on the common borderland of Asia and of Europe, -- in the steppe country of southern Russia.

entry.ety: Indigo + -gen
entry.def: A complex, nitrogenous radical, C8H5NO, regarded as the essential nucleus of indigo.
Any one of the derivatives of indogen, which contain that group as a nucleus.

entry.ety: Indo- + Germanic

sn.def: Same as Aryan, and Indo-European.
Pertaining to or denoting the Teutonic family of languages as related to the Sanskrit, or derived from the ancient Aryan language.

entry.def: A substance resembling indigo blue, obtained artificially from certain isatogen compounds.

entry.ety: Indigo + -ol of phenol
entry.def: A white, crystalline substance, C8H7N, obtained from blue indigo, and almost all indigo derivatives, by a process of reduction; chemically, it is 2,3-benzopyrrole, a bicyclic heterocyclic compound, having a benzene ring fused to a pyrrole ring. It is also formed from proteinaceous matter, together with skatol, by putrefaction, and by fusion with caustic potash, and is present in human excrement, as well as in the intestinal canal of some herbivora. It is produced in rich growth media by the intestinal bacterium Escherichia coli.
A plant hormone (C10H9NO2) recognized as the principle growth regulator in higher plants; called also heteroauxin. Abbreviated IAA. Chemically it is 1H-indole-3-acetic acid.

entry.ety: L. indolentia freedom from pain: cf. F. indolence

sn.def: Freedom from that which pains, or harasses, as toil, care, grief, etc.
sn.q: I have ease, if it may not rather be called indolence.

sn.def: The quality or condition of being indolent; inaction, or lack of exertion of body or mind, proceeding from love of ease or aversion to toil; habitual idleness; indisposition to labor; laziness; sloth; inactivity.
sn.q: Life spent in indolence, and therefore sad.

As there is a great truth wrapped up in “diligence,” what a lie, on the other hand, lurks at the root of our present use of the word “indolence”! This is from “in” and “doleo,” not to grieve; and indolence is thus a state in which we have no grief or pain; so that the word, as we now employ it, seems to affirm that indulgence in sloth and ease is that which would constitute for us the absence of all pain.

entry.def: Indolence.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + L. dolens -entis, p. pr. of dolere to feel pain: cf. F. indolent. See Dolorous

sn.def: Free from toil, pain, or trouble.
Indulging in ease; avoiding labor and exertion; habitually idle; lazy; inactive; as, an indolent man.
sn.q: To waste long nights in indolent repose.

sn.def: Causing little or no pain or annoyance; as, an indolent tumor.
sn.syn: Idle; lazy; slothful; sluggish; listless; inactive; inert. See Idle.

entry.def: In an indolent manner.
entry.q: Calm and serene you indolently sit.

entry.ety: L. Cf. Adolescence
entry.def: Natural disposition; natural quality or abilities.

entry.ety: See Indol
entry.def: A dark resinous substance, polymeric with indol, and obtained by the reduction of indigo white.

entry.ety: L. indomabilis; pref. in- not + domabilis tamable
entry.def: Indomitable.

A nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory, antipyretic and analgesic substance (C19H16ClNO4) prepared synthetically and used for the treatment of pain and arthritis. It blocks prostaglandin biosynthesis. Chemically, it is 1-(4-chlorobenzoyl)-5-methoxy-2-methyl-1H-indole-3-acetic acid.

entry.ety: L. indomitabilis; pref. in- not + domitare, intens. fr. domare to tame. See Tame
entry.def: Not to be subdued; untamable; invincible; as, an indomitable will, courage, animal.

entry.ety: L. indomitus
entry.def: Not tamed; untamed; savage; wild.

entry.ety: F. indomptable, L. indomitabilis
entry.def: Indomitable.

entry.ety: Indo- + Gr. � island
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Indonesia or Indonesians.

sn.def: A member of a race forming the chief pre-Malay population of the Malay Archipelago, and probably sprung from a mixture of Polynesian and Mongoloid immigrants. According to Keane, the autochthonous Negritos were largely expelled by the Caucasian Polynesians, themselves followed by Mongoloid peoples of Indo-Chinese affinities, from mixture with whom sprang the Indonesian race.
sn.q: The term Indonesian, introduced by Logan to designate the light-colored non-Malay inhabitants of the Eastern Archipelago, is now used as a convenient collective name for all the peoples of Malaysia and Polynesia who are neither Malay nor Papuans, but of Caucasic type. . . . The true Indonesians are of tall stature (5 ft. 10 in.), muscular frame, rather oval features, high, open forehead, large straight or curved nose, large full eyes always horizontal and with no trace of the third lid, light brown complexion (cinnamon or ruddy brown), long black hair, not lank but often slightly curled or wavy, skull generally brachycephalous like that of the melanochroic European.

The Indonesiansof the Philippines], with the tribal population of some 251, 200, live almost exclusively on the great island of Mindanao. They are not only physically superior to the Negritos, but to the peoples of the Malayan race as well, and are, as a rule, quite intelligent.

sn.def: A native or inhabitant of Indonesia.

entry.def: Done or being within doors; within a house or institution; domestic; as, indoor work.
Within the house; -- sometimes separated, in doors.

entry.ety: Indigo + phenol
entry.def: Any one of a series of artificial blue dyestuffs, resembling indigo in appearance, and obtained by the action of phenol on certain nitrogenous derivatives of quinone. Simple indophenol proper, the parent compound of the dye series, is a quinonimine derivative with the formula C12H9NO2.
Capable of being indorsed; transferable; convertible.
Indorsement.

cs.cd: to write one's name on the back of a note or bill, leaving a blank to be filled by the holder.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Indorsed; p. pr. & vb. n. Indorsing
entry.ety: LL. indorsare. See Endorse

sn.def: To cover the back of; to load or burden.
sn.q: Elephants indorsed with towers.

sn.def: To write upon the back or outside of a paper or letter, as a direction, heading, memorandum, or address.

To write one's name, alone or with other words, upon the back of (a paper), for the purpose of transferring it, or to secure the payment of a note, draft, or the like; to guarantee the payment, fulfillment, performance, or validity of, or to certify something upon the back of (a check, draft, writ, warrant of arrest, etc.).
To give one's name or support to; to sanction; to aid by approval; to approve; as, to indorse an opinion.

entry.def: See Addorsed.
The person to whom a note or bill is indorsed, or assigned by indorsement.

entry.cs: Blank indorsement. See under Blank.
entry.ety: From Indorse; cf. Endorsement

sn.def: The act of writing on the back of a note, bill, or other written instrument.

That which is written on the back of a note, bill, or other paper, as a name, an order for, or a receipt of, payment, or the return of an officer, etc.; a writing, usually upon the back, but sometimes on the face, of a negotiable instrument, by which the property therein is assigned and transferred.
Sanction, support, or approval; as, the indorsement of a rumor, an opinion, a course, conduct.

entry.def: The person who indorses.
See Endow.
See Endowment.

entry.ety: Indigo + hydroxyl
entry.def: A nitrogenous substance, C8H7NO, isomeric with oxindol, obtained as an oily liquid.
Of or pertaining to, or producing, indoxyl; as, indoxylic acid.

sn.def: An opening from the sea into the land; an inlet.
A draught of air or flow of water setting inward.

entry.def: Drawn in.
To overwhelm with water; to drench; to drown.

entry.note: ☞ Several species are known, all of them natives of Madagascar, as the diadem indris (Indris diadema), which has a white ruff around the forehead; the woolly indris (Indris laniger); and the short-tailed or black indris (Indris brevicaudatus), which is black, varied with gray.
entry.def: Any lemurine animal of the genus Indris.

entry.ety: L. indubius. See In- not, and Dubious

sn.def: Not dubious or doubtful; certain.
Not doubting; unsuspecting.
sn.q: Indubiousconfidence.

entry.def: the quality of being beyond question or dispute or doubt; indubitableness.

entry.ety: L. indubitabilis: cf. F. indubitable. See In- not, and Dubitable
entry.def: Not dubitable or doubtful; too evident to admit of doubt; unquestionable; evident; apparently certain; as, an indubitable conclusion.
entry.syn: Unquestionable; evident; incontrovertible; incontestable; undeniable; irrefragable.

entry.def: The state or quality of being indubitable.
Undoubtedly; unquestionably; in a manner to remove all doubt.
entry.q: Oracles indubitably clear and infallibly certain.

entry.ety: L. indubitatus; pref. in- not + dubitatus, p. p. of dubitare to doubt
entry.def: Not questioned or doubtful; evident; certain.

entry.ety: L. indubitatus, p. p. of indubitare; pref. in- in + dubitare to doubt
entry.def: To bring into doubt; to cause to be doubted.
entry.q: To conceal, or indubitate, his exigency.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Induced; p. pr. & vb. n. Inducing
entry.ety: L. inducere inductum; pref. in- in + ducere to lead. See Duke, and cf. Induct

sn.def: To lead in; to introduce.
sn.q: The poet may be seen inducing his personages in the first Iliad.

sn.def: To draw on; to overspread.
To lead on; to influence; to prevail on; to incite; to persuade; to move by persuasion or influence.
sn.q: He is not obliged by your offer to do it, . . . though he may be induced, persuaded, prevailed upon, tempted.
Let not the covetous desire of growing rich induce you to ruin your reputation.

sn.def: To bring on; to effect; to cause; as, a fever induced by fatigue or exposure; anaphylactic shock induced by exposure to a allergen.
sn.q: Sour things induces a contraction in the nerves.

sn.def: To produce, or cause, by proximity without contact or transmission, as a particular electric or magnetic condition in a body, by the approach of another body in an opposite electric or magnetic state.
To generalize or conclude as an inference from all the particulars; -- the opposite of deduce.

To cause the expression of (a gene or gene product) by affecting a transcription control element on the genome, either by inhibiting a negative control or by activating a positive control; to derepress; as, lactose induces the production of beta-galactosidase in Eschericia coli..
sn.syn: To move; instigate; urge; impel; incite; press; influence; actuate.

entries.entry: induced adj. brought about or caused; not spontaneous; as, a case of steroid-induced weakness. Contrasted to spontaneous.Narrower terms: elicited, evoked
In*duced" cur"rent. Elec A current due to variation in the magnetic field surrounding its conductor.

entry.ety: From Induce

sn.def: The act of inducing, or the state of being induced.
That which induces; a motive or consideration that leads one to action or induces one to act; as, reward is an inducement to toil.
sn.q: Mark theinducement.

sn.def: Matter stated by way of explanatory preamble or introduction to the main allegations of a pleading; a leading to.
sn.syn: Motive; reason; influence. See Motive.

sn.def: One who, or that which, induces or incites.
A substance which, when it contacts a living cell, causes the activation of a gene; as, non-metabolizable inducers are useful for studying the kinetics of genetic control systems.
Capable of being induced, caused, or made to take place.
Obtainable by induction; derivable; inferable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inducted; p. pr. & vb. n. Inducting
entry.ety: L. inductus, p. p. of inducere. See Induce

sn.def: To bring in; to introduce; to usher in.
sn.q: The independent orator inducting himself without further ceremony into the pulpit.

sn.def: To introduce, as to a benefice or office; to put in actual possession of the temporal rights of an ecclesiastical living, or of any other office, with the customary forms and ceremonies.
sn.q: The prior, when inducted into that dignity, took an oath not to alienate any of their lands.

entry.note: ☞ The unit of inductance is the henry.
entry.def: Capacity for induction; the coefficient of self-induction.

entries.entry: In*duc"tance coil. Elec A choking coil.

entry.def: Rendered electro-polar by induction, or brought into the opposite electrical state by the influence of inductive bodies.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + ductile: cf. F. inductile
entry.def: Not ductile; incapable of being drawn into threads, as a metal; inelastic; tough.
The quality or state of being inductile.

cs.cd: the action by which a variable or interrupted current of electricity excites another current in a neighboring conductor forming a closed circuit.
the influence by which an electric current produces magnetic polarity in certain bodies near or around which it passes.
the action by which a body possessing a charge of statical electricity develops a charge of statical electricity of the opposite character in a neighboring body.

an apparatus producing induced currents of great intensity. It consists of a coil or helix of stout insulated copper wire, surrounded by another coil of very fine insulated wire, in which a momentary current is induced, when a current (as from a voltaic battery), passing through the inner coil, is made, broken, or varied. The inner coil has within it a core of soft iron, and is connected at its terminals with a condenser; -- called also inductorium, and Ruhmkorff's coil.
a pipe, passageway, or valve, for leading or admitting a fluid to a receiver, as steam to an engine cylinder, or water to a pump.
the action by which magnetic polarity is developed in a body susceptible to magnetic effects when brought under the influence of a magnet.
the influence by which a magnet excites electric currents in closed circuits.

an act or method of reasoning from all the parts separately to the whole which they constitute, or into which they may be united collectively; the operation of discovering and proving general propositions; the scientific method.

the inference, or the act of inferring, that what has been observed or established in respect to a part, individual, or species, may, on the ground of analogy, be affirmed or received of the whole to which it belongs. This last is the inductive method of Bacon. It ascends from the parts to the whole, and forms, from the general analogy of nature, or special presumptions in the case, conclusions which have greater or less degrees of force, and which may be strengthened or weakened by subsequent experience and experiment. It relates to actual existences, as in physical science or the concerns of life. Logical induction is founded on the necessary laws of thought; philosophical induction, on the interpretation of the indications or analogy of nature.

entry.usage: Induction Deduction. In induction we observe a sufficient number of individual facts, and, on the ground of analogy, extend what is true of them to others of the same class, thus arriving at general principles or laws. This is the kind of reasoning in physical science. In deduction we begin with a general truth, which is already proven or provisionally assumed, and seek to connect it with some particular case by means of a middle term, or class of objects, known to be equally connected with both. Thus, we bring down the general into the particular, affirming of the latter the distinctive qualities of the former. This is the syllogistic method. By induction Franklin established the identity of lightning and electricity; by deduction he inferred that dwellings might be protected by lightning rods.
entry.ety: L. inductio: cf. F. induction. See Induct

sn.def: The act or process of inducting or bringing in; introduction; entrance; beginning; commencement.
sn.q: I know not you; nor am I well pleased to make this time, as the affair now stands, the induction of your acquaintance.
These promises are fair, the parties sure, And our induction dull of prosperous hope.

sn.def: An introduction or introductory scene, as to a play; a preface; a prologue.
sn.q: This is but an induction: I will draw The curtains of the tragedy hereafter.

sn.def: The act or process of reasoning from a part to a whole, from particulars to generals, or from the individual to the universal; also, the result or inference so reached.
sn.q: Induction is an inference drawn from all the particulars.

Induction is the process by which we conclude that what is true of certain individuals of a class, is true of the whole class, or that what is true at certain times will be true in similar circumstances at all times.

sn.def: The introduction of a clergyman into a benefice, or of an official into a office, with appropriate acts or ceremonies; the giving actual possession of an ecclesiastical living or its temporalities.

A process of demonstration in which a general truth is gathered from an examination of particular cases, one of which is known to be true, the examination being so conducted that each case is made to depend on the preceding one; -- called also successive induction.

The property by which one body, having electrical or magnetic polarity, causes or induces it in another body without direct contact; an impress of electrical or magnetic force or condition from one body on another without actual contact.
sn.syn: Deduction.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or proceeding by, induction; inductive.

entries.entry: In*duc"tion gen"er*a`tor. A machine built as an induction motor and driven above synchronous speed, thus acting as an alternating-current generator; -- called also asynchronous generator. Below synchronism the machine takes in electrical energy and acts as an induction motor; at synchronism the power component of current becomes zero and changes sign, so that above synchronism the machine (driven for this purpose by mechanical power) gives out electrical energy as a generator.

Induction motor. Elec A type of alternating-current motor comprising two wound members, one stationary, called the stator, and the other rotating, called the rotor, these two members corresponding to a certain extent to the field and armature of a direct-current motor.

entry.cs:
Inductive embarrassment Physics the retardation in signaling on an electric wire, produced by lateral induction.
Inductive philosophyorInductive method . See Philosophical induction, under Induction. Inductive sciences those sciences which admit of, and employ, the inductive method, as astronomy, botany, chemistry, etc.
entry.ety: LL. inductivus: cf. F. inductif. See Induce

sn.def: Leading or drawing; persuasive; tempting; -- usually followed by to.
sn.q: A brutish vice,Inductive mainly to the sin of Eve.

sn.def: Tending to induce or cause.
sn.q: They may be . . . inductive of credibility.

sn.def: Leading to inferences; proceeding by, derived from, or using, induction; as, inductive reasoning.

sd.def: Operating by induction; as, an inductive electrical machine.
Facilitating induction; susceptible of being acted upon by induction; as, certain substances have a great inductive capacity.

entry.def: By induction or inference.

entry.ety: Induction + -meter
entry.def: An instrument for measuring or ascertaining the degree or rate of electrical induction.

entry.ety: L., one who stirs up or rouses. See Induce

sn.def: The person who inducts another into an office or benefice.
That portion of an electrical apparatus, in which is the inducing charge or current.

entries.entry: In`duc*to"ri*um n.; pl. E. Inductoriums #, L. Inductoria #. NL., fr. E. induction Elec An induction coil.

entry.def: Acting by, or in a state of, induction; relating to electrical induction.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Indued; p. pr. & vb. n. Induing
entry.ety: L. induere to put on, clothe, fr. OL. indufr. in- in) + a root seen also in L. exuere to put off, divest, exuviae the skin of an animal, slough, induviae clothes. Cf. Endue to invest

sn.def: To put on, as clothes; to draw on.
sn.q: The baron had indued a pair of jack boots.

sn.def: To clothe; to invest; hence, to endow; to furnish; to supply with moral or mental qualities.
sn.q: Indu'd with robes of various hue she flies.
Indued with intellectual sense and souls.

entry.ety: From Indue; cf. Indument Enduement
entry.def: The act of induing, or state of being indued; investment; endowment.

entry.note: ☞ It is remarked by Johnson, that if the matter of indulgence is a single thing, it has with before it; if it is a habit, it has in; as, he indulged himself with a glass of wine or a new book; he indulges himself in idleness or intemperance. See Gratify.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Indulged; p. pr. & vb. n. Indulging
entry.ety: L. indulgere to be kind or tender to one; cf. OIr. dilgud, equiv. to L. remissio, OIr. dligeth, equiv. to L. lex, Goth. dulgs debt

sn.def: To grant as by favor; to bestow in concession, or in compliance with a wish or request.
sn.q: Persuading us that something must be indulged to public manners.
Yet, yet a moment, one dim ray of lightIndulge, dread Chaos, and eternal Night!

entry.def: To indulge one's self; to gratify one's tastes or desires; esp., to give one's self up (to); to practice a forbidden or questionable act without restraint; -- followed by in, but formerly, also, by to.
entry.q: Willing toindulgein easy vices.

entry.def: Indulgence.

entry.ety: L. indulgentia: cf. F. indulgence

sn.def: The act of indulging or humoring; the quality of being indulgent; forbearance of restrain or control.
sn.q: If I were a judge, that word indulgence should never issue from my lips.
They err, that through indulgence to others, or fondness to any sin in themselves, substitute for repentance anything less.

sn.def: An indulgent act; favor granted; gratification.
sn.q: If all these gracious indulgences are without any effect on us, we must perish in our own folly.

sn.def: Remission of the temporal punishment due to sins, after the guilt of sin has been remitted by sincere repentance; absolution from the censures and public penances of the church. It is a payment of the debt of justice to God by the application of the merits of Christ and his saints to the contrite soul through the church. It is therefore believed to diminish or destroy for sins the punishment of purgatory.

entry.def: To grant an indulgence to.
Indulgence.

entry.ety: L. indulgens -entis, p. pr. of indulgere: cf. F. indulgent. See Indulge
entry.def: Prone to indulge; yielding to the wishes, humor, or appetites of those under one's care; compliant; not opposing or restraining; tolerant; mild; favorable; not severe; as, an indulgent parent.
entry.q: The indulgent censure of posterity.
The feeble old, indulgent of their ease.

entry.def: Relating to the indulgences of the Roman Catholic Church.
In an indulgent manner; mildly; favorably.
One who indulges.
To indulge.

entry.ety: Perh. fr. indigo
entry.def: Any one of a large series of aniline dyes, colored blue or violet, and represented by aniline violet.
A dark green amorphous dyestuff, produced by the oxidation of aniline in the presence of copper or vanadium salts; -- called also aniline black.

entry.ety: L. indultum indulgence, favor, fr. indultus, p. p. of indulgere: cf. It. indulto, F. indult. See Indulge

sn.def: A privilege or exemption; an indulgence; a dispensation granted by the pope.
A duty levied on all importations.

entry.ety: L. indumentum a covering. See Indue, and cf. Induement

sn.def: Plumage; feathers.
A dense covering, especially a hairy one; called also indumentum.

entry.def: Having the edges bent abruptly toward the axis; -- said of the parts of the calyx or corolla in æstivation.
Having the edges rolled inward and then arranged about the axis without overlapping; -- said of leaves in vernation.
Having induplicate sepals or petals in æstivation.
Having induplicate leaves in vernation.
See Endurance.

entry.ety: L. induratus, p. p. of indurare to harden. See Endure

sn.def: Hardened; not soft; indurated.
Without sensibility; unfeeling; obdurate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Indurated; p. pr. & vb. n. Indurating

sn.def: To make hard; as, extreme heat indurates clay; some fossils are indurated by exposure to the air.
To make unfeeling; to deprive of sensibility; to render obdurate.

entry.def: To grow hard; to harden, or become hard; as, clay indurates by drying, and by heat.
Hardened; as, indurated clay; an indurated heart.

entry.ety: Cf. F. induration, L. induratio hardness of heart

sn.def: The act of hardening, or the process of growing hard.
State of being indurated, or of having become hard.
Hardness of character, manner, sensibility, etc.; obduracy; stiffness; lack of pliancy or feeling.
sn.q: A certain induration of character had arisen from long habits of business.

cs.cd: a fresh-water limestone, largely composed of the agglomerated cases of caddice worms, or larvæ of caddice flies (Phryganea). It is found in Miocene strata of Auvergne, France, and some other localities.

entry.ety: See Indusium
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or containing, the petrified cases of the larvæ of certain insects.
Furnished with an indusium.

entries.entry: ‖In*du"si*um n.; pl.Indusia -ȧ. L., an under garment, fr. induere to put on: cf. F. indusie the covering of the seed spots of ferns Bot A collection of hairs united so as to form a sort of cup, and inclosing the stigma of a flower. The immediate covering of the fruit dots or sori in many ferns, usually a very thin scale attached by the middle or side to a veinlet. A peculiar covering found in certain fungi.

cs.cd: a public exhibition of the various industrial products of a country, or of various countries.
a school for teaching one or more branches of industry; also, a school for educating neglected children, and training them to habits of industry.

entry.ety: Cf. F. industriel, LL. industrialis. See Industry
entry.def: Consisting in industry; pertaining to industry, or the arts and products of industry; concerning those employed in labor, especially in manual labor, and their wages, duties, and rights.
entry.q: The great ideas of industrial development and economic social amelioration.

sn.def: Devotion to industrial pursuits; labor; industry.
The principles or policy applicable to industrial pursuits or organized labor.
sn.q: Industrialism must not confounded with industriousness.

entry.def: To make industrial; to develop so that most of the working population is engaged in non-agricultural labor; to develop economically; -- of nations or geographical areas; as, to industrialize underdeveloped nations.

sn.def: made industrial; converted to industrialism.

entry.def: With reference to industry.
An area designated in zoning regulations to be used by industry, often located in a suburban area, and having some park-like sections.

The changes in the methods of production as well as the resulting changes in economic and social organization accompanying the replacement of hand labor by power-driven machinery. It started in England in about 1760, and spread to other countries with very varying time lags. The introduction of powered machinery such as the steam engine and power loom led to the concentration of large areas of manufacturing in large companies, and made some goods more plentiful and cheaper by mechanical production and economies of scale.

entry.ety: L. industrius industriosus: cf. F. industrieux. See Industry

sn.def: Given to industry; characterized by diligence; constantly, regularly, or habitually occupied; busy; assiduous; not slothful or idle; -- commonly implying devotion to lawful and useful labor.
sn.q: Frugal and industrious men are commonly friendly to the established government.

sn.def: Steadily and perseveringly active in a particular pursuit or aim; as, he was negligent in business, but industrious in pleasure; an industrious mischief maker.
sn.q: Industrious to seek out the truth of all things.

entry.def: persevering application; habitual and diligent occupation with productive activity.

entries.entry:
In"dus*try n.; pl.Industries #. L. industria, cf. industrius diligent; of uncertain origin: cf. F. industrie
Habitual diligence in any employment or pursuit, either bodily or mental; steady attention to business; assiduity; -- opposed to sloth and idleness; as, industry pays debts, while idleness or despair will increase them. We are more industrious than our forefathers, because in the present times the funds destined for the maintenance of industry are much greater in proportion to those which are likely to be employed in the maintenance of idleness, than they were two or three centuries ago.
Any department or branch of art, occupation, or business; especially, one which employs much labor and capital and is a distinct branch of trade; as, the sugar industry; the iron industry; the cotton industry.
Polit. Econ Human exertion of any kind employed for the creation of value, and regarded by some as a species of capital or wealth; labor. Diligence; assiduity; perseverance; activity; laboriousness; attention. See Diligence.

entry.ety: L. indutus, p. p. of induere to put on. See Indue
entry.def: Covered; -- applied to seeds which have the usual integumentary covering.

entry.ety: L., clothes, fr. induere to put on. See Indue
entry.def: Persistent portions of a calyx or corolla; also, leaves which do not disarticulate from the stem, and hence remain for a long time.
Covered with induviæ, as the upper part of the trunk of a palm tree.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Indwelt; p. pr. & vb. n. Indwelling
entry.def: To dwell in; to abide within; to remain in possession.
entry.q: The Holy Ghost became a dove, not as a symbol, but as a constantly indwelt form.

entry.def: An inhabitant.
Residence within, as in the heart.
entry.q: The personal indwelling of the Spirit in believers.

entries.entry:
-ine ☞ All organic bases, and basic substances (especially nitrogenous substances), are systematically written with the termination -ine; as, quinine, pyridine, morphine, guanidine, etc. Certain substances containing nitrogen though with net neutral character (as certain amino acids) also end in -ine, such valine and glycine. All indifferent and neutral substances, as proteids, glycerides, glucosides, etc., should commonly be spelled with -in; as, gelatin, amygdalin, etc. This rule has no application to those numerous commercial or popular names with the termination -ine; as, gasoline, vaseline, etc. ?; 104. Chem A suffix, indicating that those substances of whose names it is a part are basic, in their nature, i.e. contain a basic nitrogen group.
Organ. Chem A suffix, formerly used to indicate hydrocarbons of the second degree of unsaturation; i. e., members of the acetyline series; as, hexine heptine, etc., but now superseded by the ending -yne, as in propyne.

entry.def: To inter.

entry.ety: L. inebrians, p. pr. of inebriare. See Inebriate
entry.def: Intoxicating.
Anything that intoxicates, as opium, alcohol, etc.; an intoxicant.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inebriated; p. pr. & vb. n. Inebriating
entry.ety: L. inebriatus, p. p. of inebriare; pref. in- in + ebriare to make drunk, fr. ebrius drunk. See Ebriety

sn.def: To make drunk; to intoxicate.
sn.q: The cups That cheer but not inebriate.

sn.def: Fig.: To disorder the senses of; to exhilarate or elate as if by spirituous drink; to deprive of sense and judgment; also, to stupefy.
sn.q: The inebriating effect of popular applause.

entry.def: To become drunk.

entry.ety: L. inebriatus, p. p
entry.def: Intoxicated; drunk; habitually given to drink; stupefied.
entry.q: Thus spake Peter, as a man inebriate and made drunken with the sweetness of this vision, not knowing what he said.

entry.def: One who is drunk or intoxicated; esp., an habitual drunkard; as, an asylum for inebriates .
