entry.q: Some inebriates have their paroxysms of inebriety.

entry.def: under the influence of alcohol; intoxicated; drunk.
entry.syn: besotted, bibulous, blind, blind drunk, drunk, drunken, inebriate, sottish.

entry.ety: L. inebriatio
entry.def: The condition of being inebriated; intoxication; figuratively, deprivation of sense and judgment by anything that exhilarates, as success.
entry.q: Preserve him from the inebriation of prosperity.

entry.ety: See Inebriate Ebriety
entry.def: Drunkenness; inebriation.
Intoxicated, or partially so; intoxicating.

entry.ety: LL. inedibilis. See In- not, and Edible
entry.def: Not edible; not fit for use as food.
Not edited; unpublished; as, an inedited manuscript.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: An arrow poison, made from an apocynaceous plant (Strophanthus hispidus) of the Gaboon country; -- called also onaye.

entry.ety: L. ineffabilitas: cf. F. ineffabilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being ineffable; ineffableness; unspeakableness.

entry.ety: L. ineffabilis: cf. F. ineffable. See In- not, and Effable Fame
entry.def: Incapable of being expressed in words; unspeakable; unutterable; indescribable; as, the ineffable joys of heaven.
entry.q: Contentment with our lot . . . will diffuse ineffable contentment over the soul.

entry.def: The quality or state of being ineffable or unutterable; unspeakableness.
In a manner not to be expressed in words; unspeakably.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + effaceable: cf. F. ineffaçable
entry.def: Incapable of being effaced; indelible; ineradicable.
So as not to be effaceable.
Ineffectual; impracticable.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + effective: cf. F. ineffectif
entry.def: Not effective; not having the desired effect; ineffectual; futile; inefficient; useless; as, an ineffective appeal; an ineffective herbal remedy.
entry.q: The word of God, without the spirit, [is] a dead and ineffective letter.

entry.def: In an ineffective manner; without effect; inefficiently; ineffectually.
Quality of being ineffective.
Not producing the proper effect; without effect; inefficient; weak; useless; futile; unavailing; as, an ineffectual attempt; an ineffectual expedient.
entry.q: The peony root has been much commended, . . . and yet has been by many found ineffectual.
entry.syn: Inefficient; useless; inefficacious; vain; fruitless; unavailing; futile. See Useless Inefficacious.

entry.def: Ineffectualness.
Without effect; in vain.
entry.q: Hereford . . . had been besieged for about two months ineffectually by the Scots.

entry.def: Lack of effect, or of power to produce it; inefficacy.
entry.q: The ineffectualness of some men's devotion.

entry.def: Lack of effervescence.
Not effervescing, or not susceptible of effervescence; quiescent.
The quality of being ineffervescible.
Not capable or susceptible of effervescence.

entry.note: ☞ Ineffectual, says Johnson, rather denotes an actual failure, and inefficacious an habitual impotence to any effect. But the distinction is not always observed, nor can it be; for we can not always know whether means are inefficacious till experiment has proved them ineffectual. Inefficacious is therefore sometimes synonymous with ineffectual.
entry.ety: Pref. in- not + efficacious: cf. F. inefficace, L. inefficax
entry.def: Not efficacious; not having power to produce the effect desired; inadequate; incompetent; inefficient; impotent.
entry.q: The authority of Parliament must become inefficacious . . . to restrain the growth of disorders.

entry.def: Without efficacy or effect.
Lack of effect, or of power to produce the effect; inefficacy.

entry.ety: L. inefficacia. See In- not, and Efficacy
entry.def: Lack of power to produce the desired or proper effect; inefficiency; ineffectualness; futility; uselessness; fruitlessness; as, the inefficacy of medicines or means.
entry.q: The seeming inefficacy of censures.
The inefficacy was soon proved, like that of many similar medicines.

entry.def: The quality of being inefficient; lack of power or energy sufficient for the desired effect; inefficacy; incapacity; as, he was discharged from his position for inefficiency .

sn.def: Not efficient; not producing the effect intended or desired, or achieiving the effect by unnnecessary and excessive expenditure of resources; inefficacious; as, inefficient means or measures; inefficient methods are too expensive.
Incapable of, or indisposed to, effective action; habitually slack or remiss; effecting little or nothing; as, inefficient workmen; an inefficient administrator.

entry.def: In an inefficient manner.

entry.ety: L. inelaboratus. See In- not, and Elaborate
entry.def: Not elaborate; not wrought with care; unpolished; crude; unfinished.

sn.def: Not elastic.
reacting little to changing price; -- of demand; as, Potatoes have an inelastic demand.

entry.def: Lack of elasticity.

entries.entry:
In*el"e*gance In*el"e*gan*cy, n.; pl.Inelegances # Inelegancies #. L. inelegantia: cf. F. inélégance
The quality of being inelegant; lack of elegance or grace; lack of refinement, beauty, or polish in language, composition, or manners. The notorious inelegance of her figure.
Anything inelegant; as, inelegance of style in literary composition.

entry.ety: L. inelegans: cf. F. inélégant. See In- not, and Elegant
entry.def: Not elegant; deficient in beauty, polish, refinement, grave, or ornament; wanting in anything which correct taste requires.
entry.q: What order so contrived as not to mix Tastes, not well joined, inelegant.
It renders style often obscure, always embarrassed and inelegant.

entry.def: In an inelegant manner.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inéligibilité
entry.def: The state or quality of being ineligible.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + eligible: cf. F. inéligible
entry.def: Not eligible; not qualified to be chosen (for an office, post, position); not worthy to be chosen or preferred; not expedient or desirable.
In an ineligible manner.

entry.ety: L. ineloquens: cf. F. inéloquent. See In- not, and Eloquent
entry.def: Not eloquent; not fluent, graceful, or moving; not persuasive; as, ineloquent language.
entry.q: Nor are thy lips ungraceful, sire of men, Nor tongue ineloquent.

entry.def: Without eloquence.

entry.ety: L. ineluctabilis; pref. in- not + eluctabilis to be surmounted, fr. eluctari to struggle out of, to surmount: cf. F. inéluctable. See Eluctate
entry.def: Not to be overcome by struggling; irresistible; inescapable; inevitable.
entry.q: The ineluctable conditions of matter.

entry.def: Incapable of being eluded or evaded; unvoidable.
entry.q: Most pressing reasons and ineludible demonstrations.

entry.def: Not embryonate.

entry.ety: L. inenarrabilis; pref. in- not + enarrabilis that may be related; fr. enarrare to relate: cf. F. inénarrable. See Enarration
entry.def: Incapable of being narrated; indescribable; ineffable.
entry.q: Inenarrablegoodness.

entry.ety: L. ineptus; prefix. in- not + aptus apt, fit: cf. F. inepte. Cf. Inapt

sn.def: Not apt or fit; unfit; unsuitable; improper; unbecoming.
sn.q: The Aristotelian philosophy is inept for new discoveries.

sn.def: Silly; useless; nonsensical; absurd; foolish.
sn.q: To view attention as a special act of intelligence, and to distinguish it from consciousness, is utterly inept.

entry.ety: L. ineptitudo

sn.def: The quality of being inept; unfitness; inaptitude; unsuitableness.
sn.q: That ineptitude for society, which is frequently the fault of us scholars.

sn.def: Absurdity; nonsense; foolishness.

entry.def: Unfitly; unsuitably; awkwardly.
entry.q: None of them are made foolishly or ineptly.

entry.def: Unfitness; ineptitude.
entry.q: The feebleness and miserable ineptness of infancy.

entry.def: Unequable.

entry.ety: L. inaequalis. See In- not, and Equal
entry.def: Unequal; uneven; various.

entries.entry:
In`e*qual"i*ty n.; pl.Inequalities #. L. inaequalitas
The quality of being unequal; difference, or lack of equality, in any respect; lack of uniformity; disproportion; unevenness; disparity; diversity; as, an inequality in size, stature, numbers, power, distances, motions, rank, property, etc.
There is so great an inequality in the length of our legs and arms as makes it impossible for us to walk on all four. Notwithstanding which inequality of number, it was resolved in a council of war to fight the Dutch fleet. Sympathy is rarely strong where there is a great inequality of condition.
Unevenness; lack of levelness; the alternate rising and falling of a surface; as, the inequalities of the surface of the earth, or of a marble slab, etc.
The country is cut into so many hills and inequalities as renders it defensible.
Variableness; changeableness; inconstancy; lack of smoothness or equability; deviation; unsteadiness, as of the weather, feelings, etc.
Inequality of air is ever an enemy to health.
Disproportion to any office or purpose; inadequacy; competency; as, the inequality of terrestrial things to the wants of a rational soul.
Alg An expression consisting of two unequal quantities, with the sign of inequality (> or <) between them; as, the inequality 2 < 3, or 4 > 1.
Astron An irregularity, or a deviation, in the motion of a planet or satellite from its uniform mean motion; the amount of such deviation.

entry.def: An inequality.
Not equally distant; not equidistant.

sn.def: Having unequal sides; unsymmetrical; unequal-sided.
Having the two ends unequal, as in the clam, quahaug, and most lamellibranch shells.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + equi- + lobate
entry.def: Unequally lobed; cut into lobes of different shapes or sizes.
Not equitable; not just.

entry.ety: L. inequitatus, p. p. inequitare to ride over. See 1st In-, and Equitant
entry.def: To ride over or through.
Lack of equity; injustice; wrong.
entry.q: Some form ofinequity.

entry.def: Having unequal valves, as the shell of an oyster.
Incapable of being eradicated or rooted out.
entry.q: The bad seed thus sown was ineradicable.

entry.def: So as not to be eradicable.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + energetic -ical
entry.def: Having no energy; sluggish.
Without energy.
Same as Inermis.

entry.ety: L. inermis inermus; pref. in- not + arma arms: cf. F. inerme
entry.def: Unarmed; destitute of prickles or thorns, as a leaf.
Freedom or exemption from error; infallibility.

entry.ety: L. inerrabilis. See In- not, and Err
entry.def: Incapable of erring; infallible; unerring.
entry.q: Inerabbleand requisite conditions.
Not aninerrabletext.

entry.def: Exemption from error; inerrability; infallibility.
With security from error; infallibly; unerringly.
Exemption from error.
entry.q: The absolute inerrancy of the Bible.

entry.def: Not erratic or wandering; fixed; settled; established.
Without error, mistake, or deviation; unerringly.

entry.usage: Inert Inactive Sluggish. A man may be inactive from mere lack of stimulus to effort; but one who is inert has something in his constitution or his habits which operates like a weight holding him back from exertion. Sluggish is still stronger, implying some defect of temperament which directly impedes action. Inert and inactive are negative, sluggish is positive.
entry.ety: L. iners inertis, unskilled, idle; pref. in- + ars art: cf. F. inerte. See Art

sn.def: Destitute of the power of moving itself, or of active resistance to motion; as, matter is inert .
Indisposed to move or act; very slow to act; sluggish; dull; inactive; indolent; lifeless.
sn.q: The inert and desponding party of the court.
It present becomes extravagant, then imbecile, and at length utterly inert.

sn.def: Not having or manifesting active properties; not affecting other substances when brought in contact with them; powerless for an expected or desired effect; as, the noble gases are chemically inert .
sn.syn: Inactive; dull; passive; indolent; sluggish; slothful; lazy; lifeless; irresolute; stupid; senseless; insensible.
sn.q: Even the favored isles . . . Can boast but little virtue; and, inert Through plenty, lose in morals what they gain In manners -- victims of luxurious ease.
Doomed to lose four months in inactive obscurity.
Sluggish Idleness, the nurse of sin, Upon a slothful ass he chose to ride.

entry.cs: Center of inertia. Mech See under Center.
entry.ety: L., idleness, fr. iners idle. See Inert

sn.def: That property of matter by which it tends when at rest to remain so, and when in motion to continue in motion, and in the same straight line or direction, unless acted on by some external force; -- sometimes called vis inertiæ. The inertia of a body is proportional to its mass.
Inertness; indisposition to motion, exertion, or action; lack of energy; sluggishness.
sn.q: Men . . . have immense irresolution and inertia.

sn.def: Lack of activity; sluggishness; -- said especially of the uterus, when, in labor, its contractions have nearly or wholly ceased.

entry.def: Lack of activity or exertion; inertness; quietude.
entry.q: These vicissitudes of exertion and inertion of the arterial system constitute the paroxysms of remittent fever.

entry.ety: See Inert
entry.def: Inertness; inertia.
Without activity; sluggishly.

sn.def: Lack of activity or exertion; habitual indisposition to action or motion; sluggishness; apathy; insensibility.
sn.q: Laziness and inertness of mind.

sn.def: Absence of the power of self-motion; inertia.

entry.ety: L. ineruditus. See In- not, and Erudite
entry.def: Not erudite; unlearned; ignorant.
Not escapable.

entry.ety: L. inescatus, p. p. of inescare; in- in + esca bait
entry.def: To allure; to lay a bait for.
entry.q: To inescate and beguile young women!

entry.ety: L. inescatio
entry.def: The act of baiting; allurement.
A small escutcheon borne within a shield.

entries.entry: ‖In` es"se. L In being; actually existing; -- distinguished from in posse, or in potentia, which denote that a thing is not, but may be.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + essential: cf. F. inessentiel

sn.def: Having no essence or being.
sn.q: The womb of inessential Naught.

sn.def: Not essential; not required to achieve a given purpose; unessential; unnecessary.

entry.ety: L. inaestimabilis: cf. F. inestimable. See In- not, and Estimate
entry.def: Incapable of being estimated or computed; especially, too valuable or excellent to be measured or fully appreciated; above all price; as, inestimable rights or privileges.
entry.q: But above all, for thine inestimable love.
Science is too inestimable for expression by a money standard.

entry.def: In a manner, or to a degree, above estimation; as, things inestimably excellent.
Incapable of being evaded; inevitable; unavoidable.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inévidence
entry.def: Lack of evidence; obscurity.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inévident
entry.def: Not evident; not clear or obvious; obscure.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inévitabilité
entry.def: Impossibility to be avoided or shunned; inevitableness.

entry.ety: L. inevitabilis: cf. F. inévitable. See In- not, and Evitable

sn.def: Not evitable; incapable of being shunned; unavoidable; certain.
sn.q: Theinevitablehour.
It was inevitable; it was necessary; it was planted in the nature of things.

sn.def: Irresistible.
sn.q: Inevitablecharms.

entry.def: The state of being unavoidable; certainty to happen; inevitability.
Without possibility of escape or evasion; unavoidably; certainly.
entry.q: Inevitably thou shalt die.
How inevitably does immoderate laughter end in a sigh!

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + exact: cf. F. inexact
entry.def: Not exact; not precisely correct or true; inaccurate.

sn.def: Inexactness; uncertainty; as, geographical inexactitude .
Something inexact; an instance of an inexact statement, measurement, etc.; as, in two minutes the senator has produced a dozen inexactitudes .

entry.def: In a manner not exact or precise; inaccurately.
Incorrectness; lack of exactness.
The quality of being inexcitable; insusceptibility to excitement.

entry.ety: L. inexcitabilis from which one cannot be aroused. See In- not, and Excite
entry.def: Not susceptible of excitement; dull; lifeless; torpid.

entry.ety: L. inexcusabilis: cf. F. inexcusable. See Excuse
entry.def: Not excusable; not admitting excuse or justification; as, inexcusable folly.
entry.q: Therefore thou art inexcusable, O man, whosoever thou art that judgest; for wherein thou judgest another, thou condemnest thyself; for thou that judgest doest the same things.

entry.def: The quality of being inexcusable; enormity beyond forgiveness.
With a degree of guilt or folly beyond excuse or justification.
entry.q: Inexcusably obstinate and perverse.

entry.def: That can not be execrated enough.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + executable: cf. F. inexécutable
entry.def: Incapable of being executed or performed; impracticable; infeasible.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + execution: cf. F. inexécution
entry.def: Neglect of execution; nonperformance; as, the inexecution of a treaty.
Lack of exertion; lack of effort; defect of action; indolence; laziness.
Incapable of being exhaled.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + exhausted: cf. F. inexhaustus
entry.def: Not exhausted; not emptied; not spent; not having lost all strength or resources; unexhausted.
Without exhaustion.
The state or quality of being inexhaustible; abundance.
Incapable of being exhausted, emptied, or used up; unfailing; not to be wasted or spent; as, inexhaustible stores of provisions; an inexhaustible stock of elegant words.
entry.q: An inexhaustible store of anecdotes.

entry.def: Inexhaustible.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + exist
entry.def: To exist within; to dwell within.
entry.q: Substances inexisting within the divine mind.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inexistant. See 1st Inexistent
entry.def: Inexistent; nonexistent; not existing.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + existence
entry.def: Inherence; subsistence.
That which exists within; a constituent.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + existence: cf. F. inexistence
entry.def: Lack of being or existence.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + existent: cf. F. inexistant
entry.def: Not having being; not existing.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + existent
entry.def: Inherent; innate; indwelling.

entry.ety: L. inexorabilitas: cf. F. inexorabilité
entry.def: The quality of being inexorable, or unyielding to entreaty.

entry.ety: L. inexorabilis: cf. F. inexorable. See In- not, and Exorable Adore
entry.def: Not to be persuaded or moved by entreaty or prayer; firm; determined; unyielding; unchangeable; inflexible; relentless; -- of people and impersonal forces; as, an inexorable prince or tyrant; an inexorable judge; the inexorable advance of a glacier.
entry.q: Inexorableequality of laws.
Death'sinexorabledoom.
You are more inhuman, more inexorable, O, ten times more than tigers of Hyrcania.

entry.def: The quality or state of being inexorable.
In an inexorable manner; inflexibly.
entry.q: Inexorablyfirm.

entry.def: Incapable of expansion, enlargement, or extension.
Not to be expected or anticipated.
Not expectant.
Absence of expectation.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + expected: cf. L. inexspectatus
entry.def: Unexpected.
Unexpectedly.
Unexpectedness.
The quality or state of being inexpedient; lack of fitness; unsuitableness to the end or object; impropriety; as, the inexpedience of some measures.
entry.q: It is not the rigor but the inexpediency of laws and acts of authority which makes them tyrannical.

entry.def: Not expedient; not tending to promote a purpose; not tending to the end desired; inadvisable; unfit; improper; unsuitable to time and place; as, what is expedient at one time may be inexpedient at another.
entry.q: If it was not unlawful, yet it was highly inexpedient to use those ceremonies.
entry.syn: Unwise; impolitic; imprudent; indiscreet; unprofitable; inadvisable; disadvantageous.

entry.def: Not expediently; unfitly.
Not expensive; cheap.

entry.ety: L. inexperientia, cf. F. inexpérience. See In- not, and Experience
entry.def: Absence or lack of experience; lack of personal and experimental knowledge; as, the inexperience of youth.
entry.q: Failings which are incident to youth and inexperience.
Prejudice and self-sufficiency naturally proceed from inexperience of the world, and ignorance of mankind.

entry.def: Not having experience; unskilled; naive.
entry.q: Inexperiencedyouth.

entry.ety: L. inexpertus inexperienced: cf. F. inexpert. See In- not, and Expert

sn.def: Destitute of experience or of much experience.
Not expert; not skilled; destitute of knowledge or dexterity derived from practice.

entry.def: Lack of expertness or skill.

entry.ety: L. inexpiabilis: cf. F. inexpiable. See In- not, and Expiable

sn.def: Admitting of no expiation, atonement, or satisfaction; as, an inexpiable crime or offense.
Incapable of being mollified or appeased; relentless; implacable.
sn.q: Inexpiablehate.
They are at inexpiable war with all establishments.

entry.def: Quality of being inexpiable.
In an inexpiable manner of degree; to a degree that admits of no atonement.

entry.ety: L. inexpiatus. See In- not, and Expiate
entry.def: Not appeased or placated.
entry.q: To rest inexpiate were much too rude a part.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + explainable; cf. L. inexplanabilis
entry.def: Incapable of being explained; inexplicable.

entry.ety: Cf. L. inexplebilis; pref. in- not + explere to fill up. See Expletion
entry.def: Insatiably.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inexplicabilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being inexplicable.

entry.ety: L. inexplicabilis: cf. F. inexplicable. See In- not, and Explicable
entry.def: Not explicable; not explainable; incapable of being explained, interpreted, or accounted for; as, an inexplicable mystery.
entry.q: Aninexplicablescratching.
Their reason is disturbed; their views become vast and perplexed, to others inexplicable, to themselves uncertain.

entry.def: A state of being inexplicable; inexplicability.
In an inexplicable manner.

entry.ety: L. inexplicitus: cf. F. inexplicite. See In- not, and Explicit
entry.def: Not explicit; not clearly stated; indefinite; vague.
Incapable of being explored, searched out, or discovered.
Not explosive.
A state of not being exposed.
Not capable of expression or utterance in language; ineffable; unspeakable; indescribable; unutterable; as, inexpressible grief or pleasure.
entry.q: Inexpressiblegrandeur.
In orbs Of circuit inexpressible they stood.

entry.def: Breeches; trousers; ; underwear generally, especially women's; -- now usually referred to as unmentionables.
In an inexpressible manner or degree; unspeakably; unutterably.

sn.def: Inexpressible.
Without expression or meaning; not expressive; dull; unintelligent; as, an inexpressive countenance.

entry.def: The state or quality of being inexpressive.

entry.ety: L. inexpugnabilis: cf. F. inexpugnable. See In- not, and Expugnable
entry.def: Incapable of being subdued by force; impregnable; unconquerable.
entry.q: A fortress, inexpugnable by the arts of war.

entry.def: So as to be inexpugnable; in an inexpugnable manner.

entry.ety: L. inexsuperabilis; pref. in- not + exsuperabilis that may be surmounted. See In- not, Ex-, and Superable
entry.def: Not capable of being passed over; insuperable; insurmountable.
Not extended.
Not capable of being extended; not elastic; as, inextensible fibers.
Lack of extension; unextended state.

entry.ety: L. inexterminabilis. See In- not, and Exterminate
entry.def: Incapable of extermination.

entry.ety: L. inextinctus inexstinctus. See Extinct
entry.def: Not quenched; not extinct.

entry.ety: L. inexstinguibilis: cf. F, inextinguible. See Inextinct
entry.def: Inextinguishable.
Not capable of being extinguished; extinguishable; unquenchable; as, inextinguishable flame, light, thirst, desire, feuds.
entry.q: Inextinguishablerage.

entry.def: So as not to be extinguished; in an inextinguishable manner.

entry.ety: L. inexstirpabilis: cf. F. inextirpable. See In- not, and Extirpate
entry.def: Not capable of being extirpated or rooted out; ineradicable.

entry.ety: L. inextricabilis: cf. F. inextricable. See In- not, and Extricate

sn.def: Incapable of being extricated, untied, or disentangled; hopelessly intricate, confused, or obscure; as, an inextricable knot or difficulty; inextricable confusion.
sn.q: Lost in the wild, inextricable maze.

sn.def: Inevitable.
sn.q: Fateinextricable.

entry.def: The state of being inextricable.
In an inextricable manner.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ineyed; p. pr. & vb. n. Ineyeing
entry.ety: Pref. in- in + eye
entry.def: To ingraft, as a tree or plant, by the insertion of a bud or eye; to inoculate.
entry.q: The arts of grafting and ineying.

entry.def: Not fabricated; unwrought; not artificial; natural.
One who accepts or maintains the dogma of papal infallibility.

cs.cd: the dogma that the pope can not, when acting in his official character of supreme pontiff, err in defining a doctrine of Christian faith or rule of morals, to be held by the church. This was decreed by the Ecumenical Council at the Vatican, July 18, 1870.

entry.ety: Cf. F. infaillibilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being infallible, or exempt from error; inerrability.
entry.q: Infallibility is the highest perfection of the knowing faculty.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + fallible: cf. F. infallible

sn.def: Not fallible; not capable of erring; entirely exempt from liability to mistake; unerring; inerrable.
Not liable to fail, deceive, or disappoint; indubitable; sure; certain; as, infallible evidence; infallible success; an infallible remedy.
sn.q: To whom also he showed himself alive, after his passion, by many infallible proofs.

sn.def: Incapable of error in defining doctrines touching faith or morals. See Papal infallibility, under Infallibility.

entry.def: The state or quality of being infallible; infallibility.
In an infallible manner; certainly; unfailingly; unerringly.

entry.ety: L. infamare, fr. infamis infamous: cf. F. infamer, It. infamare. See Infamous
entry.def: To defame; to make infamous.
entry.q: Livia is infamed for the poisoning of her husband.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Infamized; p. pr. & vb. n. Infamizing
entry.def: To make infamous; to defame.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + famous: cf. L. infamis. See Infamy

sn.def: Of very bad report; having a reputation of the worst kind; held in abhorrence; guilty of something that exposes to infamy; base; notoriously vile; detestable; as, an infamous traitor; an infamous perjurer.
sn.q: False errant knight, infamous, and forsworn.

sn.def: Causing or producing infamy; deserving detestation; scandalous to the last degree; as, an infamous act; infamous vices; infamous corruption.
Branded with infamy by conviction of a crime; as, at common law, an infamous person can not be a witness.
Having a bad name as being the place where an odious crime was committed, or as being associated with something detestable; hence, unlucky; perilous; dangerous.
sn.q: Infamouswoods.
Infamous hills, and sandy perilous wilds.
The piny shade More infamous by cursed Lycaon made.
sn.syn: Detestable; odious; scandalous; disgraceful; base; vile; shameful; ignominious.

entry.def: In an infamous manner or degree; scandalously; disgracefully; shamefully.
entry.q: The sealed fountain of royal bounty which had been infamously monopolized and huckstered.

entry.def: The state or quality of being infamous; infamy.

entries.entry:
In"fa*my n.; pl.Infamies #. L. infamia, fr. infamis infamous; pref. in- not + fama fame: cf. F. infamie. See Fame
Total loss of reputation; public disgrace; dishonor; ignominy; indignity. The afflicted queen would not yield, and said she would not . . . submit to such infamy.
A quality which exposes to disgrace; extreme baseness or vileness; as, the infamy of an action.
Law That loss of character, or public disgrace, which a convict incurs, and by which he is at common law rendered incompetent as a witness. Yesterday, Dec. 7, 1941 -- a day which will live in infamy, . . .

entry.ety: L. infantia: cf. F. enfance. See Infant

sn.def: The state or period of being an infant; the first part of life; early childhood.
sn.q: The babe yet lies in smiling infancy.
Their love in early infancy began.

sn.def: The first age of anything; the beginning or early period of existence; as, the infancy of an art.
sn.q: The infancy and the grandeur of Rome.

sn.def: The state or condition of one under age, or under the age of twenty-one years; nonage; minority.

entry.ety: L. infandus; pref. in- not + fari to speak
entry.def: Too odious to be expressed or mentioned.

entry.ety: AS. in-fangen-þeóf; in in, into + fangen taken (p. p. of fōn to take) + þeóf thief
entry.def: The privilege granted to lords of certain manors to judge thieves taken within the seigniory of such lords.

entry.note: ☞ An infant under seven years of age is not penally responsible; between seven and fourteen years of age, he may be convicted of a malicious offense if malice be proved. He becomes of age on the day preceding his twenty-first birthday, previous to which time an infant has no capacity to contract.
entry.ety: L. infans; pref. in- not + fari to speak: cf. F. enfant, whence OE. enfaunt. See Fame, and cf. Infante Infanta

sn.def: A child in the first period of life, beginning at his birth; a young babe; sometimes, a child several years of age.
sn.q: And tender cries of infants pierce the ear.

sn.def: A person who is not of full age, or who has not attained the age of legal capacity; a person under the age of twenty-one years; a minor.
Same as Infante.
Of or pertaining to infancy, or the first period of life; tender; not mature; as, infant strength.
Intended for young children; as, an infant school.

entry.ety: Cf. F. enfanter
entry.def: To bear or bring forth, as a child; hence, to produce, in general.
entry.q: This worthy motto, “No bishop, no king,” is . . . infanted out of the same fears.

entry.ety: Sp. & Pg., fem. of infante. See Infante
entry.def: A title borne by every one of the daughters of the kings of Spain and Portugal, except the eldest.

entry.ety: Sp. & Pg. See Infant
entry.def: A title given to every one of sons of the kings of Spain and Portugal, except the eldest or heir apparent.
Infancy.
Of or pertaining to infanticide; engaged in, or guilty of, child murder.

entry.ety: L. infanticidium child murder; infans -antis, child + caedere to kill: cf. F. infanticide. See Infant, and Homicide
entry.def: The murder of an infant born alive; the murder or killing of a newly born or young child; child murder.

entry.ety: L. infanticida: cf. F. infanticide
entry.def: One who commits the crime of infanticide; one who kills an infant.

entry.ety: L. infantilis: cf. F. infantile. See Infant
entry.def: Of or pertaining to infancy, or to an infant; similar to, or characteristic of, an infant; childish; as, infantile behavior.

entries.entry: In"fan*tile pa*ral"y*sis. Med An acute viral disease, affecting almost exclusively infants and young adults, characterized by inflammation of the anterior horns of the gray substance of the spinal cord. It is attended with febrile symptoms, motor paralysis, and muscular atrophy, often producing permanent deformities. Called also acute anterior poliomyelitis poliomyelitis and polio. It is caused by any one of three polioviruses, and by the end of the twentieth century had been almost completely eradicated in developed countries by a widespread campaign of immunization.

entry.ety: Cf. F. enfantin
entry.def: Infantile; childish.
entry.q: A degree of credulity next infantine.

entry.def: Like an infant.
Like an infant.

entry.ety: F. infanterie, It. infanteria, fr. infante infant, child, boy servant, foot soldier, fr. L. infans -antis, child; foot soldiers being formerly the servants and followers of knights. See Infant

sn.def: A body of children.
A body of soldiers serving on foot; foot soldiers, in distinction from cavalry.

entry.ety: L. infarcire: pref. in- in + farcire fartum and farctum, to stuff, cram
entry.def: To stuff; to swell.
entry.q: The body is infarced with . . . watery humors.

entry.ety: See Infarce

sn.def: An obstruction or embolus in one of the blood vessels.
The morbid condition of a limited area resulting from such obstruction; also, the localized necrotic (dead) tissue resulting from such obstruction; as, a hemorrhagic infarct .

entry.ety: See Infarce

sn.def: The act of stuffing or filling;
the formation of an infarct; an overloading and obstruction of any organ or vessel of the body; constipation.
An infarct{2}; as, a cardiac infarction .

entry.ety: AS. infær entrance
entry.def: A house-warming; especially, a reception, party, or entertainment given by a newly married couple, or by the husband upon receiving the wife to his house.
Unfashionable.

entry.ety: L. infatigabilis: cf. F. infatigable
entry.def: Indefatigable.

entry.ety: L. infatuatus, p. p. of infatuare to infatuate; pref. in- in + fatuus foolish. See Fatuous
entry.def: Infatuated.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Infatuated; p. pr. & vb. n. Infatuating

sn.def: To make foolish; to affect with folly; to weaken the intellectual powers of, or to deprive of sound judgment.
sn.q: The judgment of God will be very visible in infatuating a people . . . ripe and prepared for destruction.

sn.def: To inspire with a foolish and extravagant passion; as, to be infatuated with gaming.
sn.q: The people are . . . infatuated with the notion.

entry.def: Overcome by some foolish passion or desire; affected by infatuation.

entry.ety: LL. infatuatio: cf. F. infatuation
entry.def: The act of infatuating; the state of being infatuated; folly; that which infatuates.
entry.q: The infatuations of the sensual and frivolous part of mankind are amazing; but the infatuations of the learned and sophistical are incomparably more so.
Such is the infatuation of self-love.

entry.ety: L. infaustus; pref. in- not + faustus fortunate, lucky
entry.def: Not favorable; unlucky; unpropitious; sinister.
The act of making unlucky; misfortune; bad luck.
The state of being infeasible; impracticability.
Not capable of being done or accomplished; impracticable.
The state of quality of being infeasible; infeasibility.

entry.ety: L. infectus: cf. F. infect. See Infect v. t.
entry.def: Infected. Cf. Enfect.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Infected; p. pr. & vb. n. Infecting
entry.ety: L. infectus, p. p. of inficere to put or dip into, to stain, infect; pref. in- in + facere to make; cf. F. infecter. See Fact

sn.def: To taint with morbid matter or any pestilential or noxious substance or effluvium by which disease is produced; as, to infect a lancet; to infect an apartment.
To affect with infectious disease; to communicate infection to; as, infected with the plague.
sn.q: Them that were left alive being infected with this disease.

sn.def: To communicate to or affect with, as qualities or emotions, esp. bad qualities; to corrupt; to contaminate; to taint by the communication of anything noxious or pernicious.
sn.q: Infected Ston's daughters with like heat.

sn.def: To contaminate with illegality or to expose to penalty.
sn.syn: To poison; vitiate; pollute; defile.

entry.def: One who, or that which, infects.
Capable of being infected.

entry.usage: Infection is often used in a definite and limited sense of the transmission of affections without direct contact of individuals or immediate application or introduction of the morbific agent, in contradistinction to contagion, which then implies transmission by direct contact. Quain. See Contagious.
entry.ety: Cf. F. infection, L. infectio a dyeing

sn.def: The act or process of infecting.
sn.q: There was a strict order against coming to those pits, and that was only to prevent infection.

sn.def: That which infects, or causes the communicated disease; any effluvium, miasm, or pestilential matter by which an infectious disease is caused.
sn.q: And that which was still worse, they that did thus break out spread the infection further by their wandering about with the distemper upon them.

sn.def: The state of being infected; the condition of suffering from an infectious disease; contamination by morbific particles; the result of infecting influence; a prevailing disease; epidemic.
sn.q: The danger was really very great, the infection being so very violent in London.

sn.def: That which taints or corrupts morally; as, the infection of vicious principles.
sn.q: It was her chance to light Amidst the gross infections of those times.

sn.def: Contamination by illegality, as in cases of contraband goods; implication.
Sympathetic communication of like qualities or emotions; influence.
sn.q: Through all her train the soft infection ran.
Mankind are gay or serious by infection.

sn.def: A localized area of tissue which is inflamed by growth of microorganisms; as, he has an infection in his finger.
sn.syn: Infection Contagion.

entry.ety: Cf. F. infectieux

sn.def: Having qualities that may infect; communicable or caused by infection; pestilential; epidemic; as, an infectious fever; infectious clothing; infectious water; infectious vices.
sn.q: Where the infectious pestilence.

sn.def: Corrupting, or tending to corrupt or contaminate; vitiating; demoralizing.
sn.q: It [the court] is necessary for the polishing of manners . . . but it is infectious even to the best morals to live always in it.

sn.def: Contaminating with illegality; exposing to seizure and forfeiture.
sn.q: Contraband articles are said to be of an infectious nature.

sn.def: Capable of being easily diffused or spread; sympathetic; readily communicated; as, infectious mirth.
sn.q: The laughter was so genuine as to be infectious.
sn.syn: See Contagious.

entries.entry: In*fec"tious dis*ease". Any disease caused by the entrance, growth, and multiplication of microorganisms in the body; a germ disease. It may not be contagious. Sometimes, as distinguished from contagious disease, such a disease communicated by germs carried in the air or water, and thus spread without contact with the patient, as measles.

entry.def: In an infectious manner.
The quality of being infectious.

entry.ety: L. infectivus pertaining to dyeing
entry.def: Infectious.
entry.q: True love . . . hath an infective power.

entry.ety: L. infecundus: cf. F. infécond. See In- not, and Fecund
entry.def: Unfruitful; not producing young; barren; infertile.

entry.ety: L. infecunditas: cf. F. infécondité
entry.def: Lack of fecundity or fruitfulness; barrenness; sterility; unproductiveness.

entry.ety: See Infecund
entry.def: Infertile; barren; unprofitable; unproductive.
See Enfeeble.

Not felicitous; unhappy; unfortunate; not fortunate or appropriate in application; not well said, expressed, or done; as, an infelicitous condition; an infelicitous remark; an infelicitous description; infelicitous words.

entries.entry:
In`fe*lic"i*ty n.; pl.Infelicities #. L. infelicitas: cf. F. infélicité. See In- not, and Felicity
The state or quality of being infelicitous; unhappiness; misery; wretchedness; misfortune; lack of suitableness or appropriateness. Whatever is the ignorance and infelicity of the present state, we were made wise and happy.
That (as an act, word, expression, etc.) which is infelicitous; as, infelicities of speech.

entry.def: Not felonious, malignant, or criminal.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + felt
entry.def: Felt inwardly; heartfelt.
entry.q: The baron stood afar off, or knelt in submissive, acknowledged, infelt inferiority.

entry.def: See Infeudation.
See Enfeoff.
See Enfeoffment.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inferred; p. pr. & vb. n. Inferring
entry.ety: L. inferre to bring into, bring forward, occasion, infer; pref. in- in + ferre to carry, bring: cf. F. inférer. See 1 st Bear

sn.def: To bring on; to induce; to occasion.
To offer, as violence.
To bring forward, or employ as an argument; to adduce; to allege; to offer.
sn.q: Full well hath Clifford played the orator,Inferring arguments of mighty force.

sn.def: To derive by deduction or by induction; to conclude or surmise from facts or premises; to accept or derive, as a consequence, conclusion, or probability; as, I inferred his determination from his silence.
sn.q: To infer is nothing but by virtue of one proposition laid down as true, to draw in another as true.
Such opportunities always infer obligations.

sn.def: To show; to manifest; to prove.
sn.q: The first part is not the proof of the second, but rather contrariwise, the second inferreth well the first.
This doth infer the zeal I had to see him.

entry.def: Capable of being inferred or deduced from premises.
entry.q: A sufficient argument . . . is inferable from these premises.

entry.usage: Inference Conclusion. An inference is literally that which is brought in; and hence, a deduction or induction from premises, -- something which follows as certainly or probably true. A conclusion is stronger than an inference; it shuts us up to the result, and terminates inquiry. We infer what is particular or probable; we conclude what is certain. In a chain of reasoning we have many inferences, which lead to the ultimate conclusion. “An inference is a proposition which is perceived to be true, because of its connection with some known fact.” “When something is simply affirmed to be true, it is called a proposition; after it has been found to be true by several reasons or arguments, it is called a conclusion.” I. Taylor.
entry.ety: From Infer

sn.def: The act or process of inferring by deduction or induction.
sn.q: Though it may chance to be right in the conclusions, it is yet unjust and mistaken in the method of inference.

sn.def: That which inferred; a truth or proposition drawn from another which is admitted or supposed to be true; a conclusion; a deduction.
sn.q: These inferences, or conclusions, are the effects of reasoning, and the three propositions, taken all together, are called syllogism, or argument.
sn.syn: Conclusion; deduction; consequence.

entry.def: Deduced or deducible by inference.
entry.q: Inferentialproofs.

entry.def: By way of inference; using inference.

entry.ety: L., fr. inferus underneath
entry.def: Sacrifices offered to the souls of deceased heroes or friends.

cs.cd: a court subject to the jurisdiction of another court known as the superior court, or higher court.
a small letter or figure standing at the bottom of the line (opposed to superior letter or figure), as in A2, Bn, 2 and n are inferior characters.
the tide corresponding to the moon's transit of the meridian, when below the horizon.

entry.ety: L., compar. of inferus that is below, underneath, the lower; akin to E. under: cf. F. inférieur. See Under

sn.def: Lower in place, rank, value, excellence, etc.; less important or valuable; subordinate; underneath; beneath.
sn.q: A thousand inferior and particular propositions.
The body, or, as some love to call it, our inferior nature.
Whether they are equal or inferior to my other poems, an author is the most improper judge.

sn.def: Poor or mediocre; as, an inferior quality of goods.

sd.def: Nearer the sun than the earth is; as, the inferior or interior planets; an inferior conjunction of Mercury or Venus.
Below the horizon; as, the inferior part of a meridian.
Situated below some other organ; -- said of a calyx when free from the ovary, and therefore below it, or of an ovary with an adherent and therefore inferior calyx.
On the side of a flower which is next the bract; anterior.

sn.def: Junior or subordinate in rank; as, an inferior officer.

entry.def: A person lower in station, rank, intellect, etc., than another.
entry.q: A great person gets more by obliging his inferior than by disdaining him.

entry.ety: Cf. F. infériorité
entry.def: The state of being inferior; a lower state or condition; as, inferiority of rank, of talents, of age, of worth.
entry.q: A deep sense of our own great inferiority.

entry.def: In an inferior manner, or on the inferior part.

cs.cd: a machine or apparatus maliciously designed to explode, and destroy life or property.
lapis infernalis), lunar caustic; formerly so called. The name was also applied to caustic potash.

entry.ety: F. infernal, L. infernalis, fr. infernus that which lies beneath, the lower. See Inferior

sn.def: Of or pertaining to or suitable for the lower regions, inhabited, according to the ancients, by the dead; pertaining to Pluto's realm of the dead, the Tartarus of the ancients.
sn.q: The Elysian fields, the infernal monarchy.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to, resembling, or inhabiting, hell; suitable for hell, or to the character of the inhabitants of hell; hellish; diabolical; as, infernal spirits, or conduct.
sn.q: The instruments or abettors in such infernal dealings.
sn.syn: Tartarean; Stygian; hellish; devilish; diabolical; satanic; fiendish; malicious.

entry.def: An inhabitant of the infernal regions; also, the place itself.
In an infernal manner; diabolically.
entry.q: Infernallyfalse.

entry.ety: It. See Infernal

sn.def: The infernal regions; hell.
A raging fire.
sn.q: At each sudden explosion in the inferno below they sprang back from the brink [of the volcanic crater].

entry.def: One of the Inferobranchiata.

entry.ety: NL. See Inferobranchiate
entry.def: A suborder of marine gastropod mollusks, in which the gills are between the foot and the mantle.

entry.ety: L. inferus lower + E. branchiate
entry.def: Having the gills on the sides of the body, under the margin of the mantle; belonging to the Inferobranchiata.
Inferable.

entry.ety: L. infertilis: cf. F. infertile. See In- not, and Fertile
entry.def: Not fertile; not productive; barren; sterile; unable to propagate its kind; as, an infertile soil; an infertile hybrid; -- of living things and of soil or land.
In an infertile manner.

entry.ety: L. infertilitas: cf. F. infertilité
entry.def: The state or quality of being infertile; unproductiveness; barrenness.
entry.q: The infertility or noxiousness of the soil.

entry.ety: L. infestus. See Infest v. t.
entry.def: Mischievous; hurtful; harassing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Infested; p. pr. & vb. n. Infesting
entry.ety: L. infestare, fr. infestus disturbed, hostile, troublesome; in in, against + the root of defendere: cf. F. infester. See Defend
entry.def: To trouble greatly by numbers or by frequency of presence; to disturb; to annoy; to frequent and molest or harass; as, fleas infest dogs and cats; a sea infested with pirates.
entry.q: To poison vermin that infest his plants.
These, said the genius, are envy, avarice, superstition, love, with the like cares and passions that infest human life.
And the cares, that infest the day, Shall fold their tents, like the Arabs, And as silently steal away.

entry.ety: L. infestatio: cf. F. infestation
entry.def: The act of infesting or state of being infested; molestation; vexation; annoyance.
entry.q: Free from the infestation of enemies.

entry.def: One who, or that which, infests.

entry.ety: L. infestivus. See In- not, and Festive
entry.def: Having no mirth; not festive or merry; dull; cheerless; gloomy; forlorn.
Lack of festivity, cheerfulness, or mirth; dullness; cheerlessness.

entry.ety: L. infestus. See Infest a.
entry.def: Mischievous; harmful; dangerous.
entry.q: Infestuousas serpents.

entry.ety: LL. infeudatio, fr. infeudare to enfeoff: cf. F. inféodation. See Feud a fief

sn.def: The act of putting one in possession of an estate in fee.
The granting of tithes to laymen.

entry.ety: L. infibulare infibulatum, to clasp, buckle, or button together; pref. in- in + fibula clasp, buckle: cf. F. infibulation

sn.def: The act of clasping, or fastening, as with a buckle or padlock.
The act of attaching a ring, clasp, or frame, to the genital organs in such a manner as to prevent copulation.

entry.ety: L. infidelis; pref. in- not + fidelis faithful, fr. fides faith: cf. F. infidèle. See Fidelity
entry.def: Not holding the faith; -- applied by Christians to one who does not believe in the inspiration of the Scriptures, and the supernatural origin of Christianity; used by Mohammedans to refer to those who do not believe in Islam.
entry.q: The infidel writer is a great enemy to society.

entry.note: ☞ Infidel is used by English writers to translate the equivalent word used Mohammedans in speaking of Christians and other disbelievers in Mohammedanism.
entry.usage: An infidel, in common usage, is one who denies Christianity and the truth of the Scriptures. Some have endeavored to widen the sense of infidel so as to embrace atheism and every form of unbelief; but this use does not generally prevail. A freethinker is now only another name for an infidel. An unbeliever is not necessarily a disbeliever or infidel, because he may still be inquiring after evidence to satisfy his mind; the word, however, is more commonly used in the extreme sense. A deist believes in one God and a divine providence, but rejects revelation. An atheist denies the being of God. A sceptic is one whose faith in the credibility of evidence is weakened or destroyed, so that religion, to the same extent, has no practical hold on his mind. An agnostic remains in a state of suspended judgment, neither affirming nor denying the existence of a personal Deity.
entry.def: One who does not believe in the prevailing religious faith; a heathen; a freethinker; -- used especially by Christians and Mohammedans.
entry.syn: Infidel Unbeliever Freethinker Deist Atheist Sceptic Agnostic.

entries.entry:
In`fi*del"i*ty n.; pl.Infidelities. L. infidelitas: cf. F. infidélité
Lack of faith or belief in some religious system; especially, a lack of faith in, or disbelief of, the inspiration of the Scriptures, of the divine origin of Christianity. There is, indeed, no doubt but that vanity is one of the principal causes of infidelity.
Unfaithfulness to the marriage vow or contract; violation of the marriage covenant by adultery.
Breach of trust; unfaithfulness to a charge, or to moral obligation; treachery; deceit; as, the infidelity of a servant. Theinfidelityof friends.

entry.def: To inclose, as a field.

sn.def: Arable and manured land kept continually under crop; -- distinguished from outfield.
The diamond; -- opposed to outfield. See Diamond n., 5.
fighting, such as boxing, at close quarters.
rough-and-tumble, free-for-all fighting.

entry.def: To arrange in a file or rank; to place in order.
To cover with a film; to coat thinly; as, to infilm one metal with another in the process of gilding; to infilm the glass of a mirror.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Infiltered; p. pr. & vb. n. Infiltering
entry.ety: Cf. Infiltrate
entry.def: To filter or sift in.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Infiltrated; p. pr. & vb. n. Infiltrating
entry.ety: Pref. in- + filtrate: cf. F, s'infiltrer. Cf. Infilter

sn.def: To enter by penetrating the pores or interstices of a substance; to filter into or through something.
sn.q: The water infiltrates through the porous rock.

sn.def: To enter secretly (into an organization, territory, etc.) for hostile purposes, such as spying or sabotage; as, the FBI infiltrated into the U. S. communist party's upper echelons; also used transitively; as, to infiltrate the opponent's organization; to infiltrate one's agents into a hostile country.

entry.def: To penetrate gradually; -- sometimes used reflexively.

entry.cs: Fatty infiltration. Med See under Fatty. Infiltration gallery a filter gallery.
entry.ety: Cf. F. infiltration

sn.def: The act or process of infiltrating, as of water into a porous substance, of a fluid into the cells of an organ or part of the body, or of persons into a hostile organization.
The substance which has entered the pores or cavities of a body.
sn.q: Calcareous infiltrations filling the cavities.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to infiltration.

entry.ety: L. infinitus: cf. F. infini. See In- not, and Finite

sn.def: Unlimited or boundless, in time or space; as, infinite duration or distance.
sn.q: Whatever is finite, as finite, will admit of no comparative relation with infinity; for whatever is less than infinite is still infinitely distant from infinity; and lower than infinite distance the lowest or least can not sink.

sn.def: Without limit in power, capacity, knowledge, or excellence; boundless; immeasurably or inconceivably great; perfect; as, the infinite wisdom and goodness of God; -- opposed to finite.
sn.q: Great is our Lord, and of great power; his understanding is infinite.
O God, how infinite thou art!

sn.def: Indefinitely large or extensive; great; vast; immense; gigantic; prodigious.
sn.q: Infinite riches in a little room.
Which infinite calamity shall cause To human life.

sn.def: Greater than any assignable quantity of the same kind; -- said of certain quantities.

Capable of endless repetition; -- said of certain forms of the canon, called also perpetual fugues, so constructed that their ends lead to their beginnings, and the performance may be incessantly repeated.
sn.syn: Boundless; immeasurable; illimitable; interminable; limitless; unlimited; endless; eternal.

sn.def: That which is infinite; boundless space or duration; infinity; boundlessness.
sn.q: Not till the weight is heaved from off the air, and the thunders roll down the horizon, will the serene light of God flow upon us, and the blue infinite embrace us again.

sn.def: An infinite quantity or magnitude.
An infinity; an incalculable or very great number.
sn.q: Glittering chains, embroidered richly o'er With infinite of pearls and finest gold.

sn.def: The Infinite Being; God; the Almighty.

entry.note: ☞ An infinite loop is rarely written intentionally except in cases where the loop is intended merely as a waiting sequence, to be interrupted by some action of the user. It is more commonly the result of a serious logical error on the part of the programmer, resulting in a failure of the program. Its execution can be halted only by halting execution of the program, e.g. by intervention of the operating system or by halting or resetting the computer. In single-user systems, when executing an infinite loop, the computer will appear to halt operation of the program, and the program will be unresponsive to normal keyboard input, though it may be interrupted by an unmasked interrupt.

sn.def: a series of instructions in a computer program which, when executed, cause a cyclic repetition of the same instructions, with no other action by the program, for as long as the program continues to be executed, or the loop is interrupted by some external action.
Without bounds or limits; beyond or below assignable limits; as, an infinitely large or infinitely small quantity.
Very; exceedingly; vastly; highly; extremely.
sn.q: Infinitelypleased.

entry.def: The state or quality of being infinite; infinity; greatness; immensity.
A causal relationship transmitted through an indefinite number of terms in a series, with no term that begins the causal chain.

cs.cd: the different and the integral calculus, when developed according to the method used by Leibnitz, who regarded the increments given to variables as infinitesimal.

entry.ety: Cf. F. infinitésimal, fr. infinitésime infinitely small, fr. L. infinitus. See Infinite a.
entry.def: Infinitely or indefinitely small; less than any assignable quantity or value; very small.
An infinitely small quantity; that which is less than any assignable quantity.
By infinitesimals; in infinitely small quantities; in an infinitesimal degree.
Pertaining to the infinite mood.
entry.q: Infinitivalstems.

cs.cd: that form of the verb which merely names the action, and performs the office of a verbal noun. Some grammarians make two forms in English: (a) The simple form, as, speak go hear, before which to is commonly placed, as, to speak; to go; to hear. (b) The form of the imperfect participle, called the infinitive in -ing; as, going is as easy as standing.

entry.note: With the auxiliary verbs may can must might could would, and should, the simple infinitive is expressed without to; as, you may speak; they must hear, etc. The infinitive usually omits to with the verbs let dare do bid make see hear need, etc.; as, let me go; you dare not tell; make him work; hear him talk, etc.

☞ In Anglo-Saxon, the simple infinitive was not preceded by tothe sign of modern simple infinitive), but it had a dative form (sometimes called the gerundial infinitive) which was preceded by to, and was chiefly employed in expressing purpose. See Gerund, 2.
The gerundial ending (-anne) not only took the same form as the simple infinitive (-an), but it was confounded with the present participle in -ende, or -indelater -inge).
entry.ety: L. infinitivus: cf. F. infinitif. See Infinite
entry.def: Unlimited; not bounded or restricted; undefined.
An infinitive form of the verb; a verb in the infinitive mood; the infinitive mood.
In the manner of an infinitive mood.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: Infinite; perpetual, as a canon whose end leads back to the beginning. See Infinite a., 5.

sn.def: The quality or state of being infinite, or without limits; infiniteness.
Infinite extent; unlimited space; immensity; infinity.
sn.q: I am who fillinfinitude.
As pleasing to the fancy, as speculations of eternity or infinitude are to the understanding.

sn.def: Boundless number; countless multitude.
sn.q: Aninfinitudeof distinctions.

entry.ety: Cf. Quadruple
entry.def: Multiplied an infinite number of times.

entries.entry:
In*fin"i*ty ☞ Mathematically considered, infinity is always a limit of a variable quantity, resulting from a particular supposition made upon the varying element which enters it.
Circle at infinity an imaginary circle at infinity, through which, in geometry of three dimensions, every sphere is imagined to pass. Circular points at infinity. See under Circular.
n.; pl.Infinities #. L. infinitas; pref. in- not + finis boundary, limit, end: cf. F. infinité. See Finite
Unlimited extent of time, space, or quantity; eternity; boundlessness; immensity. There can not be more infinities than one; for one of them would limit the other.
Unlimited capacity, energy, excellence, or knowledge; as, the infinity of God and his perfections.
Endless or indefinite number; great multitude; as an infinity of beauties.
Math A quantity greater than any assignable quantity of the same kind.
Geom That part of a line, or of a plane, or of space, which is infinitely distant. In modern geometry, parallel lines or planes are sometimes treated as lines or planes meeting at infinity.

entry.ety: L. infirmus: cf. F. infirme. See In- not, and Firm a.

sn.def: Not firm or sound; weak; feeble; as, an infirm body; an infirm constitution.
sn.q: A poor, infirm, weak, and despised old man.

sn.def: Weak of mind or will; irresolute; vacillating.
sn.q: Aninfirmjudgment.
Infirm of purpose!

sn.def: Not solid or stable; insecure; precarious.
sn.q: He who fixes on false principles treads or infirm ground.
sn.syn: Debilitated; sickly; feeble; decrepit; weak; enfeebled; irresolute; vacillating; imbecile.

entry.ety: L. infirmare : cf. F. infirmer
entry.def: To weaken; to enfeeble.
A person dwelling in, or having charge of, an infirmary, esp. in a monastic institution.

entries.entry:
In*firm"a*ry ĭn*fẽrm"ȧ*r� n.; pl.Infirmaries -rĭz. Cf. OE. fermerie, OF. enfermerie, F. infirmerie, LL. infirmaria. See Infirm
A hospital, or place where the infirm or sick are lodged and nursed gratuitously, or where out-patients are treated.

entry.ety: Cf. F. infirmatif
entry.def: Weakening; annulling, or tending to make void.
An infirmary.

entries.entry:
In*firm"i*ty n.; pl.Infirmities #. L. infirmitas : cf. F. infirmite. See Infirm a.
The state of being infirm; feebleness; an imperfection or weakness; esp., an unsound, unhealthy, or debilitated state; a disease; a malady; as, infirmity of body or mind. 'T is the infirmity of his age.
A personal frailty or failing; foible; eccentricity; a weakness or defect. Will you be cured of your infirmity ? A friend should bear his friend's infirmities. The house has also its infirmities. Debility; imbecility; weakness; feebleness; failing; foible; defect; disease; malady. See Debility.

entry.def: In an infirm manner.
Infirmity; feebleness.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Infixed; p. pr. & vb. n. Infixing
entry.ety: L. infixus, p. p of infigere to infix; pref. in- in + figere to fix: cf. F. infixer. See Fix

sn.def: To set; to fasten or fix by piercing or thrusting in; as, to infix a sting, spear, or dart.
sn.q: The fatal dart a ready passage found, And deep within her heart infixed the wound.

sn.def: To implant or fix; to instill; to inculcate, as principles, thoughts, or instructions; as, to infix good principles in the mind, or ideas in the memory.
Something infixed.
An element that is inserted into the body of an elemt which it threby modifies, as a letter within a word.

entry.def: A notation for commands or instructions in which the operator is inserted between the terms on which it operates. Contrasted with prefix notation and postfix notation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inflamed; p. pr. & vb. n. Inflaming
entry.ety: OE. enflamen, OF. enflamer, F. enflammer, L. inflammare inflammatum; pref. in- in + flammare to flame, fr. flamma flame. See Flame

sn.def: To set on fire; to kindle; to cause to burn, flame, or glow.
sn.q: We should have made retreat By light of the inflamed fleet.

sn.def: Fig.: To kindle or intensify, as passion or appetite; to excite to an excessive or unnatural action or heat; as, to inflame desire.
sn.q: Though more, it seems,Inflamed with lust than rage.
But, O inflame and fire our hearts.

sn.def: To provoke to anger or rage; to exasperate; to irritate; to incense; to enrage.
sn.q: It will inflame you; it will make you mad.

sn.def: To put in a state of inflammation; to produce morbid heat, congestion, or swelling, of; as, to inflame the eyes by overwork.
To exaggerate; to enlarge upon.
sn.q: A friend exaggerates a man's virtues, an enemy inflames his crimes.
sn.syn: To provoke; fire; kindle; irritate; exasperate; incense; enrage; anger; excite; arouse.

entry.def: To grow morbidly hot, congested, or painful; to become angry or incensed.

sn.def: Set on fire; enkindled; heated; congested; provoked; exasperated.
Represented as burning, or as adorned with tongues of flame.
Having an inflammation in; -- of tissues; as, an inflamed appendix.

entry.def: The person or thing that inflames.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inflammabilite
entry.def: Susceptibility of taking fire readily; the state or quality of being inflammable.

cs.cd: the old chemical name for hydrogen.

entry.ety: CF. F. inflammable

sn.def: Capable of being easily set fire; easily enkindled; combustible; as, inflammable oils or spirits.
Excitable; irritable; irascible; easily provoked; as, an inflammable temper.

entry.def: The quality or state of being inflammable; inflammability.
In an inflammable manner.

entry.ety: L. inflammatio: cf. F. inflammation. See Inflame

sn.def: The act of inflaming, kindling, or setting on fire; also, the state of being inflamed.
sn.q: Theinflammationof fat.

sn.def: A morbid condition of any part of the body, consisting in congestion of the blood vessels, with obstruction of the blood current, and growth of morbid tissue. It is manifested outwardly by redness and swelling, attended with tenderness, heat and pain. It may be caused by exposure to any number of injurious agents.
Violent excitement; heat; passion; animosity; turbulence; as, an inflammation of the mind, of the body politic, or of parties.

entry.def: Inflammatory.

entry.cs: Inflammatory crust. Med Same as Buffy coat, under Buffy. Inflammatory fever a variety of fever due to inflammation.
entry.ety: Cf. F. inflammatoire

sn.def: Tending to inflame, kindle, or irritate.
Tending to excite anger, animosity, tumult, or sedition; seditious; as, inflammatory libels, writings, speeches, or publications.
Accompanied with, or tending to cause, preternatural heat and excitement of arterial action; as, an inflammatory disease.

entry.def: That may be inflated.

entry.ety: L. inflatus, p. p. of inflare to inflate; pref. in- in + flare to blow. See Blow to puff wind
entry.def: Blown in; inflated.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inflated; p. pr. & vb. n. Inflating

sn.def: To swell or distend with air or gas; to dilate; to expand; to enlarge; as, to inflate a bladder; to inflate the lungs.
sn.q: When passion's tumults in the bosom rise,Inflate the features, and enrage the eyes.

sn.def: Fig.: To swell; to puff up; to elate; as, to inflate one with pride or vanity.
sn.q: Inflate themselves with some insane delight.

sn.def: To cause to become unduly expanded or increased; as, to inflate the currency.

entry.def: To expand; to fill; to distend.

sn.def: Filled, as with air or gas; blown up; distended; as, a balloon inflated with gas.
Turgid; swelling; puffed up; bombastic; pompous; as, an inflated style.
sn.q: Inflated and astrut with self-conceit.

sn.def: Hollow and distended, as a perianth, corolla, nectary, or pericarp.
Distended or enlarged fictitiously or without due cause; as, inflated prices; inflated expectations, etc.

entry.def: One who, or that which, inflates; as, the inflaters of the stock exchange.
In a manner tending to inflate.

entry.ety: L. inflatio: cf. F. inflation

sn.def: The act or process of inflating, or the state of being inflated, as with air or gas; distention; expansion; enlargement.
The state of being puffed up, as with pride; conceit; vanity.

Persistent expansion or increase in the general level of prices, usually caused by overissue of currency, and resulting in a reduced value of the currency. It is contrasted with deflation, and is when it occurs to a very high degree is called hyperinflation.

entry.def: One who favors an increased or very large issue of paper money.

entry.ety: L. See Inflate v. t.
entry.def: A blowing or breathing into; inflation; inspiration.
entry.q: The divine breath that blows the nostrils out To ineffable inflatus.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inflected; p. pr. & vb. n. Inflecting
entry.ety: L. inflectere inflexum; pref. in- in + flectere to bend. See Flexible, and cf. Inflex

sn.def: To turn from a direct line or course; to bend; to incline, to deflect; to curve; to bow.
sn.q: Are they [the rays of the sun] not reflected, refracted, and inflected by one and the same principle ?

sn.def: To vary, as a noun or a verb in its terminations; to decline, as a noun or adjective, or to conjugate, as a verb.
To modulate, as the voice.

cs.cd: a prolate cycloid. See Cycloid.

sn.def: Bent; turned; deflected.
Having inflections; capable of, or subject to, inflection; inflective.

cs.cd: the point on opposite sides of which a curve bends in contrary ways.

entry.ety: L. inflexio : cf. F. inflexion. See Inflect

sn.def: The act of inflecting, or the state of being inflected.
A bend; a fold; a curve; a turn; a twist.
A slide, modulation, or accent of the voice; as, the rising and the falling inflection .
The variation or change which words undergo to mark case, gender, number, comparison, tense, person, mood, voice, etc.

sd.def: Any change or modification in the pitch or tone of the voice.
A departure from the monotone, or reciting note, in chanting.

sn.def: Same as Diffraction.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to inflection; having, or characterized by, inflection.

cs.cd: a language like the Greek or Latin, consisting largely of stems with variable terminations or suffixes which were once independent words. English is both agglutinative, as, manlike headache, and inflective, as, he his him. Cf. Agglutinative.

sn.def: Capable of, or pertaining to, inflection; deflecting; as, the inflective quality of the air.
Inflectional; characterized by variation, or change in form, to mark case, tense, etc.; subject to inflection.

entry.def: To incarnate.

entry.ety: Cf. Flex Inflect
entry.def: To bend; to cause to become curved; to make crooked; to deflect.

sn.def: Turned; bent.
Bent or turned abruptly inwards, or toward the axis, as the petals of a flower.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inflexibilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being inflexible, or not capable of being bent or changed; unyielding stiffness; inflexibleness; rigidity; firmness of will or purpose; unbending pertinacity; steadfastness; resoluteness; unchangeableness; obstinacy.
entry.q: The inflexibility of mechanism.
That grave inflexibility of soul.
The purity and inflexibility of their faith.

entry.ety: L. inflexiblis: cf. F. inflexible. See In- not, and Flexible

sn.def: Not capable of being bent; stiff; rigid; firm; unyielding.
Firm in will or purpose; not to be turned, changed, or altered; resolute; determined; unyieding; inexorable; stubborn.
sn.q: “Inflexibleas steel.”
A man of upright and inflexible temper . . . can overcome all private fear.

sn.def: Incapable of change; unalterable; immutable.
sn.q: The nature of things is inflexible.
sn.syn: -- Unbending; unyielding; rigid; inexorable; pertinacious; obstinate; stubborn; unrelenting.

entry.def: The quality or state of being inflexible; inflexibility; rigidity; firmness.
In an inflexible manner.
Inflection.

sn.def: Inflective.
sn.q: “Inflexive endings.”

sn.def: Inflexible.
sn.q: Foesinflexive.

entry.def: An inflection; a bend or fold.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inflicted; p. pr. & vb. n. Inflicting
entry.ety: L. inflictus, p. p. of infligere to strike on, to inflict; pref. in- in, on + fligere to strike. Cf. Flail
entry.def: To give, cause, or produce by striking, or as if by striking; to apply forcibly; to lay or impose; to send; to cause to bear, feel, or suffer; as, to inflict blows; to inflict a wound with a dagger; to inflict severe pain by ingratitude; to inflict punishment on an offender; to inflict the penalty of death on a criminal.
entry.q: What heart could wish, what hand inflict, this dire disgrace?
The persecution and the pain That man inflicts on all inferior kinds.

entry.def: One who inflicts.
entry.q: God is the sole and immediate inflicter of such strokes.

entry.ety: L. inflictio: cf. F. infliction

sn.def: The act of inflicting or imposing; as, the infliction of torment, or of punishment.
That which is inflicted or imposed, as punishment, disgrace, calamity, etc.
sn.q: His severest inflictions are in themselves acts of justice and righteousness.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inflictif
entry.def: Causing infliction; acting as an infliction.

cs.cd: determinate inflorescence.
indeterminate inflorescence. See under Determinate, and Indeterminate.

entry.ety: L. inflorescens, p. pr. of inflorescere to begin to blossom; pref. in- in + florescere to begin to blossom: cf. F. inflorescence. See Florescent

sn.def: A flowering; the putting forth and unfolding of blossoms.

sd.def: The mode of flowering, or the general arrangement and disposition of the flowers with reference to the axis, and to each other.
An axis on which all the buds are flower buds.
sd.q: Inflorescence affords an excellent characteristic mark in distinguishing the species of plants.

entry.def: To flow in.
flowing inward.

entry.ety: F. influence, fr. L. influens -entis, p. pr. See Influent, and cf. Influenza

sn.def: A flowing in or upon; influx.
sn.q: God hath his influence into the very essence of all things.

sn.def: Hence, in general, the bringing about of an effect, physical or moral, by a gradual process; controlling power quietly exerted; agency, force, or tendency of any kind which affects, modifies, or sways; as, the influence which the sun exerts on animal and vegetable life; the influence of education on the mind; the influence, according to astrologers, of the stars over affairs.
sn.q: Astrologers call the evil influences of the stars, evil aspects.
Canst thou bind the sweet influences of Pleiades, or loose the bands of Orion?
She said : “Ah, dearest lord! what evil star On you hath frown'd, and poured, his influence bad?”

sn.def: Power or authority arising from elevated station, excelence of character or intellect, wealth, etc.; reputation; acknowledged ascendency; as, he is a man of influence in the community.
sn.q: Such influence hath your excellency.

sn.def: Induction.
sn.syn: Control; persuasion; ascendency; sway; power; authority; supremacy; mastery; management; restraint; character; reputation; prestige.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Influenced ĭn"fl�*�nst; p. pr. & vb. n. Influencing ĭn"fl�*�n*sĭng
entry.def: To control or move by power, physical or moral; to affect by gentle action; to exert an influence upon; to modify, bias, or sway; to affect; to move; to persuade; to induce.
entry.q: These experiments succeed after the same manner in vacuo as in the open air, and therefore are not influenced by the weight or pressure of the atmosphere.
This standing revelation . . . is sufficient to influence their faith and practice, if they attend.
The principle which influenced their obedience has lost its efficacy.

entry.def: One who, or that which, influences.
Tending to influence; influential.

entry.ety: L. influens -entis, p. pr. of influere influxum, to flow in; pref. in- in + fluere to flow. See Fluid

sn.def: Flowing in.
sn.q: Withinfluenttide.
Influentodors.

sn.def: Exerting influence; influential.
sn.q: I find no office by name assigned unto Dr. Cox, who was virtually influent upon all, and most active.

entry.ety: See Influence
entry.def: Exerting or possessing influence or power; potent; efficacious; effective; strong; having authority or ascendency; as, an influential man, station, argument, etc.
entry.q: A very influential Gascon prefix.

entry.def: In an influential manner.

entry.ety: It. influenza influence, an epidemic formerly attributed by astrologers to the influence of the heavenly bodies, influenza. See Influence
entry.def: An epidemic viral infectious disease characterized by acute nasal catarrh, or by inflammation of the throat or the bronchi, and usually accompanied by fever and general weakness; also called grippe. It is caused by several forms of RNA virus which mutate readily and thereby render vaccines prepared against older forms ineffective, often requiring a new form of vaccine for each new outbreak.

entry.ety: L. influxus, fr. influere influxum, to flow in: cf. F. influx. See Influent

sn.def: The act of flowing in; as, an influx of light.
A coming in; infusion; intromission; introduction; importation in abundance; also, that which flows or comes in; as, a great influx of goods into a country, or an influx of gold and silver.
sn.q: The influx of food into the Celtic region, however, was far from keeping pace with the influx of consumers.
The general influx of Greek into modern languages.

sn.def: Influence; power.

entry.ety: L. influxio : cf. F. influxion
entry.def: A flowing in; infusion.
Influential.
Having a tendency to flow in; having influence; influential.
By influxion.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Infolded; p. pr. & vb. n. Infolding
entry.ety: Pref. in- in + fold

sn.def: To wrap up or cover with folds; to envelop; to inwrap; to inclose; to involve.
sn.q: Gilded tombs do worms infold.
Infold his limbs in bands.

sn.def: To clasp with the arms; to embrace.
sn.q: Noble Banquo, . . . let me infold thee, And hold thee to my heart.

entry.def: The act of infolding; the state of being infolded.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + L. folium leaf
entry.def: To cover or overspread with, or as with, leaves.

entry.ety: L. informis; pref. in- not + forma form, shape: cf. F. informe
entry.def: Without regular form; shapeless; ugly; deformed.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Informed; p. pr. & vb. n. Informing
entry.ety: OE. enformen, OF. enformer, F. informer. L. informare; pref. in- in + formare to form, share, fr. forma form. See Form

sn.def: To give form or share to; to give vital or organizing power to; to give life to; to imbue and actuate with vitality; to animate; to mold; to figure; to fashion.
sn.q: TheinformingWord.
Let others better mold the running mass Of metals, and inform the breathing brass.
Breath informs this fleeting frame.
Breathes in our soul, informs our mortal part.

sn.def: To communicate knowledge to; to make known to; to acquaint; to advise; to instruct; to tell; to notify; to enlighten; -- usually followed by of.
sn.q: For he would learn their business secretly, And then inform his master hastily.
I am informed thoroughly of the cause.

sn.def: To communicate a knowledge of facts to, by way of accusation; to warn against anybody.
sn.q: Tertullus . . . informed the governor against Paul.
sn.syn: To acquaint; apprise; tell; teach; instruct; enlighten; animate; fashion.

cs.cd: to communicate facts by way of accusation against; to denounce; as, two persons came to the magistrate, and informed against A.

sn.def: To take form; to become visible or manifest; to appear.

sn.def: To give intelligence or information; to tell.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + formal

sn.def: Not in the regular, usual, or established form; not according to official, conventional, prescribed, or customary forms or rules; irregular; hence, without ceremony; as, an informal writing, proceeding, or visit.

entries.entry:
In`for*mal"i*ty n.; pl.Informalities.
The state of being informal; lack of regular, prescribed, or customary form; as, the informality of legal proceedings.
An informal, unconventional, or unofficial act or proceeding; something which is not in proper or prescribed form or does not conform to the established rule.

entry.def: In an informal manner.

entry.ety: L. informans -antis, p. pr. of informare. See Inform v. t.

sn.def: One who, or that which, informs, animates, or vivifies.
One who imparts information or instruction.
One who offers an accusation; an informer. See Informer.
sn.q: It was the last evidence of the kind; the informant was hanged.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. informatio representation, conception. See Inform v. t.

sn.def: The act of informing, or communicating knowledge or intelligence.
sn.q: The active informations of the intellect.

sn.def: Any fact or set of facts, knowledge, news, or advice, whether communicated by others or obtained by personal study and investigation; any datum that reduces uncertainty about the state of any part of the world; intelligence; knowledge derived from reading, observation, or instruction.
sn.q: Larger opportunities of information.
He should get some information in the subject he intends to handle.

sn.def: A proceeding in the nature of a prosecution for some offense against the government, instituted and prosecuted, really or nominally, by some authorized public officer on behalf of the government. It differs from an indictment in criminal cases chiefly in not being based on the finding of a grand jury. See Indictment.

A measure of the number of possible choices of messages contained in a symbol, signal, transmitted message, or other information-bearing object; it is usually quantified as the negative logarithm of the number of allowed symbols that could be contained in the message; for logarithms to the base 2, the measure corresponds to the unit of information, the hartley, which is log210, or 3.323 bits; called also information content. The smallest unit of information that can be contained or transmitted is the bit, corresponding to a yes-or-no decision.
Useful facts, as contrasted with raw data; as, among all this data, there must be some interesting information .

entry.def: information4}.
The processing of information, especially by computers, including the organization, distribution, and frequently the analysis of data and the presentation of results in easily understood form.

The science which studies the capacity of systems to contain and transmit information{2}, and the factors such as noise and channel capacity that may affect the rate or accuracy of information transmission and reception.
Having power to inform, animate, or vivify.
Full of, or conveying, information; instructive.

entry.cs: Informed stars. See under Unformed.
entry.def: Unformed or ill-formed; deformed; shapeless.

cs.cd: one who habitually gives information of the violation of penal statutes, with a view to a prosecution therefor.

entry.ety: From Inform v.
