sn.def: One who informs, or imparts knowledge or news.
One who informs a magistrate of violations of law; one who informs against another for violation of some law or penal statute.

entry.ety: L. Cf. Inferior

entry.ety: Infra + lapse: cf. F. infralapsaire. See Lapse
entry.def: One of that class of Calvinists who consider the decree of election as contemplating the apostasy as past and the elect as being at the time of election in a fallen and guilty state; -- opposed to Supralapsarian. The former considered the election of grace as a remedy for an existing evil; the latter regarded the fall as a part of God's original purpose in regard to men.
Of or pertaining to the Infralapsarians, or to their doctrine.
The doctrine, belief, or principles of the Infralapsarians.

entry.ety: Infra- + red

sn.def: Lying outside the visible spectrum at its red end; -- said of rays having a longer wavelength (and thus less refrangible) than the extreme red rays, specifically those electromagnetic waves having a wavelength of between 700 nanometers and 1 millimeter.
relating to, using, or producing infrared radiation.
affected by infrared radiation; as, infrared detector; infrared film.

entry.note: Infrared radiation is that electromagnetic radiation lying between the visible spectrum and the longest microwaves. It may be absorbed by matter in a manner specific to the absorbing substance, causing increased vibration of molecules. The infrared absorption spectrum of a chemical compound is often very specific, and the infrared absorption spectrum is therefore used to help identify chemical substances. Infrared radiation is used in certain communication devices, such as television remote controls and communication devices between computers or between computers and peripherals.
entry.ety: Infra- + red
entry.def: electromagnetic radiation having a wavelength of between 700 nanometers and 1 millimeter.

entry.ety: Infra + scapular

sn.def: To hinder; to destroy; as, to infringe efficacy; to infringe delight or power.
To break, violate, or transgress some contract, rule, or law; to injure; to offend.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Infumated; p. pr. & vb. n. Infumating

Dried in smoke; smoked.

‖In`fun*dib"u*lum n.; pl. L. Infundibula #, E. Infundibulums #. L., a funnel, from infundere to pour in or into. See Infuse
Anat A funnel-shaped or dilated organ or part; as, the infundibulum of the brain, a hollow, conical process, connecting the floor of the third ventricle with the pituitary body; the infundibula of the lungs, the enlarged terminations of the bronchial tubes.

The siphon of Cephalopoda. See Cephalopoda.

a feeling of intense anger.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Infused; p. pr. & vb. n. Infusing

sn.def: To inspire; to inspirit or animate; to fill; -- followed by with.

entry.note: ☞ (From 1913 dictionary): They are found in all seas, lakes, ponds, and streams, as well as in infusions of organic matter exposed to the air. They are distinguished by having vibrating lashes or cilia, with which they obtain their food and swim about. They are devided into the orders Flagellata Ciliata, and Tentaculifera. See these words in the Vocabulary. Formely the term Infusoria was applied to all microscopic organisms found in water, including many minute plants, belonging to the diatoms, as well as minute animals belonging to various classes, as the Rotifera, which are worms; and the Rhizopoda, which constitute a distinct class of Protozoa. Fossil Infusoria are mostly the siliceous shells of diatoms; sometimes they are siliceous skeletons of Radiolaria, or the calcareous shells of Foraminifera.
entry.ety: [NL.; -- so called because found in infusions which are left exposed to the air for a time. See Infuse
entry.def: One of the classes of Protozoa, including a large number of species, all of minute size. Formerly, the term was applied to any microbe found in infusions of decaying organic material, but the term is now applied more specifically to one of the classes of the phylum Ciliophora, of ciliated protozoans.

cs.cd: a deposit of fine, usually white, siliceous material, composed mainly of the shells of the microscopic plants called diatoms; also called diatomaceous earth kieselguhr, and diatomite. It is used in polishing powder, and in the manufacture of dynamite.

entry.def: Belonging to the Infusoria; composed of, or containing, Infusoria; as, infusorial earth.
One of the Infusoria.
Infusorial.

entries.entry: In*fu"so*ry n.; pl.Infusories. Zoöl One of the Infusoria; -- usually in the pl.

-ing ☞ The Old English ending of the present participle and verbal noun became confused, both becoming -ing.. For OE. -and -end -ind, AS. -ende; akin to Goth. -and-, L. -ant- -ent-, Gr. � A suffix used to from present participles; as, singing, playing .
OE. -ing, AS. -ing -ung
A suffix used to form nouns from verbs, and signifying the act of; the result of the act; as, riding, dying, feeling . It has also a secondary collective force; as, shipping, clothing .
AS. -ing
A suffix formerly used to form diminutives; as, lording, farthing .

entry.ety: See Ingenious

entry.ety: LL. ingeniositas
entry.def: Ingenuity; skill; cunning.

entry.ety: L. ingeniosus, fr. ingenium innate or natural quality, natural capacity, genius: cf. F. ingénieux. See Engine

sn.q: A man . . . very wise and ingenious in feats of war.
Thou, king, send out For torturers ingenious.
The more ingenious men are, the more apt are they to trouble themselves.

sn.def: Proceeding from, pertaining to, or characterized by, genius or ingenuity; of curious design, structure, or mechanism; as, an ingenious model, or machine; an ingenious scheme, contrivance, etc.
sn.q: Thus men go wrong with an ingenious skill.

sn.def: Witty; shrewd; adroit; keen; sagacious; as, an ingenious reply.
Mental; intellectual.
sn.q: A course of learning and ingenious studies.

entry.def: In an ingenious manner; with ingenuity; skillfully; wittily; cleverly.

entry.def: The quality or state of being ingenious; ingenuity.

entry.ety: L. ingenitus, p. p. of ingignere to instill by birth or nature; pref. in- + gignere to beget
entry.def: Innate; inborn; inbred; inherent; native; ingenerate.
entry.q: It is natural or ingenite, which comes by some defect of the organs and overmuch brain.

entries.entry: ‖In`gé`nue" ăN`zh�`nụ" n.; pl. -nues # . F., fem. of ingénu ingenious An ingenuous or naïve girl or young woman, or an actress representing such a person.

entry.usage: Ingenuity Cleverness. Ingenuity is a form of genius, and cleverness of talent. The former implies invention, the letter a peculiar dexterity and readiness of execution. Sir James Mackintosh remarks that the English overdo in the use of the word clever and cleverness, applying them loosely to almost every form of intellectual ability.
entry.ety: L. ingenuitas ingenuousness: cf. F. ingénuité. See Ingenuous

sn.def: The quality or power of ready invention; quickness or acuteness in forming new combinations; ingeniousness; skill in devising or combining.
sn.q: All the means which human ingenuity has contrived.

sn.def: Curiousness, or cleverness in design or contrivance; as, the ingenuity of a plan, or of mechanism.
sn.q: He gives . . . To artist ingenuity and skill.

sn.def: Openness of heart; ingenuousness.
sn.q: The stings and remorses of natural ingenuity, a principle that men scarcely ever shake off, as long as they carry anything of human nature about them.
sn.syn: Inventiveness; ingeniousness; skill; cunning; cleverness; genius.

entry.note: ☞ (Formerly) printers did not discriminate between . . . ingenuous and ingenious, and these words were used or rather printed interchangeably almost to the beginning of the eighteenth century.
entry.usage: Ingenuous Open Frank. One who is open speaks out at once what is uppermost in his mind; one who is frank does it from a natural boldness, or dislike of self-restraint; one who is ingenuous is actuated by a native simplicity and artlessness, which make him willing to confess faults, and make known his sentiments without reserve. See Candid.
entry.ety: L. ingenuus inborn, innate, freeborn, noble, frank; pref. in- in + the root of gignere to beget. See Genius, and cf. Ingenious

sn.def: Of honorable extraction; freeborn; noble; as, ingenuous blood of birth.
Noble; generous; magnanimous; honorable; upright; high-minded; as, an ingenuous ardor or zeal.
sn.q: If an ingenuous detestation of falsehood be but carefully and early instilled, that is the true and genuine method to obviate dishonesty.

sn.def: Free from reserve, disguise, equivocation, or dissimulation; open; frank; as, an ingenuous man; an ingenuous declaration, confession, etc.
sn.q: Sensible in myself . . . what a burden it is for me, who would be ingenuous, to be loaded with courtesies which he hath not the least hope to requite or deserve.

sn.def: Ingenious.
sn.syn: Open; frank; unreserved; artless; plain; sincere; candid; fair; noble; generous.

entry.def: In an ingenuous manner; openly; fairly; candidly; artlessly.
entry.q: Being required to explain himself, he ingenuously confessed.

sn.def: The state or quality of being ingenuous; openness of heart; frankness.
Ingenuity.

entry.ety: L. ingenium. See Ingenious
entry.def: Natural gift or talent; ability; wit; ingenuity.
To cause to germinate.

entry.ety: L. ingestio: cf. F. ingestion

cs.cd: the chimney corner.
the fireside.

entry.ety: Gael. & Ir. aingeali fire; cf. L. igniculusi spark, dim. of ignis fire. Cf. Ignite
entry.def: Flame; blaze; a fire; a fireplace.

entry.ety: Written also engle enghle: cf. Gael. & Ir. aingeal an angel. Cf. Engle
entry.def: A paramour; a favourite; a sweetheart; an engle.
To cajole or coax; to wheedle. See Engle.
In the form of a globe or sphere; -- applied to nebulous matter collected into a sphere by the force of gravitation.
To infix, as in a globe; to fix or secure firmly.

entry.ety: L. inglorious; pref. in- not + gloria glory, fame: cf. F. inglorieux. See Glory

sn.def: Not glorious; not bringing honor or glory; not accompanied with fame, honor, or celebrity; obscure; humble; as, an inglorious life of ease.

Some mute inglorious Milton here may rest.

sn.def: Shameful; disgraceful; ignominious; as, inglorious flight, defeat, etc.
sn.q: Inglorious shelter in an alien land.

entry.def: In an inglorious manner; dishonorably; with shame; ignominiously; obscurely.
The state of being inglorious.
To glut.
Of or pertaining to the ingluvies or crop of birds.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: The crop, or craw, of birds.
Gluttonous.
The act of going in; entrance.
Going; entering, as upon an office or a possession; as, an in-going tenant.
See Engorge.

entry.cs: Ingot mold a box or mold in which ingots are cast. Ingot iron. See Decarbonized steel, under Decarbonize.
entry.ety: Prob. from AS. in in + geótan to pour: cf. F. linglot, LL. lingotus a mass of gold or silver, extended in the manner of a tongue, and G. einguss, LG. & OE. ingot ingot, a mold for casting metals in. See Found to cast, and cf. Linget Lingot Nugget

sn.def: That in which metal is cast; a mold.
sn.q: And from the fire he took up his matter And in the ingot put it with merry cheer.

sn.def: A bar or wedge of steel, gold, or other malleable metal, cast in a mold; a mass of unwrought cast metal.
sn.q: Wrought ingots from Besoara's mine.

entries.entry: In"got steel. Steel cast in ingots from the Bessemer converter or open-hearth furnace.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + grace
entry.def: To ingratiate.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + gracious
entry.def: Ungracious; unkind.
See Ingraft.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ingrafted; p. pr. & vb. n. Ingrafting
entry.ety: Written also engraft

sn.def: To insert, as a scion of one tree, shrub, or plant in another for propagation; as, to ingraft a peach scion on a plum tree;
to insert or introduce in such a way as to make a part of something.
sn.q: This fellow would ingraft a foreign name Upon our stock.
A custom . . . ingrafted into the monarchy of Rome.

sn.def: To subject to the process of grafting; to furnish with grafts or scions; to graft; as, to ingraft a tree.

entry.def: A person who ingrafts.

sn.def: The act of ingrafting.
The thing ingrafted; a scion.

cs.cd: a double or two-ply carpet.
a three-ply carpet.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + grain kermes. See Engrain Grain

sn.def: Dyed with grain, or kermes.
Dyed before manufacture, -- said of the material of a textile fabric; hence, in general, thoroughly inwrought; forming an essential part of the substance.

entry.def: An ingrain fabric, as a carpet.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ingrained; p. pr. & vb. n. Ingraining
entry.ety: Written also engrain

sn.def: To dye with or in grain or kermes.
To dye in the grain, or before manufacture.
To work into the natural texture or into the mental or moral constitution of; to stain; to saturate; to imbue; to infix deeply.
sn.q: Our fields ingrained with blood.
Cruelty and jealousy seem to be ingrained in a man who has these vices at all.

entry.def: teaching or impressing upon the mind by frequent instruction or repetition.
To seize; to clutch; to grapple.

entry.ety: L. ingratus. See Ingrateful
entry.def: Ingrateful.
An ungrateful person.

entry.ety: L. ingratus ingrateful (pref. in- not + gratus beloved, dear, grateful) + -ful: cf. F. ingrat. See Grateful

sn.def: Ungrateful; thankless; unappreciative.
sn.q: He proved extremely false and ingrateful to me.

sn.def: Unpleasing to the sense; distasteful; offensive.
sn.q: He gives . . . no ingrateful food.

entry.def: Ungratefully.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ingratiated; p. pr. & vb. n. Ingratiating
entry.ety: Pref. in- in + L. gratia. See Grace

sn.def: To introduce or commend to the favor of another; to bring into favor; to insinuate; -- used reflexively, and followed by with before the person whose favor is sought.
sn.q: Lysimachus . . . ingratiated himself both with Philip and his pupil.

sn.def: To recommend; to render easy or agreeable; -- followed by to.
sn.q: What difficulty would it [the love of Christ] not ingratiate to us?

entry.def: To gain favor.

sn.def: capable of winning favor; as, with open arms and an ingratiating smile.
calculated to please or gain favor; as, an unctuous, ingratiating manner.
sn.syn: ingratiatory.

sn.def: pleasingly persuasive or intended to persuade; as, her manner is quiet and ingratiatory and a little too agreeable.
sn.syn: coaxing.

sn.def: calculated to please or gain favor; same as ingratiating, 2.
sn.syn: ingratiating.

entry.ety: F. ingratitude, L. ingratitudo. See Ingrate
entry.def: Lack of gratitude; insensibility to, forgetfulness of, or ill return for, kindness or favors received; unthankfulness; ungratefulness.
entry.q: Ingratitude, thou marble-hearted fiend.
Ingratitude is abhorred both by God and man.

entry.def: To engrave.
entry.q: Whose gleaming rindingrav'n.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + grave. Cf. Engrave
entry.def: To bury.

entry.ety: L. ingravidatus, p. p. of ingravidare to impregnate. See 1st In-, and Gravidated
entry.def: To impregnate.
The state of being pregnant or impregnated.
To make great; to enlarge; to magnify.

entry.ety: See Ingredient

sn.def: Entrance; ingress.
The quality or state of being an ingredient or component part.

entry.ety: F. ingrédient, L. ingrediens -entis, entering into, p. pr. of ingredi, p. p. ingressus, to go into, to enter; pref. in- in + gradi to walk, go. See Grade
entry.def: That which enters into a compound, or is a component part of any combination, recipe, or mixture; an element; a constituent.
entry.q: By way of analysis we may proceed from compounds to ingredients.
Water is the chief ingredient in all the animal fluids and solids.

entry.def: Entering as, or forming, an ingredient or component part.
entry.q: Acts where no sin is ingredient.

entry.ety: L. ingressus, fr. ingredi. See Ingredient

sn.def: The act of entering; entrance; as, the ingress of air into the lungs.
Power or liberty of entrance or access; means of entering; as, all ingress was prohibited.
The entrance of the moon into the shadow of the earth in eclipses, the sun's entrance into a sign, etc.

entry.def: To go in; to enter.

entry.ety: L. ingressio: cf. F. ingression
entry.def: Act of entering; entrance.
To render more grievous; to aggravate.
To groove in; to join in or with a groove.
See Engross.
an exclusive circle of people with a common purpose, interests, or attitudes, especially one that produces feelings of camaraderie, exclusivity, community, and solidarity.
entry.syn: clique, coterie, ingroup, inner circle, pack, camp.

entry.def: Growing or appearing to grow into some other substance.

cs.cd: a toenail whose edges have becoming imbedded in the adjacent flesh.

entry.def: Having grown or appearing to grow into some other substance, especially a fingernail or toenail growing into the adjacent flesh.
A growth or development inward.

entry.ety: L. inguen inguinis
entry.def: The groin.
Not guilty.

entry.cs: Inguinal ring. See Abdominal ring, under Abdominal.
entry.ety: L. inguinalis, fr. inguen inguinis, the groin: cf. F. inguinal
entry.def: Of or pertaining to, or in the region of, the inguen or groin; as, an inguinal canal or ligament; inguinal hernia.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ingulfed; p. pr. & vb. n. Ingulfing
entry.ety: Cf. Engulf
entry.def: To swallow up or overwhelm in, or as in, a gulf; to cast into a gulf. See Engulf.
entry.q: A river large . . . Passed underneath ingulfed.

entry.def: The act of ingulfing, or the state of being ingulfed.

entry.ety: L. ingurgitatus, p. p. of ingurgitare to pour in; pref. in- in + gurges whirlpool, gulf

sn.def: To swallow, devour, or drink greedily or in large quantity; to guzzle.
To swallow up, as in a gulf.

entry.def: To guzzle; to swill.

entry.ety: L. ingurgitatio: cf. F. ingurgitation
entry.def: The act of swallowing greedily or immoderately; that which is so swallowed.
entry.q: He drowned his stomach and senses with a large draught and ingurgitation of wine.

entry.ety: L. ingustabilis. See Gustable
entry.def: Tasteless; insipid.

entry.ety: L. inhabilis: cf. F. inhabile. See In- not, and Habile, and cf. Unable

sn.def: Not apt or fit; unfit; not convenient; inappropriate; unsuitable; as, inhabile matter.
Unskilled; unready; awkward; incompetent; unqualified; -- said of persons.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inhabileté inhabilité. See Inability
entry.def: Unsuitableness; unaptness; unfitness; inability.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inhabited; p. pr. & vb. n. Inhabiting
entry.ety: OE. enhabiten, OF. enhabiter, L. inhabitare; pref. in- in + habitare to dwell. See Habit
entry.def: To live or dwell in; to occupy, as a place of settled residence; as, wild beasts inhabit the forest; men inhabit cities and houses.
entry.q: The high and lofty One, that inhabiteth eternity.
O, who would inhabit This bleak world alone?

entry.def: To have residence in a place; to dwell; to live; to abide.
entry.q: They say wild beasts inhabit here.

entry.ety: L. inhabitabilis. See Inhabit
entry.def: Capable of being inhabited; habitable.
entry.q: Systems of inhabitable planets.

entry.ety: L. inhabitabilis: cf. F. inhabitable. See In- not, and Habitable
entry.def: Not habitable; not suitable to be inhabited.
entry.q: The frozen ridges of the Alps Or other ground inhabitable.

sn.def: The act of inhabiting, or the state of being inhabited; the condition of an inhabitant; residence; occupancy.
sn.q: Ruins yet resting in the wild moors testify a former inhabitance.

sn.def: The state of having legal right to claim the privileges of a recognized inhabitant; especially, the right to support in case of poverty, acquired by residence in a town; habitancy.

entry.ety: L. inhabitans -antis, p. pr. of inhabitare

sn.def: One who dwells or resides permanently in a place, as distinguished from a transient lodger or visitor; as, an inhabitant of a house, a town, a city, county, or state.
sn.q: Frailinhabitantsof earth.
In this place, they report that they saw inhabitants which were very fair and fat people.

sn.def: One who has a legal settlement in a town, city, or parish; a permanent resident.

entry.def: To inhabit.

entry.ety: L. inhabitatio a dwelling

sn.def: The act of inhabiting, or the state of being inhabited; indwelling.
sn.q: The inhabitation of the Holy Ghost.

sn.def: Abode; place of dwelling; residence.
Population; inhabitants.
sn.q: The beginning of nations and of the world's inhabitation.

entry.def: A tendency or propensity to permanent residence in a place or abode; love of home and country.
Uninhabited.
An inhabitant.
See Inhabitativeness.
entry.q: What the phrenologists call inhabitiveness.

entry.def: A female inhabitant.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inhalant
entry.def: Inhaling; used for inhaling.
An apparatus also called an inhalerwhich see); also, that which is to be inhaled, especially a medicine taken by inhalation.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inhalation
entry.def: The act of inhaling; also, that which is inhaled.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inhaled; p. pr. & vb. n. Inhaling
entry.ety: L. inhalare to breathe upon; pref. in- in + halare to breathe: cf. F. inhaler. Cf. Exhale
entry.def: To breathe or draw into the lungs; to inspire; as, to inhale air; -- opposed to exhale.
entry.q: Martin was walking forth to inhale the fresh breeze of the evening.

entry.def: drawn into the lungs; breathed in; as, inhaled smoke can damage the lungs. Inverse of exhaled.
Used for inhaling; as, the inhalent end of a duct.

sn.def: One who inhales.

An apparatus for inhaling any vapor or volatile substance, such as ether or chloroform, or an aerosol mist of a solution, for medicinal purposes; as, he alway carried his inhaler around in his pocket in case he had asthmatic attack.
A contrivance to filter, as air, in order to protect the lungs from inhaling damp or cold air, noxious gases, dust, etc.; also, the respiratory apparatus for divers.

entry.def: See Enhance.
Not harmonic; inharmonious; discordant; dissonant.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + harmonious: cf. F. inharmonieux

sn.def: Not harmonious; unmusical; discordant; dissonant.
sn.q: Sounds inharmonious in themselves and harsh.

sn.def: Conflicting; jarring; not in harmony.

entry.def: Without harmony.
The quality of being inharmonious; lack of harmony; discord.
entry.q: The inharmoniousness of a verse.

entry.def: Lack of harmony.
A rope used to draw in the jib boom, or flying jib boom.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inhearsed; p. pr. & vb. n. Inhearsing
entry.def: To put in, or as in, a hearse or coffin.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inhered; p. pr. & vb. n. Inhering
entry.ety: L. inhaerere; pref. in- in + haerere to stick, hang. See Hesitate
entry.def: To be inherent; to stick (in); to be fixed in or permanently incorporated with something; to cleave (to); to belong, as attributes or qualities.
entry.q: They do but inhere in the subject that supports them.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inhérence
entry.def: The state of inhering; permanent existence in something; innateness; inseparable and essential connection.

entry.ety: L. inhaerens -entis, p. pr. of inhaerere: cf. F. inhérent. See Inhere
entry.def: Permanently existing in something; inseparably attached or connected; naturally pertaining to; innate; inalienable; as, polarity is an inherent quality of the magnet; the inherent right of men to life, liberty, and protection.
entry.q: A mostinherentbaseness.
The sore disease which seems inherent in civilization.
entry.syn: Innate; inborn; native; natural; inbred; inwrought; inseparable; essential; indispensable.

entry.def: By inherence; inseparably.
entry.q: Matter hath inherently and essentially such an internal energy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inherited; p. pr. & vb. n. Inheriting
entry.ety: OE. enheriten to inherit, to give a heritage to, OF. enheriter to appoint as an heir, L. inhereditare; pref. in- in + hereditare to inherit, fr. heres heir. See Heir

sn.def: To take by descent from an ancestor; to take by inheritance; to take as heir on the death of an ancestor or other person to whose estate one succeeds; to receive as a right or title descendible by law from an ancestor at his decease; as, the heir inherits the land or real estate of his father; the eldest son of a nobleman inherits his father's title; the eldest son of a king inherits the crown.

To receive or take by birth; to have by nature; to derive or acquire from ancestors, as mental or physical qualities, genes, or genetic traits; as, he inherits a strong constitution, a tendency to disease, etc.; to inherit hemophilia
sn.q: Prince Harry is valiant; for the cold blood he did naturally inherit of his father he hath . . . manured . . . with good store of fertile sherris.

sn.def: To come into possession of; to possess; to own; to enjoy as a possession.
sn.q: But the meek shall inherit the earth.
To bury so much gold under a tree, And never after to inherit it.

sn.def: To put in possession of.

entry.def: To take or hold a possession, property, estate, or rights by inheritance.
entry.q: Thou shalt not inherit our father's house.

entry.def: The quality of being inheritable or descendible to heirs.

cs.cd: blood or relationship by which a person becomes qualified to be an heir, or to transmit possessions by inheritance.

sn.def: Capable of being inherited; transmissible or descendible; as, an inheritable estate or title.
Capable of being transmitted from parent to child; as, inheritable qualities or infirmities.
Capable of taking by inheritance, or of receiving by descent; capable of succeeding to, as an heir.
sn.q: By attainder . . . the blood of the person attainted is so corrupted as to be rendered no longer inheritable.
The eldest daughter of the king is also alone inheritable to the crown on failure of issue male.

entry.def: By inheritance.

entry.note: ☞ The word inheritanceused simply) is mostly confined to the title to land and tenements by a descent.
entry.ety: Cf. OF. enheritance

sn.def: The act or state of inheriting; as, the inheritance of an estate; the inheritance of mental or physical qualities.
That which is or may be inherited; that which is derived by an heir from an ancestor or other person; a heritage; a possession which passes by descent.
sn.q: When the man dies, let the inheritance Descend unto the daughter.

sn.def: A permanent or valuable possession or blessing, esp. one received by gift or without purchase; a benefaction.
sn.q: To an inheritance incorruptible, and undefiled, and that fadeth not away.

sn.def: Possession; ownership; acquisition.
sn.q: Theinheritanceof their loves.
To you th' inheritance belongs by right Of brother's praise; to you eke 'longs his love.

sn.def: Transmission and reception by animal or plant generation.

A perpetual or continuing right which a man and his heirs have to an estate; an estate which a man has by descent as heir to another, or which he may transmit to another as his heir; an estate derived from an ancestor to an heir in course of law.
sn.q: Men are not proprietors of what they have, merely for themselves; their children have a title to part of it which comes to be wholly theirs when death has put an end to their parents' use of it; and this we call inheritance.

entry.def: tending to occur among members of a family usually by heredity; as, an inherited disease.
capable of inheriting by law.
One who inherits; an heir.
entry.q: Born inheritors of the dignity.

entry.def: A heiress.
Same as Inheritress.
See Inhearse.

entry.ety: L. inhaesio. See Inhere
entry.def: The state of existing, of being inherent, in something; inherence.
entry.q: Constant inhesion and habitual abode.

entry.ety: L. inhiatio, fr. inhiare to gape; pref. in- + hiare to gape
entry.def: A gaping after; eager desire; craving.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inhibited; p. pr. & vb. n. Inhibiting
entry.ety: L. inhibitus, p. p. of inhibere; pref. in- in + habere to have, hold. See Habit

sn.def: To check; to hold back; to restrain; to hinder.
sn.q: Their motions also are excited or inhibited . . . by the objects without them.

sn.def: To forbid; to prohibit; to interdict.
sn.q: All men were inhibited, by proclamation, at the dissolution, so much as to mention a Parliament.
Burial may not be inhibited or denied to any one.

sn.def: To cause the rate of (a chemical or biochemical reaction) to proceed slower, or to halt; as, vitamin C inhibits oxidation; penicillins inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis.
To restrain (a behavior) by a mechanism involving conscious or unconscious motivations.

entry.sn: held back or restrained or prevented; as, in certain conditions previously inhibited conditioned reactions can reappear; -- of behaviors. Opposite of uninhibited.Narrower terms: pent-up, repressed ; stifled, strangled, suppressed Also See: reserved restrained.

sn.def: Having a hesitancy or reluctance to exhibit normal emotional reactions; -- of people; as, he was too inhibited to make friends easily.

entry.def: discouraging (a person) from action by threat of punishment; as, an overly strict or inhibiting discipline.

entry.ety: L. inhibitio: cf. F. inhibition

sn.def: The act of inhibiting, or the state of being inhibited; restraint; prohibition; embargo.

A stopping or checking of an already present action; a restraining of the function of an organ, or an agent, as a digestive fluid or enzyme, etc.; as, the inhibition of the respiratory center by the pneumogastric nerve; the inhibition of reflexes, etc.
A writ from a higher court forbidding an inferior judge from further proceedings in a cause before; esp., a writ issuing from a higher ecclesiastical court to an inferior one, on appeal.
The reduction in rate or stopping of a chemical or biochemical reaction, due to interaction with a chemical agent.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: That which causes inhibitory action; esp., an inhibitory nerve.

cs.cd: those nerves which modify, inhibit, or suppress a motor or secretory act already in progress.

entry.ety: LL. inhibitorius: cf. F. inhibitoire
entry.def: Of or pertaining to, or producing, inhibition; consisting in inhibition; tending or serving to inhibit; as, the inhibitory action of the pneumogastric on the respiratory center.
entry.q: I would not have you consider these criticisms as inhibitory.

entry.def: A term applied to certain nerve centers which govern or restrain subsidiary centers, from which motor impressions issue.
To place in a hive; to hive.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inheld; p. pr. & vb. n. Inholding
entry.def: To have inherent; to contain in itself; to possess.
An inhabitant.
To inclose in a hoop, or as in a hoop.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + hospitable: cf. L. inhospitalis

sn.def: Not hospitable; not disposed to show hospitality to strangers or guests; as, an inhospitable person or people.
sn.q: Have you no touch of pity, that the poor Stand starved at your inhospitable door?

sn.def: Affording no shelter or sustenance; barren; desert; bleak; cheerless; wild.
sn.q: Inhospitablewastes.

entry.ety: L. inhospitalitas: cf. F. inhospitalité. See In- not, and Hospitality
entry.def: The quality or state of being inhospitable; inhospitableness; lack of hospitality.

entry.ety: L. inhumanus: cf. F. inhumain. See In- not, and Human

sn.def: Destitute of the kindness and tenderness that belong to a human being; cruel; barbarous; savage; unfeeling; as, an inhuman person or people.
Characterized by, or attended with, cruelty; as, an inhuman act or punishment.
sn.syn: Cruel; unfeeling; pitiless; merciless; savage; barbarous; brutal; ferocious; ruthless; fiendish.

entries.entry: in`hu*mane" ĭn`hū*mān" adj. not humane; lacking and reflecting lack of pity, kindness, or compassion; as, humans are innately inhumane; this explains much of the misery and suffering in the world; biological weapons are considered too inhumane to be used.Narrower terms: barbarous, brutal, cruel, fell, roughshod, savage, vicious; beastly, bestial, brute(prenominal), brutish, cannibalic ; brutal, cruel; cold, cold-blooded, inhuman, insensate ; pitiless, unfeeling, unkind ; painful (vs. painless Also See: uncivilized. Antonym: humane.

entry.def: In an inhumane manner.
the quality of lacking compassion or consideration for others; the quality of being inhumane; inhumanity; -- of people or events.

entries.entry:
In`hu*man"i*ty n.; pl.Inhumanities #. L. inhumanitas: cf. F. inhumanité
The quality or state of being inhuman or inhumane; cruelty; barbarity. Man's inhumanity to man Makes countless thousands mourn.

entry.def: In an inhuman manner; cruelly; barbarously.

entry.ety: L. inhumatus, p. p. of inhumare to inhume; pref. in- in + humare to cover with earth. See Humation, and cf. Inhume
entry.def: To inhume; to bury; to inter.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inhumation

sn.def: The act of inhuming or burying; interment.
The act of burying vessels in warm earth in order to expose their contents to a steady moderate heat; the state of being thus exposed.
Arenation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inhumed; p. pr. & vb. n. Inhuming
entry.ety: Cf. F. inhumer. See Inhumate

sn.def: To deposit, as a dead body, in the earth; to bury; to inter.
sn.q: Weeping they bear the mangled heaps of slain,Inhume the natives in their native plain.

sn.def: To bury or place in warm earth for chemical or medicinal purposes.

entry.def: A South American freshwater dolphin (Inia Boliviensis). It is ten or twelve feet long, and has a hairy snout.
Pertaining to the inion.
Unimaginable; inconceivable.

entry.ety: L. inimicalis, fr. inimicus unfriendly, hostile; pref. in- not + amicus friendly. See Amity

sn.def: Having the disposition or temper of an enemy; unfriendly; unfavorable; -- chiefly applied to private, as hostile is to public, enmity.
Opposed in tendency, influence, or effects; antagonistic; inconsistent; incompatible; adverse; repugnant.
sn.q: We are at war with a system, which, by its essence, is inimical to all other governments.

entry.def: The state or quality of being inimical or hostile; hostility; unfriendliness.
In an inimical manner.

entry.ety: L. inimicitia enmity. See Inimical
entry.def: Inimical; unfriendly.

entry.ety: L. inimicus
entry.def: Inimical; hurtful.
The quality or state of being inimitable; inimitableness.

entry.ety: L. inimitabilis: cf. F. inimitable. See In- not, and Imitable
entry.def: Not capable of being imitated, copied, or counterfeited; beyond imitation; surpassingly excellent; matchless; unrivaled; exceptional; unique; as, an inimitable style; inimitable eloquence.
entry.q: Inimitableforce.
Performing such inimitable feats.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'ini`on the back of the head
entry.def: The external occipital protuberance of the skull.

entry.usage: Iniquitous Wicked Nefarious. Wicked is the generic term. Iniquitous is stronger, denoting a violation of the rights of others, usually by fraud or circumvention. Nefarious is still stronger, implying a breach of the most sacred obligations, and points more directly to the intrinsic badness of the deed.
entry.ety: From Iniquity
entry.def: Characterized by iniquity; unjust; wicked; as, an iniquitous bargain; an iniquitous proceeding.
entry.q: Demagogues . . . bribed to this iniquitous service.
entry.syn: Wicked; wrong; unjust; unrighteous; nefarious; criminal.

entry.def: In an iniquitous manner; unjustly; wickedly.

entries.entry:
In*iq"ui*ty n.; pl.Iniquities #. OE. iniquitee, F. iniquité, L. iniquitas, inequality, unfairness, injustice. See Iniquous
Absence of, or deviation from, just dealing; lack of rectitude or uprightness; gross injustice; unrighteousness; wickedness; as, the iniquity of bribery; the iniquity of an unjust judge.
Till the world from his perfection fell Into all filth and foul iniquity.
An iniquitous act or thing; a deed of injustice or unrighteousness; a sin; a crime. Your iniquities have separated between you and your God.
A character or personification in the old English moralities, or moral dramas, having the name sometimes of one vice and sometimes of another. See Vice. Acts old Iniquity, and in the fit Of miming gets the opinion of a wit.

entry.ety: L. iniquus; pref. in- not + aequus. See Equal
entry.def: Iniquitous.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + irritable: cf. F. inirritable
entry.def: Not irritable; esp. Physiol, incapable of being stimulated to action, as a muscle.
Not accompanied with excitement; as, an inirritative fever.

entry.ety: Cf. Enisled
entry.def: To form into an island; to surround.

entry.ety: L. initialis, from initium a going in, entrance, beginning, fr. inire to go into, to enter, begin; pref. in- in + ire to go: cf. F. initial. See Issue, and cf. Commence

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the beginning; marking the commencement; incipient; commencing; as, the initial symptoms of a disease.
Placed at the beginning; standing at the head, as of a list or series; as, the initial letters of a name.

entry.def: The first letter of a word or a name.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Initialed; p. pr. & vb. n. Initialing
entry.def: To put an initial to; to mark with an initial of initials.
initialize.
to assign an initial value to (a variable or set of variables in a computer program); as, many bugs are caused by a failure to initialize variables.
In an initial or incipient manner or degree; at the beginning.
The first letters of a person's first and last name, and sometimes also the first letters of the middle name or names; as, sign your initials in the margin; people identified only by their initials .

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Initiated; p. pr. & vb. n. Initiating
entry.ety: L. initiatus, p. p. of initiare to begin, fr. initium beginning. See Initial

sn.def: To introduce by a first act; to make a beginning with; to set afoot; to originate; to commence; to begin or enter upon.
sn.q: How are changes of this sort to be initiated?

sn.def: To acquaint with the beginnings; to instruct in the rudiments or principles; to introduce.
sn.q: Providence would only initiate mankind into the useful knowledge of her treasures, leaving the rest to employ our industry.
To initiate his pupil into any part of learning, an ordinary skill in the governor is enough.

sn.def: To introduce into a society or organization; to confer membership on; especially, to admit to a secret order with mysterious rites or ceremonies.
sn.q: The Athenians believed that he who was initiated and instructed in the mysteries would obtain celestial honor after death.
He was initiated into half a dozen clubs before he was one and twenty.

entry.def: To do the first act; to perform the first rite; to take the initiative.

cs.cd: said of a husband who becomes such in his wife's estate of inheritance by the birth of a child, but whose estate is not consummated till the death of the wife.

entry.ety: L. initiatus, p. p

sn.def: Unpracticed; untried; new.
sn.q: Theinitiatefear that wants hard use.

sn.def: Begun; commenced; introduced to, or instructed in, the rudiments; newly admitted.
sn.q: To rise in science as in bliss,Initiate in the secrets of the skies.

entry.def: One who is, or is to be, initiated.

entry.ety: L. initiatio: cf. F. initiation

sn.def: The act of initiating, or the process of being initiated or introduced; as, initiation into a society, into business, literature, etc.
sn.q: Theinitiationof courses of events.

sn.def: The form or ceremony by which a person is introduced into any society; mode of entrance into an organized body; especially, the rite of admission into a secret society or order.
sn.q: Silence is the first thing that is taught us at our initiation into sacred mysteries.

entry.ety: Cf. F. initiatif
entry.def: Serving to initiate; inceptive; initiatory; introductory; preliminary.

entry.ety: Cf. F. initiative

sn.def: An introductory step or movement; an act which originates or begins.
sn.q: The undeveloped initiatives of good things to come.

sn.def: The right or power to introduce a new measure or course of action, as in legislation; as, the initiative in respect to revenue bills is in the House of Representatives.

The right or procedure by which legislation may be introduced or enacted directly by the people, as in the Swiss Confederation and in many of the States of the United States; -- chiefly used with the. The procedure of the initiative is essentially as follows: Upon the filing of a petition signed by a required number or percentage of qualified voters the desired measure must be submitted to a popular vote, and upon receiving the required majority (commonly a majority of those voting on the measure submitted) it becomes a law. In some States of the United States the initiative is only local; in others it is state-wide and includes the making of constitutional amendments.
a character trait manifested in a readiness and ability to initiate action; an enterprising spirit; a go-getting attitude; energy; drive; get-up-and-go.
in interactive activities, such as conversation or games, the right or opportunity to set the course of action; as, to have the initiative .

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who initiates.

sn.def: Suitable for an introduction or beginning; introductory; prefatory; as, an initiatory step.
Tending or serving to initiate; introducing by instruction, or by the use and application of symbols or ceremonies; elementary; rudimentary.
sn.q: Some initiatory treatises in the law.
Two initiatory rites of the same general import can not exist together.

entry.def: An introductory act or rite.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. inition. See Initial
entry.def: Initiation; beginning.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Injected; p. pr. & vb. n. Injecting
entry.ety: L. injectus, p. p. of inicere injicere, to throw in; pref. in- in + jacere to throw: cf. F. injecter. See Jet a shooting forth

sn.def: To throw in; to dart in; to force in; as, to inject cold water into a condenser; to inject a medicinal liquid into a cavity of the body; to inject morphine with a hypodermic syringe.
Fig.: To throw; to offer; to propose; to instill.
sn.q: Cæsar also, then hatching tyranny, injected the same scrupulous demurs.

sn.def: To cast or throw; -- with on.
sn.q: And mound inject on mound.

sn.def: To fill (a vessel, cavity, or tissue) with a fluid or other substance; as, to inject the blood vessels.
to add in; to insert; to interject; as, to inject a comment into the conversation; to inject humor into a tense situation.
capable of being conveniently injected; -- used of drug preparations, such as sterile lyophilize medicine in a serum-capped vial. Opposite of uninjectable.
Requiring injection for administration; -- of drugs, especially those not active by oral administration. Opposite of orally active.

entry.cs:
Injection cockorInjection valve
Steam Eng the cock or valve through which cold water is admitted into a condenser. Injection condenser. See under Condenser. Injection pipe the pipe through which cold water is through into the condenser of a steam engine. fuel injection a method of inserting fuel into internal-combustion engines by directly forcing the liquid fuel into the combustion chamber at an appropriate point in the piston cycle; in contrast to carburetion, in which an air-fuel mixture is drawn in by the downward stroke of the piston.
entry.ety: L. injectio : cf. F. injection

sn.def: The act of injecting or throwing in; -- applied particularly to the forcible insertion of a liquid or gas, by means of a syringe, pump, etc.
That which is injected; especially, a liquid inserted thrown into a cavity of the body by a syringe or pipe; a clyster; an enema.

sd.def: The act or process of filling vessels, cavities, or tissues with a fluid or other substance.
A specimen prepared by injection.
The act of throwing cold water into a condenser to produce a vacuum.
The cold water thrown into a condenser.

cs.cd: a device for actively injecting fuel into an internal-combustion engines by directly forcing the liquid fuel into the combustion chamber at an appropriate point in the piston cycle; -- an alternative to a carburetor, in which an air-fuel mixture is drawn in by the downward stroke of the piston.

sn.def: One who, or that which, injects.

A contrivance for forcing feed water into a steam boiler by the direct action of the steam upon the water. The water is driven into the boiler by the impulse of a jet of the steam which becomes condensed as soon as it strikes the stream of cold water it impels; -- also called Giffard's injector, from the inventor.

entry.def: To place in jelly.
See Enjoin.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + joint
entry.def: To join; to unite.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + joint
entry.def: To disjoint; to separate.

entry.ety: L. injucunditas. See In- not, and Jocund
entry.def: Unpleasantness; disagreeableness.
Not cognizable by a judge.
Not according to the forms of law; not judicial.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + judicious; cf. F. injudicieux

sn.def: Not judicious; wanting in sound judgment; undiscerning; indiscreet; unwise; as, an injudicious adviser.
sn.q: An injudicious biographer who undertook to be his editor and the protector of his memory.

sn.def: Not according to sound judgment or discretion; unwise; as, an injudicious measure.
sn.syn: Indiscreet; inconsiderate; undiscerning; incautious; unwise; rash; hasty; imprudent.

entry.def: In an injudicious manner.
The quality of being injudicious; lack of sound judgment; indiscretion.

entry.note: ☞ It is more generally used as a preventive than as a restorative process, although by no means confined to the former.
entry.ety: L. injunctio, fr. injungere injunctum, to join into, to enjoin. See Enjoin

sn.def: The act of enjoining; the act of directing, commanding, or prohibiting.
That which is enjoined; an order; a mandate; a decree; a command; a precept; a direction.
sn.q: For still they knew, and ought to have still remembered, The high injunction, not to taste that fruit.
Necessary as the injunctions of lawful authority.

sn.def: A writ or process, granted by a court of equity, and, in some cases, under statutes, by a court of law, whereby a party is required to do or to refrain from doing certain acts, according to the exigency of the writ.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Injured; p. pr. & vb. n. Injuring
entry.ety: L. injuriari, fr. injuria injury, perh. through F. injurier to insult, in OF. also, to injure; or perhaps fr. E. injury, or F. injure injury. See Injury
entry.def: To do harm to; to impair the excellence and value of; to hurt; to damage;
entry.specif: used in a variety of senses; as:
entry.def: To hurt or wound, as the person; to impair soundness, as of health.
To damage or lessen the value of, as goods or estate.
To slander, tarnish, or impair, as reputation or character.
To impair or diminish, as happiness or virtue.
To give pain to, as the sensibilities or the feelings; to grieve; to annoy.
To impair, as the intellect or mind.
entry.q: When have I injured thee? when done thee wrong?
entry.syn: To damage; mar; spoil; harm; sully; wrong; maltreat; abuse; insult; affront; dishonor.

entry.sn: having received an injury;-- usually used of physical or mental injury to persons. Opposite of uninjured.Narrower terms: abraded, scraped, skinned ; battle-scarred, scarred; bit, bitten, stung ; black-and-blue, livid ; bruised, contused, contusioned ; bruised, hurt, wounded ; burned; cut, gashed, slashed, split ; disabled, hors de combat, out of action ; disjointed, dislocated, separated ; hurt, wounded ; lacerated, mangled, torn; maimed, mutilated Also See: broken damaged damaged impaired unsound wronged.

sn.def: subjected to an injustice.
sn.syn: aggrieved.

entry.def: One who injures or wrongs.

entries.entry: ‖In*ju"ri*a n.; pl.Injurie #. L Law Injury; invasion of another's rights.

entry.ety: L. injuriousus, injurius; cf. F. injurieux. See Injury

sn.def: Not just; wrongful; iniquitous; culpable.
sn.q: Till the injurious Roman did extort This tribute from us, we were free.

sn.def: Causing injury or harm; hurtful; harmful; detrimental; mischievous; as, acts injurious to health, credit, reputation, property, etc.
sn.q: Without being injurious to the memory of our English Pindar.
sn.syn: Harmful; hurtful; pernicious; mischievous; baneful; deleterious; noxious; ruinous; detrimental.

entry.def: In an injurious or hurtful manner; wrongfully; hurtfully; mischievously.

entries.entry:
In"ju*ry ☞ Injury in morals and jurisprudence is the intentional doing of wrong. n.; pl.Injuries #. OE. injurie, L. injuria, fr. injurius injurious, wrongful, unjust; pref. in- not + jus juris, right, law, justice: cf. F. injure. See Just a.
Any damage or hurt done to a person or thing; detriment to, or violation of, the person, character, feelings, rights, property, or interests of an individual; that which injures, or occasions wrong, loss, damage, or detriment; harm; hurt; loss; mischief; wrong; evil; as, his health was impaired by a severe injury; slander is an injury to the character.
For he that doeth injury shall receive that that he did evil. Many times we do injury to a cause by dwelling on trifling arguments. Riot ascends above their loftiest towers, And injury and outrage. Harm; hurt; damage; loss; impairment; detriment; wrong; evil; injustice.

entry.ety: F. injustice, L. injustitia. See In- not, and Justice, and cf. Unjust

sn.def: Lack of justice and equity; violation of the rights of another or others; iniquity; wrong; unfairness; imposition.
sn.q: If this people [the Athenians] resembled Nero in their extravagance, much more did they resemble and even exceed him in cruelty and injustice.

sn.def: An unjust act or deed; a sin; a crime; a wrong.
sn.q: Cunning men can be guilty of a thousand injustices without being discovered, or at least without being punished.

entry.def: The step, or socket, in which the lower end of a millstone spindle runs.

entry.note: ☞ Ordinarily, black ink is made from nutgalls and a solution of some salt of iron, and consists essentially of a tannate or gallate of iron; sometimes indigo sulphate, or other coloring matter, is added. Other black inks contain potassium chromate, and extract of logwood, salts of vanadium, etc. Blue ink is usually a solution of Prussian blue. Red ink was formerly made from carmine (cochineal), Brazil wood, etc., but potassium eosin is now used. Also red, blue, violet, and yellow inks are largely made from aniline dyes. Indelible ink is usually a weak solution of silver nitrate, but carbon in the form of lampblack or India ink, salts of molybdenum, vanadium, etc., are also used. Sympathetic inks may be made of milk, salts of cobalt, etc. See Sympathetic inkbelow).
entry.cs:
Copying ink a peculiar ink used for writings of which copies by impression are to be taken. Ink bag Zoöl an ink sac. Ink berry. Bot A shrub of the Holly family (Ilex glabra), found in sandy grounds along the coast from New England to Florida, and producing a small black berry. The West Indian indigo berry. See Indigo. Ink plant Bot a New Zealand shrub (Coriaria thymifolia), the berries of which yield a juice which forms an ink. Ink powder a powder from which ink is made by solution. Ink sac Zoöl an organ, found in most cephalopods, containing an inky fluid which can be ejected from a duct opening at the base of the siphon. The fluid serves to cloud the water, and enable these animals to escape from their enemies. See Illust. of Dibranchiata.
Printer's inkorPrinting ink . See under Printing. Sympathetic ink a writing fluid of such a nature that what is written remains invisible till the action of a reagent on the characters makes it visible.
entry.ety: OE. enke inke, OF. enque, F. encre, L. encaustum the purple red ink with which the Roman emperors signed their edicts, Gr. �, fr. � burnt in, encaustic, fr. � to burn in. See Encaustic Caustic

sn.def: A fluid, or a viscous material or preparation of various kinds (commonly black or colored), used in writing or printing.

sn.def: A pigment. See India ink, under India.

a trough or table from which the inking roller receives its ink.

A type of printer used as a peripheral device for computers, in which the color is applied to the paper by spraying liquid ink onto paper through tiny orifices in a moving print head, to construct the desired pattern on the paper by placing one dot or several dots at a time on the paper.

entry.ety: Prob.the same word as lingle, the first l being mistaken for the definite article in French. See Lingle

of Inlay.

Confined to a country or state; domestic; not foreign; as, an inland bill of exchange. See Exchange.

Into, or towards, the interior, away from the coast.

A person who is related by marriage, as distinguished from a blood relative; esp. mother-in-lawthe mother of one's spouse), father-in-lawthe father of one's spouse), brother-in-lawthe brother of one's spouse, or husband of one's spouse's sister), sister-in-lawthe sister of one's spouse, or wife of one's spouse's brother).
A suffix meaning through marriage. See in-law.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inlaied; p. pr. & vb. n. Inlaying
entry.def: To lay within; hence, to insert, as pieces of pearl, ivory, mother-of-pearl, choice woods, or the like, in a groundwork of some other material; to form an ornamental surface; to diversify or adorn with insertions.
entry.q: Look, how the floor of heaven Is thick inlaid with patines of bright gold.
But these things are . . . borrowed by the monks to inlay their story.

entry.def: Matter or pieces of wood, ivory, etc., inlaid, or prepared for inlaying; that which is inserted or inlaid for ornament or variety; as, ornamented with ivory inlay .
entry.q: Crocus and hyacinth with rich inlay Broidered the ground.
The sloping of the moonlit sward Was damask work, and deep inlay Of braided blooms.

entry.def: One who inlays, or whose occupation it is to inlay.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inleagued; p. pr. & vb. n. Inleaguing
entry.def: To ally, or form an alliance with; to unite; to combine.
entry.q: With a willingness inleague our blood With his, for purchase of full growth in friendship.

entry.def: To beleaguer.

entry.note: ☞ Inlet is also used adjectively, as in inlet pipe, inlet valve, etc.

a narrow waterway leading into a harbor.

entry.note: ☞ As distinguished from a private boarding house, an inn is a house for the entertainment of all travelers of good conduct and means of payment, as guests for a brief period, not as lodgers or boarders by contract.

cs.cd: colleges in which young students formerly began their law studies, now occupied chiefly bp attorn`ys, solocitors, etc.

the four societies of “students and practicers of the law of England” which in London exercise the exclusive right of admitting persons to practice at the bar; also, the buildings in which the law students and barristers have their chambers. They are the Inner Temple, the Middle Temple, Lincoln's Inn, and Gray's Inn.

entry.ety: AS. in inn, house, chamber, inn, from AS. in in; akin to Icel. inni house. See In

One of the colleges (societies or buildings) in London, for students of the law barristers; as, the Inns of Court; the Inns of Chancery; Serjeants' Inns.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inned ĭnd; p. pr. & vb. n. Inning

sn.q: When he had brought them into his city And inned them, everich at his degree.

entry.def: The internal organs of an animal collectively especially those in the abdominal cavity.

cs.cd: ideas, as of God, immortality, right and wrong, supposed by some to be inherent in the mind, as a priori principles of knowledge.

Originating in, or derived from, the constitution of the intellect, as opposed to acquired from experience; as, innate ideas. See A priori Intuitive.
sn.q: There is an innate light in every man, discovering to him the first lines of duty in the common notions of good and evil.
Men would not be guilty if they did not carry in their mind common notions of morality, innate and written in divine letters.

If I could only show, as I hope I shall . . . how men, barely by the use of their natural faculties, may attain to all the knowledge they have, without the help of any innate impressions; and may arrive at certainty without any such original notions or principles.

sn.def: Joined by the base to the very tip of a filament; as, an innate anther.

entry.def: To cause to exit; to call into being.

entry.def: Naturally.
The quality of being innate.
Native.

entry.def: Incapable of being navigated; impassable by ships or vessels.
In.
entry.q: And eke in what array that they were inne.

a fore-and-aft sail set on a stay running from the fore-topmast head to the jib boom.
the wall plate which lies nearest to the center of the roof, in a double-plated roof.
a piece brought on at the fore side of the main post, to support the transoms.
the angle formed by the inner edges of a carpenter's square.

Special activity excited in any part of the nervous system or in any organ of sense or motion; the nervous influence necessary for the maintenance of life, and the functions of the various organs.

The state or turn of being in; specifically, in cricket, baseball, etc., each period during which both teams get one turn each at bat; as, in baseball there are nine innings to a complete game;often in the pl.
The turn or time of a person, or a party, in power; as, the Whigs went out, and the Democrats had their innings .
Lands recovered from the sea.

The state or quality of being morally free from guilt or sin; purity of heart; blamelessness.
sn.q: The silence often of pure innocence Persuades when speaking fails.
Banished from man's life his happiest life, Simplicity and spotless innocence!

Simplicity or plainness, bordering on weakness or silliness; artlessness; ingenuousness.
sn.syn: Harmlessness; innocuousness; blamelessness; purity; sinlessness; guiltlessness.

entry.cs: Innocent party Law,a party who has not notice of a fact tainting a litigated transaction with illegality.
entry.ety: F. innocent, L. innocens -entis; pref. in- not + nocens, p. pr. of nocere to harm, hurt. See Noxious

sn.def: Not harmful; free from that which can injure; innoxious; innocuous; harmless; as, an innocent medicine or remedy.
sn.q: The spear Sung innocent, and spent its force in air.

sn.def: Morally free from guilt; guiltless; not tainted with sin; pure; upright.
sn.q: To offer up a weak, poor, innocent lamb.
I have sinned in that I have betrayed the innocent blood.
The aidless, innocent lady, his wished prey.

sn.def: Free from the guilt of a particular crime or offense; as, a man is innocent of the crime charged.
sn.q: Innocent from the great transgression.

sn.def: Simple; artless; foolish.
Lawful; permitted; as, an innocent trade.
Not contraband; not subject to forfeiture; as, innocent goods carried to a belligerent nation.
sn.syn: Harmless; innoxious; innoffensive; guiltless; spotless; immaculate; pure; unblamable; blameless; faultless; guileless; upright.

cs.cd: Childermas day.

sn.def: An innocent person; one free from, or unacquainted with, guilt or sin.
An unsophisticated person; hence, a child; a simpleton; an idiot.
sn.q: In Scotland a natural fool was called an innocent.

entry.def: In an innocent manner.
Innocuousness.

entry.ety: L. innocuus; in- not + nocuus hurtful, fr. nocere to hurt. See Innocent
entry.def: Harmless; producing no ill effect.
entry.q: A patient, innocuous, innocent man.
Where the salt sea innocuously breaks.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Innodated; p. pr. & vb. n. Innodating
entry.ety: L. innodatus, p. p. of innodare; pref. in- in + nodus knot
entry.def: To bind up, as in a knot; to include.

entry.ety: L. innominabilis; pref. in- not + nominare to name: cf. F. innominable
entry.def: Not to be named.

cs.cd: the great bone which makes a lateral half of the pelvis in mammals; hip bone; haunch bone; huckle bone. It is composed of three bones, ilium, ischium, and pubis, consolidated into one in the adult, though separate in the fetus, as also in many adult reptiles and amphibians.
in the Roman law, contracts without a specific name.

entry.ety: L. innominatus; pref. in- not + nominare to name

sn.def: Having no name; unnamed; as, an innominate person or place.
A term used in designating many parts otherwise unnamed; as, the innominate artery, a great branch of the arch of the aorta; the innominate vein, a great branch of the superior vena cava.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Innovated; p. pr. & vb. n. Innovating
entry.ety: L. innovatus, p. p. of innovare to revew; pref. in- in + novare to make new, fr. novus new. See New

sn.def: To bring in as new; to introduce as a novelty; as, to innovate a word or an act.
To change or alter by introducing something new; to remodel; to revolutionize.
sn.q: From his attempts upon the civil power, he proceeds to innovate God's worship.

entry.def: To introduce novelties or changes; -- sometimes with in or on.
entry.q: Every man, therefore, is not fit to innovate.

entry.ety: L. innovatio; cf. F. innovation

sn.def: The act of innovating; introduction of something new, in customs, rites, commercial products, etc.
A change effected by innovating; a change in customs; something new, and contrary to established customs, manners, or rites.
sn.q: The love of things ancient doth argue stayedness, but levity and lack of experience maketh apt unto innovations.

sn.def: A newly formed shoot, or the annually produced addition to the stems of many mosses.

entry.def: One who favors innovation.
Characterized by, or introducing, innovations.

entry.ety: Cf. F. innovateur
entry.def: One who innovates.

entry.ety: L. innoxius. See In- not, and Noxious

sn.def: Free from hurtful qualities or effects; harmless; innocuous.
sn.q: Innoxiousflames.

sn.def: Free from crime; pure; innocent.

entry.ety: L. innubilus. See Nubilous
entry.def: Cloudless.

entries.entry:
In`nu*en"do ☞ The term is so applied from having been the introductory word of this averment or parenthetic explanation when pleadings were in Latin. The word “meaning” is used as its equivalent in modern forms. An innuendo is an equivocal allusion so framed as to point distinctly at something which is injurious to the character or reputation of the person referred to. An insinuation turns on no such double use of language, but consists in artfully winding into the mind imputations of an injurious nature without making any direct charge. n.; pl.Innuedoes�). L., by intimation, by hinting, gerund of innuere innutum, to give a nod, to intimate; pref. in- in, to + -nuerein comp.) to nod. See Nutation
An oblique hint; a remote allusion or reference, usually derogatory to a person or thing not named; an insinuation. Mercury . . . owns it a marriage by an innuendo. Pursue your trade of scandal picking; Your innuendoes, when you tell us, That Stella loves to talk with fellows.
Law An averment employed in pleading, to point the application of matter otherwise unintelligible; an interpretative parenthesis thrown into quoted matter to explain an obscure word or words; -- as, the plaintiff avers that the defendant said that he (innuendo the plaintiff) was a thief. Insinuation; suggestion; hint; intimation; reference; allusion; implication; representation;Innuendo Insinuation.

entry.ety: L. innuens, p. pr
entry.def: Conveying a hint; significant.

entry.ety: Native name
entry.def: An Eskimo.

entry.ety: L. innumerabilitas
entry.def: State of being innumerable.

entry.ety: L. innumerabilis : cf. F. innumefable. See In- not, and Numerable
entry.def: Not capable of being counted, enumerated, or numbered, for multitude; countless; numberless; unnumbered, hence, indefinitely numerous; of great number.
entry.q: Innumerable as the stars of night.

entry.def: Lacking knowledge and understanding of mathematical concepts and methods; by analogy with illiterate. Opposite of numerate.

entry.ety: L. innumerosus innumerus. See Numerous
entry.def: Innumerable.
Lack of nutrition; failure of nourishment.
Not nutritious; not furnishing nourishment.
Innutritious.
The yard adjoining an inn.

entry.ety: L. inoboedientia : cf. F. inobedience
entry.def: Disobedience.

entry.ety: L. inoboediens, p. pr. of inoboedire : cf. F. inobedient. See Obedient
entry.def: Not obedient; disobedient.

entry.ety: L. inobservabilis : cf. F. inobservable. See In- not, and Observable
entry.def: Not observable.

entry.ety: L. inobservantia : cf. F. inobservance
entry.def: Lack or neglect of observance.

entry.ety: L. inobservans. See In- not, and Observant
entry.def: Not observant; regardless; heedless.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inobservation
entry.def: Neglect or lack of observation.
Not obtrusive; unobtrusive.

entry.ety: Gr. 'i`s 'ino`s, muscle + karpo`s fruit
entry.def: A red, gummy, coloring matter, extracted from the colorless juice of the Otaheite chestnut (Inocarpus edulis).
Lack of occupation.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'i`s 'ino`s, a muscle + � an earthen vessel
entry.def: An extinct genus of large, fossil, bivalve shells, allied to the mussels. The genus is characteristic of the Cretaceous period.
The quality or state of being inoculable.

entry.ety: See Inoculate
entry.def: Capable of being inoculated; capable of communicating disease, or of being communicated, by inoculation.
Inserted in the corner of the eye; -- said of the antennæ of certain insects.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inoculated; p. pr. & vb. n. Inoculating
entry.ety: L. inoculatus, p. p. of inoculare to ingraft; pref. in- in, on + oculare to furnish with eyes, fr. oculus an eye, also, a bud. See Ocular

sn.def: To bud; to insert, or graft, as the bud of a tree or plant in another tree or plant.
To insert a foreign bud into; as, to inoculate a tree.

To communicate a disease to (a person) by inserting infectious matter in the skin or flesh, especially as a means of inducing immunological resistance to that or related diseases; as, to inoculate a person with the virus of smallpox, rabies, etc. See Vaccinate.
Fig.: To introduce into the mind; -- used especially of harmful ideas or principles; to imbue; as, to inoculate one with treason or infidelity.

To introduce microorganisms into (a growth medium), to cause the growth and multiplication of the microorganisms; as, to inoculate a fermentation vat with an actinomycete culture in order to produce streptomycin.
To graft by inserting buds.
To communicate disease by inoculation.

entry.note: ☞ The use was formerly limited to the intentional communication of the smallpox, but is now extended to include any similar introduction of modified virus; as, the inoculation of rabies by Pasteur. The organisms inoculated are usually an attentuated form of the disease-causing organism, which may multiply harmlessly in the body of the host, but induce immunity to the more virulent forms of the organism.
entry.ety: L. inoculatio: cf. F. inoculation

sn.def: The act or art of inoculating trees or plants.
The act or practice of communicating a disease to a person in health, by inserting contagious matter in his skin or flesh, usually for the purpose of inducing immunity to the disease.
Fig.: The communication of principles, especially false principles, to the mind.
The introduction of microorganisms into a growth medium, to cause the growth and multiplication of the microorganisms.

entry.ety: L.: cf. F. inoculateur
entry.def: One who inoculates; one who propagates plants or diseases by inoculation.
The preparation of microorganisms which is inoculated{5} into a growth medium; as, a small inoculum may not work well for the production phase of a fermentation.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + L. odium hatred
entry.def: To make odious or hateful.
Inodorous; odorless.

entry.ety: L. inodorus. See In- not, and Odorous
entry.def: Emitting no odor; wthout smell; scentless; odorless.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + offensiue: cf. F. inoffensif

sn.def: Giving no offense, or provocation; causing no uneasiness, annoyance, or disturbance; as, an inoffensive man, answer, appearance.
Harmless; doing no injury or mischief.
Not obstructing; presenting no interruption or hindrance.
sn.q: So have I seen a river gently glide In a smooth course, and inoffensive tide.

entry.def: Not official; not having official sanction or authority; unofficial; not according to the forms or ceremony of official business; as, inofficial intelligence.
entry.q: Pinckney and Marshall would not make inofficial visits to discuss official business.
entry.syn: Private; informal; unwarranted; unauthorizod; irregular; unceremonious; unprofessional.

entry.def: Without the usual forms, or not in the official character; unofficially.

entry.ety: L. inofficiosus: cf. F. inofficieux. See In- not, and Officious

sn.def: Indifferent to obligation or duty.
sn.q: Thou drown'st thyself in inofficious sleep.

sn.def: Not officious; not civil or attentive.
Regardless of natural obligation; contrary to natural duty; unkind; -- commonly said of a testament made without regard to natural obligation, or by which a child is unjustly deprived of inheritance.
sn.q: Theinofficioustestament.
Aninofficiousdisposition of his fortune.

entry.def: Not officiously.

entry.ety: Gr. 'i`s 'ino`s, a muscle + -gen
entry.def: A complex nitrogenous substance, which, by Hermann's hypothesis, is continually decomposed and reproduced in the muscles, during their life.

entry.ety: L. inoperari to effect; pref. in- in + operari to operate
entry.def: Agency; influence; production of effects.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + operative
entry.def: Not operative; not active; producing no effects; as, laws renderd inoperative by neglect; inoperative remedies or processes.
Having no operculum; -- said of certain gastropod shells.

entry.ety: L. inopinabilis. See Inopinate
entry.def: Not to be expected; inconceivable.
entry.q: Inopinable, incredible . . . sayings.

entry.ety: L. inopinatus. See In- not, and Opine
entry.def: Not expected or looked for.

entry.ety: L. inopportunus: cf. F. inopportun. See In- not, and Opportune
entry.def: Not opportune; inconvenient; unseasonable; as, an inopportune occurrence, remark, etc.
entry.q: No visit could have been more inopportune.

entry.def: Not opportunely; unseasonably; inconveniently.
Lack of opportunity; unseasonableness; inconvenience.
Not oppressive or burdensome.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + opulent: cf. F. inopulent
entry.def: Not opulent; not affluent or rich.
The state or quality of being inordinate; excessiveness; immoderateness; as, the inordinacy of love or desire.

entry.ety: L. inordinatus disordered. See In- not, and Ordinate
entry.def: Not limited to rules prescribed, or to usual bounds; irregular; excessive; immoderate; as, an inordinate love of the world.
entry.q: Inordinatedesires.
Inordinatevanity.

entry.ety: L. inordinatio
entry.def: Deviation from custom, rule, or right; irregularity; inordinacy.
entry.q: Every inordination of religion that is not in defect, is properly called superstition.

entry.note: ☞ The term inorganic is used to denote any one the large series of substances (as minerals, metals, etc.), which are not directly connected with vital processes, either in origin or nature, and which are broadly and relatively contrasted with organic substances. See Organic5}.
entry.cs: Inorganic Chemistry. See under Chemistry.
entry.ety: Pref. in- not + organic: cf. F. inorganique

sn.def: Not organic; without the organs necessary for life; devoid of an organized structure; unorganized; lifeness; inanimate.
Of or pertaining to compounds that are not derivatives of hydrocarbons; not organic{5}.

entry.def: Inorganic.
In an inorganic manner.
Quality of being inorganic.
entry.q: Theinorganityof the soul.

entry.def: The state of being without organization.
Not having organic structure; devoid of organs; inorganic.
Deviation from correct orthography; bad spelling.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inosculated; p. pr. & vb. n. Inosculating
entry.ety: Pref. in- in + osculate

sn.def: To unite by apposition or contact, as two tubular vessels at their extremities; to anastomose.
To intercommunicate; to interjoin.
sn.q: The several monthly divisions of the journal may inosculate, but not the several volumes.

sn.def: To unite by apposition or contact, as two vessels in an animal body.
To unite intimately; to cause to become as one.
sn.q: They were still together, grewFor so they said themselvesinosculated.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inosculation
entry.def: The junction or connection of vessels, channels, or passages, so that their contents pass from one to the other; union by mouths or ducts; anastomosis; intercommunication; as, inosculation of veins, etc.

entry.ety: From Inosite
entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, inosite; as, inosinic acid.

A ribonucleoside (C10H12N4O5) found in meat and meat extracts, differing from adenosine in having a hydroxyl rather than an amine attached to the purine ring. It may be prepared from adenosine by the enzyme adenosine deaminase, or by chemical deamination, as with nitrous acid. It participates in some cellular functions, but is not one of the normal nucleoside components of RNA.

entry.ety: Gr. 'i`s 'ino`s, strength, muscle
entry.def: Same as inositol.

entry.ety: Gr. 'i`s 'ino`s, strength, muscle
entry.def: A white crystalline substance (C6H12O6) with a sweet taste, widely distributed in certain animal tissues and fluids, particularly in the muscles of the heart and lungs, and also in some plants, as in unripe pease, beans, potato sprouts, etc. Although isomeric with dextrose, it has no carbonyl (aldehyde or ketone) group, and is therefore not a carbohydrate, but a derivative of cyclohexane. Called also inosite cyclohexitol cyclohexanehexol hexahydroxycyclohexane and phaseomannite. There are nine possible steroisomers, not all of which are found naturally. The predominate natural form is cis-1,2,3,5-trans-4,6-cyclohexanehexol, also called myo-inositol. The naturally occurring phytic acid in plants is the hexaphosphate of inositol, from which inositol may be manufactured; phytin is the calcium-magnesium salt of phytic acid. It is also a component of phosphatidylinositol.
Incapable of being oxidized; as, gold and platinum are inoxidizable in the air.
To prevent or hinder oxidation, rust, or decay; as, inoxidizing oils or varnishes.
A patient who receives lodging and food, as well as treatment, in a hospital or an infirmary; -- distinguished from outpatient.
undertaken by an individual in person; as, an in-person appearance.

entries.entry: ‖In` pos"se. L In possibility; possible, although not yet in existence or come to pass; -- contradistinguished from in esse.

entry.def: Quartation.

cs.cd: an inquest held by a coroner to determine the cause of any violent, sudden, or mysterious death. See Coroner.
an inquiry made, by authority or direction of proper officer, into matters affecting the rights and interests of the crown or of the state.

entry.ety: OE. enqueste, OF. enqueste, F. enquête, LL. inquesta, for inquisita, fr. L. inquisitus, p. p. of inquirere. See Inquire

sn.def: Inquiry; quest; search.
sn.q: The laborious and vexatious inquest that the soul must make after science.

sd.def: Judicial inquiry; official examination, esp. before a jury; as, a coroner's inquest in case of a sudden death.

A body of men assembled under authority of law to inquire into any matter, civil or criminal, particularly any case of violent or sudden death; a jury, particularly a coroner's jury. The grand jury is sometimes called the grand inquest. See under Grand.
The finding of the jury upon such inquiry.

entry.ety: L. inquietare: cf. F. inquieter. See Quiet
entry.def: To disquiet.

entry.ety: L. inquietatio : cf. F. inquielation
entry.def: Disturbance.
Unquietness.

entry.ety: L. inquietudo: cf. F. inquietude
entry.def: Disturbed state; uneasiness either of body or mind; restlessness; disquietude.

entry.ety: L. inquilinus a tenant, lodger
entry.def: A gallfly which deposits its eggs in galls formed by other insects.

entry.ety: L. inquinatus, p. p. of inquinare to defile
entry.def: To defile; to pollute; to contaminate; to befoul.

entry.ety: L. inquinatio
entry.def: A defiling; pollution; stain.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. enquerable
entry.def: Capable of being inquired into; subject or liable to inquisition or inquest.
Inquiry.

entry.note: ☞ This word is followed by of before the person asked; as, to inquire of a neighbor. It is followed by concerning after, or about, before the subject of inquiry; as, his friends inquired about or concerning his welfare. “Thou dost not inquire wisely concerning this.” Eccl. vii. 10. It is followed by into when search is made for particular knowledge or information; as, to inquire into the cause of a sudden death. It is followed by for or after when a place or person is sought, or something is missing. “Inquire in the house of Judas for one called Saul of Tarsus.” Acts ix. 11.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inquired; p. pr. & vb. n. Inquiring
entry.ety: OE. enqueren inqueren, OF. enquerre, F. enquérir, L. inquirere inquisitum; pref. in- in + quarere to seek. See Quest a seeking, and cf. Inquiry

sn.def: To ask a question; to seek for truth or information by putting queries.
sn.q: We will call the damsel, and inquire.
Then David inquired of the Lord yet again. And the Lord answered him.

sn.def: To seek to learn anything by recourse to the proper means of knowledge; to make examination.
sn.q: And inquire Gladly into the ways of God with man.

sn.def: To ask about; to seek to know by asking; to make examination or inquiry respecting.
sn.q: Having thus at length inquired the truth concerning law and dispense.
And all obey and few inquire his will.

sn.def: To call or name.
sn.syn: To ask; question. See Question.

entry.ety: L. inquirens p. pr.
entry.def: Making inquiry; inquiring; questioning.

entry.ety: Written also enquirer
entry.def: One who inquires or examines; questioner; investigator.
entry.q: Expert inquirers after truth.

entry.def: Given to inquiry; disposed to investigate causes; curious; as, an inquiring mind.
In an inquiring manner.

entries.entry:
In*quir"y
Court of inquiry. See under Court. Writ of inquiry a writ issued in certain actions at law, where the defendant has suffered judgment to pass against him by default, in order to ascertain and assess the plaintiff's damages, where they can not readily be ascertained by mere calculation. Burrill.
n.; pl.Inquiries #. See Inquire
enquiry
The act of inquiring; a seeking for information by asking questions; interrogation; a question or questioning. He could no path nor track of foot descry, Nor by inquiry learn, nor guess by aim. The men which were sent from Cornelius had made inquiry for Simon's house, and stood before the gate.
Search for truth, information, or knowledge; examination into facts or principles; research; investigation; as, physical inquiries . All that is wanting to the perfection of this art will undoubtedly be found, if able men . . . will make inquiry into it. Interrogation; interrogatory; question; query; scrutiny; investigation; research; examination.

entry.def: Admitting judicial inquiry.

entry.ety: L. inquisitio : cf. F. inquisition. See Inquire, and cf. Inquest

sn.def: The act of inquiring; inquiry; search; examination; inspection; investigation.
sn.q: As I could learn through earnest inquisition.
Let not search and inquisition quail To bring again these foolish runaways.

sd.def: Judicial inquiry; official examination; inquest.
The finding of a jury, especially such a finding under a writ of inquiry.
sd.q: The justices in eyre had it formerly in charge to make inquisition concerning them by a jury of the county.

sn.def: A court or tribunal for the examination and punishment of heretics, fully established by Pope Gregory IX. in 1235. Its operations were chiefly confined to Spain, Portugal, and their dependencies, and a part of Italy.

entry.def: To make inquisition concerning; to inquire into.

entry.ety: LL. inquisitionalis
entry.def: Relating to inquiry or inquisition; inquisitorial; also, of or pertaining to, or characteristic of, the Inquisition.
entry.q: All the inquisitional rigor . . . executed upon books.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inquisitionnaire
