entry.def: Inquisitional.

entry.usage: Inquisitive Curious Prying. Curious denotes a feeling, and inquisitive a habit. We are curious when we desire to learn something new; we are inquisitive when we set ourselves to gain it by inquiry or research. Prying implies inquisitiveness, and is more commonly used in a bad sense, as indicating a desire to penetrate into the secrets of others.
entry.ety: OE. inquisitif, F. inquisitif

sn.def: Disposed to ask questions, especially in matters which do not concern the inquirer.
sn.q: A wise man is not inquisitive about things impertinent.

sn.def: Given to examination, investigation, or research; searching; curious.
sn.q: A young, inquisitive, and sprightly genius.
sn.syn: Inquiring; prying; curious; meddling; intrusive.
sn.q: Wecurious are to hear, What happens new.
This folio of four pages [a newspaper], happy work! Which not even critics criticise; that holdsInquisitive attention, while I read.
Nor need we with a prying eye survey The distant skies, to find the Milky Way.

entry.def: A person who is inquisitive; one curious in research.
In an inquisitive manner.
entry.q: The occasion that made him afterwards so inquisitively apply himself to the study of physic.

entry.def: The quality or state of being inquisitive; the disposition to seek explanation and information; curiosity to learn what is unknown; esp., uncontrolled and impertinent curiosity.
entry.q: Mr. Boswell, whose inquisitiveness is seconded by great activity, scrambled in at a high window.
Curiosity in children nature has provided, to remove that ignorance they were born with; which, without this busy inquisitiveness, will make them dull.

entry.ety: L.: cf. F. inquisiteur. See Inquire

sn.def: An inquisitive person; one fond of asking questions.
sn.q: Inquisitorsare tatlers.

sn.def: One whose official duty it is to examine and inquire, as coroners, sheriffs, etc.
A member of the Court of Inquisition.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inquisitorial

sn.def: Pertaining to inquisition; making rigorous and unfriendly inquiry; searching; as, inquisitorial power.
sn.q: Illiberal andinquisitorialabuse.
He conferred on it a kind of inquisitorial and censorious power even over the laity, and directed it to inquire into all matters of conscience.

sn.def: Pertaining to the Court of Inquisition or resembling its practices.
sn.q: Inquisitorialrobes.

entry.def: In an inquisitorial manner.
Making strict inquiry; inquisitorial.
Inquisitorial.
entry.q: Ourinquisiturientbishops.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + F. racine root: cf. F. enraciner
entry.def: To enroot or implant.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inrailed; p. pr. & vb. n. Inrailing
entry.def: To rail in; to inclose or surround, as with rails.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inregistered; p. pr. & vb. n. Inregistering
entry.ety: Pref. in- in + register: cf. F. enregistrer. Cf. Enregister
entry.def: To register; to enter, as in a register.

entries.entry: ‖In rem used: Of any right (called right in remorjus in rem) of such a nature as to be available over its subject without reference to one person more than another, or, as generally expressed, a right competent, or available, against all persons. Rights in rem include not alone rights over physical property, but all rights available against all persons indifferently, as those of life, liberty, and reputation. Of actions for recovering or reducing to possession or enjoyment a specific object, as in the enforcement of maritime liens against a vessel, which is made the defendant by a sort of personification. Most actions for the specific recovery of property in English and American law are in the nature of actions in personam against a person alleged to be unlawfully withholding the property.. L Law Lit., in or against a (or the) thing;

entry.ety: Jap. inrō; in seal + rō box
entry.def: A small closed receptacle or set of receptacles of hard material, as lacquered wood, iron, bronze, or ivory, used by the Japanese to hold medicines, perfumes, and the like, and carried in the girdle. It is usually secured by a silk cord by which the wearer may grasp it, which cord passes through an ornamental button or knob called a netsuke.
The entrance of an enemy into a country with purposes of hostility; a sudden or desultory incursion or invasion; raid; encroachment.
entry.q: The loss of Shrewsbury exposed all North Wales to the daily inroads of the enemy.
With perpetual inroads to alarm, Though inaccessible, his fatal throne.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inroaded; p. pr. & vb. n. Inroading
entry.def: To make an inroad into; to invade.
entry.q: The Saracens . . . conquered Spain, inroaded Aquitaine.

entry.def: See Enroll.
The act or the place of entrance; an inlet.
A rush inwards; as, the inrush of the tide.
To rush in.

entry.ety: LL. Insabatati. See 1st In-, and Sabot
entry.def: The Waldenses; -- so called from their peculiarly cut or marked sabots, or shoes.
Insecurity; danger.
The mixing of the food with the saliva and other secretions of the mouth in eating.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + salubrious: cf. L. insalubris, F. insalubre
entry.def: Not salubrious or healthful; unwholesome; as, an insalubrious air or climate.

entry.ety: Cf. F. insalubrite
entry.def: Unhealthfulness; unwholesomeness; as, the insalubrity of air, water, or climate.

entry.ety: L. insaluteris : cf. F. insalutaire. See In- not, and Salutary

sn.def: Not salutary or wholesome; unfavorable to health.
Not tending to safety; productive of evil.

entry.def: The state of being insanable or incurable; insanableness.

entry.ety: L. insanabilis; cf. OF. insanable. See In- not, and Sanable
entry.def: Not capable of being healed; incurable; irremediable.
The state of being insanable; insanability; incurableness.
In an incurable manner.

entry.ety: L. insanus. See In- not, and Sane

sn.def: Exhibiting unsoundness or disorder of mind; not sane; mad; deranged in mind; delirious; distracted. See Insanity, 2.
Used by, or appropriated to, insane persons; as, an insane hospital.
Causing insanity or madness.
sn.q: Or have we eaten on the insaneroot That takes the reason prisoner ?

sn.def: Characterized by insanity or the utmost folly; chimerical; unpractical; as, an insane plan, attempt, etc.
sn.q: I know not which was the insane measure.

entry.def: Without reason; madly; foolishly.
Insanity; madness.
To render unsound; to make mad.
Insanity.
Not sanitary; unhealthy; unsanitary; as, insanitary conditions of drainage.
Lack of sanitation; careless or dangerous hygienic conditions.

entry.usage: Insanity is the generic term for all such diseases; lunacy has now an equal extent of meaning, though once used to denote periodical insanity; madness has the same extent, though originally referring to the rage created by the disease; derangement alienation, are popular terms for insanity; delirium mania, and frenzy denote excited states of the disease; dementia denotes the loss of mental power by this means; monomania is insanity upon a single subject.
entry.ety: L. insanitas unsoundness; cf. insania insanity, F. insanite

sn.def: The state of being insane; unsoundness or derangement of mind; madness; lunacy.
sn.q: All power of fancy over reason is a degree of insanity.
Without grace The heart's insanity admits no cure.

sn.def: Such a mental condition, as, either from the existence of delusions, or from incapacity to distinguish between right and wrong, with regard to any matter under action, does away with individual responsibility.
sn.syn: Insanity Lunacy Madness Derangement Alienation Aberration Mania Delirium Frenzy Monomania Dementia.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + sapor
entry.def: Tasteless; unsavory.

entry.ety: L. insatiabilitas; cf. F. insatiabilite
entry.def: The state or quality of being insatiable; insatiableness.
entry.q: Eagerness for increase of possession deluges the soul, and we sink into the gulfs of insatiability.

entry.ety: F. insatiable, L. ionsatiabilis. See In- not, and Satiable
entry.def: Not satiable; incapable of being satisfied or appeased; very greedy; as, an insatiable appetite, thirst, or desire.
entry.q: “Insatiable of glory.”

entry.def: Greediness of appetite that can not be satisfied or appeased; insatiability.
entry.q: The eye of the covetous hath a more particular insatiableness.

entry.def: In an insatiable manner or degree; unappeasably.
entry.q: Insatiablycovetous.

entry.ety: L. insatiatus
entry.def: Insatiable; as, insatiate thirst.
entry.q: The insatiate greediness of his desires.
And still insatiate, thirsting still for blood.

entry.def: Insatiably.
The state of being insatiate.

entry.ety: L. insatietas: cf. F. insatiete. See Satiety
entry.def: Insatiableness.

sn.def: Insufficiency; emptiness.
Dissatisfaction.

entry.ety: L. insaturabilis: cf. F. insaturable. See In- not, and Saturable
entry.def: Not capable of being saturated or satisfied.

entry.ety: L. inscientia: cf. F. inscience
entry.def: Lack of knowledge; ignorance.

entry.ety: L. insciens -entis, ignorant. See In- not, and Scient Science
entry.def: Having little or no knowledge; ignorant; stupid; silly.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + L. sciens knowing
entry.def: Having knowledge or insight; intelligent.
entry.q: Gaze on, with inscient vision, toward the sun.

entry.def: See Ensconce.
Capable of being inscribed, -- used specif. Math of solids or plane figures capable of being inscribed in other solids or figures.
Quality of being inscribable.

entry.note: ☞ A line is inscribed in a circle, or in a sphere, when its two ends are in the circumference of the circle, or in the surface of the sphere. A triangle is inscribed in another triangle, when the three angles of the former are severally on the three sides of the latter. A circle is inscribed in a polygon, when it touches each side of the polygon. A sphere is inscribed in a polyhedron, when the sphere touches each boundary plane of the polyhedron. The latter figure in each case is circumscribed about the former.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inscribed; p. pr. & vb. n. Inscribing
entry.ety: L. inscribere. See 1st In-, and Scribe

sn.def: To write or engrave; to mark down as something to be read; to imprint.
sn.q: Inscribe a verse on this relenting stone.

sn.def: To mark with letters, characters, or words.
sn.q: O let thy once lov'd friend inscribe thy stone.

sn.def: To assign or address to; to commend to by a short address; to dedicate informally; as, to inscribe an ode to a friend.
To imprint deeply; to impress; to stamp; as, to inscribe a sentence on the memory.
To draw within so as to meet yet not cut the boundaries.

entry.def: One who inscribes.
Capable of being inscribed; inscribable.

entry.ety: L. inscriptio, fr. inscribere inscriptum, to inscribe: cf. F. inscription. See Inscribe

sn.def: The act or process of inscribing.

That which is inscribed; something written or engraved; especially, a word or words written or engraved on a solid substance for preservation or public inspection; as, inscriptions on monuments, pillars, coins, medals, etc.
A line of division or intersection; as, the tendinous inscriptions, or intersections, of a muscle.
An address, consignment, or informal dedication, as of a book to a person, as a mark of respect or an invitation of patronage.

entry.def: Bearing inscription; of the character or nature of an inscription.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inscrolled; p. pr. & vb. n. Inscrolling
entry.def: To write on a scroll; to record.
The quality or state of being inscrutable; inscrutableness.

entry.ety: L. inscrutabilis : cf. F. inscrutable. See In- not, and Scrutiny
entry.def: Unsearchable; incapable of being searched into and understood by inquiry or study; impossible or difficult to be explained or accounted for satisfactorily; obscure; incomprehensible; as, an inscrutable design or event.
entry.q: 'T is not in man To yield a reason for the will of Heaven Which is inscrutable.
Waiving a question so inscrutable as this.

entry.def: The quality or state of being inscrutable; inscrutability.
In an inscrutable manner.

entry.ety: L. insculpere: cf. F. insculper. See 1st In-, and Sculptor
entry.def: To engrave; to carve; to sculpture.
entry.q: Which he insculped in two likely stones.

entry.def: Inscription.
An engraving, carving, or inscription.
entry.q: On his gravestone this insculpture.

entry.def: Engraved.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inseamed; p. pr. & vb. n. Inseaming
entry.def: To impress or mark with a seam or cicatrix.

sn.def: An inside seam of an article of clothing; especially, the seam that runs from the crotch of a trouser leg down to the bottom.
The length of the inseam of a trouser leg.

entry.def: To make search after; to investigate or examine; to ensearch.

entry.ety: L. insecabilis; pref. in- not + secabilis that may be cut: cf. F. insecable
entry.def: Incapable of being divided by cutting; indivisible.

entry.note: ☞ The hexapod insects pass through three stages during their growth, viz., the larva, pupa, and imago or adult, but in some of the orders the larva differs little from the imago, except in lacking wings, and the active pupa is very much like the larva, except in having rudiments of wings. In the higher orders, the larva is usually a grub, maggot, or caterpillar, totally unlike the adult, while the pupa is very different from both larva and imago and is inactive, taking no food.
entry.cs: Insect powder,a powder used for the extermination of insects; esp., the powdered flowers of certain species of Pyrethrum, a genus now merged in Chrysanthemum. Called also Persian powder.
entry.ety: F. insecte, L. insectum, fr. insectus, p. p. of insecare to cut in. See Section. The name was originally given to certain small animals, whose bodies appear cut in, or almost divided. Cf. Entomology

sn.def: One of the Insecta; esp., one of the Hexapoda. See Insecta.
Any air-breathing arthropod, as a spider or scorpion.
Any small crustacean. In a wider sense, the word is often loosely applied to various small invertebrates.
Fig.: Any small, trivial, or contemptible person or thing.
Of or pertaining to an insect or insects.
Like an insect; small; mean; ephemeral.

entry.ety: NL. See Insect

sn.def: One of the classes of Arthropoda, including those that have one pair of antennæ, three pairs of mouth organs, and breathe air by means of tracheæ, opening by spiracles along the sides of the body. In this sense it includes the Hexapoda, or six-legged insects and the Myriapoda, with numerous legs. See Insect n.
In a more restricted sense, the Hexapoda alone. See Hexapoda.
In the most general sense, the Hexapoda, Myriapoda, and Arachnoidea, combined.

entry.def: A place for keeping living insects.

entry.ety: L. insectatio. See Insectator
entry.def: The act of pursuing; pursuit; harassment; persecution.

entry.ety: L., fr. insectari to pursue, freq. fr. insequi. See Ensue
entry.def: A pursuer; a persecutor; a censorious critic.
Pertaining to, having the nature of, or resembling, an insect.

entry.ety: Insect + L. caedere to kill
entry.def: An agent or preparation for destroying insects; an insect powder or spray.
Pertaining to, or having the nature of, insects.

entry.ety: See Insect
entry.def: A cutting in; incisure; incision.

entry.note: ☞ They are mostly of small size, and their molar teeth have sharp cusps. Most of the species burrow in the earth, and many of those of cold climates hibernate in winter. The order includes the moles, shrews, hedgehogs, tanrecs, and allied animals, also the colugo.
entry.ety: NL., from L. insectum an insect + vorare to devour

sn.def: An order of mammals which feed principally upon insects.
A division of the Chiroptera, including the common or insect-eating bats.

entries.entry: In*sec"ti*vore n.; pl.Insectivores -vōrz. F Zoöl One of the Insectivora.

In`sec*tiv"o*rous a. See Insectivora
Feeding or subsisting on insects; carnivorous. The term is applied: to plants which have some special adaptation for catching and digesting insects, as the sundew, Venus's flytrap, Sarracenia, etc. to the Insectivora, and many bats, birds, and reptiles.

entry.def: An entomologist.

entry.ety: Insect + -logy: cf. F. insectologie
entry.def: Entomology.

sn.def: Not secure; not confident of safety or permanence; distrustful; suspicious; apprehensive of danger or loss.
sn.q: With sorrow and insecure apprehensions.

sn.def: Not effectually guarded, protected, or sustained; unsafe; unstable; exposed to danger or loss.
sn.q: The trade with Egypt was exceedingly insecure and precarious.

entry.def: In an insecure manner.
Insecurity.

entries.entry:
In`se*cu"ri*ty n.; pl.Insecurities #. Pref. in- not + security : cf. LL. insecuritas, F. insecurite
The condition or quality of being insecure; lack of safety; danger; hazard; as, the insecurity of a building liable to fire; insecurity of a debt.
The state of feeling insecure; uncertainty; lack of confidence. With what insecurity of truth we ascribe effects . . . unto arbitrary calculations. A time of insecurity, when interests of all sorts become objects of speculation.

entry.ety: L. insecutio, fr. insequi p. p. insecutus. See Ensue
entry.def: A following after; close pursuit.

entry.ety: L. inseminatus, p. p. of inseminare to sow. See Seminate

sn.def: To sow seed into.
To sow seed into; to impregnate.
To implant in, as if sowing seed; as, to inseminate one's children with one's own prejudices; -- used mostly of ideas or attitudes..

entry.def: same as fertilized, 1.
A sowing.

entry.ety: L. insensatus. See In- not, and Sensate
entry.def: Wanting sensibility; destitute of sense; stupid; foolish.
entry.q: The silence and the calm Of mute, insensate things.
The meddling folly or insensate ambition of statesmen.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + sense
entry.def: To make to understand; to instruct.

entry.ety: Cf. F. insensibilité

sn.def: The state or quality of being insensible; lack of sensibility; torpor; unconsciousness; as, the insensibility produced by a fall, or by opiates.
Lack of tenderness or susceptibility of emotion or passion; dullness; stupidity.
sn.syn: Dullness; numbness; unfeelingness; stupidity; torpor; apathy; impassiveness; indifference.

entry.ety: L. insensibilis: cf. F. insensible. See In- not, and Sensible

sn.def: Destitute of the power of feeling or perceiving; wanting bodily sensibility; unconscious.
Not susceptible of emotion or passion; void of feeling; apathetic; unconcerned; indifferent; as, insensible to danger, fear, love, etc.; -- often used with of or to.
sn.q: Accept an obligation without being a slave to the giver, or insensible to his kindness.
Lost in their loves, insensible of shame.

sn.def: Incapable of being perceived by the senses; imperceptible. Hence: Progressing by imperceptible degrees; slow; gradual; as, insensible motion.
sn.q: Two small and almost insensible pricks were found upon Cleopatra's arm.
They fall away, And languish with insensible decay.

sn.def: Not sensible or reasonable; meaningless.
sn.q: If it make the indictment be insensible or uncertain, it shall be quashed.

sn.def: Incapable of feeling a specific sensation or emotion; as, insensible to pity.
sn.syn: Imperceptible; imperceivable; dull; stupid; torpid; numb; unfeeling; apathetic; stoical; impassive; indifferent; unsusceptible; hard; callous.

entry.def: Insensibility.
In a manner not to be felt or perceived; imperceptibly; gradually.
entry.q: The hills rise insensibly.

entry.def: Not sensitive; wanting sensation, or wanting acute sensibility.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + sensuous
entry.def: Not sensuous; not pertaining to, affecting, or addressing, the senses.
entry.q: That intermediate door Betwixt the different planes of sensuous form And form insensuous.

entry.def: The state or quality of being insentient; lacking consciousness or ability to perceive sensations.
Not sentient; not having perception, or the power of perception; devoid of feeling, consciousness and animation; inanimate; as, insentient stone. Opposite of sentient.
entry.q: The . . . attributes of an insentient, inert substance.
But there can be nothing like to this sensation in the rose, because it is insentient.

sn.def: incapable of sensation.
sn.syn: insensate, insensible.

entry.ety: L. inseparabilitas: cf. F. inséparabilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being inseparable; inseparableness.

entry.ety: L. inseparabilis: cf. F. inséparable. See In-, and Separable

sn.def: Not separable; incapable of being separated or disjoined.
sn.q: The history of every language is inseparable from that of the people by whom it is spoken.
Liberty and union, now and forever, one and inseparable.

sn.def: Invariably attached to some word, stem, or root; as, the inseparable particle un-.

entry.def: The quality or state of being inseparable; inseparability.
In an inseparable manner or condition; so as not to be separable.
entry.q: And cleaves through life inseparably close.

entry.ety: L. inseparatus. See In- not, and Separate
entry.def: Not separate; together; united.
Inseparably.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inserted; p. pr. & vb. n. Inserting
entry.ety: L. insertus, p. p. of inserere to insert; pref. in- in + serere to join, connect. See Series
entry.def: To set within something; to put or thrust in; to introduce; to cause to enter, or be included, or contained; as, to insert a scion in a stock; to insert a letter, word, or passage in a composition; to insert an advertisement in a newspaper.
entry.q: These words were very weakly inserted where they will be so liable to misconstruction.

entry.def: Situated upon, attached to, or growing out of, some part; -- said especially of the parts of the flower; as, the calyx, corolla, and stamens of many flowers are inserted upon the receptacle.

sn.def: A setting in.
Something inserted or set in, as lace, etc., in garments.

cs.cd: the insertion of stamens upon the ovary.
insertion beneath the ovary.

entry.ety: L. insertio: cf. F. insertion. See Insert

sn.def: The act of inserting; as, the insertion of scions in stocks; the insertion of words or passages in writings.
The condition or mode of being inserted or attached; as, the insertion of stamens in a calyx.

That which is set in or inserted, such as a word or passage in a composition, or a narrow strip of embroidered lace, muslin, or cambric; as, there were numerous insertions and corrections to the first draft.
The point or part by which a muscle or tendon is attached to the part to be moved; -- in contradistinction to its origin.

entry.ety: L. inservire; in- in + servire to serve
entry.def: To be of use to an end; to serve.

entry.ety: L. inserviens, p. pr. of inservire
entry.def: Conducive; instrumental.

entry.ety: L. insessio, fr. insidere insessum, to sit in. See Insidious

sn.def: The act of sitting, as in a tub or bath.
sn.q: Used by way of fomentation,insession, or bath.

sn.def: That in which one sits, as a bathing tub.
sn.q: Insessions be bathing tubs half full.

entries.entry:
‖In*ses"sor n.; pl.Insessores #. See Insessores
Zoöl One of the Insessores. The group includes most of the common singing birds.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. insessor, lit., one who sits down, fr. incidere. See Insession
entry.def: An order of birds, formerly established to include the perching birds, but now generally regarded as an artificial group.

sn.def: Pertaining to, or having the character of, perching birds.
Belonging or pertaining to the Insessores.

entry.def: To infix.

sn.def: That which is inserted or set in; an insertion.

entry.sn:
Bookbinding One or more separate leaves inserted in a volume before binding; as: A portion of the printed sheet in certain sizes of books which is cut off before folding, and set into the middle of the folded sheet to complete the succession of paging; -- also called offcut.
A page or pages of advertisements inserted.

entry.def: Incapable of being severed; indivisible; inseparable.
Marked with different shades.
A plane for shaving or dressing the concave or inside faces of barrel staves.
To insert as in a sheath; to sheathe.
To hide in a shell.
To embark.
Being near or moving towards the shore; as, inshore fisheries; inshore currents.

def2.def: Towards the shore; as, the boat was headed inshore .

entry.def: See Enshrine.
The act or process of drying in.

entries.entry: In"side` prep. or adv. Within the sides of; in the interior; contained within; as, inside a house, book, bottle, etc.

cs.cd: callipers for measuring the diameters of holes, etc.

a general term for the final work in any building necessary for its completion, but other than unusual decoration; thus, in joiner work, the doors and windows, inside shutters, door and window trimmings, paneled jams, baseboards, and sometimes flooring and stairs; in plaster work, the finishing coat, the cornices, centerpieces, etc.,; in painting, all simple painting of woodwork and plastering.
the inner part of a race course; hence, colloquially, advantage of place, facilities, contacts, etc., in competition.

sn.def: Being within; included or inclosed in anything; contained; interior; internal; as, the inside passengers of a stagecoach; inside decoration.
sn.q: Kissing with inside lip.

sn.def: Adapted to the interior.

cs.cd: a name give to newspaper sheets printed on one side with general and miscellaneous matter, and furnished wholesale to offices of small newspapers, where the blank pages are filled up with recent and local news.

sn.def: The part within; interior or internal portion; content.
sn.q: Looked he o' the inside of the paper?

sn.def: The inward parts; entrails; bowels; hence, that which is within; private thoughts and feelings.
sn.q: Here's none but friends; we may speak Our insides freely.

sn.def: An inside passenger of a coach or carriage, as distinguished from one upon the outside.
sn.q: So down thy hill, romantic Ashbourne, glides The Derby dilly, carrying three insides.

entry.note: An insider is forbidden by U. S. securities laws to trade stock in publicly owned corporations based on the private information. The definition of insider for the purpose of securities law has changed in the late 29th century to become more inclusive, whereas it initially was applied only to officers of a corporation.
entry.def: an officer of a corporation or others who have access to private information about the corporation's operations, especially information relating to profitability.

entry.ety: L. insidiatus, p. p. of insidiare to lie in ambush, fr. insidiae. See Insidious
entry.def: To lie in ambush for.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who lies in ambush.

cs.cd: a disease existing, without marked symptoms, but ready to become active upon some slight occasion; a disease not appearing to be as bad as it really is.

entry.ety: L. insidiosus, fr. insidiae an ambush, fr. insidere to sit in; pref. in- + sedere to sit: cf. F. insidieux. See Sit

sn.def: Lying in wait; watching an opportunity to insnare or entrap; deceitful; sly; treacherous; -- said of persons; as, the insidious foe.
sn.q: Theinsidiouswitch.

sn.def: Intended to entrap; characterized by treachery and deceit; as, insidious arts.
sn.q: The insidious whisper of the bad angel.

sn.def: Acting or proceeding unobserved or in a seemingly harmless manner, but slowly or eventually doing great damage; as, an insidious disease; an insidious plot.
sn.syn: Crafty; wily; artful; sly; designing; guileful; circumventive; treacherous; deceitful; deceptive.

entry.def: A subtle and cumulative harmfulness, especially of a disease.

sn.def: the quality of being designed to entrap.
A sight or view of the interior of anything; a deep inspection or view; introspection; -- frequently used with into.
sn.q: He had an insight into almost all the secrets of state.

sn.def: Power of acute observation and deduction; penetration; discernment; perception.
sn.q: Quickest insight In all things that to greatest actions lead.

sn.def: having intellectual depth; having or showing an exceptional degree of insight{2}; -- of people or their comments.
sn.syn: thoughtful.

sn.def: characterized by sympathetic understanding.
sn.syn: discerning, understanding.

sn.def: having a keen intellect.
sn.syn: prehensile.

entry.def: keen insight{2}.

entry.ety: L. insigne, pl. insignia, fr. insignis distinguished by a mark; pref. in- in + signum a mark, sign. See Ensign Sign

sn.def: Distinguishing marks of authority, office, or honor; badges; tokens; decorations; as, the insignia of royalty or of an order.
Typical and characteristic marks or signs, by which anything is known or distinguished; as, the insignia of a trade.
The condition or quality of being insignificant; lack of significance, sense, or meaning; as, the insignificance of words or phrases.
Lack of force or effect; unimportance; pettiness; inefficacy; as, the insignificance of human art.
Lack of claim to consideration or notice; lack of influence or standing; meanness.
sn.q: Reduce him, from being the first person in the nation, to a state of insignificance.

entry.def: Insignificance.

sn.def: Not significant; void of signification, sense, or import; meaningless; as, insignificant words.
Having no weight or effect; answering no purpose; unimportant; valueless; futile.
sn.q: Laws must be insignificant without the sanction of rewards and punishments.

sn.def: Without weight of character or social standing; mean; contemptible; as, an insignificant person.
sn.syn: Unimportant; immaterial; inconsiderable; small; inferior; trivial; mean; contemptible.

entry.def: without significance, importance, or effect; to no purpose.
entry.q: Angerinsignificantlyfierce.

entry.ety: L. insignificativus. See In- not, and Significative
entry.def: Not expressing meaning; not significant.

entry.ety: See Insignia
entry.def: A token, mark, or explanation.

entry.ety: L. insimulatus, p. p. of insimulare to accuse
entry.def: To accuse.

entry.ety: L. insincerus. See In- not, and Sincere

sn.def: Not being in truth what one appears to be; not sincere; dissembling; hypocritical; disingenuous; deceitful; false; -- said of persons; also of speech, thought; etc.; as, insincere declarations.
Disappointing; imperfect; unsound.
sn.q: To render sleep's soft blessings insincere.
sn.syn: Dissembling; hollow; hypocritical; deceptive deceitful; false; disingenuous; untrustworthy.

entry.def: Without sincerity.

entry.ety: Cf. F. insincérité
entry.def: The quality of being insincere; lack of sincerity, or of being in reality what one appears to be; dissimulation; hypocritical; deceitfulness; hollowness; untrustworthiness; as, the insincerity of a professed friend; the insincerity of professions of regard.
entry.q: What men call policy and knowledge of the world, is commonly no other thing than dissimulation and insincerity.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Insinewed; p. pr. & vb. n. Insinewing
entry.def: To strengthen, as with sinews; to invigorate.
entry.q: All members of our cause, . . . That are insinewed to this action.

entry.ety: L. insinuans, p. pr.: cf. F. insinuant
entry.def: Insinuating; insinuative.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Insinuated; p. pr. & vb. n. Insinuating
entry.ety: L. insinuatus, p. p. of insinuareto insinuate; pref. in- in + sinus the bosom. See Sinuous

sn.def: To introduce gently or slowly, as by a winding or narrow passage, or a gentle, persistent movement.
sn.q: The water easily insinuates itself into, and placidly distends, the vessels of vegetables.

sn.def: To introduce artfully; to infuse gently; to instill.
sn.q: All the art of rhetoric, besides order and clearness, are for nothing else but to insinuate wrong ideas, move the passions, and thereby mislead the judgment.
Horace laughs to shame all follies and insinuates virtue, rather by familiar examples than by the severity of precepts.

sn.def: To hint; to suggest by remote allusion; -- often used derogatorily; as, did you mean to insinuate anything?
To push or work (one's self), as into favor; to introduce by slow, gentle, or artful means; to ingratiate; -- used reflexively.
sn.q: He insinuated himself into the very good grace of the Duke of Buckingham.
sn.syn: To instill; hint; suggest; intimate.

sn.def: To creep, wind, or flow in; to enter gently, slowly, or imperceptibly, as into crevices.
To ingratiate one's self; to obtain access or favor by flattery or cunning.
sn.q: He would insinuate with thee but to make thee sigh.
To insinuate, flatter, bow, and bend my limbs.

entry.def: Winding, creeping, or flowing in, quietly or stealthily; suggesting; winning favor and confidence insensibly.
entry.q: His address was courteous, and even insinuating.

entry.def: By insinuation.

entry.ety: L. insinuatio: cf. F. insinuation

sn.def: The act or process of insinuating; a creeping, winding, or flowing in.
sn.q: By a soft insinuation mix'd With earth's large mass.

sn.def: The act of gaining favor, affection, or influence, by gentle or artful means; -- formerly used in a good sense, as of friendly influence or interposition.
sn.q: I hope through the insinuation of Lord Scarborough to keep them here till further orders.

sn.def: The art or power of gaining good will by a prepossessing manner.
sn.q: He bad a natural insinuation and address which made him acceptable in the best company.

sn.def: That which is insinuated; a hint; a suggestion or intimation by distant allusion; as, slander may be conveyed by insinuations .
sn.q: I scorn your coarse insinuation.
sn.syn: Hint; intimation; suggestion. See Innuendo.

entry.ety: Cf. F. insinuatif

sn.def: Stealing on or into the confidence or affections; having power to gain favor.
sn.q: Crafty,insinuative, plausible men.

sn.def: Using insinuations; giving hints; insinuating; as, insinuative remark.

entry.ety: L., an introducer
entry.def: One who, or that which, insinuates.
Insinuative.

entry.ety: L. insipidus; pref. in- not + sapidus savory, fr. sapere to taste: cf. F. insipide. See Savor

sn.def: Wanting in the qualities which affect the organs of taste; without taste or savor; vapid; tasteless; as, insipid drink or food.
Wanting in spirit, life, or animation; uninteresting; weak; vapid; flat; dull; heavy; as, an insipid woman; an insipid composition.
sn.q: Flat, insipid, and ridiculous stuff to him.
But his wit is faint, and his salt, if I may dare to say so, almost insipid.
sn.syn: Tasteless; vapid; dull; spiritless; unanimated; lifeless; flat; stale; pointless; uninteresting.

entry.ety: Cf. F. insipidité
entry.def: The quality or state of being insipid; vapidity.
entry.q: Dryden's lines shine strongly through theinsipidityof Tate's.

entry.def: In an insipid manner; without taste, life, or spirit; flatly.

entry.ety: L. insipientia: cf. OF. insipience
entry.def: Lack of intelligence; stupidity; folly.

entry.ety: L. insipiens; pref. in- not + sapiens wise
entry.def: Wanting wisdom; stupid; foolish.

entry.usage: Insist implies some alleged right, as authority or claim. Persist may be from obstinacy alone, and either with or against rights. We insist as against others; we persist in what exclusively relates to ourselves; as, he persisted in that course; he insisted on his friend's adopting it.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Insisted; p. pr. & vb. n. Insisting
entry.ety: F. insister, L. insistere to set foot upon, follow, persist; pref. in- in + sistere to stand, cause to stand. See Stand

sn.def: To stand or rest; to find support; -- with in on, or upon.

To take a stand and refuse to give way; to hold to something firmly or determinedly; to be persistent, urgent, or pressing; to persist in demanding; -- followed by on upon, or that; as, he insisted on these conditions; he insisted on going at once; he insists that he must have money.
sn.q: Insisting on the old prerogative.
Without further insisting on the different tempers of Juvenal and Horace.
sn.syn: Insist Persist.

entry.def: The quality of insisting, or being urgent or pressing; the act of dwelling upon as of special importance; persistence; urgency.
the state of urgently demanding notice or attention; insistence.

sn.def: the quality of not being ignorable.
sn.syn: imperativeness, insistence.

entry.ety: L. insistens -entis, p. pr. of insistere

sn.def: Standing or resting on something; as, an insistent wall.
Insisting; persistent; persevering.
See Incumbent.

entry.def: In an insistent manner.
A dwelling or standing on something; fixedness; persistence.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + L. sitiens, p. pr. of sitire to be thirsty, fr. sitis thirst
entry.def: Freedom from thirst.
entry.q: The insitiency of a camel for traveling in deserts.

entry.ety: L. insitio, fr. inserere insitum, to sow or plant in, to ingraft; pref. in- in + serere satum, to sow
entry.def: The insertion of a scion in a stock; ingraftment.

entry.ety: L

sn.def: In its natural or original position or place; in position; -- said specif., in geology, of a rock, soil, or fossil, when in the situation in which it was originally formed or deposited.
In its original position; not extending beyond the place of origin; localized and undisturbed; as, carcinoma in situ .

entry.def: being in the original position; not having been moved or transferred to another location; as, an in-situ investigator.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Insnared; p. pr. & vb. n. Insnaring
entry.ety: Written also ensnare

sn.def: To catch in a snare; to entrap; to take by artificial means.
sn.q: Insnarea gudgeon.

sn.def: To take by wiles, stratagem, or deceit; to involve in difficulties or perplexities; to seduce by artifice; to inveigle; to allure; to entangle.
sn.q: The insnaring charms Of love's soft queen.

entry.def: One who insnares.
To make into a snarl or knot; to entangle; to snarl.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + �obriety: cf. F. insobriété
entry.def: Lack of sobriety, moderation, or calmness; intemperance; drunkenness.

entry.ety: Cf. F. insociabilité
entry.def: The quality of being insociable; lack of sociability; unsociability.

entry.ety: L. insociabilis: cf. F. insociable. See In- not, and Sociable

sn.def: Incapable of being associated, joined, or connected.
sn.q: Lime and wood are insociable.

sn.def: Not sociable or companionable; disinclined to social intercourse or conversation; unsociable; taciturn.
sn.q: This austere insociable life.

entry.def: Unsociably.
Not associate; without a companion; single; solitary; recluse.
entry.q: Theinsociatevirgin life.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Insolated; p. pr. & vb. n. Insolating
entry.ety: L. insolatus, p. p. of insolare to expose to the sun; pref. in- in + sol the sun
entry.def: To dry in, or to expose to, the sun's rays; to ripen or prepare by such exposure.

entry.ety: L. insolatio: cf. F. insolation

sn.def: The act or process to exposing to the rays of the sun for the purpose of drying or maturing, as fruits, drugs, etc., or of rendering acid, as vinegar.

sd.def: A sunstroke.
Exposure of a patient to the sun's rays; a sun bath.

sn.def: The amount of sunlight impinging on the Earth's surface.

entry.def: The inside sole of a boot or shoe; also, a loose, thin strip of leather, felt, etc., placed inside the shoe for warmth or ease.

entry.ety: F. insolence, L. insolentia. See Insolent

sn.def: The quality of being unusual or novel.
The quality of being insolent; pride or haughtiness manifested in contemptuous and overbearing treatment of others; arrogant contempt; brutal impudence.
sn.q: Flown with insolence and wine.

sn.def: Insolent conduct or treatment; insult.
sn.q: Loaded with fetters and insolences from the soldiers.

entry.def: To insult.
Insolence.

entry.usage: Insolent Insulting. Insolent, in its primitive sense, simply denoted unusual; and to act insolently was to act in violation of the established rules of social intercourse. He who did this was insolent; and thus the word became one of the most offensive in our language, indicating gross disregard for the feelings of others. Insulting denotes a personal attack, either in words or actions, indicative either of scorn or triumph. Compare Impertinent Affront Impudence.
entry.ety: F. insolent, L. insolens -entis, pref. in- not + solens accustomed, p. pr. of solere to be accustomed

sn.def: Deviating from that which is customary; novel; strange; unusual.
sn.q: If one chance to derive any word from the Latin which is insolent to their ears . . . they forthwith make a jest at it.
If any should accuse me of being new or insolent.

sn.def: Haughty and contemptuous or brutal in behavior or language; overbearing; domineering; grossly rude or disrespectful; saucy; as, an insolent master; an insolent servant.
sn.q: A paltry,insolentfellow.
Insolent is he that despiseth in his judgment all other folks as in regard of his value, of his cunning, of his speaking, and of his bearing.
Can you not see? or will ye not observe . . . How insolent of late he is become, How proud, how peremptory?

sn.def: Proceeding from or characterized by insolence; insulting; as, insolent words or behavior.
sn.q: Their insolent triumph excited . . . indignation.
sn.syn: Overbearing; insulting; abusive; offensive; saucy; impudent; audacious; pert; impertinent; rude; reproachful; opprobrious.

entry.def: In an insolent manner.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + solidity: cf. F. insolidité
entry.def: Lack of solidity; weakness; as, the insolidity of an argument.

entry.ety: L. insolubilitas: cf. F. insolubilité

sn.def: The quality or state of being insoluble or not dissolvable, as in a fluid.
The quality of being inexplicable or insolvable.

entry.ety: L. insolubilis indissoluble, that can not be loosed: cf. F. insoluble. See In- not, and Soluble, and cf. Insolvable

sn.def: Not soluble; in capable or difficult of being dissolved, as by a liquid; as, chalk is insoluble in water.
Not to be solved or explained; insolvable; as, an insoluble doubt, question, or difficulty.
Strong.
sn.q: Aninsolublewall.

entry.def: The quality or state of being insoluble; insolubility.

sn.def: Not solvable; insoluble; admitting no solution or explanation; as, an insolvable problem or difficulty.
Incapable of being paid or discharged, as debts.
Not capable of being loosed or disentangled; inextricable.
sn.q: Bandsinsolvable.

entries.entry:
In*sol"ven*cy
Act of insolvency. See Insolvent law under Insolvent a.
n.; pl.Insolvencies. Law The condition of being insolvent; the state or condition of a person who is insolvent; the condition of one who is unable to pay his debts as they fall due, or in the usual course of trade and business; as, a merchant's insolvency . Insufficiency to discharge all debts of the owner; as, the insolvency of an estate.

cs.cd: a law affording relief, -- subject to various modifications in different States, -- to insolvent debtors, upon their delivering up their property for the benefit of their creditors; bankruptcy law. See Bankrupt law, under Bankrupt a.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + solvent: cf. OF. insolvent
entry.def: Not solvent; not having sufficient estate to pay one's debts; unable to pay one's debts as they fall due, in the ordinary course of trade and business; as, in insolvent debtor.
Not sufficient to pay all the debts of the owner; as, an insolvent estate.
Relating to persons unable to pay their debts.
One who is insolvent; as insolvent debtor; -- in England, before 1861, especially applied to persons not traders.

entry.ety: L., fr. insomnis sleepless; pref. in- not + somnus sleep
entry.def: Lack of sleep; inability to sleep, especially when chronic; wakefulness; sleeplessness.

entry.ety: L. insomniosus, fr. insomnia insomnia
entry.def: Restless; sleepless.
Sleeplessness.
So; to such a degree; in such wise; -- followed by that or as, and formerly sometimes by both. Cf. Inasmuch.
entry.q: Insomusch as that field is called . . . Aceldama.
Simonides was an excellent poet, insomuch that he made his fortune by it.

entry.def: Not clear or melodious.
In sooth; truly.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Carelessness; heedlessness; thoughtlessness; unconcern.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Careless; heedless; indifferent; unconcerned.
To set a soul in; reflexively, to fix one's strongest affections on.
entry.q: He] could not but insoul himself in her.

entry.ety: D. inspannen
entry.def: To yoke or harness, as oxen to a vehicle.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inspected; p. pr. & vb. n. Inspecting
entry.ety: L. inspectus, p. p. of inspicere to inspect; pref. in- in + specere to look at, to view: cf. F. inspecter, fr. L. inspectare, freq. fr. inspicere. See Spy

sn.def: To look upon; to view closely and critically, esp. in order to ascertain quality or condition, to detect errors, etc., to examine; to scrutinize; to investigate; as, to inspect conduct.
To view and examine officially, as troops, arms, goods offered, work done for the public, etc.; to oversee; to superintend.

entry.ety: L. inspectus. See Inspect v. t.
entry.def: Inspection.

cs.cd: a mode of trial in which the case was settled by the individual observation and decision of the judge upon the testimony of his own senses, without the intervention of a jury.

entry.ety: L. inspectio: cf. F. inspection

sn.def: The act or process of inspecting or looking at carefully; a strict or prying examination; close or careful scrutiny; investigation.
sn.q: With narrow search, and with inspection deep, Considered every creature.

sn.def: The act of overseeing; official examination or superintendence.

entry.ety: L. inspectivus
entry.def: Engaged in inspection; inspecting; involving inspection.

cs.cd: a staff officer of an army, whose duties are those of inspection, and embrace everything relative to organization, recruiting, discharge, administration, accountability for money and property, instruction, police, and discipline.

entry.ety: L.: cf. F. inspecteur

sn.def: One who inspects, views, or oversees; one to whom the supervision of any work is committed; one who makes an official view or examination, as a military or civil officer; a superintendent; a supervisor; an overseer.
A police officer, typically holding a rank one below superintendent, and in some cases in charge of several precincts; as, inspector Clousseau is investigating the case.

entry.def: Inspectorship.
Of or pertaining to an inspector or to inspection.

sn.def: The office of an inspector.
The district embraced by an inspector's jurisdiction.

entry.def: A female inspector.

entry.ety: L. inspersus, p. p. of inspergere to sprinkle upon; pref. in- in, on + spargere to sprinkle
entry.def: To sprinkle; to scatter.

entry.ety: L. inspersio
entry.def: The act of sprinkling.

entry.ety: L., we have inspected
entry.def: The first word of ancient charters in England, confirming a grant made by a former king; hence, a royal grant.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Insphered; p. pr. & vb. n. Insphering
entry.ety: Cf. Ensphere
entry.def: To place in, or as in, an orb a sphere. Cf. Ensphere.
entry.q: Bright aërial spirits live insphered In regions mild of calm and serene air.

entry.def: Capable of being inspired or drawn into the lungs; inhalable; respirable; admitting inspiration.

cs.cd: that kind of inspiration which excludes all defect in the utterance of the inspired message.
that kind of inspiration which extends to the very words and forms of expression of the divine message.

entry.ety: F. inspiration, L. inspiratio. See Inspire

sn.def: The act of inspiring or breathing in; breath; specif. Physiol, the drawing of air into the lungs, accomplished in mammals by elevation of the chest walls and flattening of the diaphragm; -- the opposite of expiration.

The act or power of exercising an elevating or stimulating influence upon the intellect or emotions; the result of such influence which quickens or stimulates; as, the inspiration of occasion, of art, etc.
sn.q: Your father was ever virtuous, and holy men at their death have good inspirations.

sn.def: A supernatural divine influence on the prophets, apostles, or sacred writers, by which they were qualified to communicate moral or religious truth with authority; a supernatural influence which qualifies men to receive and communicate divine truth; also, the truth communicated.
sn.q: All Scripture is given by inspiration of God.
The age which we now live in is not an age of inspiration and impulses.

sn.def: Pertaining to inspiration.
Imparting inspiration{2}; as, an inspirational sermon.

entry.def: One who holds to inspiration.
A kind of injector for forcing water by steam. See Injector n., 2.
Pertaining to, or aiding, inspiration; as, the inspiratory muscles.

entry.ety: OE. enspiren, OF. enspirer inspirer, F. inspirer, fr. L. inspirare; pref. in- in + spirare to breathe. See Spirit

sn.def: To breathe into; to fill with the breath; to animate.
sn.q: When Zephirus eek, with his sweete breath,Inspirèd hath in every holt and heath The tender crops.
Descend, ye Nine, descend and sing, The breathing instruments inspire.

sn.def: To infuse by breathing, or as if by breathing.
sn.q: He knew not his Maker, and him that inspired into him an active soul.

sn.def: To draw in by the operation of breathing; to inhale; -- opposed to expire.
sn.q: Forced to inspire and expire the air with difficulty.

sn.def: To infuse into the mind; to communicate to the spirit; to convey, as by a divine or supernatural influence; to disclose preternaturally; to produce in, as by inspiration.
sn.q: And generous stout courage did inspire.
But dawning day new comfort hath inspired.

sn.def: To infuse into; to affect, as with a superior or supernatural influence; to fill with what animates, enlivens, or exalts; to communicate inspiration to; as, to inspire a child with sentiments of virtue; to inspire a person to do extraordinary feats.
sn.q: Erato, thy poet's mind inspire, And fill his soul with thy celestial fire.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inspired; p. pr. & vb. n. Inspiring

sn.def: To draw in breath; to inhale air into the lungs; -- opposed to expire.
To breathe; to blow gently.
sn.q: And when the wind amongst them did inspire, They wavèd like a penon wide dispread.

sn.def: Breathed in; inhaled.
Moved or animated by, or as by, a supernatural influence; affected by divine inspiration; as, the inspired prophets; the inspired writers.

Communicated or given as by supernatural or divine inspiration; having divine authority; hence, sacred, holy; -- opposed to uninspired profane, or secular; as, the inspired writings, that is, the Scriptures.
Moved to a higher level of thought, creativity, or motivation.

entry.def: One who, or that which, inspires.
entry.q: Inspirerof that holy flame.

entry.def: Animating; cheering; moving; exhilarating; as, an inspiring or scene.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inspirited; p. pr. & vb. n. Inspiriting
entry.def: To infuse new life or spirit into; to animate; to encourage; to invigorate.
entry.q: The courage of Agamemnon is inspirited by the love of empire and ambition.
entry.syn: To enliven; invigorate; exhilarate; animate; cheer; encourage; inspire.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inspissated; p. pr. & vb. n. Inspissating
entry.ety: L. inspissatus, p. p. of inspissare to thicken; pref. in- + spissare to thicken, fr. spissus thick
entry.def: To thicken or bring to greater consistence, as fluids by evaporation.

entry.ety: L. inspissatus, p. p
entry.def: Thick or thickened; inspissated.
The act or the process of inspissating, or thickening a fluid substance, as by evaporation; also, the state of being so thickened.

entry.ety: abbreviation for instant
entry.def: in or of the present month; same as instant3}, a. or instant2}, n.; as, your letter of the 10th inst. .

entries.entry:
In`sta*bil"i*ty n.; pl.Instabilities #. L. instabilitas: cf. F. instabilité
The quality or condition of being unstable; lack of stability, firmness, or steadiness; liability to give way or to fail; insecurity; precariousness; as, the instability of a building.
Lack of determination of fixedness; inconstancy; fickleness; mutability; changeableness; as, instability of character, temper, custom, etc.
Inconstancy; fickleness; changeableness; wavering; unsteadiness; unstableness.

entry.ety: L. instabilis: cf. F. instable. See In- not, and Stable a., and cf. Unstable
entry.def: Not stable; not standing fast or firm; unstable; prone to change or recede from a purpose; mutable; inconstant.
Instability; unstableness.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Installed; p. pr. & vb. n. Installing
entry.ety: F. installer, LL. installare, fr. pref. in- in + OHG. stal a place, stall, G. stall, akin to E. stall: cf. It. installare. See Stall

sn.def: To set in a seat; to give a place to; establish (one) in a place.
sn.q: She installed her guest hospitably by the fireside.

sn.def: To place in an office, rank, or order; to invest with any charge by the usual ceremonies; to instate; to induct; as, to install an ordained minister as pastor of a church; to install a college president.
sn.q: Unworthily Thou wast installed in that high degree.

entry.ety: F. installation, LL. installatio: cf. It. installazione. See Install

sn.def: The act of installing; as, the installation of the air conditioner took half an hour.
sn.syn: installing, setting up.

sn.def: the act of installing (a person) or giving possession of an office, rank, or order, with the usual rites or ceremonies; as, the installation of an ordained minister in a parish.
sn.q: On the election, the bishop gives a mandate for his installation.

sn.def: The whole of a system of machines, apparatus, and accessories, sometimes including the buildings and gorounds on which they are located, when set up and arranged for practical working, as in electric lighting, transmission of power, etc.; as, our installation in Baton Rouge can produce ten thousand gallons a day; we should move our drying installation from building A to building B.
The whole of a military base, post, camp, outpost, etc., constructed and operated for support of military operations.
the act of installing something (as equipment).
sn.syn: installation, setting up.

sn.def: The act of installing; installation.
sn.q: Take oaths from all kings and magistrates at their installment, to do impartial justice by law.

sn.def: The seat in which one is placed.
sn.q: The several chairs of order, look, you scour; . . . Each fair installment, coat, and several crest With loyal blazon, evermore be blest.

sn.def: A portion of a debt, or sum of money, which is divided into portions that are made payable at different times; that portion of a debt payed back in any one payment; as, the next installment is due January first. Payment by installment is payment by parts at different times, the amounts and times being often definitely stipulated.
a part of a broadcast serial.
sn.syn: episode.

sn.def: a part of a published serial.

entry.def: See Enstamp.

cs.cd: those which proceed at the solicitation of some party.
the court by which a case is first tried.
by way of example or illustration; for example.
the Court of Admiralty acting within its ordinary jurisdiction, as distinguished from its action as a prize court.

entry.ety: F. instance, L. instantia, fr. instans. See Instant

sn.def: The act or quality of being instant or pressing; urgency; solicitation; application; suggestion; motion.
sn.q: Undertook at her instance to restore them.

sn.def: That which is instant or urgent; motive.
sn.q: The instances that second marriage move Are base respects of thrift, but none of love.

sn.def: Occasion; order of occurrence.
sn.q: These seem as if, in the time of Edward I., they were drawn up into the form of a law, in the first instance.

sn.def: That which offers itself or is offered as an illustrative case; something cited in proof or exemplification; a case occurring; an example; as, we could find no instance of poisoning in the town within the past year.
sn.q: Most remarkable instances of suffering.

sn.def: A token; a sign; a symptom or indication.
sn.syn: Example; case. See Example.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Instanced; p. pr. & vb. n. Instancing
entry.def: To mention as a case or example; to refer to; to cite; as, to instance a fact.
entry.q: I shall not instance an abstruse author.

entry.def: To give an example.
entry.q: This story doth not only instance in kingdoms, but in families too.

entry.def: Instance; urgency.
entry.q: Those heavenly precepts which our Lord and Savior with so great instancy gave.

entry.note: ☞ The word in this sense is now used only in dates, to indicate the current month; as, the tenth of July instant.
entry.ety: L. instans -antis, p. pr. of instare to stand upon, to press upon; pref. in- in, on + stare to stand: cf. F. instant. See Stand

sn.def: Pressing; urgent; importunate; earnest.
sn.q: Rejoicing in hope; patient in tribulation; continuing instant in prayer.
I am beginning to be very instant for some sort of occupation.

sn.def: Closely pressing or impending in respect to time; not deferred; immediate; without delay.
sn.q: Impending death is thine, and instant doom.

sn.def: Present; current.
sn.q: The instant time is always the fittest time.

entry.def: Instantly.
entry.q: Instant he flew with hospitable haste.

entry.ety: F. instant, fr. L. instans standing by, being near, present. See Instant a.

sn.def: A point in time; a moment; a portion of time too short to be estimated; also, any particular moment; as, teh situation may change in an instant .
sn.q: There is scarce an instant between their flourishing and their not being.

sn.def: A day of the present or current month; as, the sixth instant; -- an elliptical expression equivalent to the sixth of the month instant, i. e., the current month. See Instant a., 3.
sn.syn: Moment; flash; second.

entry.ety: Cf. F. instantanéité
entry.def: Quality of being instantaneous.

cs.cd: in a plane or in a plane figure which has motions both of translation and of rotation in the plane, is the point which for the instant is at rest.

in a body which has motions both of translation and rotation, is a line, which is supposed to be rigidly united with the body, and which for the instant is at rest. The motion of the body is for the instant simply that of rotation about the instantaneous axis.

entry.ety: Cf. F. instantané

sn.def: Done or occurring in an instant, or without any perceptible duration of time; as, the passage of electricity appears to be instantaneous .
sn.q: His reason saw With instantaneous view, the truth of things.

sn.def: At or during a given instant; as, instantaneous acceleration, velocity, etc.

entry.ety: L., vehemently, earnestly. See Instant n. & a.
entry.def: Immediately; instantly; at once; as, he left instanter .

sn.def: Without the least delay or interval; at once; immediately.
With urgency or importunity; earnestly; pressingly.
sn.q: They besought himinstantly.
sn.syn: Directly; immediately; at once. See Directly.

entry.def: To stud as with stars.
entry.q: A golden throneinstarredwith gems.

entry.def: a postembryonic stage of life of an arthropod, especially an insect, between two successive molts; also, the arthropod when in that stage of life.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Instated; p. pr. & vb. n. Instating
entry.def: To set, place, or establish, as in a rank, office, or condition; to install; to invest; as, to instate a person in greatness or in favor.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Instaurated; p. pr. & vb. n. Instaurating
entry.ety: L. instauratus, p. p. of instaurare to renew. See 1st In-, and Store
entry.def: To renew or renovate.

entry.ety: L. instauratio: cf. F. instauration
entry.def: Restoration after decay, lapse, or dilapidation; renewal; repair; renovation; renaissance.
entry.q: Some great catastrophe or . . . instauration.

entry.ety: L.: cf. F. instaurateur
entry.def: One who renews or restores to a former condition.

entry.ety: See Instaurate
entry.def: To renew or renovate; to instaurate.

entry.ety: Pref. in- + stead place

sn.def: In the place or room; -- usually followed by of.
sn.q: Let thistles grow of wheat.
Absalom made Amasa captain of the host instead of Joab.

sn.def: Equivalent; equal to; -- usually with of.
sn.q: This very consideration to a wise man is instead of a thousand arguments, to satisfy him, that in those times no such thing was believed.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Insteeped; p. pr. & vb. n. Insteeping
entry.def: To steep or soak; to drench.
entry.q: In gore he layinsteeped.

sn.def: The arched middle portion of the human foot next in front of the ankle joint.
The part of a shoe, boot, or stocking covering the instep{1}.
That part of the hind leg of the horse and allied animals, between the hock, or ham, and the pastern joint.

entry.def: one who instigates; someone who deliberately provokes trouble; an instigator.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Instigated; p. pr. & vb. n. Instigating
entry.ety: L. instigatus, p. p. of instigare to instigate; pref. in- in + a root akin to G. stechen to prick, E. stick. See Stick
entry.def: To goad or urge forward; to set on; to provoke; to incite; -- used chiefly with reference to evil actions; as, to instigate one to a crime.
entry.q: He hath only instigated his blackest agents to the very extent of their malignity.
entry.syn: To stimulate; urge; spur; provoke; tempt; incite; impel; encourage; animate.

entry.def: Incitingly; temptingly.

entry.ety: L. instigatio: cf. F. instigation
entry.def: The act of instigating, or the state of being instigated; incitement; esp. to evil or wickedness.
entry.q: The baseness and villainy that . . . the instigation of the devil could bring the sons of men to.

entry.def: arousing to action or rebellion.

entry.ety: L.: cf. F. instigateur
entry.def: One who instigates or incites.
same as instill.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Instilled; p. pr. & vb. n. Instilling
entry.ety: L. instillare instillatum; pref. in- in + stillare to drop, fr. stilla a drop: cf. F. instiller. See Distill

sn.def: To drop in; to pour in drop by drop.
sn.q: That starlight dews All silently their tears of love instill.

sn.def: To infuse (knowledge or attitudes) into the mind of another, slowly or gradually; to impart gradually; to cause to be imbibed.
sn.q: How hast thou instilled Thy malice into thousands.
sn.syn: To infuse; impart; inspire; implant; inculcate; insinuate.

entry.ety: L. instillatio: cf. F. instillation
entry.def: The act of instilling; also, that which is instilled.
An instiller.
Belonging to instillation.
One who instills.
The act of instilling; also, that which is instilled.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + stimulate
entry.def: Not to stimulate; to soothe; to quiet.

entry.ety: L. instimulatus, p. p. instimulare to stimulate. See 1st In-, and Stimulate
entry.def: To stimulate; to excite.
Stimulation.

entry.ety: L. instinctus, p. p. of instinguere to instigate, incite; cf. instigare to instigate. Cf. Instigate Distinguish
entry.def: Urged or stimulated from within; naturally moved or impelled; imbued; animated; alive; quick; as, birds instinct with life.
entry.q: The chariot of paternal deity . . . Itself instinct with spirit, but convoyed By four cherubic shapes.
A noble performance, instinct with sound principle.

entry.ety: L. instinctus instigation, impulse, fr. instinguere to instigate: cf. F. instinct. See Instinct a.

sn.def: Natural inward impulse; unconscious, involuntary, or unreasoning prompting to any mode of action, whether bodily, or mental, without a distinct apprehension of the end or object to be accomplished.
sn.q: An instinct is a propensity prior to experience, and independent of instructions.
An instinct is a blind tendency to some mode of action, independent of any consideration, on the part of the agent, of the end to which the action leads.
An instinct is an agent which performs blindly and ignorantly a work of intelligence and knowledge.
By a divine instinct, men's minds mistrust Ensuing dangers.

sn.def: Specif., the natural, unreasoning, impulse by which an animal is guided to the performance of any action, without thought of improvement in the method.
sn.q: The resemblance between what originally was a habit, and an instinct becomes so close as not to be distinguished.

sn.def: A natural aptitude or knack; a predilection; as, an instinct for order; to be modest by instinct.

entry.def: To impress, as an animating power, or instinct.
Instinct; incitement; inspiration.

entry.note: ☞ The terms instinctive belief instinctive judgment instinctive cognition, are expressions not ill adapted to characterize a belief, judgment, or cognition, which, as the result of no anterior consciousness, is, like the products of animal instinct, the intelligent effect of (as far as we are concerned) an unknown cause.
entry.ety: Cf. F. instinctif
entry.def: Of or pertaining to instinct; derived from, or prompted by, instinct; of the nature of instinct; determined by natural impulse or propensity; acting or produced without reasoning, deliberation, instruction, or experience; spontaneous.
entry.q: Instinctivemotion.
Instinctivedread.
With taste instinctive give Each grace appropriate.
Have we had instinctive intimations of the death of some absent friends?
entry.syn: Natural; voluntary; spontaneous; original; innate; inherent; automatic.

entry.def: In an instinctive manner; by force of instinct; by natural impulse.
The quality of being instinctive, or prompted by instinct.
See Exstipulate.

entry.ety: L. institutus, p. p. of instituere to place in, to institute, to instruct; pref. in- in + statuere to cause to stand, to set. See Statute
entry.def: Established; organized; founded.
entry.q: They have but few laws. For to a people so instruct and institute, very few to suffice.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Instituted ĭn"stĭ*tū`tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Instituting

sn.def: To set up; to establish; to ordain; as, to institute laws, rules, etc.
To originate and establish; to found; to organize; as, to institute a court, or a society.
sn.q: Whenever any from of government becomes destructive of these ends it is the right of the people to alter or to abolish it, and to institute a new government.

sn.def: To nominate; to appoint.
sn.q: We institute your Grace To be our regent in these parts of France.

sn.def: To begin; to commence; to set on foot; as, to institute an inquiry; to institute a suit.
sn.q: And haply institute A course of learning and ingenious studies.

sn.def: To ground or establish in principles and rudiments; to educate; to instruct.
sn.q: If children were early instituted, knowledge would insensibly insinuate itself.

sn.def: To invest with the spiritual charge of a benefice, or the care of souls.
sn.syn: To originate; begin; commence; establish; found; erect; organize; appoint; ordain.

cs.cd: theoretical medicine; that department of medical science which attempts to account philosophically for the various phenomena of health as well as of disease; physiology applied to the practice of medicine.

entry.ety: L. institutum: cf. F. institut. See Institute v. t. & a.

sn.def: The act of instituting; institution.
sn.q: Water sanctified by Christ'sinstitute.

sn.def: That which is instituted, established, or fixed, as a law, habit, or custom.

Hence: An elementary and necessary principle; a precept, maxim, or rule, recognized as established and authoritative; usually in the plural, a collection of such principles and precepts; esp., a comprehensive summary of legal principles and decisions; as, the Institutes of Justinian; Coke's Institutes of the Laws of England. Cf. Digest n.
sn.q: They made a sort of institute and digest of anarchy.
To make the Stoics' institutes thy own.

sn.def: An institution; a society established for the promotion of learning, art, science, etc.; a college; as, the Institute of Technology; The Massachusetts Institute of Technology; also, a building owned or occupied by such an institute; as, the Cooper Institute .
The person to whom an estate is first given by destination or limitation.

entry.def: An institutor.

entry.ety: L. institutio: cf. F. institution

sn.def: The act or process of instituting; as: Establishment; foundation; enactment; as, the institution of a school.
sn.q: The institution of God's law is described as being established by solemn injunction.

sd.def: Instruction; education.
The act or ceremony of investing a clergyman with the spiritual part of a benefice, by which the care of souls is committed to his charge.

entry.sn:
That which instituted or established; as: Established order, method, or custom; enactment; ordinance; permanent form of law or polity. The nature of our people, Our city's institutions.
An established or organized society or corporation; an establishment, especially of a public character, or affecting a community; a foundation; as, a literary institution; a charitable institution ; also, a building or the buildings occupied or used by such organization; as, the Smithsonian Institution .
Anything forming a characteristic and persistent feature in social or national life or habits. We ordered a lunch (the most delightful of English institutions, next to dinner) to be ready against our return.

sn.def: That which institutes or instructs; a textbook; a system of elements or rules; an institute.
sn.q: There is another manuscript, of above three hundred years old, . . . being an institution of physic.

sn.def: Pertaining to, or treating of, an institution or institutions; as, institutional legends.
sn.q: Institutional writers as Rousseau.

sn.def: Instituted by authority.
Elementary; rudimental.
Relating to an institution, or institutions.
Containing the first principles or doctrines; elemental; rudimentary.

entry.def: A writer or compiler of, or a commentator on, institutes.

sn.def: Tending or intended to institute; having the power to establish.
Established; depending on, or characterized by, institution or order.
sn.q: Institutivedecency.

entry.def: In conformity with an institution.

entry.ety: L.: cf. F. instituteur

sn.def: One who institutes, founds, ordains, or establishes.
One who educates; an instructor.
A presbyter appointed by the bishop to institute a rector or assistant minister over a parish church.

entry.def: To stop; to close; to make fast; as, to instop the seams.

entry.ety: See Instaurate Store
entry.def: To store up; to inclose; to contain.
Interstratified.
An inward stroke; specif., in a steam or other engine, a stroke in which the piston is moving away from the crank shaft; -- opposed to outstroke.

entry.ety: L. instructus, p. p. of instruere to furnish, provide, construct, instruct; pref. in- in, on + struere. See Structure

sn.def: Arranged; furnished; provided.
sn.q: He had neither shipinstructwith oars, nor men.

sn.def: Instructed; taught; enlightened.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Instructed; p. pr. & vb. n. Instructing

sn.def: To put in order; to form; to prepare.
sn.q: They speak to the merits of a cause, after the proctor has prepared and instructed the same for a hearing.

sn.def: To form by communication of knowledge; to inform the mind of; to impart knowledge or information to; to enlighten; to teach; to discipline.
sn.q: Schoolmasters will I keep within my house, Fit to instruct her youth.

sn.def: To furnish with directions; to advise; to direct; to command; as, the judge instructs the jury.
sn.q: She, being before instructed of her mother, said, Give me here John Baptist's head in a charger.
Take her in; instruct her what she has to do.
sn.syn: To teach; educate; inform; train; discipline; indoctrinate; direct; enjoin.

entry.def: See Instructor.
Capable of being instructed; teachable; docible.

entry.note: Instructions as contained in a program are formulated in a programming language, which may be an assembly language, in which one instruction corresponds to one command executed by the coputer, or in a higher-level programming language, in which one instruction may represent one of many instructions in assembly language. Higher-level programming languages include, for example, FORTRAN, ALGOL, ADA, C, "C++", COBOL, and JAVA; each of these languages have their own distinctive set of allowable instructions.
entry.ety: L. instructio: cf. F. instruction

sn.def: The act of instructing, teaching, or furnishing with knowledge; information.

entry.sn:
That which instructs, or with which one is instructed; the intelligence or information imparted; as: Precept; information; teachings.
Direction; order; command. If myinstructionsmay be your guide.

sn.def: a segment of coded data that is interpreted by a computer as a command to perform an operation or series of operations. The term instruction is applied to both the electronic form of the data as represented in and executed by the computer, and to any line of written computer code which is interpreted as one instruction by a compiler. A computer program is comprised of one or more instructions.
sn.syn: command, statement, line of code, program line.
Education; teaching; indoctrination; information; advice; counsel. See Education.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or promoting, instruction; educational.

entry.ety: Cf. F. instructif
entry.def: Conveying knowledge; serving to instruct or inform; as, experience furnishes very instructive lessons.
entry.q: In various talk the instructive hours they past.
The pregnant instructiveness of the Scripture.

entry.ety: L., a preparer: cf. F. instructeur
entry.def: One who instructs; one who imparts knowledge to another; a teacher.
the office or position of an instructor.
A woman who instructs; a preceptress; a governess.

entry.ety: F. instrument, L. instrumentum. See Instruct

sn.def: That by means of which any work is performed, or result is effected; a tool; a utensil; an implement; a device; as, the instruments of a mechanic; astronomical instruments.
sn.q: All the lofty instruments of war.

sn.def: A contrivance or implement, by which musical sounds are produced; as, a musical instrument .
sn.q: Praise him with stringed instruments and organs.
But signs when songs and instruments he hears.

sn.def: A writing, as the means of giving formal expression to some act; a writing expressive of some act, contract, process, as a deed, contract, writ, etc.
One who, or that which, is made a means, or is caused to serve a purpose; a medium, means, or agent; as, their army was primarily an instrument of oppression.
sn.q: Or useful serving man and instrument, To any sovereign state.
The bold are but the instruments of the wise.
sn.syn: Tool; implement; utensil; machine; apparatus; channel; agent.

sn.def: To perform upon an instrument; to prepare for an instrument; as, a sonata instrumented for orchestra.
To furnish or equip with instruments; to attach instruments to; as, the fighter planes were heavily instrumented; the patient was instrumented to monitor him remotely.

cs.cd: those errors in instrumental measurements, etc., which arise, exclusively from lack of mathematical accuracy in an instrument.

entry.ety: Cf. F. instrumental

sn.def: Acting as an instrument; serving as a means; contributing to promote; conductive; helpful; serviceable; as, he was instrumental in conducting the business.
sn.q: The head is not more native to the heart, The hand more instrumental to the mouth.

sn.def: Pertaining to, made by, or prepared for, an instrument, esp. a musical instrument; as, instrumental music, distinguished from vocal music.
sn.q: He defended the use ofinstrumentalmusic in public worship.
Sweet voices mix'd with instrumental sounds.

sn.def: Applied to a case expressing means or agency; as, the instrumental case. This is found in Sanskrit and Russian as a separate case, but in Greek it was merged into the dative, and in Latin into the ablative. In Old English it was a separate case, but has disappeared, leaving only a few anomalous forms.

entry.def: The view that the sanction of truth is its utility, or that truth is genuine only in so far as it is a valuable instrument.
entry.q: Instrumentalism views truth as simply the value belonging to certain ideas in so far as these ideas are biological functions of our organisms, and psychological functions whereby we direct our choices and attain our successes.

entry.def: One who plays upon an instrument of music, as distinguished from a vocalist.

entries.entry: In`stru*men*tal"i*ty n.; pl.Instrumentalities. The quality or condition of being instrumental; that which is instrumental; anything used as a means; medium; agency. The instrumentality of faith in justification. The discovery of gunpowder developed the science of attack and defense in a new instrumentality.

sn.def: By means of an instrument or agency; as means to an end.
sn.q: They will argue that the end being essentially beneficial, the means become instrumentally so.

sn.def: With instruments of music; as, a song instrumentally accompanied.

entry.def: Usefulness or agency, as means to an end; instrumentality.
Instrumental.

sn.def: The act of using or adapting as an instrument; a series or combination of instruments; means; agency.
sn.q: Otherwise we have no sufficient instrumentation for our human use or handling of so great a fact.

sd.def: The arrangement of a musical composition for performance by a number of different instruments; orchestration; instrumental composition; composition for an orchestra or military band.
The act or manner of playing upon musical instruments; performance; as, his instrumentation is perfect.

sn.def: The act of using instruments to measure or control the behavior of an object, as a patient in a hospital or a machine being tested while under development.
The act of furnishing or attaching instruments to/
The set of instruments included in a system; as, a harvester with modern instrumentation .

entry.def: Having instruments attached for the purpose of measuring conditions while under observation; -- said of a person under medical observation or a machine whose performance is being tested.
A performer on a musical instrument; an instrumentalist.
To style.

entry.ety: L. insuavitas: cf. F. insuavité. See In- not, and Suavity
entry.def: Lack of suavity; unpleasantness.
Lack of subjection or obedience; a state of disobedience, as to government.
Not capable of being submerged; buoyant.
Lack of submission; disobedience; noncompliance.
Not submitting to authority; disobedient; rebellious; mutinous.

entry.ety: Cf. F. insubordination
entry.def: The quality of being insubordinate; disobedience to lawful authority.
Unsubstantial; not real or strong.
entry.q: Insubstantialpageant.

entry.def: Unsubstantiality; unreality.

entry.ety: L. insucare insucatum, to soak in; pref. in- + succus sucus, sap
entry.def: The act of soaking or moistening; maceration; solution in the juice of herbs.
entry.q: The medicating and insuccation of seeds.

entry.def: Lack of success.
See Ensue v. i.

entry.ety: L. insuetudo, from insuetus unaccustomed; pref. in- not + suetus, p. p. of suescere to be accustomed
entry.def: The state or quality of being unaccustomed; absence of use or habit.
entry.q: Absurdities are great or small in proportion to custom or insuetude.

sn.def: Incapable of being suffered, borne, or endured; insupportable; unendurable; intolerable; as, insufferable heat, cold, or pain; insufferable wrongs.
Offensive beyond endurance; detestable.
sn.q: A multitude of scribblers who daily pester the world with their insufferable stuff.

entry.def: In a manner or to a degree beyond endurance; intolerably; as, a blaze insufferably bright; a person insufferably proud.
Insufficiency.

entry.ety: L. insufficientia: cf. F. insuffisance, whence OE. insuffisance. See Insufficient

sn.def: The quality or state of being insufficient; lack of sufficiency; deficiency; inadequateness; as, the insufficiency of provisions, of an excuse, etc.
sn.q: The insufficiency of the light of nature is, by the light of Scripture, . . . fully supplied.

sn.def: Lack of power or skill; inability; incapacity; incompetency; as, the insufficiency of a man for an office.

entry.ety: L. insufficiens -entis. See In- not, and Sufficient
