sn.def: Not sufficient; not enough; inadequate to any need, use, or purpose; as, the provisions are insufficient in quantity, and defective in quality.
sn.q: Insufficientfor His praise.

sn.def: Wanting in strength, power, ability, capacity, or skill; incompetent; incapable; unfit; as, a person insufficient to discharge the duties of an office.
sn.syn: Inadequate; scanty; incommensurate; unequal; unfit; incompetent; incapable; inefficient.

entry.def: In an insufficient manner or degree; unadequately.

entry.ety: See Insufflation
entry.def: To blow upon; to breath upon or into; to use insufflation upon.

entries.entry:
In`suf*fla"tion n. L. insuffatio: cf. F. insuffation. See In- in, and Sufflation
The act of breathing on or into anything; especially: R. C. Ch The breathing upon a person in the sacrament of baptism to symbolize the inspiration of a new spiritual life. Med The act of blowing (a gas, powder, or vapor) into any cavity of the body.

entry.def: Unsuitable.

entry.ety: L. insularis, fr. insula island: cf. F. insulaire. See Isle

sn.def: Of or pertaining to an island; of the nature, or possessing the characteristics, of an island; as, an insular climate, fauna, etc.
Of or pertaining to the people of an island; narrow; circumscribed; illiberal; contracted; as, insular habits, opinions, or prejudices.
sn.q: The penury of insular conversation.

entry.def: An islander.
the state of being insulated.

entry.ety: Cf. F. insularité

sn.def: The state or quality of being an island or consisting of islands; insulation.
sn.q: The insularity of Britain was first shown by Agricola, who sent his fleet round it.

sn.def: Narrowness or illiberality of opinion; prejudice; exclusiveness; as, the insularity of the Chinese or of the aristocracy.

entry.def: In an insular manner.
Insular.

cs.cd: a stool with legs of glass or some other nonconductor of electricity, used for insulating a person or any object placed upon it.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Insulated; p. pr. & vb. n. Insulating
entry.ety: L. insulatus insulated, fr. insula island. See Isle, and cf. Isolate

sn.def: To make an island of.
To place in a detached situation, or in a state having no communication with surrounding objects; to isolate; to separate.
To prevent the transfer of electricity or heat to or from (bodies) by the interposition of nonconductors.

cs.cd: wire covered with some nonconducting material, such as plastic or silk, for use in conducting electricity.

sn.def: Standing by itself; not being contiguous to other bodies; separated; unconnected; isolated; as, an insulated house or column.
sn.q: The special and insulated situation of the Jews.

sn.def: Separated from other bodies by means of nonconductors of heat or electricity.
Situated at so great a distance as to be beyond the effect of gravitation; -- said of stars supposed to be so far apart that the affect of their mutual attraction is insensible.
The act of insulating, or the state of being insulated; detachment from other objects; isolation.
The act of separating a body from others by nonconductors, so as to prevent the transfer of electricity or of heat; also, the state of a body so separated.
The material or substance used to insulate from either electrical or thermal conduction; as, fiberglass is used as thermal insulation in the walls and roofs of houses.
One who, or that which, insulates.
A substance or object that insulates; a nonconductor; as, polyurethane foam is a popular thermal insulator .

entry.def: An insulating material, usually some variety of compressed cellulose, made of sawdust, paper pulp, cotton waste, etc.

entry.ety: L. insulosus, fr. insula island
entry.def: Abounding in islands.

entry.ety: L. insulsus; pref. in- not + salsus salted, fr. salire salsum, to salt
entry.def: Insipid; dull; stupid.

entry.ety: L. insulsitas
entry.def: Insipidity; stupidity; dullness.
entry.q: The insulsity of mortal tongues.

entry.ety: L. insultus, fr. insilire to leap upon: cf. F. insulte. See Insult v. t.

sn.def: The act of leaping on; onset; attack.
Gross abuse offered to another, either by word or act; an act or speech of insolence or contempt; a deprecatory remark; an affront; an indignity.
sn.q: The ruthless sneer that insult adds to grief.

sn.def: An injury to an organism; trauma; as, to produce an experimental insult to investigate healing processes.
sn.syn: Affront; indignity; abuse; outrage; contumely. See Affront.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Insulted; p. pr. & vb. n. Insulting
entry.ety: F. insulter, L. insultare, freq. fr. insilire to leap into or upon; pref. in- in, on + salire to leap. See Salient

sn.def: To leap or trample upon; to make a sudden onset upon.
To treat with abuse, insolence, indignity, or contempt, by word or action; to abuse; as, to call a man a coward or a liar, or to sneer at him, is to insult him.
To leap or jump.
sn.q: Give me thy knife, I will insult on him.
Like the frogs in the apologue, insulting upon their wooden king.

sn.def: To behave with insolence; to exult.
sn.q: The lion being dead, even hares insult.
An unwillingness to insult over their helpless fatuity.

entry.def: Capable of being insulted or affronted.

entry.ety: L. insultatio, fr. insultare: cf. OF. insultation

sn.def: The act of insulting; abusive or insolent treatment; insult.
Exultation.

entry.def: One who insults.
Containing, or characterized by, insult or abuse; tending to insult or affront; as, insulting language, treatment, etc.
entry.syn: Insolent; impertinent; saucy; rude; abusive; contemptuous. See Insolent.

entry.def: Insolent treatment; insult.
entry.q: My speech ofinsultmentended.

entry.ety: L. insumere; pre. in- in + sumere to take
entry.def: To take in; to absorb.
The quality or state of being insuperable; insuperableness.

entry.ety: L. insuperabilis: cf. OF. insuperable. See In- not, and Superable
entry.def: Incapable of being passed over or surmounted; insurmountable; as, insuperable difficulties.
entry.q: And middle natures, how they long to join, Yet never pass the insuperable line?
The difficulty is enhanced, or is . . . insuperable.

entry.ety: L. insupportabilis: cf. F. insupportable. See In- not, and Support
entry.def: Incapable of being supported or borne; unendurable; insufferable; intolerable; as, insupportable burdens; insupportable pain.
Incapable of being supposed; not supposable; inconceivable.
That can not be suppressed or concealed; irrepressible.
Insuppressible.
entry.q: Theinsuppressivemettle of our spirits.

entry.ety: From Insure
entry.def: Capable of being insured against loss, damage, death, etc.; proper to be insured.
entry.q: The French law annuls the latter policies so far as they exceed the insurable interest which remained in the insured at the time of the subscription thereof.

entry.note: ☞ The person who undertakes to pay in case of loss is termed the insurer; the danger against which he undertakes, the risk; the person protected, the insured; the sum which he pays for the protection, the premium; and the contract itself, when reduced to form, the policy.
entry.cs:
Accident insurance insurance against pecuniary loss by reason of accident to the person.
Endowment insuranceorEndowment assurance
a combination of life insurance and investment such that if the person upon whose life a risk is taken dies before a certain specified time the insurance becomes due at once, and if he survives, it becomes due at the time specified. Also called whole life insurance. Fire insurance. See under Fire. Insurance broker a broker or agent who effects insurance. Insurance company a company or corporation whose business it is to insure against loss, damage, or death. Insurance policy a certificate of insurance; the document containing the contract made by an insurance company with a person whose property or life is insured. Life insurance. See under Life.
entry.ety: From Insure

sn.def: The act of insuring, or assuring, against loss or damage by a contingent event; a contract whereby, for a stipulated consideration, called premium, one party undertakes to indemnify or guarantee another against loss by certain specified risks. Cf. Assurance n., 6.
The premium paid for insuring property or life.
The sum for which life or property is insured.
A guaranty, security, or pledge; assurance.
sn.q: The most acceptable insurance of the divine protection.

sn.def: Any means of assuring against loss; a precaution; as, we always use our seat belts as insurance against injury.

entry.def: One who effects insurance; an insurer; an underwriter.
entry.q: hose bold insurancers of deathless fame.

entry.def: The person insured, called also the insured.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Insured; p. pr. & vb. n. Insuring
entry.ety: OE. ensuren, prob. for assuren, by a change of prefix. See 1st In-, and Sure, and cf. Assure Ensure

sn.def: To make sure or secure; as, to insure safety to any one.

Specifically, to secure against a loss by a contingent event, on certain stipulated conditions, or at a given rate or premium; to give or to take an insurance on or for; as, a merchant insures his ship or its cargo, or both, against the dangers of the sea; goods and buildings are insured against fire or water; persons are insured against sickness, accident, or death; and sometimes hazardous debts are insured.

entry.def: To underwrite; to make insurance; as, a company insures at three per cent.
One who, or that which, insures; the person or company that contracts to indemnify losses for a premium; an underwriter.
A state of insurrection; an uprising; an insurrection.
entry.q: A moral insurgence in the minds of grave men against the Court of Rome.

entry.ety: L. insurgens, p. pr. of insurgere to rise up; pref. in- in + surgere to rise. See Surge
entry.def: Rising in opposition to civil or political authority, or against an established government; insubordinate; rebellious.
entry.q: Theinsurgentprovinces.

entry.ety: Cf. F. insurgent
entry.def: A person who rises in revolt against civil authority or an established government; one who openly and actively resists the execution of laws; a rebel.
The state or quality of being insurmountable.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + surmountable: cf. F. insurmountable
entry.def: Incapable of being passed over, surmounted, or overcome; insuperable; as, insurmountable difficulty or obstacle.
entry.q: Hope thinks nothing difficult; despair tells us that difficulty is insurmountable.

entry.def: The state or quality of being insurmountable; insurmountability.
In a manner or to a degree not to be overcome.

entry.usage: Sedition is the raising of commotion in a state, as by conspiracy, without aiming at open violence against the laws. Insurrection is a rising of individuals to prevent the execution of law by force of arms. Revolt is a casting off the authority of a government, with a view to put it down by force, or to substitute one ruler for another. Rebellion is an extended insurrection and revolt. Mutiny is an insurrection on a small scale, as a mutiny of a regiment, or of a ship's crew.
entry.ety: L. insurrectio, fr. insurgere insurrectum: cf. F. insurrection. See Insurgent

sn.def: A rising against civil or political authority, or the established government; open and active opposition to the execution of law in a city or state.
sn.q: It is found that this city of old time hath made insurrection against kings, and that rebellion and sedition have been made therein.

sn.def: A rising in mass to oppose an enemy.
sn.syn: Insurrection Sedition Revolt Rebellion Mutiny.
sn.q: I say again, In soothing them, we nourish 'gainst our senate The cockle of rebellion, insolence, sedition.
Insurrections of base people are commonly more furious in their beginnings.
He was greatly strengthened, and the enemy as much enfeebled, by daily revolts.
Though of their names in heavenly records now Be no memorial, blotted out and razed By their rebellion from the books of life.

entry.ety: Cf. F. insurrectionnel
entry.def: Pertaining to insurrection; consisting in insurrection.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, insurrection; rebellious; seditious.
entry.q: Their murderous insurrectionary system.

entry.def: One who favors, or takes part in, insurrection; an insurgent.
Lack of susceptibility, or of capacity to feel or perceive.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + susceptible: cf. F. insusceptible
entry.def: Not susceptible; not capable of being moved, affected, or impressed; that can not feel, receive, or admit; as, a limb insusceptible of pain; a heart insusceptible of pity; a mind insusceptible to flattery; new strains of bacteria insusceptible to penicillin.
Not susceptive or susceptible.

entry.ety: L. insusurratio, fr. insusurrare to whisper into
entry.def: The act of whispering into something.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inswathed; p. pr. & vb. n. Inswating
entry.def: To wrap up; to infold; to swathe.
entry.q: Inswathed sometimes in wandering mist.

entry.def: Narrowed at the forward end; -- said of an automobile frame when the side members are closer together at the forward end than at the rear.

entry.ety: L. intactus; pref. in- not + tactus, p. p. of tangere to touch: cf. F. intact. See In- not, and Tact Tangent
entry.def: Untouched, especially by anything that harms, defiles, or the like; uninjured; undefiled; left complete or entire.
entry.q: When all external differences have passed away, one element remains intact, unchanged, -- the everlasting basis of our common nature, the human soul.

entry.def: Not perceptible to the touch.

entry.ety: It. intagliato, p. p. of intagliare. See Intaglio
entry.def: Engraved in intaglio; as, an intagliated stone.

entries.entry:
In*tagl"io n.; pl. E. Intaglius #, It. Intagli #. It., fr. intagliare to engrave, carve; pref. in- in + tagliare to cut, carve. See Detail
A cutting or engraving; a figure cut into something, as a gem, so as to make a design depressed below the surface of the material; hence, anything so carved or impressed, as a gem, matrix, etc.; -- opposed to cameo. Also used adjectively.

entry.def: See Entail v. t.

sn.def: The place where water, air, or other substance is taken into a pipe, conduit, or machine; -- opposed to outlet.
the beginning of a contraction or narrowing in a tube or cylinder.
The quantity taken in; as, the intake of air.

entry.ety: L. intaminatus. See Contaminate
entry.def: Uncontaminated.

entries.entry:
In*tan`gi*bil"i*ty n.; pl.Intangibilities #. Cf. F. intangibilité
The quality or state of being intangible; intangibleness.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + tangible: cf. F. intangible
entry.def: Not tangible; incapable of being touched; not perceptible to the touch; impalpable; imperceptible.
entry.q: A corporation is an artificial, invisible, intangible being.

entry.def: See Entangle.
Incapable of being tasted; tasteless; unsavory.

cs.cd: an expression of the form a + b√-1, where a and b are real integers.

entry.ety: L. integer untouched, whole, entire. See Entire
entry.def: A complete entity; a whole number, in contradistinction to a fraction or a mixed number.
The quality of being integrable.
Capable of being integrated.

entry.cs: Integral calculus. See under Calculus.
entry.ety: Cf. F. intégral. See Integer

sn.def: Lacking nothing of completeness; complete; perfect; uninjured; whole; entire.
sn.q: A local motion keepeth bodies integral.

sn.def: Essential to completeness; constituent, as a part; pertaining to, or serving to form, an integer; integrant.
sn.q: Ceasing to do evil, and doing good, are the two great integral parts that complete this duty.

sd.def: Of, pertaining to, or being, a whole number or undivided quantity; not fractional.
Pertaining to, or proceeding by, integration; as, the integral calculus.

cs.cd: one of an important class of integrals, occurring in the higher mathematics; -- so called because one of the integrals expresses the length of an arc of an ellipse.

sn.def: A whole; an entire thing; a whole number; an individual.
An expression which, being differentiated, will produce a given differential. See differential Differential, and Integration. Cf. Fluent.

entry.ety: Cf. F. intégralité
entry.def: Entireness.
In an integral manner; wholly; completely; also, by integration.

cs.cd: of bodies, those smaller particles into which a body may be reduced without loss of its original constitution, as by mechanical division.

entry.ety: L. integrans -antis, p. pr. of integrare to make whole, renew: cf. F. intégrant. See Integrate
entry.def: Making part of a whole; necessary to constitute an entire thing; integral.
entry.q: All these are integrant parts of the republic.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Integrated; p. pr. & vb. n. Integrating
entry.ety: L. integratus, p. p. of integrare to make whole, renew: cf. F. intégrer. See Integer Entire

sn.def: To form into one whole; to make entire; to complete; to renew; to restore; to perfect.
sn.q: That conquest rounded andintegratedthe glorious empire.
Two distinct substances, the soul and body, go to compound and integrate the man.

sn.def: To indicate the whole of; to give the sum or total of; as, an integrating anemometer, one that indicates or registers the entire action of the wind in a given time.
To subject to the operation of integration; to find the integral of.
Formed or united into a whole.
sn.syn: incorporate, incorporated, merged, unified.

entry.sn: Formed into a whole or introduced into another entity; as, an integrated Europe. Opposite of nonintegrated.Narrower terms: coordinated interconnected unified; embedded; incorporated; tight-knit tightly knit a more closely integrated economic and political system Dwight D. Eisenhower

Having different groups treated together as equals in one group; as, racially integrated schools.Narrower terms: co-ed, coeducational; desegrated, nonsegregated, unsegregated; interracial; mainstreamed Also See: integrative joint united. Antonym: segregated.
Resembling a living organism in organization or development.Narrower terms: organicvs. inorganic) structured.

sn.def: combined. Opposite of uncombined.

entry.sn: having constituent parts mixed to form a single unit. Opposite of unmixed.Narrower terms: blended[2 amalgamated, intermingled, mixed.

entry.def: the action of incorporating a racial or religious group into a community.

entry.sn: tending to combine and coordinate diverse elements into a whole.Narrower terms: consolidative, unifying; plastic Also See: collective combinative integrated. Antonym: disintegrative.

sn.def: centralizing(prenominal). Opposite of decentralizing.
sn.syn: consolidative.

entry.note: ☞ The symbol of integration is ∫ (standing for the Latin summa sum), and the integral is also regarded as the limiting value of the sum of great numbers of differentials, when the magnitude of the differentials decreases, and their number increases indefinitely. See Limit n. When the summation is made between specified values of the variable, the result is a definite integral, and those values of the variable are the limits of the integral. When the summation is made successively for two or more variables, the result is a multiple integral.
entry.ety: L. integratio a renewing, restoring: cf. F. intégration

sn.def: The act or process of making whole or entire.
The operation of finding the primitive function which has a given function for its differential coefficient. See Integral.
In the theory of evolution: The process by which the manifold is compacted into the relatively simple and permanent. It is supposed to alternate with differentiation as an agent in development.

entry.def: That which integrates; esp., an instrument by means of which the area of a figure can be measured directly, or its moment of inertia, or statical moment, etc., be determined.

entry.ety: L. integritas: cf. F. intégrité. See Integer, and cf. Entirety

sn.def: The state or quality of being entire or complete; wholeness; entireness; unbroken state; as, the integrity of an empire or territory.

Moral soundness; honesty; freedom from corrupting influence or motive; -- used especially with reference to the fulfillment of contracts, the discharge of agencies, trusts, and the like; uprightness; rectitude.
sn.q: The moral grandeur of independent integrity is the sublimest thing in nature.
Their sober zeal, integrity, and worth.

sn.def: Unimpaired, unadulterated, or genuine state; entire correspondence with an original condition; purity.
sn.q: Language continued long in its purity and integrity.
sn.syn: Honesty; uprightness; rectitude. See Probity.

entry.ety: L. integer whole + E. pallial
entry.def: Having the pallial line entire, or without a sinus, as certain bivalve shells.

entry.ety: See Integument
entry.def: That part of physiology which treats of the integuments of animals and plants.

entry.ety: L. integumentum, fr. integere to cover; pref. in- in, on + tegere to cover: cf. F. intégument. See 1st n-, and Tegument
entry.def: That which naturally invests or covers another thing, as the testa or the tegmen of a seed; specifically Anat, a covering which invests the body, as the skin, or a membrane that invests a particular part.
Belonging to, or composed of, integuments.
The act or process of covering with integuments; the state or manner of being thus covered.

entry.ety: L. intellectus, fr. intelligere intellectum, to understand: cf. intellect. See Intelligent

sn.def: The part or faculty of the human mind by which it knows, as distinguished from the power to feel and to will; the power to judge and comprehend; the thinking faculty; the understanding.
The capacity for higher forms of knowledge, as distinguished from the power to perceive objects in their relations; mental capacity.
A particular mind, especially a person of high intelligence; as, he was a great intellect .

entry.def: Endowed with intellect; having intellectual powers or capacities.
entry.q: In body, and in bristles, they became As swine, yet intellected as before.

entries.entry:
In`tel*lec"tion n. L. intellectio synecdoche: cf. F. intellection
A mental act or process; especially: The act of understanding; simple apprehension of ideas; intuition. Bentley. A creation of the mind itself.

entry.ety: Cf. F. intellectif

sn.def: Pertaining to, or produced by, the intellect or understanding; intellectual.
Having power to understand, know, or comprehend; intelligent; rational.
Capable of being perceived by the understanding only, not by the senses.
sn.q: Intellective abstractions of logic and metaphysics.

entry.def: In an intellective manner.
entry.q: Notintellectivellyto write.

entry.ety: L. intellectualis: cf. F. intellectuel

sn.def: Belonging to, or performed by, the intellect; mental; as, intellectual powers, activities, etc.
sn.q: Logic is to teach us the right use of our reason or intellectual powers.

sn.def: Endowed with intellect; having the power of understanding; having capacity for the higher forms of knowledge or thought; characterized by intelligence or mental capacity; as, an intellectual person.
sn.q: Who would lose, Though full of pain, this intellectual being, Those thoughts that wander through eternity?

sn.def: Suitable for exercising the intellect; formed by, and existing for, the intellect alone; perceived by the intellect; as, intellectual employments.
Relating to the understanding; treating of the mind; as, intellectual philosophy, sometimes called “mental” philosophy.
The intellect or understanding; mental powers or faculties.
sn.q: Her husband, for I view far round, not nigh, Whose higher intellectual more I shun.
I kept her intellectuals in a state of exercise.

sn.def: A learned person or one of high intelligence;

one who places greatest value on activities requiring exercise of the intelligence, such as study, complex forms of knowledge, literature and aesthetic matters, reflection and philosophical speculation; a member of the intelligentsia; as, intellectuals are often apalled at the inanities that pass for entertainment on television.
Intellectual power; intellectuality.
The doctrine that knowledge is derived from pure reason.
Preference for activities involving exercise of the intellect;
an excessive emphasis on abstract or intellectual matters with deprecation of the value of feelings.
One who overrates the importance of the understanding.
One who accepts the doctrine of intellectualism.

entry.ety: L. intellectualitas: cf. F. intellectualité
entry.def: Intellectual powers; possession of intellect; quality of being intellectual.

sn.def: To treat in an intellectual manner; to discuss intellectually; to reduce to intellectual form; to express intellectually; to idealize.
sn.q: Sentiment is intellectualized emotion.

sn.def: To endow with intellect; to bestow intellectual qualities upon; to cause to become intellectual.

entry.def: In an intellectual manner.

cs.cd: an office where information may be obtained, particularly respecting servants to be hired.

entry.ety: F. intelligence, L. intelligentia intellegentia. See Intelligent

sn.def: The act or state of knowing; the exercise of the understanding.
The capacity to know or understand; readiness of comprehension; the intellect, as a gift or an endowment.
sn.q: And dimmed with darkness their intelligence.

sn.def: Information communicated; news; notice; advice.
sn.q: Intelligence is given where you are hid.

sn.def: Acquaintance; intercourse; familiarity.
sn.q: He lived rather in a fair intelligence than any friendship with the favorites.

sn.def: Knowledge imparted or acquired, whether by study, research, or experience; general information.
Information about an enemy or potential enemy, his capacities, and intentions.
sn.q: I write as he that none intelligence Of meters hath, ne flowers of sentence.

sn.def: An intelligent being or spirit; -- generally applied to pure spirits; as, a created intelligence .
sn.q: The great Intelligences fair That range above our mortal state, In circle round the blessed gate, Received and gave him welcome there.

sn.def: The division within a military organization that gathers and evaluates information about an enemy.
sn.syn: Understanding; intellect; instruction; advice; notice; notification; news; information; report.

entry.def: One who, or that which, sends or conveys intelligence or news; a messenger.
entry.q: All the intriguers in foreign politics, all the spies, and all the intelligencers . . . acted solely upon that principle.

entry.def: Informing; giving information; talebearing.
entry.q: That sad intelligencing tyrant.

entry.def: Intelligence.

entry.ety: L. intelligens intellegens -entis, p. pr. of intelligere intellegere, to perceive; inter between + legere to gather, collect, choose: cf. F. intelligent. See Legend

sn.def: Endowed with the faculty of understanding or reason; as, man is an intelligent being.

Possessed of a high level of intelligence, education, or judgment; knowing; sensible; skilled; exhibiting high intelligence; as, an intelligent young man; an intelligent architect; an intelligent answer.
Cognizant; aware; communicative.
sn.q: Intelligent of seasons.
Which are to France the spies and speculationsIntelligent of our state.
sn.syn: Sensible; understanding. See Sensible.

entry.ety: Cf. F. intelligentiel

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the intelligence; exercising or implying understanding; intellectual.
sn.q: With actintelligential.

sn.def: Consisting of unembodied mind; incorporeal.
sn.q: Food alike those pureIntelligential substances require.

entry.def: One who gives information; an intelligencer.
In an intelligent manner; with intelligence.
an educated and intellectual{2} elite; intellectuals, collectively or considered as a class.

entry.ety: Cf. F. intelligilibilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being intelligible; clearness; perspicuity; definiteness.

entry.ety: L. intellegibilis: cf. F. intelligible. See Intelligent
entry.def: Capable of being understood or comprehended; as, an intelligible account or description; intelligible pronunciation, writing, etc.
entry.q: The intelligible forms of ancient poets.

entry.def: The quality or state of being intelligible; intelligibility.
In an intelligible manner; so as to be understood; clearly; plainly; as, to write or speak intelligibly .

entry.ety: L. intemeratus; pref. in- not + temeratus defiled
entry.def: Pure; undefiled.
The state of being unpolluted; purity.
A bad state; as, the intemperament of an ulcerated part.

entry.ety: F. intempérance, L. intemperantia. See In- not, and Temperance

sn.def: The act of becoming, or state of being, intemperate; excess in any kind of action or indulgence; any immoderate indulgence of the appetites or passions.
sn.q: God is in every creature; be cruel toward none, neither abuse any by intemperance.
Some, as thou sawest, by violent stroke shall die, By fire, flood, famine, by intemperance more In meats and drinks.

sn.def: Habitual or excessive indulgence in alcoholic liquors.

entry.def: Intemperance.

entry.ety: L. intemperans -antis. See In- not, and Temperant
entry.def: Intemperate.
entry.q: Such as be intemperant, that is, followers of their naughty appetites and lusts.

entry.ety: L. intemperatus. See In- not, and Temperate

sn.def: Indulging any appetite or passion to excess; immoderate in enjoyment or exertion.
addicted to an excessive or habitual use of alcoholic liquors.
Excessive; ungovernable; inordinate; violent; immoderate; as, intemperate language, zeal, etc.; intemperate weather.
sn.q: Most do taste through fond intemperate thirst.
Use not thy mouth to intemperate swearing.

entry.def: To disorder.
In an intemperate manner; immoderately; excessively; without restraint.
entry.q: The people . . . who behaved very unwisely and intemperately on that occasion.

sn.def: The state of being intemperate; excessive indulgence of any appetite or passion; as, intemperateness in eating or drinking.
Severity of weather; inclemency.
sn.q: By unseasonable weather, by intemperateness of the air or meteors.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. intemperature
entry.def: Intemperateness.

entry.ety: L. intempestivus: cf. F. intempestif. See In- not, and Tempestive
entry.def: Out of season; untimely.
entry.q: Intempestive bashfulness gets nothing.

entry.def: Unseasonably.

entry.ety: L. intempestivitas: cf. F. intempestivité
entry.def: Unseasonableness; untimeliness.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + tenable: cf. F. intenable
entry.def: Incapable of being held; untenable; not defensible; as, an intenable opinion; an intenable fortress.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intended; p. pr. & vb. n. Intending
entry.ety: OE. entenden to be attentive, F. entendre, fr. L. intendre intentum, and intensum, to intend, attend, stretch out, extend; pref. in- in + tendere to stretch, stretch out. See Tend

sn.def: To stretch; to extend; to distend.
sn.q: By this the lungs are intended or remitted.

sn.def: To strain; to make tense.
sn.q: When a bow is successively intended and remedied.

sn.def: To intensify; to strengthen.
sn.q: Magnetism may be intended and remitted.

sn.def: To apply with energy.
sn.q: Let him intend his mind, without respite, without rest, in one direction.

sn.def: To bend or turn; to direct, as one's course or journey.
To fix the mind on; to attend to; to take care of; to superintend; to regard.
sn.q: Having no children, she did, with singular care and tenderness, intend the education of Philip.
My soul, not being able to intend two things at once, abated of its fervency in praying.

sn.def: To fix the mind upon (something to be accomplished); to be intent upon; to mean; to design; to plan; to purpose; -- often followed by an infinitely with to, or a dependent clause with that; as, he intends to go; he intends that she shall remain.
sn.q: They intended evil against thee.
To-morrow he intends To hunt the boar with certain of his friends.

sn.def: To design mechanically or artistically; to fashion; to mold.
sn.q: Modesty was made When she was first intended.

sn.def: To pretend; to counterfeit; to simulate.
sn.q: Intend a kind of zeal both to the prince and Claudio.
sn.syn: To purpose; mean; design; plan; conceive; contemplate.

entries.entry:
In*tend"an*cy n.; pl.Intendancies #. Cf. F. intendance. See Intendant
The office or employment of an intendant.
A territorial district committed to the charge of an intendant.

entry.ety: F. intendant, fr. L. intendere to direct (one's thoughts) to a thing. See Intend
entry.def: One who has the charge, direction, or management of some public business; a superintendent; as, an intendant of marine; an intendant of finance.

entry.ety: See Intend
entry.def: Attentive.

sn.def: Made tense; stretched out; extended; forcible; violent.
Purposed; designed; as, intended harm or help.
sn.q: They drew a curse from an intended good.

sn.def: Betrothed; affianced; as, an intended husband.

entry.def: One with whom marriage is designed; one who is betrothed; an affianced lover.
entry.q: If it were not that I might appear to disparage his intended, . . . I would add that to me she seems to be throwing herself away.

entry.def: Intentionally.
See Intendant n.
One who intends.

entry.ety: LL. intendimentum. See Intendment
entry.def: Attention; consideration; knowledge; understanding.

entry.ety: OE. entendement understanding, insight, F. entendement, fr. LL. intendimentum. See Intend

sn.def: Charge; oversight.
Intention; design; purpose.
sn.q: The intendment of God and nature.

sn.def: The true meaning, understanding, or intention of a law, or of any legal instrument.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intenerated; p. pr. & vb. n. Intenerating
entry.ety: Pref. in- in + L. tener soft, tender. See Tender a.
entry.def: To make tender or sensitive; to soften.
entry.q: Fear intenerates the heart.
So have I seen the little purls of a stream . . . intenerate the stubborn pavement.

entry.def: Made tender or soft; softened.
The act or process of intenerating, or the state of being intenerated; softening.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + L. tenere to hold: cf. L. intenibilis not to be grasped. Cf. Intenable
entry.def: Incapable of holding or containing.
entry.q: This captious and intenible sieve.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intensated; p. pr. & vb. n. Intensating
entry.ety: See Intense
entry.def: To intensify.
The act or process of intensifying; intensification; climax.
Adding intensity; intensifying.

entry.ety: L. intensus stretched, tight, p. p. of intendere to stretch: cf. F. intense. See Intend, and cf. Intent, and cf. Intent a.

sn.def: Strained; tightly drawn; kept on the stretch; strict; very close or earnest; as, intense study or application; intense thought.
Extreme in degree; excessive; immoderate;

sd.def: Ardent; fervent; as, intense heat.
Keen; biting; as, intense cold.
Vehement; earnest; exceedingly strong; as, intense passion or hate.
Very severe; violent; as, intense pain or anguish.
Deep; strong; brilliant; as, intense color or light.
sd.q: In this intense seclusion of the forest.

sn.def: Intently.
To an extreme degree; as, weather intensely cold.

entry.def: The state or quality of being intense; intensity; as, the intenseness of heat or cold; the intenseness of study or thought.
The act or process of intensifying, or of making more intense.
made more severe or intense, especially in law.
One who or that which intensifies or strengthens; in photography, an agent used to intensify the lights or shadows of a picture.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intensified; p. pr. & vb. n. Intensifying
entry.ety: Intense + -fly
entry.def: To render more intense; as, to intensify heat or cold; to intensify colors; to intensify a photographic negative; to intensify animosity.
entry.q: How piercing is the sting of pride By want embittered and intensified.

entry.def: To become intense, or more intense; to act with increasing power or energy.

entries.entry: intensifying adj. increasing in strength or intensity.Narrower terms: aggravating, exacerbating, exasperating ; augmentative, enhancive; deepening(prenominal), heightening(prenominal moderating

entry.ety: L. intensio: cf. F. intension. See Intend, and cf. Intention

sn.def: A straining, stretching, or bending; the state of being strained; as, the intension of a musical string.
Increase of power or energy of any quality or thing; intenseness; fervency.
sn.q: Sounds . . . likewise do rise and fall with the intension or remission of the wind.

sn.def: The collective attributes, qualities, or marks that make up a complex general notion; the comprehension, content, or connotation; -- opposed to extension extent, or sphere.
sn.q: This law is, that the intension of our knowledge is in the inverse ratio of its extension.

entry.def: Increasing the force or intensity of; intensive; as, the intensitive words of a sentence.

entry.ety: LL. intensitas: cf. F. intensité. See Intense

sn.def: The state or quality of being intense; intenseness; extreme degree; as, intensity of heat, cold, mental application, passion, etc.
sn.q: If you would deepen the intensity of light, you must be content to bring into deeper blackness and more distinct and definite outline the shade that accompanies it.

sn.def: The amount or degree of energy with which a force operates or a cause acts; effectiveness, as estimated by results produced.

The magnitude of a distributed force, as pressure, stress, weight, etc., per unit of surface, or of volume, as the case may be; as, the measure of the intensity of a total stress of forty pounds which is distributed uniformly over a surface of four square inches area is ten pounds per square inch.
The degree or depth of color or shade in a picture.

entry.ety: Cf. F. intensif. See Intense

sn.def: Stretched; admitting of intension, or increase of degree; that can be intensified.
Characterized by persistence; intent; unremitted; assiduous; intense.
Serving to give force or emphasis; as, an intensive verb or preposition.

Designating, or pertaining to, any system of farming or horticulture, usually practiced on small pieces of land, in which the soil is thoroughly worked and fertilized so as to get as much return as possible; -- opposed to extensive.

entry.def: That which intensifies or emphasizes; an intensive verb or word.
In an intensive manner; by increase of degree.
The quality or state of being intensive; intensity.

entry.ety: L. intentus, p. p. of intendere. See Intend, and cf. Intense

sn.def: Closely directed; strictly attentive; bent; -- said of the mind, thoughts, etc.; as, a mind intent on self-improvement.
Having the mind closely directed to or bent on an object; sedulous; eager in pursuit of an object; -- formerly with to, but now with on; as, intent on business or pleasure.
sn.q: Intenton mischief.
Be intent and solicitous to take up the meaning of the speaker.

entry.cs: To all intents and purposes in all applications or senses; practically; really; virtually; in essence; essentially. “He was miserable to all intents and purpose.” L'Estrange.
entry.ety: OE. entent entente, attention, purpose, OF. entente, F. entente understanding, meaning; a participial noun, fr. F. & OF. entendre. See Intend
entry.def: The act of turning the mind toward an object; hence, a design; a purpose; intention; meaning; drift; aim.
entry.q: Be thy intents wicked or charitable.
The principal intent of Scripture is to deliver the laws of duties supernatural.
entry.syn: Design; purpose; intention; meaning; purport; view; drift; object; end; aim; plan.

entry.def: Intention.

cs.cd: a conception of a thing formed by the first or direct application of the mind to the individual object; an idea or image; as, man stone.
a conception generalized from first intuition or apprehension already formed by the mind; an abstract notion; especially, a classified notion, as species genus whiteness.
cs.col: To heal by the first intention
cs.cd: to cicatrize, as a wound, without suppuration.
cs.col: To heal by the second intention
cs.cd: to unite after suppuration.

entry.ety: F. intention, L. intentio. See Intend, and cf. Intension

sn.def: A stretching or bending of the mind toward an object; closeness of application; fixedness of attention; earnestness.
sn.q: Intention is when the mind, with great earnestness, and of choice, fixes its view on any idea.

sn.def: A determination to act in a certain way or to do a certain thing; purpose; design; as, an intention to go to New York.
sn.q: Hell is paved with good intentions.

sn.def: The object toward which the thoughts are directed; end; aim.
sn.q: In [chronical distempers], the principal intention is to restore the tone of the solid parts.

sn.def: The state of being strained. See Intension.
Any mental apprehension of an object.
sn.syn: Design; purpose; object; aim; intent; drift; purport; meaning. See Design.

entry.ety: Cf. F. intentionnel
entry.def: Done by intention or design; intended; designed; as, the act was intentional, not accidental. Opposite of unintentional or unintended.
The quality or state of being intentional; purpose; design.
In an intentional manner; with intention; by design; of purpose.
Having designs; -- chiefly used in composition; as, well-intentioned, having good designs; ill-intentioned, having ill designs.

entry.ety: OE. ententif, OF. ententif, fr. L. intentivus intensive. See Intent n., and cf. Intensive
entry.def: Attentive; intent.
Attentively; closely.
entry.q: Intentivelyto observe.

entry.def: Closeness of attention or application of mind; attentiveness.
In an intent manner; as, the eyes intently fixed.
entry.syn: Fixedly; steadfastly; earnestly; attentively; sedulously; diligently; eagerly.

entry.def: The state or quality of being intent; close application; attention.
entry.q: Extreme solicitude or intentness upon business.

entries.entry:
In"ter-. L. inter, prep., among, between, a compar. form of in in; akin to intra intro, within, Skr. antar between, in, and E. in. See In, and cf. Entrails Interior Enter- Exterior
A prefix signifying among between amid; as, interact, interarticular, intermit.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interred; p. pr. & vb. n. Interring
entry.ety: OE. enteren, OF. enterer enterrer, LL. interrare; L. pref. in- in + terra the earth. See Terrace
entry.def: To deposit and cover in the earth; to bury; to inhume; as, to inter a dead body.

entry.ety: Pref. inter- + act. Cf. Entr'acte
entry.def: A short act or piece between others, as in a play; an interlude; hence, intermediate employment or time.
To act upon each other; as, two agents mutually interact .

sn.def: Intermediate action.
Mutual or reciprocal action or influence; as, the interaction of the heart and lungs on each other.
The effect, such as exertion of a force, that one object exerts on another, especially the capture or emission of a particle.
Communication between people, or the actions of people that affect others.

entry.def: Added or placed between the parts of another thing, as a clause inserted parenthetically in a sentence.
Intermediate agency.
An intermediate agent.
Entrail or inside.
Between alveoli; as, the interalveolar septa between adjacent air cells in the lungs.
Of or pertaining to the interambulacra.

entries.entry: ‖In`ter*am`bu*la"crum n.; pl. L. Interambulacra, E. Interambulacrums. Zoöl In echinoderms, one of the areas or zones intervening between two ambulacra. See Illust. of Ambulacrum.

entry.ety: Pref. inter- + L. amnis river: cf. L. interamnus
entry.def: Situated between rivers.
entry.q: Aninteramniancountry.

entry.def: To animate or inspire mutually.
The interweaving of branches of trees.
Situated between joints or articulations; as, interarticular cartilages and ligaments.
Between atoms; situated, or acting, between the atoms of bodies; as, interatomic forces.
Existing between royal courts.
entry.q: Interaulicpolitics.

entry.def: Between the auricles; as, the interauricular partition of the heart.
Situated in an interaxis.
Situated within or between the axils of leaves.

entries.entry: In`ter*ax"is n.; pl.Interaxes. Arch The space between two axes. See Axis, 6. The doors, windows, niches, and the like, are then placed centrally in the interaxes.

entry.ety: Pref. inter- + baste to sew
entry.def: Patchwork.
Between the arms.
See Thalamencephalon.
Between the branchiæ.
To breed by crossing different stocks of animals or plants.
Intercalary.

cs.cd: one on which no paroxysm of an intermittent disease occurs.

entry.ety: L. intercalaris intercalarius: cf. F. intercalaire. See Intercalate

sn.def: Inserted or introduced among others in the calendar; as, an intercalary month, day, etc.; -- now applied particularly to the odd day (Feb. 29) inserted in the calendar of leap year. See Bissextile n.
Introduced or inserted among others; additional; supernumerary.
sn.q: Intercalaryspines.
This intercalary line . . . is made the last of a triplet.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intercalated; p. pr. & vb. n. Intercalating
entry.ety: L. intercalatus, p. p. of intercalare to intercalate to intercalate; inter between + calare to call, proclaim. See Calendar

sn.def: To insert, as a day or other portion of time, in a calendar.
To insert among others, as a verse in a stanza; specif. Geol, to introduce as a bed or stratum, between the layers of a regular series of rocks.
sn.q: Beds of fresh-water shells . . . are intercalated and interstratified with the shale.

entry.ety: L. intercalatio: cf. F. intercalation

sn.def: The insertion of a day, or other portion of time, in a calendar.
The insertion or introduction of anything among others, as the insertion of a phrase, line, or verse in a metrical composition;
the intrusion of a bed or layer between other layers.
sn.q: Intercalations of fresh-water species in some localities.

entry.def: Situated between the external and internal carotid arteries; as, an intercarotid ganglion.
Between the carpal bone; as, intercarpal articulations, ligaments.
Within cartilage; endochondral; as, intercartilaginous ossification.
Between the cavernous sinuses; as, the intercavernous sinuses connecting the cavernous sinuses at the base of the brain.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interceded; p. pr. & vb. n. Interceding
entry.ety: L. intercedere intercessum; inter between + cedere to pass: cf. F. intercéder. See Cede

sn.def: To pass between; to intervene.
sn.q: He supposed that a vast period interceded between that origination and the age wherein he lived.

sn.def: To act between parties with a view to reconcile differences; to make intercession; to beg or plead in behalf of another; to mediate; -- usually followed by with and for or on behalf of; as, I will intercede with him for you.
sn.q: I to the lords will intercede, not doubting Their favorable ear.
sn.syn: To mediate; arbitrate. See Interpose.

entry.def: To be, to come, or to pass, between; to separate.
The act of interceding; intercession; intervention.

entry.ety: L. intercedens, p. pr. of intercedere
entry.def: Passing between; mediating; pleading.
One who intercedes; an intercessor; a mediator.
Lying between cells or cellules; as, intercellular substance, space, or fluids; intercellular blood channels.

cs.cd: those nerves which transmit impulses between nerve centers, as opposed to peripheral fibers, which convey impulses between peripheral parts and nerve centers.

entry.def: Between centers.

entries.entry: ‖In`ter*cen"trum n.; pl.Intercentra. Anat The median of the three elements composing the centra of the vertebræ in some fossil batrachians.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intercepted; p. pr. & vb. n. Intercepting
entry.ety: L. interceptus, p. p. of intercipere to intercept; inter between + capere to take, seize: cf. F. intercepter. See Capable

sn.def: To take or seize by the way, or before arrival at the destined place; to cause to stop on the passage; as, to intercept a letter; a telegram will intercept him at Paris.
sn.q: God will shortly intercept your breath.

sn.def: To obstruct or interrupt the progress of; to stop; to hinder or oppose; as, to intercept the current of a river.
sn.q: Who intercepts me in my expedition?
We must meet first, and intercept his course.

sn.def: To interrupt communication with, or progress toward; to cut off, as the destination; to blockade.
sn.q: While storms vindictive intercept the shore.

sn.def: To include between; as, that part of the line which is intercepted between the points A and B.
To overhear or view (a communication or message intended for another), without hindering its passage; as, to intercept a telephone call.
To catch and take possession of (a ball passed between members of an opposing team); as, the back intercepted the pass and ran the ball back for a touchdown.
sn.syn: To cut off; stop; catch; seize; obstruct.

entry.def: A part cut off or intercepted, as a portion of a line included between two points, or cut off two straight lines or curves.

sn.def: One who, or that which, intercepts.

A high-speed fighter airplane with fast-climbing capability, used to intercept enemy airplanes or identify unknown aircraft and engage them in combat if necessary; also, a missile which intercepts and destroys incoming missiles or airplanes.

entry.ety: L. interceptio a taking away: cf. F. interception
entry.def: The act of intercepting; as, interception of a letter; interception of the enemy.
Intercepting or tending to intercept.
Same as intercepter.

entry.ety: L. intercessio an intervention, a becoming surety: cf. F. intercession. See Intercede
entry.def: The act of interceding; mediation; interposition between parties at variance, with a view to reconcilation; prayer, petition, or entreaty in favor of, or (less often) against, another or others.
entry.q: But the Spirit itself maketh intercession for us with groanings which can not be uttered.

entry.def: Pertaining to, of the nature of, or characterized by, intercession or entreaty.
To entreat.

entry.ety: L., a surety: cf. F. intercesseur

sn.def: One who goes between, or intercedes; a mediator.

sd.def: One who interposes between parties at variance, with a view to reconcile them.
One who pleads in behalf of another.

sn.def: A bishop, who, during a vacancy of the see, administers the bishopric till a successor is installed.

entry.def: Intercessory.

entry.ety: LL. intercessorius
entry.def: Pertaining to, of the nature of, or characterized by, intercession; interceding; as, intercessory prayer.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interchained; p. pr. & vb. n. Interchaining
entry.def: To link together; to unite closely or firmly, as by a chain.
entry.q: Two bosoms interchained with an oath.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interchanged; p. pr. & vb. n. Interchanging
entry.ety: OE. entrechangen, OF. entrechangier. See Inter-, and Change

sn.def: To put each in the place of the other; to give and take mutually; to exchange; to reciprocate; as, to interchange places; they interchanged friendly offices and services.
sn.q: I shall interchange My waned state for Henry's regal crown.

sn.def: To cause to follow alternately; to intermingle; to vary; as, to interchange cares with pleasures.

entry.def: To make an interchange; to alternate.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. entrechange

sn.def: The act of mutually changing; the act of mutually giving and receiving; exchange; as, the interchange of civilities between two persons.
sn.q: Interchangeof kindnesses.

sn.def: The mutual exchange of commodities between two persons or countries; barter; commerce.
Alternate succession; alternation; a mingling.
sn.q: The interchanges of light and darkness.
Sweet interchange Of hill and valley, rivers, woods, and plains.

sn.def: An intersection between highways, having two or more levels and a series of connecting roadways so that traffic on one highway may pass over or under the other highway without crossing through the line of traffic, and vehicles may pass from one highway to the other while traffic on both highways continues uninterrupted. A common interchange is the cloverleaf.

entry.def: The state or quality of being interchangeable; interchangeableness.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. entrechangeable

sn.def: Admitting of exchange or mutual substitution.
sn.q: Interchangeablewarrants.

sn.def: Following each other in alternate succession; as, the four interchangeable seasons.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. entrechangement
entry.def: Mutual transfer; exchange.
An intervening or inserted chapter.

entry.ety: See Intercident
entry.def: The act or state of coming or falling between; occurrence; incident.

entry.ety: L. intercidens -entis, p. pr. of intercidere to fall between; inter between + cadere to fall
entry.def: Falling or coming between; happening accidentally.

entry.ety: L. intercipiens -entis, p. pr. of intercipere. See Intercept
entry.def: Intercepting; stopping.

def2.def: One who, or that which, intercepts or stops anything on the passage.

entry.ety: L. intercisio a cutting through, fr. intercidere to cut asunder
entry.def: A cutting off, through, or asunder; interruption.
The mutual right to civic privileges, in the different States.
See Episternum.
Between the clavicles; as, the interclavicular notch of the sternum.
Of or pertaining to the interclavicle.

entry.ety: Pref. inter- + close. See Interclude
entry.def: To shut in; to inclose.
To cloud.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intercluded; p. pr. & vb. n. Intercluding
entry.ety: L. intercludere interclusum; inter between + claudere to shut. See Close, and cf. Interclose
entry.def: To shut off or out from a place or course, by something intervening; to intercept; to cut off; to interrupt.
entry.q: So all passage of external air into the receiver may be intercluded.

entry.ety: L. interclusio. See Interclude
entry.def: Interception; a stopping; obstruction.
Existing or carried on between colleges or universities; as, intercollegiate relations, rivalry, games, etc.
Situated between hills; -- applied especially to valleys lying between volcanic cones.
Between or among colonies; pertaining to the intercourse or mutual relations of colonies; as, intercolonial trade.
Between columns or pillars; as, the intercolumnar fibers of Poupart's ligament; an intercolumnar statue.

entry.note: ☞ It is customary to measure the intercolumniation in terms of the diameter of the shaft, taken also at the bottom. Different words, derived from the Greek, are in use to denote certain common proportions. They are: Pycnostyle, when the intercolumniation is of one and a half diameters; Systyle, of two diameters; Eustyle, of two and a quarter diameters; Diastyle, of three diameters; Aræostyle, of four or more, and so great that a wooden architrave has to be used instead of stone; Aræosystyle, when the intercolumniations are alternately systyle and aræostyle.
entry.def: The clear space between two columns, measured at the bottom of their shafts.
Combat.
The act of coming between; intervention; interference.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intercommoned; p. pr. & vb. n. Intercommoning
entry.ety: OF. entrecommuner. See Inter-, and Common, and cf. Intercommune

sn.def: To share with others; to participate; especially, to eat at the same table.
To graze cattle promiscuously in the commons of each other, as the inhabitants of adjoining townships, manors, etc.

entry.def: The right or privilege of intercommoning.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intercommuned; p. pr. & vb. n. Intercommuning
entry.ety: Cf. Intercommon Intercommunicate Commune

sn.def: To intercommunicate.
To have mutual communication or intercourse by conversation.

entry.def: Capable of being mutually communicated.
To communicate mutually; to hold mutual communication.
To communicate mutually; to interchange.
Mutual communication.
Mutual communion; as, an intercommunion of deities.
Intercommunication; community of possessions, religion, etc.
entry.q: In consequence of that intercommunity of paganism . . . one nation adopted the gods of another.

entry.def: Mutual comparison of corresponding parts.
Between condyles; as, the intercondylar fossa or notch of the femur.
To join together; to connect with one another.
To become connected with one another.

entry.sn: having internal connections between parts.Narrower terms: reticulate (vs. nonreticulate interrelated.

sn.def: operating as a unit.
sn.syn: coordinated, unified.

entry.def: a state of being connected reciprocally.
Connection between; mutual connection.

sn.def: Between or among continents; subsisting or carried on between continents; as, intercontinental relations or commerce.
Passing between continents or capable of passing between continents; as, an intercontinental ballistic misile; an intercontinental airplane flight.

entry.def: Convertible the one into the other; as, coin and bank notes are interconvertible .
Between the ribs; pertaining to, or produced by, the parts between the ribs; as, intercostal respiration, in which the chest is alternately enlarged and contracted by the intercostal muscles.

cs.cd: sexual or carnal connection; coition; copulation, especially between humans.

entry.ety: Formerly entercourse, OF. entrecours commerce, exchange, F. entrecours a reciprocal right on neighboring lands, L. intercursus a running between, fr. intercurrere to run between. See Inter-, and Course

sn.def: A commingling; intimate connection or dealings between persons or nations, as in common affairs and civilities, in correspondence or trade; communication; commerce; especially, interchange of thought and feeling; association; communion.
sn.q: This sweet intercourse Of looks and smiles.

sn.def: Same as sexual intercourse.
sn.syn: Communication; connection; commerce; communion; fellowship; familiarity; acquaintance.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. -cropped; p. pr. & vb. n. -cropping
entry.def: To cultivate by planting simultaneous crops in alternate rows; as, to intercrop an orchard. Also, to use for catch crops at seasons when the ground is not covered by crops of the regular rotation.
A crop grown among or between the rows of another crop; a catch crop.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intercrossed; p. pr. & vb. n. Intercrossing

sn.def: To cross each other, as lines.
To fertilize by the impregnation of one species or variety by another; to impregnate by a different species or variety.

entry.def: The process or result of cross fertilization between different kinds of animals, or different varieties of plants.
entry.q: We have reason to believe that occasional intercrosses take place with all animals and plants.

entry.def: Between crura; -- applied especially to the interneural plates in the vertebral column of many cartilaginous fishes.

entry.ety: L. intercurrere. See Intercourse
entry.def: To intervene; to come or occur in the meantime.

entry.ety: See Intercurrent
entry.def: A passing or running between; occurrence.

entry.ety: L. intercurrens, p. pr. of intercurrere: cf. F. intercurrent. See Intercur

sn.def: Running between or among; intervening.

sd.def: Not belonging to any particular season.
Said of diseases occurring in the course of another disease.

entry.def: Something intervening.
Subcutaneous.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interdashed; p. pr. & vb. n. Interdashing
entry.def: To dash between or among; to intersperse.
To intrigue.
Occurring between or among, or common to, different denominations; as, interdenominational fellowship or belief.

sn.def: Situated between teeth; as, an interdental space, the space between two teeth in a gear wheel.
Formed between the upper and lower teeth; as, interdental consonants.

entry.def: The space between two dentils.
Mutual dependence.
entry.q: Theinterdependenceof virtue and knowledge.

entry.def: Mutual dependence; as, interdependency of interests.
Mutually dependent.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interdicted; p. pr. & vb. n. Interdicting
entry.ety: OE. entrediten to forbid communion, L. interdicere interdictum. See Interdict n.

sn.def: To forbid; to prohibit or debar; as, to interdict intercourse with foreign nations.
sn.q: Charged not to touch the interdicted tree.

sn.def: To lay under an interdict; to cut off from the enjoyment of religious privileges, as a city, a church, an individual.
sn.q: An archbishop may not only excommunicate and interdict his suffragans, but his vicar general may do the same.

entry.ety: OE. entredit enterdit, OF. entredit, F. interdit, fr. L. interdictum, fr. interdicere to interpose, prohibit; inter between + dicere to say. See Diction

sn.def: A prohibitory order or decree; a prohibition.
sn.q: These are not fruits forbidden; no interdict Defends the touching of these viands pure.

sn.def: A prohibition of the pope, by which the clergy or laymen are restrained from performing, or from attending, divine service, or from administering the offices or enjoying the privileges of the church.
An order of the court of session, having the like purpose and effect with a writ of injunction out of chancery in England and America.

entry.ety: L. interdictio: cf. F. interdiction
entry.def: The act of interdicting; prohibition; prohibiting decree; curse; interdict.
entry.q: The truest issue of thy throne By his own interdiction stands accurst.

entry.def: Having the power to prohibit; as, an interdictive sentence.

entry.ety: L. interdictorius
entry.def: Belonging to an interdiction; prohibitory.
Between the fingers or toes; as, interdigital space.
To interweave.

entry.ety: Pref. inter- + L. digitus finger
entry.def: To interlock, as the fingers of two hands that are joined; to be interwoven; to commingle.
The state of interdigitating; interdigital space.
The open space between the inner and outer shells of a dome or cupola of masonry.

entry.ety: Cf. F. entre-deux, literally, between two
entry.def: An intertie.
Between the epimeral plates of insects and crustaceans.
Coming between the equinoxes.
entry.q: Summer and winter I have called interequinoctial intervals.

entry.ety: See Interest v. t.
entry.def: To interest or affect.
Interest.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interested; p. pr. & vb. n. Interesting
entry.ety: From interess'd, p. p. of the older form interess, fr. F. intéresser, L. interesse. See Interest n.

sn.def: To engage the attention of; to awaken interest in; to excite emotion or passion in, in behalf of a person or thing; as, the subject did not interest him; to interest one in charitable work.
sn.q: To love our native country . . . to be interested in its concerns is natural to all men.
A goddess who used to interest herself in marriages.

sn.def: To be concerned with or engaged in; to affect; to concern; to excite; -- often used impersonally.
sn.q: Or rather, gracious sir, Create me to this glory, since my cause Doth interest this fair quarrel.

sn.def: To cause or permit to share.
sn.q: The mystical communion of all faithful men is such as maketh every one to be interested in those precious blessings which any one of them receiveth at God's hands.
sn.syn: To concern; excite; attract; entertain; engage; occupy; hold.

entry.note: ☞ Interest expresses mental excitement of various kinds and degrees. It may be intellectual, or sympathetic and emotional, or merely personal; as, an interest in philosophical research; an interest in human suffering; the interest which an avaricious man takes in money getting.

cs.cd: interest, not only on the original principal, but also on unpaid interest from the time it fell due.
interest on the principal sum without interest on overdue interest.

entry.ety: OF. interest, F. intérêt, fr. L. interest it interests, is of interest, fr. interesse to be between, to be difference, to be importance; inter between + esse to be; cf. LL. interesse usury. See Essence

sn.def: Excitement of feeling, whether pleasant or painful, accompanying special attention to some object; concern; a desire to learn more about a topic or engage often in an activity.
sn.q: So much interest have I in thy sorrow.

sn.def: Participation in advantage, profit, and responsibility; share; portion; part; as, an interest in a brewery; he has parted with his interest in the stocks.
Advantage, personal or general; good, regarded as a selfish benefit; profit; benefit.
sn.q: Divisions hinder the common interest and public good.
When interest calls of all her sneaking train.

sn.def: A fee paid for the use of money; a fee paid for a loan; -- usually reckoned as a percentage; as, interest at five per cent per annum on ten thousand dollars.
sn.q: They have told their money, and let out Their coin upon large interest.

sn.def: Any excess of advantage over and above an exact equivalent for what is given or rendered.
sn.q: You shall have your desires with interest.

sn.def: The persons interested in any particular business or measure, taken collectively; as, the iron interest; the cotton interest.

entry.ety: See Interest v. t.

sn.def: Having the attention engaged; having emotion or passion excited; as, an interested listener.
Having an interest; concerned in a cause or in consequences; liable to be affected or prejudiced; as, an interested witness; an interested party.

entry.def: The state or quality of being interested; selfishness.
Engaging the attention; exciting, or adapted to excite, interest, curiosity, or emotion; as, an interesting story; interesting news.
In an interesting manner.
The condition or quality of being interesting.

sn.def: a surface forming a common boundary between two things, especially between two fluids.
hardware that links one device with another (especially a computer).

That part of a computer program which controls the way a program interacts with a user; the manner of inputting and outputting of data, and the way information is presented on a computer monitor; also called user interface; as, a graphical user interface; a character-based interface .
Included between two plane surfaces or faces; as, an interfacial angle.
Of or pertaining to an interface.

entry.def: involving persons of different religious faiths; as, an interfaith marriage; interfaith good will.
Between fascicles or bundles; as, the interfascicular spaces of connective tissue.
One of the contestants in interference before the Patent Office.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interfered; p. pr. & vb. n. Interfering
entry.ety: OF. entreferir to strike each other; entre between (L. inter) + OF. ferir to strike, F. férir, fr. L. ferire. See Ferula

sn.def: To come in collision; to be in opposition; to clash; -- usually used with with; as, interfering claims, or commands; workers in a crowded shop may interfere with each other's activity.
To enter into, or take a part in, the concerns of others; to intermeddle; to interpose; -- used with in or with; as, to interfere with the way I raise my children.
sn.q: To interfere with party disputes.
There was no room for anyone to interfere with his own opinions.

sn.def: To strike one foot against the opposite foot or ankle in using the legs; -- sometimes said of a human being, but usually of a horse; as, the horse interferes .
To act reciprocally, so as to augment, diminish, or otherwise affect one another; -- said of waves, rays of light, heat, etc. See Interference, 2.
To cover the same ground; to claim the same invention; as, to interfere with another patent.
sn.syn: To interpose; intermeddle. See Interpose.

entry.note: ☞ The term is most commonly applied to light, and the undulatory theory of light affords the proper explanation of the phenomena which are considered to be produced by the superposition of waves, and are thus substantially identical in their origin with the phenomena of heat, sound, waves of water, and the like.
entry.cs: Interference figures Optics the figures observed when certain sections of crystallized bodies are viewed in converging polarized light; thus, a section of a uniaxial crystal, cut normal to the vertical axis, shows a series of concentric colored rings with a single black cross; -- so called because produced by the interference of luminous waves. Interference fringe. Optics See Fringe.
entry.ety: See Interfere

sn.def: The act or state of interfering; as, the stoppage of a machine by the interference of some of its parts; a meddlesome interference in the business of others.

The mutual influence, under certain conditions, as from streams of light, or pulsations of sound, or, generally, two waves or vibrations of any kind, producing certain characteristic phenomena, as colored fringes, dark bands, or darkness, in the case of light, silence or increased intensity in sounds; neutralization or superposition of waves generally.
The act or state of interfering, or of claiming a right to the same invention.

entry.def: One who interferes.
By or with interference.

entry.ety: See Interfere and -meter
entry.def: An instrument for measuring small movements, distances, or displacements by means of the interference of two beams of light; -- formerly also called also refractometer, but that word now has a different meaning.
To flow in.

entry.ety: L. interfluens, p. pr., and interfluus. See Inter-, and Fluent
entry.def: Flowing between or among; intervening.
Intertwined; interlocked; clasped together.

entry.ety: Pref. inter- + foliaceous: cf. F. interfoliacé
entry.def: At the same node with opposite or whorled leaves, but occupying a position between their places of attachment.

entry.ety: Pref. inter- + L. folium leaf
entry.def: To interleave.
Between follicles; as, the interfollicular septa in a lymphatic gland.
Interlaced; linked together; -- said of charges or bearings. See Fretted.

entry.ety: L. interfulgens, p. pr. See Inter-, and Fulgent
entry.def: Shining between.

entry.ety: L. interfusus, p. p. of interfundere to pour between; inter between + fundere to pour. See Fuse to melt

sn.def: To pour or spread between or among; to diffuse; to scatter.
sn.q: The ambient air, wide interfused, Embracing round this florid earth.

sn.def: To spread through; to permeate; to pervade.
sn.q: Keats, in whom the moral seems to have so perfectly interfused the physical man, that you might almost say he could feel sorrow with his hands.

sn.def: To mix up together; to associate.

entry.ety: L. interfusio
entry.def: The act of interfusing, or the state of being interfused.
Between and uniting the nervous ganglions; as, interganglionic cords.
Between globules; -- applied esp. to certain small spaces, surrounded by minute globules, in dentine.

entry.vmorph: imp. Intergraved; p. p. Intergraved or Intergraven�); p. pr. & vb. n. Intergraving
entry.def: To grave or carve between; to engrave in the alternate sections.
entry.q: The work itself of the bases, was intergraven.

entry.def: Between the hemal arches or hemal spines.

entry.ety: Inter- + the Greek letter �
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a segment sometimes present at the proximal end of the hyoidean arch.

entry.ety: L., fr. inter between + im, an old accusative of is he, this, that

sn.def: The meantime; time intervening; interval between events, etc.
sn.q: All the interim is Like a phantasms, or a hideous dream.

sn.def: A name given to each of three compromises made by the emperor Charles V. of Germany for the sake of harmonizing the connecting opinions of Protestants and Catholics.

cs.cd: an angle formed between two sides, within any rectilinear figure, as a polygon, or between two parallel lines by these lines and another intersecting them; -- called also internal angle.
those planets within the orbit of the earth.
a screw cut on an interior surface, as in a nut; a female screw.

entry.ety: L., compar. fr. inter between: cf. F. intérieur. See Inter-, and cf. Intimate

sn.def: Being within any limits, inclosure, or substance; inside; internal; inner; -- opposed to exterior, or superficial; as, the interior apartments of a house; the interior surface of a hollow ball.
Remote from the limits, frontier, or shore; inland; as, the interior parts of a region or country.
sn.syn: Internal; inside; inner; inland; inward.

cs.cd: that department of the government of the United States which has charge of pensions, patents, public lands and surveys, the Indians, education, etc.; that department of the government of a country which is specially charged with the internal affairs of that country; the home department.
the cabinet officer who, in the United States, is at the head of the Department of the Interior.

sn.def: That which is within; the internal or inner part of a thing; the inside.
The inland part of a country, state, or kingdom.

entry.def: to incorporate within oneself; same as interiorize.
State of being interior.
to incorporate within oneself.
Internally; inwardly.

entry.ety: See Interjacent
entry.def: The state of being between; a coming or lying between or among; intervention; also, that which lies between.
entry.q: England and Scotland is divided only by the interjacency of the Tweed.

entry.ety: L. interjacens -entis, p. pr. of interjacere to lie between; inter between + jacēre to lie
entry.def: Lying or being between or among; intervening; as, interjacent isles.
To ejaculate parenthetically.
To make a dissonant, discordant noise one with another; to talk or chatter noisily.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interjected; p. pr. & vb. n. Interjecting
entry.ety: L. interjectus, p. p. of interjicere to interject; inter between + jacĕre to throw. See Jet a shooting forth
entry.def: To throw in between; to insert; to interpose.
To throw one's self between or among; to come between; to interpose.

entry.ety: L. interjectio: cf. F. interjection. See Interject

sn.def: The act of interjecting or throwing between; also, that which is interjected.
sn.q: The interjection of laughing.

sn.def: A word or form of speech thrown in to express emotion or feeling, as O! Alas! Ha ha! Begone! etc. Compare Exclamation.
sn.q: An interjection implies a meaning which it would require a whole grammatical sentence to expound, and it may be regarded as the rudiment of such a sentence. But it is a confusion of thought to rank it among the parts of speech.
How now! interjections? Why, then, some be of laughing, as, ah, ha, he!

sn.def: Thrown in between other words or phrases; parenthetical; ejaculatory; as, an interjectional remark.
Pertaining to, or having the nature of, an interjection; consisting of natural and spontaneous exclamations.
sn.q: Certain of the natural accompaniments of interjectional speech, such as gestures, grimaces, and gesticulations, are restrained by civilization.

entry.def: To convert into, or to use as, an interjection.
In an interjectional manner.
Interjectional.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interjoined; p. pr. & vb. n. Interjoining
entry.ety: Pref. inter + join
entry.def: To join mutually; to unite.

sn.def: The space or interval between two joists.
A middle joist or crossbeam.

entry.ety: L. interjunctus, p. p. of interjungere to join together. See Inter-, and Join, and cf. Interjoin
entry.def: A mutual joining.
To knit together; to unite closely; to intertwine.
To know mutually.
Mutual knowledge or acquaintance.

cs.cd: arches, usually circular, so constructed that their archivolts intersect and seem to be interlaced.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interlaced; p. pr. & vb. n. Interlacing
entry.ety: OE. entrelacen, F. entrelacer. See Inter-, and Lace
entry.def: To unite, as by lacing together; to insert or interpose one thing within another; to intertwine; to interweave.
entry.q: Severed into stripes That interlaced each other.
The epic way is everywhere interlaced with dialogue.

entry.ety: Cf. F. entrelacement
entry.def: The act of interlacing, or the state of being interlaced; also, that which is interlaced.
Between lammellæ or laminæ; as, interlamellar spaces.
Placed between, or containing, laminæ or plates.
The state of being interlaminated.

entry.ety: Pref. inter- + lapse: cf. L. interlabi interlapsus, to fall, slide, or flow, between
entry.def: The lapse or interval of time between two events.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interlarded; p. pr. & vb. n. Interlarding
entry.ety: F. entrelarder. See Inter-, and Lard

sn.def: To place lard or bacon amongst; to mix, as fat meat with lean.
sn.q: Whose grain doth rise in flakes, with fatness interlarded.

sn.def: Hence: To insert between; to mix or mingle; especially, to introduce that which is foreign or irrelevant; as, to interlard a conversation with oaths or allusions.
sn.q: The English laws . . . [were] mingled and interlarded with many particular laws of their own.
They interlard their native drinks with choice Of strongest brandy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interlaid; p. pr. & vb. n. Interlaying
entry.def: To lay or place among or between.

entries.entry:
In"ter*leaf` n.; pl.Interleaves #. See Interleave
A leaf inserted between other leaves; a blank leaf inserted, as in a book.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interleaved; p. pr. & vb. n. Interleaving
entry.ety: Pref. inter- + leaf

sn.def: To insert a leaf or leaves in; to bind with blank leaves inserted between the others; as, to interleave a book.
To insert something alternately between the parts of; as, to interleave transparencies with the corresponding pages.

entry.def: To libel mutually.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interlined; p. pr. & vb. n. Interlining
entry.ety: Pref. inter- + line: cf. LL. interlineare, F. interlinéer, OF. entreligner

sn.def: To write or insert between lines already written or printed, as for correction or addition; to write or print something between the lines of; as, to interline a page or a book.
To arrange in alternate lines; as, to interline Latin and English.
To mark or imprint with lines.
sn.q: A crooked wrinkle interlines my brow.

entry.ety: Cf. LL. interlinearis, F. interlinéaire
entry.def: Contained between lines; written or inserted between lines already written or printed; containing interlineations; as, an interlinear manuscript, translation, etc.
Interlinear.

entry.ety: Cf. F. interlinéation

sn.def: The act of interlining.
That which is interlined; a passage, word, or line inserted between lines already written or printed.

entry.def: A language used as an intermediate language in translating from a source language to a target language; -- used especially in machine translation by computers; as, some machine translation systems use Esperanto as an interlingua .
Correction or alteration by writing between the lines; interlineation.
To link together; to join, as one chain to another.
An intermediate or connecting link.
Between lobes; as, the interlobar notch of the liver; the interlobar ducts of a gland.

entry.ety: Pref. inter- + lobular: cf. F. interlobulaire
entry.def: Between lobules; as, the interlobular branches of the portal vein.
