To unite, embrace, communicate with, or flow into, one another; to be connected in one system; to lock into one another; to interlace firmly.

sn.def: To unite by locking or linking together; to secure in place by mutual fastening.
sn.q: My lady with her fingers interlocked.

sn.def: To connect together so that the parts work together as a coordinated unit; to connect as a single system.

entry.def: Connected together in such a manner that the parts work together as a single unit, or in a coordianted manner.

entry.ety: L. interlocutio, from interloqui interlocutus, to speak between; inter between + loqui to speak: cf. F. interlocution. See Loquacious

sn.def: Interchange of speech; dialogue; conversation; conference.
An intermediate act or decree before final decision.
Hence, intermediate argument or discussion.

entry.ety: Cf. F. interlocuteur

sn.def: One who takes part in dialogue or conversation; a talker, interpreter, or questioner.
An interlocutory judgment or sentence.

entry.note: ☞ An order, sentence, decree, or judgment, given in an intermediate stage between the commencement and termination of a cause, is called interlocutory.
entry.ety: Cf. LL. interlocutorius, F. interlocutoire

sn.def: Consisting of, or having the nature of, dialogue; conversational.
sn.q: Interlocutory discourses in the Holy Scriptures.

sn.def: Intermediate; not final or definitive; made or done during the progress of an action; as, an interlocutory judgement.

entry.ety: Cf. F. interlocutoire
entry.def: Interpolated discussion or dialogue.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A female interlocutor.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interloped; p. pr. & vb. n. Interloping
entry.ety: See Interloper
entry.def: To run between parties and intercept without right the advantage that one should gain from the other; to traffic without a proper license; to intrude; to forestall others; to intermeddle.

entry.ety: Pref. inter- + D. looper a runner, fr. loopen to run; akin to E. leap. See Leap, and cf. Elope

entry.q: The untrained man, . . . the interloper as to the professions.

entry.ety: L. interlucatus, p. p. of interlucare; inter between + lux lucis, light

entry.ety: L. interlucens, p. pr. See Inter-, and Lucent
entry.def: Shining between.

entry.ety: OE. enterlude, LL. interludium; LL. inter between + ludus play, fr. ludere to play: cf. F. interlude. See Ludicrous

A short piece of instrumental music played between the parts of a song or cantata, or the acts of a drama; especially, in church music, a short passage played by the organist between the stanzas of a hymn, or in German chorals after each line.
Any intervening period of time, space, etc.; a pause between phases of an activity.

Connection by marriage; reciprocal marriage; giving and taking in marriage, as between two families, tribes, races, castes, or nations.

entry.q: About the middle of the fourth century from the building of Rome, it was declared lawful for nobles and plebeians to intermarry.

entries.entry: ‖In`ter*max*il"la n.; pl.Intermaxillæ. Anat See Premaxilla.

entries.entry: In`ter*me"di*a*ry n.; pl.Intermediaries. One who, or that which, is intermediate; an interagent; a go-between; a mediator.

entry.cs: Intermediate state Theol the state or condition of the soul between the death and the resurrection of the body. Intermediate terms Math the terms of a progression or series between the first and the last (which are called the extremes); the means. Intermediate tie. Arch Same as Intertie.
entry.ety: Pref. inter- + mediate: cf. F. intermédiat

entry.note: The term has the same meaning with respect to intermediate compounds produced in a biosynthetic pathway in living organisms.

sn.def: A person who intermediates between others, especially in negotiations; an intermediary; a mediator.
Something that is intermediate.

A compound which is produced in the course of a chemical synthesis, which is not itself the final product, but is used in further reactions which produce the final product; also called synthetic intermediate intermediate compound or intermediate product; -- contrasted to starting material and end product or final product. There may be many different intermediates between the starting material and end product in the course of a complex synthesis; as, many industrial chemicals are produced primarily to be used as intermediates in other syntheses.

entry.def: In an intermediate manner; by way of intervention.
A school having grades at a level between the lower primary grades and the upper secondary grades, being variously grades 4 through 6, or grades 7 through 9, etc.
The act of coming between; intervention; mediation; interposition.
A mediator.

entry.ety: L. intermedius
entry.def: Intermediate.

entries.entry:
In`ter*me"di*um n.; pl.Intermediums #, L. Intermedia #. NL., neut. of L. intermedius intermediate
Intermediate space. R
An intervening agent or instrument.
Anat The bone or cartilage between the radiale and ulnare in the carpus, and between the tibiale and fibulare in the tarsus. It corresponds to the lunar in the carpus, and to a part of the astragalus in the tarsus of man and most mammals.

Between members or limbs; as, intermembral homology, the correspondence of the limbs with each other.

Between the metatarsal bones.

entry.ety: L. intermicare; inter- between + micare to glitter

entry.ety: L. interminabilis: cf. F. interminable. See Terminate
entry.def: Without termination; admitting no limit; boundless; endless; wearisomely protracted; as, interminable space or duration; interminable sufferings; an interminable sermon.

entry.def: The state of being endless.
Without end or limit.

entry.ety: L. interminatus; in- not + terminatus, p. p. of terminate
entry.def: Endless; as, interminate sleep.

entry.ety: L. interminatus, p. p. of interminari; inter between + minari to threaten
entry.def: To menace; to threaten.
Interminable; interminate; endless; unending.

entry.def: A menace or threat.
To intersect or penetrate with mines.
To mingle or mix together; to intermix.
To be mixed or incorporated.
entry.q: Party and faction will intermingle.

entry.ety: Cf. F. entremise. See Intermission
entry.def: Interference; interposition.

entry.ety: L. intermissio: cf. F. intermission. See Intermit

sn.def: The act or the state of intermitting; the state of being neglected or disused; disuse; discontinuance.
Cessation for a time; an intervening period of time; an interval; a temporary pause; as, to labor without intermission; an intermission of ten minutes.
sn.q: Rest or intermission none I find.

sn.def: The short period between acts of a play, concert, opera, or other public performance when the audience may leave their seats for refreshment; -- it usually lasts from 10 to 20 minutes.
The temporary cessation or subsidence of a fever; the space of time between the paroxysms of a disease. Intermission is an entire cessation, as distinguished from remission, or abatement of fever.
Intervention; interposition.
sn.syn: Cessation; interruption; interval; pause; stop; rest; suspension. See Cessation.

entry.def: Having temporary cessations; not continual; intermittent.
entry.q: Intermissivemiseries.
Intermissivewars.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intermitted; p. pr. & vb. n. Intermitting

entry.def: To cause to cease for a time, or at intervals; to interrupt; to suspend.
entry.q: Pray to the gods to intermit the plague.

entry.def: To cease for a time or at intervals; to moderate; to be intermittent, as a fever.

entry.ety: Cf. F. intermittence
entry.def: Act or state of intermitting; intermission.

cs.cd: a disease with fever which recurs at certain intervals; -- applied particularly to fever and ague. See Fever.
gearing which receives, or produces, intermittent motion.

springs which flow at intervals, not apparently dependent upon rain or drought. They probably owe their intermittent action to their being connected with natural reservoirs in hills or mountains by passages having the form of a siphon, the water beginning to flow when it has accumulated so as to fill the upper part of the siphon, and ceasing when, by running through it, it has fallen below the orifice of the upper part of the siphon in the reservoir.

entry.ety: L. intermittens -entis, p. pr. of intermittere: cf. F. intermittent
entry.def: Coming and going at intervals; alternating; recurrent; periodic; as, an intermittent fever.
An intermittent fever or disease.
With intermissions; in an intermittent manner; intermittingly.
With intermissions; at intervals.
To mix together; to intermingle.
entry.q: In yonder spring of roses, intermixed With myrtle, find what to redress till noon.

entry.def: To be mixed together; to be intermingled.
In a mixed manner.

sn.def: A mass formed by mixture; a mass of ingredients mixed.
Admixture; an additional ingredient.
sn.q: In this height of impiety there wanted not an intermixture of levity and folly.

entry.def: Capacity of things to move among each other; as, the intermobility of fluid particles.
The space between two modillions.

entry.ety: Pref. inter- + L. montanus belonging to a mountain, fr. mons montis, mountain
entry.def: Between mountains; as, intermontane soil.
Being, between worlds or orbs.
entry.q: Intermundanespaces.

entry.def: Intermundane.

sn.def: Lying between walls; inclosed by walls.
Taking place between two different institutions or cities; as, an intermural soccer match between two schools.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intermured; p. pr. & vb. n. Intermuring
entry.ety: Pref. inter- + L. murus wall
entry.def: To wall in; to inclose.
Between muscles; as, intermuscular septa.
Interchange; mutual or reciprocal change.
Mutual.

entry.ety: L. internus: cf. F. interne. See Internal
entry.def: Internal.

entry.ety: F. interne. See Intern a.

sn.def: To put for safe keeping in the interior of a place or country; to confine to one locality; as, to intern troops which have fled for refuge to a neutral country.
To hold until the end of a war, as enemy citizens in a country at the time of outbreak of hostilities; -- an action performed by countries.

entry.ety: F

sn.def: A resident physician in a hospital, especially one who has recently received the Doctorate and is practising under supervision of experienced physicians, as a continuation of the training process; a house physician; also called houseman in Britain.
A person working as an apprentice to gain experience in an occupation; sometimes the position is paid a salary, and other times it is not; as, a white house intern; an intern in a law firm.

cs.cd: an interior angle. See under Interior.
a gear in which the teeth project inward from the rim instead of outward.

entry.ety: L. internus; akin to interior. See Interior

sn.def: Inward; interior; being within any limit or surface; inclosed; -- opposed to external; as, the internal parts of a body, or of the earth.
Derived from, or dependent on, the thing itself; inherent; as, the internal evidence of the divine origin of the Scriptures.
Pertaining to its own affairs or interests; especially, (said of a country) domestic, as opposed to foreign; as, internal trade; internal troubles or war.
Pertaining to the inner being or the heart; spiritual.
sn.q: With our Savior, internal purity is everything.

sn.def: Intrinsic; inherent; real.
sn.q: The internal rectitude of our actions in the sight of God.

sn.def: Lying toward the mesial plane; mesial.
sn.syn: Inner; interior; inward; inland; inside.

entry.def: Designating, or pertaining to, any engine (called an Internal-combustion engine) in which the heat or pressure energy necessary to produce motion is developed in the engine cylinder, as by the explosion of a gas, and not in a separate chamber, as in a steam-engine boiler. The gas used may be a fixed gas, or one derived from alcohol, ether, gasoline (petrol), naphtha, oil (petroleum), etc. There are three main classes: (1 gas engines proper, using fixed gases, as coal, blast-furnace, or producer gas; (2) engines using the vapor of a volatile fluid, as the typical gasoline (petrol) engine ; (3 oil engines , using either an atomized spray or the vapor (produced by heat) of a comparatively heavy oil, as petroleum or kerosene. In all of these the gas is mixed with a definite amount of air, the charge is composed in the cylinder and is then exploded either by a flame of gas (flame ignitionnow little used), by a hot tube (tube ignition) or the like, by an electric spark (electric ignition, the usual method is gasoline engines, or by the heat of compression, as in the Diesel engine. Gas and oil engines are chiefly of the stationary type. Gasoline engines are largely used for automobile vehicles, boats, etc. Most internal-combustion engines use the Otto (four-stroke) cycle, though many use the two-stroke cycle. They are almost universally trunk engines and single-acting. Because of the intense heat produced by the frequent explosions, the cylinders must be cooled by a water jacket (water-cooled) or by air currents (air cooled) to give the maximum thermodynamic efficiency and to avoid excessive friction or seizing.

entries.entry: internalise v. Psychology Same as internalize. MKChiefly Brit. internalize, interiorize, interiorise.

entry.def: The state of being internal or within; interiority.

sn.def: learning (of values or attitudes etc.) that is incorporated within yourself.
sn.syn: incorporation.

entry.def: to incorporate within oneself.

sn.def: Inwardly; within the enveloping surface, or the boundary of a thing; within the body; beneath the surface.
Hence: Mentally; spiritually.

entry.def: Between the nasal cavities; as, the internasal cartilage.

entry.cs: International code Naut a common system of signaling adopted by nearly all maritime nations, whereby communication may be had between vessels at sea. International copyright. See under Copyright. International law the rules regulating the mutual intercourse of nations. International law is mainly the product of the conditions from time to time of international intercourse, being drawn from diplomatic discussion, textbooks, proof of usage, and from recitals in treaties. It is called public when treating of the relations of sovereign powers, and private when of the relations of persons of different nationalities. International law is now, by the better opinion, part of the common law of the land. Cf. Conflict of laws, under Conflict. Wharton.
entry.ety: Pref. inter- + national: cf. F. international

sn.def: Between or among nations; pertaining to the intercourse of nations; participated in by two or more nations; common to, or affecting, two or more nations.
Of or concerning the association called the International.
Independent of national boundaries; common to all people; as, the atmosphere is an international resource; the international community of scholars.

entry.ety: Cf. F. internationale

sn.def: The International; an abbreviated from of the title of the International Workingmen's Association, the name of an association, formed in London in 1864, which has for object the promotion of the interests of the industrial classes of all nations.
A member of the International Association.

entry.def: a revolutionary socialist anthem.
the act of bringing something under international control.

sn.def: Same as internationalize.
sn.syn: internationalize, make international.

sn.def: The state or principles of international interests and intercourse.
The doctrines or organization of the International.
One who is versed in the principles of international law.
A member of the International; one who believes in, or advocates the doctrines of, the International.

entry.def: favoring cooperation among nations; -- of people and policies.
quality of being international in scope; as, he applauded the internationality of scientific terminology.

sn.def: the act of bringing something under international control.
sn.syn: internationalisation.

entry.def: To make international; to cause to affect the mutual relations of two or more nations; as, to internationalize a principle of law, or a philanthropic enterprise.
In an international manner; from an international point of view.

entry.ety: See Intern a.
entry.def: That which is within; the interior.
Same as intern.
Internecine.

entry.ety: L. internecinus deadly, murderous, fr. internecare to kill, to slaughter; inter between + necare to kill; akin to Gr. � dead. See Necromancy

sn.def: Involving, or accompanied by, mutual slaughter; mutually destructive.
sn.q: Internecine quarrels, horrible tumults, stain the streets with blood.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to internal conflicts within a group; as, internecine quarrels.
sn.syn: intramural.

entry.ety: L. internecio
entry.def: Mutual slaughter or destruction; massacre.

entry.ety: L. internecivus
entry.def: Internecine.

entry.ety: L. internectere to bind together; inter between + nectere to fasten
entry.def: Intimate connection.

A large network{3} of numerous computers connected through a number of major nodes of high-speed computers having high-speed communications channels between the major nodes, and numerous minor nodes allowing electronic communication among millions of computers around the world; -- usually referred to as the internet. It is the basis for the World-Wide Web.
Between the neural arches or neural spines.
State of being within; interiority.

entry.ety: F. internement. See Intern

sn.def: Confinement within narrow limits, -- as of foreign troops, to the interior of a country.
Confining within a country for the duration of a war; -- usually of citizens of a hostile power.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to internodes; intervening between nodes or joints.

entry.ety: L. internodium; inter between + nodus knot

sn.def: The space between two nodes or points of the stem from which the leaves properly arise.
A part between two joints; a segment; specifically, one of the phalanges.

entry.def: Internodal.

sn.def: The state of being an intern; the position of an intern.
The period of time during which a person is an intern; as, she served her internship over the summer.
A program to provide novices in a field with apprenticeship training.
The period of time during which a novice in a field serves in a subordinate capacity and continues to gain experience; the learning period before one becomes an expert.

entry.ety: See Internuncio

sn.def: Of or pertaining to an internuncio.
Communicating or transmitting impressions between different parts of the body; -- said of the nervous system.

entry.def: A female messenger.

entries.entry:
In`ter*nun"ci*o ☞ This title was formerly given also to the Austrian envoy at Constantinople. n.; pl.Internuncios #. L. internuntius; inter between + nuntius nuncius, messenger: cf. It. internunzio. See Nuncio
A messenger between two parties.
A representative, or chargé d'affaires, of the pope at a foreign court or seat of government, ranking next below a nuncio.

entry.def: The office or function of an internuncio.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: Internuncio.
Between oceans; connecting oceans; as, interoceanic communication; an interoceanic canal.
Between, or within, the eyes; as, the interocular distance; situated between the eyes, as the antennæ of some insects.
Of or pertaining to the interoperculum.

entries.entry: ‖In`ter*o*per"cu*lum n.; pl.-la -lȧ. Anat The postero-inferior opercular bone, in fishes.

entry.def: Between the orbits; as, the interorbital septum.

sn.def: Mutually touching or intersecting; as, interosculant circles.
Uniting two groups; -- said of certain genera which connect family groups, or of species that connect genera. See Osculant.
To kiss together to touch. See Osculate.
To have the character of, or to lie between, two distinct groups.

entry.ety: Pref. inter- + osseous: cf. F. interosseux
entry.def: Situated between bones; as, an interosseous ligament.

sn.def: To place pales between or among; to separate by pales.
To interweave or interlace.

entry.def: Between the parietal bones or cartilages; as, the interparietal suture.
An intermission.
To interpel.
Between peduncles; esp., between the peduncles, or crura, of the cerebrum.

entry.ety: L. interpellare interpellatum; inter between + pellarein comp.), akin to pellere to drive: cf. F. interpeller. Cf. Interpellate
entry.def: To interrupt, break in upon, or intercede with.
entry.q: I am interpelled by many businesses.

entry.ety: L. interpellans, p. pr. See Interpel
entry.def: Interpelling; interrupting.

def2.def: One who, or that which, interpels.

entry.ety: See Interpel
entry.def: To question imperatively, as a minister, or other executive officer, in explanation of his conduct; -- generally on the part of a legislative body.

entry.ety: L. interpellatio: cf. F. interpellation

sn.def: The act of interpelling or interrupting; interruption.
sn.q: Continualinterpellations.

sn.def: The act of interposing or interceding; intercession.
sn.q: Accepted by his interpellation and intercession.

sn.def: An act of interpellating, or of demanding of an officer an explanation of his action; imperative or peremptory questioning; a point raised in a debate.
A official summons or citation.

entry.def: To penetrate between or within; to penetrate mutually.
entry.q: It interpenetrates my granite mass.

cs.cd: in late Gothic architecture, a decoration by means of moldings which seem to pass through solid uprights, transoms, or other members; often, two sets of architectural members penetrating one another, in appearance, as if both had been plastic when they were put together.

entry.def: To penetrate each the other; to penetrate between bodies or their parts.
The act or process of penetrating between or within other substances; mutual penetration; also, the result of a process of interpenetration.
Penetrating among or between other substances; penetrating each the other; mutually penetrative.

entry.ety: Pref. inter- + petal
entry.def: Between the petals of a flower.
Being between petioles. Cf. Intrapetiolar.
Between phalanges; as, interphalangeal articulations.
The interval or space between two pilasters.
To place between or among; as, to interplace a name.
Between planets; as, interplanetary spaces; interplanetary travel.
Mutual action or influence; interaction; as, the interplay of affection.
To plead against each other, or go to trial between themselves, as the claimants in an in an interpleader. See Interpleader.

sn.def: One who interpleads.

A proceeding devised to enable a person, of whom the same debt, duty, or thing is claimed adversely by two or more parties, to compel them to litigate the right or title between themselves, and thereby to relieve himself from the suits which they might otherwise bring against him.

entry.def: To pledge mutually.
To point; to mark with stops or pauses; to punctuate.
entry.q: Her sighs should interpoint her words.

entry.def: That may be interpolated; suitable to be interpolated.
entry.q: A most interpolable clause of one sentence.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interpolated; p. pr. & vb. n. Interpolating
entry.ety: L. interpolatus, p. p. of interpolare to form anew, to interpolate, fr. interpolus interpolis, falsified, vamped up, polished up; inter between + polire to polish. See Polish v. t.

sn.def: To renew; to carry on with intermission.
sn.q: Motion . . . partly continued and unintermitted, . . . partly interpolated and interrupted.

sn.def: To alter or corrupt by the insertion of new or foreign matter; especially, to change, as a book or text, by the insertion of matter that is new, or foreign to the purpose of the author.
sn.q: How strangely Ignatius is mangled and interpolated, you may see by the vast difference of all copies and editions.
The Athenians were put in possession of Salamis by another law, which was cited by Solon, or, as some think, interpolated by him for that purpose.

sn.def: To fill up intermediate terms of, as of a series, according to the law of the series; to introduce, as a number or quantity, in a partial series, according to the law of that part of the series; to estimate a value at a point intermediate between points of knwon value. Compare extrapolate.
Inserted in, or added to, the original; introduced; foisted in; changed by the insertion of new or spurious matter.

sd.def: Provided with necessary interpolations; as, an interpolated table.
Introduced or determined by interpolation; as, interpolated quantities or numbers.

entry.ety: L. interpolatio an alteration made here and there: cf. F. interpolation

sn.def: The act of introducing or inserting anything, especially that which is spurious or foreign.
That which is introduced or inserted, especially something foreign or spurious.
sn.q: Bentley wrote a letter . . . . upon the scriptural glosses in our present copies of Hesychius, which he considered interpolations from a later hand.

sn.def: The method or operation of finding from a few given terms of a series, as of numbers or observations, other intermediate terms in conformity with the law of the series.

entry.ety: L., a corrupter: of. F. interpolateur
entry.def: One who interpolates; esp., one who inserts foreign or spurious matter in genuine writings.

entry.ety: L. interponere; inter between + ponere to place. See Position
entry.def: To interpose; to insert or place between.
One who, or that which, interposes; an interloper, an opponent.

entry.ety: From Interpose
entry.def: The act of interposing; interposition; intervention.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interposed; p. pr. & vb. n. Interposing
entry.ety: F. interposer. See Inter-, and Pose v. t.

sn.def: To place between; as, to interpose a screen between the eye and the light.
sn.q: Mountains interposed Make enemies of nations.

sn.def: To thrust; to intrude; to put between, either for aid or for troubling.
sn.q: What watchful cares do interpose themselves Betwixt your eyes and night?
The common Father of mankind seasonably interposed his hand, and rescues miserable man.

sn.def: To introduce or inject between the parts of a conversation or argument.

entry.usage: To Interpose Intermeddle Interfere. A man may often interpose with propriety in the concerns of others; he can never intermeddle without being impertinent or officious; nor can be interfere without being liable to the same charge, unless he has rights which are interfered with. “In our practical use, interference is something offensive. It is the pushing in of himself between two parties on the part of a third who was not asked, and is not thanked for his pains, and who, as the feeling of the word implies, had no business there; while interposition is employed to express the friendly, peacemaking mediation of one whom the act well became, and who, even if he was not specially invited thereunto, is still thanked for what he has done.” Trench.

sn.def: To be or come between.
sn.q: Long hid by interposing hill or wood.

sn.def: To step in between parties at variance; to mediate; as, the prince interposed and made peace.
To utter a sentiment by way of interruption.
sn.syn: To intervene; intercede; mediate; interfere; intermeddle.

entry.def: Interposition.
One who, or that which, interposes or intervenes; an obstacle or interruption; a mediator or agent between parties.

entry.ety: From L. interpositus, p. p. of interponere. See Interposition
entry.def: An intermediate depot or station between one commercial city or country and another.

entry.ety: L. interpositio a putting between, insertion, fr. interponere interpositum: cf. F. interposition. See Interpone Position

sn.def: The act of interposing, or the state of being interposed; a being, placing, or coming between; mediation.
The thing interposed.

entry.def: Interposition.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interpreted; p. pr. & vb. n. Interpreting
entry.ety: F. interprêter, L. interpretari, p. p. interpretatus, fr. interpres interpeter, agent, negotiator; inter between + (prob.) the root of pretium price. See Price

sn.def: To explain or tell the meaning of; to expound; to translate orally into intelligible or familiar language or terms; to decipher; to define; -- applied esp. to language, but also to dreams, signs, conduct, mysteries, etc.; as, to interpret the Hebrew language to an Englishman; to interpret an Indian speech.
sn.q: Emmanuel, which being interpreted is, God with us.
And Pharaoh told them his dreams; but there was none that could interpret them unto Pharaoh.

sn.def: To apprehend and represent by means of art; to show by illustrative representation; as, an actor interprets the character of Hamlet; a musician interprets a sonata; an artist interprets a landscape.
sn.syn: To translate; explain; solve; render; expound; elucidate; decipher; unfold; unravel.

entry.def: To act as an interpreter.

entry.ety: L. interpretabilis: cf. F. interprêtable
entry.def: Admitting of interpretation; capable of being interpreted or explained.

entry.ety: L. interpretamentum
entry.def: Interpretation.

entry.ety: L. interpretatio: cf. F. interprétation

sn.def: The act of interpreting; explanation of what is obscure; translation; version; construction; as, the interpretation of a foreign language, of a dream, or of an enigma.
sn.q: Look how we can, or sad or merrily,Interpretation will misquote our looks.

sn.def: The sense given by an interpreter; exposition or explanation given; meaning; as, commentators give various interpretations of the same passage of Scripture.
The power or explaining.
An artist's way of expressing his thought or embodying his conception of nature.
The act or process of applying general principles or formulæ to the explanation of the results obtained in special cases.
sn.syn: Explanation; solution; translation; version; sense; exposition; rendering; definition.

entry.ety: Cf. F. interprétatif

sn.def: Designed or fitted to interpret; explanatory.
sn.q: Interpretativelexicography.

sn.def: According to interpretation; constructive.
sn.q: An interpretative siding with heresies.

entry.def: By interpretation.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. entrepreteur, L. interpretator
entry.def: One who or that which interprets, explains, or expounds; a translator; especially, a person who translates orally between two parties.
entry.q: We think most men's actions to be the interpreters of their thoughts.

entry.def: Interpretative.
Between the pubic bones or cartilages; as, the interpubic disk.

entry.ety: L. interpunctio, fr. interpungere interppunctum, to interpoint. See Inter-, and Point
entry.def: The insertion of points between words or sentences; punctuation.
Between the radii, or rays; -- in zoölogy, said of certain parts of radiate animals; as, the interradial plates of a starfish.

entry.ety: Pref. inter- + L. ramus a branch
entry.def: Between rami or branches; esp., between the mandibles, or rami of the lower jaw; intermandibular.
To receive between or within.
An interregnum.
A person who discharges the royal functions during an interregnum.

entries.entry:
In`ter*reg"num n.; pl.Interregnums #. L., fr. inter between + regnum dominion, reign. See Reign, and cf. Interreign
The time during which a throne is vacant between the death or abdication of a sovereign and the accession of his successor.
Any period during which, for any cause, the executive branch of a government is suspended or interrupted.

entry.ety: Cf. F. interrègne
entry.def: An interregnum.
Having a mutual or reciprocal relation or parallelism; correlative.
mutual or reciprocal relation or relatedness; interrelation.
Mutual or reciprocal relation; correlation.
Between the kidneys; as, the interrenal body, an organ found in many fishes.
Mutually repellent.
One who inters.

entries.entry: In"ter*rex` n.; pl. E. Interrexes #, L. Interreges #. L., fr. inter between + rex king An interregent, or a regent.

entry.ety: L. interrogatus, p. p. of interrogare to ask; inter between + rogare to ask. See Rogation
entry.def: To question formally; to question; to examine by asking questions; as, to interrogate a witness.
entry.q: Wilt thou, uncalled, interrogate, Talker! the unreplying Fate?

entry.def: To ask questions.
An interrogation; a question.
One who is interrogated.

entry.note: ☞ In works printed in the Spanish language this mark is not only placed at the end of an interrogative sentence, but is also placed, inverted [as thus (¿)], at the beginning.
entry.ety: L. interrogatio: cf. F. interrogation

sn.def: The act or process of interrogating or questioning; examination by questions; an instance of interrogating; inquiry.
A question put; an inquiry.

A point, mark, or sign, thus [?], indicating that the sentence with which it is connected is a question. It is used to express doubt, or to mark a query. Usually called a question mark; called also interrogation point.

entry.ety: L. interrogativus: cf. F. interrogatif
entry.def: Denoting a question; expressed in the form of a question; as, an interrogative sentence; an interrogative pronoun.
A word used in asking questions; as, who? which? why?
In the form of, or by means of, a question; in an interrogative manner.

entry.ety: L.: cf. F. interrogateur
entry.def: One who asks questions; a questioner.

entries.entry:
In`ter*rog"a*to*ry n.; pl.Interrogatories #. Cf. F. interrogatoire
A formal question or inquiry; esp. Law a question or series of questions asked in writing, usually as part of a lawsuit.

entry.ety: L. interrogatorius
entry.def: Containing, expressing, or implying a question; as, an interrogatory sentence.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interrupted; p. pr. & vb. n. Interrupting
entry.ety: L. interruptus, p. p. of interrumpere to interrupt; inter between + rumpere to break. See Rupture

sn.def: To break into, or between; to stop, or hinder by breaking in upon the course or progress of; to interfere with the current or motion of; to cause a temporary cessation of; as, to interrupt the remarks of anyone speaking.
sn.q: Do not interrupt me in my course.

sn.def: To divide; to separate; to break the monotony of; as, the evenness of the road was not interrupted by a single hill.

entry.ety: L. interruptus, p. p
entry.def: Broken; interrupted.

sn.def: Broken; intermitted; suddenly stopped.
Irregular; -- said of any arrangement whose symmetry is destroyed by local causes, as when leaflets are interposed among the leaves in a pinnate leaf.

cs.cd: pinnate with small leaflets intermixed with large ones.

entry.def: With breaks or interruptions; discontinuously.

sn.def: One who, or that which, interrupts.
A device for opening and closing an electrical circuit; a vibrating spring or tuning fork, arranged to make and break a circuit at rapidly recurring intervals, by the action of the current itself.

entry.ety: L. interruptio: cf. F. interruption

sn.def: The act of interrupting, or breaking in upon.
The state of being interrupted; a breach or break, caused by the abrupt intervention of something foreign; intervention; interposition.
sn.q: Lest the interruption of time cause you to lose the idea of one part.

sn.def: Obstruction caused by breaking in upon course, current, progress, or motion; stop; hindrance; as, the author has met with many interruptions in the execution of his work; the speaker or the argument proceeds without interruption.
Temporary cessation; intermission; suspension.

entry.def: Tending to interrupt; interrupting.
entry.q: Interruptiveforces.

sn.def: Between the scapulæ or shoulder blades.
Pertaining to the upper back, or the part between the shoulders; as, the interscapular feathers.

entry.def: The interscapular feathers of a bird.

cs.cd: a series whose terms are interscendent quantities.

entry.ety: See Inter-, and Ascend
entry.def:
Having exponents which are radical quantities; -- said of certain powers; as, x√2 , or x√a
.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interscinded; p. pr. & vb. n. Interscinding
entry.ety: L. interscindere; inter between + scindere to cut
entry.def: To cut off.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interscribed; p. pr. & vb. n. Interscribing
entry.ety: L. interscribere; inter between + scribere to write
entry.def: To write between.

entry.ety: L. intersecans, p. pr. of intersecare. See Intersect
entry.def: Dividing into parts; crossing; intersecting.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intersected; p. pr. & vb. n. Intersecting
entry.ety: L. intersectus, p. p. of intersecare to intersect; inter + secare to cut. See Section
entry.def: To cut into or between; to cut or cross mutually; to divide into parts; as, any two diameters of a circle intersect each other at the center.
entry.q: Lands intersected by a narrow frith Abhor each other.

entry.def: To cut into one another; to meet and cross each other; as, the point where two lines intersect .
having at least one spatial point in common.

entry.ety: L. intersectio: cf. F. intersection

sn.def: The act, state, or place of intersecting.
The point or line in which one line or surface cuts another.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or formed by, intersections.

entry.ety: L. interseminatus, p. p. of interseminare. See Inter-, and Seminate
entry.def: To sow between or among.
Between septa; as, the interseptal spaces or zones, between the transparent, or septal, zones in striated muscle; the interseptal chambers of a shell, or of a seed vessel.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interserted; p. pr. & vb. n. Interserting
entry.ety: L. intersertus, p. p. of interserere to intersert; inter between + serere to join, weave
entry.def: To put in between other things; to insert.
The act of interserting, or that which is interserted.
Between sesamoid bones; as, intersesamoid ligaments.
To set between or among.
To shock mutually.
Between or among constellations or stars; interstellar.
Pertaining to the mutual intercourse or relations of persons in society; social.

entry.ety: Pref. inter- + L. somnus sleep
entry.def: Between the times of sleeping; in an interval of wakefulness.

entry.ety: L. interspatium. See Inter-, and Space
entry.def: Intervening space.
A speech interposed between others.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Interspersed; p. pr. & vb. n. Interspersing
entry.ety: L. interspersus interspersed; inter between, among + spargere to scatter. See Sparse

sn.def: To scatter or set here and there among other things; to insert at intervals; as, to intersperse pictures in a book.
sn.q: There, interspersed in lawns and op'ning glades, Thin trees arise that shun each other's shades.

sn.def: To diversify or adorn with things set or scattered at intervals; to place something at intervals in or among; as, to intersperse a book with pictures.
sn.q: Which space is interspersed with small islands and rock.

entry.def: The act of interspersing, or the state of being interspersed.
Between spines; esp., between the spinous processes of the vertebral column.

entry.ety: L. interspiratio. See Inter-, and Spirit
entry.def: Spiritual inspiration at separate times, or at intervals.
Pertaining to a part of the columella of the ear, between the stapes and the mediostapedial.

def2.def: The interstapedial part of the columella.

entry.def: Pertaining to the mutual relations of States; existing between, or including, different States; as, interstate commerce.
An interstate highway, part of the United States Interstate Highway system.
Commerce that involves transportation of articles of commerce across state lines.
The governmental commision charged with making and enforcing regulations concerning interstate commerce.
Between or among the stars; as, interstellar space.
Interstellar.
Between the sternal; -- said of certain membranes or parts of insects and crustaceans.

entries.entry:
In*ter"stice ?; 277 n.; pl.Interstices #. L. interstitium a pause, interval; inter between + sistere to set, fr. stare to stand: cf. F. interstice. See Stand
That which intervenes between one thing and another; especially, a space between things closely set, or between the parts which compose a body; a narrow chink; a crack; a crevice; a hole; an interval; as, the interstices of a wall.
An interval of time; specifically R. C. Ch, in the plural, the intervals which the canon law requires between the reception of the various degrees of orders. Nonobservance of the interstices . . . is a sin.

entry.def: Provided with interstices; having interstices between; situated at intervals.

entry.ety: L. interstinctus, p. p. of interstinguere to separate; inter + stinguere to extinguish
entry.def: Distinguishing.
Of or pertaining to interstices; intermediate; within the tissues; as, interstitial cavities or spaces in the tissues of animals or plants.
An intervening period of time; interval.
Stratification among or between other layers or strata; also, that which is interstratified.
Stratified among or between other bodies; as, interstratified rocks.
To put or insert between other strata.
To converse.
To entangle; to intertwine.
entry.q: Moss andintertangledvines.

entry.def: Between the tarsal bones; as, the intertarsal articulations.

entry.ety: L. intertexere; inter between + texere to weave
entry.def: To intertwine; to weave or bind together.

entries.entry: In`ter*tex"ture ?; 135 n. The act of interweaving, or the state of being interwoven; that which is interwoven. ”Knit in nice intertexture.” Coleridge. Skirted thick with intertexture firm Of thorny boughs.

entry.def: In the thorax.
In any framed work, a horizontal tie other than sill and plate or other principal ties, securing uprights to one another.
Interwoven.
Mutual trade of traffic.
Transpicuous within or between.
Between the transverse processes of the vertebræ.

entry.ety: L., fr. inter between + terere tritum, to rub
entry.def: A rubbing or chafing of the skin; especially, an abrasion or excoriation of the skin between folds, as in fat or neglected children.
Between the trochanters of the femur.
Situated between or within the tropics.
Between tubes or tubules; as, intertubular cells; intertubular substance.
To unite by twining one with another; to entangle; to interlace.
To be twined or twisted together; to become mutually involved or enfolded.
The act of intertwining, or the state of being intertwined.
By intertwining or being intertwined.
To twist together one with another; to intertwine.
By intertwisting, or being intertwisted.
Between ungulæ; as, interungular glands.
Going between, or connecting, cities or towns; as, interurban electric railways.

entry.cs: At intervals coming or happening with intervals between; now and then. “And Miriam watch'd and dozed at intervals.” Tennyson. Augmented interval Mus an interval increased by half a step or half a tone.
entry.ety: L. intervallum; inter between + vallum a wall: cf. F. intervalle. See Wall

sn.def: A space between things; a void space intervening between any two objects; as, an interval between two houses or hills.
sn.q: 'Twixt host and host but narrow space was left, A dreadful interval.

sn.def: Space of time between any two points or events; as, the interval between the death of Charles I. of England, and the accession of Charles II.
A brief space of time between the recurrence of similar conditions or states; as, the interval between paroxysms of pain; intervals of sanity or delirium.
Difference in pitch between any two tones.

entry.def: A tract of low ground between hills, or along the banks of a stream, usually alluvial land, enriched by the overflowings of the river, or by fertilizing deposits of earth from the adjacent hills. Cf. Bottom n., 7.
entry.q: The woody intervale just beyond the marshy land.

entries.entry: ‖In`ter*val"lum n.; pl.Intervallums #, L. Intervalla #. L An interval. R And a' shall laugh without intervallums. In one of these intervalla.

entry.def: To alter or vary between; to change.
Intersected, as with veins.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intervened; p. pr. & vb. n. Intervening
entry.ety: L. intervenire interventum, to intervene, to hinder; inter between + venire to come; akin to E. come: cf. F. intervenir. See Come

sn.def: To come between, or to be between, persons or things; -- followed by between; as, the Mediterranean intervenes between Europe and Africa.

To occur, fall, or come between, points of time, or events; as, an instant intervened between the flash and the report; nothing intervenedi. e., between the intention and the execution) to prevent the undertaking.
To interpose; as, to intervene to settle a quarrel.
In a suit to which one has not been made a party, to put forward a defense of one's interest in the subject matter.

entry.def: To come between.
entry.q: Self-sown woodlands of birch, alder, etc., intervening the different estates.

entry.def: A coming between; intervention; meeting.
One who intervenes; especially Law, a person who assumes a part in a suit between others.
Intervention; interposition.

entry.ety: L. interveniens, p. pr. of intervenire
entry.def: Being or coming between; intercedent; interposed.

entry.ety: See Intervene
entry.def: To thwart; to obstruct.

entry.ety: L. interventio an interposition: cf. F. intervention

sn.def: The act of intervening; interposition.
sn.q: Sound is shut out by the intervention of that lax membrane.

sn.def: Any interference that may affect the interests of others; especially, of one or more states with the affairs of another; -- the intervention of one state in the affairs of another is typically unwelcome by the state being intervened in, but some cases of mediation between states may be called intervention. Opposed to nonintervention.
sn.q: Let us decide our quarrels at home, without the intervention, of any foreign power.

sn.def: The act by which a third person, to protect his own interest, interposes and becomes a party to a suit pending between other parties.

entry.ety: L.: cf. F. interventeur
entry.def: One who intervenes; a mediator; especially Eccles. Hist, a person designated by a church to reconcile parties, and unite them in the choice of officers.
Between the ventricles; as, the interventricular partition of the heart.

entry.ety: See Intervene Avenue
entry.def: Interposition.

entry.ety: L. intervertere; inter between + vertere to turn
entry.def: To turn to another course or use.
Between vertebræ.

entry.note: ☞ A recent use, originating in American newspapers, but apparently becoming general.
entry.ety: F. entrevue, fr. entrevoir to see imperfectly, to have a glimpse of, s'entrevoir to visit each other. See Inter-, and View

sn.def: A mutual sight or view; a meeting face to face; usually, a formal or official meeting for consultation; a conference; as, the secretary had an interview with the President.
A conversation, or questioning, for the purpose of eliciting information for publication; the published statement so elicited.

entry.def: To have an interview with; to question or converse with, especially for the purpose of obtaining information for publication.
a person who is interviewed.
One who interviews; especially, one who obtains an interview with another for the purpose of eliciting his opinions or obtaining information for publication.
entry.q: It would have made him the prince of interviewers in these days.

entry.def: The act or custom of holding an interview or interviews.
entry.q: An article on interviewing in the “Nation” of January 28, 1869, . . . was the first formal notice of the practice under that name.

entry.def: Mutually visible, or in sight, the one from the other, as stations.
To exchange visits.
Between two lives.
entry.q: Through all its [the spirit'sintervital gloom.

entry.def: Situated between vowels; immediately preceded and followed by vowel sounds, as, p in occupyd in idea, etc.
The state of being intervolved or coiled up; a convolution; as, the intervolutions of a snake.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. intervolved; p. pr. & vb. n. intervolving
entry.ety: Pref. inter- + L. volvere volutum, to roll
entry.def: To involve one within another; to twist or coil together.

entry.vmorph: imp. & obs. p. p. interwove; p. p. interwoven; p. pr. & vb. n. interweaving

sn.def: To weave together; to intermix or unite in texture or construction; to intertwine; as, threads of silk and cotton interwoven .
sn.q: Under the hospitable covert nigh Of trees thick interwoven.

sn.def: To intermingle; to unite intimately; to connect closely; as, to interweave truth with falsehood.
sn.q: Words interwove with sighs found out their way.

entry.def: To wish mutually in regarded to each other.
The act of working in together; interweaving.
A world between other worlds.
imp. & p. p. of interweave.
To weave into a wreath; to intertwine.

entry.ety: L. intestabilis: cf. F. intestable. See In- not, and Testable
entry.def: Not capable of making a will; not legally qualified or competent to make a testament.

entry.ety: From Intestate
entry.def: The state of being intestate, or of dying without having made a valid will.

entry.ety: L. intestatus; pref. in- not + testatus, p. p. of testari to make a will: cf. F. intestat. See Testament

sn.def: Without having made a valid will; without a will; as, to die intestate .
sn.q: Airy succeeders of intestate joys.

sn.def: Not devised or bequeathed; not disposed of by will; as, an intestate estate.

entry.def: A person who dies without making a valid will.

entry.cs:
Intestinal canal. Same as Intestine n.
Intestinal worm Zoöl any species of helminth living in the intestinal canal of any animal. The species are numerous.
entry.ety: Cf. F. intestinal
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the intestines of an animal; as, the intestinal tube; intestinal digestion; intestinal enzymes.

entry.ety: L. intestinus, fr. intus on the inside, within, fr. in in: cf. F. intestine. See In

sn.def: Internal; inward; -- opposed to external.
sn.q: Epilepsies, fierce catarrhs,Intestine stone and ulcers.

sn.def: Internal with regard to a state or country; domestic; not foreign; -- applied usually to that which is evil; as, intestine disorders, calamities, etc.
sn.q: Hoping here to endIntestine war in heaven, the arch foe subdued.
An intestine struggle . . . between authority and liberty.

sn.def: Depending upon the internal constitution of a body or entity; subjective.
sn.q: Everything labors under an intestine necessity.

sn.def: Shut up; inclosed.

entries.entry:
In*tes"tine
Large intestine Human Anat. & Med the lower portion of the bowel, terminating at the anus. It is adapted for the retention of fecal matter, being shorter, broader, and less convoluted than the small intestine; it consists of three parts, the cæcum, colon, and rectum. Small intestine Human Anat. & Med the upper portion of the bowel, in which the process of digestion is practically completed. It is narrow and contorted, and consists of three parts, the duodenum, jejunum, and ileum.
n.; pl.Intestines #. L. intestinum: cf. F. intestin. See Intestine a.
Anat That part of the alimentary canal between the stomach and the anus. See Illust. of Digestive apparatus.
pl. The bowels; entrails; viscera.

entry.def: The text of a book.

entry.ety: Infine + extine
entry.def: A thin membrane existing in the pollen grains of some plants, and situated between the extine and the intine, as in Œnothera.
Inwrought; woven in.
To make thirsty.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inthralled; p. pr. & vb. n. Inthralling
entry.ety: Cf. Enthrall
entry.def: To reduce to bondage or servitude; to make a thrall, slave, vassal, or captive of; to enslave.
entry.q: She soothes, but never can inthrall my mind.

entry.ety: Written also inthralment enthrallment
entry.def: Act of inthralling, or state of being inthralled; servitude; bondage; vassalage.
Same as Enthrone.
To throng or collect together.

entry.ety: LL. inthronizatio
entry.def: Enthronement.

entry.ety: LL. inthronisare, Gr. �. See Enthrone
entry.def: To enthrone.
See Entice.
the innermost coat of an organ, such as a blood vessel. It usually consists of an endothelial layer of cells, backed by connective tissue and elastic tissue.
of or pertaining to the intima.

entries.entry:
In"ti*ma*cy n.; pl.Intimacies #. From Intimate
The state of being intimate; close familiarity or association; nearness in friendship. Acquaintance; familiarity; fellowship; friendship. See Acquaintance.

entry.ety: Formerly intime, L. intimus, a superl. corresponding to the compar. interior: cf. F. intime. The form intimate is due to confusion with intimate, v. t. See Interior

sn.def: Innermost; inward; internal; deep-seated; hearty.
sn.q: I knew fromintimateimpulse.

sn.def: Near; close; direct; thorough; complete.
sn.q: He was honored with an intimate and immediate admission.

sn.def: Close in friendship or acquaintance; familiar; confidential; as, an intimate friend.
sn.syn: Familiar; near; friendly; confidential.

entry.def: An intimate friend or associate; a confidant.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intimated; p. pr. & vb. n. Intimating
entry.ety: L. intimatus, p. p. of intimare to put, bring, drive, or press into, to announce, make known, from intimus the inmost. See Intimate a.

sn.def: To announce; to declare; to publish; to communicate; to make known.
sn.q: He, incontinent, did proclaim and intimate open war.
So both conspiring 'gan to intimate Each other's grief.

sn.def: To suggest obscurely or indirectly; to refer to remotely; to give slight notice of; to hint; as, he intimated his intention of resigning his office.
sn.q: The names of simple ideas and substances, with the abstract ideas in the mind, intimate some real existence, from which was derived their original pattern.

entry.def: In an intimate manner.

entry.ety: L. intimatio: cf. F. intimation

sn.def: The act of intimating; also, the thing intimated.
Announcement; declaration.
sn.q: They made an edict with an intimation that whosoever killed a stork, should be banished.

sn.def: A hint; an obscure or indirect suggestion or notice; a remote or ambiguous reference; as, he had given only intimations of his design.
sn.q: Without mentioning the king of England, or giving the least intimation that he was sent by him.

entry.ety: See Intimate a.
entry.def: Inward; internal; intimate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intimidated; p. pr. & vb. n. Intimidating
entry.ety: LL. intimidatus, p. p. of intimidare to frighten; pref. in- in + timidus fearful, timid: cf. F. intimider. See Timid
entry.def: To make timid or fearful; to inspire of affect with fear; to deter, as by threats; to dishearten; to abash.
entry.q: Now guilt, once harbored in the conscious breast,Intimidates the brave, degrades the great.
entry.syn: To dishearten; dispirit; abash; deter; frighten; terrify; daunt; cow.

sn.def: made timid or fearful as by threats.
frightened into submission or compliance.
sn.syn: browbeaten, bullied, cowed, hangdog.

entry.def: discouraging; inhibiting; deterring. Opposite of encouraging.

entry.ety: Cf. F. intimidation
entry.def: The act of making timid or fearful or of deterring by threats; the state of being intimidated; as, the voters were kept from the polls by intimidation .
entry.q: The king carried his measures in Parliament by intimidation.

entry.def: Tending or serving to intimidate.

entry.ety: L. intinctio, fr. intingere to dip in; pref. in- in + tingere to tinge

sn.def: The act of tingeing or dyeing.
A method or practice of the administration of the sacrament by dipping the bread or wafer in the wine and administering both together.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + L. tinctus, p. p. of tingere to tinge
entry.def: The lack of the quality of coloring or tingeing other bodies.

entry.ety: L. intus within. Cf. Extine
entry.def: A transparent, extensible membrane of extreme tenuity, which forms the innermost coating of grains of pollen.
See Entire a. Entirely adv.
See Entitle.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intituled; p. pr. & vb. n. Intituling
entry.ety: Cf. F. intituler. See Entitle
entry.def: To entitle; to give a title to.

entry.note: Compare In.
entry.ety: In + to
entry.def: To the inside of; within. It is used in a variety of applications.

sn.def: Expressing entrance, or a passing from the outside of a thing to its interior parts; -- following verbs expressing motion; as, come into the house; go into the church; one stream falls or runs into another; water enters into the fine vessels of plants.
Expressing penetration beyond the outside or surface, or access to the inside, or contents; as, to look into a letter or book; to look into an apartment.
Indicating insertion; as, to infuse more spirit or animation into a composition.
Denoting inclusion; as, put these ideas into other words.

Indicating the passing of a thing from one form, condition, or state to another; as, compound substances may be resolved into others which are more simple; ice is convertible into water, and water into vapor; men are more easily drawn than forced into compliance; we may reduce many distinct substances into one mass; men are led by evidence into belief of truth, and are often enticed into the commission of crimes; she burst into tears; children are sometimes frightened into fits; all persons are liable to be seduced into error and folly.

entry.def: The quality of being intolerable; intolerableness.

entry.ety: F. intolérable, L. intolerabilis. See In- not, and Tolerable

sn.def: Not tolerable; not capable of being borne or endured; not proper or right to be allowed; insufferable; insupportable; unbearable; as, intolerable pain; intolerable heat or cold; an intolerable burden.
sn.q: His insolence is more intolerable Than all the princes in the land beside.

sn.def: Enormous.
sn.q: This intolerable deal of sack.

entry.ety: L. intolerantia impatience, unendurableness: cf. F. intolérance

sn.def: Lack of capacity to endure; as, intolerance of light.

The quality of being intolerant; refusal to allow to others the enjoyment of their opinions, chosen modes of worship, and the like; lack of patience and forbearance; illiberality; bigotry; as, intolerance shown toward a religious sect.
sn.q: These few restrictions, I hope, are no great stretches of intolerance, no very violent exertions of despotism.

entry.def: Intolerance.

entry.ety: L. intolerans -antis: cf. F. intolérant. See In- not, and Tolerant

sn.def: Not enduring; not able to endure.
sn.q: The powers of human bodies being limited and intolerant of excesses.

sn.def: Not tolerating difference of opinion or sentiment, especially in religious matters; refusing to allow others the enjoyment of their opinions, rights, or worship; unjustly impatient of the opinion of those disagree with us; not tolerant; unforbearing; bigoted.
sn.q: Religion, harsh, intolerant, austere, Parent of manners like herself severe.

entry.def: An intolerant person; a bigot.
In an intolerant manner.
Not tolerated.
Intolerant.
Intolerance; lack of toleration; refusal to tolerate a difference of opinion.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intombed; p. pr. & vb. n. Intombing
entry.def: To place in a tomb; to bury; to entomb. See Entomb.
See Entombment.

entry.ety: L. intonatus, p. p. of intonare to thunder, resound
entry.def: To thunder.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intonated; p. pr. & vb. n. Intonating
entry.ety: See Intone

sn.def: To sound the tones of the musical scale; to practice the sol-fa.
To modulate the voice in a musical, sonorous, and measured manner, as in reading the liturgy; to intone.

entry.def: To utter in a musical or sonorous manner; to chant; as, to intonate the liturgy.

entry.ety: See 1st Intonate
entry.def: A thundering; thunder.

entry.ety: Cf. F. intonation. See Intone

sd.def: The act of sounding the tones of the musical scale.
Singing or playing in good tune or otherwise; as, her intonation was false.
Reciting in a musical prolonged tone; intonating, or singing of the opening phrase of a plain-chant, psalm, or canticle by a single voice, as of a priest. See Intone v. t.

sn.def: The manner of speaking, especially the placement of emphasis, the cadence, and the rise and fall of the pitch of the voice while speaking.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intoned; p. pr. & vb. n. Intoning
entry.ety: LL. intonare intonatum; pref. in- in + L. tonus tone. See Tone and cf. Entune Intonate

sn.def: To utter with a musical or prolonged note or tone; to chant; as, to intone the church service.
To speak with a distinctive or unusual tone in the voice, or in a monotone; as, the professor intoned his lectures as though by rote.

entry.def: To utter a prolonged tone or a deep, protracted sound; to speak or recite in a measured, sonorous manner; to intonate.

entry.ety: L. intortio a curling, crisping: cf. F. intorsion. See Intort, and cf. Intortion

sn.def: A winding, bending, or twisting.
The bending or twining of any part of a plant toward one side or the other, or in any direction from the vertical.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intorted; p. pr. & vb. n. Intorting
entry.ety: L. intortus, p. p. of intoquere to twist; pref. in- in + torquere to twist
entry.def: To twist in and out; to twine; to wreathe; to wind; to wring.
See Intorsion.
That which intoxicates; an intoxicating agent; as, alcohol, opium, and laughing gas are intoxicants .

entry.ety: LL. intoxicatus, p. p. of intoxicare to drug or poison; pref. in- in + L. toxicum a poison in which arrows were dipped, Gr. �, fr. � pertaining to a bow. See Toxic

sn.def: Intoxicated.
Overexcited, as with joy or grief.
sn.q: Alas, good mother, be not intoxicate for me; I am well enough.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intoxicated; p. pr. & vb. n. Intoxicating

sn.def: To poison; to drug.
To make drunk; to inebriate; to excite or to stupefy by strong drink or by a narcotic substance.
sn.q: With new wine inoxicated both.

sn.def: To excite to a transport of enthusiasm, frenzy, or madness; to elate unduly or excessively.
sn.q: Intoxicated with the sound of those very bells.
They are not intoxicated by military success.

entry.def: The state of being intoxicated; intoxication; drunkenness.
Producing intoxication; fitted to intoxicate; as, intoxicating liquors.

sn.def: A poisoning, as by a alcoholic or a narcotic substance.
The state of being intoxicated or drunk; inebriation; ebriety; drunkenness; the act of intoxicating or making drunk.
A high excitement of mind; an elation which rises to enthusiasm, frenzy, or madness.
sn.q: That secret intoxication of pleasure.
sn.syn: Drunkenness; inebriation; inebriety; ebriety; infatuation; delirium. See Drunkenness.

entries.entry:
‖In"tra-. L. intra, prep., within, on the inside; akin to inter. See Inter-
A prefix signifying in within interior; as, intraocular, within the eyeball; intramarginal.

entry.def: Situated below the point where a leaf joins the stem.
Within a cell; as, the intracellular movements seen in the pigment cells, the salivary cells, and in the protoplasm of some vegetable cells; intracellular enzymes. Contrasted with extracellular.
Within the colon; as, the intracolic valve.
Within the cranium or skull.
The quality of being intractable; intractableness.

entry.ety: L. intractabilis: cf. F. intraitable, formerly also intractable. See In- not, and Tractable
entry.def: Not tractable; not easily governed, managed, or directed; indisposed to be taught, disciplined, or tamed; violent; stubborn; obstinate; refractory; as, an intractable child.
entry.syn: Stubborn; perverse; obstinate; refractory; cross; unmanageable; unruly; headstrong; violent; ungovernable; unteachable.

entry.def: Not tractile; incapable of being drawn out or extended.
relating to areas between the layers of the skin.
relating to areas between the layers of the skin.
same as intradermal.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. intra within + F. dos the back, L. dorsum. Cf. Extrados
entry.def: The interior curve of an arch; esp., the inner or lower curved face of the whole body of voussoirs taken together. See Extrados.
Growing immediately above, or in front of, a leaf; as, intrafoliaceous stipules.

entry.ety: Pref. intra- + L. fundere fusum, to pour
entry.def: The act of pouring into a vessel; specif. Med, the operation of introducing a substance into a blood vessel; as, intrafusion of blood.
Within lobules; as, the intralobular branches of the hepatic veins.
Situated within the margin.
Between the planet Mercury and the sun;as, the hypothetical Vulcan is intramercurial .

sn.def: Between molecules; situated, or acting, between the molecules of bodies.
Being or occurring within a single molecule; as, intramolecular hydrogen bonds.

entry.def: Being within the material world; -- opposed to extramundane.

sn.def: Being within the walls, as of a city.

Of or pertaining to those activities occurring within a single institution or organization, such as intramural sports involving students of a single school; an intramural debate within a professional society.
Being within the substance of the walls of an organ; as, intramural pregnancy.

entry.def: Unquietness; restlessness.
Impervious to heat; adiathermic.

entry.ety: L. intragressibilis that can not be crossed. See In- not, and Transgress
entry.def: Incapable of being transgressed; not to be passed over or crossed.
Not transient; remaining; permanent.

entry.ety: F. intransigeantcf. Sp. intransigente); pref. in- not + L. transigere to come to an agreement; trans across + agere to lead, act
entry.def: Refusing compromise; uncompromising; inflexible; irreconcilable.

entry.ety: Sp
entry.def: The extreme radicals; the party of the irreconcilables.

entry.note: ☞ Intransitive verbs have no passive form. Some verbs which appear at first sight to be intransitive are in reality, or were originally, transitive verbs with a reflexive or other object omitted; as, he keepsi. e., himself) aloof from danger. Intransitive verbs may take a noun of kindred signification for a cognate object; as, he died the death of a hero; he dreamed a dream. Some intransitive verbs, by the addition of a preposition, become transitive, and so admit of a passive voice; as, the man laughed at; he was laughed at by the man.
entry.ety: L. intransitivus: cf. F. intransitif. See In- not, and Transitive

sn.def: Not passing farther; kept; detained.
sn.q: And then it is for the image's sake and so far is intransitive; but whatever is paid more to the image is transitive and passes further.

sn.def: Not transitive; not passing over to an object; expressing an action or state that is limited to the agent or subject, or, in other words, an action which does not require an object to complete the sense; as, an intransitive verb, e. g., the bird flies; the dog runs .

entry.def: Without an object following; in the manner of an intransitive verb.

entries.entry: ‖In` tran"si*tu. L Law In transit; during passage; as, goods in transitu .

entry.def: Not capable of being transmitted; as, an intransmissable illness.
The quality of being intransmutable.
Not capable of being transmuted or changed into another substance.

entry.ety: L. intrans, p. pr. of intrare to enter. See Enter
entry.def: Entering; penetrating.
One who enters; especially, a person entering upon some office or station.

Of or pertaining to, or located on the inside of a nucleus; taking place within a nucleus; referring especially to the nucleus of a cell; as, the intranuclear network of fibrils, seen in the first stages of karyokinesis.
See Entrap.
Situated or occurring within an inclosure; shut off from public sight; private; secluded; retired.
entry.q: I have no Turkish proclivities, and I do not think that, after all, impaling is preferable as a mode of capital punishment to intraparietal hanging.

entry.def: Situated between the petiole and the stem; -- said of the pair of stipules at the base of a petiole when united by those margins next the petiole, thus seeming to form a single stipule between the petiole and the stem or branch; -- often confounded with interpetiolar, from which it differs essentially in meaning.
Within the territory or a territory.
Within the thorax or chest.
Within the tropics.
Within the uterus or womb; as, intrauterine hemorrhage; an intrauterine device.
A contraceptive device consisting of a small, usually plastic object placed within the uterus to prevent conception; also called IUD.
Between valves.

sn.def: Within the veins.
Administered by injection into a vein; as, an intravenous antibiotic infusion.

entry.def: Within or between ventricles.
a wood or metal receptacle placed on a desk to hold incoming material requiring attention, especially documents.
To lay up, as in a treasury; to hoard.
See Entreat.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + treatable
entry.def: Not to be entreated; inexorable.
Entreaty.
Full of entreaty.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intrenched; p. pr. & vb. n. Intrenching

sn.def: To cut in; to furrow; to make trenches in or upon.
sn.q: It was this very sword intrenched it.
His face Deep scars of thunder had intrenched.

sn.def: To surround with a trench or with intrenchments, as in fortification; to fortify with a ditch and parapet; as, the army intrenched their camp, or intrenched itself.
sn.q: In the suburbs closeintrenched.

entry.def: To invade; to encroach; to infringe or trespass; to enter on, and take possession of, that which belongs to another; -- usually followed by on or upon; as, the king was charged with intrenching on the rights of the nobles, and the nobles were accused of intrenching on the prerogative of the crown.
entry.q: We are not to intrench upon truth in any conversation, but least of all with children.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + trenchant
entry.def: Not to be gashed or marked with furrows.
entry.q: As easy mayest thou the intrenchant air With thy keen sword impress, as make me bleed.

entry.ety: From Intrench

sn.def: The act of intrenching or the state of being intrenched.
Any defensive work consisting of at least a trench or ditch and a parapet made from the earth thrown up in making such a ditch.
sn.q: On our side, we have thrown up intrenchments on Winter and Prospect Hills.

sn.def: Any defense or protection.
An encroachment or infringement.
sn.q: The slight intrenchment upon individual freedom.

entry.ety: L. intrepidus: cf. F. intrépide. See In- not, and Trepidation
entry.def: Not trembling or shaking with fear; fearless; bold; brave; undaunted; courageous; as, an intrepid soldier; intrepid spirit.
entry.syn: Fearless; dauntless; resolute; brave; courageous; daring; valiant; heroic; doughty.

entry.ety: Cf. F. intrépidité
entry.def: The quality or state of being intrepid; fearless bravery; courage; resoluteness; valor.
entry.q: Sir Roger had acquitted himself of two or three sentences with a look of much business and great intrepidity.
entry.syn: Courage; heroism; bravery; fortitude; gallantry; valor. See Courage Heroism.

entry.def: In an intrepid manner; courageously; resolutely.

entry.ety: See Intricate
entry.def: Entangling.

entries.entry:
In"tri*ca*cy n.; pl.Intricacies #. From Intricate
The state or quality of being intricate or entangled; perplexity; involution; complication; complexity; that which is intricate or involved; as, the intricacy of a knot; the intricacy of accounts; the intricacy of a cause in controversy; the intricacy of a plot.
Freed from intricacies, taught to live The easiest way.

entry.usage: A thing is complex when it is made up of parts; it is complicated when those parts are so many, or so arranged, as to make it difficult to grasp them; it is intricate when it has numerous windings and confused involutions which it is hard to follow out. What is complex must be resolved into its parts; what is complicated must be drawn out and developed; what is intricate must be unraveled.
entry.ety: L. intricatus, p. p. of intricare to entangle, perplex. Cf. Intrigue Extricate
entry.def: Entangled; involved; perplexed; complicated; difficult to understand, follow, arrange, or adjust; as, intricate machinery, labyrinths, accounts, plots, etc.
entry.q: His style was fit to convey the most intricate business to the understanding with the utmost clearness.
The nature of man is intricate.

entry.def: To entangle; to involve; to make perplexing.
entry.q: It makes men troublesome, and intricates all wise discourses.

entry.def: In an intricate manner.
The state or quality of being intricate; intricacy.
Entanglement.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A female intriguer.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intrigued -trēgd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Intriguing
entry.ety: F. intriguer, OF. intriquer entriquer; cf. It. intrigare. See Intricate Extricate

sn.def: To form a plot or scheme; to contrive to accomplish a purpose by secret artifice.
To carry on a secret and illicit love or amour.

entry.def: To fill with artifice and duplicity; to complicate; to embarrass.
entry.q: How doth it [sin] perplex and intrique the whole course of your lives!

entry.ety: Cf. F. intrique. See Intrigue v. i.

sn.def: Intricacy; complication.
A complicated plot or scheme intended to effect some purpose by secret artifice; conspiracy; stratagem.
sn.q: Busy meddlers with intrigues of state.

sn.def: The plot of a play or romance; a complicated scheme of designs, actions, and events.
A secret and illicit love affair between two persons of different sexes; an amour; a liaison.
sn.q: The hero of a comedy is represented victorious in all his intrigues.
sn.syn: Plot; scheme; conspiracy; machination.

entry.def: One who intrigues.
Arts or practice of intrigue.
By means of, or in the manner of, intrigue.

entry.ety: See Intrinsic, and Intense
entry.def: Tightly drawn; or (perhaps) intricate.
entry.q: Like rats, oft bite the holy cords atwain, Which are too intrinse to unloose.

entry.cs: Intrinsic energy of a body Physics the work it can do in virtue of its actual condition, without any supply of energy from without. Intrinsic equation of a curve Geom the equation which expresses the relation which the length of a curve, measured from a given point of it, to a movable point, has to the angle which the tangent to the curve at the movable point makes with a fixed line. Intrinsic value. See the Note under Value n.
entry.ety: L. intrinsecus inward, on the inside; intra within + secus otherwise, beside; akin to E. second: cf. F. intrinsèque. See Inter- Second, and cf. Extrinsic

sn.def: Inward; internal; hence, true; genuine; real; essential; inherent; not merely apparent or accidental; -- opposed to extrinsic; as, the intrinsic value of gold or silver; the intrinsic merit of an action; the intrinsic worth or goodness of a person.
sn.q: He was better qualified than they to estimate justly the intrinsic value of Grecian philosophy and refinement.

sn.def: Included wholly within an organ or limb, as certain groups of muscles; -- opposed to extrinsic.
sn.syn: Inherent; innate; natural; real; genuine.

entry.def: A genuine quality.

sn.def: Intrinsic.
Intimate; closely familiar.

entry.def: The quality of being intrinsic; essentialness; genuineness; reality.
Internally; in its nature; essentially; really; truly.
entry.q: A lie is a thing absolutely and intrinsically evil.

entry.def: The quality of being intrinsical; intrinsicality.
Intricate.

entries.entry:
In"tro-. L. intro, adv., inwardly, within. See Inter-
A prefix signifying within into in inward; as, introduce, introreception, introthoracic.

entry.ety: L. introcedere introcessum, to go in; intro within + cedere to go
entry.def: A depression, or inward sinking of parts.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Introduced; p. pr. & vb. n. Introducing
entry.ety: L. introducere introductum; intro within + ducere to lead. See Intro-, and Duke

sn.def: To lead or bring in; to conduct or usher in; as, to introduce a person into a drawing-room.
To put (something into a place); to insert; as, to introduce the finger, or a probe.
To lead to and make known by formal announcement or recommendation; hence, to cause to be acquainted; as, to introduce strangers; to introduce one person to another.
To bring into notice, practice, cultivation, or use; as, to introduce a new fashion, method, or plant.
To produce; to cause to exist; to induce.
sn.q: Whosoever introduces habits in children, deserves the care and attention of their governors.

sn.def: To open to notice; to begin; to present; as, he introduced the subject with a long preface.
sn.syn: To bring in; usher in; insert; begin; preface.

entry.def: Introduction.
One who, or that which, introduces.
To introduce.

entry.ety: L. introductio: cf. F. introduction. See Introduce

sn.def: The act of introducing, or bringing to notice.
The act of formally making persons known to each other; a presentation or making known of one person to another by name; as, the introduction of one stranger to another.
That part of a book or discourse which introduces or leads the way to the main subject, or part; preliminary; matter; preface; proem; exordium.
A formal and elaborate preliminary treatise; specifically, a treatise introductory to other treatises, or to a course of study; a guide; as, an introduction to English literature.

entry.ety: Cf. F. introductif
entry.def: Serving to introduce; introductory.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: An introducer.
By way of introduction.

entry.ety: L. itroductorius: cf. F. introductoire
entry.def: Serving to introduce something else; leading to the main subject or business; preliminary; prefatory; as, introductory proceedings; an introductory discourse.
A female introducer.
Flexed or bent inward.

entry.ety: L. introgressus, p. p. of introgredi to go in; intro- within + gradi to step, go
entry.def: The act of going in; entrance.

entry.ety: L. introitus, fr. introire to go into, to enter; intro within + ire to go: cf. F. introit

sn.def: A going in.

sd.def: A psalm sung or chanted immediately before the collect, epistle, and gospel, and while the priest is entering within the rails of the altar.
A part of a psalm or other portion of Scripture read by the priest at Mass immediately after ascending to the altar.

sn.def: An anthem or psalm sung before the Communion service.
Any composition of vocal music appropriate to the opening of church services.

entry.ety: Cf. F. intromission. See Intromit

sn.def: The act of sending in or of putting in; insertion.
The insertion of the male copulatory organ into the female in the process of coitus.

q.au: Edith Dempster (African Small Mammals Newsletter, Issue No. 16, May 1996, Laboratoir Mammifères & Oiseaux, Paris)

sn.q: Four populations [of the vlei rat] varied in a number of parameters of copulatory behavior, such as latency to first mount, number of intromissions per series, and latency to intromission after first ejaculation.

sn.def: The act of letting go in; admission.
An intermeddling with the affairs of another, either on legal grounds or without authority.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intromitted; p. pr. & vb. n. Intromitting
entry.ety: L. intromittere intromissum; intro- within + mittere to send

sn.def: To send in or put in; to insert or introduce.
To allow to pass in; to admit.
sn.q: Glass in the window intromits light, without cold.

entry.def: To intermeddle with the effects or goods of another.

entry.ety: L. intromittens, p. pr

sn.def: Throwing, or allowing to pass, into or within.
Used in copulation; -- said of the external reproductive organs of the males of many animals, and sometimes of those of the females.

entry.def: One who intromits.
Pressure acting within.
The act of admitting into or within.

entry.ety: L. introrsus inward, contr. from introversus. See Introvert
entry.def: Turning or facing inward, or toward the axis of the part to which it belongs.

entry.ety: L. introspectus, p. p. introspicere to look into; intro within + specere to look. See Spy
entry.def: To look into or within; to view the inside of.

entry.ety: Cf. F. introspection
entry.def: A view of the inside or interior; a looking inward;
the act or process of self-examination, or inspection of one's own thoughts and feelings; the cognition which the mind has of its own acts and states; self-consciousness; reflection.
entry.q: I was forced to make an introspection into my own mind.

entry.def: One given to the introspective method of examining the phenomena of the soul.

entry.ety: Cf. F. introspectif
