sn.def: Inspecting within; seeing inwardly; capable of, or exercising, inspection; self-conscious.
Involving the act or results of conscious knowledge of physical phenomena; -- contrasted with associational.

entry.ety: Pref. intro- + L. sumere to take
entry.def: To draw in; to swallow.

sn.def: The act or process of receiving within.
sn.q: The person is corrupted by the introsusception of a nature which becomes evil thereby.

sn.def: Same as Intussusception.

entry.ety: L. introveniens, p. pr. of introvenire to come in; intro within + venire to come
entry.def: Coming in together; entering; commingling.

entry.ety: See Introvert
entry.def: The act of introverting, or the state of being introverted; the act of turning the mind inward.

entries.entry: introversive adj. Psychol directed inward; marked by interest in oneself or concerned with inner feelings. Contrasted with extroversive.Narrower terms: introvert, introverted, introvertive; introvertish, shut-in ]. Antonym: ambiversive. Also See: unsociable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Introverted; p. pr. & vb. n. Introverting
entry.ety: Pref. intro- + L. vertere versum, to turn

sn.def: To turn or bend inward.
sn.q: Introvertedtoes.

sn.def: To look within; to introspect.
A person who is introverted; one concerned predominantly with himself or his own feelings. Contrasted with extrovert.
A person who is shy.
A part that can be introverted{1}.
examining one's own sensory and perceptual experiences. Contrasted with extrospective.
sn.syn: introspective.

sn.def: marked by concern predominantly with oneself or one's own feelings. Contrasted with extroverted.
sn.syn: introvert, introvertive.

entry.def: somewhat introverted.
same as introverted, 2.

entry.ety: L. intrudere intrusum; pref. in- in + trudere to thrust, akin to E. threat. See Threat
entry.def: To thrust one's self in; to come or go in without invitation, permission, or welcome; to encroach; to trespass; as, to intrude on families at unseasonable hours; to intrude on the lands of another.
entry.q: Thy wit wants edge And manners, to intrude where I am graced.
Some thoughts rise and intrude upon us, while we shun them; others fly from us, when we would hold them.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intruded; p. pr. & vb. n. Intruding

sn.def: To thrust or force (something) in or upon; especially, to force (one's self) in without leave or welcome; as, to intrude one's presence into a conference; to intrude one's opinions upon another.
To enter by force; to invade.
sn.q: Why should the worm intrude the maiden bud?

sn.def: The cause to enter or force a way, as into the crevices of rocks.
sn.syn: To obtrude; encroach; infringe; intrench; trespass. See Obtrude.

entry.def: Same as Intrusive.

sn.def: One who intrudes; one who thrusts himself in, or enters without right, or without leave or welcome; a trespasser.
sn.q: They were all strangers and intruders.

sn.def: A person who enters a private residence or place of business with the intention to perform a criminal act; as, killed by an intruder .

entry.def: A female intruder.
To inclose as in a trunk; to incase.

entry.ety: Cf. F. intrusion. See Intrude

sn.def: The act of intruding, or of forcing in; especially, the forcing (one's self) into a place without right or welcome; encroachment.
sn.q: Why this intrusion? Were not my orders that I should be private?

sn.def: The penetrating of one rock, while in a plastic or metal state, into the cavities of another.
The entry of a stranger, after a particular estate or freehold is determined, before the person who holds in remainder or reversion has taken possession.
The settlement of a minister over a congregation without their consent.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to intrusion.
One who intrudes; especially, one who favors the appointment of a clergyman to a parish, by a patron, against the wishes of the parishioners.

cs.cd: rocks which have been forced, while in a plastic or melted state, into the cavities or between the cracks or layers of other rocks. The term is sometimes used as equivalent to plutonic rocks. It is then contrasted with effusive or volcanic rocks.

entry.def: Apt to intrude; characterized by intrusion; entering without right or welcome.

To deliver (something) to another in trust; to deliver to (another) something in trust; to commit or surrender (something) to another with a certain confidence regarding his care, use, or disposal of it; as, to intrust a servant with one's money or intrust money or goods to a servant.
entry.syn: To commit; consign; confide. See Commit.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + tube
entry.def: The introduction of a tube into an organ to keep it open, as into the larynx in croup.

entry.ety: L. intuitus, p. p. of intueri to look on; in- in, on + tueri: cf. F. intuition. See Tuition

sn.def: A looking after; a regard to.
sn.q: What, no reflection on a reward! He might have an intuition at it, as the encouragement, though not the cause, of his pains.

sn.def: Direct apprehension or cognition; immediate knowledge, as in perception or consciousness; -- distinguished from “mediate” knowledge, as in reasoning; as, the mind knows by intuition that black is not white, that a circle is not a square, that three are more than two, etc.; quick or ready insight or apprehension.
sn.q: Sagacity and a nameless something more, -- let us call it intuition.

sn.def: Any object or truth discerned by intuition.
Any quick insight, recognized immediately without a reasoning process; a belief arrived at unconsciously; -- often it is based on extensive experience of a subject.

The ability to have insight into a matter without conscious thought; as, his chemical intuition allowed him to predict compound conformations without any conscious calculation; a mother's intuition often tells her what is best for her child.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, intuition; characterized by intuition; perceived by intuition; intuitive.
The doctrine that the perception or recognition of primary truth is intuitive, or direct and immediate; -- opposed to sensationalism, and experientialism.
One who holds the doctrine of intuitionalism.
Same as Intuitionalism.
Same as Intuitionalist.

entry.ety: Cf. F. intuitif

sn.def: Seeing clearly; as, an intuitive view; intuitive vision.
Knowing, or perceiving, by intuition; capable of knowing without deduction or reasoning.
sn.q: Whence the soul Reason receives, and reason is her being, Discursive, or intuitive.

sn.def: Received, reached, obtained, or perceived, by intuition; as, intuitive judgment or knowledge; -- opposed to deductive.

entry.def: In an intuitive manner.
The doctrine that the ideas of right and wrong are intuitive.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Intumesced; p. pr. & vb. n. Intumescing
entry.ety: L. intumescere; pref. in- in + tumescere to swell up, incho. fr. tumere to swell. See Tumid
entry.def: To enlarge or expand with heat; to swell; specifically, to swell up or bubble up under the action of heat, as before the blowpipe.
entry.q: In a higher heat, it intumesces, and melts into a yellowish black mass.

entry.ety: Cf. F. intumescence

sn.def: The act or process of swelling or enlarging; also, the state of being swollen; expansion; tumidity; especially, the swelling up of bodies under the action of heat.
sn.q: The intumescence of nations.

sn.def: Anything swollen or enlarged, as a tumor.

entry.ety: L. intumescens, p. pr
entry.def: Swelling up; expanding.

entry.ety: L. intumulatus. See In- not, and Tumulate
entry.def: Unburied.
To intone. Cf. Entune.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inturbidated; p. pr. & vb. n. Inturbidating
entry.ety: Pref. in- in + turbid
entry.def: To render turbid; to darken; to confuse.
entry.q: The confusion of ideas and conceptions under the same term painfully inturbidates his theology.

entry.ety: L. inturgescens, p. pr. of inturgescere to swell up. See 1st In-, and Turgescent
entry.def: A swelling; the act of swelling, or state of being swelled.

entry.ety: L. intundere to bruise; pref. in- in + tundere tusum, to beat, bruise
entry.def: A bruise; a contusion.

entry.ety: See Intussusception
entry.def: Received into some other thing or part, as a sword into a sheath; invaginated.

entry.ety: L. intus within + susception. Cf. Introsusception

sn.def: The reception of one part within another.

The abnormal reception or slipping of a part of a tube, by inversion and descent, within a contiguous part of it; specifically, the reception or slipping of the upper part of the small intestine into the lower; introsusception; invagination.
The interposition of new particles of formative material among those already existing, as in a cell wall, or in a starch grain.

The act of taking foreign matter, as food, into a living body; the process of nutrition, by which dead matter is absorbed by the living organism, and ultimately converted into the organized substance of its various tissues and organs.
sn.q: Dead bodies increase by apposition; living bodies by intussusception.

entry.ety: Cf. Entwine
entry.def: To twine or twist into, or together; to wreathe; as, a wreath of flowers intwined .
To be or to become intwined.
The act of intwining, or the state of being intwined.

entry.ety: Cf. Entwist
entry.def: To twist into or together; to interweave.
See Innuendo.

entry.ety: From NL. Inula Helenium, the elecampane: cf. F. inuline
entry.def: A substance of very wide occurrence. It is found dissolved in the sap of the roots and rhizomes of many composite and other plants, as Inula Helianthus Campanula, etc., and is extracted by solution as a tasteless, white, semicrystalline substance, resembling starch, with which it is isomeric, having fructose units in place of most of the glucose units. It is intermediate in nature between starch and sugar, and replaces starch as the reserve food in Compositae. Called also dahlin helenin alantin alant starch, etc.

entry.ety: Inulin + -oid
entry.def: A substance resembling inulin, found in the unripe bulbs of the dahlia.

entry.ety: L. inumbratus, p. p. of inumbrare to shade
entry.def: To shade; to darken.

entry.ety: See Inunction
entry.def: Anointed.

entry.ety: L. inunctio, fr. inungere inunctum, to anoint. See 1st In-, and Unction
entry.def: The act of anointing, or the state of being anointed; unction; specifically Med, the rubbing of ointments into the pores of the skin, by which medicinal agents contained in them, such as mercury, iodide of potash, etc., are absorbed.
The lack of unctuosity; freedom from greasiness or oiliness; as, the inunctuosity of porcelain clay.

entry.ety: L. inundans, p. pr. of inundare
entry.def: Overflowing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inundated; p. pr. & vb. n. Inundating
entry.ety: L. inundatus, p. p. of inundare to inundate; pref. in- in + undare to rise in waves, to overflow, fr. unda a wave. See Undulate

sn.def: To cover with a flood; to overflow; to deluge; to flood; as, the river inundated the town.
To fill with an overflowing abundance or superfluity; as, the country was inundated with bills of credit.
sn.syn: To overflow; deluge; flood; overwhelm; submerge; drown.

entry.ety: L. inundatio: cf. F. inondation

sn.def: The act of inundating, or the state of being inundated; an overflow; a flood; a rising and spreading of water over grounds.
sn.q: With inundation wide the deluge reigns, Drowns the deep valleys, and o'erspreads the plains.

sn.def: An overspreading of any kind; overflowing or superfluous abundance; a flood; a great influx; as, an inundation of tourists.
sn.q: To stop the inundation of her tears.

entry.def: Void of understanding.

entry.ety: L. inurbanus. See In- not, and Urbane
entry.def: Uncivil; unpolished; rude. Opposite of urbane.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inurbanité
entry.def: Lack of urbanity or courtesy; unpolished manners or deportment; inurbaneness; rudeness.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inured; p. pr. & vb. n. Inuring
entry.ety: From pref. in- in + ure use, work. See Ure use, practice, Opera, and cf. Manure
entry.def: To apply in use; to train; to discipline; to use or accustom till use gives little or no pain or inconvenience; to harden; to habituate; to practice habitually.
entry.q: Toinureour prompt obedience.
He . . . did inure them to speak little.
Inured and exercised in learning.
The poor, inured to drudgery and distress.

q.au: Gibbon [quoting Tacitus] (Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire, Ch. 10)

entry.q: “Here the fortune of the day turned, and all things became adverse to the Romans; the place deep with ooze, sinking under those who stood, slippery to such as advanced; their armor heavy, the waters deep; nor could they wield, in that uneasy situation, their weighty javelins. The barbarians on the contrary, were inured to encounter in the bogs, their persons tall, their spears long, such as could wound at a distance.” In this morass the Roman army, after an ineffectual struggle, was irrecoverably lost; nor could the body of the emperor ever be found. Such was the fate of Decius, in the fiftieth year of his age; . . .

entry.def: To pass into use; to take or have effect; to be applied; to serve to the use or benefit of; as, a gift of lands inures to the heirs.
Use; practice; discipline; habit; custom.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inurned; p. pr. & vb. n. Inurning
entry.def: To put in an urn, as the ashes of the dead; hence, to bury; to intomb.
entry.q: The sepulcher Wherein we saw thee quietly inurned.

entry.ety: L. inusitatus unusual. See Use
entry.def: Unusual.
Lack of use; disuse.

entry.ety: L. inurere inustum, to burn in; pref. in- in + urere to burn
entry.def: Burnt in.
The act of burning or branding.

entry.ety: L. inutilis: cf. F. inutile. See In- not, Utile
entry.def: Useless; unprofitable.

entry.ety: L. inutilitas: cf. F. inutilité
entry.def: Uselessness; the quality of being unprofitable; unprofitableness; as, the inutility of vain speculations and visionary projects.
Unutterable; inexpressible.

entries.entry: ‖In` vac"u*o. L Physics In a vacuum; in empty space; as, experiments in vacuo .

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Invaded; p. pr. & vb. n. Invading
entry.ety: L. invadere invasum; pref. in- in + vadere to go, akin to E. wade: cf. OF. invader, F. envahir. See Wade

sn.def: To go into or upon; to pass within the confines of; to enter; -- used of forcible or rude ingress.
sn.q: Which becomes a body, and doth then invade The state of life, out of the grisly shade.

sn.def: To enter with hostile intentions; to enter with a view to conquest or plunder; to make an irruption into; to attack; as, the Romans invaded Great Britain.
sn.q: Such an enemy Is risen to invade us.

sn.def: To attack; to infringe; to encroach on; to violate; as, the king invaded the rights of the people.
To grow or spread over; to affect injuriously and progressively; as, gangrene invades healthy tissue.
sn.syn: To attack; assail; encroach upon. See Attack.

entry.def: To make an invasion.
One who invades; an assailant; an encroacher; an intruder.
same as invasive1}.
To insert as in a sheath; to produce intussusception in.
Sheathed.
Having one portion of a hollow organ drawn back within another portion.

entry.note: ☞ In embolic invagination, one half of the blastosphere is pushed in towards the other half, producing an embryonic form known as a gastrula. -- In epibolic invagination, a phenomenon in the development of some invertebrate ova, the epiblast appears to grow over or around the hypoblast.
entry.ety: L. pref. in- + vagina sheath

sn.def: The condition of an invaginated organ or part.
The inward movement of the wall of a tissue or cell, to form a cavity; also, the cavity thus formed.
The inward movement of one part of the wall of a blastula, to form a gastrula; the process of gastrulation, in which layers of the ovum are differentiated.

entry.ety: L. invalescens, p. pr. of invalescere to become strong. See 1st In-, and Convalesce
entry.def: Strength; health.
Wanting health; valetudinary.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + valid: cf. F. invalide, L. invalidus infirm, weak. Cf. Invalid infirm

sn.def: Of no force, weight, or cogency; not valid; weak.
Having no force, effect, or efficacy; void; null; as, an invalid contract or agreement.

entry.ety: F. invalide n. & a., L. invalidus a. See Invalid null
entry.def: A person who is weak and infirm; one who is disabled for active service; especially, one in chronic ill health who is unable to care for himself.

entry.ety: See Invalid n.
entry.def: Not well; feeble; infirm; sickly; as, he had an invalid daughter.

sn.def: To make or render invalid or infirm.
sn.q: Invalided, bent, and almost blind.

sn.def: To classify or enroll as an invalid.
sn.q: Peace coming, he was invalided on half pay.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Invalidated; p. pr. & vb. n. Invalidating
entry.ety: From Invalid null
entry.def: To render invalid; to weaken or lessen the force of; to destroy the authority of; to render of no force or effect; to overthrow; as, to invalidate an agreement or argument.
deprived of legal force.
tending to invalidate or prove false.
The act of inavlidating, or the state of being invalidated.
entry.q: So many invalidations of their right.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: See Invalid n.
The condition of an invalid; sickness; infirmity.

entry.ety: Cf. F. invalidité, LL. invaliditas lack of health

sn.def: Lack of validity or cogency; lack of legal force or efficacy; invalidness; as, the invalidity of an agreement or of a will.
Lack of health; infirmity.

entry.def: Invalidity; as, the invalidness of reasoning.
Not valorous; cowardly.
Valuable beyond estimation; inestimable; priceless; precious.
Inestimably.
Inestimable.

entry.ety: Cf. F. invariabilité
entry.def: The quality of being invariable; invariableness; constancy; uniformity.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + variable: cf. F. invariable
entry.def: Not given to variation or change; unalterable; unchangeable; always uniform.
entry.q: Physical laws which are invariable.

entry.def: An invariable quantity; a constant.
Always; in every case.
The property of remaining invariable under prescribed or implied conditions.
An invariable quantity; specifically, a function of the coefficients of one or more forms, which remains unaltered, when these undergo suitable linear transformations.

entry.usage: Invasion is the generic term, denoting a forcible entrance into a foreign country. Incursion signifies a hasty and sudden invasion. Irruption denotes particularly violent invasion. Inroad is entry by some unusual way involving trespass and injury.
entry.ety: L. invasio: cf. F. invasion. See Invade

sn.def: The act of invading; the act of encroaching upon the rights or possessions of another; encroachment; trespass.
A warlike or hostile entrance into the possessions or domains of another; the incursion of an army for conquest or plunder.
The incoming or first attack of anything hurtful or pernicious; as, the invasion of a disease.
sn.syn: Invasion Irruption Inroad.

entry.ety: LL. invasivus: cf. F. invasif. See Invade

sn.def: Tending to invade; characterized by invasion; aggressive.
sn.q: Invasivewar.

entry.def: To inveigh.

entry.ety: L. invectus carried in. See Inveigh
entry.def: Having a border or outline composed of semicircles with the convexity outward; -- the opposite of engrailed.

entry.ety: L. invectio. See Inveigh
entry.def: An inveighing against; invective.

entry.ety: L. invectivus: cf. F. invectif. See Inveigh
entry.def: Characterized by invection; critical; denunciatory; satirical; abusive; railing.

entry.ety: F. invective
entry.def: An expression which inveighs or rails against a person; a severe or violent censure or reproach; something uttered or written, intended to cast opprobrium, censure, or reproach on another; a harsh or reproachful accusation; -- followed by against, having reference to the person or thing affected; as, an invective against tyranny.
entry.q: The world will be able to judge of his [Junius'] motives for writing such famous invectives.
entry.syn: Abuse; censure; reproach; satire; sarcasm; railing; diatribe. See Abuse.

entry.def: In an invective manner.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inveighed; p. pr. & vb. n. Inveighing
entry.ety: L. invehere invectum, to carry or bring into or against, to attack with words, to inveigh; pref. in- in + vehere to carry. See Vehicle, and cf. Invective
entry.def: To declaim or rail (against some person or thing); to utter censorious and bitter language; to attack with harsh criticism or reproach, either spoken or written; to use invectives; -- with against; as, to inveigh against character, conduct, manners, customs, morals, a law, an abuse.
entry.q: All men inveighed against him; all men, except court vassals, opposed him.
The artificial life against which we inveighed.

entry.def: One who inveighs.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inveigled; p. pr. & vb. n. Inveigling
entry.ety: Prob. fr. F. aveugler to blind, to delude, OF. aveugler avugler avegler, fr. F. aveugle blind, OF. aveugle avugle, properly, without eyes, fr. L. ab + oculus eye. The pref. in- seems to have been substituted for a- taken as the pref. F. à, L. ad. See Ocular
entry.def: To lead astray as if blind; to persuade to something evil by deceptive arts or flattery; to entice; to insnare; to seduce; to wheedle.
entry.q: Yet have they many baits and guileful spells To inveigle and invite the unwary sense.

entry.def: The act of inveigling, or the state of being inveigled; that which inveigles; enticement; seduction.
One who inveigles.
To cover, as with a veil.
The quality of being invendible; invendibleness; unsalableness.

entry.ety: L. invendibilis. See In- not, and Vendible
entry.def: Not vendible or salable.
See Envenom.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Invented; p. pr. & vb. n. Inventing
entry.ety: L. inventus, p. p. of invenire to come upon, to find, invent; pref. in- in + venire to come, akin to E. come: cf. F. inventer. See Come

sn.def: To come or light upon; to meet; to find.
sn.q: And vowed never to return again, Till him alive or dead she did invent.

sn.def: To discover, as by study or inquiry; to find out; to devise; to contrive or produce for the first time; -- applied commonly to the discovery of some serviceable mode, instrument, or machine.
sn.q: Thus first Necessity invented stools.

sn.def: To frame by the imagination; to fabricate mentally; to forge; -- in a good or a bad sense; as, to invent the machinery of a poem; to invent a falsehood.
sn.q: Whate'er his cruel malice could invent.
He had invented some circumstances, and put the worst possible construction on others.
sn.syn: To discover; contrive; devise; frame; design; fabricate; concoct; elaborate. See Discover.

entry.def: One who invents.
Full of invention.
Capable of being invented.
Quality of being inventible.

cs.cd: a festival celebrated May 3d, in honor of the finding of our Savior's cross by St. Helena.

entry.ety: L. inventio: cf. F. invention. See Invent

sn.def: The act of finding out or inventing; contrivance or construction of that which has not before existed; as, the invention of logarithms; the invention of the art of printing.
sn.q: As the search of it [truth] is the duty, so the invention will be the happiness of man.

sn.def: That which is invented; an original contrivance or construction; a device; as, this fable was the invention of Esop; that falsehood was her own invention; she patented five inventions.
sn.q: We entered by the drawbridge, which has an invention to let one fall if not premonished.

sn.def: Thought; idea.
A fabrication to deceive; a fiction; a forgery; a falsehood.
sn.q: Filling their hearers With strange invention.

sn.def: The faculty of inventing; imaginative faculty; skill or ingenuity in contriving anything new; as, a man of invention .
sn.q: They lay no less than a want of invention to his charge; a capital crime, . . . for a poet is a maker.

sn.def: The exercise of the imagination in selecting and treating a theme, or more commonly in contriving the arrangement of a piece, or the method of presenting its parts.

entry.def: Inventive.

entry.ety: Cf. F. inventif
entry.def: Able and apt to invent; quick at contrivance; ready at expedients; as, an inventive head or genius.

entry.ety: L.: cf. F. inventeur
entry.def: One who invents or finds out something new; a contriver; especially, one who invents mechanical devices, new drugs, new processes, or other useful objects or procedures.
Of or pertaining to an inventory.

entries.entry:
In"ven*to*ry n.; pl.Inventories #. L. inventarium: cf. LL. inventorium, F. inventaire, OF. also inventoire. See Invent
An account, catalogue, or schedule, made by an executor or administrator, of all the goods and chattels, and sometimes of the real estate, of a deceased person; a list of the property of which a person or estate is found to be possessed; hence, an itemized list of goods or valuables, with their estimated worth. Hence: Any listing, as in a catalogue, of objects or resources on hand and available for use or for sale. Specifically, the annual account listing the stock on hand, taken in any business. There take an inventory of all I have.
The objects contained on an inventory{1}; especially: the stock of items on hand in any business, either for sale and not yet sold, or kept as raw materials to be converted into finished products.
The total value of all goods in an inventory{2}.
The act of making an inventory{1}. List; register; schedule; catalogue. See List.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inventoried; p. pr. & vb. n. Inventorying
entry.ety: Cf. F. inventorier
entry.def: To make an inventory of; to make a list, catalogue, or schedule of; to insert or register in an account of goods; as, a merchant inventories his stock.
entry.q: I will give out divers schedules of my beauty; it shall be inventoried, and every particle and utensil labeled.

entry.def: the act or process of making an inventory; making an itemized list of merchandise or supplies on hand.

entry.ety: Cf. L. inventrix, F. inventrice
entry.def: A woman who invents.
Lack of veracity.
Lack of verisimilitude or likelihood; improbability.

entries.entry: In`ver*ness" n.orIn`ver*ness" cape" . A kind of full sleeveless cape, fitting closely about the neck. Robert's wind-blown head and tall form wrapped in an Inverness cape.

cs.cd: two figures, such that each point of either figure is inverse to a corresponding point in the order figure.

two points lying on a line drawn from the center of a fixed circle or sphere, and so related that the product of their distances from the center of the circle or sphere is equal to the square of the radius.
the ratio of the reciprocals of two quantities.
an equality between a direct ratio and a reciprocal ratio; thus, 4 : 2 : : 1/3 : 1/6 , or 4 : 2 : : 3 : 6, inversely.

entry.ety: L. inversus, p. p. of invertere: cf. F. inverse. See Invert

sn.def: Opposite in order, relation, or effect; reversed; inverted; reciprocal; -- opposed to direct.
Inverted; having a position or mode of attachment the reverse of that which is usual.

Opposite in nature and effect; -- said with reference to any two operations, which, when both are performed in succession upon any quantity, reproduce that quantity; as, multiplication is the inverse operation to division. The symbol of an inverse operation is the symbol of the direct operation with -1 as an index. Thus sin-1x means the arc or angle whose sine is x.

entry.def: That which is inverse.
entry.q: Thus the course of human study is the inverse of the course of things in nature.

entry.cs: Inversely proportional. See Directly proportional, under Directly, and Inversion, 4.
entry.def: In an inverse order or manner; by inversion; -- opposed to directly.

entry.note: ☞ The terms invert and inversion, in this sense, owe their meaning to the fact that the plane of polarization of light, which is rotated to the right by cane sugar, is turned toward the left by levulose.
This condition in the vicinity of cities can give rise to a severe episode of atmospheric pollution, as it inhibits normal circulation of the air.
entry.ety: L. inversio: cf. F. inversion. See Invert

sn.def: The act of inverting, or turning over or backward, or the state of being inverted.
A change by inverted order; a reversed position or arrangement of things; transposition.
sn.q: It is just the inversion of an act of Parliament; your lordship first signed it, and then it was passed among the Lords and Commons.

sn.def: A movement in tactics by which the order of companies in line is inverted, the right being on the left, the left on the right, and so on.
A change in the order of the terms of a proportion, so that the second takes the place of the first, and the fourth of the third.

A peculiar method of transformation, in which a figure is replaced by its inverse figure. Propositions that are true for the original figure thus furnish new propositions that are true in the inverse figure. See Inverse figures, under Inverse.
A change of the usual order of words or phrases; as, “of all vices, impurity is one of the most detestable,” instead of, “impurity is one of the most detestable of all vices.”
A method of reasoning in which the orator shows that arguments advanced by his adversary in opposition to him are really favorable to his cause.

sd.def: Said of intervals, when the lower tone is placed an octave higher, so that fifths become fourths, thirds sixths, etc.
Said of a chord, when one of its notes, other than its root, is made the bass.
Said of a subject, or phrase, when the intervals of which it consists are repeated in the contrary direction, rising instead of falling, or vice versa.
Said of double counterpoint, when an upper and a lower part change places.

sn.def: The folding back of strata upon themselves, as by upheaval, in such a manner that the order of succession appears to be reversed.

The act or process by which cane sugar (sucrose), under the action of heat and acids or enzymes (as diastase), is broken or split up into grape sugar (dextrose), and fruit sugar (levulose); also, less properly, the process by which starch is converted into grape sugar (dextrose).
A reversal of the usual temperature gradient of the atmosphere, in which the temperature increases with increased altitude, rather than falling. Called also temperature inversion.
The conversion of direct current into alternating current; the inverse of rectification. See inverted rectifier.
A portion of the genome in which the DNA has been turned around, and runs in a direction opposite to its normal direction, and consequently the genes are present in the reverse of their usual order.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inverted; p. pr. & vb. n. Inverting
entry.ety: L. invertere inversum; pref. in- in + vertere to turn. See Verse

sn.def: To turn over; to put upside down; to upset; to place in a contrary order or direction; to reverse; as, to invert a cup, the order of words, rules of justice, etc.
sn.q: That doth invert the attest of eyes and ears, As if these organs had deceptious functions.
Such reasoning falls like an inverted cone, Wanting its proper base to stand upon.

sn.def: To change the position of; -- said of tones which form a chord, or parts which compose harmony.
To divert; to convert to a wrong use.
To convert; to reverse; to decompose by, or subject to, inversion. See Inversion n., 10.

entry.def: To undergo inversion, as sugar.

cs.cd: a variety of sugar, consisting of a mixture of dextrose and levulose, found naturally in fruits, and produced artificially by the inversion of cane sugar (sucrose); also, less properly, the grape sugar or dextrose obtained from starch. See Inversion Dextrose Levulose, and Sugar.

entry.def: Subjected to the process of inversion; inverted; converted; as, invert sugar.
An inverted arch.
An enzyme capable of effecting the inversion of cane suger, producing invert sugar. It is found in many plants and in the intestines of animals.
By extension, any enzyme which splits cane sugar, milk sugar, lactose, etc., into monosaccharides.
Same as Invertebrate.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. in- not + vertebratus vertebrate
entry.def: A comprehensive division of the animal kingdom, including all except the Vertebrata.

entry.cs: Age of invertebrates. See Age, and Silurian.
entry.def: Destitute of a backbone; having no vertebræ; of or pertaining to the Invertebrata.
Having no backbone; invertebrate.

cs.cd: an arch placed with crown downward; -- much used in foundations.

sn.def: Changed to a contrary or counterchanged order; reversed; characterized by inversion.
Situated apparently in reverse order, as strata when folded back upon themselves by upheaval.

entry.def: In an inverted order.
A device which converts direct current to alternating current.

entry.ety: From Invert

sn.def: Capable of being inverted or turned inside out.
Capable of being changed or converted; as, invertible sugar.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + L. vertere to turn + -ible
entry.def: Incapable of being turned or changed.
entry.q: An indurate and invertible conscience.

entry.def: An enzyme which causes cane sugar to take up a molecule of water and be converted into invert sugar.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Invested; p. pr. & vb. n. Investing
entry.ety: L. investire investitum; pref. in- in + vestire to clothe, fr. vestis clothing: cf. F. investir. See Vest

sn.def: To put garments on; to clothe; to dress; to array; -- opposed to divest. Usually followed by with, sometimes by in; as, to invest one with a robe.
To put on.
sn.q: Can not find one this girdle to invest.

sn.def: To clothe, as with office or authority; to place in possession of rank, dignity, or estate; to endow; to adorn; to grace; to bedeck; as, to invest with honor or glory; to invest with an estate.
sn.q: I do invest you jointly with my power.

sn.def: To surround, accompany, or attend.
sn.q: Awe such as must always invest the spectacle of the guilt.

sn.def: To confer; to give.
sn.q: It investeth a right of government.

sn.def: To inclose; to surround or hem in with troops, so as to intercept reinforcements of men and provisions and prevent escape; to lay siege to; as, to invest a town.
To lay out (money or capital) in business with the view of obtaining an income or profit; as, to invest money in bank stock.

To expend (time, money, or other resources) with a view to obtaining some benefit of value in excess of that expended, or to achieve a useful pupose; as, to invest a lot of time in teaching one's children.

entry.def: To make an investment; as, to invest in stocks; -- usually followed by in.

entry.ety: L. investiens, p. pr. of investire
entry.def: Covering; clothing.

entry.ety: L. investigabilis. See Investigate
entry.def: Capable or susceptible of being investigated; admitting research.

entry.ety: L. investigabilis. See In- not, and Vestigate
entry.def: Unsearchable; inscrutable.
entry.q: So unsearchable the judgment and so investigable the ways thereof.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Investigated; p. pr. & vb. n. Investigating
entry.ety: L. investigatus, p. p. of investigare to investigate; pref. in- in + vestigare to track, trace. See Vestige
entry.def: To follow up step by step by patient inquiry or observation; to trace or track mentally; to search into; to inquire and examine into with care and accuracy; to find out by careful inquisition; as, to investigate the causes of natural phenomena.
To pursue a course of investigation and study; to make investigation.
the work of inquiring into something thoroughly and systematically.

entry.ety: L. investigatio: cf. F. investigation
entry.def: The act of investigating; the process of inquiring into or following up; research; study; inquiry, esp. patient or thorough inquiry or examination; as, the investigations of the philosopher and the mathematician; the investigations of the judge, the moralist.
Given to investigation; inquisitive; curious; searching.

entry.ety: L.: cf. F. investigateur
entry.def: One who searches diligently into a subject.
Of or pertaining to an investigation; accomplished by investigation; designed to find information or ascertain facts; as, investigatory committee; the investigatory excesses of the prosecutor.
the act or process of expending resources, especially money, to achieve rewards.

entry.ety: LL. investitura: cf. F. investiture

sn.def: The act or ceremony of investing, or the state of being invested, as with an office; a giving possession; also, the right of so investing.
sn.q: He had refused to yield up to the pope the investiture of bishops.

sn.def: Livery of seizin.
sn.q: The grant of land or a feud was perfected by the ceremony of corporal investiture, or open delivery of possession.

sn.def: That with which anyone is invested or clothed; investment; clothing; covering.
sn.q: While we yet have on Our gross investiture of mortal weeds.

entry.def: Investing.

sn.def: The act of investing, or the state of being invested.
That with which anyone is invested; a vestment.
sn.q: Whose white investments figure innocence.

sn.def: The act of surrounding, blocking up, or besieging by an armed force, or the state of being so surrounded.
sn.q: The capitulation was signed by the commander of the fort within six days after its investments.

sn.def: The laying out of money in the purchase of some species of property; also, the amount of money invested, or that in which money is invested.
sn.q: Before the investment could be made, a change of the market might render it ineligible.
An investment in ink, paper, and steel pens.

entry.def: One who invests.
Investiture; investment.
To clothe; to invest; to install.
entry.q: Monks . . .investuredin their copes.

entry.ety: From Inveterate

sn.def: Firm establishment by long continuance; firmness or deep-rooted obstinacy of any quality or state acquired by time; as, the inveteracy of custom, habit, or disease; -- usually in a bad sense; as, the inveteracy of prejudice or of error.
sn.q: An inveteracy of evil habits that will prompt him to contract more.

sn.def: Malignity; spitefulness; virulency.
sn.q: The rancor of pamphlets, the inveteracy of epigrams, and the mortification of lampoons.

entry.ety: L. inveteratus, p. p. of inveterare to render old; pref. in- in + vetus veteris, old. See Veteran

sn.def: Old; long-established.
sn.q: It is an inveterate and received opinion.

sn.def: Firmly established by long continuance; obstinate; deep-rooted; of long standing; as, an inveterate disease; an inveterate abuse.
sn.q: Heal the inveterate canker of one wound.

sn.def: Having habits fixed by long continuance; confirmed; habitual; as, an inveterate idler or smoker.
Malignant; virulent; spiteful.

entry.def: To fix and settle by long continuance.
In an inveterate manner or degree.
entry.q: Inveteratelytough.

entry.def: Inveteracy.

entry.ety: L. inveteratio
entry.def: The act of making inveterate.

entry.ety: L. invictus. See In- not, and Victor
entry.def: Invincible.

entry.ety: L. invidiosus, fr. invidia envy. See Envy, and cf. Envious

sn.def: Envious; malignant.
Worthy of envy; desirable; enviable.
sn.q: Such a person appeareth in a far more honorable and invidious state than any prosperous man.

sn.def: Likely to or intended to incur or produce ill will, or to provoke envy or resentment; hateful; offensive; as, invidious distinctions.
sn.q: Agamemnon found it an invidious affair to give the preference to any one of the Grecian heroes.

entry.ety: in- not + vigilance: cf. OF. invigilance
entry.def: Lack of vigilance; neglect of watching; carelessness.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Invigilated ĭn*vĭj"ĭl*ā`tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Invigilating
entry.ety: L. invigilare to stay awake, to be vigilant
entry.def: To keep watch.

sn.def: To keep watch over examination candidates to prevent cheating.

entry.def: keeping watch over examination candidates to prevent cheating.
someone who watches examination candidates to prevent cheating.
To invigorate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Invigorated ĭn*vĭg"ẽr*ā`tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Invigorating
entry.ety: Pref. in- in + vigor
entry.def: To give vigor to; to strengthen; to animate; to give life and energy to.
entry.q: Christian graces and virtues they can not be, unless fed, invigorated, and animated by universal charity.

entry.def: The act of invigorating, or the state of being invigorated.
To render vile.
Turned into, or reduced to, a village.

entry.ety: Cf. F. invincibilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being invincible; invincibleness.

entry.ety: L. invincibilis: cf. F. invincible. See In- not, and Vincible
entry.def: Incapable of being conquered, overcome, or subdued; unconquerable; insuperable; as, an invincible army, or obstacle.
entry.q: Lead forth to battle these my sonsInvincible.

entry.ety: L. inviolabilitas: cf. F. inviolabilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being inviolable; inviolableness.

entry.ety: L. inviolabilis: cf. F. inviolable. See Inviolate a.

sn.def: Not violable; not susceptible of hurt, wound, or harm (used with respect to either physical or moral damage); not susceptible of being profaned or corrupted; sacred; holy; as, inviolable honor or chastity; an inviolable shrine.
sn.q: He tried a third, a tough, well-chosen spear, The inviolable body stood sincere.

sn.def: Unviolated; uninjured; undefiled; uncorrupted.
sn.q: For thou, be sure, shalt give account To him who sent us, whose charge is to keep This place inviolable, and these from harm.

sn.def: Not capable of being broken or violated; as, an inviolable covenant, agreement, promise, or vow.
sn.q: Their almighty Maker first ordained And bound them with inviolable bands.
And keep our faiths firm and inviolable.

entry.def: The quality or state of being inviolable; as, the inviolableness of divine justice.
Without violation.
The state or quality of being inviolate; as, the inviolacy of an oath.

entry.ety: L. inviolatus. See In- not, and Violate

sn.def: Not violated; uninjured; unhurt; unbroken.
sn.q: His fortune of arms was still inviolate.

sn.def: Not corrupted, defiled, or profaned; chaste; pure.
sn.q: Inviolatetruth.
There chaste Alceste lives inviolate.

entry.def: In an inviolate manner.
The state of being inviolate.

entry.ety: L. invius; pref. in- not + via way
entry.def: Untrodden.
Deficient in manhood; unmanly; effeminate.
Absence of virility or manhood; effeminacy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inviscated; p. pr. & vb. n. Inviscating
entry.ety: L. inviscatus, p. p. of inviscare to birdlime; pref. in- in + viscum viscus, the mistletoe, birdlime
entry.def: To daub or catch with glue or birdlime; to entangle with glutinous matter.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inviscerated; p. pr. & vb. n. Inviscerating
entry.ety: L. invisceratus, p. p. of inviscerare to put into the entrails. See Viscera
entry.def: To breed; to nourish.

entry.ety: L. invisceratus, p. p
entry.def: Deep-seated; internal.

entries.entry:
In*vis`i*bil"i*ty n.; pl.Invisibilities #. L. invisibilitas: cf. F. invisibilité
The state or quality of being invisible; also, that which is invisible. Atoms andinvisibilities.

cs.cd: a small, shy singing bird (Myadestes sibilons), of St. Vincent Islands.
a very dark shade of green, approaching to black, and liable to be mistaken for it.

entry.ety: F. invisible, L. invisibilis. See In- not, and Visible

sn.def: Incapable of being seen; not perceptible by vision; not visible.

sd.def: Not visible due to an inherent property, such as lack of color; as, the invisible air; invisible ink;
hidden from view; out of sight;
Not perceptible due to lack of light;
Too small or too distant to be perceived; as, people on the ground invisible at cruising altitude.
sd.q: To us invisible, or dimly seen In these thy lowest works.

sn.def: Hidden from the public; as, invisible transactions.
imperceptible to the mind; as, differences invisible to most observers.
An invisible person or thing; specifically, God, the Supreme Being.
A Rosicrucian; -- so called because avoiding declaration of his craft.
One of those (as in the 16th century) who denied the visibility of the church.

entry.def: A fluid that has no color in the visible spectrum, but may be detected under certain conditions, as under ultraviolet light. It may be used to write notes not readable under normal light.
The quality or state of being invisible; invisibility.
In an invisible manner.
Lack of vision or of the power of seeing.

entry.ety: L. invitatio: cf. F. invitation. See Invite

sn.def: The act of inviting; solicitation; the requesting of a person's company; as, an invitation to a party, to a dinner, or to visit a friend.
A document written or printed, or spoken words, conveying the message by which one is invited.
Allurement; enticement.
sn.q: She gives the leer of invitation.

entry.def: open only to persons issued an invitation; -- of gatherings, usually sports events; as, an invitational tournament.

entry.ety: L. invitatorius: cf. F. invitatoire
entry.def: Using or containing invitations.
entry.q: The “Venite” [Psalm xcv.], which is also called the invitatory psalm.

entries.entry:
In*vi"ta*to*ry n.; pl.Invitatories #. LL. invitatorium: cf. F. invitatoire
That which invites; specifically, the invitatory psalm, or a part of it used in worship.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Invited; p. pr. & vb. n. Inviting
entry.ety: L. invitare: cf. F. inviter. See Vie

sn.def: To ask; to request; to bid; to summon; to ask to do some act, or go to some place; esp., to ask to an entertainment or visit; to request the company of; as, to invite to dinner, or a wedding, or an excursion.
sn.q: So many guests invite as here are writ.
I invite his Grace of Castle Rackrent to reflect on this.

sn.def: To allure; to draw to; to tempt to come; to induce by pleasure or hope; to attract.
sn.q: To inveigle and invite the unwary sense.
Shady groves, that easy sleep invite.
There no delusive hope invites despair.

sn.def: To give occasion for; as, to invite criticism.
sn.syn: To solicit; bid; call; ask; summon; allure; attract; entice; persuade.

entry.def: To give invitation.
Invitation.
One who, or that which, invites.
Not vitiated.
Alluring; tempting; as, an inviting amusement or prospect.
entry.q: Nothing is so easy and inviting as the retort of abuse and sarcasm.

entry.def: Not admitting of being vitrified, or converted into glass.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Invocated; p. pr. & vb. n. Invocating
entry.ety: L. invocatus, p. p. of invocare. See Invoke
entry.def: To invoke; to call on, or for, in supplication; to implore.
entry.q: If Dagon be thy god, Go to his temple, invocate his aid.

entry.ety: F. invocation, L. invocatio

sn.def: The act or form of calling for the assistance or presence of some superior being; earnest and solemn entreaty; esp., prayer offered to a divine being.
sn.q: Sweet invocation of a child; most pretty and pathetical!
The whole poem is a prayer to Fortune, and the invocation is divided between the two deities.

sn.def: A call or summons; especially, a judicial call, demand, or order; as, the invocation of papers or evidence into court.

entry.def: Making or containing invocation; invoking.

entry.ety: F. envois things sent, goods forwarded, pl. of envoi a sending or things sent, fr. envoyer to send; cf. F. lettre d'envoi letter of advice of goods forwarded. See Envoy

sn.def: A written account of the particulars of merchandise shipped or sent to a purchaser, consignee, factor, etc., with the value or prices and charges annexed.
The lot or set of goods as shipped or received; as, the merchant receives a large invoice of goods.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Invoiced; p. pr. & vb. n. Invoicing
entry.def: To make a written list or account of, as goods to be sent to a consignee; to insert in a priced list; to write or enter in an invoice.
entry.q: Goods, wares, and merchandise imported from Norway, and invoiced in the current dollar of Norway.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Invoked; p. pr. & vb. n. Invoking
entry.ety: F. invoquer, L. invocare; pref. in- in, on + vocare to call, fr. vox voice. See Voice, and cf. Invocate
entry.def: To call on for aid or protection; to invite earnestly or solemnly; to summon; to address in prayer; to solicit or demand by invocation; to implore; as, to invoke the Supreme Being, or to invoke His and blessing.
entry.q: Go, my dread lord, to your great grandsire's tomb, . . . Invoke his warlike spirit.

entry.ety: Dim. of involucre, or involucrum: cf. F. involucelle
entry.def: A partial, secondary, or small involucre. See Illust. of Involucre.
Furnished with involucels.

entries.entry: ‖In`vo*lu*cel"lum n.; pl.Involucella #. NL See Involucel.

entry.ety: Cf. F. involucral
entry.def: Pertaining to, possessing, or like, an involucrum.
Having an involucre; involucred.

entry.ety: L. involucrum a covering, wrapper, fr. involvere to wrap up, envelop: cf. F. involucre. See Involve
entry.def: A whorl or set of bracts around a flower, umbel, or head.
A continuous marginal covering of sporangia, in certain ferns, as in the common brake, or the cup-shaped processes of the filmy ferns.
The peridium or volva of certain fungi. Called also involucrum.
Having an involucre, as umbels, heads, etc.
An involucel.

entries.entry:
‖In`vo*lu"crum n.; pl. L. Involucra #, E. Involucrums #. L. See Involucre
Bot See Involucre.
Zoöl A sheath which surrounds the base of the lasso cells in the Siphonophora.

entry.ety: From Involuntary
entry.def: In an involuntary manner; not voluntarily; not intentionally or willingly.
The quality or state of being involuntary; unwillingness; automatism.

entry.ety: L. involuntarius. See In- not, and Voluntary

sn.def: Not having will or the power of choice.
Not under the influence or control of the will; not voluntary; as, the involuntary movements of the body; involuntary muscle fibers.
Not proceeding from choice; done unwillingly; reluctant; compulsory; as, involuntary submission.

entry.ety: L. involutus, p. p. of involvere. See Involve

sn.def: Rolled inward from the edges; -- said of leaves in vernation, or of the petals of flowers in æstivation.

sd.def: Turned inward at the margin, as the exterior lip of the Cyprea.
Rolled inward spirally.

entry.def: A curve traced by the end of a string wound upon another curve, or unwound from it; -- called also evolvent. See Evolute.

entry.ety: L. involutio: cf. F. involution. See Involve

sn.def: The act of involving or infolding.
The state of being entangled or involved; complication; entanglement.
sn.q: All things are mixed, and causes blended, by mutual involutions.

sn.def: That in which anything is involved, folded, or wrapped; envelope.
The insertion of one or more clauses between the subject and the verb, in a way that involves or complicates the construction.
The act or process of raising a quantity to any power assigned; the multiplication of a quantity into itself a given number of times; -- the reverse of evolution.

The relation which exists between three or more sets of points, a.a' b.b' c.c', so related to a point O on the line, that the product Oa.Oa' = Ob.Ob' = Oc.Oc' is constant. Sets of lines or surfaces possessing corresponding properties may be in involution.
The return of an enlarged part or organ to its normal size, as of the uterus after pregnancy.

entry.usage: To Involve Imply. Imply is opposed to express, or set forth; thus, an implied engagement is one fairly to be understood from the words used or the circumstances of the case, though not set forth in form. Involve goes beyond the mere interpretation of things into their necessary relations; and hence, if one thing involves another, it so contains it that the two must go together by an indissoluble connection. War, for example, involves wide spread misery and death; the premises of a syllogism involve the conclusion.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Involved; p. pr. & vb. n. Involving
entry.ety: L. involvere involutum, to roll about, wrap up; pref. in- in + volvere to roll: cf. OF. involver. See Voluble, and cf. Involute

sn.def: To roll or fold up; to wind round; to entwine.
sn.q: Some of serpent kind . . . involved Their snaky folds.

sn.def: To envelop completely; to surround; to cover; to hide; to involve in darkness or obscurity.
sn.q: And leave a singèd bottom all involved With stench and smoke.

sn.def: To complicate or make intricate, as in grammatical structure.
sn.q: Involveddiscourses.

sn.def: To connect with something as a natural or logical consequence or effect; to include necessarily; to imply.
sn.q: He knows His end with mine involved.
The contrary necessarily involves a contradiction.

sn.def: To take in; to gather in; to mingle confusedly; to blend or merge.
sn.q: The gathering number, as it moves along,Involves a vast involuntary throng.
Earth with hell To mingle and involve.

sn.def: To envelop, infold, entangle, or embarrass; as, to involve a person in debt or misery.
To engage thoroughly; to occupy, employ, or absorb.
sn.q: Involvedin a deep study.

sn.def: To raise to any assigned power; to multiply, as a quantity, into itself a given number of times; as, a quantity involved to the third or fourth power.
sn.syn: To imply; include; implicate; complicate; entangle; embarrass; overwhelm.

entry.def: Same as Involute.
The state of being involved.
The act of involving, or the state of being involved.

entry.ety: Pref. in- in + vulgar
entry.def: To cause to become or appear vulgar.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + vulgar
entry.def: Not vulgar; refined; elegant.

entry.ety: Cf. F. invulnérabilité
entry.def: Quality or state of being invulnerable.

entry.ety: L. invulnerabilis: cf. F. invulnérable. See In- not, and Vulnerable

sn.def: Incapable of being wounded, or of receiving injury.
sn.q: Neither vainly hope To be invulnerable in those bright arms.

sn.def: Unanswerable; irrefutable; that can not be refuted or convinced; as, an invulnerable argument.

entry.def: Invulnerability.

entry.ety: L. invulneratus unwounded
entry.def: Invulnerable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Inwalled ĭn*w�ld"; p. pr. & vb. n. Inwalling
entry.def: To inclose or fortify as with a wall.
An inner wall; specifically Metal, the inner wall, or lining, of a blast furnace.

entry.ety: AS. inweard inneweard innanweard, fr. innan inne, within (fr. in in; see In) + the suffix -weard, E. -ward

sn.def: Being or placed within; inner; interior; -- opposed to outward.
Seated in the mind, heart, spirit, or soul.
sn.q: Inwardbeauty.

sn.def: Intimate; domestic; private.
sn.q: All my inward friends abhorred me.
He had had occasion, by one very inward with him, to know in part the discourse of his life.

sn.def: That which is inward or within; especially, in the plural, the inner parts or organs of the body; the viscera.
sn.q: Then sacrificing, laid the inwards and their fat.

sn.def: The mental faculties; -- usually pl.
An intimate or familiar friend or acquaintance.
sn.q: I was aninwardof his.

entry.ety: AS. inweard. The ending -s is prop. a genitive ending. See Inward a. -wards

sn.def: Toward the inside; toward the center or interior; as, to bend a thing inward .
Into, or toward, the mind or thoughts; inwardly; as, to turn the attention inward .
sn.q: So much the rather, thou Celestial Light, Shine inward.

entry.ety: AS. inweardlice

sn.def: In the inner parts; internally.
sn.q: Let Benedick, like covered fire, Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly.

sn.def: Toward the center; inward; as, to curve inwardly .
In the heart or mind; mentally; privately; secretly; as, he inwardly repines.
Intimately; thoroughly.
sn.q: I shall desire to know him more inwardly.

entry.def: moving or directed toward the center or axis, especially when spinning or traveling in a curve.

sn.def: Internal or true state; essential nature; as, the inwardness of conduct.
sn.q: Sense can not arrive to the inwardness Of things.

sn.def: Intimacy; familiarity.
Heartiness; earnestness.
sn.q: What was wanted was more inwardness, more feeling.

entry.def: See Inward.
To weave in or together; to intermix or intertwine by weaving; to interlace.
entry.q: Down they cast Their crowns, inwove with amaranth and gold.

entry.def: To encircle.
Inward sense; mind; understanding; conscience.
Within.
entry.q: This purse hath she inwith her bosom hid.

entry.ety: Pref. in- + work. Cf. Inwrought
entry.def: To work in or within.
Worn, wrought, or stamped in.

entry.ety: Written also enwrap

sn.def: To cover by wrapping; to involve; to infold; as, to inwrap in a cloak, in smoke, etc.
To involve, as in difficulty or perplexity; to perplex.

entry.def: To surround or encompass as with a wreath.
entry.q: Resplendent locks, inwreathed with beams.

entry.ety: Pref. in- + wrought. Cf. Inwork
entry.def: Wrought or worked in or among other things; worked into any fabric so as to from a part of its texture; wrought or adorned, as with figures.
entry.q: His mantle hairy, and his bonnet sedge,Inwrought with figures dim.

entries.entry:
I"o n.; pl.Ios #. L.; cf. Gr. "iw`
An exclamation of joy or triumph; -- often interjectional.

entry.ety: Gr. 'Iw`

sn.def: In Greek mythology, the beautiful daughter of Inachus, king of Argos, Greece, who was changed by Hera (Juno), in a fit of jealousy, into a white heifer, and placed under the watch of Argus of the hundred eyes. When Argus was killed by Hermes at the command of Zeus, the heifer was maddened by a terrible gadfly sent by Hera, and wandered about until she arrived in Egypt. There she recovered her original shape, and bore Epaphus to Zeus. Epaphus became the ancestor of Ægyptus, Damaus, Cepheus, and Phineus. She was identified by the Egyptians with Isis. According to another legend, Io was carried off by Phoenician traders who landed in Argos. The myth is generally explained to be Aah or the moon wandering in the starry skies, symbolized by the hundred-eyed Argus; her transformation into a horned heifer representing the crescent moon.
sn.q: Greek mythology, too, knew her [Astarte] as Iô and Europa, and she was fitly symbolised by the cow whose horns resemble the supine lunar crescent as seen in the south.

entries.entry: I"od-. Chem See Iodo-.

entry.ety: Iod- + alcohol
entry.def: An oily liquid, CI3.CHO, analogous to chloral and bromal.
A salt of iodic acid.

entry.ety: Iod- + chlorhydrin
entry.def: One of a series of compounds containing iodine, and analogous to the chlorhydrins.

cs.cd: a monobasic acid (HIO3), consisting of iodine with three parts of oxygen and one of hydrogen.

entry.ety: Cf. F. iodique. See Iodine
entry.def: Pertaining to, or containing, iodine; specif., denoting those compounds in which it has a relatively high valence; as, iodic acid.
A binary compound of iodine, or one which may be regarded as binary, in which iodine has a valence of -1; as, potassium iodide .
to cause to combine with iodine; as, iodinate thyroxine.

entry.note: The iodinating agent may be other than iodine itself, such as compounds with active iodine.
entry.def: treated or reacted with iodine; treated so as to combine with iodine.

entry.ety: p. p. of verb iodinate
entry.def: combining or causing to combine with iodine; as, the active iodinating species; the in vivo iodinating mechanism. Inverse of de-iodinating.
the substitution or addition of iodine atoms in organic compounds.

entry.note: ☞ Iodine was formerly obtained from the ashes of seaweed (kelp or varec), but is now also extracted from certain natural brines. In the free state, iodine, even in very minute quantities, colors starch blue. Iodine and its compounds are largely used in medicine (as in liniments, antisyphilitics, etc.), in photography, in the preparation of aniline dyes, and as an indicator in titration.

cs.cd: an artificial green dyestuff, consisting of an iodine derivative of rosaniline; -- called also night green.
a pigment of an intense scarlet color, consisting of mercuric iodide.
a brilliant yellow pigment, consisting of plumbic iodide.

entry.ety: Gr. 'iw`dhs violetlike; 'i`on a violet + e'i^dos form: cf. F. iode iodine. The name was given from the violet color of its vapor. See Violet Idyl
entry.def: A nonmetallic element, of the halogen group of atomic number 53, occurring always in combination, as in the iodides. When isolated it is in the form of dark gray metallic scales, resembling plumbago, soft but brittle, and emitting a chlorinelike odor. Symbol I. Atomic weight 126.90. If heated, iodine volatilizes in beautiful violet vapors.
A morbid state produced by the use of iodine and its compounds, and characterized by palpitation, depression, and general emaciation, with a pustular eruption upon the skin.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Iodized; p. pr. & vb. n. Iodizing
entry.def: To treat or impregnate with iodine or its compounds; as, to iodize a plate for photography.
Table salt to which an inorganic iodide compound has been added as a nutritional supplement to prevent goiter.
One who, or that which, iodizes.
A prefix, or combining from, indicating iodine as an ingredient; as, iodoform.
a compound containing the covalent iodine radical.

entry.ety: Iodo- + cresol
entry.def: Any of several isomeric iodine derivatives of the cresols, C6H3I(CH3)OH, esp. one, an odorless amorphous powder, used in medicine as a substitute for iodoform.

entry.ety: Iodo- + formyl. See Formyl, and cf. Chloroform
entry.def: A yellow, crystalline, volatile substance, CI3H, having an offensive odor and sweetish taste, and analogous to chloroform. It is used in medicine as a healing and antiseptic dressing for wounds and sores.

entry.ety: Iodoform + -gen root of gi`gnesqai to be born
entry.def: A light powder used as a substitute for iodoform. It is a compound of iodoform and albumin.

entry.ety: Iodo- + pyrrol
entry.def: A crystallized substance of the composition C4I4NH, technically tetra-iodo-pyrrol, used like iodoform.

entry.ety: Iodo- + quinine
entry.def: A iodide of quinine obtained as a brown substance,. It is the base of herapathite. See Herapathite.

entry.note: ☞ It is a very stable compound, and is believed to be active principle in thyroid extracts and in the internal secretion of the thyroid gland. It was originally called thyroiodin.
☞ It is probably an impure extract of thyroid gland, containing thyroxine. See Merck Index 11th Ed. #9345, the entry for thyroidin.
entry.ety: Iodo- + thyro- + -in
entry.def: A peculiar substance obtained from the thyroid gland, containing from nine to ten per cent of iodine.

cs.cd: a hypothetical acid, analogous to chlorous acid.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or containing, iodine. See -ouschemical suffix).
Iodide.

entry.ety: From Iodine
entry.def: Silver iodide, a mineral of a yellowish color.

entry.ety: Gr. 'i`on a violet + -lite
entry.def: A silicate of alumina, iron, and magnesia, having a bright blue color and vitreous luster; cordierite. It is remarkable for its dichroism, and is also called dichroite. A variety called Caribbean iolite has a lighter blue color.

entries.entry: I"o moth` ?; 115. Zoöl A large and handsome American moth (Hyperchiria Io), having a large, bright-colored spot on each hind wing, resembling the spots on the tail of a peacock. The larva is covered with prickly hairs, which sting like nettles.

-ion ?; 106. L. -io, acc. -ionem: cf. F. -ion
A noun suffix denoting act process result of an act or a process thing acted upon state, or condition; as, revolution, the act or process of revolving; construction, the act or process of constructing; a thing constructed; dominion, territory ruled over; subjection, state of being subject; dejection; abstraction.

entry.note: Thus, hydrochloric acid (HCl) dissociates, in aqueous solution, into the hydrogen ion, H+, and the chlorine ion, Cl-; ferric nitrate, Fe(NO3)3, yields the ferric ion, Fe+++, and nitrate ions, NO3- NO3- NO3-. When a solution containing ions is made part of an electric circuit, the cations move toward the cathode, the anions toward the anode. This movement is called migration, and the velocity of it differs for different kinds of ions. If the electromotive force is sufficient, electrolysis ensues: cations give up their charge at the cathode and separate in metallic form or decompose water, forming hydrogen and alkali; similarly, at the anode the element of the anion separates, or the metal of the anode is dissolved, or decomposition occurs. Aluminum and chlorine are elements prepared predominantly by such electrolysis, and depends on dissolving compounds in a solvent where the element forms ions. Electrolysis is also used in refining other metals, such as copper and silver. Cf. Anion Cation.
entry.ety: Gr. 'io`n, neut, of 'iw`n, p. pr. of 'ie`nai to go

sn.def: an atom or goup of atoms (radical) carrying an electrical charge. It is contrasted with neutral atoms or molecules, and free radicals. Certain compounds, such as sodium chloride, are composed of complementary ions in the solid (crystalline) as well as in solution. Others, notably acids such as hydrogen chloride, may occur as neutral molecules in the pure liquid or gas forms, and ionize almost completely in dilute aqueous solutions. In solutions (as in water) ions are frequently bound non-covalently with the molecules of solvent, and in that case are said to be solvated. According to the electrolytic dissociation theory, the molecules of electrolytes are divided into ions by water and other solvents. An ion consists of one or more atoms and carries one unit charges of electricity, 3.4 x 10-10 electrostatic units, or a multiple of this. Those which are positively electrified (hydrogen and the metals) are called cations; negative ions (hydroxyl and acidic atoms or groups) are called anions.

One of the small electrified particles into which the molecules of a gas are broken up under the action of the electric current, of ultraviolet and certain other rays, and of high temperatures. To the properties and behavior of ions the phenomena of the electric discharge through rarefied gases and many other important effects are ascribed. At low pressures the negative ions appear to be electrons; the positive ions, atoms minus an electron. At ordinary pressures each ion seems to include also a number of attached molecules. Ions may be formed in a gas in various ways.

entry.def: to add ions.
A region of Western Asia Minor colonized by the Ancient Greeks.

entry.ety: L. Ionius. See Ionic
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Ionia or the Ionians; Ionic.

def2.def: A native or citizen of Ionia.

entry.cs:
Ionic dialect Gr. Gram a dialect of the Greek language, used in Ionia. The Homeric poems are written in what is designated old Ionic, as distinguished from new Ionic, or Attic, the dialect of all cultivated Greeks in the period of Athenian prosperity and glory. Ionic foot. Pros See Ionic n., 1.
Ionic modeorIonian mode, Mus an ancient mode, supposed to correspond with the modern major scale of C. Ionic sect a sect of philosophers founded by Thales of Miletus, in Ionia. Their distinguishing tenet was, that water is the original principle of all things. Ionic type a kind of heavy-faced type (as that of the following line). ☞This is Nonpareil Ionic.
entry.ety: L. Ionicus, Gr. �, fr. � Ionia

sn.def: Of or pertaining to Ionia or the Ionians.

Pertaining to the Ionic order of architecture, one of the three orders invented by the Greeks, and one of the five recognized by the Italian writers of the sixteenth century. Its distinguishing feature is a capital with spiral volutes. See Illust. of Capital.

sd.def: A foot consisting of four syllables: either two long and two short, -- that is, a spondee and a pyrrhic, in which case it is called the greater Ionic; or two short and two long, -- that is, a pyrrhic and a spondee, in which case it is called the smaller Ionic.
A verse or meter composed or consisting of Ionic feet.

sn.def: The Ionic dialect; as, the Homeric Ionic .
Ionic type.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to ions; composed of ions, containing ions, or breaking down into ions when dissolved in a polar solvent; as, an ionic solution will conduct a current of electricity. Opposite of nonionic.

entry.ety: NL. Cf. Iodine
entry.def: A genus of violaceous plants, chiefly found in tropical America, some species of which are used as substitutes for ipecacuanha.

the process of converting neutral atoms or molecules into ions. The process may occur by dissolving an ionic substance in a dissociating solvent, such as water, or by adding or subtracting an electron to or from an atom or molecule. The latter process occurs, for example, in an electron beam in a mass spectrometer and by interaction of substances with ionizing radiation.

sn.def: to dissociate into ions, as by dissolution in water or another polar solvent.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ionized; p. pr. & vb. n. Ionizing
entry.def: To convert (an atom or molecule) into ions, e. g. by dissolving in water, by reaction with acid or alkali, or by interaction with ionizing radiation. See ionization.
converted totally or partly into ions. Opposite of nonionized and unionized.

entry.note: Such radiation is emitted by radioactive elements, or may be generated by highly energetic physical processes, as in stars. When absorbed by living tissue, ionizing radiation can cause mutation, cellular damage, or death.
entry.def: rays of rapidly moving subatomic particles, x-reys, or gamma rays, sufficiently energetic to cause ionization when absorbed by matter.

entry.ety: ion + -phore
entry.def: A compound that enhances transport of ions across cellular membranes, by binding them and carrying them across. As a class ionophores tend to be lipophilic in nature; each compound is usually specific for one or a small number of ions.

the outer region of the earth's atmosphere, beyond which is the exosphere; it contains a high concentration of free electrons and ions, and extends from about 50 miles to about 250 miles above the earth's surface, but the height shows daily and seasonal variation, and the composition of the particles in the ionosphere is also affected by events such as solar flares.

entries.entry: I"o*qua shell`. From the native name Zoöl The shell of a large Dentalium (Dentalium pretiosum), formerly used as shell money, and for ornaments, by the Indians of the west coast of North America.

cs.cd: iota written beneath a preceding vowel, as a, h, w,, -- done when iota is silent.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. 'iw^ta. See Jot

sn.def: The ninth letter of the Greek alphabet (ι) corresponding with the English i.

sn.ety: from iota being the smallest letter in the Greek alphabet
sn.def: A very small quantity or degree; a jot; a particle.
sn.q: They never depart an iota from the authentic formulas of tyranny and usurpation.

entry.ety: Gr. 'iotakismo`s a laying too much stress upon the iota (ι): cf. F. iotacisme. See Iota
entry.def: The frequent use of the sound of iota (that of English e in be), as among the modern Greeks; also, confusion from sounding ε, ι, η, υ, ει, etc., like ι.

entries.entry:
I O U I.O.U
ī" ō" ū". phonetic, from I owe you
A paper having on it these letters, with a sum named, and duly signed; -- in use in England as an acknowledgment of a debt, and taken as evidence thereof, but not amounting to a promissory note; a due bill.
I"o*was n. pl.; sing. Iowa. Ethnol A tribe of Indians which formerly occupied the region now included in the State of Iowa.

entry.def: An abbreviation of Ipecacuanha, and in more frequent use.

entry.ety: Pg. ipecacuanhacf. Sp. ipecacuana); fr. Braz. ipe-kaa-guena, prop., a creeping plant that causes vomiting
entry.def: The root of a Brazilian rubiaceous herb (Cephaëlis Ipecacuanha), largely employed as an emetic; also, the plant itself; also, a medicinal extract of the root. Many other plants are used as a substitutes; among them are the black or Peruvian ipecac (Psychotria emetica), the white ipecac (Ionidium Ipecacuanha), the bastard or wild ipecac (Asclepias Curassavica), and the undulated ipecac (Richardsonia scabra).
Hippocras.

entry.ety: NL. “Named, according to Linnæus, from Gr. 'i`ps 'ipo`s, a bindweed [which it is not], and "o`moios like.” Gray.
entry.def: A genus of twining plants with showy monopetalous flowers, including the morning-glory, the sweet potato, and the cypress vine.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by the oxidation of convolvulin (obtained from jalap, the tubers of Ipomœa purga), and identical in most of its properties with sebacic acid.
a battle between the successors of Alexander the Great301 BC); Lysimachus and Seleucus defeated Antigonus and Demetrius.
a measure of a person's intelligence as indicated by an intelligence test; the ratio of a person's mental age to their chronological age (multiplied by 100).
The chemical symbol for iridium, a metallic element of the platinum group. It has atomic number 77 and an atomic weight of 192.22.

entries.entry: Ir-. A form of the prefix in-. See In-.

entry.def: individual retirement account; -- a special type of savings account allowed by law to provide deferred taxation of the interest paid.

The Irish Republican Army, a group in Ireland with the primary goal of promoting the unification of Ireland and the severing of the political bond of Northern Ireland with Great Britain, of mostly secret membership, with a militant wing sponsoring terrorist activities such as bombings and the killings of police, British soldiers, and Unionist sympathizers in Northern Ireland.

entry.ety: L. iracundus, fr. ira anger
entry.def: Irascible; choleric.
entry.q: Iracundpeople.

entry.ety: Turk
entry.def: A decree of the Sultan.
same as Iraqi.

entry.ety: Mod. Persian Irān. Cf. Aryan
entry.def: The native name of Persia, the name adopted by the modern nation of Iran.
a native or inhabitant of Iran.
Of or pertaining to Iran.

def2.def: A native of Iran; also, the Iranian or Persian language, a division of the Aryan family of languages, the modern version of which is called Farsi.

entry.def: Iranian.
of or relating to Iraq or its people or culture; as, Iraqi oil; Iraqi terrorists.
a native or inhabitant of Iraq.

entry.ety: Cf. F. irascibilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being irascible; irritability of temper; irascibleness.

entry.ety: L. irascibilis, fr. irasci to be angry, ira anger: cf. F. irascible. See Ire
entry.def: Prone to anger; easily provoked or inflamed to anger; choleric; irritable; as, an irascible man; an irascible temper or mood.

entry.ety: L. iratus, fr. irasci to be angry. See Ire
entry.def: Angry; incensed; enraged.
entry.q: The irate colonel . . . stood speechless.
Mr. Jaggers suddenly became most irate.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. ira
entry.def: Anger; wrath.
entry.syn: Anger; passion; rage; fury. See Anger.

entry.def: Full of ire; angry; wroth.
entry.q: Theirefulbastard Orleans.

entry.def: Wrathfulness.

entry.ety: L. irenarcha irenarches, Gr. �; � peace + � to rule
entry.def: An officer in the Greek empire having functions corresponding to those of a justice of the peace.

entry.ety: Gr. �
entry.def: Fitted or designed to promote peace; pacific; conciliatory; peaceful.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. � peaceful, fr. � peace
entry.def: A proposition or device for securing peace, especially in the church.
That branch of Christian science which treats of the methods of securing unity among Christians or harmony and union among the churches; -- called also Irenical theology.
Any very hard rock.
Of or pertaining to the iris.
entry.q: Iriannerves.

entry.def: Irishism.

entry.ety: From NL. Iris Iridis, the Iris
entry.def: Pertaining to, or resembling, a large natural order of endogenous plants (Iridaceæ), which includes the genera Iris Ixia Crocus Gladiolus, and many others.

entry.ety: L. iris iridis, rainbow. See Iris
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the iris or rainbow; prismatic; as, the iridal colors.

entry.ety: Gr. �, �, iris + � cutting out; � out + te`mnein to cut
entry.def: The act or process of cutting out a portion of the iris in order to form an artificial pupil.

entry.ety: See Iridescent
entry.def: Exhibition of colors like those of the rainbow, especially a surface reflection which changes color with the angle at which the object is viewed; the quality or state of being iridescent; a prismatic play of color; as, the iridescence of mother-of-pearl. It is due to interference of light waves reflected from the front and back surfaces of a thin layer transpatrent or semitransparent film.

entry.ety: L. iris iridis, the rainbow: cf. F. iridescent
entry.def: Having colors like the rainbow; exhibiting a play of changeable colors; nacreous; prismatic; as, iridescent glass. See iridescence.
Of or pertaining to the iris or rainbow.
Iridescent.
Of or pertaining to the iris of the eye.
Of or pertaining to iridium; -- said specifically of those compounds in which iridium has a relatively high valence.

entry.ety: See Iris, and -scope
entry.def: A kind of ophthalmoscope.
Of or pertaining to iridium; -- applied specifically to compounds in which iridium has a low valence.

entry.note: ☞ Iridium usually occurs as a native alloy with osmium (iridosmine or osmiridium), which may occur alone or with platinum. Iridium, as an alloy with platinum, is used in bushing the vents of heavy ordnance. It is also used for the points of gold pens, and in a finely powdered condition (iridium black), for painting porcelain black.
entry.ety: NL., fr. L. iris iridis, the rainbow. So called from the iridescence of some of its solutions. See Iris
entry.def: A rare metallic element of atomic number 77, of the same group as platinum, which it much resembles, being silver-white and indifferent to most corrosive agents, but harder, more brittle, and with a higher melting temperature (2410° C, versus platinum 1772° C). With the exception of osmium, it is the heaviest substance known, its specific gravity being 22.4. Symbol Ir. Atomic weight 192.22.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Iridized; p. pr. & vb. n. Iridizing

sn.def: To point or tip with iridium, as a gold pen.
To make iridescent; as, to iridize glass.

entry.ety: Iridescent + L. oleum oil
entry.def: A nitrogenous base C10H9N, extracted from coal-tar naphtha, as an oily liquid. It is a member of the quinoline series, and is probably identical with lepidine.

entry.ety: Iridium + osmium
entry.def: The native compound of iridium and osmium. It is found in flattened metallic grains of extreme hardness, and is often used for pointing gold pens.

entries.entry:
I"ris n.; pl. E. Irises #, L. Irides #. L. iris iridis, the goddess, Gr. �, �, the rainbow, iris of the eye, the plant Iris. Cf. Orris
Class. Myth The goddess of the rainbow, and swift-footed messenger of the gods.
The rainbow.
An appearance resembling the rainbow; a prismatic play of colors.
Anat The contractile membrane perforated by the pupil, and forming the colored portion of the eye. See Eye.
Bot A genus of plants having showy flowers and bulbous or tuberous roots, of which the flower-de-luce (fleur-de-lis), orris, and other species of flag are examples. See Illust. of Flower-de-luce.
Her See Fleur-de-lis, 2.
Zoöl the inner circle of an oscillated color spot.
same as iris diaphragm.

entry.ety: See Iris
entry.def: Exhibiting the prismatic colors; irised; iridescent.

entry.ety: Iris + -scope
entry.def: A philosophical toy for exhibiting the prismatic tints by means of thin films.

entries.entry: I"ris di"a*phragm. An adjustable diaphragm, reminiscent of the iris of the eye in its action, by which the diameter of an approximately circular opening may be controlled, as for regulating the aperture of a lens; it consists of a number of movable thin curved plates fastened at regular intervals around the inside of a ring, the positions of which are simultaneously adjusted by a single knob on the outside of the lens. It is used in cameras and microscopes.

entry.ety: See Iris
entry.def: Having colors like those of the rainbow; iridescent.

entry.cs:
