Irish elk. Zoöl See under Elk. Irish moss. Bot Carrageen. A preparation of the same made into a blanc mange. Irish poplin. See Poplin. Irish potato the ordinary white potato, so called because it is a favorite article of food in Ireland.
Irish reeforIrishman's reef
Naut the head of a sail tied up. Irish stew meat, potatoes, and onions, cut in small pieces and stewed.
entry.ety: AS. īrisc, fr. īras the Irish. Cf. Aryan Erse
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Ireland or to its inhabitants; produced in Ireland.

cs.cd: to become angry.

sn.def: The natives or inhabitants of Ireland, esp. the Celtic natives or their descendants.
The language of the Irish; also called Irish Gaelic or the Hiberno-Celtic.
An old game resembling backgammon.

entries.entry: I"rish A*mer"i*can I"rish-A*mer"i*can . A native of Ireland who has become an American citizen; also, a child or descendant of such a person.

entry.def: A mode of speaking peculiar to the Irish; an Hibernicism.

entries.entry:
I"rish*man
Irishman's hurricane Naut a dead calm. Irishman's reef. Naut See Irish reef, under Irish a.
n.; pl.Irishmen. A man born in Ireland or of the Irish race; an Hibernian.

entry.def: The Celtic people of Ireland.
entry.q: The wholeIrishryof rebels.

entry.ety: NL. See Iris, and -itis
entry.def: An inflammation of the iris of the eye.

entry.ety: OE. irken to tire, become tired; cf. Sw. yrka to urge, enforce, press, or G. ekel disgust, MHG. erklich disgusting; perh. akin to L. urgere to urge, E. urge
entry.def: To weary; to give pain; to annoy.
entry.q: To see this sight, it irks my very soul.
It irketh him to be here.

entry.usage: Irksome Wearisome Tedious. These epithets describe things which give pain or disgust. Irksome is applied to something which disgusts by its nature or quality; as, an irksome task. Wearisome denotes that which wearies or wears us out by severe labor; as, wearisome employment. Tedious is applied to something which tires us out by the length of time occupied in its performance; as, a tedious speech.

sn.def: Wearisome; tedious; disagreeable or troublesome by reason of long continuance or repetition; as, irksome hours; irksome tasks.
sn.q: For not to irksome toil, but to delight, He made us.

sn.def: Weary; vexed; uneasy.
sn.q: Let us therefore learn not to be irksome when God layeth his cross upon us.
sn.syn: Wearisome; tedious; tiresome; vexatious; burdensome.
sn.q: Wearisome nights are appointed to me.
Pity only on fresh objects stays, But with the tedious sight of woes decays.

entry.note: ☞ The value of iron is largely due to the facility with which it can be worked. Thus, when heated it is malleable and ductile, and can be easily welded and forged at a high temperature. As cast iron, it is easily fusible; as steel, is very tough, and (when tempered) very hard and elastic. Chemically, iron is grouped with cobalt and nickel. Steel is a variety of iron containing more carbon than wrought iron, but less that cast iron. It is made either from wrought iron, by roasting in a packing of carbon (cementation) or from cast iron, by burning off the impurities in a Bessemer converter (then called Bessemer steel), or directly from the iron ore (as in the Siemens rotatory and generating furnace).
entry.cs:
Bar iron. See Wrought ironbelow). Bog iron bog ore; limonite. See Bog ore, under Bog. Cast iron Metal an impure variety of iron, containing from three to six percent of carbon, part of which is united with a part of the iron, as a carbide, and the rest is uncombined, as graphite. It there is little free carbon, the product is white iron; if much of the carbon has separated as graphite, it is called gray iron. See also Cast iron, in the Vocabulary. Fire irons. See under Fire n.
Gray irons. See under Fire n.
Gray iron. See Cast ironabove). It irons Naut said of a sailing vessel, when, in tacking, she comes up head to the wind and will not fill away on either tack. Magnetic iron. See Magnetite. Malleable iron Metal iron sufficiently pure or soft to be capable of extension under the hammer; also, specif., a kind of iron produced by removing a portion of the carbon or other impurities from cast iron, rendering it less brittle, and to some extent malleable. Meteoric iron Chem iron forming a large, and often the chief, ingredient of meteorites. It invariably contains a small amount of nickel and cobalt. Cf. Meteorite. Pig iron the form in which cast iron is made at the blast furnace, being run into molds, called pigs. Reduced iron. See under Reduced. Specular iron. See Hematite. Too many irons in the fire too many objects or tasks requiring the attention at once. White iron. See Cast ironabove). Wrought iron Metal the purest form of iron commonly known in the arts, containing only about half of one per cent of carbon. It is made either directly from the ore, as in the Catalan forge or bloomery, or by purifying (puddling) cast iron in a reverberatory furnace or refinery. It is tough, malleable, and ductile. When formed into bars, it is called bar iron.
entry.ety: OE. iren, AS. īren īsen īsern; akin to D. ijzer, OS. īsarn, OHG. īsarn īsan, G. eisen, Icel. īsarn jārn, Sw. & Dan. jern, and perh. to E. ice; cf. Ir. iarann, W. haiarn, Armor. houarn

sn.def: The most common and most useful metallic element, being of almost universal occurrence, usually in the form of an oxide (as hematite magnetite, etc.), or a hydrous oxide (as limonite turgite, etc.). It is reduced on an enormous scale in three principal forms; viz., cast iron steel, and wrought iron. Iron usually appears dark brown, from oxidation or impurity, but when pure, or on a fresh surface, is a gray or white metal. It is easily oxidized (rusted) by moisture, and is attacked by many corrosive agents. Symbol Fe (Latin Ferrum). Atomic number 26, atomic weight 55.847. Specific gravity, pure iron, 7.86; cast iron, 7.1. In magnetic properties, it is superior to all other substances.
An instrument or utensil made of iron; -- chiefly in composition; as, a flatiron, a smoothing iron, etc.
sn.q: My young soldier, put up your iron.

sn.def: Fetters; chains; handcuffs; manacles.
sn.q: Four of the sufferers were left to rot in irons.

sn.def: Strength; power; firmness; inflexibility; as, to rule with a rod of iron .
An iron-headed club with a deep face, chiefly used in making approaches, lifting a ball over hazards, etc.

entry.note: ☞ Iron is often used in composition, denoting made of iron relating to iron of or with iron; producing iron, etc.; resembling iron, literally or figuratively, in some of its properties or characteristics; as, iron-shod, iron-sheathed, iron-fisted, iron-framed, iron-handed, iron-hearted, iron foundry or iron-foundry.
entry.cs:
Iron age. Myth The age following the golden, silver, and bronze ages, and characterized by a general degeneration of talent and virtue, and of literary excellence. In Roman literature the Iron Age is commonly regarded as beginning after the taking of Rome by the Goths, A. D. 410. Archæol That stage in the development of any people characterized by the use of iron implements in the place of the more cumbrous stone and bronze. Iron cement a cement for joints, composed of cast-iron borings or filings, sal ammoniac, etc. Iron clay Min a yellowish clay containing a large proportion of an ore of iron. Iron cross a German, and before that Prussian, order of military merit; also, the decoration of the order. Iron crown a golden crown set with jewels, belonging originally to the Lombard kings, and indicating the dominion of Italy. It was so called from containing a circle said to have been forged from one of the nails in the cross of Christ. Iron flint Min an opaque, flintlike, ferruginous variety of quartz. Iron founder a maker of iron castings. Iron foundry the place where iron castings are made. Iron furnace a furnace for reducing iron from the ore, or for melting iron for castings, etc.; a forge; a reverberatory; a bloomery. Iron glance Min hematite. Iron hat a headpiece of iron or steel, shaped like a hat with a broad brim, and used as armor during the Middle Ages. Iron horse a locomotive engine. Colloq Iron liquor a solution of an iron salt, used as a mordant by dyers. Iron man Cotton Manuf a name for the self-acting spinning mule.
Iron moldorIron mould
a yellow spot on cloth stained by rusty iron. Iron ore Min any native compound of iron from which the metal may be profitably extracted. The principal ores are magnetite, hematite, siderite, limonite, Göthite, turgite, and the bog and clay iron ores. Iron pyrites Min common pyrites, or pyrite. See Pyrites. Iron sand an iron ore in grains, usually the magnetic iron ore, formerly used to sand paper after writing. Iron scale the thin film which forms on the surface of wrought iron in the process of forging. It consists essentially of the magnetic oxide of iron, Fe3O4. Iron works a furnace where iron is smelted, or a forge, rolling mill, or foundry, where it is made into heavy work, such as shafting, rails, cannon, merchant bar, etc.
entry.ety: AS. īren īsen. See Iron n.

sn.def: Of, or made of iron; consisting of iron; as, an iron bar, dust.
Resembling iron in color; as, iron blackness.

entry.sn:
Like iron in hardness, strength, impenetrability, power of endurance, insensibility, etc.; as: Rude; hard; harsh; severe.
Iron years of wars and dangers. Jove crushed the nations with an iron rod.
Firm; robust; enduring; as, an iron constitution.
Inflexible; unrelenting; as, an iron will.
Not to be broken; holding or binding fast; tenacious. Him death'sironsleep oppressed.

cs.cd: resolve differences; settle a dispute.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ironed; p. pr. & vb. n. Ironing

sn.def: To smooth with an instrument of iron; especially, to smooth, as cloth, with a heated flatiron; -- sometimes used with out.
To shackle with irons; to fetter or handcuff.
sn.q: Ironedlike a malefactor.

sn.def: To furnish or arm with iron; as, to iron a wagon.

entries.entry: I"ron*bark` I"ron*bark` tree` . Bot The Australian Eucalyptus Sideroxylon, used largely by carpenters and shipbuilders; -- called also ironwood. Also applied to other Australian eucalyptuses with a hard, solid bark

sn.def: Bound as with iron; rugged; as, an ironbound coast.
Rigid; unyielding; as, ironbound traditions.

entry.def: Cased or covered with iron, as a vessel; ironclad.

sn.def: Clad in iron; protected or covered with iron, as a vessel for naval warfare.
Rigorous; unbreakable; severe; exacting; inflexible; as, an ironclad oath or pledge.

entry.def: A naval vessel having the parts above water covered and protected by iron or steel usually in large plates closely joined and made sufficiently thick and strong to resist heavy shot. Modern naval vessels are made of steel throughout, and this term is only used in historical contexts.

sn.def: having an outer covering of iron or steel; as, an ironclad war vessel.
so strong or secure as to be unbreakable; as, an ironclad contract.

entry.def: A fragrant liquid substance, a mixture of several isomers of the formula C14H22O, forming the essence of the violet fragrance, commonly isolated from orris oil or from the rhizomes of Iris. The main ingredient in violets is α-irone, which occurs as both cis and trans stereoisomers. Called also 6-methylionone.
One who, or that which, irons.

sn.def: Closefisted; stingy; mean.
Ruthless; tyrranical; allowing no opposition; as, an iron-fisted tyrant.

entry.def: A famous gorge, about 11/2 miles long, cut by the Danube in the Carpathian mountains near the intersection of Hungary, Serbia, and Rumania.
Of a gray color, somewhat resembling that of iron freshly broken.

def2.def: An iron-gray color; also, a horse of this color.

entry.def: Same as gossan.
A European composite herb (Centaurea nigra); -- so called from the resemblance of its knobbed head to an iron ball fixed on a long handle.
Hard-hearted; unfeeling; cruel; as, an iron-hearted master.
A locomotive; -- an term no longer used.
Ironical.

entry.ety: LL. ironicus, Gr. � dissembling: cf. F. ironique. See Irony

sn.def: Pertaining to irony; containing, expressing, or characterized by, irony; as, an ironical remark.
Addicted to the use of irony; given to irony.

cs.cd: a flat board, upon which clothes are laid while being ironed.

sn.def: The act or process of smoothing, as clothes, with hot flatirons.
The clothes ironed.

entry.def: Resembling iron, as in taste.
One who uses irony.

A steel chamber, usually cylindrical, enclosing the entire body of a person except for the head, used to assist respiration for people suffering from disease, especially poliomyelitis. A reciprocating piston at the end causes alternating high and low pressure inside, which forces or assists the breathing of the patient within.

An instrument of torture used in the middle ages, consisting of a box large enough to hold a person, often in the shape of a woman, and having multiple sharp spikes on the inside. Called also the iron maiden of Nuremberg.
A manufacturer of iron, or large dealer therein.
A dealer in iron or hardware.
Hardware; a general name for all articles made of iron.

Able to be attached (to clothing) by applying pressure and heat, as with a hand iron; -- of cloth items specially made with a glue that is softened by heat; -- used especially of patches to clothing or accessories to clothing, such as replacement pockets.
Any of the oxides of iron, especially ferric oxide.
Having the ironwork loose or corroded; -- said of a ship when her bolts and nails are so eaten with rust that she has become leaky.
The the process of deterioration afflicting a ship that is iron-sick.
a man of great strength and endurance, especially on who is brave.

sn.def: A nickname for Oliver Cromwell.
A nickname for Edmund II of England.

entry.def: Having iron sides, or very firm sides.

entry.cs: Old Ironsides. U. S. Hist A nickname for the U.S.S. Constitution, a sailing ship which fought in the American Revolutionary war, and now functions as a floating museum in Boston harbor. It was given its nickname because cannonballs bounced off its hard wooden sides.
entry.def: A cuirassier or cuirassiers; also, hardy veteran soldiers; -- applied specifically to Cromwell's cavalry.

sn.def: A worker in iron; one who makes and repairs utensils of iron; a blacksmith.
An East Indian barbet (Megalaima faber), inhabiting the Island of Hainan. The name alludes to its note, which resembles the sounds made by a smith.

entry.cs: Clay ironstone. See under Clay. Ironstone china a hard white pottery, first made in England during the 18th century.

sn.def: A hard, earthy ore of iron.
ironstone china.

entry.def: Articles made of iron, as household utensils, tools, and the like.
A tall weed with purplish flowers (Vernonia Noveboracensis). The name is also applied to other plants of the same genus.

entry.note: ☞ In the United States, the hornbeam and the hop hornbeam are so called; also the Olneya Tesota, a small tree of Arizona; in the West Indies, the Erythroxylon areolatum, and several other unrelated trees; in China, the Metrosideros vera; in India, the Mesua ferrea, and two species of Inga; in Australia, the Eucalyptus Sideroxylon, and in many countries, species of Sideroxylon and Diospyros, and many other trees.
entry.def: A tree unusually hard, strong, or heavy wood.
Anything made of iron; -- a general name of such parts or pieces of a building, vessel, carriage, etc., as consist of iron.

entries.entry: I"ron works`. See under Iron a.

entry.def: An herb of the Mint family (Sideritis), supposed to heal sword cuts; also, a species of Galeopsis.

entry.ety: From Iron

sn.def: Made or consisting of iron; partaking of iron; iron; as, irony chains; irony particles; -- In this sense iron is the more common term.
Resembling iron in taste, hardness, or other physical property.

entry.ety: L. ironia, Gr. � dissimulation, fr. � a dissembler in speech, fr. � to speak; perh. akin to E. word: cf. F. ironie

sn.def: Dissimulation; ignorance feigned for the purpose of confounding or provoking an antagonist.
A sort of humor, ridicule, or light sarcasm, which adopts a mode of speech the meaning of which is contrary to the literal sense of the words.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A powerful and warlike confederacy of Indian tribes, formerly inhabiting Central New York and constituting most of the Five Nations. Also, any Indian of the Iroquois tribes.

Of, pertaining to, or designating, one of the principal linguistic stocks of the North American Indians. The territory of the northern Iroquoian tribes, of whom the Five Nations, or Iroquois proper, were the chief, extended from the shores of the St. Lawrence and of Lakes Huron, Ontario, and Erie south, through eastern Pennsylvania, to Maryland; that of the southern tribes, of whom the Cherokees were chief, formed part of Virginia, the Carolinas, Georgia, Tennessee, and Kentucky. All of the tribes were agricultural, and they were noted for large, communal houses, palisaded towns, and ability to organize, as well as for skill in war.

def2.def: An Indian of an Iroquoian tribe.

entry.ety: OF. iros, from ire. See Ire
entry.def: Irascible; passionate.

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain
entry.def: A fantastic grimace or contortion of the body.
entry.q: Smirks and irps and all affected humors.

entry.def: Making irps.

entry.ety: From irradiant

sn.def: The act of irradiating; emission of rays of light.
That which irradiates or is irradiated; luster; splendor; irradiation; brilliancy.

entry.ety: L. irradians -antis, p. pr. See Irradiate
entry.def: Irradiating or illuminating; as, the irradiant moon.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Irradiated ĭr*rā"dĭ*ā`tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Irradiating ĭr*rā"dĭ*ā`tĭng
entry.ety: L. irradiatus, p. p. of irradiate. See In- in, and Radiate

sn.def: To throw rays of light upon; to illuminate; to brighten; to adorn with luster.
sn.q: Thy smile irradiates yon blue fields.

sn.def: To enlighten intellectually; to illuminate; as, to irradiate the mind.
To animate by heat or light.
To radiate, shed, or diffuse.
sn.q: A splendid façade, . . . irradiating hospitality.

sn.def: To expose to radiation of any kind, especially ionizing radiation; as, to sterilize food by irradiating it with gamma rays; one can cause mutations in bacteria by irradiating them with ultraviolet light.

entry.def: To emit rays; to shine.

entry.ety: L. irradiatus, p. p
entry.def: Illuminated; irradiated.

entry.ety: Cf. F. irradiation

sn.def: Act of irradiating, or state of being irradiated; as, irradiation of foods with X-rays can preserve their freshness by killing the bacteria that cause spoilage .
Illumination; irradiance; brilliancy.
Fig.: Mental light or illumination.

The apparent enlargement of a bright object seen upon a dark ground, due to the fact that the portions of the retina around the image are stimulated by the intense light; as when a dark spot on a white ground appears smaller, or a white spot on a dark ground larger, than it really is, esp. when a little out of focus.

entry.def: To root deeply.

entry.ety: L. irrationalis: cf. F. irrationnel. See In- not, and Rational

sn.def: Not rational; void of reason or understanding; as, brutes are irrational animals.
Not according to reason; having no rational basis; clearly contrary to reason; easily disproved by reasoning; absurd; -- of assertions and beliefs.
foolish; unreasonable.
sn.q: It seemed utterly irrational any longer to maintain it.

sn.def: Not capable of being exactly expressed by an integral number, nor by a ratio of integral numbers; surd; -- said especially of roots. See Surd.
sn.syn: Absurd; foolish; preposterous; unreasonable; senseless. See Absurd.

entry.def: The quality or state of being irrational; absence of rationality.
entry.q: Brutishirrationaliity.

entry.def: In an irrational manner.
Irrationality.
Incapable of being rebutted.
Not receiving; incapable of receiving.
Incapable of being reclaimed.

entry.ety: Pref. in- not + recognition
entry.def: A failure to recognize; absence of recognition.
Not recognizable; unrecognizable.
The quality or state of being irreconcilable; irreconcilableness.

entry.ety: Pref. ir- not + reconcilable: cf. F. irréconciliable
entry.def: Not reconcilable; not able to be reconciled or brought into accord; implacable; incompatible; inconsistent; disagreeing; as, irreconcilable enemies, statements.
To prevent from being reconciled; to alienate or disaffect.
The state or quality of being unreconciled; disagreement.
Lack of reconciliation; disagreement.

entry.ety: Pref. ir not + record: cf. L. irrecordabilis not to be remembered
entry.def: Not fit or possible to be recorded.
Not capable of being recovered, regained, or remedied; irreparable; as, an irrecoverable loss, debt, or injury.
entry.q: That which is past is gone and irrecoverable.
entry.syn: Irreparable; irretrievable; irremediable; unalterable; incurable; hopeless.

entry.ety: L. irrecuperabilis: cf. OF. irrecuperable. See In- not, and Recuperate
entry.def: Irrecoverable.
Incurable.

entry.ety: L. irrecusabilis; pref. ir not + recusabilis that should be rejected, fr. recusare to reject: cf. F. irrécusable
entry.def: Not liable to exception or rejection.
The state or quality of being irredeemable; irredeemableness.

Not redeemable; that can not be redeemed; not payable in gold or silver, as a bond; -- used especially of such government notes, issued as currency, as are not convertible into coin at the pleasure of the holder.
A region that is related ethnically or historically to one country but is controlled politically by another.
the doctrine that irredenta should be controlled by the country to which they are ethnically or historically related.
an advocate of irredentism, especially a person in one country who advocates the incorporation of a region in another country related historically to his country.
The state or quality of being irreducible.

cs.cd: a particular case in the solution of a cubic equation, in which the formula commonly employed contains an imaginary quantity, and therefore fails in its application.

sn.def: Incapable of being reduced, or brought into a different state; incapable of restoration to its proper or normal condition; as, an irreducible hernia.
Incapable of being reduced to a simpler form of expression; as, an irreducible formula.

entry.def: Lack of reflection.
Not reflective.
Incapable of being reformed; incorrigible.
The quality or state of being irrefragable; incapability of being refuted.

entry.ety: F. irréfragable, L. irrefragabilis. See Refragable
entry.def: Not refragable; not to be gainsaid or denied; not to be refuted or overthrown; irrefutable; unanswerable; incontestable; undeniable; as, an irrefragable argument; irrefragable evidence.
entry.syn: Incontrovertible; unanswerable; indisputable; unquestionable; incontestable; indubitable; undeniable; irrefutable.

entry.def: The quality or state of being irrefrangible; irrefrangibleness.
Not refrangible; that can not be refracted in passing from one medium to another.

entry.ety: L. irrefutabilis: cf. F. irréfutable. See Refute
entry.def: Incapable of being refuted or disproved; indisputable.
Unregeneracy.
An unregenerate state.

entry.ety: Pref. ir- not + regular: cf. F. irrégulier
entry.def: Not regular; not conforming to a law, method, or usage recognized as the general rule; not according to common form; not conformable to nature, to the rules of moral rectitude, or to established principles; not normal; unnatural; immethodical; unsymmetrical; erratic; no straight; not uniform; as, an irregular line; an irregular figure; an irregular verse; an irregular physician; an irregular proceeding; irregular motion; irregular conduct, etc. Cf. Regular.
entry.q: Mazes intricate, Eccentric, intervolved, yet regular Then most when most irregular they seem.
Leading the men of Herefordshire to fight Against the irregular and wild Glendower.
A flowery meadow through which a clear stream murmured in many irregular meanders.
entry.syn: Immethodical; unsystematic; abnormal; unnatural; anomalous; erratic; devious; crooked; eccentric; unsettled; uneven; variable; changeable; mutable; desultory; disorderly; wild; immoderate; intemperate; inordinate; vicious.

entry.def: One who is not regular; especially, a soldier not in regular service.
One who is irregular.

entries.entry:
Ir*reg`u*lar"i*ty n.; pl.Irregularities #. Cf. F. irrégularité
The state or quality of being irregular; that which is irregular.

entry.def: In an irregular manner.
To make irregular; to disorder.
Lawless.
That can not be rejected; irresistible.
Not liable to relapse; secure.
Irrelative; unconnected.
The quality or state of being irrelative; lack of connection or relation.

cs.cd: those having no common tone.
the multiplication of parts that serve for a common purpose, but have no mutual dependence or connection.

entry.def: Not relative; without mutual relations; unconnected.
Irrelevancy.
The quality or state of being irrelevant; as, the irrelevancy of an argument.
Not relevant; not applicable or pertinent; not bearing upon or serving to support; foreign; extraneous; as, testimony or arguments irrelevant to a case.
Not admitting relief; incurable; hopeless.

entry.ety: L. irreligio: cf. F. irréligion. See In- not, and Religion
entry.def: The state of being irreligious; lack of religion; impiety.
One who is irreligious.

entry.ety: L. irreligiosus: cf. F. irréligieux

sn.def: Destitute of religion; not controlled by religious motives or principles; ungodly. Cf. Impious.
sn.q: Shame and reproach are generally the portion of the impious and irreligious.

sn.def: Indicating a lack of religion; profane; wicked; as, irreligious speech.

entry.def: In an irreligious manner.
The state or quality of being irreligious; ungodliness.

entry.ety: L. irremeabilis; pref. ir- not + remeabilis returning, fr. remeare: cf. F. irréméable. See Remeant
entry.def: Admitting no return; as, an irremeable way.

entry.ety: L. irremediabilis: cf. F. irrémédiable. See In- not, and Remediable
entry.def: Not to be remedied, corrected, or redressed; incurable; as, an irremediable disease or evil.
The state or quality of being irremediable.
In a manner, or to a degree, that precludes remedy, cure, or correction.

entry.ety: L. irremissibilis: cf. F. irrémissible. See In- not, and Remissible
entry.def: Not remissible; unpardonable; as, irremissible crimes.
Refusal of pardon.
Not remitting; unforgiving.
Not capable of being remitted; irremissible.
The quality or state of being irremovable; immovableness.
Not removable; immovable; inflexible.
Absence of removal.

entry.ety: L. irremunerabilis: cf. F. irrémunérable. See Remunerate
entry.def: Not remunerable; not capable of remuneration.
Not renowned.

entry.ety: Cf. F. irréparabilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being irreparable; irreparableness.

entry.ety: L. irreparabilis: cf. F. irréparable. See In- not, and Reparable
entry.def: Not reparable; not capable of being repaired, recovered, regained, or remedied; irretrievable; irremediable; as, an irreparable breach; an irreparable loss.
Quality of being irreparable.
In an irreparable manner.
The quality or state of being irrepealable.
Not repealable; not capable of being repealed or revoked, as a law.
Lack of repentance; impenitence.
Not capable of being replevied.

entry.ety: L. irreprehensibilis: cf. F. irrépréhensible. See Reprehensible
entry.def: Not reprehensible; blameless; innocent.
Not capable of being represented or portrayed.
Not capable of being repressed, restrained, or controlled; as, irrepressible joy; an irrepressible conflict.
In a manner or to a degree that can not be repressed.

entry.ety: Pref. ir- not + reproachable: cf. F. irréprochable
entry.def: Not reproachable; above reproach; not deserving reproach; blameless.
entry.q: He [Berkely] erred, -- and who is free from error? -- but his intentions were irreproachable.

entry.def: The quality or state of being irreproachable; integrity; innocence.
In an irreproachable manner; blamelessly.
Incapable of being justly reproved; irreproachable; blameless; upright.

entry.ety: L. irrepere irreptum, to creep in; pref. ir- in + repere to creep
entry.def: Surreptitious; spurious.
Disreputable.
Not resilient; not recoiling or rebounding; inelastic.
Nonresistance; passive submission.

entry.ety: Cf. F. irrésistibilité
entry.def: The quality or state of being irresistible, irresistibleness.

entry.ety: Pref. ir- not + resistible: cf. F. irrésistible
entry.def: That can not be successfully resisted or opposed; superior to opposition; resistless; overpowering; as, an irresistible attraction.
entry.q: An irresistible law of our nature impels us to seek happiness.

entry.def: Quality of being irresistible.
In an irresistible manner.
Irresistible.

entry.ety: L. irresolubilis: cf. F. irrésoluble. See Resoluble, and cf. Irresolvable

sn.def: Incapable of being dissolved or resolved into parts; insoluble.
Incapable of being relieved or assisted.
sn.q: The second is in the irresoluble condition of our souls after a known sin committed.

entry.def: The state or quality of being irresoluble; insolubility.

entry.ety: Pref. ir- not + resolute: cf. F. irrésolu, L. irresolutus not loosened
entry.def: Not resolute; not decided or determined; wavering; given to doubt or irresolution.
entry.q: Weak and irresolute is man.
entry.syn: Wavering; vacillating; undetermined; undecided; unsettled; fickle; changeable; inconstant.

entry.def: the failure to behave in a resolute manner; fluctuation in intention.

entry.ety: Cf. F. irrésolution
entry.def: Lack of resolution; lack of decision in purpose; a fluctuation of mind, as in doubt, or between hope and fear; irresoluteness; indecision; vacillation.
entry.q: Irresolution on the schemes of life which offer themselves to our choice, and inconstancy in pursuing them, are the greatest causes of all unhappiness.

entry.def: The quality of being irresolvable; irresolvableness.

cs.cd: nebulæ of a cloudlike appearance, which have not yet been resolved by the telescope into stars, and are often distant galaxies. See galaxy2}.

entry.ety: Pref. ir- not + resolvable. Cf. Irresoluble
entry.def: Incapable of being resolved; not separable into component parts.
The quality or state of being irresolvable; irresolvability.
Without settled determination; in a hesitating manner; doubtfully.

cs.cd: regardless of; without regard to; as, irrespective of differences.

sn.def: Without regard for conditions, circumstances, or consequences; unbiased; independent; impartial; as, an irrespective judgment.
sn.q: According to this doctrine, it must be resolved wholly into the absolute, irrespective will of God.

sn.def: Disrespectful.

entry.def: Without regard to conditions; not taking circumstances into consideration.
entry.q: Prosperity, considered absolutely and irrespectively, is better and more desirable than adversity.

entry.ety: L. irrespirabilis: cf. F. irrespirable. See Respirable
entry.def: Unfit for respiration; not having the qualities necessary to support animal life; as, irrespirable air.

entry.ety: Cf. F. irresponsabilité

sn.def: Lack of, or freedom from, responsibility or accountability.
A trait causing one to act without a proper sense of responsibility; acting without giving proper weight to one's responsibilities.

entry.ety: Pref. ir- not + responsible: cf. F. irresponsable

sn.def: Not responsible; not liable or able to answer for consequences; innocent.
Not to be trusted; unreliable; lacking a proper sense of responsibility.

entry.def: the habitual failure to behave in a responsible manner; irresponsibility.

sn.def: So as not to be responsible.
In an irresponsible{2} manner; without due care or diligence.

entry.def: Not responsive; not able, ready, or inclined to respond.
Incapable of being resuscitated or revived.
Lack of retaining power; forgetfulness.
Not retentive; as, an irretentive memory.
Incapable of being retraced; not retraceable.

sn.def: Not retractile.
Not tractile or ductile.

entry.def: Not retrievable; irrecoverable; irreparable; as, an irretrievable loss.
The state or quality of being irretrievable.
In an irretrievable manner.
Not to be returned.
Incapable of being revealed.

entry.ety: L. irreverentia: cf. F. irrévérence
entry.def: The state or quality of being irreverent; lack of proper reverence; disregard of the authority and character of a superior.
Irreverent.
entry.q: Immodest speech, or irreverend gesture.

entry.ety: L. irreverens -entis: cf. F. irrévérent. See In- not, and Reverent
entry.def: Not reverent; showing a lack of reverence; expressive of a lack of veneration; as, an irreverent babbler; an irreverent jest.
In an irreverent manner.
The state or quality of being irreversible; irreversibleness.

sn.def: Incapable of being reversed or turned about or back; incapable of being made to run backward; as, an irreversible engine; an irreversible process; an irreversible reaction.
Incapable of being reversed, recalled, repealed, or annulled; as, an irreversible sentence or decree.
sn.q: This rejection of the Jews, as it is not universal, so neither is it final and irreversible.
sn.syn: Irrevocable; irrepealable; unchangeable.

entry.def: The state or quality of being irreversible.

entries.entry: Ir`re*vers"i*ble steering gear. Mach A steering gear, esp. for an automobile, not affected by the road wheels, as when they strike an obstacle side ways, but easily controlled by the hand wheel or steering lever.

entry.def: In an irreversible manner.

entry.ety: Cf. F. irrévocabilité
entry.def: The state or quality of being irrevocable; irrevocableness.

entry.ety: L. irrevocabilis: cf. F. irrévocable. See In- not, and Revoke, and cf. Irrevocable
entry.def: Incapable of being recalled or revoked; unchangeable; irreversible; unalterable; as, an irrevocable promise or decree; irrevocable fate.
entry.q: Firm and irrevocable is my doom.

entry.ety: Pref. ir- not + revoke
entry.def: Irrevocable.
That has no finite period of revolution; not revolving.
entry.q: The dateless and irrevoluble circle of eternity.

entry.def: Not rhetorical.
See irredenta irredentism irredentist.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Irrigated; p. pr. & vb. n. Irrigating
entry.ety: L. irrigatus, p. p. of irrigare to irrigate: ir- in + rigare to water; prob. akin to E. rain. See Rain

sn.def: To water; to wet; to moisten with running or dropping water; to bedew.
To water, as land, by causing a stream to flow upon, over, or through it, as in artificial channels.
To rinse (a wound, infected area, etc.) with a flow or spray of a liquid.

entry.ety: L. irrigatio: cf. F. irrigation
entry.def: The act or process of irrigating, or the state of being irrigated; especially, the operation of causing water to flow over lands, for nourishing plants.

entry.ety: L. irriguus. See Irrigate

sn.def: Watered; watery; moist; dewy.
sn.q: The flowery lap Of some irriguous valley spreads her store.

sn.def: Gently penetrating or pervading.

entry.ety: Pref. ir- not + risible. See Irrision
entry.def: Not risible.

entry.ety: L. irrisio, fr. irridere irrisum, to laugh at; pref. ir- in + ridere to laugh: cf. F. irrision
entry.def: The act of laughing at another; derision.
entry.q: This being spoken scepticè, or by way of irrision.

entry.ety: L. irritabilitas: cf. F. irritabilité

sn.def: The state or quality of being irritable; quick excitability; petulance; fretfulness; as, irritability of temper.

A natural susceptibility, characteristic of all living organisms, tissues, and cells, to the influence of certain stimuli, response being manifested in a variety of ways, -- as that quality in plants by which they exhibit motion under suitable stimulation; esp., the property which living muscle possesses, of responding either to a direct stimulus of its substance, or to the stimulating influence of its nerve fibers, the response being indicated by a change of form, or contraction; contractility.
A condition of morbid excitability of an organ or part of the body; undue susceptibility to the influence of stimuli. See Irritation n., 3.

entry.ety: L. irritabilis: cf. F. irritable. See Irritate

sn.def: Capable of being irritated.
Very susceptible of anger or passion; easily inflamed or exasperated; as, an irritable temper.
sn.q: Vicious, old, and irritable.

sn.def: Endowed with irritability; susceptible of irritation; capable of being excited to action by the application of certain stimuli.
Susceptible of irritation; unduly sensitive to irritants or stimuli. See Irritation n., 3.
sn.syn: Excitable; irascible; touchy; fretful; peevish.

entry.def: Irritability.
In an irritable manner.

entry.ety: From 1st Irritant
entry.def: The state or quality of being null and void; invalidity; forfeiture.

entry.ety: From 2d Irritant
entry.def: The state or quality of being irritant or irritating.

entry.ety: LL. irritants -antis, p. pr. of irritare to make null, fr. L. irritus void; pref. ir- not + ratus established
entry.def: Rendering null and void; conditionally invalidating.
entry.q: The states elected Harry, Duke of Anjou, for their king, with this clause irritant; that, if he did violate any part of his oath, the people should owe him no allegiance.

entry.ety: L. irritans -antis, p. pr. of irritare: cf. F. irritant. See Irritate to excite
entry.def: Irritating; producing irritation or inflammation.

entry.cs: Counter irritant. See under Counter. Pure irritant Toxicology a poison that produces inflammation without any corrosive action upon the tissues.
entry.ety: Cf. F. irritant

sn.def: That which irritates or excites.
Any agent by which irritation is produced; as, a chemical irritant; a mechanical or electrical irritant.
A poison that produces inflammation.

entry.ety: See 1 st Irritant
entry.def: To render null and void.

entry.usage: To Irritate Provoke Exasperate. These words express different stages of excited or angry feeling. Irritate denotes an excitement of quick and slightly angry feeling which is only momentary; as, irritated by a hasty remark. To provoke implies the awakening of some open expression of decided anger; as, a provoking insult. Exasperate denotes a provoking of anger at something unendurable. Whatever comes across our feelings irritates; whatever excites anger provokes; whatever raises anger to a high point exasperates. “Susceptible and nervous people are most easily irritated; proud people are quickly provoked; hot and fiery people are soonest exasperated.” Crabb.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Irritated; p. pr. & vb. n. Irritating
entry.ety: L. irritatus, p. p. of irritare. Of doubtful origin

sn.def: To increase the action or violence of; to heighten excitement in; to intensify; to stimulate.
sn.q: Cold maketh the spirits vigorous and irritateth them.

sn.def: To excite anger or displeasure in; to provoke; to tease; to exasperate; to annoy; to vex; as, the insolence of a tyrant irritates his subjects.
sn.q: Dismiss the man, nor irritate the god: Prevent the rage of him who reigns above.

sn.def: To produce irritation in; to stimulate; to cause to contract. See Irritation n., 2.
To make morbidly excitable, or oversensitive; to fret; as, the skin is irritated by friction; to irritate a wound by a coarse bandage.
sn.syn: To fret; inflame; excite; provoke; tease; vex; exasperate; anger; incense; enrage.

entry.def: Excited; heightened.
aroused to impatience or anger; as, made an irritated gesture.

sn.def: causing annoyance.
sn.syn: annoying, galling, chafing, nettlesome, pesky, pestiferous, pestilent, plaguy, plaguey, teasing, vexatious, vexing.

sn.def: causing irritation of living tissue; -- used of physical stimuli.
sn.syn: irritant, irritative.

sn.def: causing pain or physical discomfort; as, an irritating burr under his stocking.
sn.syn: painful.

entry.ety: L. irritatio: cf. F. irritation

sn.def: The act of irritating, or exciting, or the state of being irritated; excitement; stimulation, usually of an undue and uncomfortable kind; especially, excitement of anger or passion; provocation; annoyance; anger.
sn.q: The whole body of the arts and sciences composes one vast machinery for the irritation and development of the human intellect.

sn.def: The act of exciting, or the condition of being excited to action, by stimulation; -- as, the condition of an organ of sense, when its nerve is affected by some external body; esp., the act of exciting muscle fibers to contraction, by artificial stimulation; as, the irritation of a motor nerve by electricity; also, the condition of a muscle and nerve, under such stimulation.
A condition of morbid excitability or oversensitiveness of an organ or part of the body; a state in which the application of ordinary stimuli produces pain or excessive or vitiated action.
Serving to excite or irritate; irritating; as, an irritative agent.
Accompanied with, or produced by, increased action or irritation; as, an irritative fever.

entry.def: Exciting; producing irritation; irritating.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Irrorated; p. pr. & vb. n. Irrorating
entry.ety: L. irroratus, p. p. of irrorare to bedew; pref. ir- in + ros roris, dew
entry.def: To sprinkle or moisten with dew; to bedew.
Covered with minute grains, appearing like fine sand.

entry.ety: Cf. F. irroration
entry.def: The act of bedewing; the state of being moistened with dew.
Not rotatory; passing from one point to another by a movement other than rotation; -- said of the movement of parts of a liquid or yielding mass.
Contrary to the rubric; not rubrical.

entry.ety: L. irrugatus, p. p. of irrugare to wrinkle
entry.def: To wrinkle.

entry.ety: L. irruptus, p. p. of irrumpere to break in; pref. ir- in + rumpere to break or burst. See Rupture
entry.def: Broken with violence.

entry.ety: L. irruptio: cf. F. irruption. See Irrupted

sn.def: A bursting in; a sudden, violent rushing into a place; as, irruptions of the sea.
sn.q: Lest evil tidings, with too rude irruption Hitting thy aged ear, should pierce too deep.

sn.def: A sudden and violent inroad, or entrance of invaders; as, the irruptions of the Goths into Italy.
sn.syn: Invasion; incursion; inroad. See Invasion.

entry.def: Rushing in or upon.

The common designation of a member of a sect founded by the Rev. Edward Irvingabout 1830), who call themselves the Catholic Apostolic Church. They are highly ritualistic in worship, have an elaborate hierarchy of apostles, prophets, etc., and look for the speedy coming of Christ.

entries.entry: Is-. See Iso-.

entry.note: ☞ In some varieties of the Northern dialect of Old English, is was used for all persons of the singular.
☞ The idiom of using the present for future events sure to happen is a relic of Old English in which the present and future had the same form; as, this year Christmas is on Friday.
entry.ety: AS. is; akin to G. & Goth. ist, L. est, Gr. �, Skr. asti. √9. Cf. Am Entity Essence Absent
entry.def: The third person singular of the substantive verb be, in the indicative mood, present tense; as, he is; he is a man. See Be.
entry.q: For thy is I come, and eke Alain.
Aye is thou merry.
To-morrow is the new moon.

entry.ety: F. isabelle
entry.def: See Isabella.

entries.entry: Is`a*bel"la n. Is`a*bel"la col"or . Said to be named from the Spanish princess Isabella, daughter of king Philip II., in allusion to the color assumed by her shift, which she wore without change from 1601 to 1604, in consequence of a vow made by her A brownish yellow color.
Is`a*bel"la grape`. Bot A favorite sweet American grape of a purple color. See Fox grape, under Fox.

Is`a*bel"la moth` ?; 115. Zoöl A common American moth (Pyrrharctia isabella), of an isabella color. The larva, called woolly bear and hedgehog caterpillar, is densely covered with hairs, which are black at each end of the body, and red in the middle part.

entry.def: Of an isabel or isabella color.

entry.ety: Is- + Gr. a`gelos information
entry.def: Containing the same information; as, isagelous sentences.
entry.q: The coded message and the original, though appearing entirely unlike, are completelyisagelous.
The complementary strands haveisageloussequences.

def2.def: One of two or more objects containing the same information.

entry.ety: L., fr. Fr. �, fr. � to introduce; � into + � to lead
entry.def: An introduction.

entry.ety: L. isagogicus, Gr. �
entry.def: Introductory; especially, introductory to the study of theology.
That part of theological science directly preliminary to actual exegesis, or interpretation of the Scriptures.

entry.ety: Gr. 'i`sos equal + gwni`a angle: cf. F. isagone a.
entry.def: A figure or polygon whose angles are equal.

entry.ety: Gr. �
entry.def: Having equal, or almost equal, authority with the apostles of their teachings.
Pertaining to, or derived from, isatin; as, isatic acid, which is also called trioxindol .
A white crystalline substance obtained by the partial reduction of isatin.

entry.ety: See Isatis
entry.def: An orange-red crystalline substance, C8H5NO2, obtained by the oxidation of indigo blue. It is also produced from certain derivatives of benzoic acid, and is one important source of artificial indigo.

entry.ety: L., a kind of plant, Gr. � woad
entry.def: A genus of herbs, some species of which, especially the Isatis tinctoria, yield a blue dye similar to indigo; woad.

entry.ety: Isatin + -gen
entry.def: A complex nitrogenous radical, C8H4NO2, regarded as the essential residue of a series of compounds, related to isatin, which easily pass by reduction to indigo blue.

entry.ety: Is- + atropine
entry.def: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from atropine, and isomeric with cinnamic acid.
See Ischial.

cs.cd: a rheumatic or neuralgic affection of some part about the hip joint; -- called also sciatica.

entry.ety: L. ischiadicus, Gr. 'ischiadoko`s, fr. 'ischi`on the hip joint, hip or loin. Cf. Sciatic
entry.def: Ischial.

cs.cd: one of the patches of thickened, hairless, and often bright-colored skin, on the buttocks of many apes, as the drill.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the ischium or hip; ischiac; ischiadic; ischiatic.
Same as Ischial.

entry.ety: Ischium + capsular
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the ischium and the capsule of the hip joint; as, the ischiocapsular ligament.

entry.ety: Gr. 'ischi`on the hip + ke`ras a horn
entry.def: The third joint or the antennæ of the Crustacea.

entry.ety: L., Gr. 'ischi`on

sn.def: The ventral and posterior of the three principal bones composing either half of the pelvis; seat bone; the huckle bone.
One of the pleuræ of insects.

entry.ety: Gr. 'ischi`on the hip joint + �, �, foot
entry.def: The third joint of the typical appendages of Crustacea.

entry.ety: Ischium + rectal
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the region between the rectum and ishial tuberosity.
Having the quality of relieving ischury.

entry.ety: L. ischuria, Gr. �; � to hold, check + � urine: cf. F. ischurie
entry.def: A retention or suppression of urine.

entries.entry: -ise. See -ize.

cs.cd: lines which pass through points having equal entropy.

entry.ety: Is- + entropy + -ic
entry.def: Having equal entropy.

entry.ety: Is- + ethionic
entry.def: Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an acid, HO.C2H4.SO3H, obtained as an oily or crystalline substance, by the action of sulphur trioxide on alcohol or ether. It is derivative of sulphuric acid.

entries.entry:
-ish. AS. -isc; akin to G. -isch, OHG. -isc, Goth. & Dan. -isk, Gr. �. Cf. -esque
A suffix used to from adjectives from nouns and from adjectives. It denotes relation resemblance similarity, and sometimes has a diminutive force; as, selfish, boyish, brutish; whitish, somewhat white.

-ish. OE. -issen, fr. F. -is -iss-found in the present particle, etc., of certain verbs, as finir to finish, fleurir to flourish), corresponding to L. -escere, an inchoative ending A verb ending, originally appearing in certain verbs of French origin; as, abolish, cherish, finish, furnish, garnish, impoverish .

sn.def: A descendant of Ishmaelthe son of Abraham and Hagar), of whom it was said, “His hand will be against every man, and every man's hand against him.”
One at enmity with society; a wanderer; a vagabond; an outcast.
See Ismaelian.

entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, an Ishmaelite or the Ishmaelites.

entry.ety: L. Isiacus, Gr. �, fr. �
entry.def: Pertaining to the goddess Isis; as, Isiac mysteries.
A icicle.
Pertaining, or ascribed, to Isidore; as, the Isidorian decretals, a spurious collection of decretals published in the ninth century.

entry.ety: Prob. corrupted fr. D. huizenblasakin to G. hausenblase), lit., bladder of the huso, or large sturgeon; huizen sturgeon + blas bladder. Cf. Bladder Blast a gust of wind

sn.def: A semitransparent, whitish, and very pure form of gelatin, chiefly prepared from the sounds or air bladders of various species of sturgeons (as the Acipenser huso) found in the rivers of Western Russia. It used for making jellies, as a clarifier, etc. Cheaper forms of gelatin are not unfrequently so called. Called also fish glue.
A popular name for mica, especially when in thin sheets.

entry.ety: L., the goddess Isis, fr. Gr. �

sn.def: The principal goddess worshiped by the Egyptians. She was regarded as the mother of Horus, and the sister and wife of Osiris. The Egyptians adored her as the goddess of fecundity, and as the great benefactress of their country, who instructed their ancestors in the art of agriculture.
Any coral of the genus Isis, or family Isidæ, composed of joints of white, stony coral, alternating with flexible, horny joints. See Gorgoniacea.
One of the asteroids.

entry.ety: acronym from The International Society for Krishna Consciousness
entry.def: The abbreviation for International Society for Krishna Consciousness, a society founded in the US in 1966; based on Vedic scriptures. Groups of devotees engage in joyful chanting of "Hare Krishna" ("O Krishna!").
entry.syn: Hare Krishna, International Society for Krishna Consciousness, the Hare Krishnas.

entry.ety: Ar. islām obedience to the will of God, submission, humbling one's self, resigning one's self to the divine disposal. Cf. Moslem

sn.def: The religion of the Mohammedans; Mohammedanism; Islamism. Their formula of faith is: There is no God but Allah, and Mohammed is his prophet.
The whole body of Mohammedans, or the countries which they occupy.

entry.def: The the capital city of Pakistan.
of or pertaining to Islamism; as, Islamic art.

entry.ety: Cf. F. islamisme
entry.def: The faith, doctrines, or religious system of the Mohammedans; Mohammedanism; Islam.
A Mohammedan.
Of or pertaining to Islam; Mohammedan.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Islamized; p. pr. & vb. n. Islamizing
entry.def: To conform, or cause to conform, to the religion of Islam.

cs.cd: islands supposed to lie in the Western Ocean, where the favorites of the gods are conveyed at death, and dwell in everlasting joy.

entry.ety: OE. iland yland, AS. īgland �gland �glond; īg �g, island + land lond, land. AS. īg �g, is akin to AS. eá water, river, OHG. �uwa, G. au meadow, Icel. ey island, Dan. & Sw. ö, Goth. ahwa a stream, water, L. aqua water. The s is due to confusion with isle. Cf. Ait Eyot Ewer Aquatic

sn.def: A tract of land surrounded by water, and smaller than a continent. Cf. Continent.
Anything regarded as resembling an island; as, an island of ice.
See Isle n., 2.
To cause to become or to resemble an island; to make an island or islands of; to isle.
To furnish with an island or with islands; as, to island the deep.

entry.def: An inhabitant of an island.
Of or pertaining to islands; full of islands.
See Aisle.

entry.ety: OF. isle, F. île, L. insula; cf. Lith. sala. Cf. Insulate

sn.def: An island.
sn.q: Imperial rule of all the seagirt isles.

sn.def: A spot within another of a different color, as upon the wings of some insects.

entry.def: To cause to become an island, or like an island; to surround or encompass; to island.
entry.q: Isled in sudden seas of light.

entry.ety: OF. islettecf. F. îlot), dim. of isle
entry.def: A little island.

entries.entry: -ism. F. -isme, or L. -ismus, Gr. � A suffix indicating an act, a process, the result of an act or a process, a state; also, a characteristicas a theory, doctrine, idiom, etc.); as, baptism, galvanism, organism, hypnotism, socialism, sensualism, Anglicism .

entry.ety: See ism, above
entry.def: A doctrine or theory; especially, a wild or visionary theory.
entry.q: The world grew light-headed, and forth came a spawn of isms which no man can number.

entry.def: One of a sect of Mohammedans who favored the pretensions of the family of Mohammed ben Ismael, of the house of Ali.

entries.entry: I"so- Is-. Gr. 'i`sos equal A prefix or combining form, indicating identity, or equality; the same numerical value; as in isopod, isomorphous, isochromatic. Specif.: Chem Applied to certain compounds having the same composition but different properties; as in isocyanic. Organic Chem Applied to compounds of certain isomeric series in whose structure one carbon atom, at least, is connected with three other carbon atoms; -- contrasted with neo- and normal; as in isoparaffine; isopentane.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. � weight
entry.def: A line connecting or marking places upon the surface of the earth where height of the barometer reduced to sea level is the same either at a given time, or for a certain period (mean height), as for a year; an isopiestic line.
Denoting equal pressure; as, an isobaric line; specifically, of or pertaining to isobars.
The quality or state of being equal in weight, especially in atmospheric pressure. Also, the theory, method, or application of isobaric science.

entry.ety: Iso + barometric
entry.def: Indicating equal barometric pressure.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. � deep + � heat
entry.def: A line connecting the points on the surface of the earth where a certain temperature is found at the same depth.
Of or pertaining to an isobathytherm; possessing or indicating the same temperature at the same depth.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. bronth` thunder
entry.def: An imaginary line, or a line on a chart, marking the simultaneous development of a thunderstorm, as noted by observing the time when the thunder is heard at different places.

entry.ety: From Gr. � like-headed. See Iso-, and Cephalon
entry.def: A peculiarity in the design of bas-relief by which the heads of human figures are kept at the same height from the ground, whether the personages are seated, standing, or mounted on horseback; -- called also isokephaleia.

entry.ety: Iso- + chasm
entry.def: A line connecting places on the earth's surface at which there is the same mean frequency of auroras.
Indicating equal auroral display; as, an isochasmic line.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. �, �, winter
entry.def: A line connecting places on the earth having the same mean winter temperature. Cf. Isothere.
Pertaining to, having the nature of, or making, isocheims; as, an isocheimal line; an isocheimal chart.
The same as Isocheimal.
The same as Isocheimal.
The same as Isocheim.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. xhw`ra space
entry.def: A line upon a thermodynamic diagram so drawn as to represent the pressures corresponding to changes of temperature when the volume of the gas operated on is constant.

entry.ety: Iso- + chromatic
entry.def: Having the same color; connecting parts having the same color, as lines drawn through certain points in experiments on the chromatic effects of polarized light in crystals.

entry.ety: See Isochronous
entry.def: Uniform in time; of equal time; performed in equal times; recurring at regular intervals; as, isochronal vibrations or oscillations.
Isochronal.
The state or quality of being isochronous.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. -nized; p. pr. & vb. n. -nizing
entry.ety: See Isochronous
entry.def: To make, or tend to make (the motion of a moving body), uniform in rate of rotation, or in frequency of vibration.

entry.ety: NL. See Isochronous
entry.def: A clock that is designed to keep very accurate time.

entry.ety: Gr. �; 'i`sos equal + � time
entry.def: Same as Isochronal.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. � color
entry.def: Having the same tint or color throughout; uniformly or evenly colored.

cs.cd: lines on the earth's surface connecting places at which a dipping needle indicates the same inclination or dip.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. � to incline
entry.def: Of or pertaining to, or indicating, equality of inclination or dip; having equal inclination or dip.
Pertaining to, having the nature of, or illustrating, an isocryme; as, an isocrymal line; an isocrymal chart.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. � cold
entry.def: A line connecting points on the earth's surface having the same mean temperature in the coldest month of the year.
Isocrymal.

cs.cd: an acid metameric with cyanic acid, and resembling it in its salts. It is obtained as a colorless, mobile, unstable liquid by the heating cyanuric acid. Called technically carbimide.

entry.ety: Iso- + cyanic
entry.def: Designating an acid isomeric with cyanic acid.

entry.ety: Iso- + cyanuric
entry.def: Designating, or pertaining to, an acid isomeric with cyanuric acid, and called also fulminuricacid. See under Fulminuric.

cs.cd: a pair of lines or curves exhibiting, on a diagram of energy, the law of variation of the pressure and density of a fluid, the one during the lowering, and the other during the raising, of its temperature, when the quantity of heat given out by the fluid during any given stage of the one process is equal to the quantity received during the corresponding stage of the other. Such lines are said to be isodiabatic with respect to each other. Compare Adiabatic.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. � to pass through
entry.def: Pertaining to the reception or the giving out of equal quantities of heat by a substance.

entry.ety: Iso- + diametric

sn.def: Developed alike in the directions of the several lateral axes; -- said of crystals of both the tetragonal and hexagonal systems.
Having the several diameters nearly equal; -- said of the cells of ordinary parenchyma.

entry.ety: Iso- + dimorphic
entry.def: Isodimorphous.
Isomorphism between the two forms severally of two dimorphous substances.

entry.ety: Iso- + dimorphous
entry.def: Having the quality of isodimorphism.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. � course
entry.def: A method of moving a fleet from one formation to another, the direction usually being changed eight points (90°), by means of paths of equal length for each ship. It is prohibited in the United States navy.

entry.ety: Iso- + dulcite
entry.def: A white, crystalline, sugarlike substance, obtained by the decomposition of certain glucosides, and intermediate in nature between the hexacid alcohols (dulcite mannite, etc.) and the glucoses.

cs.cd: those foods that produce a similar amount of heat.
lines on the earth's surface connecting places at which the magnetic intensity is the same.

entry.ety: Iso- + dynamic
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, having, or denoting, equality of force.

entry.ety: Gr. �. See Isodynamic
entry.def: Of equal force or size.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. gh^ the earth + qe`rmh heat
entry.def: A line or curved surface passing beneath the earth's surface through points having the same mean temperature.
Pertaining to, having the nature of, or marking, isogeotherms; as, an isogeothermal line or surface; as isogeothermal chart.

cs.cd: lines traced on the surface of the globe, or upon a chart, connecting places at which the deviation of the magnetic needle from the meridian or true north is the same.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. gwni`a angle
entry.def: Pertaining to, or noting, equal angles.
Characterized by isogonism.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. � offspring, generative parts
entry.def: The quality of having similar sexual zooids or gonophores and dissimilar hydrants; -- said of certain hydroids.
Of or pertaining to isography.

entry.ety: Iso- + -graphy
entry.def: Imitation of another's handwriting.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. "yeto`s rain
entry.def: Of or pertaining to lines connecting places on the earth's surface which have the same mean annual rainfall.

def2.def: An isohyetose line; called also isohyet.

entry.ety: See Isolate
entry.def: Capable of being isolated, or of being obtained in a pure state; as, gold is isolable .

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Isolated ī"s�*lā`tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Isolating ī"s�*lā`tĭng
entry.ety: It. isolato, p. p. of isolare to isolate, fr. isola island, L. insula. See 2d Isle, and cf. Insulate

sn.def: To place in a detached situation; to place by itself or alone; to insulate; to separate from others; as, to isolate an infected person from others; to isolate the troublemakers in a classroom.
sn.q: Short isolated sentences were the mode in which ancient wisdom delighted to convey its precepts.

sn.def: To insulate. See Insulate.
To separate from all foreign substances; to make pure; to obtain in a free state; as, to isolate the desired product from a reaction mixture.
To obtain a culture of a microorganism in pure form (from a complex mixture); as, to isolate Eschericia coli from a patient's blood.

entry.def: Something that has been isolated; as, an isolate of a powerful antibiotic from a tropical plant; an isolate of tuberculosis bacillus from an infected patient.

entry.cs: Isolated point of a curve. Geom See Acnode.
entry.def: Placed or standing alone; detached; separated from others.
In an isolated manner.

entry.ety: Cf. F. isolation
entry.def: The act of isolating, or the state of being isolated; insulation; separation; loneliness.

entry.ety: Cf. F. isolation
entry.def: The doctrine or policy of minimal participation by one's country in international economic and political relations, specifically by not entering into alliances or other international agreements, in order to avoid becoming entangled in foreign wars, and to be able to devote the nation's energies primarily to advancing its own domestic interests.
A proponent or supporter of isolationism; one who is isolationistic.

sn.def: of or pertaining to isolationism.
sn.syn: isolationist.

sn.def: Favoring or supporting isolationism; -- of people.

entry.def: One who, or that which, isolates.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. lo`gos proportion
entry.def: Having similar proportions, similar relations, or similar differences of composition; -- said specifically of groups or series which differ by a constant difference; as, ethane, ethylene, and acetylene, or their analogous compounds, form an isologous series.

entry.note: ☞ An isomer may be a structural isomer, in which some of the atoms are bonded to different atoms (as in CH3.CH2.NH2 and CH3.NH.CH3), or an optical isomer, in which the number and types of chemical bonds are identical, but the arrangement of the atoms in three-dimensional space is different; the latter are also called stereoisomers.
entry.ety: See Isomeric
entry.def: A compound which is isomeric with another body or compound; a compound having the same chemical composition as another compound; a member of an isomeric series.

entry.ety: Iso- + -mere

sn.def: A homologous or corresponding part or segment.
same as Isomer.

entry.note: ☞ Formerly the term isomeric applied also to comopounds having the same percentage chemical composition, even if the number of atoms in a molecule differed. In the 1913 dictionary isomeric was defined as: “Having the same percentage composition; -- said of two or more different substances which contain the same ingredients in the same proportions by weight, often used with with. Specif.: Polymeric; i. e., having the same elements united in the same proportion by weight, but with different molecular weights; as, acetylene and benzine are isomeric polymeric) with each other in this sense. See Polymeric. Metameric; i. e., having the same elements united in the same proportions by weight, and with the same molecular weight, but with a different structure or arrangement of the ultimate parts; as, ethyl alcohol and methyl ether are isomeric metameric) with each other in this sense. See Metameric.”
entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. me`ros part: cf. F. isomérique
entry.def: Having the same chemical composition and molecular weight; having the same number of atoms of each kind in the molecule; -- said of chemical compounds with known chemical composition. This property used to be called metameric to distinguish it from other forms of isomerism.
An isomer.

cs.cd: a former term for optical isomerism.

the condition or relation of certain (isomeric) substances, which, while chemically identical (in that they have the same composition, the same molecular weights, and the same ultimate constitution), are yet physically different, as in their action on polarized light, as dextro- and lævo-tartaric acids, or the sugars galactose and glucose. In such compounds there is usually at least one unsymmetrical carbon atom and typically more than one. See Unsymmetrical.

entry.def: The state, quality, or relation, of two or more isomeric substances.

entry.ety: Isomer + Gr. morfh` form + -ism
entry.def: Isomorphism between substances that are isomeric.

entry.cs: Isometric lines Thermodynamics lines representing in a diagram the relations of pressure and temperature in a gas, when the volume remains constant. Isometrical perspective. See under Perspective. Isometrical projection a species of orthographic projection, in which but a single plane of projection is used. It is so named from the fact that the projections of three equal lines, parallel respectively to three rectangular axes, are equal to one another. This kind of projection is principally used in delineating buildings or machinery, in which the principal lines are parallel to three rectangular axes, and the principal planes are parallel to three rectangular planes passing through the three axes.
entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. me`tron measure

sn.def: Pertaining to, or characterized by, equality of measure.
Noting, or conforming to, that system of crystallization in which the three axes are of equal length and at right angles to each other; monometric; regular; cubic. Cf. Crystallization.
Of or pertaining to isometrics.

entry.def: A system of exercise to strengthen specific muscles of the body by pushing parts of the body (such as the two hands) strongly against each other, or against a fixed object, so that the muscles are strongly stressed, but are stretched only a little. It is claimed to produce strength in the muscles thus exercised. Also called isometrics.
Same as isometric exercise.

entry.ety: See Isomorphous

sn.def: A substance which is similar to another in crystalline form and composition.
An animal, plant, or group having superficial similarity to another, although phylogenetically different.
Isomorphous.
Alike in form; exhibiting isomorphism.
Of or pertaining to sets related by an isomorphism.

entry.ety: Cf. F. isomorphisme

sn.def: A similarity of crystalline form between substances of similar composition, as between the sulphates of barium (BaSO4) and strontium (SrSO4). It is sometimes extended to include similarity of form between substances of unlike composition, which is more properly called homœomorphism.
A one-to-one mapping of one set onto another set which preserves the relations between the elements of the domains of the sets.

entry.ety: Iso- + -morphous
entry.def: Having the quality of isomorphism.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. �, �, a man, male
entry.def: A genus of sapotaceous trees of India. Isonandra Gutta is the principal source of gutta-percha.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. � a cloud
entry.def: Having, or indicating, an equal amount of cloudiness for a given period; as, isonephelic regions; an isonephelic line.

entry.ety: Iso- + nicotine
entry.def: A crystalline, nitrogenous base, C10H14N2, isomeric with nicotine.
Pertaining to, or derived from, isonicotine.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid isomeric with nicotinic acid.

entries.entry: I`so*ni*tro"so-. Iso- + nitroso- Chem A combining form (also used adjectively), signifying: Pertaining to, or designating, the characteristic, nitrogenous radical, NOH, called the isonitroso group.

entry.ety: Gr. �; 'i`sos equal + no`mos law
entry.def: The same, or equal, in law or right; one in kind or origin; analogous; similar.

entry.ety: Gr. �: cf. F. isonomie. See Isonomic
entry.def: Equal law or right; equal distribution of rights and privileges; similarity.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. � suffering
entry.def: The system which undertakes to cure a disease by means of the virus of the same disease.
The theory of curing a diseased organ by eating the analogous organ of a healthy animal.
The doctrine that the power of therapeutics is equal to that of the causes of disease.

entry.ety: Iso- + pepsin
entry.def: Pepsin modified by exposure to a temperature of from 40° to 60° C.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � equal + � circumference: cf. F. isopérimètre. See Perimeter
entry.def: Having equal perimeters of circumferences; as, isoperimetrical figures or bodies.
The science of figures having equal perimeters or boundaries.

cs.cd: lines showing, in a diagram, the relations of temperature and volume, when the elastic force is constant; -- called also isobars.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. � to press
entry.def: Having equal pressure.

entry.note: ☞ The intestine terminates at the posterior end of the body, and the gills and circulatory and reproductive organs are paired. It includes the chitons (Polyplacophora), together with Neomenia and Chætoderma, which are wormlike forms without a shell.
entry.ety: NL. See Iso-, and Pleura
entry.def: A subclass of Gastropoda, in which the body is symmetrical, the right and left sides being equal.
Having the legs similar in structure; belonging to the Isopoda.

entry.note: ☞ The body is usually depressed, with the abdominal segments short, and often consolidated in part. The branchiæ are on the abdominal appendages. The group includes the terrestrial pill bugs and sow bugs, with numerous marine forms. See Arthrostrata Gribble.
entry.ety: NL. See Iso-, and -poda
entry.def: An order of sessile-eyed Crustacea, usually having seven pairs of legs, which are all similar in structure.

entry.ety: Isopod + -form
entry.def: Having the shape of an isopod; -- said of the larvæ of certain insects.
Same as Isopod.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. � beard
entry.def: Having the two webs equal in breadth; -- said of feathers.

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain
entry.def: An oily, volatile unsaturated hydrocarbon (C5H8), obtained by the distillation of caoutchouc or gutta-percha, and used to make synthetic rubber by polymerization. In organic chemistry, it is viewed conceptually as the building block of the terpene series of hydrocarbons.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. pykno`s dense
entry.def: Having equal density, as different regions of a medium; passing through points at which the density is equal; as, an isopycnic line or surface.
A line or surface passing through those points in a medium, at which the density is the same.

entry.ety: Iso- + orcin
entry.def: A crystalline hydrocarbon derivative, metameric with orcin, but produced artificially; -- called also cresorcin.

entry.cs: Isorropic linein a diagramGeom the locus of all the points for which a specified function has a constant value. Newcomb.
entry.ety: Gr. 'iso`rropos in equipoise; 'i`sos equal + "roph` downward inclination or momentum
entry.def: Of equal value.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �; 'i`sos equal + � leg
entry.def: Having two legs or sides that are equal; -- said of a triangle.
having the same or equal osmotic pressure; isotonic; -- used of solutions. Contrasted with hypertonic and hypotonic

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'i`sos equal + �, �, a vertebra
entry.def: An extensive order of fishes, including the salmons, herrings, and many allied forms.
Of or pertaining to the Isospondyli; having the anterior vertebræ separate and normal.
One of the spores produced by an isosporous organism.
A zygospore.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. spo`ros fruit
entry.def: Producing but one kind of spore, as the ferns and Equiseta. Cf. Heterosporic.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. spo`ros fruit
entry.def: Producing but one kind of spore, as the ferns.

entry.ety: See Iso-; Stasis
entry.def: The state or quality of being isostatic.

general equilibrium in the earth's crust, supposed to be maintained by the yielding or flow of rock material beneath the surface under gravitative stress. By the theory of isostasy each unit column of the earth, from surface to center, has approximately the same weight, and the continents stand higher than the ocean beds chiefly because the material of the crust has there less density.

entry.ety: Iso- + static
entry.def: Subjected to equal pressure from every side; being in hydrostatic equilibrium, as a body submerged in a liquid at rest; pertaining to, or characterized by, isostasy.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. sth`mwn thread
entry.def: Having exactly as many stamens as petals.
The quality or state of being isostemonous.
A salt of isosulphocyanic acid.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid, HNCS, isomeric with sulphocyanic acid.
Having the nature of an isothere; indicating the distribution of temperature by means of an isothere; as, an isotheral chart or line.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. � summer, � to heat
entry.def: A line connecting points on the earth's surface having the same mean summer temperature.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. � heat, fr. � hot

sn.def: A line connecting or marking points on the earth's surface having the same temperature. This may be the temperature for a given time of observation, or the mean temperature for a year or other period. Also, a similar line based on the distribution of temperature in the ocean.
A line on a graph connecting points representing states having the same temperature; an isothermal line.

entry.cs: Isothermal line. An isotherm. A line drawn on a diagram of energy such that its ordinates represent the pressures of a substance corresponding to various volumes, while the absolute temperature is maintained at a constant value. Isothermal zones spaces on opposite sides of the equator having the same mean temperature, and bounded by corresponding isothermal lines.
entry.ety: Cf. F. isotherme
entry.def: Relating to equality of temperature, or an isotherm.
Having reference to the geographical distribution of temperature, as exhibited by means of isotherms; as, an isothermal line; an isothermal chart.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. � hot + � depth
entry.def: A line drawn through points of equal temperature in a vertical section of the ocean.
Of or pertaining to an isothermobath; possessing or indicating equal temperatures in a vertical section, as of the ocean.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. qe`ros summer + 'o`mbros rain
entry.def: A line connecting or marking points on the earth's surface, which have the same mean summer rainfall.

cs.cd: a system consisting of intervals, in which each concord is alike tempered, and in which there are twelve equal semitones.

entry.ety: Iso- + tonic

sn.def: Having or indicating, equal tones, or tension.
Having an osmotic pressure (tonicity) equal to that of a reference solution; -- of aqueous solutions. Contrasting with hypotonic and hypertonic. See hypertonic.

q.au: Cook & Martin (Remington's Practice of Pharmacy, Tenth Ed.: Mack Publ., Easton Pa., 1951)

sn.q: A knowledge of the colligative properties of solutions . . . is essential for one to understand fully the principles involved in rendering intravenous solutions isotonic with blood serum, or opthalmic solutions isotonic with lachrymal fluid. Solutions thus adjusted produce less shock and much less irritation than those which are hypotonic or hypertonic, and present-day practise recognizes the desirability of making the necessary adjustments whenever possible.

entry.def: Isotrimorphous.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. � thrice + morfh` form
entry.def: Isomorphism between the three forms, severally, of two trimorphous substances.
Having the quality of isotrimorphism; isotrimorphic.

entry.ety: Iso- + Gr. � a turning, fr. � to turn
entry.def: Having the same properties in all directions; specifically, equally elastic in all directions.
Isotropy.
Isotropic.
Uniformity of physical properties in all directions in a body; absence of all kinds of polarity; specifically, equal elasticity in all directions.

entry.ety: Iso- + uric
entry.def: Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acid, isomeric with uric acid.

entry.ety: L. Israëlites, Gr. �, fr. �, �, Israel, Heb. Yisrāēl, i. e., champion of God; sārāh to fight + ēl God
entry.def: A descendant of Israel, or Jacob; a Hebrew; a Jew.
Of or pertaining to Israel, or to the Israelites; Jewish; Hebrew.

cs.cd: a plea to the merits, on which the adverse party may take issue and proceed to trial.

entry.ety: From Issue

sn.def: Leading to, producing, or relating to, an issue; capable of being made an issue at law.
Lawful or suitable to be issued; as, a writ issuable on these grounds.

entry.def: In an issuable manner; by way of issue; as, to plead issuably .
The act of issuing, or giving out; as, the issuance of an order; the issuance of rations, and the like.
Issuing or coming up; -- a term used to express a charge or bearing rising or coming out of another.

entry.cs:
At issue in controversy; disputed; opposing or contesting; hence, at variance; disagreeing; inconsistent. As much at issue with the summer day As if you brought a candle out of doors. Mrs. Browning.
Bank of issue Collateral issue , etc. See under Bank Collateral, etc. Issue pea a pea, or a similar round body, used to maintain irritation in a wound, and promote the secretion and discharge of pus.
To join issueorTo take issue
to take opposing sides in a matter in controversy.
entry.ety: OF. issue eissue, F. issue, fr. OF. issir eissir, to go out, L. exire; ex out of, from + ire to go, akin to Gr. 'ie`nai, Skr. i, Goth. iddja went, used as prefect of gaggan to go. Cf. Ambition Count a nobleman, Commence Errant Exit Eyre Initial Yede went

sn.def: The act of passing or flowing out; a moving out from any inclosed place; egress; as, the issue of water from a pipe, of blood from a wound, of air from a bellows, of people from a house.
The act of sending out, or causing to go forth; delivery; issuance; as, the issue of an order from a commanding officer; the issue of money from a treasury.
That which passes, flows, or is sent out; the whole quantity sent forth or emitted at one time; as, an issue of bank notes; the daily issue of a newspaper.
Progeny; a child or children; offspring. In law, sometimes, in a general sense, all persons descended from a common ancestor; all lineal descendants.
sn.q: If the king Should without issue die.

sn.def: Produce of the earth, or profits of land, tenements, or other property; as, A conveyed to B all his right for a term of years, with all the issues, rents, and profits.
A discharge of flux, as of blood.
An artificial ulcer, usually made in the fleshy part of the arm or leg, to produce the secretion and discharge of pus for the relief of some affected part.
The final outcome or result; upshot; conclusion; event; hence, contest; test; trial.
sn.q: Come forth to view The issue of the exploit.
While it is hot, I 'll put it to the issue.

sn.def: A point in debate or controversy on which the parties take affirmative and negative positions; a presentation of alternatives between which to choose or decide; a point of contention; a matter in controversy.

In pleading, a single material point of law or fact depending in the suit, which, being affirmed on the one side and denied on the other, is presented for determination. See General issue, under General, and Feigned issue, under Feigned.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Issued ĭsh"�d; p. pr. & vb. n. Issuing

sn.def: To pass or flow out; to run out, as from any inclosed place.
sn.q: From it issued forced drops of blood.

sn.def: To go out; to rush out; to sally forth; as, troops issued from the town, and attacked the besiegers.
